headline: A Few Visit Steinbrenner’s Grave, but No Sign of Yankees
text: TRINITY, Fla. — The Boss’s final resting place looked as neat and pressed as Yankee pinstripes. No flower bouquets, no gaudy makeshift shrines. Only a lone Rawlings baseball resting at the entrance to his mausoleum.

headline: Town Elbows Its Way Into Clinton Wedding
text: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  Bill and Hillary Clinton have tried to shield their daughter, Chelsea, from the gaze of the public for most of her life.

headline: Families Fear Phone Call From Mexico’s Cartels
text: T was lucky he heard his cellphone ring over the racket of his construction equipment as he worked outside in the suburbs last September. “We have your father,” said a man in a voice T recalled as eerily calm. “Try to get the money together as soon as you can so that your dad can be freed.”

headline: Márquez Is Closer to Joining Red Bulls
text: The Red Bulls’ second designated player, Thierry Henry, was scheduled to make his debut in Major League Soccer on Saturday night in Houston while the man who is expected to soon become the club’s third high-priced import, Rafael Márquez, was released from his contract with Barcelona earlier in the day.

headline: To Help Democrats in the Fall, Obama May Stay Away
text: WASHINGTON  As lunch was served in the Roosevelt Room of the White House one day last week, President Obama assured the nine Democratic members of Congress sitting around the table that he would do anything he could to help them survive their fall elections.

headline: Charging Station
text: Electric cars are not clogging local streets yet, but auto industry analysts expect California to be the largest market for electric vehicles in the United States. An infrastructure for charging the vehicles is being built in places like the parking lot of the Amtrak station in Martinez.

headline: Whatever the Verdicts, Blagojevich Trial Hasn’t Answered All the Questions
text: As Rod Blagojevich’s lawyer declared to the jury in his closing argument last week, “Think about it.” He wanted jurors to consider what he thinks is self-evident about his client’s innocence.

headline: Age and the Demands of Managing
text: Lou Piniella turns 67 next month. Last week he decided that 23 years managing five big-league teams was enough, and he told the Cubs he would be stepping down and heading home to Tampa after the season.

headline: After Development Plan Fails, the Accusations Fly
text: Alameda, an island long resistant to growth, threw a warm embrace around an unlikely suitor last year. The Southern California developer SunCal Companies proposed to build thousands of homes, sports fields, offices and a ferry terminal on 770 acres of a decommissioned naval base.

headline: In Series of Trades, Yanks Take Another Shot at Firming Up Weak Spots
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  As Manager Joe Girardi was walking toward the Yankees’ clubhouse after Thursday’s game in Cleveland, he spotted a former teammate.

headline: Mets Remain the Same, but That Could Change
text: For many teams, Saturday was a time to evaluate the deals at the nonwaiver trading deadline and to look ahead with optimism to the final third of the season, which could include pennant races and the playoffs.

headline: Family Is Selling Huntington Hotel, Nob Hill Fixture, but Allure Is Faded
text: John J. Cope’s father may have been known as the high-living “nabob of Nob Hill,” but Mr. Cope, who runs his family’s Huntington Hotel, is clearly eager to move on.

headline: Alabama Shrimping Opens Late and Starts Slow
text: For the Skinner family, the official opening to the shrimping season was as slow as expected. Gary Skinner had to purchase shrimp from Florida and his sons, who do the fishing for the store, hope the season turns around later this month.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 1
text: Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, appears on CBS’s “Face the Nation” and NBC’s “Meet the Press” this Sunday, one week after the release of thousands of leaked documents detailing the war in Afghanistan.

headline: Far Away From Cellar, Padres Top the Buyers
text: Before the season, conventional wisdom said the San Diego Padres would be active leading to the nonwaiver trading deadline. The wisdom was correct, but in a way few people expected.

headline: For Roethlisberger, Feelings of Anxiety Fade With the Sound of Cheers
text: LATROBE, Pa.  By the end of the day, Ben Roethlisberger stood in his stocking feet, still signing autographs long after he had given away his shoes to fans. Saturday’s practice had been a success  the fans cheered, his passes were caught, his escape into his comfort zone complete. But hours earlier, when he stood behind the smoked-glass doors, waiting to take what might have been a very long walk to practice past a gantlet of those fans, Roethlisberger felt the familiar first-day-of-camp butterflies for very unfamiliar reasons.

headline: ‘Oh, Please. It’s the Tour!’ A Grueling Event for All Involved
text: Sitting on the high-speed train from Bordeaux to Paris last Sunday, the final day of the Tour de France, I never saw the sharp-edged and evidently heavy suitcase perched precariously above me.

headline: Robert C. Tucker, a Scholar of Marx, Stalin and Soviet Affairs, Dies at 92
text: Robert C. Tucker, a distinguished Sovietologist whose frustrations in persuading the authorities in Stalin’s Russia to let his new Russian wife accompany him home to the United States gave him crucial and influential insights into the Soviet leader, died Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 92.

headline: Erich Steidtmann, Ex-Nazi Officer in Inquiry, Dies at 95
text: Three months after German prosecutors reopened an investigation into whether he had participated in massacres of thousands of Polish Jews  an investigation he inadvertently instigated  Erich Steidtmann, a former Nazi officer, died last Sunday in Hanover, Germany. He was 95.

headline: Reader Comments on Medical Abortion
text: My Sunday column is about pharmaceutical breakthroughs — particularly misoprostol — in the provision of safe abortion. In the United States and Europe, abortion is safe, but five-sixths of abortions take place in the developing world where the procedure is often highly unsafe. As I write in the column, misoprostol may change that, and it’ll be very difficult for governments to prevent this revolution.

headline: For Pocono, Solar Power and Safety Improvements
text: LONG POND, Pa.  Doc Mattioli is 85 and does not get around his racetrack in the mountains quite as well as he used to. Even 10 years ago, he would hop into a bulldozer to take care of a rough spot. Now he must use a wheelchair, and his once-booming voice seems several decibels softer.

headline: John R. Branca, Advocate for Boxers, Dies at 86
text: John R. Branca, a former legislator who worked to enhance the safety of fighters in the boxing ring as the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, died July 17 in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 86 and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

headline: Building the Future With the Past
text: Steven Erlanger, The Times's Paris bureau chief, visited Burgundy, where artisans are using 13th-century techniques to build a replica of a medieval chateau.

headline: Flooding in Pakistan
text: Monsoon-driven floods are reported to have killed at least 800 people and destroyed thousands of homes in the past week, officials said Saturday, as some of the 1 million Pakistanis affected were reported with fevers, diarrhea and other waterborne illnesses.

headline: Targeted Killing Is New U.S. Focus in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama announced his new war plan for Afghanistan last year, the centerpiece of the strategy  and a big part of the rationale for sending 30,000 additional troops  was to safeguard the Afghan people, provide them with a competent government and win their allegiance.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Trade Deadline Comes and Goes, but Mets Make Do in the Ninth Inning
text: Some Mets players and fans might have been discouraged by the lack of action from their front office Saturday afternoon at the nonwaiver trading deadline.

headline: Big Homer (No, Not That One) Wins It
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  In the rare moments Saturday night when the fans at Tropicana Field were not clapping rhythmically, blowing horns, ringing cowbells or chanting players’ names, their hands might have been clutching their seats, gripped by the excitement and intensity of a late October game that was playing out on the final day of July.

headline: It’s Not Too Late to Hit the Road
text: For restless travelers still itching to hit the road this summer, Lonely Planet has a few suggestions. To mark the publication of “USA’s Best Trips: 99 Themed Itineraries Across America” in September, the company is releasing a road trip itinerary (in PDF) on Lonely Planet’s Facebook page each week until Aug 30.

headline: Chelsea Clinton’s Wedding: ‘Royalty’ in Rhinebeck
text: Marc Mezvinsky and Chelsea Clinton were married Saturday night at a ceremony that captivated the town of Rhinebeck, N.Y., though the proceedings and high-profile guests were largely hidden from view.

headline: Two Vietnamese Players Make a Name for Their Homeland
text: Could the emergence of world-class chess players be a sign of a country’s economic progress?

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about the Menier Chocolate Factory, a theater in London known for its scaled-down productions, misidentified the original director of “Phantom of the Opera.” He is Harold Prince, not Trevor Nunn.

headline: No Penalty for Party Profiler
text: ESPN will not discipline one of its online writers, Arash Markazi, for not properly disclosing that he was writing an article about LeBron James’s partying in Las Vegas, according to a person briefed on the decision who was not authorized to speak publicly.

headline: Events in Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Vows: Jess and Jeff
text: Jessica Rivkin and Jeffrey Larson met in 2002 at a summer opera workshop in Italy. Sparks flew at a dress rehearsal, when their eyes locked through Jeff's mask.

headline: Baltimore Ravens 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit@NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: In Berlin, Finding Art in Unlikely Places
text: This summer, the Berlin Biennale isn’t the only art show in town. Kreuzberg, long one of Berlin’s creative districts, is hosting the first-ever Kreuzberg Biennale, through August. Though it’s on a smaller scale than the city-wide event, it’s got plenty of edgy offerings — and in some unlikely places.

headline: Core Values and Employees Who Don’t Belong, Part 2
text: Last week, I wrote a post about the adoption of our core values. I explained that we created awards that honor employees who best demonstrate those values and give us extra incentive to deliver great service. I also explained that I’d asked everyone to rate their team members — on a scale of 1 to 10 — on how well they align with our values, a process that helped me identify a couple of employees who really weren’t a good fit. I think it’s fair to say that some readers reacted negatively to this post.

headline: Where Not to Use Your Debit Card
text: Add one more place to the growing list of locations where you should be wary about using your debit card: gas station pumps.

headline: What About Parents?
text: One more reaction to the new kindergarten research, this one from Greg Mankiw:

headline: When 81% Passing Suddenly Becomes 18%
text: LINDA L. SINGER, the principal of Public School 255 in Gravesend, Brooklyn, has some phone calls she is dreading to make.

headline: Pakistan Challenged in Flood Rescue
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The military and other emergency workers struggled against time and nature on Sunday to reach at least 10,000 people trapped by collapsed bridges and flooded roads and threatened by rising water brought by the worst monsoon rains in Pakistan’s history.

headline: The Sunday Word
text: Democrats are gearing up for their final four workdays before the August recess and their return to their districts, where they will face questions over two dramas, President Obama’s health care plan and the sputtering economy.

headline: The Pirates Are Puppets, but the Treasure (They Say) Is Real
text: Ignore the puppets for a moment. Set aside the narrative of a ragtag team of incompetent pirates. And look past the fact that the two men behind the videos featuring the pirates refuse to identify themselves.

headline: D’oh! We Almost Spaced on Lisa Simpson’s Wedding Date!
text: While the news media was focused on another set of nuptials, we nearly forgot to congratulate Lisa Simpson on her impending marriage to Hugh Parkfield, as predicted in a 1995 episode of “The Simpsons”:

headline: Floods Devastate Northwest Pakistan
text: The Pakistani military is leading rescue and relief activities, but lack of access has hampered its efforts.

headline: U.S. Cleared in Afghan Crash That Led to Rioting
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Kabul police have cleared a United States Embassy vehicle of fault for a deadly collision on Friday that set off anti-American rioting near the embassy, a senior police official said Sunday.

headline: Space Station Malfunction Prompts Shutdowns
text: One of two critical cooling systems aboard the International Space Station malfunctioned late on Saturday, setting off alarms and triggering an extensive reduction in power. Mission managers gave tentative approval on Sunday to plans for a complex two-spacewalk repair job late this week.

headline: Still Chasing 600, Rodriguez Is Not in Yankees Lineup
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Alex Rodriguez was onto something Saturday night when he said “it’s probably going to take a while” for him to hit his 600th career homer. It seemed unlikely to happen on Sunday, when Rodriguez was held out of the lineup for the Yankees’ series finale with the Rays. He had played the last 13 games, and Manager Joe Girardi felt Rodriguez could use a break from the Tropicana Field turf.

headline: Seeking New Deal, Jets’ Revis Is Absent, but a Presence
text: CORTLAND, N.Y.  All Sunday afternoon, the Jets carried pillows, monogrammed luggage and flat-screen televisions into their dormitory, stocking this temporary training camp abode with every last item except the belongings of their best player, cornerback Darrelle Revis.

headline: Emirates to Cut Data Services of BlackBerry
text: The United Arab Emirates, citing security concerns, said Sunday that it would suspend BlackBerry mobile services like e-mail and text messaging beginning in October, the latest high-stakes clash between governments and communications providers over the flow of digital information.

headline: James Ehnes
text: The violinist performs with the pianist Andrew Armstrong at the Kaplan Penthouse. (Video courtesy of the Mostly Mozart Festival)

headline: 'Dionysos'
text: Images from Wolfgang Rihm’s opera at the Salzburg Festival.

headline: ‘Rules of Betrayal’
text: Zabul Province, Afghanistan

headline: Flooding in Pakistan Continues
text: More than 700 people have died across Pakistan after record-breaking rainfall caused catastrophic floods.

headline: Slower Pace of Growth in China
text: China’s manufacturing contracted for the first time in 16 months in July, as the government clamped down on property speculation and closed energy-intensive and polluting factories.

headline: ‘Miss Daisy’ Gets a Son: Boyd Gaines
text: Boyd Gaines (“The Grand Manner,” “Gypsy”) will round out the three-member cast of the coming Broadway production of Alfred Uhry’s play “Driving Miss Daisy,” joining Vanessa Redgrave and James Earl Jones. Mr. Gaines will play Boolie Werthan, who hires Hoke (Mr. Jones) as a chauffeur for his mother, Daisy (Ms. Redgrave). (Dan Aykroyd played Boolie in the film version of “Driving Miss Daisy.”) Mr. Gaines is the recipient of four Tony Awards for acting, most recently for the latest revival of “Gypsy” (starring Patti LuPone); he also earned Tonys for “Contact,” “She Loves Me” and “The Heidi Chronicles.” The Broadway production of Mr. Uhry’s play  its first, having had its premiere Off Broadway in 1987  is scheduled to begin 16 weeks of performances on Oct. 7. David Esbjornson will direct.

headline: ‘Inception’ Continues Its Juggernaut
text: In the spring Hollywood was snickering that “Inception” was nothing more than an expensive vanity project, a movie that Warner Brothers allowed the director Christopher Nolan to make because “The Dark Knight” was so successful. But who’s laughing now? “Inception,” starring Leonardo DiCaprio (above left, with Joseph Gordon-Levitt), was No. 1 at North American theaters for the third week in a row with an estimated $27.5 million in ticket sales, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. It has sold a cumulative $193.4 million in North America, making it one of the biggest nonanimated hits of the year. “Dinner for Schmucks,” a comedy from Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks Studios, was a soft second with about $23.3 million. That film, which stars Steve Carell, must now hope to replicate the pattern of “Date Night,” Mr. Carell’s last comedy, which opened with a so-so $25 million but managed to take in about $100 million before its run was over. Angelina Jolie’s “Salt” (Columbia Pictures) was third with about $19.3 million, for a new domestic total of $70.8 million. “Despicable Me,” the animated blockbuster from Universal Studios, sold another $15.5 million for fourth place and a new total of $190.3 million. A whimsical marketing campaign for “Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore” (Warner Brothers) couldn’t overcome deadly reviews, and it opened in fifth place with $12.5 million. Also disappointing was Zac Efron and Universal’s “Charlie St. Cloud,” which was sixth in its first weekend with $12.1 million, proving that young actor does not yet have the ability to anchor a major release.

headline: Two Tied for Lead in Women’s Chess Grand Prix
text: The top seed was held to a draw by the lowest-ranked played on Sunday in the fifth Women’s Grand Prix. That allowed Zhao Xue of China to overtake the second-round leader, Humpy Koneru of India.

headline: Mets Celebrate Their Past, Then Cringe at Their Present
text: The Mets made a weekend out of celebrating four members of the best team in franchise history, the 1986 squad that won a club-record 108 games and one of the more dramatic World Series in baseball history.

headline: Rays, Here to Stay, Give the Yankees a Farewell Message
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees will not return to Tropicana Field for six weeks, so the Tampa Bay Rays gave them a parting gift Sunday to tide them over. It came in the form of a 3-0 victory that further reminded the Yankees, as if they needed it, that the standings in the American League East do not figure to change much before their next visit, in mid-September.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Comparative Disinflations
text: Tim Duy has taken my clockwise spirals of disinflation during slumps and put them on a single graph; here’s a cleaned-up version:

headline: A Film’s Mysteries Include a Tease to Édith Piaf
text: Having systematically picked apart the critical arguments for and against Christopher Nolan’s “Inception” and the many possible meanings of that dream-within-a-dream-within-a-dream caper, the film’s fans on the Web have gone a level deeper by focusing on its music.

headline: Another Star for New ‘Law & Order’
text: Though the original “Law & Order” television series ended in May, another spinoff, “Law & Order: Los Angeles,” is breathing new life into the franchise. On top of the already announced casting of Alfred Molina, the Oscar-nominated actor Terrence Howard, left, has been cast as a deputy district attorney, the show’s creator Dick Wolf told the Television Critics Association on Friday, The Associated Press reported. Corey Stoll (“Salt”) also joins the cast as partner to the detective played by Skeet Ulrich, best known for his work in the “Scream” movie franchise. Further casting and details on the new characters have yet to be announced. The show is set to have its premiere in the fall.

headline: Obama and Sasha Check Out the WNBA
text: President Obama soaked up some WNBA action Sunday at the Verizon Center in Washington, where the Washington Mystics took on the Tulsa Shock.

headline: Entertaining the Troops With Touring Writers
text: Remember the old U.S.O. days of Marilyn Monroe and Bob Hope? Well, today’s U.S.O. is turning to literature to entertain the troops. Representatives of the U.S.O., a nonprofit group that provides morale and recreational services to members of the military, have announced the start of “Operation Thriller,” a weeklong tour in the Persian Gulf this fall by five professional thriller writers. The authors scheduled to participate are Steve Berry (“The Paris Vendetta”), David Morrell (“First Blood”), Douglas Preston (“Relic”), James Rollins (“Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull”) and Andy Harp (“A Northern Thunder”). The tour begins in Washington, where the writers will visit troops at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center and National Naval Medical Center. Exact dates and locations will not be released because of security concerns.

headline: Cosmos: Twice in a Lifetime?
text: The title of the film about the world’s most famous defunct soccer team was “Once in a Lifetime.”

headline: Nacho Duato Joins Mikhailovsky Ballet
text: After the Spanish choreographer Nacho Duato announced in April that he was retiring as artistic director of the Compañía Nacional de Danza in Madrid, it seemed he would be without a dance home. Now Agence France-Presse reports that Mr. Duato will lead the Mikhailovsky Ballet of St. Petersburg, beginning Jan. 1, 2011. “I will start working in St. Petersburg with energy and enthusiasm,” Mr. Duato was quoted as saying. “It is a challenge for me.” He has said that after 20 years at the Madrid company, he and administrators had a falling out over the troupe’s direction.

headline: Philosophy and Faith
text: One of my jobs as a teacher of bright, mostly Catholic undergraduates is to get them thinking about why they hold their religious beliefs.  It’s easy enough to spark discussion about the problem of evil (“Can you really read the newspaper every day and continue to believe in an all-perfect God?”) or about the diversity of religious beliefs (“If you’d been born in Saudi Arabia, don’t you think you’d be a Muslim?”).  Inevitably, however, the discussion starts to fizzle when someone raises a hand and says (sometimes ardently, sometimes smugly) “But aren’t you forgetting about faith?”

headline: Double Dostoevsky at Baryshnikov Center
text: Two productions based on works by Dostoevsky will help to round out the Baryshnikov Arts Center’s new season of dance, music and theater, the center announced. The Theater Art Studio in Moscow brings “The Boys,” a reworking of “The Brothers Karamazov,” to the center for its United States premiere, Oct. 6 to 10. In association with Theater for a New Audience, the center will present Yale Repertory Theater’s “Notes From Underground,” the director Robert Woodruff’s adaptation of Dostoevsky’s first-person novella, Nov. 7 to 20. Other season highlights will include performances by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and the Australian dancer and choreographer Russell Dumas, as well as a collaboration between the pianist Eteri Andjaparidze and the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton, exploring the connections between chords and colors in their piece “Spectral Scriabin.” The center’s chamber music series, the Movado Hour, continues with performances throughout the season, which begins Sept. 9. Tickets for all events go on sale Aug. 30; (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com.

headline: Ailey’s New Season: ‘Revelations’ at 50
text: A celebration of the 50th anniversary of the seminal “Revelations” (above, with Antonio Douthit and Akua Parker) will be among the highlights of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s 2010 season at City Center, the company announced. The season, which runs from Dec. 1 through Jan. 2, will feature special performances of this piece, choreographed by Ailey and first performed in 1960. The season, which will be Judith Jamison’s last as artistic director, includes nine premieres, including a world premiere by Christopher Huggins, a former company member, and company premieres by Camille A. Brown and by Robert Battle, who will be taking over as artistic director. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis will join the company for one week during the season for a program titled, “Ailey/Jazz,” which will include the first full production in over 30 years of “Three Black Kings,” a collaboration between Ailey and Duke Ellington. The season will conclude with a tribute to Ms. Jamison on Jan. 2 featuring guest artists.

headline: A TV Host Challenges a Guest. That’s News.
text: The new host of ABC’s Sunday morning news program, renamed “This Week With Christiane Amanpour,” tried to get a rise out of Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker.

headline: Plastic Surgeon Fights an Ugly World
text: If one of the Hardy Boys had grown up to be a plastic surgeon for Doctors Without Borders, he might be a lot like Christopher Reich’s gung-ho Dr. Jonathan Ransom. Dr. Ransom has now chased heroically through three of Mr. Reich’s feverish espionage novels, working medical miracles while thwarting terrorist attacks. He is capable of “brooking no retort” while holding up his end of a conversation.

headline: Admiral Mullen on Afghanistan
text: MSNBC's David Gregory interviews Adm. Mike Mullen about the war in Afghanistan and the impact of the WikiLeaks revelations on strategy.

headline: ‘Easy, Tychus, This Ain’t Science Fiction’
text: Wouldn’t you know, Blizzard’s still got it.

headline: A Nietzschean Plunge Into Sensual Labyrinths
text: SALZBURG, Austria  The German composer Wolfgang Rihm has little interest in music-theater works that tell realistic stories realistically. The operas that hooked him as a child were concoctions like Mozart’s “Zauberflöte,” with its ladies from the beyond, ghostly queen, mysterious guards and magic bells. “That is opera,” he said in an interview for the program book of this summer’s Salzburg Festival.

headline: Blog Meta
text: One thing readers may not realize is that although this blog is located at the New York Times, it’s essentially a personal not-for-pay venture. It’s mainly a scratchpad where I can try out ideas, lay out some of the data and wonkery behind columns, and blow off steam on matters not worth spending the precious 4830 characters including spaces that the Times grants me twice a week in the column proper.

headline: Photo Finish in the Spingold Knockout Teams
text: NEW ORLEANS  At the Summer Nationals here the 64-board final of the Spingold Knockout Teams had a nail-biting finish in the early hours of Sunday.

headline: Ka-ching
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Sometimes a tiny twist is all that’s needed to elevate a mundane crossword theme into something memorable. Three answers based on the straightforward phrases THE SPEED OF LIGHT, THE SOUND OF MUSIC and THE COLOR OF MONEY would be bland. Simply by spinning the dial on the last words so they don’t match up properly, a new constructor, Diane Baker van Hoff, ups the ante with unexpected interconnectedness.

headline: Clinton’s Gown Spoke Beyond the Silence
text: Chelsea Clinton isn’t the first presidential daughter who has tried to keep private the details of her wedding day. “I feel that marriage vows are sacred, and I hope that mine will be spared the hurly-burly attending a news event,” Margaret Truman said before her 1956 nuptials in Missouri. At least she and the groom, Clifton Daniel, consented to a press conference with 50 reporters.

headline: Taking Down The Goalposts
text: So I just read the latest speech from Richard Fisher of the Dallas Fed; it’s one of the most depressing things I’ve read lately, and given what I read that’s saying a lot.

headline: A Show Is Not Just a Show but an Album, and That Album Is a Floating Epic
text: Jason Pierce didn’t face the audience when he led Spiritualized on Friday night at Radio City Music Hall, and rightly so. He was performing music to get lost in.

headline: Game Playing, Storytelling and Psyches Stuck in Surprising Ruts
text: The seven performers of A. O. Movement Collective  three men, four women  bring a raw, vulnerable quality to their movement that’s highly arresting. They look untutored, improvisatory and unpolished, so that a regular dancegoer starts to wonder how much technique any of them has ever tried to acquire. They don’t even look as if they spend time at the gym.

headline: Motor City Zooms Into Town for a Visit
text: There were two through-lines at the Detroit Breakdown, a festival of music from Michigan on Saturday at Lincoln Center Out of Doors. One was the crisp, enterprising gospel-turned-pop that found its biggest audience on Motown Records. The other was a cantankerous streak that runs from Detroit blues through the city’s proto-punk and garage-rock, and arguably into the combative hip-hop of Eminem. Through afternoon and evening shows, craftsmanship and commotion kept recombining.

headline: Detroit Breakdown
text: Photos from a concert of famous Michigan acts.

headline: First Daughters’ Weddings, From Johnson to Clinton
text: Since the 1960s, the weddings of daughters of presidents (current or former) have been the subject of media scrutiny and public fascination.

text: LOS LOBOS

headline: As iPad Gains, Others Will Lose
text: Apple sold 3.3 million iPads last quarter. That is one of the best starts ever for a consumer electronic device. It could sell 25 million of the electronic tablets next year, based on the trajectory of past consumer hits.

headline: ‘Idol’ Is Now Free to Be ...What?
text: “American Idol” is holding auditions for its 10th season, to be broadcast next year, but those lining up to sing for producers have no idea what the show they’re trying out for will actually look like.

headline: Minorities Favor Phones in Using Web
text: Nearly six in 10 Americans are now connected to the Internet wirelessly via a Wi-Fi connection, mobile broadband card or cellphone, compared to about half at this point last year, according to a report from Pew Internet.

headline: Man Fatally Stabbed During Fight in Brooklyn
text: A man was stabbed and beaten to death in Park Slope, Brooklyn, early Sunday morning, according to the police and relatives of the man.

headline: New Site Aims to Connect Reporters and Publicists
text: There are few professional relationships that seesaw between love and hate more than those of public relations people and journalists. While they provide valuable help to each other at times, they rarely need the same things at the same time.

headline: Desirée, Making Her Entrance Again
text: The pleasures of love recollected and the possibilities of love anticipated are contemplated in “A Little Night Music,” the musical by Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler currently in revival on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater. The satisfactions of love in the present? That’s a more complicated matter in this melancholy romantic comedy.

headline: A Renegade Site, Now Working With the News Media
text: THE four stages of a political movement, as Gandhi told it, were: “First they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they fight you, then you win.”

headline: Corona Light Sets Sights on a Younger Party Crowd
text: LIGHT beer commercials usually focus on men, who are its biggest consumers, with machismo, humor and outright goofiness. Corona Light is going after a different group with a campaign for socially active men and women in their 20s.

headline: In India, Using Facebook to Catch Scofflaw Drivers
text: NEW DELHI  This city is famous for its snarled traffic and infamous for its unruly drivers  aggressive rule-breakers who barrel through red lights, ignore crosswalks and veer into bicycle or bus lanes to find open routes.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 1
text: A view of the day in sports, from N.F.L. training camps to a snowmobile race on a river.

headline: Border Deployment Will Take Weeks
text: SAN DIEGO — No boots were seen tromping in the desert sand on Sunday. No commanders were heard barking out orders to their troops. The National Guard, which officials had announced would turn out en masse along the United States-Mexico border over the weekend for sentry duty, was nowhere to be found.

headline: Bing and Google in a Race for Features
text: Edwin Perello discovered that Bing, the Microsoft search engine, could find addresses in his rural Indiana town when Google could not. Laura Michelson, an administrative assistant in San Francisco, was lured by Bing’s flight fare tracker. Paul Callan, a photography buff in Chicago, fell for Bing’s vivid background images.

headline: Rough Start for One Giant
text: ALBANY — It was not even 11 a.m., but the day already looked lost for Gartrell Johnson.

headline: Media Companies Try Getting Social With Tumblr
text: By now, plenty of traditional media companies have hopped on the social media bandwagon, pumping out news updates on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: State-Owned Bidders Fuel China’s Land Boom
text: WUHU, China  The Anhui Salt Industry Corporation is a state-owned company that has 11,000 employees, access to government salt mines and a Communist Party boss.

headline: After Rough Start, Niese May Be Skipped
text: As if the Mets do not already have enough problems, there is now some uncomfortable ambiguity surrounding the rotation as the team heads into three-game series at Atlanta and at Philadelphia.

headline: In Koreas, Floods Carry Land Mines
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Dozens of North Korean land mines loosened by heavy rains have washed ashore on South Korean riverbanks and beaches near the border, presenting a lethal new threat to residents already wary of surprises and nefarious motives from the North.

headline: Joy in Mudville, Wherever It May Be
text: STOCKTON, Calif.  They stepped on the field dressed as ballplayers from a bygone era: the hats smaller, the pants baggier, the gloves tighter than those of today. The unlikely rivals shook hands and slapped backs, exchanging pleasantries and barbs as they warmed up for a game some had crossed the country to play.

headline: Wedding Planner for a High-Profile Affair
text: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  The shroud of secrecy surrounding Chelsea Clinton’s wedding here was due in part to the wedding planner, not the Clintons.

headline: Berkman’s Rough Opening Weekend
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Looking more like Fat Elvis than the Big Puma, Lance Berkman had a rocky first two games with the Yankees, which he readily acknowledged. He went 1 for 8 over the weekend with a few shaky plays at first base Sunday that helped the Rays score all of their runs in a 3-0 victory.

headline: The Palestinians, Alone
text: London

headline: Protests Test Patience of Mexico City Drivers
text: MEXICO CITY  On almost any given day, drivers hopelessly paralyzed by the protesters marching down Mexico City’s avenues may feel that the city’s jaunty logo and slogan, plastered everywhere, are taunting them.

headline: Fans at Meadowlands Baffled by a State Plan
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Neighbors Press Goldman Sachs on Ferry Noise
text: Goldman Sachs, which has certainly borne its share of public anger about the financial crisis, is now drawing heat for another reason: noisy ferryboats.

headline: Lookin at Lucky Dominates in Haskell
text: OCEANPORT, N.J.  Mike Pegram, the owner of horse racing’s unluckiest colt, had been waiting for this moment, a race in which everything would break Lookin at Lucky’s way and the black cloud would finally disappear.

headline: Taking a Break From the Lord’s Work
text: The findings have surfaced with ominous regularity over the last few years, and with little notice: Members of the clergy now suffer from obesity, hypertension and depression at rates higher than most Americans. In the last decade, their use of antidepressants has risen, while their life expectancy has fallen. Many would change jobs if they could.

headline: Editor’s Impact Begins With a Capital O
text: Susan Casey’s publishing résumé reflects what one would expect from someone who has chased great white sharks in California, stalked elk in Colorado and tramped the oil-slicked marshlands of Louisiana. Editor of Sports Illustrated Women? Check. Creative director of Outside? Check. Author of a book on sharks and another on extreme surfing? Check, check.

headline: For a College President, the Criticisms Pile Up
text: It has been only a year since William L. Pollard was named president of Medgar Evers College, a historically black institution in central Brooklyn that is named for the slain civil rights leader. In that time, Dr. Pollard has focused on increasing graduation rates, making the college more student-friendly and, mostly, getting to know the campus.

headline: Immigrant Maids Flee Lives of Abuse in Kuwait
text: KUWAIT  With nowhere else to go, dozens of Nepalese maids who fled from their employers now sleep on the floor in the lobby of their embassy here, next to the visitors’ chairs.

headline: Mexican Youth Is Attacked on Staten Island
text: The police on Staten Island were searching for three assailants Sunday in connection with the robbery and beating of a Mexican teenager a day earlier  the latest in a series of attacks on Mexican immigrants in Port Richmond that has spurred a heightened police presence and discussions among community leaders and residents on how to curb the rising violence.

headline: Couric’s Future Clouded by CNN
text: For years, whenever television fortune-tellers forecast Larry King’s eventual replacement, Katie Couric’s name was the first to be mentioned: one of the best interviewing jobs on television, and one of the best-known interviewers on television. It seemed a perfect match.

headline: A Plan to Recover More Organs for Transplant Runs Into Difficulty
text: For years, even as the medical community persuaded more people to become organ donors, it faced a seemingly insurmountable problem: Most people do not die in hospitals, making saving their organs for transplant nearly impossible.

headline: Hurdles Deter Obama’s Pledge to Double Exports
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama announced at his State of the Union address in January a goal of doubling American exports over five years, business owners applauded, envisioning a flood of goods moving into new markets in the Asian and Latin American countries that are leading the global recovery. The chief executives of Boeing and Xerox agreed to lead an advisory council to support the effort, called the National Export Initiative.

headline: In Iowa Tour (Already), Republican Tests His Voice
text: WAVERLY, Iowa — The scene had all the makings of an American Gothic painting from Iowa’s own Grant Wood. A red and white barn served as the backdrop. A cornfield was in the distance. And a politician spoke of making the country great again.

headline: Four New Inductees in Mets Hall of Fame
text: When they opened Citi Field last year, the Mets were criticized for not doing enough at the new ballpark to embrace their history. But the team opened a Hall of Fame and Museum at the start of this season, and on Sunday, it inducted four new members.

headline: On Television, Playing Down an Image of Wealth
text: The Republican running for governor in Connecticut went to Andover, Harvard and Harvard Business School, founded a private equity firm and settled in Greenwich. He owns a private plane, six cars and three motorcycles, as well as a 100-foot yacht registered in the Marshall Islands.

headline: Iraq's Dark Age
text: Eight hot summers after American troops entered Iraq, one of the most basic needs, electricity, remains unreliable.

headline: Ratify the Treaty
text: The New Start treaty, the first arms control agreement signed with the Russians in nearly a decade, calls for modest nuclear reductions, from 2,200 deployed warheads to 1,550. It will make the world safer, guaranteeing each country continued insight into the other’s strategic arsenals, with data exchanges and regular inspections.

headline: Disgusting but Not Illegal
text: Chief Justice John Roberts Jr., who has become one of the First Amendment’s most adamant defenders, led the Supreme Court earlier this year in refusing to create a new exception to the free speech clause. With only one dissent, the court struck down a law that banned depictions of animal cruelty. The House has come back with a replacement bill that is an improvement over its predecessor but still misses the constitutional point Justice Roberts made.

headline: Tribal Law and Order
text: The notion of only one federal patrolman available to police a 2.3 million-acre beat presents ludicrously impossible odds for law enforcement. Yet that was often the case on the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North and South Dakota in 2008, when the rate of violent crime was more than eight times the national average and the police force totaled nine members.

headline: Arlington’s Broken Trust
text: The nation’s obligation to honor its war dead has been shockingly and painfully dishonored at Arlington National Cemetery. We are all familiar with Arlington’s iconic images: green hills, simple white gravestones and solemn military guards accompanying the bodies of soldiers and sailors to their rest. Now there is another deeply troubling image: a cemetery defiled by unmarked and mismarked graves; funeral urns unearthed and contents discarded. That is a trauma the families of the fallen should never have to endure.

headline: The Cameras Are Rolling, and the Jets Expect to Be, Too

text: I’m starting to have a sick feeling about prospects for American workers  but not, or not entirely, for the reasons you might think.

headline: A Benchmark of Progress, Electrical Grid Fails Iraqis
text: BAGHDAD  Ikbal Ali, a bureaucrat in a beaded head scarf, accompanied by a phalanx of police officers, quickly found what she was out looking for in the summer swelter: electricity thieves. Six black cables stretched from a power pole to a row of auto-repair shops, siphoning what few hours of power Iraq’s straining system provides.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Electricity Shortage
text: Almost seven and a half years after the American invasion of Iraq, the new democratic government still struggles to provide one of the most basic services: electricity.

text: Fox News moves up, The Associated Press moves over and National Public Radio comes in second.

headline: CBS Adds 3 Gay Roles
text: LOS ANGELES — For years CBS has lagged behind other television networks in its inclusion of gay, lesbian and transgender characters. In the season that starts in September, however, a gay character will join “The Good Wife,” a lesbian character will join “Rules of Engagement” and a gay character will appear in the new sitcom “$#*! My Dad Says.”

headline: Cosmos Begin Anew, With Eye Toward M.L.S.
text: The title of the film about perhaps the world’s most famous defunct soccer team was “Once in a Lifetime.”

text: Admit it: You’ve always wanted Carmen Electra to wish you a happy birthday. Or maybe not. But she is going to be at the ready just in case.

headline: ‘The Bulldozers Are Coming’: Garden Crusaders Hop on Their Bikes
text: The bikes departed Tompkins Square, pedaled by men and women dressed in 21st-century thrift-store versions of 18th-century garb. There were tricorn hats, vests and, in a few cases, shirts with long, flowing sleeves. Many of the bicycles were decorated with cardboard cutouts in the shape of a horse’s head. One man rang a bell. Others shouted to passers-by on Avenue B, calling out, “The bulldozers are coming.”

headline: Palin Has Some Pointed Words for Obama
text: Former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska could have chosen courage, boldness, guts or even lion-heartedness as a yardstick to compare the immigration stances of President Obama and Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona. But the former vice presidential candidate instead went with a much more pointed term on Sunday.

headline: Gates Cites Peril in Leak of Afghan War Logs by WikiLeaks
text: WASHINGTON  Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates said Sunday that an announcement by the Taliban that they were going through classified military dispatches from Afghanistan posted by the Web site WikiLeaks “basically proves the point” that the disclosures put at risk the lives of Afghans who had aided American forces.

Paid Leave for Family Care

headline: On the G.O.P. Precampaign Trail
text: For the men (and one rather polarizing woman) who might run for president as Republicans in 2012, now is the wilderness campaign. After the midterms, the struggle for the nomination will move out into open country. But for the moment, it’s all guerrilla warfare and tactical maneuvering  in the form of Web videos and op-eds, speeches and endorsements, and the occasional public dig at a potential rival.

headline: Agency Role Could Limit Basketball Broker’s Power
text: LAS VEGAS  In the perpetually gray world of basketball recruiting, one question in recent years has always doubled as a punch line: Whom does William Wesley work for?

headline: Domestic Abuse
text: Ramadan highlights the ongoing difficulties facing thousands of domestic workers in Kuwait.

headline: For the Recently Homeless, Belonging by Competing in a Soccer Tournament
text: WASHINGTON  With the help of their namesake hairdo, members of the Sacramento Mohawks managed to stand out among their competition at the 2010 Street Soccer USA Cup on Sunday. Their collective rows of trimmed hair atop bald scalps helped form a sense of team commonality against the strong individualists on display during the tournament here. One player from the six-member Mohawks made herself even more distinguishable by virtue of her gender and her level of play.

headline: In House Ethics Battles, a Partywide Threat
text: WASHINGTON  By defiantly pushing for full-fledged ethics trials, Representatives Charles B. Rangel and Maxine Waters are raising the prospect of a spectacle focusing on Congressional corruption this fall, just as Democrats are fighting to hold on to their majority in an election already defined by distrust of Washington.

headline: Plagiarism Lines Blur for Students in Digital Age
text: At Rhode Island College, a freshman copied and pasted from a Web site’s frequently asked questions page about homelessness  and did not think he needed to credit a source in his assignment because the page did not include author information.

headline: Known for Making Locker Room Listen, Rolle Has a New Team to Lead
text: ALBANY  Standing in front of a backdrop of Giants logos, safety Antrel Rolle seemed at ease at his first training camp here. But the T-shirt he was wearing might as well have been vested with 100-pound weights.

headline: Corrections
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. headline: Different Views of New Phase in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  When gunmen ambushed Iraqi security checkpoints in a large Sunni neighborhood of Baghdad last Thursday, terrorized residents said the attack reminded them of the worst days of the war. The United States military said it was unaware of any gunfighting.

headline: A School District That Takes the Isolation Out of Autism
Take a Walk After a Poor Shot
text: One of the interesting findings of a recent study conducted on amateur golfers by Neil Wolkodoff, the director of the Center for Health and Sport Science at the Rose Medical Center in Denver, is that golfers generally score lower while walking with a pushcart or a caddie as opposed to riding in a golf cart. There could be a multitude of reasons for this, but one proposed by Wolkodoff centered on the idea that walking golfers have more time — and a built-in, physical, stress-reducing response to a poor shot.

headline: Brazil’s President Offers Asylum to Woman Facing Stoning in Iran
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has called on Iran’s president to send an Iranian woman facing execution by stoning to Brazil, where she would be granted asylum.

headline: Electricity: Iraq’s Other Power Vacuum
text: BAGHDAD — It was April 2003, and American tanks had just punched through into Baghdad. A safe distance behind came the first post-invasion American bureaucracy, the Office of Reconstruction and Humanitarian Assistance (ORHA).

headline: A Little Scientific Research for All Those 19th-Hole Debates
text: Ever wonder if you play better golf riding in a cart or walking? Ever wonder how many calories you burn in a typical round? Or if you would play better if you were in better shape? Ever wonder if golf is truly a sport?

headline: Why Both Parties Want an Economic Fight
text: Senators return to the Capitol this week for more close-quarters combat over the economy, before heading home on summer recess to continue the battle long-distance.

headline: No Sign of Favre at Camp, but the Vikings Don’t Seem to Mind
text: MANKATO, Minn.  The rain held off, but it was still overcast and a little muggy last Friday when Minnesota Vikings players, coaches and staffers trudged out for the first practice of training camp at Minnesota State University. No one expected Brett Favre to be there, but that did not stop Jennifer Farasyn of Redwood Falls, Minn., from staking out a prime photo-taking spot.

headline: The Other Gulf Stain
text: To the west of the oil slicks and fleets of vessels working to seal the BP well, another less invisible stain, mainly the result of vast amounts of nitrogen and other nutrients washing down the Mississippi River from agricultural lands upstream, has spread beneath the waters of the Gulf of Mexico. It is the annual blossoming of a zone of low dissolved oxygen levels, anathema to fish, shrimp and other marine life, known colloquially as the “dead zone.”

headline: Book Review: A Call to Fix the Fundamentals
text: In 2005, Raghuram G. Rajan told a meeting of the world’s top central bankers, Alan Greenspan included, that the global financial system was threatened from within and might well be facing a full-blown crisis. At the time, he says, he was roundly criticized. But given what happened a few years later we may not want to dismiss his recent assertion that the global economy is vulnerable to another implosion.

headline: Get a Diploma, but Then Get a Passport
text: This interview with Quintin E. Primo III, co-founder and chief executive of Capri Capital Partners, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant for the latest edition of Corner Office. Capri is a real estate investment and development firm based in Chicago.

headline: News Quiz | August 2, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Carr: The Zeal of a Convert to Twitter
text: Two years ago, Buzz Bissinger took a stand against digital culture, David Carr writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

headline: Meet Tumblr, Facebook and Twitter’s New Rival
text: By now, plenty of traditional media companies have hopped on the social media bandwagon, pumping out news updates on Facebook and Twitter, Jenna Wortham writes in The New York Times.

headline: A Richter Scale for Markets
text: It’s tempting to pull out the old earthquake metaphor when talking about the latest financial crises, Eric Dash writes in The New York Times. How else to describe the economic devastation — the tremors in the subprime mortgage market, the seismic collapse of Lehman Brothers, and the aftershocks reverberating in Europe?

headline: European Bank Stress Tests Worked, Sort Of
text: A week after the authorities released results of stress tests on the largest European banks, market data is starting to provide an indication of whether the exercise had the desired effect on confidence. The answer: sort of.

headline: Morgenson: With Friends Like This …
text: Is it a blinding statement of the obvious to say that trust in the world’s banks has suffered lately? Indeed, just when you think you’re ready to move past the steady drumbeat of disconcerting revelations, something else crops up to test your faith, Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest Fair Game column in The New York Times.

headline: Small Step on Small Fees, but Big Charges Remain
text: Picture a tiny hole in the hull of a ship on a long ocean voyage. It is slowly letting in water. If the hole isn’t plugged, the leak will eventually slow the vessel drastically — maybe even sink it, Jeff Sommer writes in The New York Times.

headline: Europe Opens Broader Inquiry of Greek Airlines’ Merger Plan
text: The European Commission said Friday that it would deepen its investigation of the proposed merger of Olympic Air and Aegean Airlines, saying a preliminary inquiry had shown the deal could “raise serious competition concerns.”

headline: UBS to Hire Goldman and BofA Executives
text: UBS said on Sunday that it planned to hire executives from Goldman Sachs and Bank of America to build its mortgages and lending business in the United States.

text: WHO did Chelsea Clinton marry? WHO were among the invited wedding guests?

headline: Crompton Said to Bid $400 Million for Emerson Unit
text: The Indian power equipment maker Crompton Greaves has offered $400 million for the transformer division of United States-based Emerson Electric Company, India’s Business Standard reported, citing three unnamed investment bankers familiar with the development.

headline: Rocket Hits Resort on Border of Jordan and Israel
text: AQABA, Jordan  A mysterious rocket that may have been launched from the Egyptian desert slammed into this Red Sea resort on Monday morning, and Jordanian officials said it killed a taxi driver and wounded five others.

headline: Two Funds Target Oxy Board Over Executive Pay
text: Funds that own 1 percent of Occidental Petroleum are targeting board seats at the fourth-largest U.S. oil company because of their concern about how it pays executives, one of the funds said on Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: China’s Geely Set to Close $1.8 Billion Volvo Buy
text: China’s Geely will complete its $1.8 billion purchase of the Ford Motor Company‘s Volvo unit on Monday, a source with direct knowledge of the matter said, capping China’s biggest purchase of a foreign carmaker.

headline: M.U.F.G. Plans to Buy China Fund Stake From BNP
text: The Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group planned to buy BNP Paribas‘ stake in a Chinese fund venture for $50 million, giving Japan’s biggest bank access to China’s $300 billion mutual funds market, two sources with direct knowledge of the deal said on Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: In the Italian Night, Islands of Light
text: Driving in the dark between Catania and Gela in Sicily, the Italian photographer Massimo Cristaldi couldn’t help gaze at something twinkling in the distance.

headline: BP Said to Seek Buyers for German Gas Stations
text: BP‘s sell-off has reportedly come to Europe, with Wirtschafts Woche, a German business weekly, citing unidentified investment bankers as saying that the oil company is seeking to sell its Aral chain of gas stations, whose value is estimated at 2 billion euros.

headline: BP Said to Ask Kuwait Fund to Raise Stake
text: BP has asked Kuwait’s sovereign wealth fund to raise its share in the company to 3 percent, Reuters said, citing a report in the al-Anba newspaper Monday.

text: Linc Energy of Australia said Monday that it was in negotiations that were “very well advanced” with Adani Enterprises, the Indian commodity trader, to sell certain of its coal assets in the province of Queensland.

text: We’re asking this question every Monday this summer for our Summer Reading Student Challenge. You can post your answer here anytime until next Monday, August 9.

headline: Private Equity Firms Go Fishing
text: According to research published on Monday by the Centre for Management Buy-Out Research at Nottingham University, the share of private equity activity coming from what The Financial Times referred to as “pass-the-parcel” deals between private equity groups reached an all-time high in the first half of 2010.

text: Gordmans Stores, a Midwestern discount retailer,  is preparing an initial public offering this week and, reports The Wall Street Journal, investors are watching.

text: With activist directors driving up the price, Sanofi-Aventis could find itself shelling out at least $80 a share, or $21.3 billion, to acquire the drug maker ,Genzyme, Bloomberg News reported.

text: Ford Motor said Monday that it had completed the sale of its Swedish unit Volvo to Zhejiang Geely Holding Group.

headline: Museums Part of New Cultural Circuit in London
text: It’s hard to imagine how George Washington’s false teeth could be linked to Africa’s largest mask. The answer is that they are both on show in museums that are within walking distance of a new stretch of railway line in London, the Overground East London line. This 14-mile route runs from Dalston Junction in north east London to West Croydon in the south of the city. It is being promoted as the CultureLine (www.cultureline.org.uk), because 10 of London’s hidden-gem museums are within walking distance of stations on the route.

headline: Credit Suisse Bolsters Prime Services Coverage
text: Credit Suisse has appointed Myo Schollum to head up its prime services coverage in Japan, as the bank endeavors to expand its business catering to hedge funds.

text: HSBC said Monday that its earnings had doubled in the first half of the year, as its American unit returned to profit and provisions for bad loans dropped to the lowest level since the start of the financial crisis, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

headline: Funds Bullish on Natural Gas as Heat Wave Strikes
text: With the mercury rising — along with an increase in air-conditioning demand — hedge funds last week upped the ante on natural gas prices believing they will rise for the first time in six weeks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Amid Tertiary Deals, Bridgepoint Talks to Jewelers
text: Bridgepoint Capital is in exclusive talks to buy and merge the French jewelers Histoire d’Or and Marc Orian, Bloomberg News reported, while The Financial Times noted that transactions in which a company is sold to its third private equity owner will this week reach $2.1 billion.

headline: Recent M&A Deals Bode Well for Second Semester
text: A comeback for global deal-making demand? According to a Bloomberg News report, a series of mergers and acquisitions over the last two weeks may signal just that.

headline: The Phone Call, Dead or on Hold?
text: Today’s idea: The telephone call as we know it “deserves to die,” a commentator says, because new forms of communication — texting, chatting and social-network messaging — are more efficient. Yet it will probably evolve and survive.

headline: With C.F.O. Hire, Zynga Looks Closer to I.P.O.

text: David Tyree’s retirement on Friday  was an occasion to look back at what some call the greatest play in N.F.L. history.

headline: Goldman’s Expensive Tastes Anger N.Y.C. Neighbors
text: Local New York City residents are up in arms over a plan by Goldman Sachs to replace a discount shoe shop, a pizza joint, a recently closed New York Sports Club gym and a budget inn outside its new $2.1 billion headquarters with a string of designer restaurants and a luxury hotel. The Telegraph reported that the bank is being accused by denizens of “breaking promises.”

headline: Rob Lowe Likes His Miramax Investment
text: Following various reports that he had met with Tom Barrack of Colony Capital — and was perhaps pursuing a big media deal with the private equity firm — the actor Rob Lowe has confirmed that he is one of the investors in the recent acquisition of Miramax Films.

headline: U.A.E. to Bar BlackBerry Data Services, Citing Security
text: The United Arab Emirates, citing security concerns, said Sunday that it would suspend BlackBerry mobile services like e-mail and text messaging beginning in October, the latest high-stakes clash between governments and communications providers over the flow of digital information.

headline: France Telecom Confirms Moroccan Interest

headline: Sympathy For Mira Sorvino
text: Here’s an exercise: Read Sam Anderson’s profile of James Franco for New York Magazine. Then go back and read Andrew Corsello’s 1996 profile of Mira Sorvino for GQ. Both are essays about highly-cerebral, possibly-overeducated celebrity actors whose peculiar personae are more interesting than any of the movies they’ve made. Both are the work of extremely skillful and engaging writers. But Anderson’s profile is an exercise in rueful wonderment, whereas Corsello’s profile is a brutal takedown. Franco’s intellectual pretentions are celebrated and his eccentricities are smiled upon; Sorvino’s intellectual ambitions are used against her and her eccentricities mercilessly mocked. Anderson goes out of his way to insist that Franco’s academic work is legitimate; Corsello makes fun of Sorvino for talking about her honors thesis. Anderson takes a rueful attitude toward the gulf between Franco’s ambitions and his actual body of work; Corsello has a good time making fun of “Romy and Michelle’s High School Reunion.” And so forth.

headline: Justin Bieber, Age 16, Will Write His Memoirs

In October, HarperCollins will release “Justin Bieber: First Step 2 Forever: My Story,” the publisher announced on Monday. “Between the behind-the-scenes pictures and the story I think this is going to be something they can all enjoy,” Mr. Bieber, 16, said in a statement. “This is just another way for me to say thank you to my fans.” HarperCollins described the book as an “illustrated memoir” in hardcover that will detail Mr. Bieber’s rise to stardom, complemented by exclusive photos — “a must-have for fans afflicted with Bieber-fever.” “All kidding aside, it’s going to sell a million-billion copies,” predicted Publishers Weekly.

headline: Broad Museum Could Get Millions Via Developers
text: The Los Angeles financier Eli Broad may get millions of dollars back on the $100 million museum he is planning to build as part of the Grand Avenue Project, a development of condominiums, cultural sites, stores, offices and a hotel in downtown Los Angeles. According to The Los Angeles Times, a deal approved last month by the Community Redevelopment Agency of Los Angeles calls for Mr. Broad’s museum to receive millions of dollars as the Grand Avenue Project moves forward. The redevelopment agency requires developers — in this case Related Companies — to pay one percent of their project’s design and construction costs to create public artworks or to support cultural sites in the neighborhood where they build. The deal, which was approved on July 15, includes the Broad Collection at Grand Avenue and 2nd Street as the cultural facility that will fulfill a large amount of Related Company’s percent-for-art obligation.

headline: A Brand New Squeeze
text: Some cynics regard Philippe Starck as merely a master of self-promotion. But they don’t know that the French design superstar has always championed the work of talented newcomers. Last year, Starck was the mentor for a competition — organized by the British Web site mydeco.com and MGX, the Belgian rapid-prototyping pioneer — that invited students aged 18 to 25 to design a domestic object. Starck was so impressed by the work of the German student, Roland Kreiter, that he telephoned Alberto Alessi, the C.E.O. of the Italian manufacturer Alessi, and urged him to produce it. (Starck also hired Kreiter as an intern in his office.) By coincidence, Kreiter’s design, My Squeeze, is a juicer. And one of the products that made Starck famous is the now-iconic Juicy Salif, the gangly three-legged objet that celebrates its 20th anniversary this year. Perfect timing.

headline: What Should I Ask of My Accountant?
text: No story today, just a question: what is the proper kind of relationship to have with one’s accountant? I see my bookkeeper twice a week, so I know where the money is going, but I’ve never actually met the accountant (she was hired by my ex-partner). As far as I know, there’s nothing wrong with her work. We ship her the ledgers at the end of the year and get back the tax returns in March, and that’s it. That can’t possibly be the best arrangement, but I’m curious as to what the alternatives are. And while I’m at it, a few more queries:

headline: Judge Allows Virginia’s Suit Against Health Care Law to Proceed

headline: Film Company to Appeal Rating of Holocaust Documentary
text: Oscilloscope Laboratories said it planned to appeal an R rating assigned by the Classification and Rating Administration to the Holocaust documentary “A Film Unfinished.” The documentary, which screened at the Sundance Film Festival this year, dissects a Nazi propaganda film that was shot in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1942. In assigning an R rating, which requires viewers under the age of 17 to be accompanied by an adult, the ratings board cited “disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities including graphic nudity.” Adam Yauch, an owner of Oscilloscope and its Oscilloscope Pictures operation, said the proposed rating would block use of the film as an educational tool. “This is too important of a historical document to ban from classrooms,” Mr. Yauch said in a statement on Monday. “A Film Unfinished” is to open in New York on Aug. 18, and two days later in Los Angeles, before a planned national release.

headline: Waters Sought Advice on Conflict

Ryan, the rangy Republican who represents this southeastern Wisconsin district, was in full PowerPoint roll, gesturing and barking out, in staccato tones, why the nation must make major changes to Social Security and Medicare.
