He has been developing the Lambs Club restaurant in the Chatwal Hotel, off Times Square, which is due to open soon, and now he is working on another hotel restaurant, the National Bar and Dining Rooms, in the Benjamin, 557 Lexington Avenue (51st Street).

headline: Russia Declares Fire Emergencies
text: MOSCOW — President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Monday declared a state of emergency in seven regions as forest and peat bog fires raged across Russia, killing dozens and leaving thousands homeless in a heat wave that has badly hurt Moscow and many other parts of the country.

headline: Longtime Meredith Executive Leaves Suddenly
text: Jack Griffin, who served two stints in advertising and marketing jobs at the Meredith Corporation, is leaving unexpectedly. The company said on Monday that he was departing to “pursue another opportunity.”

headline: The Financial Earthquake: Finding a New Economics in the Rubble
text: Calling the recent financial crisis an “earthquake” may be a more apropos nickname than many people realize.

headline: A Call for Safety Where Broadway Meets Amsterdam
text: The intersection on the Upper West Side where Broadway and Amsterdam merge just as they cut across 71st Street has long been a danger zone. On Tuesday, 18-wheelers and Peter Pan buses heading out of the city jockeyed for position along with taxicabs, sport utility vehicles and bulldozers, while pedestrians, and even a man in an electronic wheelchair, disregarded crossing signals.

headline: Patterns: Rethinking Prostate Cancer Treatment
text: Many men given a diagnosis of prostate cancer receive intensive treatment like surgery or radiation therapy even though the cancer is unlikely to spread or to be fatal, a new study has found.

headline: The Caucus With John Harwood
text: With New York Times reporters Helene Cooper and Jackie Calmes, John Harwood discusses the country's unemployment rate, the war strategy for Afghanistan and other issues facing President Obama this week.

headline: Johnson Says Jets, Revis ‘Far Apart’ on Contract
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, spent his 15-minute interview session with reporters on Monday mostly talking about the holdout cornerback Darrelle Revis, offering little new information about the contract dispute, but used the words “far apart” to describe it.

headline: Extreme Heritage | Maison Delvaux
text: Beloved by Belgian royalty and society types for almost 200 years, the luxury leather goods purveyor Maison Delvaux is finally coming to America. This bag is a slouchier, modern take on the sleek, structured Brillant, which was originally designed in 1958 for the Brussels World’s Fair. Handmade from supple Bridon leather with 24-karat-gold-plated brass hardware, it’s available exclusively at Barneys New York for $5,600.

headline: CBS Makes a Surprise Deal With Comcast
text: In a deal that could mean hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue for CBS, the network has secured subscriber fees for its local stations from Comcast for the next 10 years.

headline: M.L.S. Falters in Concacaf Champions League
text: Major League Soccer has been relentless, and moderately successful, in chasing global acceptance. But in the major regional competition, the revamped Concacaf Champions League, M.L.S. teams have experienced embarrassing results.

headline: A Video Look at the Week’s Political Issues
text: New York Times reporters Helene Cooper and Jackie Calmes join John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC to offer insight into the week’s major issues in national politics.

headline: Two Weeks, One Stage: The Forging of a Sound
text: The band’s name, 40Twenty, has nothing to do with the John Deere 4020 family-farm tractor, extraordinary long-range vision or the numerical code for smoking marijuana. It’s a Brooklyn jazz group with the trombonist Jacob Garchik, the pianist Jacob Sacks, the bassist Dave Ambrosio and the drummer Vinnie Sperrazza. The name refers to the 40-20 set, a grueling 1950s nightclub-booking practice in which jazz groups played up to five 40-minute sets a night, separated by 20-minute breaks.

headline: Pakistan Vies With Islamists to Aid Flood Victims
text: Five years after Islamic charities with ties to militant groups aided victims of a deadly earthquake in Pakistan, earning good will as the country’s government struggled to respond, reports suggest that the same scenario may be unfolding again.

headline: Taking Over a Tree to Save Community Gardens
text: A woman dressed as a sunflower climbed more than 20 feet into a tree in City Hall Park on Monday morning and said she would not come down unless the city agreed to make all community gardens permanent. After a short period of time, however, she descended and was taken into custody by the police.

headline: Pakistanis’ Anger Grows as Flood Damage Mounts
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The damage from Pakistan’s worst floods in generations mounted on Monday as rescue operations continued and public fury rose in the country’s most volatile province.

headline: Feeding Dementia Patients With Dignity
text: First Alzheimer’s disease stole Rosemary DeFelice’s speech, mobility and independence. Then, at 75, she lost the ability to eat.

headline: Screening: Cholesterol Checks for Young Adults
text: Young adults tend to be notoriously lax about preventive health care, and cholesterol screening is no exception. Barely half of all young men and women are screened for high LDL, the so-called bad cholesterol, a new study has found.

headline: Be Sure Exercise Is All You Get at the Gym
text: When you go to the gym, do you wash your hands before and after using the equipment? Bring your own regularly cleaned mat for floor exercises? Shower with antibacterial soap and put on clean clothes immediately after your workout? Use only your own towels, razors, bar soap, water bottles?

headline: Avoiding Germs at the Gym
text: In the latest Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores the dermatological perils lurking on exercise equipment, and in health club showers and locker rooms.

headline: Patients Want Patent Broken on Genzyme Drug
text: Updated: Three patients with a rare genetic disease are asking the federal government to abrogate the exclusive patent rights held by the biotechnology company Genzyme on the only drug now approved to treat the illness.

headline: Childbirth: Respiratory Distress in Premature Infants
text: Babies born six weeks prematurely are 40 times as likely as full-term infants to suffer respiratory distress syndrome, a new study reports.

headline: Justice Is Blind, but Its Nose Rules for the Plaintiff
text: Nineteen pages into a ruling on an insurance case, a federal judge did not actually declare that the defendant’s claim — that odors from a restaurant should be considered pollution — stank. The way Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald put it was, that argument was “malodorous to this court.”

headline: Justin Bieber, 16, 2 Write Memoir
text: If anything can turn young people on to reading, it might be a memoir by the teenage pop superstar Justin Bieber, below. In October HarperCollins will release “Justin Bieber: First Step 2 Forever: My Story,” the publisher announced on Monday. “Between the behind-the-scenes pictures and the story, I think this is going to be something they can all enjoy,” Mr. Bieber, 16, said in a statement. “This is just another way for me to say thank you to my fans.” HarperCollins described the book as an “illustrated memoir” that will detail Mr. Bieber’s rise to stardom, complemented by exclusive photos  “a must-have for fans afflicted with Bieber-fever.” “All kidding aside,” predicted Publishers Weekly, “it’s going to sell a million-billion copies.”

headline: Lindsay Lohan Out of Jail, Into Rehab
text: On her previous trip to the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif., in 2007, Lindsay Lohan was incarcerated for just under 90 minutes after arrests for drunken driving and cocaine possession. On a return visit, she was there only slightly longer: The Associated Press reported that Ms. Lohan, the 24-year-old “Mean Girls” and “Freaky Friday” star, was released from the jail on Monday at 1:35 a.m. Pacific time, having been jailed for less than two weeks of a 90-day sentence for violating the terms of her probation. The A.P. said Ms. Lohan would have to fulfill the rest of her sentence at a rehabilitation center. On July 20 she surrendered herself in the Beverly Hills courtroom of Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court, having missed a May parole hearing stemming from the 2007 arrests and after a court-ordered monitoring device detected the presence of alcohol.

headline: Want Instant Replay in Baseball? Try the Little League World Series
text: Little League World Series officials announced Monday that their instant replay system — in place for the past two years to cover mostly home runs or other close outfield-fence calls — would be expanded this year and managers would be allowed to challenge calls on forceouts, tags, missed bases and hit batsmen.

headline: Boon for Broad Museum: Millions From Developers
text: The Los Angeles financier Eli Broad may get millions of dollars back on the $100 million museum he is planning to build as part of the Grand Avenue Project, a development of condos, cultural sites, stores, offices and a hotel in downtown Los Angeles. According to The Los Angeles Times, a deal approved last month by the Community Redevelopment Agency of Los Angeles calls for Mr. Broad’s museum to receive millions of dollars as the Grand Avenue Project moves forward. The redevelopment agency requires developers  in this case Related Companies  to pay 1 percent of their projects’ design and construction costs to create public artworks or support cultural sites in the neighborhood where they build. The deal, which was approved on July 15, includes the Broad Collection at Grand Avenue and Second Street as the cultural site that will fulfill a large part of Related Companies’ percent-for-art obligation. If the Grand Avenue Project costs its estimated $3 billion, the 1 percent requirement would generate $30 million for arts and culture, and Mr. Broad’s museum would receive about a third of that under the plan approved last month.

headline: From Allies to Rivals to Allies in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  It is the political relationship that has long mystified Indonesia’s chattering classes, one whose ups and downs regularly send tremors throughout the capital, and one whose future is intricately tied to this country’s.

headline: Oscilloscope Appealing ‘Film Unfinished’ Rating
text: Oscilloscope Laboratories said it planned to appeal an R rating assigned by the Classification and Rating Administration to the Holocaust documentary “A Film Unfinished” (a scene, above). The documentary, which screened at the Sundance Film Festival this year, dissects a Nazi propaganda film that was shot in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1942. In assigning an R rating, which requires viewers under the age of 17 to be accompanied by an adult, the ratings board cited “disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities, including graphic nudity.” Adam Yauch, an owner of Oscilloscope and its Oscilloscope Pictures operation, said the proposed rating would block use of the film as an educational tool. “This is too important of a historical document to ban from classrooms,” Mr. Yauch said in a statement on Monday. “A Film Unfinished” is to open in New York on Aug. 18, and two days later in Los Angeles, before a planned national release.

headline: Bush to Promote Book in NBC Interviews
text: Former President George W. Bush’s first one-on-one television interview in nearly two years will take place on NBC in early November, the network said on Monday. Matt Lauer will interview Mr. Bush on a prime-time broadcast on Nov. 8, one day before Mr. Bush’s book, “Decision Points,” is to be released by Crown Publishers. Mr. Lauer will also interview Mr. Bush live on the “Today” show, the country’s highest-rated morning show, on Nov. 10. The meetings will probably garner wide attention, given that Mr. Bush has largely stayed out of the public eye since leaving office in January 2009. He has a family connection to the “Today” show: his daughter Jenna Bush Hager has been a contributing correspondent since last year.

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Supreme
text: “Big Brother” helped lift CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday night, while the CBS newsmagazine “60 Minutes” delivered the largest audience in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.8 million viewers tuned in at 7 for CBS’s “60 Minutes.” “Big Brother” finished close behind at 8, with 7.1 million viewers, while reruns of “Undercover Boss” (6 million) and “The Good Wife” (4.1 million) helped CBS maintain a strong enough average for the night, outperforming new episodes of ABC’s “Scoundrels” at 9 (3.2 million) and “The Gates” at 10 (2.8 million). ABC was second, boosted by solid ratings for a repeat of “America’s Funniest Home Videos” at 7 (6.2 million). NBC was third, and Fox ranked fourth with reruns of its comedy lineup.

headline: Royal Shakespeare Company’s New York Slate
text: “King Lear” and “Antony and Cleopatra,” two Shakespeare plays not frequently produced in New York City, will be among the five productions that the Royal Shakespeare Company will mount at the Lincoln Center Festival next summer, the organizers announced on Monday. The other plays will be “As You Like It,” “Romeo and Juliet” and “The Winter’s Tale.” Actors in the company’s 44-member ensemble will play various roles in the productions, with 7 to 10 performances scheduled for each piece. The entire run, July 6 to Aug. 14, will be at the Park Avenue Armory on a thrust stage (with seats on three sides) that the Royal Shakespeare Company is building now to the specifications of its Courtyard Theater in Stratford-upon-Avon. All five plays are currently running at the company’s home base in England. Among the lead actors will be the veteran company member Greg Hicks  playing two mad kings, Lear and Leontes in “The Winter’s Tale”  and Kathryn Hunter, who will play Cleopatra and the Fool in “Lear.” (Above, Mr. Hicks and Ms. Hunter in “Lear.”) The timing for ticket sales to the public is to be announced in the fall.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: The struggle against time and nature continues in northwest Pakistan, where the worst monsoon rains in the country’s history have left soldiers and emergency workers fighting to reach those threatened by rising waters.

headline: A Snapshot of a Generation May Come Out Blurry
text: Trying to pin down the character of a generation is a controversial and, some say, presumptuous exercise. Who’s to say whether 50 million Americans should be called the Me Generation, or the Greatest? Who’s to decide exactly when Gen X ends and Gen Y begins?

headline: Is Every Generation Self-Absorbed?
text: The latest Mind column by Benedict Carey explores a fascinating debate about the psychological traits of “Generation Y,” the current crop of 20- and 30-year-olds who are often described as self-absorbed and narcissistic.

headline: Not on the Doctor’s Checklist, but Touch Matters
text: A new patient comes to my office, a healthy middle-aged woman. The medical assistant has already documented her normal blood pressure. Of our allotted 15 minutes, I spend more than two-thirds talking with her.

headline: Africa: In a Meningitis Hotbed, a New Vaccine at a Price Governments Can Afford
text: In Africa’s “meningitis belt”  25 countries along the bottom edge of the Sahara from Senegal to Ethiopia  epidemics arrive with the dry harmattan winds in March. In the worst years, meningitis has killed more than 25,000 people and left thousands more deaf or retarded.

headline: Mahler and Strauss Keep Conductors (but Not Levine) Busy
text: LENOX, Mass.  This was to have been another weekend of hectic triumph for James Levine here at the Tanglewood Festival, in what increasingly emerges as a ridiculously overcrowded schedule for someone in dubious health.

headline: On the Road | Dallas Eats
text: A recent trip to Dallas to report on a new show at the Dallas Theater Center also turned into an opportunity to sample a range of what the city has to offer the hungry traveler. Here, a few standout restaurants.

headline: Rumors in Astrophysics Spread at Light Speed
text: Dimitar Sasselov, an astrophysicist at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, lit up the Internet last month with a statement that would stir the soul of anyone who ever dreamed of finding life or another home in the stars.

headline: Citing Tests, E.P.A. Says It Was Wise to Use Oil Dispersant
text: Spraying dispersants on oily water in the Gulf of Mexico doesn’t make the mixture any more toxic than the water was with Louisiana sweet crude alone, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday.

headline: In Restive Chinese Area, Cameras Keep Watch
text: URUMQI, China  For a street whose name suggests throwing off shackles, South Liberation Road doesn’t look like a very free place these days.

headline: The Bolshoi and the British: A Special Affection
text: LONDON  The Bolshoi Ballet’s current season at the Royal Opera House here is on an impressively grand scale: five full-length ballets, two mixed bills, full orchestra, singers, luxurious changes of cast. It’s as if American Ballet Theater’s two-month Metropolitan Opera House season were compressed into three weeks.

headline: Breast Milk Sugars Give Infants a Protective Coat
text: A large part of human milk cannot be digested by babies and seems to have a purpose quite different from infant nutrition  that of influencing the composition of the bacteria in the infant’s gut.

headline: Canada’s Kinross to Buy Red Back for $7.1 Billion
text: Kinross Gold of Canada said Monday that it would acquire the shares of Red Back Mining that it does not already own, in an all-stock deal valued at $7.1 billion.

headline: Newsweek Deal Announced; Meacham Will Leave
text: Newsweek announced its own sale to Sidney Harman and said that Jon Meacham, the magazine’s editor for the past four years, was stepping down.

headline: Oil Spill Aid Is Small, but Some Companies Step Up
text: CORPORATE and individual donations after the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico have paled in comparison to responses to other disasters.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Plan FrontPoint Spinoff
text: Morgan Stanley is planning to spin off FrontPoint Partners, the Greenwich, Conn., hedge fund it bought in 2006, CNBC reports, citing unidentified people familiar with the situation.

headline: Gay Men Condemn Blood Ban as Biased
text: For most people, donating blood is as simple as rolling up a sleeve. But not for gay men. Since 1983, the Food and Drug Administration has barred them from donating.

headline: Making Friends Aloft, With Meatballs as the Icebreaker
text: A FEW years ago, I left a three-decade career running clothing companies to follow my dream. I always wanted to head a company based on the recipe for meatballs my Grandma Anna taught me how to make when I just was 15 years old.

headline: Why It Still Feels Like a Recession
text: Are you one of the many Americans who thinks the recession isn’t over? Alan Greenspan feels your pain.

headline: Summer Must-Read for Kids? Any Book
text: Has your child cracked a book this summer?

headline: Why Is Deflation Bad?
text: A number of readers have asked me to explain why deflation is a bad thing; and the truth is that while I’ve alluded to the issue a number of times, I’m not sure if I’ve ever laid out the whole case. So here goes.

headline: With a Glimmer of a Chance, Stardust Is Identified
text: Three specks of matter captured by the NASA spacecraft Stardust may be stardust that has just entered our solar system.

headline: More Fake ‘Mad Men'; More Real Ads
text: The fact that Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, the new agency on “Mad Men,” has landed the Pond’s cold cream account is not the only ad news to come out of “Mad Men” this week. AMC, the cable channel that presents the series about the ad industry — and America — in the 1960s has made a deal with a giant marketer, Unilever, for a season-long sponsorship agreement.

headline: Sisterhood? Still Powerful, if a Bit Stressed
text: HARTFORD  “I don’t believe in anything but myself” were the first words sung on the main stage of the Lilith Fair revival tour, which arrived at the Comcast Theater here on Sunday. They came from “Soldier,” by Ingrid Michaelson, the soundtrack-friendly folkie from Staten Island, and they encapsulated the Lilith worldview established during the tour’s initial run from 1997 to 1999: direct, empowered, emotive, a little sullen.

headline: 99 Weeks Later, Jobless Have Only Desperation
text: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  Facing eviction from her Tennessee apartment after several months of unpaid rent, Alexandra Jarrin packed up whatever she could fit into her two-door coupe recently and drove out of town.

headline: World War II Still Shapes Atoll’s Ecosystem
text: I often wonder what life was like for military personnel who served on Palmyra Atoll during World War II. We see ghosts of their activities — whether abandoned buildings and ancient, odd-shaped light bulbs or structural changes to the islets and the lagoon. The military occupation there was brief, but the effects, like causeways built across the waterways, are long lasting. Some of the modifications cut off the flow of water and turned the lagoons into warm, silty bathwater, which influences what can grow and live there.

headline: King Tut’s Chariot Arrives in Times Square
text: As 18th-Dynasty pharaohs’ chariots go, the one that arrived in Times Square on Friday night was not a Mercedes or a Bentley. There was no gold leaf or fine animal-fur interior or richly appointed cartouche-ing. It was more like a teenager’s dragster stripped down for speed, just a lightweight frame of tamarisk, elm and birch, missing only its two-horsepower engine.

headline: A Hot Month, and a Record for Power Demand
text: Although July fell just short of being the hottest month in New York City history, it did set a record for energy consumption.

headline: A Different Side of Barber, in Songs and Piano Work
text: Pity the composer whose birth date falls 25, 50 or 100 years after that of a more famous predecessor: in what might otherwise be a celebratory year, neglect results. This year Chopin and Schumann, both born 200 years ago, have attracted widespread attention; among the worthy figures overshadowed is the American composer Samuel Barber, born in 1910.

headline: A Footnote Gets His Spotlight at Last
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Among worldly Europeans during the early decades of the 20th century, the Austrian composer Franz Schreker was a heroic figure, a worthy successor to Wagner and Strauss. To the Nazis, Schreker, the son of a Jewish father, was a degenerate pornographer to be censured and shunned. For Americans he became an obscure footnote, a formidable artist whose works never reached the New World.

headline: Off the Menu: Harold Dieterle Goes Thai
text: Harold Dieterle, the chef at Perilla,  is renovating the space that had been Philippe Chow Express to turn it into Kin Shop, for contemporary Thai fare in a casual setting.

headline: Burnished Tones Evoke Ravel and Others in a Candlelit Room
text: “We prefer our audiences to be intoxicated,” the Canadian violinist James Ehnes said before his recital at the Kaplan Penthouse on Saturday evening, part of the Mostly Mozart Festival’s Little Night Music series.

headline: Cause for Worry: A Deep Drink of Bliss, With Confusion for a Chaser
text: SALZBURG, Austria  Before the opening-night performance of Dieter Dorn’s new production of Gluck’s “Orfeo ed Euridice” at the Salzburg Festival here on Saturday, anticipation was mostly focused on the conductor, Riccardo Muti, long a favorite with festival audiences.

headline: Showalter Leads the Charge
text: BALTIMORE – Buck Showalter managed in the National League, and he heard all about St. Louis as the quintessential baseball town. In the American League, he said, its equivalent is Baltimore.

headline: Sensuous and Serious Tango
text: On Sunday night I took the No. 7 train to Willets Point and walked through Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, past the giant Unisphere constructed for the 1964-65 World’s Fair, to the Queens Theater in the Park, where the Chase Latino Cultural Festival was presenting its fourth show this year. The Unisphere is a Queens landmark; I’m embarrassed to admit that this was my first view of it.

headline: Rodriguez’s Waiting Game
text: On July 25, 2007, Alex Rodriguez hit home run No. 499 off Gil Meche in Kansas City. On Aug. 4, 2007, Alex Rodriguez hit home run No. 500 off Kyle Davies of the Royals inNew York.

headline: No E-Books Allowed in This Establishment
text: A few weeks ago I decided to mosey over to a local Manhattan coffee shop for an afternoon cappuccino.

headline: Royal Shakespeare Company Announces New York Lineup
text: “King Lear” and “Antony and Cleopatra,” two Shakespeare plays that are not frequently produced in New York City, will be among the five productions that the Royal Shakespeare Company will mount in next summer’s Lincoln Center Festival, the organizers announced on Monday.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Foreign Correspondent'
text: A. O. Scott discusses Alfred Hitchcock's "Foreign Correspondent," an unusual celebration of America's lack of seriousness.

headline: Tracing Oil Reserves to Their Tiny Origins
text: In 1913, as the automobile zoomed into American life, The Outing Magazine gave its readers a bit of background on what fueled the new motorcars in “The Story of Gasoline.” After a brief vignette describing the death of “old Colonel Stegosaurus Ungulatus,” the article explained that “yesterday you poured the remains of the dinosaur from a measuring-can — which, let us hope, held five gallons, full measure — into your gasoline tank.”

headline: Audit Finds Problems in Cattlemen’s Spending
text: An influential cattle industry group misused money raised from ranchers and farmers for promoting beef sales and violated federal rules by spending some of it to support lobbying activities, according to an outside financial review.

headline: Zhao Holds Small Lead in Women’s Chess Grand Prix
text: With her second consecutive win, and third in four games, Zhao Xue of China leads the tournament in Mongolia, though three rivals are close behind.

headline: Increasing Returns And Economic Areography
text: Increasing Returns and Economic Geography (pdf) was, I think, my best academic paper; economists apparently think so too, putting it at the top of the list on Google Scholar. Now Charlie Stross, my favorite contemporary science fiction author, takes on the issue of increasing returns and their implications for, among other things, the possibility or lack thereof of space colonization:

headline: Filling the Science Communication Gap
text: I was recently invited to contribute an essay to a special issue of the journal Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment summarizing a conference on communication and environmental controversies held at the Cary Institute for Ecosystem Studies last year. My piece focuses on the responsibility of scientists to jump into the communication breach that’s being created as specialized journalism shrinks. The issue has just been published online. Here’s the core paragraph of my piece:

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Foreign Correspondent’
text: Is the person best suited to deal with a crisis someone who knows very little about it and cares even less? A. O. Scott seeks the answer to this question in this week’s pick, “Foreign Correspondent.” Alfred Hitchcock‘s 1940 film centers on an American reporter Joel McCrea sent to Europe on the brink of World War II. For a movie about characters caught up in a global catastrophe, Mr. Scott says it is “a lot of fun. But it’s never simply escapist.” Have you seen “Foreign Correspondent?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Connecting Brains to the Outside World
text: About four years ago, John Donoghue’s son, Jacob, then 18, took his father aside and declared, “Dad, I now understand what you do — you’re ‘The Matrix’!” Dr. Donoghue, 61, is a professor of engineering and neuroscience at Brown University, studying how human brain signals could combine with modern electronics to help paralyzed people gain greater control over their environments. He’s designed a machine, the BrainGate, that uses thought to move objects. We spoke for two hours in his Brown University offices in Providence, R.I., and then again by telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows:

headline: Russian Billionaires Battle Over Norilsk Nickel
text: A feud between Russian billionaires threatens to destabilize Norilsk Nickel, one of the world’s largest mining companies. The fallout could result in a major change of control at the company, leading to further consolidation in Russia’s powerful natural resource sector.

headline: An All-Oil Diet
text: Q. How does the metabolism of oil-eating bacteria break down oil? And how do they survive when no oil is available?

headline: Midwest Seismic Zone Became Frozen in Time
text: A ferocious swarm of earthquakes shook the center of the United States two centuries ago, and it remains a mystery how such strong temblors could have occurred there, in the middle of the North American tectonic plate where the ground ought to be stable.

headline: It’s About the Money, Not the Frequent Flier
text: YOU want frequent-flier miles? Well, step right up, ladies and gentlemen, because the airlines and the banks that issue the airlines’ credit cards have got some deals for you.

headline: The Evolution of Sonoma Coast Chardonnay
text: CALIFORNIA chardonnays are not nearly what they once were. This makes me very happy.

headline: U.N. Forms Review Panel for Israeli Raid on Flotilla
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, announced Monday the formation of a panel to look into the deadly Israeli raid on a Turkish-led aid flotilla bound for Gaza in May.

headline: For Data, Tug Grows Over Privacy vs. Security
text: The threat by the United Arab Emirates to shut down mobile services on BlackBerrys like e-mail and text messaging underscores a growing tension between communications companies and governments over how to balance privacy with national security.

headline: Have Republicans Learned Their Lesson?
text: That’s the subject taken up in an American Spectator symposium, which is divided, roughly speaking, between writers who think the Republicans have become serious about limited government again and writers who think they haven’t. Not surprisingly, I incline toward the latter camp: There may be specific Republicans (a Paul Ryan, a Chris Christie, a Mitch Daniels) who are committed to spending restraint in practice as well as theory, but the party as a whole is still more eager to posture about earmarks than to wrestle with entitlements. Most Republicans talk a good game about America’s looming fiscal crisis, but then dance away when the subjects turns to what, specifically, they want to do about it.

headline: Dove Ad
text: AMC has made a deal with a giant marketer, Unilever, for a season-long sponsorship agreement centered on six commercials being created in the Mad Men vein.

headline: Rocket Strikes Jordanian Resort
text: New York Times reporter Stephen Farrell reports on a mysterious rocket that landed in front of the InterContinental Hotel in  Aqaba, Jordan.

headline: G.E. and Intel Form Health Venture
text: General Electric and Intel said on Monday that they had formed a joint venture to create products for patients with chronic diseases and for elderly people at home or in assisted living.

headline: Earnings at HSBC and BNP Lift Banks
text: LONDON  HSBC and BNP Paribas reported higher earnings on Monday as a result of declines in provisions for bad loans. The reports set a positive backdrop for other European banks poised to report their earnings this week.

headline: Losses Signal Gains at HSBC
text: Fewer losses coupled with growth in certain areas helped the bank double its first-half earnings from 2009.

headline: Chinese Carmaker Geely Completes Acquisition of Volvo From Ford
text: The Chinese carmaker Zhejiang Geely Holding Group completed the acquisition of Volvo from Ford Motor on Monday and named a chief executive to lead the company.

headline: Scott McNealy on Nonprofits and Bailouts
text: Scott McNealy, a founder of Sun Microsystems, is not shy. In the past, he’s opined on putting tracking chips between the shoulder blades of children, birth control in the McNealy household, and Microsoft’s similarities to a heroin dealer.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,199 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Cheating Inquiry in Atlanta Largely Vindicates Schools
text: ATLANTA  The Atlanta public school system was substantially vindicated Monday when the results of an independent investigation into cheating on standardized tests were released.

headline: Space Station Repair Work Is Scheduled
text: With research on the International Space Station curtailed to save power, two astronauts are scheduled to venture out early Friday to begin repairs on a cooling system.

headline: U.S. Puts Oil Spill Total at Nearly 5 Million Barrels
text: NEW ORLEANS — Nearly five million barrels of oil have gushed from the BP’s well since the Deepwater Horizon spill began on April 20, federal scientists said on Monday in announcing the most precise estimates yet of the well’s flow rate. The estimates would make this spill far bigger than the 3.3 million barrels spilled by the Mexican rig Ixtoc I in 1979, previously believed to be the world’s largest accidental release of oil.

headline: Challenges Await Sanofi as Genzyme Talks Begin

headline: ‘Law & Order’ Probably Doesn’t Like You
text: Nothing personal. But now that Dick Wolf’s “Law & Order” has called it a day — or rather a 20-year run — it is time to notice what may be its most remarkable feature; not the brilliant formula that offers both the comfort of predictability and the promise of constant surprise (an episode almost never ends up where it seems to be going at the beginning), not the ability of the show to survive major cast changes without missing a beat, not the considerable accomplishment of making the arcane vocabulary of the law ( “fruit of the poisonous tree,” “asked and answered,” “prejudicial,” “allocute,” “goes to relevance”) as familiar to TV viewers as the jargon of sports, but the extraordinarily long list of professions, classes and category of persons it doesn’t like.

headline: In Praise of the Broken Home
text: My childhood home broke in half during the autumn of 1973, when my twin sister and I were 10 years old. Our parents called us together one evening to announce that they were splitting up, and just like that we became “products of a broken home.” The scene still flickers in my mind: my sister and I sat between our two parents on a monstrous neo-Victorian couch upholstered in a weird, synthetic shade of pink. Everybody cried.

headline: Bernanke Says Rising Wages Will Lift Spending

headline: Political Ads Off Limits, Goldman Promises
text: Facing pressure from critics of Wall Street to limit its role in elections, Goldman Sachs has pledged not to spend any of its vast corporate reserves on political advertising.

headline: Fifteen Buyers File Lawsuit Against Trump SoHo Project
text: A group of 15 buyers at the Trump SoHo Hotel Condominium New York is suing groups and individuals behind the project, contending that they inflated sales figures in the first year and a half of marketing the project.

headline: Restaurants Call Health Web Site Unfair
text: The new requirement that New York City’s 24,000 restaurants prominently display letter grades for cleanliness has provoked dire predictions that would-be customers will flee when they see a big green B or dreaded yellow C in the window.

headline: Kashmir: More Deadly Protests Over Disputed Region
text: The toll of a deadly summer of angry protest in the disputed Kashmir region rose to at least 33 people after a bloody weekend in which security forces fired on stone-throwing protesters, officials said Monday. After a two-week lull, demonstrations began anew last week against what many Kashmiris see as the Indian occupation of part of the region. The Indian state’s top elected official, Omar Abdullah, rushed to New Delhi on Monday to consult with government leaders about how to quell the violence. Political leaders and human rights groups have accused security forces of using excessive violence against civilians.

headline: China: 11 Die in Attack by Man Driving Shovel Loader
text: An enraged man drove a shovel loader through shops and over cars at a coal depot in northeast China on Sunday, killing 11 people and injuring 17 more, officials in Yuanshi County of Hebei Province said Monday. The man, Li Xianliang, 38, had been drinking when he killed a customer at the Hongyuan coal depot, then drove his loader down a nearby road, ripping buildings and vehicles before being stopped an hour later in an open field, the officials said. A government statement offered no motive for his acts. China has been on edge this summer following a series of rampages, including several attacks on schoolchildren by knife-wielding men. The attacks have drawn attention to lapses in the treatment of mentally ill people.

headline: Nepal: Third Failure in Parliament to Elect a Premier
text: Nepal’s Parliament failed to elect a new prime minister for the third time on Monday as a large number of lawmakers remained neutral and neither of the two runoff candidates got a majority of votes. Prime Minister Madhav Kumar Nepal resigned June 30, but neither the Maoist leader, Pushpa Kamal Dahal, known as Prachanda, or the leader of the Nepali Congress Party, Ram Chandra Poudel, has been able to get 300 votes in the current 599-member Parliament. A date for the next runoff vote was under discussion.

headline: Giants’ Linebackers Have Plenty to Prove
text: ALBANY  There is Keith Bulluck, and there is everyone else. These are the Giants linebackers, Version 2010, perhaps the most intriguing and important unit on a defense in desperate need of repair.

headline: China: Mao’s Grandson Gets Army Promotion
text: The 40-year-old grandson of Mao Zedong has been elevated to major general from senior colonel in the People’s Liberation Army, making him one of the youngest ever to achieve that rank, the Communist Party-run newspaper Global Times reported Monday. The grandson, Mao Xinyu, left, is a researcher at the Academy of Military Sciences, a secretive army research institute. His grandfather founded the army in 1927, led the 1949 revolution, and ruled with cultlike authority for the next 37 years. An academy spokesman, Bao Guojun, was quoted as saying the promotion was “a natural elevation” based on General Mao’s many achievements.

headline: Even Without Homers, Rodriguez Has Been Driving in Runs
text: There were 47,034 people watching Alex Rodriguez attempt to hit his 600th home run Monday night and about as many theories why it has eluded him.

headline: China: Police Break Up Protest After Hundreds Support TV Network’s Use of Cantonese
text: Police officers in Guangzhou, the capital of Guangdong Province, broke up a protest on Sunday by hundreds of people who had gathered to demonstrate against a proposal by politicians to change the programming language on a local television network, according the Web site of the Guangzhou Public Security Bureau. The protesters were defending the use of Cantonese, the local language, in the programming on Guangzhou Television against a proposal to increase the use of Mandarin, the official language of China. Protesters in Hong Kong, where Cantonese is also spoken, held their own protest as a show of solidarity on Sunday.

Only a transparent and credible inquiry has a chance of calming international outrage over the incident and beginning to repair fractured Israeli-Turkish ties.

headline: A-List Bankers Not Fleeing the Street, Just Crossing It
text: It’s been a miserable few years for investment banks, writes Fortune. Along with the “epochal meltdowns, shotgun marriages, a federal pay czar, congressional investigations, reform legislation, and S.E.C. lawsuits,” has been an exodus of talent. But rather than flee Wall Street altogether, some bankers are simply crossing it to small boutique firms.

text: The beers are cold, the water off the harbor is warm (we hope), and the movies are not your standard fare.Amsterdam’s popular Pluk de Nacht, which runs from Aug. 5 to 15 with a series of open-air screenings, is quite possibly the most laid-back film festival you’ll find anywhere.

text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea warned South Korean fishermen on Tuesday to stay away from disputed border waters and threatened a “strong physical retaliation” against a coming South Korean naval drills.

text: Today’s idea: Contrary to popular wisdom, Afghanistan is not the “graveyard of empires,” an article says. Centuries of history show it was often more like the cradle of conquest.

text: Freddie Mac on Monday named a company insider, Jerry Weiss, to its newly created position of chief administrative officer, The Associated Press reported.

text: Adani Enterprises has agreed to buy an Australian coal asset from Linc Energy for 500 million Australian dollars ($456 million). On Monday, Linc Energy confirmed it was in “very well advanced” talks with the Indian coal importer.

text: Until last May, Kenneth I. Starr, the man indicted for defrauding celebrities in a modest but notorious Ponzi scheme, who is now languishing in a Manhattan jail, was always so upbeat, Vanity Fair says in a profile published Tuesday.

text: Charlie Sheen avoided jail time and was instead given a sentence Monday by a Colorado judge that included 30 days in a rehabilitation facility after pleading guilty to a misdemeanor third-degree assault on his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, The Associated Press reported. The charges faced by Mr. Sheen, a star of the hit CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men,” stemmed from a Christmas Day altercation in Aspen with Ms. Sheen; asked by Pitkin County District Judge James Boyd why he was pleading guilty, The A.P. reported, Mr. Sheen replied: “Because I’m guilty, your honor.”

headline: For the World’s Ills, ‘Trickle Up’ Solutions

headline: Off the Menu: Niko, Sushi With Pedigree
text: The space at 170 Mercer Street (West Houston Street) in SoHo that had a devoted following as Honmura An will remain Japanese but become Niko in the fall. The sushi chef, Hiro Sawatari, was at Sushi Yasuda, and he will be working with a consultant, Trevor Corson, a writer and teacher who specializes in sushi. The more substantial fare on the non-sushi side of the menu will be the responsibility of Raj Dixit, who worked at Bouley and the Ryland Inn. Cobi Levy is the chief operating partner and Ben Leventhal, of NBC’s The Feast food blog is a shareholder.

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Be Looking Into Potential Insider Trading at BP

headline: Will Ferrell to Take On ‘A Little Night Music’? That’s Rich.
text: Could someone kindly forward Will Ferrell a copy of Charles Isherwood’s review of the newly recast Broadway production of “A Little Night Music”? On the same day that Mr. Isherwood described Bernadette Peters‘s performance of “Send In the Clowns” as “an indelible moment in the history of musical theater,” Mr. Ferrell goes on David Letterman’s “Late Show” to announce (jokingly) that he will be taking over from Catherine Zeta-Jones in the role of Desirée Armfeldt. (Never mind that Ms. Zeta-Jones finished her run in June, or that Mr. Ferrell was last seen impersonating a human vuvuzela on the ESPY Awards.)

headline: On Our Radar: Blocking BP’s Write-Off

headline: Return Engagement | Camelot
text: In an extreme case of camel coat envy, a frustrated New York socialite who had long fetishized the trench coat Ali MacGraw wore in ‘‘Love Story’’ engaged a patternmaker last year to copy it in caramel cashmere, down to the patch pockets and double-wide lapel and collar (which, like MacGraw’s character, Jenny, you gotta wear popped). From Paris to New York, from Kate Moss to Blake Lively (who seem to be as attached to their fawn-colored coats as Grace Kelly and Katharine Hepburn were to theirs), camel is dans l’air this fall. Céline’s Phoebe Philo jump-started the trend last spring with the ultimate boyfriend coat, a honey-toned Crombie. Jean Paul Gaultier — in his penultimate, fall collection for Hermès — showed a three-quarter camel coat pinched from the guys, saving his most luxurious discursion for duffel coats like the ones once worn by the British Royal Navy. Michael Kors imagined a gender mix-up at the coat check, or maybe that blushingly erotic moment when a gentleman slips his camel coat over his date’s chilly shoulders. If it’s all beginning to sound like a male conspiracy, well, a lot of women’s outerwear in the buff register does lead back to the blokes. Think of the peacoat — and the polo coat. Around 1900, polo players began wrapping themselves in camel ‘‘wait coats’’ — patterned, essentially, on a dressing gown — to keep warm between chukkers. Later, women borrowed freely of the details: half belt, full cut, chest pocket. In 1949 the camel coat was the American coed’s favorite. Kors made winking reference to all that history, pairing a great big muff of a fur skirt with a camel knit tee. Among the other camel offerings were satin blouses and high-waisted slacks (Chloé), even a strapless dress (Gianfranco Ferré). But in the end, it was the camel coat that scored, whether sable-trimmed at Carolina Herrera or sleeveless at Alexander Wang. A real love story.

headline: BMW Celebrates New Classic Center With First Restoration
text: The BMW CS, produced from 1968 to 1975 and known internally as the E9 (or to its many ardent admirers, simply “the coupe”) is often mentioned among the most beautiful BMWs ever built. It also ranks among the most delicate. Rust goblins gorged on its lithe body and undercarriage even in dry climates. Engines powered by carburetors protested violently under cold starts. Even so, the CS’s cult, next to that of the 2002 coupe, is fiercely dedicated.

headline: When (and Why) Adoption Goes Awry

It started out well — with newly painted rooms, closets full of new clothes, a new school, new toys and a big sister. Then came months of discipline problems, lack of attachment, violence, stealing, lying and fear.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Bosom Buddies
text: In 1913, the provocateur Marcel Duchamp created a ruckus at the New York Armory Show with his ‘‘Nude Descending a Staircase (No. 2).’’ The painting didn’t go down well; apparently nudes don’t use staircases, they’re busy lolling on divans or dancing with seven veils. Looking at ‘‘Nude’’ today (in the Philadelphia Museum of Art), the Samurai Shopper sees nothing R-rated, just a fractured maze of lines and planes. What’s naked is Duchamp’s ambition to shock the stuffed shirts.

headline: ‘Inception’ to Materialize in China
text: Having topped the United Space box office list, burned out brain cells and tied up Twitter feeds for the past three weeks, the Christopher Nolan mind caper “Inception” has earned another rare distinction: it will be one of only 20 foreign-made blockbusters that China will allow to be shown at its movie theaters this year, The Associated Press reported. The government-owned China Film Group told The A.P. that “Inception” will be one of the few non-domestically produced films that it annually imports and for which it shares ticket revenues with the studio that produced it. (The company also buys smaller foreign films for flat fees.)

headline: Stuck on 599 Laughs

The first is trying to count where we are in Alex Rodriguez’s tortured quest for home run No. 600 (officially, 11 games, 43 at-bats, 527 A-Rod face crinkles). The second is counting the number of cameras pointed at Jets Coach Rex Ryan’s stomach at training camp, which are trying to detect some sign that he actually had weight-loss surgery. And the third is the ridiculous standoff over the Redskins’ Albert Haynesworth’s inability to pull his ample midsection through a conditioning test.

headline: Me and the Bond Market
text: Whenever I point out that bond markets are not, in fact, demanding immediate fiscal austerity, I get comments along the lines of “So now you believe markets are perfect?” That’s missing the point. The starting point for the argument people like me make is that markets shouldn’t be demanding immediate austerity, because the long-run fiscal effects of short-run deficits are relatively small; the burden of proof is therefore on the other side to show that markets will demand something they shouldn’t.

headline: ‘Millennium’-Plus: A Stieg Larsson Boxed Set
text: Forget about that unpublished, almost-finished fourth manuscript. The next Stieg Larsson volume is a collection that includes essays about Mr. Larsson and e-mails between Mr. Larsson and his publisher, Eva Gedin. The volume, called “On Stieg Larsson,” will be released by Knopf as part of a boxed set including the best-selling “Millennium” trilogy, which began with “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” then was followed by “The Girl Who Played With Fire” and “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest.” According to Knopf, the new book will include an essay by John-Henri Holmberg, a member of the Swedish Crime Fiction Academy, “placing Stieg Larsson in the context of the resurgence of Scandinavian crime writing,” and an essay by Svante Weyler, the publishing director from Mr. Larsson’s publisher in Sweden, about the phenomenon surrounding Mr. Larsson. The boxed set, priced at $99, will go on sale the day after Thanksgiving — also known as the start of the holiday shopping season.

headline: Between Queens and Brooklyn, an Oil Spill’s Legacy

headline: I’m With the Bland | Montreal’s Backstage Feast
text: One might think that rock bands are fed like kings backstage, but the reality is more like a tuna wrap and a bowl of M&M’s. This weekend at the Osheaga Festival in Montreal, however, the National, Arcade Fire, Beach House, Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros et al. were treated to a feast: the artists’ area was catered by Chuck Hughes, the chef at the city’s Garde Manger restaurant and host of the Cooking Channel’s “Chuck’s Day Off.” Highlights on the menu — which I sampled as the guest of my husband, the Walkmen‘s Walter Martin — included pulled-pork tacos, jerk crab, smoked chicken (cooked in a 50-foot smoker) and a poutine bar where guests could customize the classic Québécois dish. Salads were made to order, with options including pea shoots snipped from the plant, golden beets, prosciutto and poached asparagus. Bands took advantage of the full raw bar with oysters shucked on the spot and scallops on the half shell. Beach House dug the smoothie station, and fried Mars bars were a hit as Arcade Fire was getting ready to play Saturday night. Meals are usually a to-be-avoided part of backstage life, but these bands lingered at picnic tables under twinkling lanterns. The vote was unanimous that this was the best catering ever.

headline: Russian Billionaire Stands Firm on Norilsk Nickel

headline: Afghan War Is Being Lost, Pakistani President Says
text: LONDON — On the eve of an official visit to Britain, Pakistan’s president, Asif Ali Zardari, was quoted in a French newspaper on Tuesday as saying that coalition forces were losing the war in Afghanistan because they had “lost the battle to win hearts and minds” of Afghans, and that the Taliban’s success lay “in knowing how to wait” for NATO forces to withdraw.

headline: ‘Mentor’
text: The sun set at 4:30 p.m., frost glazed our lawn each morning, and while pumpkins still rested on our neighborhood's front porches I completed "Book One" of my novel. Instinctively, I knew I'd reached its midpoint. Its scope could no longer be enlarged, no characters added. Conflicts would now be resolved, not developed. As always, I'd tracked how much time I'd written, and how many words I'd produced daily in a small, gray-covered assignment pad. In seventy-two days I'd written one hundred and fifty-three pages. Of them, Frank had read only the chapter I'd put up in workshop. One night at the Mill, where we now regularly shared a table, I told him I was burning out. "So, take a break," he said. "Slow down." I received no other advice from him. But in a literary sense, I didn't need it. His presence was all that mattered.

headline: A Writer’s Prayer, Halfway Answered
text: Every serious fiction writer, published or unpublished, has a pile of horror stories about trying to get his or her work out into the world. The funny ones are told in bars. The ones that aren’t funny — the ones that may never be funny — are told only to therapists or to the insides of medicine cabinets.

headline: London Theater Journal: Pomp and Circumstance
text: I wasn’t around for the coronation of Elizabeth II, and it seems unlikely I’ll be invited to the crowning of her successor, should that day ever arrive. So I was delighted to be able to attend the ceremonies celebrating the ascension of one Anne Boleyn as the Queen of England. Such pomp, such circumstance. The gold canopy, the procession of ecclesiastics, the charming boys’ choir. And as for young Anne herself, well, that ultimate royal fashion plate Diana, Princess of Wales, might have envied the sumptuous, megatrain-bearing dress with which the second wife of King Henry VIII has been outfitted.
