text: That great macho bit of dialogue from B-movie westerns, “Eat lead!” was humorously reprised in the movie “Back to the Future II” and in video-game form in “Eat Lead: The Return of Matt Hazard.” It derives from the centuries-old fact that virtually all ammunition for firearms is lead-based.

headline: Writhing in the Iron Grip of Opera’s Dark Siren
text: SALZBURG, Austria  From the first minutes of the Salzburg Festival’s new production of Berg’s “Lulu,” which opened here on Sunday night at the Felsenreitschule, it was clear that musical matters were in very capable hands. The German conductor Marc Albrecht drew a consistently plush, urgent and taut performance from the Vienna Philharmonic.

headline: Sky Blue F.C. and the Power of Seven
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog during the defending champions’ 2010 season.

headline: As Iraq Drawdown Nears, a Soldier Shares Hopes and Fears
text: President Obama marked the coming end of the combat mission in Iraq “as promised and on schedule” in a speech to veterans in Atlanta on Monday. As Mr. Obama outlined the drawdown of United States forces in Iraq and the changing nature of the engagement in Iraq from military to diplomatic, he noted that this new chapter in the conflict will get a new name. Operation Iraqi Freedom will become Operation New Dawn. The change is meant to be symbolic of the new, more tacit role the United States will play in Iraq’s evolving internal affairs.

headline: Before Revis, There Was Washington
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — The backdrop behind the Darrelle Revis contract stalemate centers on Leon Washington, a former Jets running back now playing in Seattle. His experience last season still resonates, quite strongly, throughout the locker room.

headline: Surfing the Webster
text: The Webster, a South Beach luxury boutique, has transformed the ground floor of the 20,000-square-foot space into a surfing-inspired pop-up store called Surf the Webster. Conceived in collaboration with Timothee Verrecchia (the editor of L’Officiel Homme and the multi-hyphenate behind such disparate ventures as the new Café Gitane at the Jane Hotel and D.J.’ing with his brother as Tim & Vass), it’s intended to educate shoppers about Florida’s surf culture.

headline: Texan Tall Tales
text: Apparently there’s a lot of discussion about the sources of the miraculous resilience of Texas in the current slump, with the usual suspects claiming that it proves the virtues of capitalism red in tooth and claw, or something.

headline: As Obama Talks Peace, Many Iraqis Are Unsure
text: BAGHDAD  The morning after President Obama spoke of bringing the war in Iraq to “a responsible end,” insurgents planted their black flag on Tuesday at a checkpoint they overran by killing the five policemen who staffed it. It was the second time in a week.

headline: At CBS, a Recovery in Local Ad Sales and a Focus on Cost Controls Bolster Results
text: Reflecting a resurgence in advertising revenue, the CBS Corporation on Tuesday reported earnings of $150.1 million in its second quarter, up from $15.4 million in the period a year earlier.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: A sense of fortitude runs through a number of images in today’s show, many of which depict individuals standing alone amid turmoil.

headline: Backman Is Poised on Top Step of the Dugout
text: Brooklyn and Queens are on the same island, which means Wally Backman can feel the tremors from out east.

headline: In Colorado, an Extraordinary Presidential Effort
text: There is no Democratic contest in the country where President Obama has weighed in as aggressively – or as frequently – as the Colorado Senate primary.First, he made telephone calls on behalf of Senator Michael Bennet. Then, he appeared in television advertisements. And on Tuesday evening, the White House said, the president will speak to voters of Colorado in a telephone town-hall-style meeting.

headline: The Broken Senate and the Energy and Climate Challenge
text: The riven Senate, with the decision today not to close out a modest package of energy initiatives focused on oil drilling, is basically saying the following: Don’t look for the vital 21st-century energy quest, let alone a reality-based approach to global warming, to begin within the borders of the United States.

headline: Honoring a Historic Team by Refusing to Copy It
text: “I am not a Billie Holiday imitator,” the jazz singer Rebecca Kilgore remarked on Monday evening at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, where she and the Harry Allen Quartet performed “Lady Day and Prez: A Musical Tribute to Billie Holiday and Lester Young.” “But if you ever did want to hear one, David Sedaris on the radio does a great imitation.”

headline: Working Moms Are Fine for Kids
text: Eight years ago, researchers at Columbia University worried a lot of new parents when they concluded that children whose mothers left home for full-time work in the first year of life were cognitively delayed compared with one-year-olds whose mothers stayed home. (No, the study did not measure the effect of working fathers.)

headline: ‘American Idol’ Switches Labels To Universal
text: More changes are afoot at “American Idol” than the shuffling of the show’s judges.

headline: Birdcalls and Other Sounds for Piano
text: “Visions de l’Amen” (1943), Messiaen’s work for two pianos, is as prismatic and astounding in its way as his “Quartet for the End of Time” (1941), a glimpse of the apocalypse crystallized as a work for clarinet, violin, cello and piano. That the scoring of “Visions” is more monochromatic scarcely matters: Messiaen approached the piano not only with an organist’s sense of sonority but also with an imagination that drew on birdcalls, Asian music (and tuning systems) and recent innovations in Western harmony, as well as his own ideas about Roman Catholic mysticism.

headline: The Good Food Awards
text: The Seedling Projects in San Francisco has created the Good Food Awards to recognize the best food makers and growers in the United.

headline: Man Arrested in Queens Subway Killing
text: Updated, 6:01 p.m. | A 19-year-old has been arrested and charged with murder in the Friday night stabbing of a man attacked by a group of people inside an elevated subway station in Queens, the police said.

headline: He Sings, He Conducts (and He’s Not Bad on the Oboe)
text: ASPEN, Colo. — Since the end of May, the bass-baritone Eric Owens has sung a major role in the modernist opera “Le Grand Macabre” with the New York Philharmonic and made 10 other appearances with major orchestras. Later this month he begins rehearsals as the scheming Alberich for a Metropolitan Opera “Ring” cycle.

headline: McCain Allows Clapper Nomination to Proceed
text: Senator John McCain released his hold Tuesday on the confirmation of James R. Clapper Jr. to become the next director of national intelligence, but it remained unclear whether that would clear the way for a vote this week before the Senate goes home for summer recess.

headline: Contest Winners Chirp, ‘Cheap! Cheap!’
text: The idea of contests for consumers to create commercials has been a popular one of late, and it shows few signs of losing its appeal — even as more contests are won by folks who either do something similar for a living or plan to.

headline: That Old-Timey Sound (It’s Good Enough for Them)
text: Abigail and Lily Chapin are daughters of the singer-songwriter Tom Chapin, who has won three Grammys for children’s albums, and nieces of the folk music star Harry Chapin.

headline: Fire, Brimstone and Sympathy: The New Drilling Czar
text: The head of the new federal agency for regulating offshore drilling would like to lift the moratorium on deep-water offshore drilling as soon as the agency is “comfortable” that enough safety improvements are in place, he told reporters on Tuesday. But he also wants stiffer penalties for companies that violate the rules and a pack of FBI agents to investigate lawbreaking in offshore drilling — including any misdeeds inside his own agency.

headline: Barnes & Noble Considers Selling Itself
text: 1:30 a.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Julie Bosman has more:

headline: Scholar Emerges From Doghouse
text: NEW HAVEN — On this hot summer day, Michael A. Bellesiles is sitting outside the abandoned red brick armory here. It is, he said, a much friendlier building than the one that occupied this spot in 1877. In the middle of what was then a working-class neighborhood northwest of Yale, the old Gothic armory, made of stone with no windows on the first floor, was meant to withstand the American precursor of a Molotov cocktail, he explained: “It was a testament to middle-class fears.”

headline: Gibbs: Mosque by Ground Zero a Local Matter
text: President Obama, who made outreach to Muslims a central theme of his first year in office, has decided to sit out the national debate now raging over the plan to build a mosque near the site of Ground Zero in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Iran’s Account of Woman’s Crime Shifting From Adultery to Murder
text: TEHRAN  Iran appears to be answering international criticism of its handling of the case of a woman sentenced to death by stoning by suggesting that she is guilty not only of adultery, but also of murder.

headline: Senator Defends New York’s New Short-Term Rental Ban
text: First Paris began cracking down on short-term vacation rentals. Now, travelers who use apartment-rental Web sites to find lodging in New York may have fewer places to choose from.

headline: Singing Along With Mitch (and Johnny)
text: After I wrote a Big City column about Mitch Miller, the music impresario and television personality who died Saturday at age 99, dozens of people wrote to share their personal memories of the man and his recordings.

headline: Charlie Sheen Sentenced
text: The actor Charlie Sheen, below, avoided jail time and was instead given a sentence on Monday by a Colorado judge that included 30 days in a rehabilitation center after pleading guilty to a misdemeanor third-degree assault on his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, The Associated Press reported. The charges faced by Mr. Sheen, a star of the CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men,” stemmed from a Christmas Day altercation in Aspen, Colo. Mr. Sheen was also sentenced to 30 days of probation and 36 hours of anger management counseling, and may not have to serve the 30 days in rehab, having already spent 93 days this year at a treatment center.

headline: ‘Millennium’ Plus: A Larsson Boxed Set
text: Forget about that unpublished, almost-finished fourth manuscript. The next Stieg Larsson volume is a collection that includes essays about Mr. Larsson, below, who died in 2004, and e-mails between him and his publisher, Eva Gedin. The volume, called “On Stieg Larsson,” will be released by Alfred A. Knopf as part of a boxed set including the best-selling “Millennium” trilogy, which began with “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo” and was followed by “The Girl Who Played With Fire” and “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest.” According to Knopf, the new book will include, among other essays, one by John-Henri Holmberg, a member of the Swedish Crime Fiction Academy, that places “Stieg Larsson in the context of the resurgence of Scandinavian crime writing.” The set, priced at $99, will go on sale the day after Thanksgiving.

headline: ‘Glee’ Making Room for McCartney and Boyle
text: The second season of “Glee” will feature one of the most popular singing sensations to emerge from Britain  and the music of Paul McCartney, too. Ryan Murphy, a creator of the Fox musical comedy series, said at the Television Critics Association press tour on Monday that Susan Boyle, below, would appear in a coming episode of “Glee” and that Mr. McCartney’s music would also be featured, Reuters reported. Mr. Murphy said that Ms. Boyle, the best-selling pop singer who was discovered on the reality series “Britain’s Got Talent,” would appear in a Christmas-theme episode of “Glee”; Reuters said she would play the (not-at-all-typecast) role of a high school lunch lady. The episode featuring Mr. McCartney’s songs wasn’t specified, but Mr. Murphy said he had been won over by a set of mix CDs Mr. McCartney sent to him. “It came out of blue in a package, handwritten, and it had two CDs, and it said, ‘Hi Ryan, I hope you will consider some of these songs for “Glee,” ’ Mr. Murphy said, according to Reuters.

headline: Broadway ‘Wonderland’
text: Frank Wildhorn is about to take another leap down the rabbit hole of Broadway. After his big-budget musicals  including “Jekyll and Hyde,” “The Civil War” and “The Scarlet Pimpernel”  had lost nearly $20 million on Broadway by the end of 2000, and a 2004 production, “Dracula: The Musical,” shut down after five months, Mr. Wildhorn, the composer, is readying a new work inspired by Lewis Carroll’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland.” On Tuesday the producers of “Wonderland: A New Alice. A New Musical Adventure,” said they would bring the updated take on the classic children’s story to Broadway in the spring, presenting it at a Nederlander theater to be determined. The musical, which focuses on a new, grown-up Alice, features a book by Gregory Boyd and Jack Murphy, as well as lyrics by Mr. Murphy and music by Mr. Wildhorn. It will be directed by Mr. Boyd and choreographed by Marguerite Derricks. Previews are scheduled to begin on March 21, with an opening night of April 17.

headline: Commence Squealing: 3-D Movie for Bieber
text: Justin Bieber, the 16-year-old pop phenomenon who is simply too big to be contained in two dimensions, will star in an autobiographical film in which every floppy hair on his adorable head will leap off the screen in 3-D, Paramount Pictures said on Tuesday. The movie, which does not yet have a title or a director, will feature footage from Mr. Bieber’s current tour and is planned for release over Valentine’s Day weekend next year. Mr. Bieber, who also struck a deal this week to write his memoirs, said in a statement that the film was a chance “to give something very special back to all the fans who have been a huge source of inspiration and support throughout my entire career thus far.”

headline: Climate Policy Is Paralyzed, but the Climate Isn’t
text: While American energy and climate policy remain paralyzed, physics isn’t standing still. And the science pointing to big, long-lasting consequences for the world from the buildup of greenhouse gases continues to accumulate.

headline: Lady Gaga Leads MTV Award Nominees
text: Lady Gaga, who was shut out of the big categories at the Grammy Awards this year, might get another chance to deliver an acceptance speech through stretched red lace at the MTV Video Music Awards next month. She leads this year’s contenders with 13 nominations, MTV said on Tuesday. Lady Gaga’s songs “Bad Romance” and “Telephone” are both up for video of the year, the top prize, in which she will compete against B.o.B’s “Airplanes,” Florence + the Machine’s “Dog Days Are Over,” 30 Seconds to Mars’s “Kings and Queens” and “Not Afraid” by Eminem, whose eight nominations this year are the second-most. B.o.B has five nominations, and Kesha has three, including best new artist: her competition is Jason Derulo, Justin Bieber, Nicki Minaj and Broken Bells. The Video Music Awards will be held at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on Sept. 12.

headline: Horton Says Home Sales Gained 60%
text: D.R. Horton, the American home builder, reported its third consecutive quarterly profit on Tuesday after sales climbed and the company cut costs.

headline: Strong ‘Bachelorette’ End
text: Closing its highest-rated season since 2004, “The Bachelorette” attracted 11.6 million viewers with the two-hour finale of its sixth season on Monday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, helping ABC dominate the night. CBS placed second, averaging 6.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 for reruns of its comedies and 6 million at 10 for a repeat of “CSI: Miami.” Fox and NBC finished in a virtual tie for third.

headline: Aretha Franklin Cancels Free Concerts In Brooklyn
text: Aretha Franklin has canceled two free concerts in Brooklyn next week because of an injury suffered on Sunday. The shows  at Wingate Field in East Flatbush on Monday, and Asser Levy Park in Brighton Beach on Aug. 12  were part of two series presented by Marty Markowitz, the borough president, and were to be the first concerts by Ms. Franklin, above, in Brooklyn. There was no immediate word on the nature of her injury, and the office of Debra Garcia, who organizes the concerts for Mr. Markowitz, said it did not know if her appearances would be rescheduled for this season.

headline: Wringing Art Out of the Rubble in Detroit
text: DETROIT — The latest must-go event in this gritty, left-behind city — where D.J.’s flourish among ruins, trespassing in tumbledown buildings is part of a night out, and even garage rock is bare-bones — centers on soup.

headline: Artists Making It in Detroit
text: Photographs of D.I.Y. artists in Detroit and at the Maker Faire, held for the first time in nearby Dearborn, Mich.

headline: Stop and Go: Reinventing the Car Pedal
text: Masuyuki Naruse, a Japanese inventor, combined the accelerator and brake pedal. He believes the contraption will reduce the number of car accidents by limiting driver confusion over the two pedals.

headline: On-Demand Options for Hard-to-Find Films
text: The Hong Kong director Johnnie To, one of the great virtuosos of the gangster film, makes movies worth rushing out to see.

headline: Gas-and-Brake Pedal Gets New Look After Recalls
text: TAMANA, Japan  Two pedals, inches apart, one for gas and the other for brakes. For years, a Japanese inventor has argued that this most basic of car designs is dangerously flawed.

headline: Pay Scandal Roils Two California Cities
text: For the first few weeks, things seemed to be going fine in Maywood, the California city that gave up the fiscal ghost in June, when it fired almost all of its employees and signed a contract with a neighboring town to run its affairs.

headline: An Angry Soul From a Hard Island
text: When we first meet Rita Mancuso, the purposeful heroine of “The Sicilian Girl,” she’s a bratty 11-year-old (played by Miriana Faja) slapping tomato sauce onto her mother’s freshly laundered sheets. Later we see her mouthing off to a prosecutor from Palermo (Gérard Jugnot) who has come to Rita’s village to question her adored father — an old-school Mafioso who defends his neighbors from less gentlemanly wiseguys — about the murder of a local rapist. The year is 1985, and Rita, her authority-flouting credentials firmly established, is poised to mouth off on a much grander scale.

headline: Revis-Jets Stalemate Was Year in Making
text: CORTLAND, N.Y.  The backdrop behind the Darrelle Revis contract stalemate centers on Leon Washington, a former Jets running back now playing in Seattle. His experience last season still resonates, quite strongly, throughout the locker room.

headline: Airline Fees Test Travelers’ Limits
text: AFTER a United flight hit severe turbulence over Kansas on July 20, injuring dozens of people on board, Jay Leno joked that flight attendants administered first aid only to passengers who paid a $7.50 “triage fee.” It was a bit of morbid humor reflecting the view that airline fees are out of control.

headline: Schumann’s Troubled Spirit Is Fertile Ground for Players
text: Even highly competent orchestral concerts can sound like just another day at the office for jaded musicians. But when the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen appeared at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening in the Mostly Mozart Festival, it seemed that work was certainly play for these fiery performers.

headline: In Europe, Chess Is King, but Not in the U.S.
text: The commonly held belief that chess is more popular in Europe than it is in the United States is not hard to prove. Just compare major tournaments under way or recently concluded in both areas.

headline: Target Touches Up Manhattan’s Makeup
text: NOW that Target has come to Manhattan, savvy beauty shoppers no longer have to brave the weekend crowds at the chain’s Atlantic Terminal outpost in Brooklyn to score exclusive products, like the Boots No. 7 skin-care line. They can just take the No. 6 train to Harlem.

headline: Another Anise Spirit Worth Knowing
text: In the Middle Eastern lands along the Mediterranean, arak has long been the drink of choice to accompany meze. But Lebanese wineries are paying more attention to the finesse with which they produce this ancient anise-flavored spirit. At Massaya, for example, the fermented juice of native white grapes is triple-distilled in a traditional pot still. On the third still run, the spirit is infused with fresh, organic green anise seeds from Mount Hermon. The arak (106 proof) is aged in clay amphorae for 18 months, making a smooth, deeply flavorful spirit. Like pastis (although less sweet), arak is meant to be diluted: one part spirit to two of water, before adding ice.

headline: Calendar
text: Eat Like a Medici

headline: Summer Berry Ice Cream
text: Time: 10 minutes, plus churning and chilling

headline: La Guardia Terminal Getting New Dining Choices
text: La Guardia Airport is mostly for domestic flights, the stingiest when it comes to feeding passengers aloft. At Delta Airlines’ Terminal D, at least, the food options for those who have time before boarding are about to become much more alluring.

headline: Maple Spice Ice Cream
text: Time: 20 minutes, plus churning and chilling

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: A Glove to Exfoliate Potatoes, Carrots and More
text: Slip on these textured elastic nylon gloves from Skrub’a in Denmark and you make short work of scrubbing vegetables without removing too much skin (and the nutrients just beneath it). The company makes black gloves labeled “potato” and orange ones for carrots, but you do not need a wardrobe: except for the color, they’re interchangeable. Nevertheless, there could be one labeled “clams” because I found them effective for scrubbing littlenecks. They also provide about enough cushioning for opening clams and oysters.

headline: Tigerlily
text: 299 Greene Avenue (Classon Avenue), Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, (917) 652-4648; tigerlilybrooklyn.com

headline: Robust Garlic, Fresh and Juicy
text: In addition to yarn from merino rams, the Catskill Merino Sheep Farm in Goshen, N.Y., grows and sells organic garlic. The harvest is in and dried bulbs are now available: hard-neck garlic with tight, fat, fairly uniform cloves often tinged with purple. It is strong, pungent and juicy because it is so fresh. The cloves are easy to peel, slice, sliver or chop.

headline: Bittersweet Chocolate Ice Cream
text: Time: 20 minutes, plus churning and chilling

headline: Kuti’s
text: 355 West 116th Street (between Manhattan and Morningside Avenues), (212) 222-1127.

headline: Roasted Hazelnut Vanilla Ice Cream
text: Time: 30 minutes, plus churning and chilling

headline: Conservatism Beyond Deficit Cutting
text: Ezra Klein and David Frum both have posts touching on the issue I raised here yesterday — the deeper socioeconomic forces that helped midwife the current Democratic majority, and that will pose an ongoing dilemma for leaders of both parties once the current economic debacle is behind us. Here’s Klein, pointing out that while right now we’re dreaming about getting back to the growth of early 2007, we need to recognize that by historical standards “early 2007 was terrible.”

headline: When the Trifle Turns Serious, Experience Counts
text: LENOX, Mass.  When a new team of conductors was announced to fill the many vacancies in the Tanglewood Festival season left by the withdrawal of James Levine, who is still recovering from back surgery, some may have been surprised to see Christoph von Dohnanyi assigned to an opera: the Tanglewood Music Center production of Strauss’s “Ariadne auf Naxos.” Mr. Dohnanyi is known in the United States chiefly as an orchestral conductor, especially for his two decades with the Cleveland Orchestra. He was, in fact, already scheduled to conduct concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra here at Tanglewood this weekend.

headline: John Aylesworth, a ‘Hee-Haw’ Creator, Dies at 81
text: John Aylesworth, co-creator of the long-running television hit “Hee Haw,” a blend of cornball humor and country music, died July 28 in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Palm Desert, Calif.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: IN this summer’s heat, putting your best face forward often means mopping up shine and fighting unruly hair. Here’s some advice to help you get ahead of the heat.

headline: Bristol and Levi’s Engagement Is Off Again
text: The roller coaster continues.

headline: Dollar Thrifty Finds Avis Bid Is ‘Problematic’
text: The Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group told the Avis Budget Group late Tuesday that its $1.3 billion takeover offer was “problematic” because Avis did not prove that its proposed merger could get antitrust clearance and it did not provide for a break-up fee if the deal fell through.

headline: Egg-Free Ice Cream Lets Flavors Bloom
text: ALTHOUGH I’d spent most of my childhood licking wan soft-serve vanilla and shockingly green mint-chocolate chip, I never looked back after my first taste of premium custard-based ice cream. Exceedingly creamy and as smooth as a stick of softened butter, it blew those crystallized supermarket cartons away with an icy blast.

headline: Homes for $350,000
text: A one-bedroom condo in Chicago, a three-bedroom cape in Vermont and a two-bedroom house in California.

headline: Obama Freezes Bonuses for Political Appointees
text: President Obama on Tuesday ordered federal agencies to temporarily cut out bonuses and other non-salary payments for federal political appointees in light of the economy’s lackluster performance.

headline: What You Get for ... $350,000
text: CHICAGO

headline: Suso Cecchi D’Amico, Writer of Literate Screenplays, Dies at 96
text: Suso Cecchi D’Amico, whose spare, literate screenplays made her a favored collaborator for directors including Vittorio De Sica, Michelangelo Antonioni, Luchino Visconti and Mario Monicelli, died on Saturday in Rome. She was 96.

headline: Assassination Sets Off Wave of Killings in Pakistani City
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A wave of violence after the assassination of a senior politician on Monday has left at least 47 people dead in Pakistan’s largest city, the southern port of Karachi.

headline: Second Quarter G.D.P. Was Probably Worse Than Reported
text: The economy most likely grew much less in the second quarter of 2010 than initially estimated.

headline: Infighting at Russian Mining Company Threatens Markets
text: MOSCOW  A struggle for control has erupted on the board of Norilsk Nickel, one of Russia’s most valuable mining companies and the world’s largest producer of nickel and platinum group metals, which currently have new uses in fuel cells for electric cars.

headline: Muscle Tear Sends Youkilis to D.L.
text: BOSTON – The Red Sox’ season of woe took another dark turn on Tuesday when the team placed Kevin Youkilis on the disabled list with a torn adductor muscle in his right thumb. Mike Lowell was activated and started for Youkilis at first base.

headline: Energy Bill a No-Go in the Senate
text: Senate Democrats on Tuesday abandoned all hopes of passing even a slimmed-down energy bill before they adjourn for the summer recess, saying that they did not have sufficient votes even for legislation tailored narrowly to respond to the Gulf oil spill.

headline: In Italy, Perched in the Alps
text: A house ringed by tall pines, with breathtaking unobstructed views of the mountains.

headline: Obesity Rates Keep Rising, Troubling Health Officials
text: Americans are continuing to get fatter and fatter, with obesity rates reaching 30 percent or more in nine states last year, as opposed to only three states in 2007, health officials reported on Tuesday.

headline: In Italy, Framing (and Preserving) the View
text: TIROL, Italy — About three years ago, Michael Pirpamer, 51, finally moved out of his mother’s house.

headline: BlackBerry Maker Resists Governments’ Pressure
text: A top executive of Research In Motion, the Canadian company that makes BlackBerry smartphones, said on Tuesday that his company would not give in to pressure from foreign governments to provide access to its customers’ messages.

headline: House Hunting in ... Ireland
text: A THREE-BEDROOM COUNTRY HOUSE WITH A GUEST COTTAGE AND TURKISH BATH IN COUNTY WICKLOW, IRELAND

headline: A Country House in Ireland
text: A three-bedroom house, with a guest house and Turkish baths, is on the market for 2 million euros ($2.6 million) in County Wicklow, Ireland.

headline: A Mosque That Stirs the Passions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fair Director Misapplied State Funds, Report Says
text: A former director of the New York State Fair used state resources to help put on weddings for his two daughters, and also gave away more than $700,000 worth of free fair and concert tickets to politicians, employees and other officials, an investigation by the New York State inspector general found.

headline: Building a New History by Exhuming Bolívar
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  The clock had just struck midnight. Most of the country was asleep. But that did not stop President Hugo Chávez from announcing in the early hours of July 16 that the latest phase of his Bolivarian Revolution had been stirred into motion.

headline: Improving Train Service
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Shrink the Pentagon
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rage and Floods in Pakistan
text: The worst floods in a generation in northwestern Pakistan have killed more than 1,400 people, left as many as 1.3 million others homeless and destroyed as much as 70 percent of the region’s livestock. Responding to the needs of the region and its desperately vulnerable people is not something the Pakistani government or the United States can afford to get wrong.

headline: Commercials in ‘Mad Men’ Style, Created for the Series
text: THE fact that Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, the new agency on “Mad Men,” has landed the Pond’s cold cream account is not the only advertising news to come out of the television series this week. AMC, the cable channel that presents the show about the ad industry  and America  in the 1960s has made a deal with a giant marketer, Unilever, for a season-long sponsorship agreement.

headline: After Afghan War Leaks, Revisions in a Shield Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Democratic senators who have been working on legislation providing greater protections to reporters who refuse to identify confidential sources are backpedaling from WikiLeaks, the Web site that recently disclosed more than 75,000 classified documents related to the Afghanistan war.

headline: Putting Investors First
text: In large part, the success of financial reform will depend on regulators writing tough rules and enforcing them, which they have failed to do in the past. An early and important test of such willpower will come soon as the Securities and Exchange Commission finalizes new rules for nominating directors to corporate boards.

headline: South Africa: Ex-police Chief Is Sentenced to 15 Years
text: Jackie Selebi, the former national police chief, was sentenced to 15 years in prison on Tuesday after his conviction last month for accepting bribes from a drug kingpin. In issuing the sentence, Judge Meyer Joffe chastised Mr. Selebi, the former president of Interpol, the international police group, for fabricating evidence. Mr. Selebi is free on bond during the two weeks he has to file an appeal.

headline: Mexico: Death Toll From Drug-Related Violence Is Thousands Higher Than Was Reported Earlier
text: The number of deaths from drug-related violence is higher than previous acknowledged, the director of Mexico’s intelligence agency said Tuesday. Guillermo Valdés Castellanos, director of the National Security and Investigation Center, or Cisen, put the new toll at a “little more than 28,000 murders” since President Felipe Calderón took office in December 2006. Last month the attorney general’s office reported that 24,826 lives had been lost nationwide.

headline: Giants Happy to Let Others (Like the Jets) Make the Headlines
text: ALBANY  At Giants training camp, the only thing to disturb the silence has been the screaming of the boisterous new defensive coordinator, Perry Fewell.

headline: The Hunt for American Decency in the Arizona Quicksand
text: The federal judge who struck down most of Arizona’s new immigration law last week wasn’t trying to strike a blow for immigrants’ rights, about which her ruling said little. She wasn’t dictating what immigration laws should look like or how strict they should be. She was making a much more fundamental argument, one that has regularly emerged in America’s long and often ugly history in dealing with noncitizens and other vulnerable minorities.

headline: Taste Testing Strawberry Ice Cream

headline: You Scream, I Scream ... at the Price of Ice Cream
text: EMILY EISENBERG, who lives in the Eagle Rock neighborhood of Los Angeles, said she let her young sons talk her into trying a new scoop shop, Gelato Bar, in nearby Los Feliz in June. It is the kind of place that describes its ice cream as “premium and handmade,” the mix-ins are from local artisans and farmers, and the prices are accordingly high. For two small servings, she paid more than $10, and walked out vowing never to return.

headline: Lottery Numbers

This Bureau of Labor Statistics report from 2007, which I mentioned in my column this week, offers a good overview.

headline: Mom and Dad, Meet My Budget

As the only  guests, we were seated without delay and were soon digging into three whole fried sea bass smothered in chopped tomatoes alongside rice, salad and gooey, sweet fried plantains.

headline: Phys Ed: How Much Does Knee Surgery Really Help?
text: A study published late last month in The New England Journal of Medicine is raising provocative questions about how best to treat a torn anterior cruciate ligament. For the study, researchers from Lund University in Sweden recruited 121 young adults who had injured their A.C.L.’s. The volunteers, between 18 and 35, were physically active, and many were competitive athletes. They agreed, rather bravely, to be randomly assigned to one of two groups and accept radically different treatments for their torn A.C.L.’s. The first group began physical therapy and then underwent surgical reconstruction of the ligament, considered by many people to be the best option for injured athletes. The second group received only physical therapy, with the option to have the operation later. Twenty-three subjects of that group did eventually have the operation. (For those fortunate enough not to be personally familiar with A.C.L. surgery, reconstruction involves replacing the injured ligament with tissue from elsewhere in your own leg or from a cadaver.)

headline: Interfaith Marriages Stir Mixed Feelings
text: When Steven Cohn, a Chicago-area lawyer, looked at photographs of Marc Mezvinsky, outfitted with a yarmulke and a prayer shawl, and Chelsea Clinton, luminous in a strapless gown and a 100-watt smile, he recalled his own interfaith marriage 30 years ago to Loreli Fritz-Cohn, a Methodist, on her grandmother’s farm in Ohio. He, too, wore a prayer shawl — though he recalled how hard it had been to find a Reform rabbi to perform the ceremony.

headline: Rabbi at Chelsea Clinton’s Wedding Has Been on a Spiritual Journey
text: Rabbi James Ponet, who last Saturday co-officiated at the wedding of Chelsea Clinton and Marc Mezvinsky, will henceforth be known for presiding at the most publicized interfaith wedding in recent American history. Yet not long ago, the wedding that put him in the spotlight is one he would not have performed. As Yale’s chief rabbi since 1981, Rabbi Ponet has led a very public journey, from strict observance  which counseled against intermarriages  to a more open liberalism that can permit them.

headline: Taxes Don’t Cross New England State Lines, but Controversies Do

headline: Twitter for Businesses? StatusNet Gets $1.4 Million
text: StatusNet, a microblogging service with similarities to Twitter but designed for businesses, on Tuesday announced that it had  secured a second round of financing for $1.4 million. The financing will be used to support and grow its sales team and continue aiming at  the world’s 1,000 largest businesses, it said in an announcement.

headline: Campaign for Chess Federation Presidency Becomes More Heated

headline: McCain Enters Citizenship Debate
text: Senator John McCain of Arizona joined other senior Republicans calling for Congressional hearings on the 14th Amendment, which provides that anyone born in the United States is an American. Last week Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, a Republican leader on immigration, said he would craft an amendment to revoke citizenship for children of illegal immigrants. Mr. Graham’s comments brought the birthright citizenship issue to the center of the immigration debate. In a statement, Mr. McCain did not take a position but he said any change to the Constitution would require extensive hearings.

headline: Obama Signs Drug Parity Law
text: President Obama signed legislation on Tuesday reducing sentencing disparities between those caught with crack and those arrested with powder cocaine. The legislation was a compromise reached by Democrats and Republicans who agreed that the old law imposed unduly harsh sentences for crack violations, which especially affected minorities, compared with powder cocaine violations. Under the old law, a person caught with five grams of crack received a mandatory five years in prison, while a person caught with powder cocaine had to have 500 grams to merit the same term. The new law reduces the 100-to-1 disparity to 18-to-1.

headline: A Prague Show About the Outdoors, Held Outdoors

And to add some local flair, “Wilds of Sumava,” a separate exhibition of images from that Czech national park in south Bohemia, is also featured. Both shows are free.

headline: Now Prescribing | Mood-Altering Scarves
text: Julien David apprenticed with Narciso Rodriguez and Ralph Lauren in New York, but when the 31-year-old French designer ventured out on his own, he went back to Square 1: the scarf. His collection, which he started in Tokyo in 2007, uses the finest Japanese silks and cashmere — to wildly irreverent effect. Artificial growth, for example, is his theme for this fall. This plays itself out in something as unusual as a pill motif, which the designer blows up into a giant two-toned capsule, whose colorful geometry drapes around the neck. ‘‘I tend to like gigantism,’’ David says. ‘‘I thought I could make the silk scarves look very different and interesting [by] changing prints and proportions.’’ This September, David will add coats and bags to the mix. Artificial growth? More likely, natural progression.

headline: My Life in Therapy
text: All those years, all that money, all that unrequited love. It began way back when I was a child, an anxiety-riddled 10-year-old who didn’t want to go to school in the morning and had difficulty falling asleep at night. Even in a family like mine, where there were many siblings (six in all) and little attention paid to dispositional differences, I stood out as a neurotic specimen. And so I was sent to what would prove to be the first of many psychiatrists in the four and a half decades to follow — indeed, I could be said to be a one-person boon to the therapeutic establishment — and was initiated into the curious and slippery business of self-disclosure. I learned, that is, to construct an ongoing narrative of the self, composed of what the psychoanalyst Robert Stoller calls “microdots” (“the consciously experienced moments selected from the whole and arranged to present a point of view”), one that might have been more or less cohesive than my actual self but that at any rate was supposed to illuminate puzzling behavior and onerous symptoms — my behavior and my symptoms.

headline: All-American Roulette

headline: Unesco Adds 21 Sites to World Heritage List

As of Sunday, 890 locations were designated by the World Heritage Committee as “having outstanding universal value.” On Monday, when the committee completed its consideration of new nominees, a new set of 21 places joined that list. The additions range from remote natural locations, like the central highlands of Sri Lanka, to well-trodden urban places, like Amsterdam’s 17th-century canal belt.

headline: Graphic Content | Surrealism for Art and Profit
text: “Picture yourself in a boat on a river, / With tangerine trees and marmalade skies,” wrote John Lennon in “Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds.” This symbolic lyric is a good example of surrealism. Once a radical art movement, today it is a common visual style. Yet before surrealism was an early-20th-century European avant-garde manifestation, it was the language of comics and commercial art.

headline: An Irishwoman Back From Obscurity
text: IN the first half of the 1930s Teresa Deevy, a deaf writer from a small city in the southeast of Ireland, was one of the most prolific and acclaimed female playwrights in the world. She was “the most important dramatist writing for the Irish theater,” her fellow playwright Lennox Robinson wrote in The Dublin Magazine. Her most famous drama, “Katie Roche” (1936), a complex portrait of a lower-class servant with dreams of grandeur, inspired the critic St. John Ervine to write in the London newspaper The Observer, “Miss Deevy may be a genius.”

headline: Teaching ‘Frankenstein’ With The New York Times
text: There are many discoveries to be made when students read “Frankenstein” for the first time – that “Frankenstein” is the name not of a created “monster” but of the scientist who creates him, that the nameless creation himself is a sympathetic, lonely nature-lover, and that the novel raises ever-relevant questions about a range of issues including bioethics, the meaning of life and “the deepest mysteries of creation,” as Mary Shelley herself put it.

headline: Rodriguez Hits 600th Career Home Run
text: On the outside, Alex Rodriguez could find humor in his home run drought. He poked fun at his inability to hit the elusive No. 600, advising fans and teammates to “get comfortable” because it was going to take a while, and he hardly seemed flustered as the homerless streak followed him to Cleveland, Florida and back to the Bronx. But in reality, Rodriguez was growing weary of it all. Every at-bat, all 46 of them, Rodriguez wanted to hit a home run, and each time he did not, the cycle perpetuated itself.

headline: Climate Change Risk and the ‘Steve Schneider Memorial Exercise’

He was a source of mine on the two-way relationship between climate and people from the early 1980s until three weeks ago, when he died of a pulmonary embolism on a flight from Stockholm to London — part of his 3 million miles of relentless (and ultimately fatal) journeying to study or communicate the science of climate change and its significance for society. (Yes, that’s a lot of carbon; we remain very much in the fossil fuel age.)

Avenged Sevenfold, from Huntington Beach, Calif., sold 163,000 copies of its new album, “Nightmare” (Warner Brothers), while Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) was close behind with 159,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: On Deck for 600: Jim Thome
text: The next player to join Alex Rodriguez in the 600 home run club, if he keeps playing, should be Jim Thome of the Minnesota Twins. Thome, who turns 40 this month, has 577 career homers, including 13 in 227 plate appearances this season.

headline: Asked & Answered | Kelis, Singer/Saucier
text: Kelis’s song “Milkshake” may have brought all the boys to the yard in 2003, but these days it’s just as likely to be her haute cuisine that lures admirers. It’s been a whirlwind couple of years for Kelis (née Kelis Rogers). In addition to marrying and divorcing the rapper Nas, having her first child and just releasing “Flesh Tone” — her first album in four years — the R&B and pop singer somehow found time to graduate from culinary school. The Moment caught up with the chanteuse/saucier by phone from Los Angeles to find out more about her gastronomic pursuits before she hits Manhattan’s Webster Hall tonight and tomorrow night.

headline: Freedom and Reality: A Response
text: It has been a privilege to read the comments posted in response to my July 25th post, “The Limits of the Coded World” and I am exceedingly grateful for the time, energy and passion so many readers put into them. While my first temptation was to answer each and every one, reality began to set in as the numbers increased, and I soon realized I would have to settle for a more general response treating as many of the objections and remarks as I could. This is what I would like to do now.

headline: In Push to Detect Early Alzheimer’s Markers, Hopes for Prevention
text: Will Alzheimer’s disease, a terrible degenerative brain disease with no treatments and no clear guidelines for diagnosis before its end stages, become like heart disease? That might mean early markers of risk, analogous to high cholesterol levels, that predict who is likely to get it. And it might mean drugs that actually prevent it.

headline: The Politics of Dispersants
text: Republicans were ready to accept the use of dispersants in oil spills but Democrats were eager to get their doubts on record on Wednesday at a Senate hearing on the Deepwater Horizon spill in the gulf.

headline: Who Benefits From Early Diagnosis of Alzheimer’s?
text: In July, medical experts proposed a major change in the criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, part of a new movement to diagnose and, eventually, treat the disease earlier. The new diagnostic guidelines would mean that new technology like brain scans would be used to detect the disease even before there are evident memory problems or other symptoms.

headline: Behind Dollar Thrifty’s Dance With Avis
text: The Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group has taken a notable step in its letter to the Avis Budget Group: Although it outlined its concerns about Avis’s current takeover offer, Dollar Thrifty did not reject the bid outright.

headline: For Ballet, Plots Thicken, or Just Stick?
text: “DEAR friends,” the retired ballerina Gelsey Kirkland wrote in an open letter on the Web site for the new Gelsey Kirkland Academy of Classical Ballet (gelseykirklandballet.org), “I have come to believe over the years that the future of ballet lies in the art of dramatic storytelling, drawing on the wellsprings of classical tradition.” The school’s mission statement underscores this belief: “To encourage a renaissance of dramatic storytelling in ballet by providing specialized training for gifted students and by establishing a classically oriented studio company capable of creating new dramatic works.”

headline: Has Crowdsourcing Worked for You?
text: We’ve just published a small-business guide to crowdsourcing that explains how to tap the wisdom of the crowd to help you complete tasks like designing new products or managing an AdWords campaign. That’s what Lee Rosen, president of the Rosen Law Firm, used it for — with some success. “Really,” he said, “it’s magical.”

headline: Summer Camp for Parents
text: Yes, yes, of course we miss the dear hearts when they are away at summer camp. And, yes, naturally we fret over their letters (or lack thereof) and meet the stereotype of the enmeshed parent as we sort through photos on the Web site every night.
