text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday cleared the way for a $26 billion package of aid to states and school districts, and the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, said she would summon members from their summer recess to grant final approval to the bill.

headline: 110th Congress: Opening Day
text: In a day of transition and pageantry, exultant Democrats took control of both houses of Congress.

headline: German Agency Finds Flaws in Apple’s Mobile Software
text: BERLIN  A German government agency warned citizens on Wednesday about two software vulnerabilities in Apple’s mobile operating system, iOS, which it said could be exploited to infect the company’s best-selling iPhone, iPad and iPod devices.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Iraq war to be over in 26 days? We spent a century in Iraq these last seven years.

headline: Pedal Pusher
text: In The Times today, Hiroko Tabuchi reports on an inventor in Japan who has come up with a new design for the brake and accelerator pedals, incorporating both functions in one pedal.

headline: Sounds of the Caucasus
text: Images from music groups in the Caucasus.

headline: Cellphone Service by the Day, Month or Tankful
text: The two-year contract.

headline: Police Official Assassinated by Taliban in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber wearing 20 pounds of explosives assassinated the prominent leader of a Pakistani security force and three other people on Wednesday afternoon at a busy intersection here in northwest Pakistan, security officials said.

headline: On President’s Birthday, Doubts Persist About His Birthplace
text: As President Obama heads home to Chicago to celebrate his 49th birthday with friends, about one-quarter of the American public still believes that he was not born in the United States, according to a CNN poll released Wednesday.

headline: Richard L. Feigen Collection
text: Roughly 60 pieces from Mr. Feigen’s personal collection of Italian paintings are on view at the Yale University Art Gallery.

headline: A Place Where Ms. Pac-Man Still Has a Home
text: WALKING down the southern end of Mott Street  a stretch lined with cheap-toy traps and Chinese restaurants of varying quality  is a fairly unremarkable experience until the sidewalk is suddenly packed with grungy and very loud teenagers and young adults loitering in front of a prominent “No Loitering” sign.

headline: Coming to the Defense of Community Gardens
text: Members of a citywide community garden group and the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn ,called upon the Bloomberg administration on Wednesday to help make permanent hundreds of community gardens scattered across the city.

headline: A Fresh Face in South London
text: ON a recent Thursday evening, Brixton Market in South London was a study in odd juxtapositions.

headline: Hotel Review: Town Hall Hotel & Apartments in East London
text: BASICS

headline: Plenty of Bees, but No Food
text: A good beekeeper knows what’s going on inside his or her hives. By now you know I am anything but a good beekeeper. Last weekend, after the 100-degree temperatures cooled a bit, my friend and I enjoyed an evening meal in the back yard, and we both wondered why bees from one hive were massed above the hive entrance -– typical bee behavior -– while the other hive had no loiterers.

headline: Roundabout Names Theresa Rebeck to Associate Artist Post
text: The playwright Theresa Rebeck (“The Understudy,” “Mauritius”) has become the first dramatist to be named as associate artist of Roundabout Theater Company, the nonprofit theater said on Wednesday, as part of its effort to develop more new work for its stages.

headline: A Shoe In
text: Massimiliano Giornetti planned to spend his summer vacation in Puglia, a popular Italian getaway several hours from his home in Florence. ‘‘I’m not entirely a free spirit on holiday,’’ says the 38-year-old designer, who was recently named Ferragamo’s creative director. ‘‘I like some structure, with a little room to be adventurous.’’ A perfect metaphor for his design mantra at Ferragamo, where he has helmed the men’s-wear divison for the last decade. Any question as to whether Giornetti could translate his masculine sensibilities to the more mercurial closets of women was answered in his much lauded fall collection. He managed to channel the independent spirit of Salvatore Ferragamo’s devoted customer, Greta Garbo, while creating sharp, assertive glamour: fur-lined capes, cuffed leather shorts, thick cable knits and a three-piece pinstriped suit that seemed like a 21st-century version of ‘‘Annie Hall.’’

headline: Tale of Immigrant Tribe Viewed in Emerald Lens
text: There was an interval in the 1990s when all things Hibernian were at the cultural forefront: bands like the Pogues and the Waterboys had devoted followings; Neil Jordan’s “Crying Game” was a hit movie; the Good Friday, or Belfast, Agreement was signed. And Frank McCourt, a retired Manhattan high school teacher, wrote “Angela’s Ashes,” his best-selling memoir about a destitute childhood in Limerick, which won a Pulitzer Prize.

headline: A Plimpton Family Affair
text: AMID the clink of Scotch glasses and the din of conversation was a sense that there were two parties taking place last Wednesday at a literary salon on the Upper East Side.

headline: Hyundai Says Its Cars Will Average 50 M.P.G. by 2025
text: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. — Hyundai said on Wednesday that its entire product lineup in the United States would average at least 50 miles per gallon by 2025 — somehow. That would be an improvement of about 60 percent from the ratings of the cars and trucks Hyundai sells today.

headline: Invitation to Dance to Shostakovich
text: The Knights, a dynamic young chamber orchestra, had to cut short their performance in June at the Naumburg Bandshell when it began to pour. But they were luckier on Tuesday, when it neither rained nor was hideously hot. The event, part of the Naumburg Orchestral Concerts series, went according to plan, with a large crowd in attendance.

headline: When Stravinsky Looked to History
text: You would think Stravinsky’s “Dumbarton Oaks” Concerto (1938) would be played more than it is. As Stravinsky’s music goes, this chamber work, written with the Bach “Brandenburg” Concertos as a loose model, is certainly not as monumental as the early ballets or as tartly amusing as “Histoire du Soldat” or “Pulcinella.” But a lot of it is just plain likable. It’s as if Stravinsky, for once, had found an earlier form that he wanted to emulate rather than parody, extend rather than distend.

headline: Jets’ Ferguson Is Looking for Continuity
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — As the Jets continue to audition Matt Slauson and Vladimir Ducasse for their opening at left guard, left tackle D’Brickashaw Ferguson is experiencing flashbacks.

headline: Giants’ Umenyiora Softens His Stance on Playing Time
text: ALBANY  Osi Umenyiora was wearing sweatpants and carrying a box of pizza Wednesday morning, so perhaps it made sense that he sounded like a man at ease with the world.

headline: London Theater Journal: Screams! Thrills! Chills!
text: I screamed three times. O.K., maybe it was four or five. And I bruised my elbow against an armrest from (how embarrassing) jumping out of my seat. But wouldn’t you scream if you were in a dark room and a large, ambiguous figure – like a shadow, really, but with heft – suddenly…. Oh, right. I’m not supposed to talk about that.

headline: Hard Science, Softened With Stories
text: On the one hand, as Sam Kean points out at the start of “The Disappearing Spoon,” the periodic table of the elements is a clear, accessible-looking chart that ought to make sense to anyone who ever set foot in a chemistry classroom. On the other, many a would-be chemist has found it as impenetrable as it is alluring.

headline: ‘The Disappearing Spoon’
text: Introduction

headline: The Cheat: Deep-Fried Fishing
text: General Tso’s striped bass is a dish served at a restaurant called Wok n’ Roll in Montauk, N.Y. It is a modest place at the far eastern end of Long Island, often crowded: a fishing town’s only Chinese restaurant. The bass comes to the table in fat chunks that have been battered and fried to golden crispness, then tossed in a sauce that is molten, sweet, sour and fiery, and piled high on a plate for sharing. The dish is as authentically Chinese as baseball or white-picket fences. It is no less delicious for that.

headline: General Tso’s Scallops
text: 1 extra-large egg

headline: Deloitte Ex-Partner Charged With Insider Trading
text: A former partner at Deloitte & Touche and his son have agreed to pay more than $1.1 million to settle civil charges that they engaged in illegal insider trading in the securities of several of the audit firm’s clients.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
text: The Iranian government denied reports on Wednesday that President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was the target of a grenade attack about 200 miles south of Tehran. A photographer for Reuters captured Mr. Ahmadinejad’s bodyguards as they reacted to the sound of an explosion behind his entourage. [Slide 1].

headline: Restaurant Review: The Blind Pig in Louisville, Ky.
text: At the Blind Pig, Joseph Frase, the chef and an owner, smokes his own sausage in the backyard — appropriate for a restaurant in Louisville’s Butchertown neighborhood. His menu reflects the working-class history of the area, with upscale renditions of pan-European peasant fare like spaghetti alla putanesca and shepherd’s pie. Unlike their humble ancestors, however, the dishes at the Blind Pig use simple preparations to highlight the strong, natural flavors of the ingredients.

headline: And the Oscar Officers Are …
text: Tom Sherak, a longtime film distribution executive, was re-elected on Tuesday night as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the academy said.

headline: Palin Backs Maryland Underdog
text: Sarah Palin’s wading into a Republican primary again, this time endorsing a seemingly long-shot gubernatorial candidate in Maryland.

headline: Vice, a Media Company, Shows Big Brands How to Reach the Hip Crowd
text: Vice is happy to be known as a hipster media company. From its headquarters in a former warehouse in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, the company oversees magazines covering youth culture in 23 editions distributed in 26 countries, an online television network and a record label.

headline: The Smartpen Gets Smarter
text: Several months ago, I took a look at Livescribe’s Pulse smartpen, a digital pen that simultaneously records audio and your handwritten notes, and syncs the two together to allow you to find what you heard by simply tapping on a word you wrote.

headline: Bradley Calls On World Cup Veterans for Brazil Game
text: Aug. 6, 9:50 a.m. |Altidore and Gonzalez Replace Jones and Marshall

headline: MarketRiders Offering Commission-Free E.T.F. Portfolios
text: Want to build an inexpensive investment portfolio?

headline: Los Angeles Dispatch | Will Lemon at Eighth Veil Gallery
text: Most makeup artists consider the skin their canvas, but William Lemon III takes the idea more literally. Lemon, who is also a musician and painter, created a water-based acrylic body painting technique called skin printing, and he has used it to cover Marc Jacobs’s naked body with hot pink Stephen Sprouse/Louis Vuitton logos, and to transform Chloë Sevigny into a tattooed-lady-slash-clown for Beck’s trippy “Gamma Ray” video. (Look close: Lemon is the dancing mime.) In N.E.R.D.’s new “Hot and Fun” video, directed by Jonas Akerlund, he trussed up a tribe of apocalyptic party girls with animal prints, mystical symbols and ash. “He let me go a little bit far out,” Lemon said of the director — not surprising since Akerlund is also the man behind Lady Gaga’s “Telephone.”

headline: Google to Buy Levchin’s Slide
text: 6:57 p.m. | Updated Bits’s Claire Cain Miller has more on Google‘s acquisition of Slide, though she reports the purchase price is $228 million.

headline: Safari Extends Its Options
text: Catching up with the technologies offered by browsers including Mozilla’s Firefox and Google’s Chrome, Apple this week began offering a version 5.01 update to its Safari Web browser that includes the option to create “lite” Web extensions.

headline: Bookmarks, From A to Z
text: Bookmarks

headline: Fairies, Goblins and a Thumb-Sucking Hero in Battery Park City
text: There are fairies in Battery Park City (faeries, according to the publicity), with flapping wings and floral headdresses. There is also a young man, possibly answering to the name of Garbhglas, if only you could pronounce that properly, who  though bare-chested  wears a pixie hat, long pointed booties and a kilt, all in one of the more subdued shades of rustic green. And there are three mud-colored bestial creatures whom I will call goblins, who have udders all over their bodies, even their high-pointed heads.

headline: Into the Breach, Clad in Adolfo
text: NO one really remembers. Actually, that is not altogether true. There are those who do recall, the ones who survived the terrifying place that New York became in the 1980s, when a disease with no fixed medical designation  beyond an acronym that made it seem as though those most affected were somehow its cause  was killing people in droves.

headline: Bridging Jazz Generations Without Nostalgia
text: Greg Osby has a keen, focused tone on alto saxophone and a hummingbird’s phrasing, an equilibrium of hover and flutter. His style hasn’t changed drastically since the mid-1980s, when he was among the more important new arrivals on the New York scene. What has changed is his stature, and the context around his work. Mr. Osby is now a mentor and a pacesetter, one of the sturdier bridges between jazz generations. His music, for all its coiled intricacies, has gradually been absorbed by the modern mainstream.

headline: For Fannie Stock, Even Betting Pennies Is a Risk
text: It is flotsam of the housing wreck, a stock no longer worthy of the Big Board. But penny by penny, the mortgage giant Fannie Mae is being salvaged in the stock market.

headline: How Much Debt Should Households Have?
text: One of the biggest question marks for the economic recovery going forward is how consumer behavior — usually one of the drivers of growth — has changed in this post-housing-bust world.

headline: Meeting Force With Force: A Police Unit’s Beat Is Behind Bars
text: Is there any outlet on television that comes close to A&E in showing us just what it takes to clean up the broad mess of American life? Whenever current events threaten to sever faith in our institutions, there is A&E reminding us that federal marshals are capturing killers on the lam (“Manhunters: Fugitive Task Force”); that mental-health professionals are rehabilitating drunks, germophobes and hoarders (“Intervention,” “Obsessed,” “Hoarders”); that transit officials are nailing parking rogues (“Parking Wars”); that annihilators are whacking household pests (“Billy the Exterminator”); that the patriarchy is being upheld however unconventionally (“Gene Simmons Family Jewels”).

headline: Antismoking Forces Revive Ads With a Jagged Edge
text: Weeks ago, a popular commercial that fought smoking among teenagers and young adults as part of the “Truth” campaign returned after a six-year absence.

headline: City Barred From Hiring New Firefighters
text: The federal judge overseeing a discrimination lawsuit against the city’s Fire Department ruled on Wednesday that the hiring test being used by the department was unfair to minority applicants and issued an injunction that will prevent the city from offering positions to 300 applicants who had already taken the exam.

headline: Aggressive, Delicate and Enduring
text: There is no shame in the singing of Ann Wilson of Heart. Feet planted squarely, hand on microphone, she anticipates the bigness of notes to come, then still sings them in such an overwhelming fashion that they appear to knock her off her center. Many times at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night she took a pause, howled a few lines in a manner that would have impressed even Meat Loaf, then took another pause, needing to refocus.

headline: Grilled Fish, a Smartphone and Dinner
text: I had an hour to pull dinner together.

headline: Digging Deep, and Riding High (at Last)
text: ANDY gave me a shove and the 10-foot longboard took off like a shark on the hunt. I felt a sense of lightness as the roll of water caught up with me, tilting down the foam plank on which I lay. I paddled hard to stay ahead of the wave.

headline: Motion Picture Academy Re-elects Its President
text: Tom Sherak, below, a longtime film-distribution executive, was re-elected on Tuesday night as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the academy said. Sidney Ganis, a previous academy president, was elected first vice president, while James L. Brooks and Phil Robinson were elected as vice presidents, Hawk Koch was elected treasurer, and Annette Bening was elected secretary. Officers of the Academy, whose 6,000 members present the Oscars each year, are elected to one-year terms by the group’s board of governors.

headline: An Argentine Gem Hidden No More
text: EVERY August, the people of Jujuy pay tribute to the earth goddess Pachamama. Families prepare elaborate dishes — tamales, stews, llama or lamb — and then bury the food in a backyard or field, along with abundant hard liquor, coca leaves and even cigarettes. They believe that these offerings will satisfy the deity’s appetites and thus bring them good fortune and an abundant harvest. It’s an ancient Andean tradition that remains strong in this province in the northwestern corner of Argentina.

headline: Man Dies at Kansas Stop of Vans Warped Tour
text: The Vans Warped Tour expressed its condolences to the family of a man who died at a concert stop in Bonner Springs, Kan., on Monday. In a statement publicists for the tour said they were awaiting “a complete report from the Bonner Springs law enforcement and medical examiner,” adding: “Tour organizers are working closely with Capitol Federal Park @ Sandstone staff and local officials to determine the actual facts surrounding this tragic incident and will make further details known as they become available.” The Web page of the concert site, sandstoneamp.com, identified the man as Curtis Alan DeForest, 26, of Wichita. A statement on the site said that he had been taken to a nearby medical center where he died, and that a cause of death had not been determined.

headline: ‘Nightmare’ for Eminem: He Loses Top Album Spot
text: It took a metal band to knock Eminem from his five-week perch atop the Billboard album chart. Avenged Sevenfold, from Huntington Beach, Calif., sold 163,000 copies of its new album, “Nightmare” (Warner Brothers), above, while Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) was close behind with 159,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week with no major new releases Rick Ross’s “Teflon Don” (Maybach Music/Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam) fell one spot to No. 3 with 63,000 in sales, Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) rose two to No. 4 with 38,000, and Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) had 34,000, enough for No. 5. Total album sales for the year are at 174.9 million, down 12 percent from the same period last year.

headline: Chevron Cites Documentary Outtakes in Legal Papers
text: The Chevron Corporation says in federal court filings in Manhattan that footage it was provided from the Joe Berlinger documentary “Crude” demonstrated “pervasive corruption and fraud” by lawyers representing Ecuadorians who are suing the company, an accusation those lawyers vigorously dispute. In July a federal appeals court ruled that Mr. Berlinger had to provide the oil company with some footage from his 2009 film, which chronicles Ecuadorians who say that an oil field established by Texaco (now owned by Chevron) polluted their water. Chevron said in a statement that interactions between lawyers for the Ecuadorian plaintiffs and a court-appointed expert showed the parties “engaged in an illegal scheme to corrupt the proceedings in Ecuador.” Ilann M. Maazel, a lawyer whose firm represents the Ecuadorean plaintiffs, said that neither Chevron nor Mr. Berlinger had provided his team with the film outtakes, and that lawyers for Chevron had similar access to court experts. “They cherrypick a couple of minutes and share it with the court, but they’re not willing to release all the tapes,” Mr. Maazel said in a telephone interview. He said that neither Chevron nor Mr. Berlinger would provide the outtakes to him.

headline: Roundabout Theater Writing Assignments
text: The playwright Theresa Rebeck, below, (“The Understudy,” “Mauritius”) has become the first dramatist to be named as associate artist of Roundabout Theater Company, the not-for-profit theater said on Wednesday, as part of its effort to develop more new work for its stages. In addition to having a home at Roundabout to develop work, associate artists consult with the artistic director, Todd Haimes, on projects that Roundabout is considering for readings, workshops and productions. Other associate artists include the directors Scott Elliott, Joe Mantello and Kathleen Marshall. Mr. Haimes announced 10 playwriting commissions for new works that are in development, including playwrights like Julia Cho (“The Language Archive”) and Lydia Diamond (“The Bluest Eye”). Roundabout also said that a new play by David West Read, “The Dream of the Burning Boy,” will be the first spring 2011 production at its 62-seat black-box theater. The play, about the fallout from the death of a high school overachiever, will be directed by Evan Cabnet (“Oliver Parker!”) and is scheduled to begin performances on Feb. 25 and open on March 20.

headline: Another Cast Signing for ‘Women on the Verge’
text: If playing a woman who was driven to a life of striptease by the most overbearing stage mother in show business history did not leave Laura Benanti, right, in a state of mental collapse, her next role just might: Ms. Benanti will reunite with her “Gypsy” co-star Patti LuPone in Lincoln Center Theater’s coming musical version of Pedro Almodóvar’s “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,” the theater company said on Wednesday. Ms. Benanti, who won a Tony Award for her portrayal of Louise in the recent “Gypsy” revival, is joining the musical as Candela, a fashion model whose lover turns out to be a terrorist. Previously announced cast members include Sherie Rene Scott as Pepa, the television actress at the center of the farce; Brian Stokes Mitchell as her boyfriend, Iván; Ms. LuPone as Lucía, Iván’s wife; de’Adre Aziza as Paulina, Lucía’s lawyer; and Nikka Graff Lanzarone as Marisa, the fiancée of the son of Iván and Lucía. (Got all that?) The “Women on the Verge” musical is directed by Bartlett Sher with a book by Jeffrey Lane and music and lyrics by David Yazbek. Previews are to begin at the Belasco Theater on Oct. 2 with an opening night set for Nov. 4.

headline: ‘Talent’ Takes Tuesday
text: The last group of 12 quarterfinalists competed on Tuesday night’s episode of “America’s Got Talent” as that NBC reality show topped the ratings with 10.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network drew meager ratings earlier in the night for the second installment of “Breakthrough With Tony Robbins” (2.8 million). CBS ranked second over all with a lineup of crime-show repeats. In third place Fox edged ahead of ABC with the cooking-themed reality shows “Hell’s Kitchen” (7.1 million) and “MasterChef” (5.9 million). ABC drew its best ratings with “Wipeout” (8.8 million) but lagged with the second-season premiere of “Shaq Vs.” (5.4 million) and “Primetime” (4.7 million).

headline: In a Video Game, Tackling the Complexities of Protein Folding
text: Gamers, 1; computer, 0.

headline: Enjoying the Waterfront, Actively and Passively
text: Back-Flipping | Fort Tilden, Queens

headline: Judge Is Still Missing, but Novel Tracks Him Down
text: One day last week, the novelist Peter Quinn (“I’m actually a lapsed historian”) was walking west on 45th Street, beyond Eighth Avenue, when he stopped outside the old home of a vanished Broadway restaurant called Billy Haas’s Chophouse.

headline: Still Wild for Animal Prints
text: THE animal print frenzy shows no sign of abating. Starting today, Alexander Wang is having a sample sale from its resort and spring 2010 collection.

headline: Seeking the ‘Eye’ for Art
text: NEW HAVEN  A dozen years ago the art dealer Richard L. Feigen attended an auction of European paintings at Sotheby’s in London and found a picture he liked: a richly colored scene of a religious vision, with a hovering saint and four angels, all topped by shimmering gold halos, that was attributed to a minor Italian painter.

headline: For Fannie Stock, Even Betting Pennies Is a Risk
text: It is flotsam of the housing wreck, a stock no longer worthy of the Big Board. But penny by penny, the mortgage giant Fannie Mae is being salvaged in the stock market, The New York Times’s David Gillen reports.

headline: Colorado Candidate Warns of Bicycle Plot
text: The front-runner for the Republican nomination in the Colorado governor’s race is causing a stir with claims that his likely Democratic opponent, Mayor John Hickenlooper of Denver, is bringing the city under United Nations control by promoting bike riding and other sustainability measures.

headline: "Recall" by Truth
text: A commercial, called "Recall," is part of a new campaign for the Truth anti-smoking effort that revives a fake product, Shards O'Glass.

headline: This Summer’s Hamptons
text: SILHOUETTED against a dying sun on a late July evening, more than a dozen Hamptons regulars eased into the warm darkness of Sagaponack Pond.

headline: Avant-Garde Director Gathers Rats Into a Wagnerian Maze
text: BAYREUTH, Germany  It has become practically a part of the tradition at the Bayreuth Festival for the director of an avant-garde Wagner production to be vociferously booed on opening night. So it was on July 25, when the festival opened with the new Hans Neuenfels production of “Lohengrin,” which I saw here on Tuesday, the second performance.

headline: Google Acquires Slide, Maker of Social Apps
text: Google has acquired Slide, the start-up that makes apps for social networking Web sites, according to two sources briefed on the deal.

headline: Fox To Make Nigel Lythgoe’s ‘Idol’ Return Official
text: Fox and the production companies behind “American Idol” are expected to announce Wednesday that Nigel Lythgoe will return to the show as an executive producer, a person with knowledge of his hiring said.

headline: Turkey and Israel Do a Brisk Business
text: ISTANBUL — Israeli business executives here like to point out that most of the angry Turks who protested Israel’s deadly raid on a Turkish-led flotilla to Gaza this past spring do not know that their cellphones, personal computers and plasma televisions were made using parts and technology from Tel Aviv.

headline: Laptop and Piano, Dispelling Traditions
text: Tune in to any pop radio station today, and the ubiquity of electronic music is evident in the Auto-Tune vocals and programmed beats of even the most banal hit single. Listen closely, and you realize that gifted pop producers routinely turn out sophisticated orchestrations that surpass the reckonings of avant-garde prophets like Busoni, Varèse and Stockhausen.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Vacuuming Robots
text: In this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast we ask: How smart can a vacuum robot be? J.D. Biersdorfer and Sam Grobart, deputy editor of the Times Home section, get on the ground with the Neato XV-11.

headline: NCAPS
text: How I Saved My Company | Reaching out directly to the client base

headline: Ravi Coltrane Signs With Blue Note
text: Ravi Coltrane, the highly regarded tenor and soprano saxophonist, is the newest addition to the roster of Blue Note Records, with an album due out next spring. His signing unites the most storied label in jazz, one of the last majors standing, with a saxophonist-bandleader from an imposing lineage: Mr. Coltrane’s father was John Coltrane, who similarly played tenor and soprano, reshaping the language of jazz improvisation from the mid-1950s up to his death in 1967.

headline: A Sly Lead Succeeds in the Heat Down South
text: When you’re hot, you’re hot  especially in New Orleans at the just completed Summer North American Championships, where the thermometer flirted with 100 degrees most days.

headline: The Mystery and Majesty of the Number 600
text: Six hundred: a six followed by two zeroes. Just a number, and not even a prime number or anything like that. But in baseball, it is a milestone — though for a while, as one of the Yankees’ YES Network commentators said on Wednesday, it seemed to be a millstone around Alex Rodriguez’s neck. And then he passed it. On to 700.

headline: White House Praise for Moynihan Continues
text: From a Q. & A. session between The Charlotte Observer and Michael S. Barr, an assistant Treasury secretary:

headline: A Texas Address Migrates
text: KATHY and Scott Formby, a husband-and-wife design team in New York, have started a new line of women’s clothing and accessories called no.1808. The name is taken from the address of an elegant, eccentric Texas home that has been in Mr. Formby’s family for years.

headline: Old and New
text: DAVID ZWIRNER, the blue-chip gallery with three locations in Chelsea, is opening a pop-up bookstore next week, from Aug. 9 to 13, that will feature rare and out-of-print books and new artist catalogs.

headline: Think Green and Young
text: LORETTA GENDVILLE is a mini-mogul. Her first Area Kids store opened in 2005 in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. She now has nine stores, including a new one (above) in Manhattan, at 55 West 14th Street, (212) 229-1700. She offers eco-friendly and locally made toys and clothing.

headline: Delta to Move at Kennedy as End Nears for Old Home
text: Delta Air Lines is set to decamp from its squat, crowded and much-maligned terminal at Kennedy International Airport and take up residence in an adjacent space that will undergo a $1.2 billion renovation and expansion.

headline: Happy Birthday, Mr. President
text: With President Obama turning 49 today, both parties’ national committees are seizing on his birthday to cash in.

headline: Jack Griffin To Succeed Ann Moore At Time Inc.
text: The shake-up of the magazine industry’s corner offices will continue next week as Time Warner is expected to announce that Jack Griffin, the former Meredith Corporation executive, will become chief executive at Time Inc., succeeding Ann S. Moore.

headline: Google Kills Wave, Its Collaboration Tool
text: Google Wave was one of Google’s most prominent new services. Now it is one of its most prominent flops.

headline: In Battle Over Mosque, a Defender of Architecture
text: In the tsunami of hubbub over the Landmarks Preservation Commission’s decision Tuesday not to grant landmark status a building near ground zero that is now to be demolished to make way for an Islamic community center and mosque, little attention has been paid to the actual landmark-worthiness of the building under consideration.

headline: W.N.B.A. Signs Jamba Juice as New Sponsor
text: The smoothie retailer Jamba Juice has made its first investment in a national sports league by signing a multi-year deal to sponsor the W.N.B.A.

headline: Hamptons Hot Spots of the Season
text: Drinks, dinner or dancing? Stand-up paddling yoga, anyone?

headline: More Evidence That Group Tied to Mumbai Attacks Provides Aid in Pakistan
text: As Pakistan’s government struggles to provide aid to about three million Pakistanis displaced by flooding, foreign correspondents continue to find evidence that the aid vacuum is being filled by militant Islamist groups, including one that is run by the founder of a banned militant group held responsible for the Mumbai terror attacks in 2008.

headline: Giuliani’s Daughter, 20, Is Arrested
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s 20-year-old daughter was arrested on Wednesday after workers in an Upper East Side cosmetics store caught her stuffing makeup worth more than $100 into her coat pocket, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Method’s Single-Handed Soap Dispenser
text: The cleaning-products company Method is updating its range, aiming to keep every corner of the home spotless — and equipped with sculptural bottles. The new line of dishwashing soap ($3) is notable. “We had been trying to crack dish soap for years,” said Eric Ryan, one of the company’s founders.

headline: Sales at Jonathan Adler, M2L and Design Within Reach
text: During Jonathan Adler’s first rug sale, through Aug. 15, all rugs including custom orders are 20 percent off (the 8-by-10-foot Greek Key, regularly $2,200, is $1,760; the 4-by-6 Lollipop, regularly $650, is $520; and the 8-by-10 Pat Nixon, regularly $2,200, is $1,760); for information and locations: (800) 963-0891 or jonathanadler.com.

headline: An Area Store in the East Village
text: Anki Spets, who 20 years ago founded a line called Area known mainly for its bed linens, has finally opened a store of her own. “A lot of my retail outlets closed in the past couple years,” Ms. Spets said. “Which meant the time was right for me to open a retail store.” Area’s 2,000 square feet, complete with a mezzanine that doubles as Ms. Spets’s design studio, showcases the full range of the company’s bed linens — sheets, blankets and quilts (for adults and babies), as well as throw pillows, beds and bedside tables. There’s also a small selection of kitchen items in simple, modern shapes by the industrial designer Magnus Lundstrom, her husband. They include cutting boards of walnut, oak or maple; peppermills of porcelain and walnut; and mortar and pestle sets. Prices range from $10 for a kitchen towel to $4,300 for a king bed. Area, 58 East 11th Street (Broadway), (212) 924-7084 or areahome.com.

headline: Christophe Pillet’s Unintrusive Outdoor Umbrella
text: Those who need a break from the summer sun, but dislike the ungainly look of many patio umbrellas, may prefer the minimalist Shade, created by the Paris-based designer Christophe Pillet for the Italian outdoor furniture company Emu. It is a study in simplicity. “The detailing is elegant, as opposed to clunky and chunky,” said Tom Dilillo, a spokesman for the furniture company Coalesse, which recently introduced the umbrella in the United States. The pared down aluminum frame, he said, is designed to withstand years of use.

headline: Architect Carlos Ott on Playa Vik in Uruguay
text: The architect Carlos Ott, above, is known for sweeping structures of steel and glass designed for wealthy corporate clients in places like Dubai. But this month he completed a rare residential project, Playa Vik, in his native Uruguay. It is a beachside retreat on the José Ignacio peninsula, with a center structure surrounded by six casitas. It was built for a family, but can be rented as a private retreat.

headline: Sandy Chilewich’s RayTray
text: Sandy Chilewich’s RayTray was originally released in 1997; it was discontinued in 2000. Ten years later, it is about to make its return. Ms. Chilewich is known for her innovative use of textiles in everyday items; true to that, the 19-inch-tall RayTray’s sloping stainless-steel frame holds three separate trays, made of a flexible nylon-Lycra blend. The tiered trays, which are removable and machine-washable, allow fruit and vegetables (or whatever other food they’re holding) to breathe. “I was inspired by the idea of making a container entirely out of fabric,” Ms. Chilewich said, “because I love stretching the limits of what material can do.” Available in black/smoke/off-white, green and off-white, the RayTray ($125) goes on sale Sept. 8 on chilewich.com; orders will be taken on the site starting Aug. 16.

headline: Pressed-Glass Chandeliers by Elizabeth Lyons
text: Elizabeth Lyons’s new pressed-glass chandeliers, which she makes by hand, are a result of an unlikely inspiration: her collection of vintage kitchen objects like pizzelle presses, drain grates and cast-iron hot plates.

headline: Making Arrangements
text: Scenes from the Little Flower School’s wildflower-arranging class in Brooklyn.

headline: Flower Arranging Finds a Younger Audience
text: THE first time I bought flowers for myself was about five years ago at the Greenmarket in Union Square, in the midst of the hottest, dullest days of summer. Feeling very alone that afternoon for a reason now forgotten, I stood admiring some tulips. For $8 they could be mine. I was in my mid-20s and it seemed like such a luxury to buy myself flowers for no reason, no occasion. But that day I had the money in my wallet, and soon I was carrying the tulips home. I stuck them in a glass pitcher and watched them bloom, until their stems bowed and swept the tabletop and the petals all dropped off.

headline: Moss Mountain Farm
text: P. Allen Smith, author of gardening and home-entertaining books and host of his own public-television series, lives on a 650-acre estate near Little Rock, Ark.

headline: The Martha Stewart of the South
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

headline: Counter-Cyclical Politics
text: Our sib-blog Green reports that Dan Maes, a Republican candidate for governor in Colorado, has claimed that the Democrat in the race, Denver Mayor John Hickenlooper, is leading the city toward United Nations control by encouraging the use of bicycles and otherwise rolling with the sustainable development crowd.

headline: Portrait of Pain Ignites Debate Over Afghan War
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  She cannot read or write and had never heard of Time magazine until a visitor brought her a copy of this week’s issue, the one with  the cover picture of her face, the face with no nose.

headline: As Chase to 600 Ends, Pressure Is Still On
text: It’s a number. A nice round number, but still, just a number.

headline: A-Rod Fill-In
text: Directions: Here’s a fun way to recognize Alex Rodriguez’s entry to the 600 club. Fill in the blanks in the first 10 paragraphs of the article “Rodriguez Hits 600th Career Home Run.”

headline: Ex-Meredith Officer to Be Time’s Chief
text: The shake-up of the magazine industry’s corner offices will continue next week as Time Warner is expected to announce that Jack Griffin, the former Meredith Corporation executive, will become chief executive at Time Inc., succeeding Ann S. Moore.

headline: Taking the Pulse of a Swing County in Colorado
text: Larimer County, Colo., went Democratic in 2008, but insecurity over the economy may sway the results of next week’s primary.

headline: Shopping With Doug Meyer
text: The designer scoured Manhattan for rugs that can define an outdoor space.

headline: Still in the Time of Economic Anxiety
text: To the Editor:

headline: Outdoor Rugs
text: DOUG MEYER, a Kentucky native, splits his time between New York and Miami, where he has owned four homes, all with pools — something that makes him, he said, an expert on outdoor living.

headline: Joe Simon Named Chief Technology Officer of Condé Nast
text: Condé Nast continued its retooling on Wednesday with the appointment of Joe Simon as chief technology officer. Mr. Simon, 48, was previously chief technology officer for Viacom.

headline: Conserving Creativity, Cow Bones Included
text: As a conservator specializing in sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art since 1984, Lynda A. Zycherman, 61, has applied a preservationist’s touch to sculpture composed of every conceivable material: marble, bronze, steel, textiles, chocolate and  once was enough  three tons of cow bones imported from Italy. Ms. Zycherman deemed the bones unsanitary and sent them to Oklahoma to be pickled before allowing a Marina Abramovic sculpture to go on display recently. Widowed with two grown children, she lives on the Upper West Side.

headline: The ADL, the Mosque and the Fight Against Bigotry
text: To the Editor:

headline: Voters in Colorado Swing With the Economy
text: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  Two years ago, as the election season roared toward November, people here in northern Colorado feared the economy was headed for a cliff. They sought refuge in voting for Democrats in numbers not seen in generations.

headline: Veterans and Suicide
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clip: 'The Disappearance of Alice Creed'
text: An exclusive clip from "The Disappearance of Alice Creed," with Eddie Marsan and Martin Compston.

headline: The Causes of Food-Borne Illness
text: To the Editor:

headline: What That 401(k) Costs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sorry, No Cake for the President’s 49th Birthday
text: CHICAGO  Let’s face it, turning 49 is no fun. Especially when your wife and children are not around to celebrate. But to have the birthday cake scratched by the Secret Service?

headline: Before and After: Turning a Spare Room Into an Indian Sanctuary
text: Vicente Wolf, a designer known for his pale interiors, turned a plain room in a Manhattan apartment into a fuchsia-saturated space on a budget of $5,000.

headline: Tips From Europe on I.P.O. for G.M.
text: The Obama administration should brush up on recent European financial history. That could help it pitch the coming initial public offering of General Motors. If the I.P.O. is priced too high and flops, it will be much harder for the government to offload the rest of its shares without losing money in future sales. But if G.M.’s stock market debut is priced too low and shares surge, the White House would risk accusations of favoring Wall Street at the expense of taxpayers.

headline: Oil Spill Cleanup Workers Include Many Very, Very Small Ones
text: Among the hidden stars of the gulf cleanup is an oil-hungry bacterium that Dr. Seuss could have named  Alcanivorax. It and fellow microbes are breaking down a significant amount of the oil that gushed into the environment from BP’s runaway well, scientists say. The microbial feasting is known as biodegradation.

headline: What the River Dragged In
text: Traverse City, Mich.

headline: Promising Results Reported for Cholesterol and Hepatitis C Drugs
text: New drugs for hepatitis C and superhigh cholesterol succeeded in late-stage clinical trials, the developers of the products announced on Wednesday. But both drugs have side effects that could dampen sales, analysts said.

headline: Vicente Wolf Creates an Indian Sanctuary in Kips Bay
text: FOUR years ago, after selling her weekend home in Amagansett, Harrice Miller, a dealer in and historian of costume jewelry, began reexamining her life.

headline: Toyota Recovers From a Slump to Report a $2.2 Billion Profit
text: TOKYO  Despite a strong yen and the lingering fallout from recalls, the automaker Toyota said Wednesday that it had returned to a profit in the April-to-June quarter because of strong sales in emerging markets and aggressive cost-cutting.

headline: Samba Bands Yes, Vuvuzelas No
text: Before the World Cup final in Johannesburg last month, Danny Jordaan, the chief executive of the 2010 organizing committee, issued a warning to soccer fans around the world.

headline: In Fire Country
text: You fall asleep on a summer night bound for the mind’s winter pantry, a memory to be opened  in some dark, cold day as an anti-depressant.  Windless.  Warm. The lake in glassy repose.  The mountains in silvery silhouette lit by the moon.  Sleep is deep. You control your fate.

headline: The Weight at the Plate
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Framing the Afghan Debate With a Magazine Cover
text: Not only has President Obama found flagging support among Democrats on the U.S. troop buildup in Afghanistan, the recent disclosure by WikiLeaks of military documents which paint a bleak picture of the war has added to skepticism about the buildup of forces, the progress made so far, and whether the goals of U.S. policy are realistic or achievable.

headline: Favre Tries to Put the Rumors to Rest, Saying He’ll Play if He’s Healthy
text: The latest development in the Brett Favre retirement drama came Wednesday morning, from Favre himself.

headline: Woods, Still Winless, Returns to the Right Place for a Victory
text: AKRON, Ohio  Wearing a goatee and his game face, Tiger Woods was all business when he showed up Wednesday at Firestone Country Club. In his first meeting with the news media since he tied for 23rd in the British Open at St. Andrews, Woods looked both rested and ready and left no doubt about the confidence he is bringing to his latest title defense, a W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational event that he has won seven times.

headline: Phelps Finds His Form With Two Victories
text: IRVINE, Calif.  While resting this week for his swim races, Michael Phelps watched the Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez strain.

headline: Ryan and Mark Cuban Start Texas Showdown in the Rangers’ Auction
text: FORT WORTH  For nearly six hours, the packed bankruptcy courtroom awaited the first bid in the auction of the Texas Rangers. Finally, it came, at about 3 p.m. Wednesday, from Mark Cuban, the outspoken Dallas Mavericks owner, and his partner, Jim Crane.

headline: Violence Said to Be Rising in Sudan’s Darfur Region
text: UNITED NATIONS  Violence in the turbulent Darfur region of Sudan has spiked over the past several months, Alain Le Roy, the head of United Nations peacekeeping operations, said Wednesday. He attributed the increase to a combination of factors, including fitful peace talks, renewed tribal rivalries and overall tension in Africa’s largest nation as its south prepares for an independence referendum.

headline: U.S. Coach Picks Veteran Team for What May Be His Finale
text: For what may be his final game as United States coach, Bob Bradley chose many of the same players he took to South Africa for the World Cup.

headline: Ex-Deloitte Partner and Son Settle Insider Trading Claims
text: A former Deloitte & Touche partner and his son will pay more than $1.1 million to settle claims they illegally traded on inside information about the audit firm’s clients, federal regulators said on Wednesday.

headline: Campaigning to the Choir
text: Russellville, Tenn.

headline: I.R.S. Shifts to Combat Tax Evasion
text: The Internal Revenue Service said Wednesday that it would overhaul a unit devoted to scrutinizing large corporations and wealthy individuals, a shift that would bolster the agency’s growing focus on international tax evasion.

headline: Google Will Sell Brand Names as Keywords in Europe
text: PARIS  The Internet giant Google said on Wednesday that it would change its search policy for most of Europe to allow advertisers to buy and use as keywords terms that have been trademarked by others.

headline: Show Me Your Insiders
text: Missouri just went to the polls! Perhaps some of you didn’t notice because you were on vacation this week. Or watering your hydrangea. This is a tough time of the year for hydrangeas. Their little leaves begin to shrivel, and before you know it, there’s a large wilted bush studded with pompons and you’ve missed the Missouri primary.

headline: Google and Verizon Near Deal on Web Pay Tiers
text: WASHINGTON  Google and Verizon, two leading players in Internet service and content, are nearing an agreement that could allow Verizon to speed some online content to Internet users more quickly if the content’s creators are willing to pay for the privilege.

headline: Maxine Waters Seeks Speedy Ethics Review
text: Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, frustrated that the start of her ethics trial has not even been scheduled, urged the House ethics committee on Wednesday to formally release a list of charges that have been filed against her and to accelerate any trial so that her case can be resolved before the November election.

headline: Football Provides Relief For Jets’ New Receiver
text: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Santonio Holmes looked exuberant on the practice field Wednesday, as if his absence for the first three days of Jets training camp had provided a measure of relief. His debut seemed like more than a routine practice, transforming a normally dreary August afternoon into the most welcomed of distractions.

headline: 13 Facts About No. 13
text: Alex Rodriguez has become the seventh player and the youngest member of the 600 Club. A-Rod joins Barry Bonds (762), Hank Aaron (755), Babe Ruth (714), Willie Mays (660), Ken Griffey Jr. (630) and Sammy Sosa (609). Ruth had been the youngest to hit 600, reaching the mark in 1931 at 36 years, 196 days. Rodriguez is just eight days past his 35th birthday. Both Ruth and Rodriguez hit No. 600 wearing a Yankee uniform.

headline: Too Early and Bad Location: Milestone Homer Has Its Critics
text: Yankees fans were understandably happy to see Alex Rodriguez hit his 600th home run on Wednesday afternoon. But not everyone was particularly thrilled about when or where he hit it.

headline: As It Shrinks, the Dead Sea Nourishes Promises of an Economic Bloom
text: KALIA, West Bank  For many, the shrinking of the Dead Sea has long signaled its impending demise. But even with its waters steadily disappearing, the ancient salt lake, where no fish can survive, is showing other signs of life.

headline: Senator to Review Accreditation of For-Profit Colleges
text: As part of the expanding Congressional scrutiny of for-profit colleges, Senator Tom Harkin announced at a hearing on Wednesday that he plans to examine their accreditation process.

headline: Marriage Is a Constitutional Right
text: Until Wednesday, the thousands of same-sex couples who have married did so because a state judge or Legislature allowed them to. The nation’s most fundamental guarantees of freedom, set out in the Constitution, were not part of the equation. That has changed with the historic decision by a federal judge in California, Vaughn Walker, that said his state’s ban on same-sex marriage violated the 14th Amendment’s rights to equal protection and due process of law.

headline: Condé Nast Names a Chief Technology Officer
text: Condé Nast continued its retooling on Wednesday with the appointment of Joe Simon as chief technology officer. Mr. Simon, 48, was previously chief technology officer for Viacom Inc.

headline: A Tough Birthday for Obama
text: WASHINGTON – Let’s face it, turning 49 is no fun. Especially when your wife and children aren’t around to celebrate. But to have the birthday cake scratched by the Secret Service?

headline: Start Poor, Spread ‘Glee,’ Then Try ‘Eat Pray Love’
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Outsourcing to India Draws Western Lawyers
text: NOIDA, India — As an assistant attorney general for New York State, Christopher Wheeler used to spend most of his time arguing in courtrooms in New York City.

headline: Wyclef Jean Confirms Plans to Run for Haitian Presidency
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Wyclef Jean, a Haitian-American hip-hop artist who left his homeland for Brooklyn at the age of 9, confirmed Wednesday that he planned to run for president of this earthquake-battered country.

headline: Diversity Debate Convulses Elite High School
text: With one of its alumnae, Elena Kagan, poised for confirmation as a justice on the United States Supreme Court, it should be a triumphant season for Hunter College High School, a New York City public school for the intellectually gifted.

headline: Cyclists Said to Back Claims That Armstrong Doped
text: Federal prosecutors have intensified their criminal investigation of the cyclist Lance Armstrong since the end of the Tour de France last month. They questioned many of his former associates, including cyclists who have supported and detailed claims that Armstrong and his former United States Postal Service team participated in systematic doping, according to a cyclist who has been interviewed and two others privy to the inquiry.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Happy-Go-Lucky’
text: Mike Leigh, director of “Happy-Go-Lucky,” narrates and explains one of the scenes from the film that is now on DVD.

headline: A Go-to Actor for ‘That Guy’ Roles
text: LONDON

headline: Oil Rig’s Owner Had Safety Issue at Three Other Wells
text: The company that owned the oil rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in April had widespread safety concerns about several of its other rigs in the gulf, and a month before the disaster it commissioned a broad review of the safety culture of the company’s North American operations, according to confidential internal reports.

headline: For Internet Travel Sites, a New Hotel Room Tax
text: Tourists visiting New York State who book their hotel rooms through travel agencies and Web sites like Expedia or Orbitz may face higher prices after state lawmakers passed legislation requiring the booking industry to collect sales tax on lodging.

headline: Meadowlands Is a Vuvuzela-Free Zone
text: Before the World Cup final in Johannesburg last month, Danny Jordaan, the chief executive of the 2010 organizing committee, issued a warning to soccer fans around the world.

headline: Lawyers Win Right to Aid U.S. Target
text: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department on Wednesday granted permission to a group of human rights lawyers who want to file a lawsuit on behalf of a radical Muslim cleric thought to be hiding in Yemen. The Obama administration has authorized killing the cleric as a terrorist despite his American citizenship.

headline: Oil Spill Calculations Stir Debate on Damage
text: The Obama administration’s latest report on the Gulf of Mexico disaster set off a war of words Wednesday among scientists, Gulf Coast residents and political pundits about what to make of the Deepwater Horizon spill and its aftermath.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Gulf, Good News Is Taken With Grain of Salt
text: NEW ORLEANS  There is little celebration on the Gulf Coast.

headline: Gaston Has Seen No. 600, Twice
text: Asked after Tuesday’s game about Alex Rodriguez’s increasingly frustrating quest for 600 home runs, Manager Joe Girardi pointed out that neither he nor anyone on the Yankees had ever been stuck at 599 home runs.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 4
text: A view of the day in sports, including Alex Rodriguez’s 600th home run.

headline: Beltran to Stay in Center Field, for Now
text: ATLANTA  Both Jerry Manuel and Carlos Beltran were surprised to hear that the Angels had moved the Gold Glove center fielder Torii Hunter to right field, and do not expect the Mets to make a similar move during the season with Beltran.

headline: President Awards Civilian Service Medals
text: President Obama presented 13 people – including a woman who went on to help Afghan widows after losing her husband on Sept. 11, 2001 – with the Presidential Citizens Medal at the White House on Wednesday.

headline: For Cuomo, Foretaste of a Bitter Ideological Divide
text: ALBANY  For Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, the arduous budget battle that was concluded on Tuesday with the passage of one of the tardiest budgets in state history could serve as a preview of next year.

headline: Netherlands: Court Clears Way for Model to Testify at Taylor Trial
text: Judges at the war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, turned down an effort to delay the appearance of the model Naomi Campbell, left, scheduled for Thursday in The Hague. Mr. Taylor’s defense had argued that prosecutors had not provided a full statement of Ms. Campbell’s planned testimony. The judges rejected the motion on Wednesday, saying that Ms. Campbell, a hostile witness, had been “uncooperative” and that prosecutors could not be expected to provide such a statement from her. Ms. Campbell was subpoenaed to testify whether Mr. Taylor had sent her a gift of rough diamonds after they met at a charity dinner in 1997 in South Africa. Prosecutors hope to show that Mr. Taylor lied under oath when he said that he never had any diamonds and did not trade any for weapons to support the bloody rampage by rebels in Sierra Leone during the country’s civil war.

headline: Dr. Robert M. Chanock, Prominent Virologist, Dies at 86
text: Dr. Robert M. Chanock, a pediatrician whose discoveries of viruses led to far-reaching improvements in preventing and treating common respiratory illnesses, particularly among children, died Friday in Sykesville, Md. He was 86.

headline: Health Care Reform, British Style
text: The National Health Service is the third rail of British politics. Britons cherish the historic achievement of bringing decent medical care within everyone’s reach, while complaining regularly about the bureaucratic rigidity  and bristling at any suggestion of change.

headline: Russia: Chechen Rebel Leader Reverses Resignation
text: Doku Umarov, a Chechen rebel leader who has claimed responsibility for a string of deadly terrorist attacks in Russia, said in an Internet video posting that he would not step down as the leader of an Islamist insurgent network in the North Caucasus region, reversing an earlier announcement. “Given the current situation in the Caucasus, I believe that it is impossible to resign from my post,” Mr. Umarov said in the video, which was posted to a separatist Web site on Wednesday. In his earlier statement, he claimed to have been in poor health. But in the latest video, with his arm resting on the barrel of an automatic rifle, he said, “My health, thanks to Allah, by the will of Allah, is good.”

headline: Not Too Much Ethics, Please
text: House Republicans are chortling over the Democratic majority’s troubles with ethics allegations, but they also are ominously signaling their distaste for the Office of Congressional Ethics  the one new player on Capitol Hill with a clear determination to do something about the morass.

headline: The Senate Balks Again
text: Elouise Cobell’s longstanding lawsuit against the Interior Department was settled in December. The settlement brought victory  and, she thought, $3.4 billion  to half a million American Indians who had been cheated of proceeds from lands that had once been theirs.

headline: Run Through the Middle
text: ONCE upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered weak and weary,Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore, …

headline: Senate Debate Looms on Tax Cuts for Rich
text: WASHINGTON  Senate leaders said Wednesday that debate would most likely begin in September over whether to let the Bush income tax cuts for the rich expire at the end of this year as scheduled, setting up a new battle just weeks before the midterm elections.

headline: Voters in Missouri Oppose Health Law
text: Missouri voters on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a measure intended to nullify the new federal health care law, becoming the first state in the nation where ordinary people made known their dismay over the issue at the ballot box.

headline: Remembering Lives Lost in a Warehouse Rampage
text: MANCHESTER, Conn.  They were burly men who supported their families with an all-American pursuit: getting kegs and cases of Budweiser from the warehouse to store shelves and saloons. Husbands and fathers, even a grandfather among them, they had collectively held their jobs for well over a century at a family-owned business that had been remarkably stable.

headline: Maybe the Race Goes to Those Not Running
text: With many voters revolting against politics as usual and gravitating toward new political faces, one United States Senate candidate may have discovered a powerful new way to campaign: stop campaigning. At least until two weeks before the election.

headline: No Charges After Inquiry of Lawmaker
text: Don Young, Alaska’s sole representative in the House, said Wednesday that his lawyers had been informed by the Department of Justice that he would not be prosecuted after years of being investigated as part of a wide-ranging corruption inquiry.

headline: Reginald Levy Is Dead at 88; Hailed as a Hero in a ’72 Hijacking
text: Reginald Levy, who as captain of a hijacked Belgian airliner in 1972 was hailed as a hero for enabling Israeli commandos to storm the plane and rescue all 100 passengers and crew members, died Sunday at a hospital near his home in Dover, England. He was 88.

headline: Day 106: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Static Kill of the Gulf Oil Well Is Called a Success

headline: In Same-Sex Ruling, an Eye on the Supreme Court
text: A federal judge’s forceful opinion Wednesday in favor of same-sex marriage is only the beginning of a process that is likely to go all the way to the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Young Residents on Staten Island Try to Make Sense of a Spate of Violence
text: Arianna Rodriguez, a bright and verbose 11-year-old, was bravely attempting to explain the swirl of race and class divisions, immigration politics and bewildering violence that had swamped Port Richmond, her neighborhood on Staten Island. Finally, she sighed and threw up her hands.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: In Huge Game, Four Big Mets Errors
text: ATLANTA  There are times when it seems as if nothing can bring out the worst in the Mets like playing at Turner Field. It is where they have suffered numerous ugly defeats, where a playoff series was lost on a bases-loaded walk, where Scott Kazmir was traded for an injured pitcher, and where so many pennant chases came to their virtual close.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Islamic Triumphalism?
text: Joshua Cohen, left, of Stanford University and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate the mosque near ground zero.

headline: Quality Road Is Favored
text: Quality Road, undefeated in three starts this year and ranked as the nation’s leading male thoroughbred, was made the 2-5 morning line favorite for Saturday’s Whitney Invitational at Saratoga Race Course. Quality Road drew the No. 3 post in a six-horse field for the $750,000, one-and-one-eighth-mile Grade I race. The 4-year-old colt trained by Todd Pletcher will be ridden by John Velazquez.

headline: Grants for Education Are Awarded
text: Teach for America and the KIPP Foundation, which runs a nationwide network of charter schools, each won $50 million in a $650 million federal grant competition known as Investing in Innovation, the Department of Education said Wednesday. The Success for All Foundation, a Baltimore group that helps to turn around troubled elementary schools, won $49 million. Ohio State University, partnered with several other universities, was awarded $46 million to train about 3,750 teachers in the Reading Recovery approach, intended for struggling first-grade students.

headline: Word of the Day | expletive
text: expletive •\ˈek-splə-tiv\• noun

headline: Obama’s Birthday Dinner With Oprah
text: CHICAGO – The ladies of “The View” may have gotten him on the set, but Oprah got him for the birthday.

headline: News Quiz | August 5, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Asian Shares Fall on Signs of Fitful U.S. Recovery
text: Most Asian stock markets rose Thursday as economic data relieved worries about a second recession in the world’s biggest economy but gains were modest ahead of a closely watched United States  jobs report.

headline: CenturyLink and Qwest Top Estimates
text: Qwest Communications International, the phone company being acquired by CenturyLink, said Wednesday that its second-quarter profit declined 25 percent as it lost home-phone subscribers.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Open Up Proxy Access
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to pass a proxy access rule that would give large shareholders the right to directly nominate directors on corporate ballots alongside the company’s choices, with the cost being borne by the company, The Wall Street Journal said.

headline: Buffett Gets in a Bind Over Options
text: One small change in the law could make Warren Buffett‘s billion dollar bet on global equity markets look less like a winner, Reuters reports.

headline: HSBC Subject of U.S. Money Laundering Inquiry
text: American authorities are investigating the United States division of the global banking group, HSBC, over its compliance with anti-money laundering procedures, according to a regulatory filing, Reuters reports.

headline: Texas Rangers Sold at Auction
text: FORT WORTH  When the bankruptcy auction of the Texas Rangers ended early Thursday morning after a nearly 16-hour slog, the team was in the hands of Nolan Ryan and Chuck Greenberg, who were all along the preferred buyers by Major League Baseball.

headline: I.R.S. Shifts to Combat Tax Evasion Overseas
text: The Internal Revenue Service said Wednesday that it would overhaul a unit devoted to scrutinizing large corporations and wealthy individuals, a shift that would bolster the agency’s growing focus on international tax evasion, Lynnley Browning reports in The New York Times.

headline: Model Testifies at War Crimes Trial
text: THE HAGUE — The supermodel Naomi Campbell appeared Thursday at the war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, and testified that she had been given a pouch containing “very small, dirty-looking stones” after she met Mr. Taylor at a dinner with Nelson Mandela in South Africa 13 years ago.

headline: Continuing Rain Slows Flood Aid in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani military commander said Thursday that hundreds of villages along the Indus River remained submerged from flooding over the past week as concern grew that high waters could soon reach the south of the country.

headline: China Said to Conduct its Own Stress Tests
text: China’s banking regulator told lenders last month to conduct a new round of stress tests to gauge the impact of residential property prices falling as much as 60 percent in the hardest-hit markets, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Merkin Wants Madoff Feeder Lawsuit Dismissed
text: The hedge fund manager, J. Ezra Merkin, asked a United States judge to dismiss a class-action lawsuit accusing him of recklessly funneling millions of dollars in client funds to the now-imprisoned Ponzi schemer Bernard Madoff, Reuters reported.

headline: South Korea Begins Naval Exercises
text: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea kicked off one of its largest-ever naval exercises on Thursday in waters near a disputed western sea border with North Korea, despite the North’s threat to retaliate by attacking the South’s warships participating in the drill.

headline: Motorola Shares Up on Icahn Stake Raise
text: Shares in Motorola rose 6 percent on Wednesday after the billionaire investor,  Carl C. Icahn,  said he had raised his stake in the company to 9.9 percent from 8.75 percent, Reuters reported.

headline: Warner Brothers Said Set to Buy Shed Media
text: Warner Brothers is set to buy the British television production company Shed Media, maker of such programs as Supernanny and The Choir, for around £100 million ($158 million) to boost its presence in the key market, Reuters reported.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Wheeldom

headline: A Ruling on Same-Sex Marriage

headline: Venture Capital’s Next Generation
text: Lawrence Aragon, editor in chief of the Thomson Reuters publication The Venture Capital Journal, has compiled a list of 10 young venture capitalists who, he says, “are poised to do great things.”

headline: Kenyans Approve New Constitution
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  With a new Constitution overwhelmingly approved by voters, Kenyan politicians are now talking excitedly about their country’s golden future.

headline: In Afghanistan, a Personal Perspective
text: Dima Gavrysh, who was born in Ukraine, is a New York-based photographer. He has photographed for a number of major publications worldwide and collaborated with Doctors Without Borders and the United Nations Population Fund in Uganda, Senegal and Niger. For his most recent project, he spent last summer with the United States Army in Afghanistan for The Associated Press.

headline: Commerzbank Posts Profit and Raises Outlook
text: Commerzbank, the second-largest lender in Germany after Deutsche Bank, said Thursday that it had earned 352 million euros, or $463 million, in the second quarter as loan loss provisions shrunk, the German economy recovered and it booked a tax credit. The bank also raised its outlook, saying it expected to turn a profit for the year.

headline: Greek Debt Tests Results to Be Released
text: The European Commission, International Monetary Fund and European Central Bank will outline the results of an inspection Thursday that will determine whether debt-ridden Greece will receive the second installment of rescue loans to keep it from bankruptcy, The Associated Press reported.

headline: G.I.C. Said to Add Three Banks to Logistics Unit’s I.P.O.
text: The Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, the sovereign wealth fund known as G.I.C., has added three banks as joint bookrunners for the upcoming initial public offering of its logistics unit that could raise as much as $3 billion, Reuters reported, citing two sources familiar with the deal.

headline: China Fund Lines Up Cash for Liverpool
text: The China Investment Corporation, the sovereign wealth fund represented by Kenny Huang, has lined up the cash needed to purchase Liverpool Football Club in Britain, The Guardian reports.

headline: What Is Your Favorite Ice Cream Flavor?
text: By CARRIE MONTGOMERY

headline: Mumbai Film Festival Highlights World Classics
text: It’s not just in the United States that classic single-screen movie theaters have become an endangered species, steadily replaced by nearly interchangeable multiplexes. Most of the legendary cinema halls where Mumbaikars of a certain age first fell in love with movies have either ceased operations, been subdivided into smaller rooms, or primarily screen B-movies or regional films. But one of these celebrated halls, Edward Cinema, seems to be trapped in time. And an ongoing film festival is a great reason to visit.

headline: Fantasy Rookies in Context: Part I, Runners and Passers
text: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he pens The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

headline: More Than 30 Billionaires to Halve Their Fortunes
text: David Rockefeller, Ronald Perelman, Larry Ellison, Sanford Weill, Ted Turner and Paul Allen joined a pledge started by Warren Buffett for billionaires to give more than half their wealth to charity, Bloomberg News reported.

text: — Yves Smith follows up on the foreclosure mill story by digging deeper into how mortgages are securitized: “The parties to securitization have so screwed up the procedures that they set up that it is pretty much impossible to foreclose (in the 45 of 50 states where the note is the critical element of the transaction) unless they forge documents.”

headline: A Dead Sea Debate Divides Yet Unifies
text: As I write in Thursday’s issue of The Times, the Dead Sea and its depleted waters have become a rare symbol of regional cooperation among the people that share its shores, which stretch across Israel, Jordan and the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Officials and activists in Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian Authority have joined forces in trying to find solutions to a drop in the water level of the salt lake even as diplomatic progress on other fronts has stalled.

headline: After Years of Inefficiency, Indonesia Emerges as an Economic Model
text: JAKARTA — After years of being known for inefficiency, corruption and instability, Indonesia is emerging from the global financial crisis with a surprising new reputation — economic golden child.

headline: Will Ferrell vs. Broadway: Round 2
text: On Wednesday night Will Ferrell brought his promotional tour for “The Other Guys” — a k a his one-man war on Broadway — to NBC’s “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” and people, it’s turning ugly. Not only did Mr. Ferrell continue to fail to apologize for his outrageous snub of Bernadette Peters, he also brought the fight to Kelsey Grammer, the neutral, non-aggressive co-star of “La Cage aux Folles.”

headline: Afghans Say NATO Strikes Killed Civilians
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO officials acknowledged preliminary reports that four to a dozen or more civilians were killed in a coalition airstrike Thursday in Nangarhar Province. Afghan accounts put the civilian deaths as high as 32.

headline: Sales Were Sluggish in July for Retailers
text: The second half of the year is off to a slow start for retailers, who reported Thursday that sales at stores open at least a year were weaker than expected in July, increasing 2.9 percent from July of last year, according to a tally by Thomson Reuters.

headline: Despite Losses, Asian Hedge Funds Draw Money
text: Hedge funds focusing on Asian investments experienced heavy losses in the second quarter, but that did not seem to deter investors from giving them more money.

headline: And Now for Someone Completely Indifferent: Terry Gilliam on Directing Arcade Fire
text: If you’re a big corporate sponsor, like, say, American Express, and you’re seeking a director to oversee Thursday night’s Web broadcast of a performance by Arcade Fire at Madison Square Garden (which will be streamed live on YouTube), you could presumably have your choice of talent, from up-and-coming music-video auteurs to established Hollywood hotshots.

headline: Spokes | Cities Engage in Vast Biking Conspiracy (Shh!)
text: Could bicycling around the city for fun and transport have a more insidious purpose? Could it be that all these networked bike lanes, spreading across the nation’s cities like falling dominoes, are actually part of a vast conspiracy by the United Nations to take over America’s urban spaces, and in the process, take away our “freedom”?

Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: Thursday Reading: Scrutiny of For-Profit Colleges
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Does Education Stop at Kindergarten?
text: Richard Rothstein of the Economic Policy Institute had a letter in The Times on Tuesday about the recent study on the value of good kindergarten teachers. Mr. Rothstein agreed that kindergarten was a worthwhile investment, but his main point was that education offered only a modest benefit to most workers.

headline: Budgeting for Overtime, and Stopping a Beating
text: A month and a couple of days into the city’s new fiscal year is as good a time as any to examine police overtime spending habits. Historically, overtime numbers, as kept by the city’s Independent Budget Office, have shown a proclivity for breaking budgets.

headline: Artest Steps Right Up and Raps About the Mets

text: Thieves avoid hybrids and fuel-efficient cars. [Grist]

headline: Video of Naomi Campbell’s ‘Blood Diamond’ Testimony
text: Updated |12:57 p.m. As my colleagues Marlise Simons and Alan Cowell report, Naomi Campbell appeared at the war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, on Thursday in the Hague. Ms. Campbell was called to testify about a gift of rough diamonds she was given after a dinner she attended in 1997 at which Mr. Taylor had been present.

headline: Migraine Treatments on the Horizon
text: Will more effective migraine treatments be available soon? Several are in development, says Dr. David Dodick of the Mayo Clinic, who has been responding to readers on the Consults blog.

headline: A Broken Senate, or an Unpopular Agenda?
text: In a recent bloggingheads conversation with Matt Yglesias, I tried to make the point that we’re unlikely to get sweeping procedural reform in Congress anytime soon — despite liberal optimism on that front — because nobody who isn’t immersed in the angst of movement liberalism sees the first two years of the Obama administration as a period of gridlock and inaction. That conversation took place before George Packer came out with his epic New Yorker story on the dysfunctions of the Senate, which makes the strongest possible case that the institution is incapable of governing the country. I recommend reading the whole thing — but I’d also associate myself with this comment, from David Frum:

headline: Mary Hart to Leave ‘Entertainment Tonight’
text: After almost three decades of imbuing “Entertainment Tonight” with one of the perkiest dispositions and some of the shiniest teeth in television, Mary Hart said on Thursday she will leave that syndicated pop-culture program at the end of its coming 30th season.

headline: Why No Villains Have Emerged From the Crisis
text: It’s been almost two years since the collapse of Lehman Brothers, and so far no villain has emerged who can be brought to account.

text: Even when he isn’t winning, the son of the late Dale Earnhardt Sr. remains the most popular driver in Nascar.

headline: In the Name of the Father
text: “He is very, very introverted,” a publicist says. “He lives alone. He plays video games by himself eight hours at a clip. He’s a multimillionaire, yet he lived alone for months in a 20-by-20 garage loft.” The publicist makes him out to be the Howard Hughes of Nascar.

headline: A Chance to Re-examine Hank Aaron
text: Alex Rodriguez was hailed as the golden one, the natural, the five-tool template almost certain to wind up with baseball’s most cherished cherry on top.
