text: The Senate today is likely to confirm Solicitor General Elena Kagan as the 112th Supreme Court justice and the fourth woman to sit on the court.

headline: BP Done Pumping Cement Into Well
text: HOUSTON  For more than three months, an oil-weary nation has waited for the moment when engineers would begin pumping cement into BP’s runaway well, in hopes of plugging its flow for good.

headline: Seeing Things | Cathy of California
text: If you put Martha Stewart and Rhoda Morgenstern together, you might just get Cathy Callahan. As Cathy of California, Callahan creates whimsical shop windows and styles merchandise for Los Angeles shops like Heath Ceramics; the fashion boutique Market; Stripes, an upscale shoe store in Bel Air; and Yolk, a purveyor of groovy gifts and housewares in Silver Lake. The garland of bright yellow marshmallow Peeps that graced Yolk’s window around Easter time was Cathy of California’s handiwork. Callahan’s displays blend elegance, whimsy and humor; her windows often include cheeky one-liners. Her current window for Market, which features hanging embroidery hoops festooned with paper price tags, declares, “Tag, you’re it!” She’s also an avid crafter and often makes the props for her displays. When a client wanted to buy the props from a display that was coming down, Callahan added a handmade craft business to her repertory. Her colorful vintage-inspired creations — like plump toadstool pincushions and bright butterfly brooches — sell out quickly at West Coast indie craft fairs like Renegade and Felt Club. Callahan once appeared on Martha Stewart’s TV show, kindly but firmly demonstrating to the design maven herself how to make straw flowers from a vintage kit.

headline: What We’re Reading: Borders Matter
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: I.B.M.’s Strategy in Electronic Health Records
text: I.B.M. has been quietly saying for months that it planned to enter the market for electronic health records, a business being primed with hefty government subsidies.

headline: New York Send-Off | Closer to Heaven
text: Jan Benzel is an editor at The Times who is being reassigned to Paris. Before she leaves, she is attempting to do all the things in the city that every New Yorker should do, at least once.

headline: Sketching a Future for Brooklyn Museum
text: THOUGH it resides in a prime example of traditional museum architecture — a Beaux-Arts building designed in 1893 by McKim, Mead & White — there is little stale or stodgy about the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Children’s Programming at Bayreuth: Wagner, of Course, and They Love It
text: BAYREUTH, Germany — There is a general and mostly well-founded perception of the Bayreuth Festival as an elitist stronghold for opera, as much a shrine to Wagner as a festival of his works. And there is no ticket harder to come by. Wagner-lovers wait an average of 10 years to get a coveted ticket to the Festspielhaus, which seats only about 2,000.

headline: Russia, Crippled by Drought, Bans Grain Exports
text: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday banned all exports of grain after millions of acres of Russian wheat withered in a severe drought, driving up prices around the world and pushing them to their highest level in two years in the United States.

headline: Esoteric and Other Juices
text: Wine bars and restaurants mentioned in this article:

headline: Greens Debating Tactics Instead of Ideas
text: In Politco, Darren Samuelsohn has a solid roundup of reflections by environmental campaigners on why, despite spending tens of millions of dollars, they failed to gain the votes for any climate action in the Senate. But the entire discussion is about tactics, not ideas. There are scant signs, yet, that anyone within the Beltway is willing to shift toward attacking the entwined energy and climate challenges as less a 20th-century-style pollution problem and more a 21st-century-style technology and innovation opportunity.

headline: Tipsy Diaries: Riesling Restraint
text: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, quarrels with a Riesling aficionado over the flexibility of the sugary drink.

headline: How I Spent My Summer of Riesling, by Terroir
text: On June 21 the sommelier and restaurateur Paul Grieco did something mischievous, idealistic, provocative, ornery and, in its way, rather sweet. Which is to say he summed up, in one sweeping gesture, what makes him such an indelible character in the New York dining and drinking scene.

headline: New York Tackles ‘Brownfields’ Cleanup
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Pete Grannis, the commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, announced an agreement Thursday morning that paved the way for the city to start cleaning up “brownfields,” or light-to-moderately contaminated areas that are not toxic enough to qualify for federal or state Superfund cleanup programs. About 7,000 vacant or underused acres around the city could be readied for new development under the program, city officials said.

headline: C.I.C. Said to Deny Ties to Liverpool Bid
text: A spokesman for the sovereign wealth fund the China Investment Corporation told The Financial Times on Thursday that the fund had no plans to help Kenneth Huang, a Hong Kong businessman, buy the Liverpool soccer team, despite reports to the contrary.

headline: Politician Apologizes to Don Henley for Song Parodies
text: Usually in situations like these, we’d begin with a tongue-in-cheek gloss on one of Don Henley‘s songs — “Dirty Laundry,” maybe? — but under the circumstances, we’ll just play it straight: Mr. Henley, the once and future Eagle and solo singer-songwriter, has reached a settlement with and received an apology from Chuck DeVore, the California politician, and Justin Hart, a worker for Mr. DeVore’s 2010 United States Senate campaign, who were found to have violated the copyrights to two of Mr. Henley’s best-known tracks.

headline: Sale of Troubled Buildings May Not Mean Rescue
text: “Bronx portfolio,” the Web posting read. “These distressed properties fetches prices that are much below its market value.”

headline: Education Department Deals Out Big Awards
text: Teach for America, the nonprofit group that recruits elite college students to teach in public schools, and the KIPP Foundation, which runs a nationwide network of charter schools, were big winners in a $650 million federal grant competition known as Investing in Innovation, the Department of Education said Wednesday.

headline: A Weekend in Boston
text: The city is starting to take on a glossier, more modern sheen.

headline: Q&A: Savannah for Parents in Their 70s
text: My parents, who are in their 70s, are coming to visit Savannah this summer. They are from New York, and Savannah is on their list of possible places to retire to. Do you have any sights you’d recommend?

headline: Bar + Food | Portland’s Happiest Hours
text: Add this to the growing list of reasons to visit (or relocate to) Portland, Ore.: the city’s food-focused happy hour tradition. While other towns — notably Seattle, Los Angeles, Atlanta and Charleston, S.C. — also serve cheap eats in the late afternoon, Portland has been doing it since the last recession. If you ask restaurant owners, they’ll tell you the back story: a state liquor law forbids businesses from promoting discounted alcohol, so it made sense to lure in diners with at-cost food. (Though this law has recently changed, $5 plates are more ubiquitous than ever.) And this being Portland, you’re more likely to find charcuterie plates or pig heart with quince jam on the menu than sliders and fries.

headline: A Lightning Rod for Debate
text: Say what you will about Alex Rodriguez  and judging from our Bats blog comments after he hit his 600th questionably legitimate home run Wednesday, a lot of you are moved to do that  he sure knows how to get people talking about him. They are rarely saying the things he would want them saying, but that’s part of Rodriguez’s talent, too. He is a publicity train wreck.

headline: Popcast: Arcade Fire’s New Album
text: This week on Popcast, The Times’s music podcast, Jon Pareles discusses “The Suburbs” by Arcade Fire, the indie-rock band from Montreal that went gold with “whoa-oh-oh” choruses and meditations on death and family.

headline: White House Party for Africa Leaves Out Leaders
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Many of Africa’s leaders have spent part of their summer shuttling between capitals, congratulating one another on 50 years of independence. One capital they will not be visiting together is Washington.

headline: 36 Hours in Boston
text: BOSTON is known for its bricks and brownstones, but the city is starting to take on a glossier, more modern sheen. With the completion of the $15 billion Big Dig, downtown now stretches unimpeded to the harbor, making Boston feel like a whole new city. History abounds, of course — Faneuil Hall still stands, Paul Revere is still buried at the Granary Burying Ground — but it is now joined by a high-tech exuberance, modern parks and a reclaimed harbor. Revere would not recognize it.

headline: Law Will Extend Medicare Fund, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON  Medicare will remain financially solvent for 12 years longer than projected a year ago  until 2029  because of the cost-cutting measures in President Obama’s recently enacted health care legislation, the program’s trustees reported on Thursday.

headline: Delgado Becoming an Option for Some Teams
text: The former Mets first baseman Carlos Delgado, recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his right hip, seems to be on the verge of a major league return.

headline: A Patient Is Rescued, Quietly
text: From watching television we tend to think we know what a hospital emergency looks like: violent, dramatic and optimally bloody. Someone calls the alarm, a team that includes at least one handsome doctor surges into the room, and people yell out “STAT!” as needed. The patient always survives.

headline: Let the Chevrolet Volt Buyer Beware, as Some Dealers Mark Up Price
text: After Chevrolet’s announcement last week that its 2011 Volt plug-in hybrid would sell for $41,000, it seemed that only President Obama could muster an unequivocal assessment of the car. “Pretty smooth,” he said, grinning, after a brief test drive on the Volt’s factory floor in Hamtramck, Mich. Others criticized Chevrolet’s parent company, General Motors, for pricing the car beyond the reach of many taxpayers who buoyed the corporation before its June 2009 bankruptcy filing.

headline: Further Scrutiny of For-Profit Colleges
text: Readers of The Choice enrolled at for-profit colleges, or considering doing so, would do well to read two articles by my colleague Tamar Lewin in The Times on Thursday and Wednesday.

headline: Visiting France’s Côte Fleurie
text: Former fishing villages in northern France know how to keep both visitors from Paris and local residents entertained.

headline: Trying Triggerfish, Unusual in New York
text: I’m not the man to write about climate change, but I can say that I was a little surprised last week to see triggerfish at our local farmers’ market, caught off the Hamptons. Members of this pretty large family are not unheard of around here, but I’ve always thought of them as warmer-water fish. I look to readers to set me straight on this, especially if they’re anglers by profession or avocation. Anyway, never having tasted triggerfish, my wife, Jackie, and I bought a couple of five-ounce fillets to slot into the previously designed template for dinner that night.

headline: Broadway Joe Pulls Up Just Short of a Guarantee
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. – The Hall of Fame quarterback Joe Namath met with reporters Thursday morning in the media room of the Jets’ training facility. He labeled the Jets’ Super Bowl aspirations “justified,” claimed he was not concerned with the stalled contract negotiations for Darrelle Revis and repeatedly expressed concern about the team’s opening at left guard.

headline: Normandy’s Quiet Glamour
text: THE anticipation was palpable as French paparazzi and gawkers crowded the red carpet outside the beachfront Grand Hôtel and awaited the arrival of the film festival stars.

headline: Killer of Opposition Leader in a Russian Republic Is Slain
text: MOSCOW  Gunmen strode into the Eastern Fairy Tale Cafe in the southern Russian city of Nazran on Wednesday afternoon and opened fire with automatic weapons on two police officials, Russia’s Investigative Committee announced. Dead on the spot was Ibragim D. Yevloyev, a police official who was involved in a notorious killing two years ago.

headline: Are Your Children Really Hungry?
text: Our children are overweight. Experts blame everything from high fructose corn syrup and too much computer time to too little sleep and insidious advertising.

headline: Are You Calling Me Alaïa?
text: Oh, the trials of being a supermodel. Naomi Campbell testified in the war crimes trial against former Liberian President Charles Taylor this morning in The Hague. La Campbell, who had been subpoenaed about whether Taylor had gifted her blood diamonds, was asked why she didn’t find being given a small pouch of “dirty-looking stones” by two men in the middle of the night strange. Her reply? She responded, “It’s not abnormal for me to get gifts, I get gifts all the time.” She also claimed she didn’t even know the stones, which she subsequently donated to charity, were diamonds: “I’m used to seeing diamonds shiny and in a box, that’s the kind of diamonds I’m used to seeing.” At least she had the common sense not to wear diamonds with her Azzedine Alaïa knit dress and matching cardigan.

headline: Yoga’s Newest Fans
text: The 18 men and women slowly climbing the steps to their yoga class at RAIN Inwood Senior Center the other day hardly resembled the young, lithe exemplars of America’s yoga boom. You won’t find the likes of Sylvia Guzman, 81, on the covers of yoga magazines or Francisco Batista, 88, on the proliferating Web sites hawking trendy yoga clothing.

headline: Alignment Is Crucial, Even When You’re Great
text: Stuart Appleby had just birdied the last three holes. It was the final round of the Greenbrier Classic, and he had birdied nine holes and eagled another to shoot a historic 59. He had bogeyed only one of 72 holes during the tournament. He was on fire, playing almost as precisely -– 22-under par for the four days -– as any golfer could reasonably expect.

headline: TimesCast | August 5, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, political repercussions from the ruling on same sex marriage in California, a Ground Zero update and Frank Bruni on the virtues of Riesling wine.

headline: Jerry Garcia Biopic Won’t Be Allowed to Use His Songs
text: Bummer, man: a planned biographical film about Jerry Garcia will have to keep on truckin’ without any of the original music of the Grateful Dead or the involvement of Mr. Garcia’s family, Variety reported [registration required].

headline: Visual Diary: How Hot Is It?
text: How August feels in Afghanistan.

headline: Sign Says Mohawk. But You’re in Red Sox Camp.
text: Baseball fans throughout the Northeast are eagerly anticipating the return of the Boston Red Sox to the Bronx this weekend to face their archrivals, the New York Yankees.

headline: New Law Extends Medicare Fund
text: In reports issued on Thursday, the long-term outlook for Medicare remained gloomy unless further reforms are put in place. But the financial picture for both Medicare and Social Security has improved because of changes mandated by the new health care law, according to a new article by The Times’s Jackie Calmes.

headline: Alternatives to Overdraft Protection
text: Because of the new overdraft law fully going into effect on Aug. 15, new and existing bank customers will be able to withdraw more than is in their checking accounts only if they opt in to pay for overdraft protection from their banks. Previously, banks had automatically signed up consumers for the service and then charged customers hefty fees whenever they covered an overdraft.

headline: From Musical Unity to the Political Kind
text: Music, not politics, made Wyclef Jean a household name in Haiti and a multimillion-record-selling international star who has always proclaimed his Haitian origins. That was before he announced that he would run for president of Haiti.

headline: Mets Trot Out Reliever of Last Resort
text: Too big to fail. This was the slogan for all the wonderful financial institutions the federal government shored up in 2008 and 2009.

headline: Do Dispersants Pose a Risk in Seafood?
text: In an article on Wednesday and a followup on Thursday, my colleague Leslie Kaufman and I wrote about a new government report that says that about three-quarters of the oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill has effectively been dealt with through capture, skimming, burning, dispersion or dissolution. The implication is that the oil poses little additional risk to shorelines or at the ocean’s surface.

headline: Brown to Vote ‘No’ on Kagan Nomination
text: Senator Scott Brown, the Massachusetts Republican, said on Thursday that he would not support Solicitor General Elena Kagan’s nomination to the Supreme Court, denying her a Republican vote that many had expected to be in her corner.

headline: Teaching ‘The Lord of the Flies’ With The New York Times
text: Earlier this year, we asked students and teachers to name the books they love to read and teach. Books like “The Catcher in the Rye” and “To Kill a Mockingbird” were favorites among teachers and students alike.

headline: Marriage Ruling’s Unpredictable Unions
text: From the start, postures in the lawsuit challenging California’s same-sex marriage ban have been unpredictable. There was the David Boies-Ted Olson alliance arguing for the plaintiffs. The defendant in the case, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, a Republican, said, essentially, that he was glad he lost.

headline: Hot Dog Champ Cleared in Stage-Storming Incident
text: The Japanese speed-eating powerhouse Takeru Kobayashi was given a pass Thursday morning on charges of trespassing and resisting arrest after he rushed the stage at last month’s Nathan’s Hot Dog Eating Contest in Coney Island.

headline: We Three Things | Jiggledy-Jig
text: Jellies and jelly molds seem to be wiggling into the picture. Their structured yet bosomy shapes provide a flourish of Victoriana, and their wobbly weirdness seems to prefigure molecular cuisine. I store my hair elastics in upended enamel molds, and turned out my third summer pudding in a rabbit-shaped one from a tag sale. They’re remarkably pretty, and they satisfy the current food-geist of homemade and arcane.

headline: Ecuadorean Immigrant’s Killers Get Long Sentences
text: A 30-year-old man who confessed to the 2008 baseball-bat murder of a 31-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant by saying, “So I killed someone — that makes me a bad guy?” was sentenced on Thursday to more than 30 years in prison.

headline: At Chicago Ford Plant, Obama Says Critics Lack Faith in Americans
text: CHICAGO  Against a backdrop of American-made cars, President Obama cast his Republican critics on Thursday as having lost faith in the American people, part of an emerging campaign strategy to try to turn the country’s populist mood against his opponents.

headline: In Comments on Oil’s Fate, an Air of Mistrust
text: As my colleagues Campbell Robertson, Justin Gillis and I reported on reaction, scientific and otherwise, to a government report on the fate of the oil in the gulf, it emerged that the Obama administration faced something of a credibility gap in conveying its findings to some gulf residents, environmental groups and even scientists.

headline: Question: Globally Recognized Words?

headline: Israeli Police Claim Video of Crying Palestinian Boy Was Staged
text: Israel’s border police force insisted in a statement on Thursday that video of a 5-year-old Palestinian boy reacting with dismay to the arrest of his father this week in the West Bank, which has been broadcast internationally, was staged.

headline: Beyond the Harlem Renaissance
text: FEW aesthetic labels are as linked to a neighborhood as the Harlem Renaissance, the cultural movement of the 1920s and ’30s that created some of the most significant American art of the 20th century.

headline: Hipster Replacement
text: At a recent Chanel party, a little-known D.J. took the stage to a remix of ‘‘Carmina Burana’’ and spun the crowd — which included Tim Burton, Vanessa Paradis and Johnny Depp — into a frenzy. This mix master wasn’t a model or a downtown doyenne: it was Ruth Flowers, a k a Mamy Rock, a grandmother well into her 70s who has put in appearances at Cannes, Glastonbury and Paris, where her ‘‘factotum’’ is based. ‘‘I thought, What are they going to think of this old biddy who gets up there to play records?’’ she says from her home in southwest England. Inspired to become a D.J. when she attended her grandson’s birthday party, Flowers has worked with a French producer on mixing, as well as on her ‘‘stage persona,’’ which includes a hairstyle that ‘‘looks as if I’ve been plugged into an electricity cord.’’ Spinning has eclipsed some of her other hobbies, like giving historical talks about Henry VIII, but she’s happy to be busy. ‘‘When you get to 60, that’s when you just go to bingo, I suppose,’’ she says, adding unnecessarily, ‘‘That’s not my scene.’’

headline: At the Playground. On the Stage. In the Backyard.
text: At the playground. On the stage. In the backyard. Everywhere you look, somebody’s going a little wild this week.

headline: Women, the Young and Other Items of Web Interest

headline: Reliance’s Big Bet on a Pricey Shale Deal
text: Reliance Industries of India continues to pay top dollar to tap into the natural gas market in the United States, pushing up what some people in the energy industry think are exorbitant prices to obtain unconventional shale gas. Reliance’s $392 million deal with Carrizo Oil and Gas is just one of several shale transactions that are expected by energy bankers.

text: Two men were arrested in connection with a string of gunpoint robberies in Central Park during the night, the police said.

headline: To Follow Feagles as the Giants’ Punter, a Rookie Is Using Muscle
text: ALBANY  Matt Dodge admitted that walking into the Giants’ locker room for the first time was somewhat unsettling. He was not only a rookie  a punter, no less  he was also replacing the stalwart Jeff Feagles. But because of Dodge’s physique, he did not go unnoticed.

text: Okay, this is just cool. Researchers from Northeastern and Harvard Universities have analyzed hundreds of millions of Twitter messages to determine the “Pulse of the Nation,” or at least the pulse of the nation’s Twitterbots, of which I am one.

headline: When Your Choice Is Riesling, Riesling or Riesling
text: In this week’s Tipsy Diaries, I profile Paul Grieco, one of the city’s most knowledgeable, passionate and eccentric sommeliers, whose stamp on the two Terroir wine bars he runs downtown is not unlike a colorful bartender’s stamp on his saloon. Both Terroirs are infused with Mr. Grieco’s particular spirit, which I discuss in the article.

headline: 2 Killed After School Buses Crash Into Truck Cab

headline: Poverty and Lack of Research Block Path to a Well-Fed World
text: I’m catching up with a great package of reports, commentary and analysis in the July 28th edition of the journal Nature on the challenging, but entirely doable, task of feeding roughly 9 billion people by midcentury (and doing so without using up the last patches of arable land). One of the best things about the package is that most of the content is freely accessible, as was the case with an important paper on feeding the world in the competing journal Science in February.

headline: Dutch Opponent of Muslims Gains Ground
text: LONDON  Geert Wilders, the anti-Muslim politician who has campaigned for a tax on head scarves and a ban on the Koran, seemed poised Thursday to emerge as a prominent player in a new minority government in the Netherlands.

headline: Charles Guislain | Like Tavi, Only French, Male and Blogless
text: Charles Guislain was just 15 when he crashed his first Paris runway show, Gareth Pugh in 2008. For a petit écolier, he cuts an unusual image, clad in an apocalyptic Rad Hourani chain mail sheath or a princely Martin Margiela cape with hooflike Rick Owens wedge boots. The fashion commentariat thinks of him as the goth counterpoint to the kooky, hat-loving Tavi, but Guislain is no blogger. He was discovered by the raspy-voiced cult fashion journalist Diane Pernet and became something of a flaxen-haired YouTube curiosity, and he was recently the subject of a spread in Italian Vogue. He’s still in school, studying Rimbaud, Barthes, Proust — serious reading for a serious boy.

headline: Tax Cuts And The Economy
text: If we could wave away political reality, I’d let all the Bush tax cuts expire, and use the improvement in the budget outlook to justify a large, temporary increase in public spending. Unfortunately, that’s not going to happen. Given the political realities, I’d go for a temporary extension of the lower-end cuts, and just letting the upper-end cuts expire.

headline: Feagles Eases Into Retirement, but Still Helps Giants
text: Jeff Feagles arrived at Giants training camp in Albany this week, as he had for the past seven years. The familiar fields and teammates are smoothing his career transition. Feagles is with the Giants as a punting consultant this summer, the first summer since his retirement after a remarkable 22-year career.

headline: Riding High: A Chinese Concept for Bus Transit
text: The Internet is all aflutter over a new concept for bus transit that was developed in China to help address the country’s congested roads. The bus would ride on top of a platform that leaves room for car traffic to pass underneath — like a puppy darting through its mother’s legs.

headline: Thomas Jane on ‘Hung,’ Symbol of the Recession
text: Though it feels like a cultural violation to talk about any television shown in contest with “Mad Men,” our national homage to past depravities, it is merely one of two series about a good-looking divorced white man in conflict with his virility that is offered on Sunday nights at 10. The other series is “Hung,” a comedy that, although it has not given birth to a single trend, expression or style of tie, has distinguished itself as the most topical fictional programming on television. As it’s moved into its second season on HBO, “Hung” has become an even more finely drawn satire of the Great Recession.

headline: Warning Letter Sent to Supporters of Espada Opponent
text: There appear to be some shady practices taking place in a Bronx election.

headline: A Man, a Woman and the Pyramids
text: You might say that there is, in the literal, plot-summary sense, a romantic triangle at the heart of Ruba Nadda’s “Cairo Time.” An American woman waiting to meet her husband in the Egyptian capital is drawn toward a dalliance with a former colleague of his, a local resident who drives her from the airport to her hotel and graciously offers his services as tour guide and companion. But what gives this delicate, decorous movie its distinctive throb of melancholy sensuality is less the humdrum possibility of adultery than the intimation of a three-way entanglement involving the man, the woman and Cairo. The city is also clearly the principal object of Ms. Nadda’s ardor.

headline: The Jets’ All-Weather Team
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. -– When Rex Ryan became the Jets’ coach before last season, he promised an “all-weather” football team. On Thursday morning, extreme conditions tested that theory out at training camp.

Murtha was indicted Thursday on charges that as a lobbyist he made hundreds of thousands of dollars in laundered campaign contributions to lawmakers, using straw donors and other illicit means to disguise the source of the money.

headline: Investors Are Still Behaving Badly
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital.

headline: Resurrecting Laurelton Hall
Cult Director Courts the Mass, Keeps the Crazy
text: AS he prepared to board another in a series of Virgin Atlantic flights from London to Los Angeles that have lately defined his life, Edgar Wright was presented with a quandary: Should he spend the 11 ½-hour trip getting some much-needed shut-eye or playing Super Mario Bros. on an in-flight video-game system?

headline: Grass Fed | Korean in Massachusetts
text: The Pioneer Valley, home to a whole mess of Western Massachusetts’s finest higher-education operations, is not a bad place to eat per se. But I know from friends who live or have lived there that the options can feel limited. So I was stoked, when passing through last week, to be taken to a restaurant that I hadn’t heard of and actually liked: Gohyang Korean Restaurant, a shoebox of a place on Route 9. There’s no reason why there shouldn’t, couldn’t or wouldn’t be a good Korean restaurant there, but I was quietly thrilled about it.

headline: Fungus on Track to Extinguish Bats in Northeast
text: .A research team organized by Thomas Kunz of Boston University has concluded in a new paper that a common, beneficial bat species is likely to be completely wiped out across much of the Northeastern United States within 20 years due to a spreading fungal infection. The basics are laid out in the news section of the journal Science, which is also publishing the research paper. The news report mentions that bat biologists suggest landowners can boost bats’ prospects by erecting bat houses.

headline: Letter: A Cheaper Phone Choice
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Staying in Touch, for Less” (Aug. 1): If you are a truly global traveler, the simplest solution by far is to buy a cheap, unlocked SIM-ready phone ($50 or less) and buy SIM cards in each country you travel to. SIMs generally cost $5 or less. With a local number you can very cheaply call hotels, restaurants, etc., in that country to book a spot, and you can call or text home much more cheaply than you can while roaming on your home-based plan.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: This  isn’t the first time we have highlighted the work of Mohammad Sajjad, who captured a heart-rending image of a child on a roadside near Peshawar, Pakistan, on Thursday (Slide 5). Of the estimated three million people the United Nations said have been uprooted by recent flooding, nearly half are children.

headline: Big 12 Defections Force Kansas to Sing a New Tune
text: Conference realignment has upended rivalries, schedules and perhaps the balance of power in college football, but it has also caused some musical consternation at Kansas. The Kansas fight song, “I’m a Jayhawk,” contains multiple references to Nebraska and Colorado, who left the Big 12 this summer for the Big Ten and Pac-10:

headline: For Love and Money
text: Not everyone who has a child is cut out to be a parent, and not every kid is cut out for a carefree childhood. There’s no clean connection between these two accidents of character and fate. Hot-housed children can end up with blighted lives, while neglected kids can succeed and thrive as adults. Nonetheless, when Claire, one of the two women at the center of Mona Simpson’s new novel, “My Hollywood,” has a baby in her late 30s, she convinces herself not only that she’s an unfit mother but that her 17-week-old son, Will (who “seemed more furious than other babies, more bereft”) is aware of her shortcomings: “Will and I both felt astonished that he was stuck with me.” Is an infant capable of such nuanced misgiving? Or could Claire be projecting? Taking no chances, she hires a nanny, Lola — a mother of five from the Philippines and the novel’s other central character — to take care of Will and to lighten her psychic load. But eventually she starts to worry: What if the nanny isn’t up to the job either? How can she know?

headline: Measures to Legalize Pot May Lure Young to Polls
text: A coalition of liberals, police officers, and a former Reagan administration lawyer say weed could be the secret to high voter turnout this November.

headline: A Dictator Is No Match for a Tough School Board
text: When Cassius declares, “I ... have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone,” what the audience sees is that noble Roman’s open blouse with a black bra underneath.

headline: Letter: Holiday on Campus
text: To the Editor: “In Britain, Dorms Have Summer Jobs” (Aug. 1): What a delightful article. Before I read the piece, I noticed the gorgeous photo of the dining hall at Oxford University’s Keble College. It reminded me of a Harry Potter production, as it did your writer.

headline: G.M. Pushes for U.S. to Sell Entire Stake at I.P.O.

Whitacre Jr., said Thursday that G.M. wanted Washington to sell its entire stake during an initial public offering, The New York Times’s Nick Bunkley reports from Traverse City, Mich.

text: For busy, harried or distractible readers who have the time and energy only to skim the opening paragraph of a review, I’ll say this as quickly and clearly as possible: “The Death of the Adversary” and “Comedy in a Minor Key” are masterpieces, and Hans Keilson is a genius.

headline: ‘Devil Wears Prada’ Author Buys Condo
text: IN Lauren Weisberger’s new novel, “Last Night at Chateau Marmont,” a musician shoots from modest Manhattan nightclubs to big-time name-in-lights stardom after a performance on “The Tonight Show with Jay Leno.” The book follows his wife as she deals with the difficulties of their new life, fame and the media.

text: The Senate on Thursday approved $26 billion in aid to states and school districts, a decision that Democrats said would prevent the layoffs of tens of thousands of teachers and public employees.

headline: An Art Experiment in Flashy Las Vegas
text: Las Vegas may be known for gambling and gaudiness, but when it comes to art, the exhibitions on view there have been surprisingly highbrow. Over the years its galleries have displayed canvases by Rembrandt and Picasso, Monet and van Gogh.

headline: New Editor Named for Architectural Digest
text: Margaret Russell will succeed Paige Rense as editor in chief of Architectural Digest, Condé Nast announced on Thursday. Ms. Russell was previously vice president and editor in chief of brand content at Elle Decor. She will step into her new digs in early September. Ms. Rense joined Architectural Digest in 1970 as an associate editor and was named editor in chief shortly thereafter.

headline: Goldman’s Trading Plan: Shades of Volcker
text: With Goldman Sachs planning a move of its proprietary trading desk to its asset management arm, according to press reports, another bank is planning a big response to the just-passed financial regulatory overhaul

headline: The Global War on Small People
text: In Graham Greene’s 1940 novel, “The Power and the Glory,” the unnamed protagonist, a “whisky priest,” utters the book’s most resonant line. “Hate,” the priest says, “was just a failure of imagination.”

headline: ‘A Foreigner Carrying in the Crook of His Arm a Tiny Bomb’
text: Prologue: A Missile in the Living Room

headline: Continental Tries Out Self-Boarding
text: First they took away the complimentary travel kits. Then the meals. The inexorable transition of the experience of flying into something more akin to public transportation may be taking a major step forward. Continental Airlines has begun testing out self-boarding at George Bush Intercontinental  Airport in Houston, it said recently, becoming the first airline in the United States to do so. Passengers who have checked in can swipe their boarding passes at gates reminiscent of turnstiles and then proceed to their departing flight.

headline: Mapquest, Nicaraguan Style
text: Nicaragua is infamous for being a land of few street signs and fewer house numbers, a place where “three blocks north of where the market used to be” is a legitimate address. (Like, even on business cards.)

headline: A Not-So-Macho Cop’s Moment of Truth
text: Is it possible to run a bait-and-switch scam in reverse? I can’t think of another way to describe the odd trick pulled off by “The Other Guys,” a new goofballs-and-fireballs comedy directed by Adam McKay. The closing credit sequence is, in effect, a tease for a movie quite different from the one that has just concluded.

headline: Lookbooks
text: Three books due out this fall find fashion in a retrospective mood. ‘‘Yohji Yamamoto: My Dear Bomb’’ (Ludion), the first-ever biography of the designer, fittingly ditches an orthodox chronology for a series of short fictions written by Yamamoto interspersed with vivid reminiscences. (For those looking for something a little more linear, the book concludes with a timeline featuring never-before-seen personal images.) Anna Sui’s eponymous biography (Chronicle Books), on the other hand, is a more visual feast. Written by Andrew Bolton, a curator at the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this book will showcase 400 photographs from the Sui archives and include text by the White Stripes frontman Jack White and her longtime collaborator Steven Meisel. Finally, two photographers put the art in Rodarte in a new book from JRP Ringier. ‘‘Rodarte, Catherine Opie, Alec Soth’’ (above) is an off-the-cuff collaboration with Kate and Laura Mulleavy that delves into the design duo’s myriad obsessions.

headline: Despite Appeal, Holocaust Documentary Will Retain R-Rating
text: The R-rating for the Holocaust documentary “A Film Unfinished” will stand, an appeals board ruled on Thursday, according to Oscilloscope Laboratories, which is releasing the movie. Oscilloscope had appealed the rating by the Classification and Rating Administration, which cited “disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities including graphic nudity.” The film, directed by Yael Hersonski, dissects a Nazi propaganda film that purported to depict life among Jews in the Warsaw ghetto during World War II but actually manipulated its portrayal to reinforce anti-Jewish policies. The rating bars those under 17 from seeing the film without an accompanying parent or guardian. Oscilloscope argued that a similar film, “The Last Days,” on which Steven Spielberg was an executive producer, had been rated PG-13. Spokesmen for the ratings administration did not immediately respond to a query. Oscilloscope said the board ruled 12 to 3 against changing the rating. “A Film Unfinished” won a film editing award at the Sundance Film Festival earlier this year.

headline: Beyond the Blockbusters at the Met
text: Wall Street may be fattening up, but New York’s art institutions aren’t. There’s a conspicuous recessionary logic behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s two marquee spring-summer exhibitions, one devoted to Picasso, the other to American fashion. Both were homegrown, low-overhead productions, pulled entirely from the permanent collection.

headline: Five and Five: No. 34, Texas A&M
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 34, is Texas A&M. You can find a larger Texas A&M preview at Pre-Snap Read.

headline: Staying Ashore, or Wading In
text: Cover the Waterfront week on City Room is drawing to an end. Thank you for all your waterfront photos — we’re no longer accepting submissions. Tomorrow, we will publish a slideshow of several hundred of them. Here’s the last installment in our series of riparian adventures.

headline: The Hard Part of Tennis in New York? Finding an Open Court
text: THE pleas are routinely posted in online forums like one devoted to sports on Yelp.com: “Is there a way to play tennis ‘on the cheap’ in N.Y.C.?” asked Abel M., who couldn’t help recalling growing up where “tennis was free.” Laura A. had waited three hours at Riverside Park and wanted to know where there were less crowded courts. Another Yelp poster, Jim R., captured their frustration: “I wish I could play more tennis, but it’s such a hassle to play living in N.Y.”

headline: Varieties of Abstraction
text: Happy birthday, abstract painting! One of the prides and joys of Western modernism is in the vicinity of its first centennial. It’s hard to be much more exact, since its invention was a scattered effort extending over years if not decades. Fans of Frantisek Kupka should have celebrated last year; Kandinsky’s crowd can uncork the Champagne in 2012. Devotees of Mondrian or Malevich will have to wait a year or two longer.

headline: Beach-Blanket Lingo
text: When Jake Tapper of ABC’s “This Week” asked Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey last month for his opinion of the MTV reality series “Jersey Shore,” the contempt in the governor’s voice was obvious. “What it does is it takes a bunch of New Yorkers — most of the people on ‘Jersey Shore’ are New Yorkers — drops them at the Jersey Shore and tries to make America feel like this is New Jersey,” Christie said. In other words, in the parlance of the Jersey Shore, the show is about a bunch of bennies — disagreeable tourists from the metropolitan New York region who crowd the beaches every summer.

headline: What Friday’s Jobs Report May Hold
text: Is it a pause, or are we spluttering?

headline: Still Upbeat About the Recovery
text: I know I raised some eyebrows a few months ago when I wrote that the economy was turning around (“Here Comes the Recovery!“). While lots of folks commented that they, too, were experiencing a resurgence in their business over the past few quarters, there seemed to be just as many naysayers who saw only dark clouds ahead. With the recent news that gross domestic product grew at a less-than-expected 2.4 percent in the second quarter (down from a revised 3.7 percent in the first quarter), the naysayers (including economists) who are predicting a double-dip recession are getting louder than ever.

headline: Letters: The End of Forgetting
text: Jeffrey Rosen’s article overlooks the simplest tactic for managing your reputation online: Don’t post. No one is forcing you to upload embarrassing photos, reveal personal information or make ill-informed comments on Web sites. Life will continue, even if it’s not broadcast in its entirety.

headline: The Mystery of the Lost City
text: WHEN it was built in 1833 Colonnade Row was the biggest thing in New York since the British occupation, a 200-foot-long sweep of glistening white marble in the form of a Corinthian colonnade, nine houses combined into one great Greek revival statement on what is now Lafayette Street, opposite the Public Theater.

headline: Lonely Hearts Club Ban
text: My husband and I moved next door to a beautiful park. I enjoy walking there for exercise and quiet time to think. But a woman who is often there approaches random strangers and asks if they would like company. She’s with someone different every day. She’s done this to me a couple of times, then proceeds to divulge extremely intimate details about her life. I’ve tried switching the times I walk, but she’s always there. I find her off-putting, and I bet my neighbors do, too. What should be done?

headline: Despite Industry Skepticism, South Korea and China Are Said to Plan Trade Talks
text: BEIJING  South Korea and China are likely to open free-trade talks next year, South Korea’s ambassador to China said in an interview published on Thursday.

headline: The View From the Lens of an Israeli Tank’s Scope
text: A scene early in “Lebanon” dramatizes the moral confusion of combat with unusual clarity and force. Shmulik (Yoav Donat), a nervous young Israeli soldier who operates the main gun in a tank, has orders to shoot a fast-approaching car. Through his viewfinder he can see the faces of the driver and passengers, and the fact of their humanity paralyzes his hand, preventing him from firing.

headline: In 911 Call, Gunman in Connecticut Says He Wishes He Had ‘Gotten More’
text: After Omar S. Thornton had gone on a shooting rampage, killing eight people at the Hartford Distributors warehouse on Tuesday morning, he called 911 from inside the building’s offices in Manchester, Conn., saying he wanted to leave a permanent record of his deadly acts.

headline: Giants and Moss Both Hope He Can Contribute
text: ALBANY — By the time Sinorice Moss reached the N.F.L., in 2006, his older brother, Santana, had two seasons with more than 1,000 receiving yards. There was hope the younger Moss would follow.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Opposes Fees for Internet Priority
text: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said Thursday that he believed it was “unacceptable” for Internet service providers to offer faster Internet transmission to content providers willing to pay higher fees.

headline: Still Paying for Lehman’s Demise
text: Nearly two years ago, in the middle of a financial crisis of historic proportions, a federal bankruptcy judge, James M. Peck, made the gutsy decision to approve the sale of the bulk of Lehman Brothers’ domestic investment-banking business to Barclays for between $1.3 and $1.7 billion, including Lehman’s Seventh Avenue headquarters, which was worth nearly $1 billion. Judge Peck’s decision came four days after a deal to sell all of Lehman to Barclays fell apart at the 11th hour and Lehman filed the largest bankruptcy case ever.

headline: August: Time for an Unexamined Life
text: August in New York City is predictable: There’s a surplus of heat and a dearth of therapists, many of whom take the month off, following a tradition of Sigmund Freud’s. At McNally Jackson Books in SoHo on Wednesday evening, four authors read selections of their work, under the loose theme of having a nervous breakdown, at an annual event, “The Shrinks Are Away!”

headline: Van Hollen: Rangel, Waters Cases Show Ethics Progress
text: A high-ranking House Democrat argued on Thursday that the ethics charges against Representatives Charles B. Rangel and Maxine Waters signal something of an achievement for Democrats.

headline: A Band of Neo-Nazis, Navigating Sexuality
text: Nicolo Donato’s melodrama “Brotherhood” digs into the collective psyche of a Danish neo-Nazi group whose brightest recruit and biggest potential star, Lars (Thure Lindhardt), is a semi-closeted gay man with masculinity issues. An up-and-coming army officer, Lars abruptly abandons the military when his expected promotion to master sergeant is denied because of rumors that he has made drunken passes at fellow soldiers. While he bides his time considering a course of action, his well-connected middle-class parents arrange behind his back for him to take an army post in New Zealand; he angrily rejects their interference.

headline: Dear FloFab: Do I Need Furniture to Have a Party?
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Life, That Continuing Mystery, Should Be Lived, Not Worried Over
text: In “Eccentricities of a Blond Hair Girl,” the Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira’s exquisite but peculiar screen adaptation of a short story by Eça de Queiros, everything changes yet remains the same. All is illusion and beyond human understanding, and memory is not to be trusted in a film that takes a long view that encompasses generations. An excerpt from “The Keeper of Sheep,” a 1914 poem by the Portuguese writer Fernando Pessoa that is recited in the movie, distills the perspective of Mr. de Oliveira, who at the age of 101 should know something about farsightedness.

headline: Holocaust-Denying Cartoonist Finds a Home Online
text: On Thursday, a brief report on the Web site of Iran’s semiofficial Fars news agency announced the launch of a new Web site, Holocartoons.com, devoted to the work of Maziar Bijani, a Holocaust-denying Iranian cartoonist.

headline: A Purveyor of Prurience in a Family-Man Guise
text: Apparently there is quite a bit of pornography on the Internet. If you have also heard something about this, and wondered how exactly it came to be, then you might be curious about “Middle Men,” a new movie about the discreet online use of credit cards, directed by George Gallo.

headline: G.M. Pushes for U.S. to Sell Entire Stake at I.P.O.
text: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich.  Eager to rid his company of the stigma of being government owned, the chief executive of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., said Thursday that G.M. wanted Washington to sell its entire stake during an initial public offering.

headline: In a One-Horse Stable, a Forlorn Filly Has Come From Nowhere
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — A few days after he bought a modestly bred horse from a friend named Don Hunt, Tim Snyder took a moment to reflect. He had no money, no horse trailer to get his new acquisition to where he needed to go and a filly that had been rejected by nearly everyone else who had come in contact with her. The horse had a clubfoot, a bad shoulder, a reputation for being slow and was blind in one eye, reason enough for Snyder to second-guess what he had just done.

headline: Revolving-Door Romances for Modern-Day Chinese
text: “Drunken nights without hope, like this one: I spend them wandering outside until the sky grows pale.” Those words, written in 1923 by the Chinese author Yu Dafu, serve as the epigraph for Lou Ye’s rambling, unstrung soap opera “Spring Fever.” As a voice-over murmurs the epigraph, the camera surveys the murky skyline of Nanjing, the Chinese city through which its restless young characters drift in a state of sullen heat. The tableau is one of the few reflective moments in an otherwise chaotic, distracted melodrama.

headline: Mexican Guest Workers, Laid Off, Want BP’s Help
text: NEW ORLEANS  Soon after the oil from the Deepwater Horizon began gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, business at the Ramada Plaza Beach Resort in Fort Walton Beach, Fla., dried up  and so did the jobs of five Mexican housekeepers who were guest workers at the hotel under contracts guaranteeing them work until Nov. 1.

headline: Keeping Score: An Ace, and Some Hope, Return for Red Sox
text: On Friday, the Boston Red Sox will arrive at Yankee Stadium for a four-game series. When Boston came to New York last August, they were only two and a half games out of first place. In 2008, they were four and a half out of first when they made the August trip. And in 2007, the Red Sox were in first place, by seven and a half games, when they traveled to Yankee Stadium in August.

headline: Happy Feet Waging Hip-Hop Battles
text: Partway through “Step Up 3D” there’s a number unlike anything else in the movie. Set to a remix of Fred Astaire’s version of “I Won’t Dance,” blaring from an ice cream truck’s loudspeaker, it’s the film’s most conspicuous attempt to ride  Astaire’s coattails and is its only memorable dance. That’s not because of the choreography, which is ho-hum, but because for a few moments the dancing helps tell the story, taking the tentative romance of Moose (Adam G. Sevani) and Camille (Alyson Stoner) a few steps further.

headline: U.S. Tells WikiLeaks to Return Afghan War Logs
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon demanded on Thursday that WikiLeaks “do the right thing” and remove from its Web site tens of thousands of classified documents about the war in Afghanistan, and return to the military thousands of others that it had not yet made public.

headline: A Whirlwind Moves Into G.M.’s Marketing Office
text: NEVER mind the globe-trotting roué whom Dos Equis beer describes as “the most interesting man in the world.” On Madison Avenue, at least, that sobriquet belongs these days to Joel Ewanick.

headline: Senate Passes Child Nutrition Act
text: The Senate on Thursday approved a long-awaited child nutrition act that intends to feed more hungry kids and make school food more nutritious, and it provides for $4.5 billion over the next decade to make that happen.

headline: A New Drug Is King in Manhattan
text: “Twelve,” the Joel Schumacher-directed screen adaptation of Nick McDonell’s “controversial best-selling novel,” to quote the film’s production notes, sinks under the weight of its pretensions, beginning with the first words uttered by its omniscient narrator, Kiefer Sutherland. Introducing the main character, White Mike (Chace Crawford of “Gossip Girl,” painfully miscast), a drug dealer to rich and disaffected youth living on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, Mr. Sutherland affects the insinuating, too-cool-to-be-ruffled tone of a latter-day Humphrey Bogart, minus the vocal gravel.

headline: A Legal Victory for Gay Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Avon Calling!
text: At first I didn’t notice the Avon truck parked on Fifth Avenue in front of the General Motors Building this morning, and I thought the line of people was for the Apple store. On second glance I noted that people inside the Avon truck had their heads in washbowls and were getting a public shampoo. What had they done to deserve that? No, no, Avon was just promoting a new anti-frizz product on a steamy summer day, and a lot of folks were giving it a whirl.

headline: A Discouraged Moviegoer, and a Cause for Optimism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Abuse of Painkillers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Old-Fashioned Farming
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Indicts 14 Accused of Supporting Terrorist Group in Somalia
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Thursday announced the indictment of 14 people  many of them United States citizens  accused of funneling “money, personnel and services” to the Shabab, the Islamist terrorist group fighting an insurgency in Somalia.

headline: Survival and a Cancer Drug
text: To the Editor:

headline: Frim Fram Sauce
text: Why, you ask? To go with tomorrow’s column.

headline: Ryan Group Wins Rights to Rangers at Auction
text: FORT WORTH  When the bankruptcy auction of the Texas Rangers ended early Thursday morning after a nearly 16-hour slog, the team was in the hands of Nolan Ryan and Chuck Greenberg, who all along were Major League Baseball’s preferred buyers.

headline: Dursts Make Deal for Stake In New Trade Center Tower
text: The Durst real estate family, which has 10 office towers in Midtown Manhattan, will soon own a piece of what will be New York City’s tallest building  the 1,776-foot skyscraper known as 1 World Trade Center.

headline: Blagojevich Deliberations Lead to Speculation
text: CHICAGO  Speculation over how long it will take jurors to decide the fate of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, has reached the point where one blogger here wondered publicly what a juror’s new choice of casual attire (khaki shorts) might signal about how much longer they would deliberate.

headline: McConnell Not Amused as Franken Fidgets
text: Senator Al Franken, the Minnesota Democrat and former comedian, has kept his irrepressible side pretty well repressed since entering Congress last year. But he failed Thursday.

headline: $16.6 Million in Fines After Fatal Blast at a Connecticut Plant
text: Federal safety officials on Thursday issued $16.6 million in proposed fines in connection with a huge explosion at a power plant that killed six workers in Middletown, Conn., determining that construction companies had blatantly disregarded industry procedures designed to safeguard workers.

headline: Hiroshima and the Art of Outrage
text: Tokyo

headline: Wildfires Spread in Russia
text: Russia’s worst heat wave since record-keeping began here more than 130 years ago has exacerbated a severe drought and wildfires, which have been spreading across the country’s central and western regions.

headline: Romer Leaves as Head of Council of Economic Advisers
text: Christina D. Romer, the chairwoman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, will step down from the post next month, the White House announced Thursday night.

headline: Senate Votes $26 Billion for States and Schools
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday approved $26 billion in aid to states and school districts to prevent the layoffs of tens of thousands of teachers and government workers while allocating $600 million to strengthen border security as senators headed toward an August recess.

headline: Nascar Schedule Shuffle Begins as a Sprint Race Leaves Atlanta
text: Atlanta Motor Speedway, which has played host to at least two races per year in Nascar’s top series since 1960, announced Thursday that it would have only one Sprint Cup race in 2011  the first tweak in what may become a substantial alteration to the season schedule.

headline: Inventing Our Way Out of Joblessness
text: AS President Obama and Congress search for ways to jump-start job creation in our stalled economy, their best strategy may be right under their noses  in the voluminous backlogged files of the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

headline: Creepiness and Twists in a Hostage Thriller
text: The British actor Eddie Marsan ("The New World," "Happy-Go-Lucky") does clenched rage and disappointment better than anyone right now, and he provides the creeps in the creepy, twisty “Disappearance of Alice Creed,” a hostage thriller written and directed by J Blakeson in his feature debut.

headline: Despite Mets’ Struggles, Wilpon Hints at Minaya’s Return
text: Fred Wilpon, principal owner of the Mets, made a comment at a news conference Thursday that indicated Omar Minaya would still be the general manager next year.

headline: In Indonesia, Many Eyes Follow Money for Hajj
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  As the nation with the world’s largest number of Muslims, Indonesia every year sends the most pilgrims to Mecca by far. About one out of 10 believers who performed the hajj last year were Indonesian.

headline: It’s Jeter’s Turn to Chase a Milestone
text: Derek Jeter has an uncluttered mind. It frees him to concentrate on the everyday grind of baseball, not the hypothetical or theoretical. Winning is all that seems to matter to Jeter, who once again is on the cusp of a milestone, even if he would be one of the last to talk about it.

headline: Corporate Funds Aid Centers Tied to Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly a dozen current or former lawmakers have been honored by university endowments financed in part by corporations with business before Congress, posing some potential conflicts like that attributed to Representative Charles B. Rangel in an House ethics complaint.

headline: Jeter Foundation Honors Graduates
text: On the eve of a four-game series against the Boston Red Sox and in the middle of a tight division race, Derek Jeter still found an opportunity Thursday night to have dinner with a few friends.

headline: The Flimflam Man
text: One depressing aspect of American politics is the susceptibility of the political and media establishment to charlatans. You might have thought, given past experience, that D.C. insiders would be on their guard against conservatives with grandiose plans. But no: as long as someone on the right claims to have bold new proposals, he’s hailed as an innovative thinker. And nobody checks his arithmetic.

headline: Guest List for Rangel’s Birthday Celebration Shrinks
text: One New York representative said he could not make it because he had to march in a local firefighters’ parade. Another said that, as much as she wanted to go, she had to visit family out of town. Yet another just sent his regrets, saying he would be traveling that day  in Connecticut.

headline: Ragbrai
text: Bike enthusiasts and amateurs -- numbering near 20,000 this year -- meander across Iowa's highways every July for Ragbrai, a bike event centered more around camaraderie than competition.

headline: A War Story Continued
text: If you saw Ari Taub’s World War II drama “The Fallen” when it was released in New York in 2006, then you know how his new World War II drama, “Last Letters From Monte Rosa,” ends. You also have a pretty good idea of how it begins, and what comes in between. That’s because they’re essentially the same movie.

headline: Home for Life
text: My husband and I spent a year looking for our first home. Every Sunday, we’d jump in the car with driving directions and hope, the latter often dashed before we even got out of the car. The open houses were often short stories unto themselves: what exactly — or who — was behind that padlocked door in the hall? Who thought to put the kitchen next to the master bedroom? What sort of people suspend a suit of armor over their bed?

headline: Martinez Going to Disney World, Then Maybe to Contender
text: Last July, Pedro Martinez signed with Philadelphia as a free agent and helped the defending champion Phillies make a second straight run to the World Series. That run ended in the Bronx, where Martinez was the starting pitcher in the Game 6 finale, won by the Yankees, 7-3.

headline: Xenophobia: Casting Out the Un-French
text: France has no equivalent to the 14th Amendment, but the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, who likes to be known as Sarko the American, also is fanning dangerous anti-immigrant passions for short-term political gain.

headline: An Unusual Concert Tour
text: León Gieco, the well-known Argentine folk singer, is so determined to put the spotlight on others in “Mundo Alas” (“World Wings”), an admirable documentary about an unusual concert tour he led, that you end up wanting to wrestle him into a chair and make him talk.

headline: Xenophobia: Fear-Mongering for American Votes
text: Leading Republicans have gotten chilly toward the Constitution’s 14th Amendment, which guarantees citizenship to people born in the United States. Senators Mitch McConnell, John McCain, Lindsey Graham, Jeff Sessions and Jon Kyl have been suggesting that the country should take a look at it, re-examine it, think it over, hold hearings. They seem worried that maybe we got something wrong nearly 150 years ago, after fighting the Civil War, freeing enslaved Africans and declaring that they and their descendants were not property or partial persons, but free and full Americans.

headline: Exotic Deals Put Denver Schools Deeper in Debt
text: In the spring of 2008, the Denver public school system needed to plug a $400 million hole in its pension fund. Bankers at JPMorgan Chase offered what seemed to be a perfect solution.

headline: In 911 Call, Killer of 8 Spoke of Wanting to Kill More
text: The 911 call lasted just more than four minutes, the rare recorded words of a killer moments after he had slain eight people and was about to end his own life.

headline: Gay Marriage Ruling a Challenge for Both Parties
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A federal judge’s decision on Wednesday overturning Proposition 8 — California’s ban on same-sex marriage — has tossed a largely unwanted issue into the middle of the November midterm elections.

headline: Caveat Emptor, Continued
text: A few years ago, the securities markets financed hundreds of billions of dollars in mortgages without any government guarantee. Now, those markets are virtually closed to such financing.

headline: Wall St. Faces Specter of Lost Trading Units
text: They are the elite among the elite at Goldman Sachs, highfliers who are the envy of Wall Street.

headline: A Mountain View
text: You may not believe it’s possible to bore people to death with a film about risking your life, but “The Wildest Dream” comes shockingly close. Positing that George Mallory, the renowned British climber who vanished on Mount Everest in 1924, might have actually reached the summit, this stodgy documentary from National Geographic Entertainment feels as antiquated as Mallory’s hobnailed boots.

headline: Turning a Crisis Into an Opportunity
text: CHICAGO  At a political fund-raiser on Thursday for a close friend running for his old Senate seat, President Obama brought up the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico to make his case to voters.

headline: The Broadband Gap
text: Since it started measuring in 1999, the Federal Communications Commission invariably concluded that the spread of broadband service was progressing just fine. In 2008, it said more than 99 percent of Americans lived in areas that had access to high-speed Internet networks.

headline: A Campaign Vow Come Due
text: As the nation veers toward an era of laissez-faire campaign spending by corporations and unions, it is urgent that President Obama deliver on his promise to repair the system of publicly subsidized campaign financing.

headline: Two New Paths to the Dream: Regeneration
text: Two research reports published Friday offer novel approaches to the age-old dream of regenerating the body from its own cells.

headline: Revenue at Viacom Remains the Same, but Cost-Cutting Helps Lift Profit
text: Viacom, which is controlled by Sumner M. Redstone, reported roughly the same amount of revenue for the quarter ending in June  $3.3 billion  as it did in the quarter a year earlier, yet its profit rose almost 52 percent, to $420 million, from $277 million last year, largely because of cost cutting.

headline: Imperfect Attendants
text: Watching “The Parking Lot Movie,” a quirky documentary about, yes, a parking lot, is probably not unlike working at such a lot: there are long stretches when not much happens, but every once in a while there’s a burst of activity that is kind of enthralling.

headline: Knoxville Mayor Wins Tennessee G.O.P. Primary
text: Knoxville’s mayor, Bill Haslam, won the Republican primary for governor of Tennessee, beating four opponents in a hotly contested race.

headline: Top Obama Adviser on Economics to Step Down
text: WASHINGTON  Christina D. Romer is resigning as the chairwoman of President Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers, the White House announced on Thursday night. She will be the second member this summer to leave an economic team that has steered the administration through the worst recession since the Depression.

headline: Barclays Reports 29% Rise in Profit, Highlighting European Gains
text: The British banking giant Barclays said Thursday that its profit rose 29 percent in the first half as provisions for credit losses declined, especially at its investment banking unit.

headline: Two Men and Not Quite a Baby
text: Tanya Tucker belting on the soundtrack of a Swedish romantic comedy is not something you hear every day, but she fits right in with the general eccentricity of “Patrik, Age 1.5.”

headline: Conservative Jurist, With Independent Streak
text: Judge Vaughn R. Walker has ruled on cases involving newspaper mergers, high-tech corporate battles and the Bush administration’s use of wiretaps without warrants. But nothing has earned him as much attention  and ire  as Wednesday’s decision declaring California’s Proposition 8 ban on same-sex marriage unconstitutional.

headline: Five and Five: No. 33, Missouri
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 33, is Missouri. You can find a larger Missouri preview at Pre-Snap Read.

headline: Chancellor Declares Emergency to Sidestep State Ruling and Expand Charter School
text: It took almost six months for David M. Steiner, the state education commissioner, to decide that New York City had broken the law when it decided to take space from a program for autistic children on the Lower East Side and give it to an expanding charter school.

headline: Bloggingheads: Did Obama Save Us?
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Rich Lowry of National Review debate whether President Obama prevented economic catastrophe.

headline: Body of Missing Boy Is Found in Desert About a Mile From Home
text: PHOENIX  It was not a needle in a haystack but a toddler in the desert, both of which are extremely challenging to find.

headline: Snurfer
text: I feel the earth — move — under my feetI feel the sky tum-b-ling down — tum-b-ling down

headline: A Busy Love Life
text: There are moments during the slog through “Lucky Days,” a dreary vanity project by Angelica Torn, that you think the whole thing could be a very, very deadpan parody. But eventually you have to acknowledge that this unpleasant drama set on Coney Island isn’t deadpan; it’s just dead.

headline: Medicare Stronger, Social Security Worse in Short Run, Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON  Medicare will remain financially solvent for 12 additional years, until 2029, because of the cost-cutting measures in President Obama’s recently enacted health care legislation, the program’s trustees projected on Thursday.

headline: Boxing Dreams
text: In “The Kid: Chamaco,” a gauche but likable first feature from Miguel Necoechea, a Mexican boy dreams of becoming a famous boxer. In his way are poverty, an abusive father, a corrupt cop and a bad case of asthma; in his corner are a washed-up Olympian and a kindly American doctor. Since the doctor is played by none other than Martin Sheen, we know the cinema gods, at least, are on the kid’s side.

headline: Judge Orders Protection for Wolves in 2 States
text: A federal judge ruled Thursday that gray wolves in Montana and Idaho must be given the same protections under the federal Endangered Species Act as their cousins in Wyoming.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Excerpt From New York Education: Powers and Duties of Chancellor
text: From Article 52-A - 2590-h (2-a) (f):Powers and Duties of Chancellor

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Top Time of Year in Breaststroke
text: IRVINE, Calif.  Rebecca Soni clocked the fastest time in the world this year in the 100-meter breaststroke Thursday at the USA Swimming national championships, easily beating a star-studded field that included the sentimental favorite, Amanda Beard.

headline: After Marriage Ruling, Uncertainty Still Lingers
text: Hours after a federal judge declared California’s ban on same-sex marriage unconstitutional on Wednesday, Phil Ting, San Francisco’s assessor-recorder, stood on the steps of City Hall and addressed a cheering crowd.

headline: Zhao Retakes Lead at Women’s Chess Grand Prix
text: After a clash of co-leaders in Round 6 on Thursday, Zhao Xue is once again leading the tournament in Mongolia.

headline: Schumer Bill Seeks to Protect Fashion Design
text: The American fashion industry has been pushing hard over the last four years for copyright protection for its designs. An earlier bill in the House was deemed too broad; clothing makers argued that protection against knock-offs would only encourage frivolous lawsuits from people claiming they had the idea first. Today, after a year of negotiations, Senator Charles E. Schumer introduced a bill that seemed to satisfy the different sides of the fashion industry — and may provide some protection, too.

headline: South Korea: Naval Exercises Start
text: South Korea on Thursday began one of its largest naval exercises ever in waters near a disputed border with North Korea, despite the North’s threat to retaliate. The exercises took place near where a South Korean Navy ship sank in March, torpedoed, according to South Korean investigators, by North Korea. Military officials said that South Korean marines spent the first day running drills aimed at searching for and destroying enemy submarines.

headline: Mexico: Marriage Law Upheld
text: The Supreme Court upheld Mexico City’s same-sex marriage law on Thursday in an 8-to-2 decision, but postponed deciding related issues, like the adoption of children by same-sex couples, until next week. Rejecting a challenge by the attorney general, the court based its decision on the principle of equal rights and the responsibility of state governments, including the federal district that includes Mexico City, for writing their own marriage laws. The federal government had argued that the law, the first in Latin America allowing same-sex couples to marry, violates a constitutional clause protecting the family. The justices in the majority said the Constitution did not define what constituted a family.

headline: Pakistan: U.S. Flood Aid Arrives
text: American helicopters began evacuating people and delivering aid to flood-ravaged northwestern Pakistan on Thursday in an effort to aid Pakistani rescue efforts and sway hearts and minds. Six Army helicopters evacuated more than 800 people from the Swat Valley and ferried 66,000 pounds of relief supplies, the United States Embassy said. The United States also said that it would provide $25 million in relief aid, in addition to the $10 million already committed. The floods, which began last week, have claimed at least 1,400 lives and uprooted more than three million people.

headline: In Violent Oakland, a Rap Producer Is Changing His Tune
text: John Davis is one of the most popular rap producers in Oakland, even though he is no longer allowed to live there under the conditions of his parole.

headline: Rosie O’Donnell to Be Host of OWN Channel Talk Show
text: Rosie O’Donnell, no longer determined to fill the time slots soon to be left by Oprah Winfrey on broadcast television, said Thursday that she was joining Ms. Winfrey’s forthcoming cable channel, OWN.

headline: Belongings of Russian Agents Reveal Their Everyday Lives
text: Mini-recorders and notebooks. A publication on a Lockheed military aircraft. A pocket watch containing Russian writing. Sheet music. And a whoopee cushion.

headline: Tofu Maker Is Idled After Recall of Products
text: Outside a padlocked warehouse on Airport Boulevard in South San Francisco, a row of parked trucks bearing the slogan “Quong Hop & Co. quality soy foods since 1906” sit idle.

headline: Dreams and Schemes Explode Into Global Trouble
text: A comedy with you-know-who’s name in the title may not be a natural sell in America, but it’s hard to imagine the likable, gently satiric Bollywood film “Tere Bin Laden” (“Without Bin Laden”) ruffling too many feathers.

headline: With an Assist From Craigslist, a Sex Worker Plies His Trade
text: James sat at the Sweet Inspiration cafe on Market Street in San Francisco, sipped ginger ginseng tea and talked about his job. He was once a barista in a place like this, but today he works in the oldest profession.

headline: U.S. Changes Plan for Capturing Emissions From Coal
text: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department abruptly shifted course on Thursday on a flagship federal effort to capture and sequester carbon dioxide from coal-fired power plants, saying it would not finance construction of a new plant in Mattoon, Ill.

headline: The Uncertainties of the Volcker Rule
text: Goldman Sachs may be rushing to reorganize or spin off its private equity and proprietary trading units to comply with the newly enacted Volcker Rule. But the directive, intended to prevent banks from making big bets for their own accounts, remains vague enough for Goldman and its Wall Street rivals to put plenty of money at risk.

headline: New Editor of the Stylish at Condé Nast
text: Margaret Russell will succeed Paige Rense  once known as the archduchess of decorating  as editor in chief of Architectural Digest, Condé Nast announced on Thursday.

headline: Israel: Turkish Boat Heads Home
text: The Mavi Marmara, the Turkish passenger boat at the center of a deadly raid by Israeli naval commandos as it tried to breach the blockade of Gaza in late May, was towed out of Haifa on Thursday on its way back to Turkey. Israel’s Defense Ministry said it would release two more Turkish vessels that were part of the flotilla.

headline: Judge Sentences Ex-Officer to 5 Years for Sexual Abuse
text: A former New York City police officer who was convicted in separate trials of sexually abusing two women and trying to coerce a third to give him oral sex was sentenced on Thursday to five years in prison.

headline: Marilyn Buck, Imprisoned for Brink’s Holdup, Dies at 62
text: Marilyn Buck, who served more than two decades in prison for her role in the 1981 Brink’s armored-car robbery in Rockland County, N.Y., in which three people were killed, died on Tuesday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 62.

headline: Snagged by an N.C.A.A. Rule on Transfers
text: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: After Broadway, Obamas Turn to Washington Theater
text: Having shined a White House spotlight on Broadway over the last year, President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama are turning their attentions to theater closer to home. Arena Stage, the 60-year-old theatrical company in Washington, announced Thursday that the Obamas would be the honorary chairpeople for its inaugural 2010-11 season at its new home, the Mead Center for American Theater, in Southwest Washington. The Obamas will also serve as honorary chairs for an Oct. 25 black-tie dinner  to celebrate Arena’s move into the Mead Center.

headline: Pressure Building on Future of 2 Coal-Burning Power Plants
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley has repeatedly billed himself as a green mayor and recently vowed to use “every available tool” to reduce the city’s carbon footprint, but critics say City Hall has failed to grapple with Chicago’s two most significant sources of greenhouse-gas pollution.

headline: Settling Scores and Looking Out for No. 1, Hendon-Style
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A City Deal Doesn’t End Overtime
text: Even though most of Chicago’s unionized workers agreed to forgo overtime pay and take unpaid furlough days to help reduce the city’s staggering budget deficit, many city workers continue to enjoy some of the most lucrative blue-collar work available: overtime.

headline: Space Walkers Will Sit It Out Another Day
text: A spacewalk to replace a broken coolant pump on the International Space Station has been delayed another day to Saturday morning. NASA officials said the additional day was needed to finish details and gave the space walkers a day to review the plans. A second spacewalk, to finish hooking up the replacement pump has also been pushed back, to Wednesday. The pump, which broke last Saturday, moves ammonia coolant through a loop on the outside of the space station, one of two such cooling loops. Until the pump repairs are complete, the station is operating with reduced power to avoid overheating, and scientific research has been curtailed.

headline: Exotic Deals Put Denver Schools Deeper in Debt
text: In the spring of 2008, the Denver public school system needed to plug a $400 million hole in its pension fund. Bankers at JPMorgan Chase offered what seemed to be a perfect solution, Gretchen Morgenson reports in The New York Times.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.
