text: They are the elite among the elite at Goldman Sachs, highfliers who are the envy of Wall Street.

headline: Biopic About Jerry Garcia Won’t Include His Songs
text: Bummer, man: a planned biographical film about Jerry Garcia will have to keep on truckin’ without any of the original music of the Grateful Dead or the involvement of Mr. Garcia’s family, Variety reported. Last month it was announced that Amir Bar-Lev, a filmmaker whose features include the documentaries “The Tillman Story” and “My Kid Could Paint That,” would direct a biographical film about Mr. Garcia, above, the Grateful Dead co-founder, lead guitarist and vocalist, who died on Aug. 9, 1995. Mr. Bar-Lev’s film, written by Topper Lilien, is adapted from the Robert Greenfield book “Dark Star: An Oral Biography of Jerry Garcia,” which includes interviews with Mr. Garcia’s band mates and relatives, and focuses on his frequent drug use, among other problems he faced in his life. In a statement reported by Variety, Mr. Garcia’s estate and the band’s production company said: “We want to make clear that neither Grateful Dead Productions nor the Jerry Garcia Family LLC are in any way working with  or are in any other way affiliated with  the supposed upcoming Amir Bar-Lev-directed biopic about Jerry Garcia. We will not be licensing any recordings from Grateful Dead or Jerry Garcia’s music library for this production, nor will we provide the producer-director with access to any Garcia family members.” Variety said the film would probably use other people’s songs covered by Mr. Garcia earlier in his career.

headline: Greece Gets Good Progress Report
text: Greece’s international lenders cleared the way Thursday for Athens to receive the next installment of its bailout package, in the latest sign that the crisis surrounding European finances was starting to ebb, Suzanne Daley and Matthew Saltmarsh report in The New York Times.

headline: Mary Hart to Leave ‘entertainment Tonight’
text: After almost three decades of imbuing “Entertainment Tonight” with one of the perkiest dispositions and some of the shiniest teeth on television, Mary Hart said on Thursday that she would leave that syndicated pop-culture show at the end of its coming 30th season. Ms. Hart, right, a Miss South Dakota turned television broadcaster, joined the fast-paced “Entertainment Tonight” in 1982. In a statement she said: “I’ve reached a point when I clearly realize it’s time for a change. There are many things I want to do in my life, and I’d better get on with them. It will certainly be with mixed sentiments that I say goodbye at the end of the season, but it will definitely be with a sense of celebration.” The coming season of “Entertainment Tonight” is to have its premiere on Sept. 13. CBS Television Distribution, which produces the series, said no decision had been made on Ms. Hart’s replacement.

headline: Politician Settles Case Over Don Henley Songs
text: Don Henley, the once and future Eagle and solo singer-songwriter, has reached a settlement with, and received an apology from, Chuck DeVore, the California politician, and Justin Hart, a worker for Mr. DeVore’s 2010 United States Senate campaign, who were found to have violated the copyrights to two Henley hits. Mr. Henley, above, and his fellow musicians Mike Campbell and Danny Kortchmar filed suit against Mr. DeVore, a Republican member of the California State Assembly, and Mr. Hart, saying that parodies of “The Boys of Summer” (originally written by Mr. Henley and Mr. Campbell) and “All She Wants to Do Is Dance” (Mr. Kortchmar) that Mr. DeVore used in his campaign ads were made without permission. In June Judge James V. Selna of United States District Court in Santa Ana, Calif., sided with Mr. Henley on his claim. In a statement Mr. DeVore and Mr. Hart apologized to the musicians, saying: “The court’s ruling in this case confirms that political candidates, regardless of affiliation, should seek appropriate license authority before they use copyrighted works. Further, we regret all inaccurate, derogatory or disparaging remarks made about Mr. Henley during the course of this dispute.”

headline: Ravi Coltrane Signs With Blue Note
text: Ravi Coltrane, the highly regarded tenor and soprano saxophonist, is the newest addition to the roster of Blue Note Records, with an album due out next spring. His signing unites the most storied label in jazz, one of the last majors standing, with a saxophonist-bandleader from an imposing lineage: Mr. Coltrane’s father was John Coltrane, who similarly played tenor and soprano, reshaping the language of jazz improvisation from the mid-1950s up to his death in 1967. Mr. Coltrane, above, who turns 45 on Friday, comes to Blue Note with an established track record, having made albums for RCA Victor and Savoy Jazz. “Ravi’s a guy we’ve been watching for a long time,” said Bruce Lundvall, the chairman emeritus of Blue Note. The decision to sign Mr. Coltrane was made last year, he said, in the midst of festivities around the label’s 70th anniversary. John Coltrane was never signed to Blue Note, but he did make one important album for the label, the 1957 hard-bop classic “Blue Train.” And in 2005 Blue Note released “Thelonious Monk Quartet With John Coltrane at Carnegie Hall,” a newly discovered recording of a 1957 concert.

headline: Major-Network Choices: Reality or Reruns?
text: Wednesday night’s edition of “America’s Got Talent” lifted NBC to another victory in the ratings, as 10 million viewers tuned in to the reality competition, according to Nielsen’s estimates. NBC drew somewhat lower ratings the rest of the night with “Minute to Win It” (6.8 million) and a repeat of “Law & Order: SVU” (5.9 million). CBS ranked second with a new “Big Brother” (6.9 million) and a repeat of “Criminal Minds” (7.1 million). Fox was third as “So You Think You Can Dance” averaged 6.1 million viewers. ABC finished fourth with comedy reruns.

headline: An Early ‘idol’ Producer Returns to the Fold
text: The makeover of “American Idol” marched forward on Thursday when Fox confirmed that Nigel Lythgoe would return to the show as one of the executive producers. The creator of “Idol,” Simon Fuller, said in a statement that Mr. Lythgoe would “help redefine” the nine-year-old singing competition. His return to the show, which he helped get off the ground, was first reported as likely last week. Mr. Lythgoe signaled in an interview this week that he wanted the show to renew its focus on the contestants. “Where are these kids?” he told Variety. “That has got to be the priority, more than anything. More than the judges’ panel.” That said, the changes to the panel are a priority at the moment. Last week the judge Ellen DeGeneres confirmed she was quitting the program, and another judge, Kara DioGuardi, is also expected to leave. The leading candidates to join the judges’ panel are Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler of the band Aerosmith, though Fox said on Monday that no deals had been signed. Separately, The Los Angeles Times said on Wednesday that the music producer Jimmy Iovine was joining “Idol” as “a mentor of sorts” for the contestants.

headline: Trichet Sees Reasons for Optimism in Europe
text: The president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, offered a somewhat more optimistic assessment of the euro zone economy Thursday and said that bank stress tests in July were “an important step forward in restoring market confidence.”

headline: Wildfires Ravaging Swaths of Russia
text: MOSCOW  Wildfires that have overwhelmed Russia’s firefighting services and burned freely through large areas of the heat-seared countryside have claimed 52 lives, clouded Moscow in smoke and on Friday forced the military to transfer rockets away from a garrison near the capital.

headline: Canadian Finance Chief’s So-Called Problem
text: In a world of deepening fiscal deficits, Finance Minister Jim Flaherty of Canada has a rare problem: His country’s strong economy is pushing up the currency. And even that doesn’t really worry him.

headline: Winning Funds Wary of Slowdown
text: Winning hedge fund managers expect the American and European economies to slow, according to Bloomberg Businessweek. With some saying they plan to bet against industries that do poorly when the economy loses steam and others betting against consumer-related stocks, hedge fund managers are taking less risk, using less debt and making fewer trades.

text: The European Central Bank supports temporary bans on naked short selling of European credit default swaps and shares in extreme market conditions, but has warned against permanent action to stop shorting, Retuers reported.

text: Axiom Asia Private Capital, run by former managers of the  Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, plans to allocate more money to Vietnam and other private-equity markets that are shunned by most investors, Bloomberg News reported.

text: Barclays delivered a thinly veiled threat to the British government on Thursday, warning that a break-up could force it to move abroad. The Financial Times reported that the warning came as the bank defended its approach of combining retail and investment banking under one roof.

headline: At Hiroshima Ceremony, a First for a U.S. Envoy

headline: Tip of the Week: Navigating Microsoft Office 2010
text: Microsoft Office 2010 came out this summer, and users who made the leap from Office 2003 or earlier may find the “ribbon” that replaces the on-screen toolbars to be confusing. To help newcomers get used to the ribbon, Microsoft has made a game of it. Ribbon Hero, released this year, is a tool that combines casual gaming with interactive software training to teach users how to find commands in the ribbon for Word, Excel, PowerPoint and OneNote. While the experimental game may not be for everyone (or for those who wish the ribbon were more intuitive in the first place), it may help ease some frustration for others. Ribbon Hero is free to download.

headline: Samsung Adds Pop-Out U.S.B. to Camera

headline: America’s Venture Capitalist in Chief

headline: Hard-Line Islam Fills Void in Flooded Pakistan
text: CHARSADDA, Pakistan  As public anger rises over the government’s slow and chaotic response to Pakistan’s worst flooding in 80 years, hard-line Islamic charities have stepped into the breach with a grass-roots efficiency that is earning them new support among Pakistan’s beleaguered masses.

headline: The Rabbi
text: Newsweek just published a list, “The 50 Most Influential Rabbis in America,” and placed you at No. 1. As a Hasidic rabbi and a leader of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement, do you think you can rank rabbis or any other religious leaders as if they were athletes?  I am of the opinion that you can’t rank human beings. Every person has something to contribute to the welfare of the next human being. No two people think alike or look alike, and everyone has something that another person does not have. Who’s to say who is higher and who’s lower? In terms of the essence of human beings, I don’t feel it’s proper to rank them because we don’t really know what their mission in life is.

headline: Accounting Charge Aside, A.I.G.’s Profits Rise
text: 7:39 a.m. | Updated The American International Group said on Friday that it lost nearly $2.7 billion for the second quarter, swinging from a profit during the same time last year as it took an accounting charge for a big unit it plans to sell to MetLife.

headline: The Classroom Showroom
text: My husband donated time and money to computerize a public-middle-school-teacher’s successful remedial math program. It is up and running in that teacher’s classroom. A number of people, including the school’s principal, have come to see it in action and are interested in using it in their private- and public-school classrooms. This teacher would be pleased to sell it to them and other math teachers. May this public-school classroom ethically be a showroom for interested visitors? NAME WITHHELD, NEW MEXICO

headline: Amazon’s Prime Suspect
text: I’m a member of Amazon Prime, and I can’t help congratulating myself. Though I should know better, I persist in believing that Amazon Prime, a program that for an annual fee gets me “free” two-day shipping on purchases from Amazon, is something I’ve been tapped for — like Skull and Bones. Sure, I know that Amazon flogs Amazon Prime on every Web street corner, and if you shop even once at the nation’s largest online retailer you practically have to fight not to join up, which is to say, to pay the 79 bucks that make you a member. But on most days I’m so delighted by the warm welcome the site gives me, the exciting word “free” — it never gets old — and Amazon Prime’s many right-this-way-madams that I let myself believe I’m just better and wiser than other Amazon shoppers. With the double-consciousness of the recreational shopper, who knows the clerks are on commission but still craves their solicitousness, I refuse to even entertain the idea I’m being suckered.

headline: Creative New Uses for Books
text: In July, Amazon.com announced that, during the previous three months, it sold more e-books than hardback books. This may or may not portend something about the future of the form in which long chunks of text are published. But what about the future of the long chunks of text that have already been published as physical objects with paper pages bound between covers? There are, after all, many such things around. Set aside any emotional attachment you may feel toward the reading of physical books; the truth is that creative uses for books that do not involve engaging with words on a page already abound.

headline: A Discarded Chair Finds Its Way Home Again
text: Every year our city, Winston-Salem, has Bulky Item Collection days, which are greeted with rabid interest by the gleaning appetites of, it seems, the entire population. The year I helped move my parents out of the house they’d been in for more than 40 years, we would drag some of the detritus of the ages to the street and then stumble back for another load, and in the seven minutes it took to bring some more junk to the curb, the first pile would be picked clean. Only pottery shards and a few rusted hangers resembling dried bones were left.

headline: It’s Friday, So Why Not Talk to Betty White?
text: Betty White doesn’t need your approval. She’s such a rock star now that in addition to her regular role on the TV Land comedy “Hot in Cleveland” (which was recently picked up for a second season), she can also accept a recurring guest spot on the NBC series “Community” and call its cast delightful to their faces and no one can stop her. And she will turn down your offer to appear in a Hallmark Hall of Fame movie until you ask again nicely, and then tell you it’s a lovely script, just to let you know who’s boss. And if you tease her sarcastically at a public event, be prepared to face the full force of her endearing rejoinders.

headline: On Our Radar: Russia Warns of Climate Change
text: During an unparalleled heat wave, President Dmitri Medvedev of Russia steps up his climate warnings. “Everyone is talking about climate change now. Unfortunately, what is happening now in our central regions is evidence of this global climate change, because we have never in our history faced such weather conditions in the past,” he says. “This means that we need to change the way we work, change the methods that we used in the past.” [Kremlin]

They think you can just skim it and get the gist; and people like Mr. Ryan have taken advantage of that misconception.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Avengers Assemble!
text: The hardcover list continues to show how event stories can pay off for the big two comic-book companies. This week, 6 of the 10 slots are devoted to “Blackest Night,” which reigned over the DC Comics universe while killing off some characters, reintroducing others and generally shaking up the status quo. “Rise of the Black Lanterns” at No. 2 and “Tales of the Corps” at No. 3 provide more back story for the main event. At No. 7 is the collected edition of the Marvel Comics series “Siege,” which put aside years of distrust among that company’s heroes and ushered in a new age of camaraderie.

headline: Sportier but Thirstier, a Hybrid Honda Tries to Be Hip
text: WHEN Honda showed the CR-Z concept car at the Tokyo Motor Show in 2007, it appeared alongside some of the wacky Japanese design exercises that the biannual show is known for. One difference between the CR-Z and the Nissan Pivo 2 (with a pivoting cabin), the Toyota Hi-CT (with styling akin to a shrunken Zamboni) and other flights of fancy is that the CR-Z actually goes on sale Aug. 24, looking pretty much as it did on stage.

headline: Demystifying, and Maybe Decreasing, the Emergency Room Bill

headline: A Lehman Survivor’s View of a World Upended

Mr. McDonald sat down with DealBook to discuss the future of derivatives, how more securitization would help the American economy, what some bank balance sheets are hiding, and why Lehman and Bear Stearns were brought down not by their real estate investments, but by their hedges.

headline: Terry Gilliam Takes Total Control of Arcade Fire
text: Despite what Terry Gilliam told us on Thursday, that he was “just a follower,” not really the director of Arcade Fire‘s YouTube concert Webcast. a comedy skit shown before the performance (and in the above video) revealed otherwise: in fact, the band is comprised entirely of robots who obey Mr. Gilliam’s every command, more or less. The skit also features Andrew Garfield, the actor who was recently cast to play Spider-Man in a reboot of that film franchise. So, knowing Mr. Gilliam’s movie-making karma, watch for Mr. Garfield to drop out of “Spider-Man” because of  a herniated disk any day now.

headline: How I Saved My Company: The New Center for Advanced Psychotherapy Studies
text: The New Center for Advanced Psychotherapy Studies is a training institute for psychotherapists and psychoanalysts. It offers supervision and consultation and study groups by telephone — and tries to help therapists succeed financially in their practices.

headline: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Changes
text: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that month’s nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: What the Great Recession Has Done to Family Life
text: Economists may assert that we’re in the early stages of a recovery, but surveys continue to show that the impact of the Great Recession on American families is deep, widespread and grim. A Pew Research poll published last month indicated that more than half of all adults in the U.S. labor force had experienced some “work-related hardship” — a period of unemployment, a pay cut, a reduction in work hours or an involuntary move to part-time employment — since the recession began in December 2007. A report in March from the Population Reference Bureau showed that more than 70 percent of Americans age 40 and over felt they had been affected by the economic crisis. Government data indicate that the net worth of the average American household has shrunk by about 20 percent — the greatest such decline since the end of World War II. Long-term unemployment — joblessness lasting six months or more — is also at its highest level since the mid-1940s. According to recent data from the Rockefeller Institute, 20 percent of Americans have seen their available household income decline by 25 percent or more.

headline: ‘Marienbad’ Revisited
text: Movies haunt culture like starlit ghosts, circling our collective unconscious. Some insinuate themselves because they are comforting and friendly, which is not the case with ‘‘Last Year at Marienbad,’’ a famously impenetrable monument to the avant-garde directed by Alain Resnais. But the discovery of six reels of behind-the-scenes footage from 1960 forever fractures the movie’s cool, calculated surface. With a Super-8 camera, Françoise Spira, a young cast member with a bit part, produced what seems like an amateur version of the film itself, her relationship to its protagonist, played by Delphine Seyrig, as intimate as Resnais’s. Spira committed suicide a few years later, and her celluloid diary languished until 2008. The movie’s second assistant director, Volker Schlöndorff, later turned it into the documentary ‘‘The Making of ‘Last Year at Marienbad,’ ’’ which Diane von Furstenberg toasted at her studio in June after a screening at New York University. Schlöndorff was there, as well as Jean-Luc Godard’s biographer Richard Brody, the photographer Steven Klein, Ahn Duong, Daphne Guinness and the documentary’s principal promoter, Bernard-Henri Lévy.

Those teams are so easy to cheer for, bring so much charm to sports. Can you really not root for the Tampa Bay Rays, with their microscopic payroll (compared with the Yankees) and aw-shucks manager? Can you really not root for Boise State football, with all those status quo rattling rallies in a sport whose stuffed-shirt establishment refuses to acknowledge it belongs?

headline: Astral Bodies
text: Anyone who thinks astronauts ply a glamorous trade would do well to read Mary Roach’s “Packing for Mars.” The book is an often hilarious, sometimes queasy-making catalog of the strange stuff devised to permit people to survive in an environment for which their bodies are stupendously unsuited. Roach eases us into the story, with an anecdote that reveals the cultural differences among spacefaring nations. In Japan, psychologists evaluate astronaut candidates by, among other things, their ability to fold origami cranes swiftly under stress.

headline: Bloomberg Blasts Mosque Critics

headline: Never Say Die
text: Early in Gary Shteyngart’s “Absurdistan” the narrator says he is “almost disabused” of the belief that he can fly. The word “almost” is beautifully exact. Shteyngart’s characters never give in to reality all at once. They have immigrant skills and immigrant illusions, and they come from countries that are themselves in the process of migrating: in one novel a Russia that wants to be America, in another an America that imagines it is not Russia.

headline: When the Screen Goes Blank
text: It’s become gauche, lately, to criticize television. In the age of “The Sopranos,” “The Wire,” “Lost” and “Mad Men,” TV has achieved a measure of cultural respectability that would flummox longtime naysayers. The guy who constantly mentions he doesn’t own a television is an Onion joke. If you really believe that TV is a wasteland, you’re either a crank, a pedant or unfortunate enough to have missed that one episode of “Battlestar Galactica” in which we find out about the Cylons.

headline: Going Digital
text: It sounds odd, but a comic novel need not be particularly funny. Of course it doesn’t hurt if it is. Whenever I read “Don Quixote” I am laughing to myself in the first page or two, and I have involuntary bursts of laughter probably every 10 minutes. But other great comic novels — Dawn Powell’s “Time to Be Born,” John Barth’s “Giles Goat-Boy,” Gilbert Sorrentino’s “Mulligan Stew” — make me laugh less often than many other novels that aren’t in the genre. What distinguishes the comic novel is that it takes the spiritual rather than the tragic view of life. It tries to reconcile us to existence as it ­really is, rather than suggesting that we try to change things or chuck the whole mess. This is why Miguel de Unamuno once remarked that, given the choice between Christ and Don Quixote, the Spanish take sides with the knight of the doleful countenance. Christ makes us weep for this world, while Quixote makes us glad to be here. We’re not eager for the next life because this one is very entertaining.

headline: State and Local Government Jobs Take a Beating
text: Most of the net payroll loss in July can be attributed to the end of temporary federal Census jobs. But state and local government payrolls also took a beating last month.

headline: They Got the Beat
text: So let’s assume that if you’re reading this, you already know that the first clip ever to run on MTV was “Video Killed the Radio Star” by the Buggles. The goofy New Wave number was a shot across the bow, the perfect mission statement for the upstart network, which will celebrate its 30th anniversary this summer. O.K., then, smart guy, what was broadcast next — what was MTV’s first “regular” video?

headline: Sorrow in Her Voice
text: In 1970, after the Vietnam War and a host of heated causes had turned the country into a mass of raw nerve endings, a young duo emerged on AM radio. Singing of “white lace and promises” and “so much of life ahead,” they offered America hope, and became sudden super­stars. The Carpenters were a sister and brother who lived with their parents in a West Coast suburb. Karen sang lead; Richard played keyboards, multitracked his voice into an electronic choral blur and arranged with an obsessive ear for perfection. Every rough edge was buffed away and bathed in Southern California sunlight.

headline: Your Tired, Your Poor and Their Food
text: One of the first sights that greeted immigrants in New York, right after the Statue of Liberty, was a prune sandwich. The offending object appeared on the menu in the vast dining hall at Ellis Island, and it served as a warning that food was going to be a cultural struggle in this strange land. Keeping faith with their native cuisines, the newcomers made a series of counteroffers — sauerkraut, spaghetti, borscht — that changed the national palate forever. Jane Ziegelman tells this story exuberantly in “97 Orchard: An Edible History of Five Immigrant Families in One New York Tenement.” Highly entertaining and deceptively ambitious, the book resurrects the juicy details of breakfast, lunch and dinner (recipes included) consumed by poor and working-class New Yorkers a century and more ago. It could well have been subtitled “How the Other Half Ate.”

headline: Seth MacFarlane: From ‘Family Guy’ to Music Man
text: You give a nerd a record deal, and this is the record you get: Seth MacFarlane, the pop-cultural polymath who created and provides many of the voices on the Fox animated comedy “Family Guy,” will be lending his pipes to an album of 1940s and ’50s-era show tunes for Universal Republic Records, the label said on Friday. The album, which will be produced and arranged by Joel McNeely (whose credits include Mr. MacFarlane’s series “American Dad”) will include standards by Rodgers and Hammerstein, and Lerner and Loewe, as well as a song called “She’s Wonderful, Too” that Mr. McNeely wrote for the television show “The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles.” (Mr. MacFarlane and Mr. McNeely said in a statement that they had received the approval of the “Indiana Jones” producer George Lucas to add “additional lyrics and melodies to make a new and more complete song” out of it.)

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE GOOD SOLDIERS, by David Finkel. (Picador, $15.) The soldiers of Finkel’s title belong to an Army battalion from Fort Riley, Kan. (average age 19), and they are stationed in a violent neighborhood on the eastern edge of Baghdad during the surge of 2007-8. This “ferociously reported, darkly humorous and spellbinding book,” as our reviewer, Doug Stanton, described it, tells “what it felt like” and “gives unforgettable voice” to those “whose voices we otherwise might not have heard.” It was one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2009.

headline: The Kids’ Books Are All Right
text: While au fait literary types around town await the buzzed-about new novels from Jonathan Franzen and Nicole Krauss, other former English majors have spent the summer trying to get hold of “Mockingjay,” the third book in Suzanne Collins’s dystopian trilogy, so intensely under wraps that not even reviewers have been allowed a glimpse before its airtight Aug. 24 release. What fate will befall our heroine, Katniss Everdeen? My fellow book club members and I are desperate to know. When will the Capitol fall? And how can Collins possibly top the first two installments, “The Hunger Games” and “Catching Fire”?

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FOUR FISH: The Future of the Last Wild Food,  by Paul Greenberg (Penguin Press, $25.95.) Even as Greenberg lays out the grim and complicated facts about the ravaging of our seas, he manages to sound some hopeful notes about the ultimate fate of fish.

headline: The Next-to-Last Tycoon
text: Jay Gatsby is one of the most memorable characters in American fiction. But so is Tom Buchanan, his adversary and foil. Cruel, avaricious, thick as two planks, Tom is the apotheosis of the Ivy League slob, Jazz Age edition. Tom, as F. Scott Fitzgerald conceives him, has no redeeming virtues. He’s a lecher, a racist and a dope. He reads books like “The Rise of the Colored Empires” and then declares: “If we don’t look out the white race will be — will be utterly submerged. It’s all scientific stuff, it’s been proved.” He never says anything original or interesting; he’s too stupid to realize his wife despises him. He went to Yale in an era when Yale was still turning out battalions of well-connected dopes, an era that’s not as far in the past as some would like to believe. Buchanan, in the words of Nick Carraway, the narrator of “Gatsby,” is a man of “hard malice” with a “peculiar quality of oppressiveness.”

headline: Presumed Indecent
text: No one likes having her husband murdered, but it’s just plain mortifying when he turns up dead in the apartment of an unattractive prostitute. “Objectively speaking,” says Susie Gersten, wife of the victim, “I swear to God, she looked like a ewe in a blond wig.” Susie is certain that her husband, Jonah, would never have visited Dorinda Dillon (formerly Cristal Rousseau) for any unsavory reason. Objectively speaking, Susie (formerly Susan B. Anthony Rabinowitz) knows that she herself is gorgeous. Besides, Jonah, a Park Avenue plastic surgeon, had a moral code so strict that he never even tried to get out of jury duty. Most important, he adored Susie and their triplet sons, Dashiell, Evan and Mason.

headline: Mad to Talk
text: “Tonight while walking on the waterfront in the angelic streets I suddenly wanted to tell you how wonderful I think you are,” Jack Kerouac began a typical letter to his friend Allen Ginsberg in 1950. “God’s angels are ravishing and fooling me. I saw a whore and an old man in a lunch cart, and God — their faces! I wondered what God was up to.” God’s purpose would remain opaque to Kerouac — try as he might to impart some glimpse of it in his work — and a dec­ade later he was pretty much a burnt-out case. Poring over his old correspondence with Ginsberg and others in 1961, he sadly wondered at “the enthusiasms of younger men.” “Someday ‘The Letters of Allen Ginsberg to Jack Kerouac’ will make America cry,” he wrote.

headline: A View of the Bridge
text: It’s hard to believe that only 73 years ago, the Golden Gate Bridge did not exist. The airplane is older than the Golden Gate Bridge. The particle accelerator is older than the Golden Gate Bridge. Betty White is older than the Golden Gate Bridge.

headline: Average Length of Unemployment Falls
text: For the first time since February, the average length that the typical jobless worker has been looking for work declined, to 34.2 weeks in July.

headline: Wanderlust | Tel Aviv’s New Un-Mall
text: A seaside promenade notwithstanding, Tel Aviv is not known for its open spaces. But this concrete condition has improved considerably with the gleaming transformation of HaTachana, the Hebrew name for the old Jaffa railway station, into the city’s newest marketplace. Constructed in 1892 as the terminus for the Jaffa-Jerusalem railway, it’s become an instant hit with locals who, like Manhattanites, never say no to a piece of the sky or a new hipster nook. HaTachana offers both, and the location couldn’t be better: between the beach and Neve Tzedek, the city’s first Jewish settlement outside Jaffa and now a lively district of renovated pastel houses and designer boutiques, especially along Shabazi Street, which ends where the HaTachana complex begins.

headline: The Next Steps for a Buyout of Barnes & Noble
text: Barnes & Noble is exploring “strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the company,” and its chairman and founder, Leonard Riggio, has already expressed interest in being the buyer. Mr. Riggio would seem at first glance to have an advantage in buying the bookseller since he and his family already own about 33 percent of its stock, based on the company’s proxy statement.

headline: He Still Plays Weddings: A Musical Polymath’s Quirky Career
text: Lev Zhurbin, the violist, composer and arranger who performs and writes under the name Ljova, almost always has a lot of projects before him. If he isn’t writing for, or recording with, his folk-classical ensemble, Ljova and the Kontraband, or performing in Romashka, a Gypsy band led by his wife, the singer Inna Barmash, he is working on film scores or transcriptions. (He has arranged Indian and Sephardic pieces for the Kronos Quartet; Asian and Eastern European works for Yo-Yo Ma’s Silk Road Project; Schubert and Shostakovich compositions for the Knights, a chamber orchestra). But even by Ljova’s standards, the coming week is unusually packed.

headline: Marry a Man Who Loves His Mother
text: WHEN Miles and I decided to live together, I asked him if his mother, Terry, would be upset. We sat at the kitchen table in his apartment near Fort Rucker, Ala., while the warm fall evening pressed against the sliding glass doors. Miles would graduate from flight school in a few months, and the Army would be sending him to Fort Bragg, N.C. My job in Tallahassee would be ending at the same time, and the move felt right to both of us.

headline: Russia Is Burning
text: Living in the Russian capital right now must feel like life in a bowl of pea soup. The air is full of a murky yellowish haze — the aerosolized remains of forests, peat bogs and villages — as more than 800 wildfires burned across the country by the end of the week. Our colleagues Andrew E. Kramer and Kevin Drew report that the fires have led to the deaths of 52 people throughout the country.

headline: Thomas Returns to Knicks as Part-Time Consultant
text: Isiah Thomas, the former Knicks executive and coach who was a central contributor to the disarray from which the franchise is still struggling to emerge, is returning to the organization as a part-time consultant, the team announced Friday.

headline: Battle Looms Over Huge Costs of Public Pensions
text: There’s a class war coming to the world of government pensions.

headline: Another Rate Increase Warning From Lenders
text: AT the end of the first quarter, most bankers, brokers and market analysts seemed to be in general agreement that mortgage rates would soon head higher; the only question was how much.

headline: Who Should Pay for the Trillion-Dollar Pension Gap?
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I explore the debate around a question that will bedevil our municipalities and states for some time to come: given that we’ve promised at least $1 trillion more in retirement benefits to public employees than we have put aside to pay for them, who should pay to make up the difference?

headline: Keeping Legal Work From Moving to India
text: With the continued and rapid growth of the legal outsourcing industry in India, it raises the question of how this trend could impact the legal landscape in New York, a hub for law firms large and small and various areas of expertise.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Red Sea Rave, Ryan Murphy, Brooklyn Museum and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Living in Woodmont, Conn.
text: A waterfront village in a compact section of the city of Milford, Conn., exudes modesty, though it remains studded with relics of its grand past.

headline: Republicans Set Limits on Early Primaries
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. – The Republican National Committee approved a plan on Friday that seeks to avoid a stampede of early primaries in the 2012 presidential campaign by requiring states to hold their contests no sooner than Feb. 1, 2012.

headline: Looking to Follow the Lead of Clinton-Mezvinsky Wedding
text: THE wedding of Chelsea Clinton and Marc Mezvinsky happened barely a week ago, but wedding planners are reporting that clients are already clamoring for “a wedding like Chelsea’s.”

headline: Literary Drinking Games
text: Geoff Nicholson’s delightful essay on the thin line between rules for drinking and rules for writing got me trolling the Web in search of some fun literary drinking games.

headline: Cleveland Critic Loses in Suit Over Job Change
text: A jury on Friday rejected the lawsuit brought by a classical music critic of The Plain Dealer in Cleveland who sued his newspaper and the Cleveland Orchestra management after being reassigned following complaints about negative reviews.

headline: My Dinner With Takeru
text: The waitress turned and faced Takeru Kobayashi, a wisp of a guy but a giant in the calories-be-damned universe of competitive eating, a sometime champion at downing double-digit loads of hot dogs or bratwurst or whatever some contest promoter happens to be serving. The moment the noisy crowd around him had been waiting for had arrived. The what-is-he-having moment.

headline: Ryan Predictions
text: Aha — I just realized that I should probably post my predictions about Rep. Paul Ryan’s response to today’s column before I see the inevitable letter to the Times.

headline: A License to Scream
text: ONLY three times in my life have I been so scared that I trembled  legs quivering, hands jittering, heart out of control. The first was at 12, when I watched “The Exorcist” before I should have. The second was at 41, when, on the kind of dare to which middle-aged men seem peculiarly vulnerable, I got into a canvas harness and prepared to jump some 250 feet into a gorge in Zambia.

headline: A Tough Opening Act for NXP
text: It has been a disappointing first day for NXP Semiconductors as a public company.

headline: Saab’s Owners Offer a Peek Into Its Future
text: General Motors’ sale of Saab to Spyker Cars, a small sports car company, was a first-class cliffhanger, and it wasn’t clear until the very last minute that the deal would go through. But Spyker made a final $24 million payment for the Swedish automaker last month, and now Saab can turn its attention to producing cars and, it hopes, making a profit.

headline: 30 Seconds With Jerry Rice
text: Jerry Rice, who will be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday, holds numerous receiving records after a 20-year career spent mostly with the San Francisco 49ers, including most receptions (1,549), receiving yards (22,895) and total touchdowns (208). Rice, 47, who retired in 2005, is working with Procter & Gamble, an N.F.L. sponsor, on an advertising campaign called “Take It to the House.”

text: Digby:

headline: First U.S. IVF Baby Has a Baby of Her Own
text: The country’s first “test-tube baby” has had a baby.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Scratch Pies
text: Two things everybody loves: an underdog and pie. Phoebe Lawless’s story has both. It’s also full of lemon and buttermilk.

headline: Pulse
text: What the artist Olympia Scarry is wearing now, an exhibition of the photographer Christopher Makos’s Polaroids from the late ’70s and early ’80s, and more items.

headline: New Ways to Scrub Out the Carbon
text: Three technologies lead the pack for capturing the carbon dioxide in coal while also harnessing the energy. On Thursday, the Energy Department endorsed the “oxyburn” strategy, which involves filtering the nitrogen out of air and burning coal in pure oxygen, with a resulting flue gas that is almost pure carbon dioxide; it will attempt that in Illinois.

headline: Chrysler Dealers Find Barriers to Re-entry
text: After a year of fighting Chrysler’s decision to cast aside his dealership, Jim Bickford expected to be back running Westminster Dodge, the only Chrysler franchise in Boston.

headline: New Charges in Subway Bomb Plot
text: One of the men accused in a plot to bomb three New York City subway lines pleaded not guilty on Friday to new charges in the case.

headline: Remaking the Face of Brooklyn
text: KARL FISCHER may not enjoy the name recognition of architects like Robert A. M. Stern and Richard Meier, whose designs have helped alter the face of New York in recent years.

headline: Eugenia Chen and Michael Pang
text: Eugenia Ruth Chen and Michael Ming Pang were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Blanca Martinez, a staff member of the city clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Leaders of Britain and Pakistan Smooth Over Frictions
text: LONDON  The antagonism that flared between Britain and Pakistan in the past 10 days over the war in Afghanistan and the fight against Islamic terrorism appeared to have been smoothed over on Friday in a carefully orchestrated appearance before reporters.

headline: Giants’ Seubert Has Broken Bone in Hand
text: ALBANY — The Giants’ offensive line is getting thin at training camp.

headline: No Such Thing as a Setback
text: TONY ROBBINS  self-help guru, business mogul and, most recently, aspiring television star  needed some encouragement. The Great Motivator was on a chest press anchored with a 460-pound weight, which he had to slowly lift. A metronome counted the beats: One ... two ... three. Release.

headline: Obama’s Endangered Economists
text: Well, gang, it’s the first Friday of the month, and we all know what that means: the nonfarm payroll employment report! So close your eyes and cross your fingers and, well, don’t bother, we know it’s not going to be good. “The nation’s economy continued to sputter as private-sector employers added just 71,000 jobs in July,” write The Washington Post’s Michael A. Fletcher and William Branigin. “The small increase in private-sector employment was more than offset by the loss of 143,000 temporary census jobs, and the nation’s unemployment rate remained unchanged at 9.5 percent. Overall, the nation shed 131,00 jobs in July.”

headline: At a Chicago Orchestra, Diversity Is on the Program
text: The Chicago Sinfonietta is an orchestra that was founded in 1987 to give classical musicians who are members of minority groups greater professional opportunities. In a field with a minuscule number of black performers, it prides itself on the racial composition of its players, staff members and board, with roughly half representing minorities.

headline: Boxer Devon Alexander Rises Above Streets of St. Louis
text: ST. LOUIS  On the steps of an old police station, Kevin Cunningham looked out into the impoverished streets of north St. Louis. Cunningham, a boxing trainer and former narcotics detective, first stood on these steps 15 years ago and had a grin on his face as he spoke. “A white woman driving all slow around here is going to get pulled over on suspicion to buy crack,” he said.

headline: A Vision of Darkness: Behind This Week’s Cover Art
text: Once again, an arresting piece of cover art was the talk among Book Review editors in the run-up to the issue of Aug. 8. It is an unsettling wartime scene by Paolo Ventura in illustration of Francine Prose’s review of “The Death of the Adversary” and “Comedy in a Minor Key,” two remarkable midcentury novels set in Nazi-occupied Europe by the centenarian Hans Keilson.

headline: Building Lollapalooza

headline: At Vegans’ Weddings, Beef or Tofu?
text: WEDDINGS are all about compromise. City or country? June or November? My religion or yours?

headline: Injury Could Knock Westwood From Bridgestone
text: AKRON, Ohio — Lee Westwood, who had a glimmer of hope of overtaking Tiger Woods for the No. 1 spot in the rankings, aggravated an injury to his right calf on Friday and said he does not know if he will be able to play the weekend rounds in the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational.

headline: Obama Lets Kagan Bask in the Applause
text: President Obama was in no hurry for the applause to stop. When your poll numbers are down and your party is facing a potential drubbing in the fall elections, you take every affirming moment that comes along.

headline: Parent Rap
text: I am off to BlogHer this weekend — a gathering of thousands of female bloggers, many of whom write about parenting, and all of whom are using new technology to share the realities of their lives.

headline: Volkswagens Investigated for Failing Ignition Coils
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened an investigation into an old problem: failing ignition coils on Volkswagens.

text: For Lisa Spellman, the owner of 303 Gallery in Manhattan, home is a meticulously restored, art-friendly 1827 town house.

text: Sam Tanenhaus talks to Mary Roach about her new book, “Packing for Mars.”

headline: Currently Struggling as a ‘Formerly’
text: GIVEN that most young people would prefer to be older and most old people yearn to be young, coming up with a new in-between life stage is an inherently thankless task. Many would be all too glad to be rid of dicey concepts like “tweens” and “adultescents.”

headline: Music for Sailing | Tennis, Anyone?
text: Concept albums are nothing new, but the story behind the latest seven-inch from the band Tennis feels pretty fresh. The summery, lo-fuzz songs on the “Marathon” EP, which was released this week on Underwater Peoples, are based on the sailing trip taken by the husband-and-wife duo Patrick Riley and Alaina Moore in 2009 — an eight-month journey along the East Coast that took them from “Bimini Bay” in the Bahamas through “Marathon” Florida, “South Carolina” and up to “Baltimore” on their 30-foot “Cape Dory.” Not bad for two kids from Denver who’d never sailed before.

headline: The Costs – And Savings – of Traveling Alone
text: In the last two weeks, I welcomed two very different pairs of travel partners: my high school friends Jon and Doug in Colombia, and my parents in Nicaragua.

headline: An Affordable Apartment for One
text: DAN WOHL met Marisa Wallace on the job at the Barnes & Noble bookstore in Brooklyn Heights. She was hired to work with him in the children’s department, and he was happy to show her the ropes. Two years ago, when they decided to find a place together, he was sharing an apartment with friends in Greenpoint and she was living with her family in Carroll Gardens.

headline: Apartment Dwellers Settle for Less Than the Best
text: “I did not need a balcony,” said Foram Matalia, a renter at the new 225 Grand building in Jersey City. She also decided in advance that she could live without a sparkling view of the New York City skyline. But she knew she wanted a one-bedroom apartment in a classy new structure for herself and her husband

headline: Woodmont, Conn.
text: MOST roadside signs have blocky letters on plain backgrounds, but not so in Woodmont, Conn., a compact section of the city of Milford 70 miles from Midtown Manhattan. There, arrivals are greeted by signs in a typeface that playfully flows around anchors, starfish and shells.

text: IF ever a building threaded itself into the hallowed history of New York City, it is the red brick town house at 41 Charlton Street, framed by lustrous wrought-iron railings topped with little pineapples, a symbol of hospitality.

text: APARTMENT hunters always have a wish list of things that will help them call a new place home  doormen, laundry rooms, southern exposures.

text: In this week’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about how some small-business owners are being forced to reconsider or delay their retirement plans.

headline: Look Who’s Back: The Original Talking Head
text: TODAY’S blockbusters strive to mimic reality with seamless computer-generated imagery, but for one defining television chatterbox of an earlier era, the resemblance went in the other direction. Max Headroom, the slick yet glitchy talking-head of the 1980s ABC series, looked like an early computer animation come to life: a chiseled-face plastic man in shades and ultraflat suit, jabbering in front of shifting geometric rays that evoked a broken television (or the arcade game Tempest).

headline: Food (Truck) Fight: Putting Griddle to the Metal
text: GET Matt Chernus going on the subject of food trucks  those big refrigerated chuck wagons that frequent construction sites and late-night watering holes  and he could be a 6-year-old describing his favorite Tonka. “They’re just cool,” Mr. Chernus, a tattooed former professional wrestler, said the other day. “They’re big. They’re really noisy. They’re cool to look at. I drove by three new trucks in Hollywood today, and I got so excited. I was like a little kid.”

headline: Grilled Lobster
text: Mark Bittman demonstrates an easy way to grill lobster.

headline: The Award for Virtual Reality Goes to …
text: The coming “Teen Choice 2010” awards show on Fox Broadcasting will have an online complement in the form of a virtual beach party. (If only Gidget were around to get some virtual sand between her toes.)

headline: Back in the Groove: Jazz Reissues on Vinyl
text: THERE are two kinds of obsessive record collectors: those who buy original pressings of rare old LPs because they’re rare and old, and those who buy them because they sound good.

headline: Two Crewmen, One Makeshift Boat and 135 Miles to New York
text: At noon on Friday, a strange-looking floating vessel -– picture a partially submerged Hummer with blown-out windows –- drifted up on a sandy stretch of Manhattan shoreline along the Hudson River, just south of the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Lots of Inventive Jazz, and Then a Heavy Jolt
text: Guillermo Klein

headline: Traditions Reimagined, Both Ballet and Basque
text: BECKET, Mass.  The choreographer Trey McIntyre addresses several questions this week at Jacob’s Pillow: How can ballet reflect the world we know  and, in particular, how men and women relate to each other today? What’s American about ballet? How can ballet work to different kinds of music  pop hits, modernist purity, folk traditions and even recorded speech? The results are amazingly fresh, dancy, communicative. So are his dancers.

headline: Grilled Lobster With a Head Start
text: THROUGHOUT the world, lobster is commonly considered the height of elegance: it’s often the priciest thing on the menu in restaurants, served on fancy platters with lots of fanfare.

headline: Alabama Tops Coaches’ Poll
text: The USA Today coaches’ poll was released Friday and, no surprise, Alabama was No. 1.

headline: Lobster on the Grill
text: Steamed or boiled lobster is good. Grilled lobster might be even better. But how do you get a live creature on the grill without cutting it in half? See this week’s Minimalist column.

headline: Resurfacing | Museum-Quality Men’s Wear
text: Hart Schaffner Marx, the 123-year-old Chicago-based clothier best known for its sartorial style (and for suiting up President Obama), has been rediscovered, and in the process has made its own exciting discovery. After a tumultuous 2009 — which included a bankruptcy filing and new overseas owners — Joseph Abboud, a master of soft tailoring, has been placed at the helm as creative director to oversee the redesign of its roster of well-known brands, which include Hickey Freeman, Austin Reed and Bobby Jones. While mining the company archives for inspiration, he and his colleagues discovered a cache of valuable Maxfield Parrish paintings that had been used for Hickey Freeman advertisements.

headline: Demand Media Files for an I.P.O.
text: Demand Media, the online media company that commissions content based on search engine inquiries, filed on Friday for an initial public offering.

headline: Feeding Fewer Than 9 Billion
text: Discussions of food policy, climate change, international security and many other global issues often take place in isolation, cut off from consideration of other factors delineating the pinch points as humanity’s population and appetites crest in the next couple of generations.

headline: Beak-to-Tail Chicken Yakitori
text: THERE are approximately 30 distinct chicken parts that can be skewered and grilled for traditional Japanese yakitori.

headline: Senate Smackdown Over a Fed Nominee
text: 2:05 a.m. | Updated Sewell Chan has more on the Senate’s reasoning.

headline: Youth Indicted in Staten Island Hate-Crime Assault
text: A Staten Island grand jury has handed up a four-count indictment, including hate-crime charges, against a man accused of assaulting and robbing a Mexican teenager last week, the authorities said on Friday. The assault was the latest in a series of attacks on Mexican immigrants in the Port Richmond neighborhood.

headline: Opposites Attract, Even Joy and Melancholy
text: It’s startling to see a work of genius composed largely from movements as basic as walking, running, hopping, skipping, lying down and the like. When it was new in 1988, “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” Mark Morris’s full-evening Handel-oratorio dance, made me quote Schumann’s line about Chopin: “Hats off, gentlemen, a genius.” I do so again with pleasure now. Even after 22 years I find no end to the intricacies of Mr. Morris’s construction, and the meanings that continually pour from them. It fills the soul with wonder; it fascinates the mind with suggestion.

headline: First Time Together Leads to a National Title
text: When two experts play together for the first time, they usually do well. And that again proved to be the case when Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., and Gary Cohler of Miami paired up with the husband-and-wife players JoAnna and Lew Stansby of Dublin, Calif., for the Richard Freeman Mixed Board-a-Match Teams in New Orleans last week. They cruised to the national title, finishing nearly five and a half boards ahead of two married couples: Gloria and Les Bart of Bradenton, Fla., and Sally and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif.

headline: From ‘Family Guy’ to Music Man
text: You give a nerd a record deal, and this is the record you get: Seth MacFarlane, below, the pop-cultural polymath who created and provides many of the voices on the Fox animated comedy “Family Guy,” will be lending his pipes to an album of 1940s and ’50s-era show tunes for Universal Republic Records, the label said on Friday. The album, which will be produced and arranged by Joel McNeely (whose credits include Mr. MacFarlane’s series “American Dad”) will include standards by Rodgers and Hammerstein, and Lerner and Loewe, as well as a song called “She’s Wonderful, Too” that Mr. McNeely wrote for the television show “The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles.” Universal Republic said in a news release that Mr. MacFarlane would sing to the accompaniment of a live orchestra and a big band, using vintage equipment and analog tape to replicate the sound of classic records by artists like Frank Sinatra, Nat King Cole and Rosemary Clooney.

headline: Show Gets Ratings When Contestants Are Cut
text: The live elimination episode of “Big Brother” on Thursday attracted seven million viewers for CBS, helping the network lead the night’s ratings over all, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS earned relatively solid ratings the rest of the night as well with crime show repeats. ABC ranked a strong second, garnering its best ratings with “Rookie Blue” (6.8 million), which came in between a rerun of “Wipeout” (6.5 million) and the second-to-last installment of ABC’s documentary miniseries “Boston Med” (4.9 million). Fox placed third and NBC was fourth.

headline: Holocaust Documentary Will Retain R Rating
text: The R rating for the Holocaust documentary “A Film Unfinished” will stand, an appeals board ruled on Thursday, despite arguments by the picture’s director and distributor that young people would needlessly be closed off from its historical lessons. In a 12-to-3 vote, the appeals board of the Classification and Rating Administration, which rates films released in the United States, upheld an earlier R rating that cited the movie’s “disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities including graphic nudity.” Directed by Yael Hersonski, “A Film Unfinished” dissects a Nazi propaganda film that purported to depict life among Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto during World War II, but was later discovered to have manipulated situations to help reinforce negative images of Jews. David Fenkel, who with Adam Yauch founded Oscilloscope Laboratories, the movie’s distributor, said that the rating “makes it much harder for libraries to accept it” and that “some won’t.” The film is set to open in New York on Aug. 18, and is expected to play later across the United States according to Oscilloscope. Howard Gantman, a spokesman for the Motion Picture Association of America, which helps to oversee the ratings board, declined to comment on the rating, which the association confirmed in a brief statement.

headline: Obamas, After Broadway, Turn to Washington Theater
text: Having shined a White House spotlight on Broadway over the last year, President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, above, are turning their attentions to theater closer to home. Arena Stage, the 60-year-old theatrical company in Washington, announced that the Obamas would be the honorary chairman and chairwoman for its inaugural 2010-11 season at its new home, the Mead Center for American Theater, in Southwest Washington. The Obamas will also serve as honorary chairman and chairwoman for a black-tie fund-raising dinner on Oct. 25  with table sponsorships and tickets ranging from $1,500 to $50,000  to celebrate Arena’s move to the center. A spokesman for Arena said it was not known whether the Obamas would attend the dinner, nor was it clear what, if anything, their honorary designation involved beyond the title itself. The dinner is to feature a performance by the Tony Award-winning actor Brian Stokes Mitchell (“Kiss Me, Kate”) on his Monday night off from his new Broadway musical this fall, “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown.” The evening will raise money for Arena’s work at the center, which includes the renovated 683-seat Fichandler Stage and the 514-seat Kreeger Theater, as well as a new third stage, the 200-seat Kogod Cradle.

headline: Two Basque Country Vineyards
text: In northern Spain, two vineyards where the fizzy wine Txakolina is produced.

headline: Wyclef Jean Can’t Count on Fugees Vote
text: The people of Haiti will not officially make their presidential preference known at the polls until the election scheduled for Nov. 28. But Wyclef Jean, the hip-hop artist who declared this week that he would run as a potential successor to President René Préval, has already lost one-third of the crucial Fugees vote. Pras, a cousin of Mr. Jean and a fellow Haitian-American performer who worked with him in that influential rap group, told The Daily News of New York that he backed one of his former bandmate’s rivals. In a statement, Pras, whose name is Prakazrel Michel, told The Daily News that he supported Michel Martelly “as the next president of Haiti because he is the most competent candidate for the job,” and wrote on his Twitter feed, “I support and believe in my heart that Michel Martelly is prez for Haiti!” Like Pras and Mr. Jean, Mr. Martelly is also a Haitian musician, and performs under the stage name Sweet Micky.

headline: Youtube ‘Day’ Project Will Consume Many
text: For his “Life in a Day” documentary project (poster, above), Ridley Scott asked people around the world to film a snippet of what they were doing on July 24 and upload the videos onto a special YouTube channel. Be careful what you ask for: Mr. Scott said on Thursday that submissions totaled 80,000  or about 4,600 hours of footage. He was expecting about 300 hours’ worth. To power forward  the goal is to make a feature documentary by splicing together the best moments  Mr. Scott and his partner on the project, the director Kevin Macdonald (“The Last King of Scotland”), have assembled 20 editors and researchers to log and vet the footage. “It’s a mountain, but we’re eager to climb it,” Mr. Macdonald said. The team will winnow the videos, which came from 197 countries, down to 100 hours and begin sharing some results at youtube.com/lifeinaday, in September. The final film will have its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival and on YouTube in January.

headline: Lollapalooza and Its Promoters Rise on the Stage of Chicago
text: CHICAGO  Surrounded by the tranquil green of Grant Park, and with the towers of Chicago in the distance, workers at the Lollapalooza festival here lugged Lady Gaga’s gear at full speed across an outdoor stage on Thursday afternoon. To one side, shaded from the hot afternoon sun, were a box of signs with profanities spelled out in lights and a prop subway car heading to “Glitter Way.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 6
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include an effort to protect public gardens, horse racing in New Jersey and a workplace shooting in Connecticut.

headline: A Wagnerian Treat for Children: ‘Tannhäuser’
text: BAYREUTH, Germany  There is a general and well-founded perception of the Bayreuth Festival as an elitist stronghold for opera, as much a shrine to Wagner as a festival of his works. And there is no ticket harder to come by. Wagner lovers wait an average of 10 years to get a coveted ticket to the Festspielhaus, which seats only about 2,000.
