headline: Those Pre-Season Jitters
text: All the editors in my department want to talk about the New York shows. Already? It was more than I could take, and I decided to go shopping. I love the lull before the storm — the arrival of runway clothes in stores. The expected arrival of runway clothes. They are coming, aren’t they? Stores now want more deliveries than a squirrel wants nuts. I saw Alexander Wang the other day over lunch at ABC Kitchen, and he said he’s up to nine deliveries a year.

headline: Venturesome Whites
text: Channing Daughters, in Bridgehampton, specializes in venturesome whites with complex scents and flavors that shift as the wines are being drunk.

headline: In the Spirit of an Old Favorite
text: THE Laundry on Race Lane in East Hampton had a 26-year run as a hangout for Hamptonites before moving to other quarters four years ago and subsequently closing. After a few years as a restaurant called the Lodge, the building has a new incarnation.

headline: Always on Offer: Fresh Fish, a Relaxed Vibe
text: The Boondocks Fishery sits on the busy banks of the Navesink River in Red Bank, but this small red shack has an easy, low-key feel.

headline: A Bid to Modernize the Traditional
text: THE chef Ryan DePersio has been setting the pace for Italian restaurants in Montclair for seven years. Less than six months after he and his family opened Fascino there in 2003, David Corcoran, writing in The New York Times, called it a “walloping success.” More recently Mr. DePersio has been building a much wider following, with appearances on the “Today” show and praise in Maxim magazine. This year he extended his brand — all the way to neighboring Bloomfield.

headline: Fizzies for Grown-ups
text: After a string of hot July days, I couldn’t bring myself to open another bottle of rosé. And then I found prosecco.

headline: Home-Style Thai With a Spicy Kick
text: D THAI KITCHEN is a sweet little restaurant, charming and relaxing. And whether diners choose to enjoy the airiness of the patio under wide market umbrellas hung with festive pin lights or the coziness of the narrow dining room, most will find it easy to while away an hour or two over drinks and dishes bearing the bright flavors and scents of herbaceous Thai cuisine.

headline: Fresh, Cold and Creamy
text: Il Bacio means “the kiss” in Italian, and in this long hot summer, there may be no kiss sweeter than a lip-cooling lick of Il Bacio’s house-made ice creams.

headline: The Food Is Nice, the Views Majestic
text: IT was a scorcher of a July evening and we were dining on the harbor as the blue of the water — almost close enough to touch — deepened with the setting sun. Cormorants on nearby pilings stretched their necks toward a pink-streaked sky while a flotilla of swans drifted by.

headline: Tracking the Rise of Color on Film
text: “Black and white are the colors of photography,” Robert Frank declared. “Color photography is vulgar,” Walker Evans once wrote in an essay. And Ansel Adams weighed in on a William Eggleston photograph this way: “If you can’t make it good, make it red.”

headline: Antigraft Units, Backed by U.S., Draw Karzai’s Ire
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has promised to root out corruption, but after one of his own top aides was arrested by American-supported antigraft units recently, he fired back by investigating the investigators and apparently seeking control over their actions.

headline: In the Black for a Year, Ford to Restore Its Chairman’s Pay
text: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company said Friday that it would pay its executive chairman, William Clay Ford Jr., for the first time since 2005, now that it has been profitable for more than a year.

headline: Fed Nominee Said to Lack Experience
text: In 1979, a 25-year-old economics student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology named Ben S. Bernanke turned in his doctoral dissertation. In his acknowledgments, he thanked a faculty member, Peter A. Diamond, as one of four professors who “gave generously of their time, reading and discussing my work.”

headline: A Bit of Everything, Including a Peephole
text: In a city clogged with nostalgic paint-by-the-numbers brasseries where the check can easily creep toward $100 a person, this black-and-white-tiled spot on Third Avenue between 10th and 11th Streets pulls in buzzing crowds with a lightly louche retro décor and a reasonably priced, globally inspired New American menu. Offering a little bit of everything — from Alsatian pizza to lamb Milanese to jalapeño cheddar grits — the restaurant packs in diners who might venture downstairs to snap pictures in the old-fashioned photo booth or watch a bit of vintage porn through a peephole. On Wednesday night, the crowd included reunited friends laughing over a recent birthday celebration.

headline: Trooper Praised for 911 Exchanges With Killer
text: In February 2009, a distraught man armed with a handgun stopped his vehicle on a busy stretch of Interstate 84 in Hartford. State Trooper William Taylor was among the first police officers on the scene. He immediately closed off access to the highway and coordinated communications with other police agencies, “all while keeping the suicidal male calm while speaking with him on the phone,” read the citation for the Meritorious Service Award he later received.

headline: Women and Modern Art in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Under the watchful eye of a male instructor, a teenage boy is deep in focus, trying to trace and copy from a postcard as accurately as possible. For years, this has been the art scene in Afghanistan: stale, and dominated by men. Realism has long ruled as the only accepted style.

headline: For Triple-Murder Trial, Echoes in a 2004 Case
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: A Spray, but No Stampede
text: ON a scorching day at the end of June, humidity at 61 percent and rising, Felix Woskoski pulled out his hydrant cap, just as he has on summer scorchers for the past two decades. He said he got it  all legal and whatnot  from the Fire Department.

headline: Cracking the Locks on Relief
text: ROASTING in the July heat, a teenager entered a dry cleaner near the northern tip of Manhattan carrying an electric drill and an extension cord. He told the owner he needed to plug the cord in for one minute.

headline: Sorry, Kid: No License, No Lemonade
text: When life gives you lemons, make lemonade.

headline: Who Will Help the Palestinians?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Remembering a Town Swallowed by the Sea
text: WEST CAPE MAY, N.J.  Joseph G. Burcher draws in the sand using his cane, mapping from memory a town that no longer exists. He stands near the site of the home where he spent much of his childhood, but he cannot be sure if it was here, or beneath the waves that break behind him.

headline: Go Figure the American League East, Inside and Out
text: Even after 80 days, the Red Sox and the Yankees remembered how to play each other in the American League East, the toughest division in baseball.

headline: A Bad Movie Is Getting a Sequel
text: Isiah Thomas is back with the Knicks, but what does it mean?

headline: Steps That We Can Take to Lower the Deficit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Navy Building’s Next Tenant Has Paris Guessing
text: PARIS  The building where Marie Antoinette’s death certificate was signed, and from whose balcony her execution by guillotine was witnessed, may soon be up for grabs.

headline: Proceed With Caution: Driving Schools Ahead
text: Driving anywhere is a risk. In New York it’s a dare. Choosing the city as the place where you learn to drive borders on reckless. So what is climbing into a car with someone who has no idea what she’s doing, then guiding her into heavy traffic while pedestrians dart in and out of view, bicycles weave in and out of lanes, subways rattle overhead and taxi drivers decide fading yellow is the new green?

headline: Military Suicides
text: To the Editor:

headline: Conversions in Israel: The Chief Rabbi’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Persecuted Muslim Sect Uses Brochure Campaign to Push for Peace
text: WEST ALLIS, Wis.

headline: Dress Code? Camp Allows Giants to Try a New Look
text: ALBANY  Underneath his Giants jersey, safety Antrel Rolle wears a shirt long enough to be a miniskirt and billowy enough to be a parachute. This is what training camp looks like here.

headline: The Town That Used to Be
text: A town called South Cape May in New Jersey was washed away in the mid-20th century by a series of storms.

headline: Kelly Holohan, Margaret Sommer
text: Kelly Anne Holohan and Margaret Anne Sommer were married Thursday evening in Provincetown, Mass. Andrew L. Kellner, a youth minister for the Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania who received temporary permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to perform the ceremony, officiated at the Long Point Lighthouse.

headline: Jennifer Stolper, Jonathan Muenz
text: Jennifer Ann Stolper, the daughter of Lauren and Edward Stolper of Pasadena, Calif., is to be married there Sunday to Jonathan Warren Muenz, a son of Janet and Larry Muenz of Gaithersburg, Md. Rabbi Morley Feinstein is to officiate at the faculty club at the California Institute of Technology, where the bride’s father is the provost.

headline: Rachael Hope, Jeremy Tilsner
text: Rachael Blain Hope and Jeremy Nathan Tilsner were married Saturday evening at Architectural Antiques, an antiques store in Minneapolis. Judge Richard Spicer, who sits on the First Judicial District Court in Hastings, Minn., officiated.

headline: Alexis Cook, Bayard Templeton
text: Alexis Rachel Cook, the daughter of Margaret A. Seligman of Kent, N.Y., and Robert A. Cook of Stamford, Conn., was married Friday evening in Chappaqua, N.Y., to John Bayard Templeton, a son of Betty Cuningham Templeton and E. Rick Templeton of Bronxville, N.Y. The ceremony, at Crabtree’s Kittle House, an inn, was led by Donna Merow, a member of the Ambler Mennonite Church in Ambler, Pa., who was authorized by her congregation to officiate.

headline: Rachael Wagner, Samuel Abrams
text: Rachael Anne Wagner and Samuel Jeremy Abrams are to be married Sunday evening at the Chrysler Museum of Art in Norfolk, Va. Rabbi Arthur Ruberg is to officiate.

headline: Emily Ludwig, Andrew Serazin
text: Emily Pembroke Ludwig and Andrew Charnes Serazin were married Saturday at Mount Moriah Lutheran Church in Baker, W.Va. The Rev. Miller Hunter, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Margarita Vergara, Joseph Rinaggio
text: Dr. Margarita Regina Vergara, a dentist, and Dr. Joseph Rinaggio Jr., an oral pathologist, were married Saturday at the Blessed Sacrament Church in Buffalo. The Rev. Francis Conde, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: A Prairie Wanderer in Search of the Human Touch
text: Dave Jordano’s series “Prairieland” offers a window into a place rooted in its own vernacular. At the same time, the series conveys the universal desire to mark one’s place in the world.

headline: Katherine Drake, David Czehut
text: Katherine Jessica Drake and David Chamberlain Czehut are to be married Sunday evening at Firestone Vineyard in Los Olivos, Calif. The Rev. Jon G. Lemmond, an Evangelical Covenant minister, is to officiate.

headline: Kristin Heinz, Andrew Wiechmann
text: Kristin Elizabeth Heinz and Andrew Craig Wiechmann were married Saturday at the Exmoor Country Club in Highland Park, Ill. The Rev. Robert E. McWilliams, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Louisa Bradtmiller and Katharine Stebinger
text: Louisa Irene Bradtmiller and the Rev. Katharine Elizabeth Stebinger were joined in a commitment ceremony Friday at the Mill City Museum in Minneapolis. The Rev. Joy M. Caires, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Frances Knechel, Charles Vos
text: Frances Amelia Knechel and Charles Cutler Vos were married Wednesday by Judge Tom W. DePriest Jr. at the St. Louis County Courthouse in Clayton, Mo. On Saturday, the couple had a Quaker ceremony at Whittemore House, the Washington University faculty club, also in Clayton.

headline: Rebecca Tenenbein, Aaron Weitman
text: Rebecca Beth Tenenbein, a daughter of Marian Tenenbein and Aaron Tenenbein of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to Aaron Michael Weitman, the son of Sheryl Weitman and Dr. Mark Weitman of Aventura, Fla. Rabbi Robert Scheinberg is to officiate at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan. Cantor Lorna Wallach will take part.

headline: Naomi Gottschalk, Richard Nocera
text: Naomi Belle Gottschalk, a daughter of Cynthia A. Gottschalk of Freeport, Ill., is to be married Sunday in Brooklyn to Richard Nocera, the son of Sharon R. Nocera of Marlborough, Mass., and Richard J. Nocera of Newburyport, Mass. The bridegroom’s father, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate at iCi Restaurant.

headline: Midge Woolsey and Jerry Stolt
text: Midge Woolsey and Jerry Stolt were married Saturday at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, an Episcopal priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony in his office.

headline: Lauren Smith, Haney Hong
text: Lauren Olivia Smith and Lt. Haney Druse Hong were married Saturday at Stanford Memorial Church on the campus of Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif. The Rev. James Thompson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Samantha Perry, James David
text: Samantha Jean Perry, the daughter of Lisa Perry and Richard C. Perry of New York, is to be married Sunday evening to James Andrew Watson David, a son of Hilary David and Philip David of London. Rabbi Lionel Rosenfeld is to officiate at the summer home of the bride’s parents in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

headline: Katrin Stamatis, Jonathan Ruck
text: Katrin Stamatis and Jonathan Charles Ruck are to be married Sunday in a lakeside park in Mohegan Lake, N.Y. Peggy Klinger, a former violin teacher of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, will officiate.

headline: Cori Prilik, Robert Siegel
text: Cori Hope Prilik and Robert Adam Siegel were married Friday evening at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. Stuart E. Scott, a Universal Life minister officiated.

headline: Dana Goodman, Joshua Fisher
text: Dana René Goodman and Joshua Leigh Fisher were married Saturday evening at the Landmarc, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi Shai Specht officiated.

headline: Patrice Galletly, Jonathan Heins
text: Patrice Emma Galletly and Jonathan Paul Heins were married Saturday at Christ Church Cathedral in Houston. The Rev. Martin J. Bastian, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Elisa Schindler and Larry Frankel
text: Elisa Ruth Schindler and Larry Samuel Frankel are to be married Sunday at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Rabbi Judith R. Schindler, a sister of the bride, is to perform the ceremony, with Rabbi Alfredo Borodowski taking part.

headline: Aliza Watters, Tarun Chhabra
text: Aliza Hapgood Watters and Tarun Chhabra were married Wednesday evening at their home in Cambridge, Mass. Elizabeth Aibel Sherwood, a friend of the couple who received temporary authorization from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated. On Aug. 14, the couple is to have another ceremony incorporating Hindu and Christian elements at the Divinity School of the Bodleian Library at Oxford in England.

headline: Valentine Edgar, Eric Schewe
text: Valentine Boatwright Edgar, the daughter of Sarah S. O. Edgar and Robert V. Edgar of New York, was married Saturday to Eric Andrew Schewe, a son of Andrea Schewe and Phillip F. Schewe of Takoma Park, Md. The Rev. John F. Smith, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Lakeview Chapel in Scipio Center, N.Y.

headline: Shira Rosenhaft, Thomas Conoscenti
text: Shira Abbie Rosenhaft and Thomas Salvatore Conoscenti were married Saturday in Brooklyn Bridge Park. The Rev. Jesse D. Hendrich, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated.

headline: Alexandra Davies, Patrick Hodgins
text: Alexandra Yard Davies and Patrick Buchanon Hodgins were married Saturday at Pacific Union Pocket Park at the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego in La Jolla, Calif. Jessica Lyn Goldman, a friend of the couple who was temporarily appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by the County of San Diego, officiated.

headline: Dorit Ingber, Michael Corwin
text: Dorit Peck Ingber, a daughter of Shelley S. Ingber of Montreal and Rabbi Abie I. Ingber of Cincinnati, is to be married Sunday to Michael Benjamin Corwin, the son of Anne P. Corwin and Paul M. Corwin of New York, The bride’s father is to officiate at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York.

headline: Sarah Bardinelli, Ryan Gibbs
text: Sarah Nicole Bardinelli and Ryan David Gibbs were married Saturday in the Dovecote garden at Fearrington Village, a residential and commercial development in Pittsboro, N.C. The Rev. Wilbur I. Jackson, a United Methodist minister and the stepfather of the bridegroom, officiated.

headline: Angela McGregor, Benjamin Hedstrom
text: Angela Coralie McGregor and Benjamin Charles Hedstrom are to be married Sunday at the Intervale Center in Burlington, Vt. Mandy Davis, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

headline: Jacqueline Klinger, Dave Price
text: Jacqueline Klinger and Dave Price were married Saturday at their home in Weston, Conn. Rabbi Jeremy Wiederhorn officiated.

headline: Andrea Grimes and Lonnie Parker
text: Andrea Elaina Grimes, a daughter of Octavia R. Grimes and Vincent E. Grimes of San Jose, Calif., was married Friday to Lonnie Thomas Parker IV, the son of Rosalia G. Parker and Mr. Parker III of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Kent Hawkins, a Church of God minister, performed the ceremony at Mount Paran Church of God in Atlanta.

headline: On the Street | Field Day
text: The chic colony of the Hamptons was out in full force for the 13th Super Saturday sale of discounted clothing from more than 200 fashion designers, held in a field in Water Mill, N.Y.

headline: Republicans Push Back Primaries One Month
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Republican National Committee approved a plan on Friday seeking to avoid a stampede of early primaries in the next presidential campaign by pushing back the contests one month to extend the nominating season and produce a nominee who is tested in all parts of the country.

headline: After a Fall, a Substitute Is Lined Up for Rangel’s Gala
text: At least a big-name performer will show up.

headline: Phillies Glimpse Future in Cameo
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Pension Pain
text: Ron Lieber on the painful trade-offs as states try to meet their pension obligations to their public employees.

headline: Advice From a New Kind of Nun
text: The idea of rough, tough Kathleen Turner playing a nun is fairly delicious in itself. But it stands to reason that this particular nun  Sister Jamison Connelly, the protagonist of Matthew Lombardo’s smartly tangled drama “High”  is no demure, soft-spoken model of reticence.

headline: Greenspan Calls for Repeal of All the Bush Tax Cuts
text: It was not enough, it seems, for Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman and a self-described lifelong Republican libertarian, to call for stringent government regulation of giant banks, as he did a few months ago.

headline: An Artist Unpacks His ‘Graphic Toolbox’
text: Yonkers

headline: Fruits of a Photographer’s Pleasure at LongHouse Reserve
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

headline: Charity Backing Bloomberg 3rd Term Got Millions
text: It was one of the flash points of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s bid to overturn term limits and clear the way for a third term: officials and workers with the Doe Fund, a nonprofit group that works with the city’s homeless, testifying at Mr. Bloomberg’s behest before the City Council in support of his effort.

headline: White House Revamps Ethics Team, Without a Familiar Name
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has pledged to run the most ethical and transparent administration in history. Now, with ethics issues swirling in the capital, his administration plans to move forward with a revamped structure for overseeing ethics issues, but without a senior adviser and friend to Mr. Obama to guide them.

headline: Goosen Leads, Woods Tumbles, and Mickelson Has Shot at No. 1
text: AKRON, Ohio  The W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational turned into the Revolving Door Open on Friday at Firestone Country Club. Golf balls bounced off spectators and trees and spun off the soft greens. Names hopped around the leader board like drops of water on a hot skillet, but by the end of the day, the board shook out with three major championship winners poised for the weekend.

headline: Two Housekeepers Happen Upon History
text: Ruby Lee of Marion, Ala., is thrilled when she gets her first real job: cleaning house for a white woman in Montgomery. But once she’s settled in, a local black woman named Rosa Parks refuses to give up her seat to a white person on a city bus and starts a yearlong bus boycott that costs Ruby her job.

headline: Kaplan Suspends Enrollment at 2 Campuses
text: The Washington Post Company’s Kaplan Inc. unit suspended enrollment on Friday at its campuses in Pembroke Pines, Fla., and Riverside, Calif., where undercover investigators for the Government Accountability Office found deceptive practices by admissions officials.

headline: What Does It Mean? Artists Will Explain
text: EVER stand in a museum or gallery looking at a work of art and wonder: “Gee, what were they thinking?” Some artists are willing to answer that question in person, and dozens, including the photographer Tom Steele, the multimedia artist Avital Oz and the painter Roseline Koener, will meet participants in a self-guided tour of artists’ studios in the greater Westhampton area next weekend. The tour is being presented for the second year by Family Counseling Services in Westhampton.

headline: A Career Reprieve for the Red Sox’ Lowell
text: A week ago, after he finished a rehabilitation assignment in Class AAA and was not immediately activated, Mike Lowell concluded that he very well might have played his last game for the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Pettitte, on Schedule, Pitches Off the Rubber
text: Andy Pettitte’s recovery from a left groin strain has progressed according to schedule, if not ahead of it. He threw off a half mound Sunday and Tuesday, then off the pitching rubber Friday afternoon. Originally told he would miss up to five weeks, Pettitte, almost three weeks into his convalescence, said a return is not far off.

headline: Universal Music Videos Pulled from MTV Site
text: MTV, which made its name from music videos before venturing heavily into the realities of the “Jersey Shore” and “My Sweet 16,” is no longer carrying most of the videos from Universal, the largest music label, on its Web sites.

headline: Wind Farm Deal Assures Bigger U.S. Role
text: WASHINGTON  The United Steelworkers and two Chinese companies announced Friday that they had signed an agreement assuring that major components of machines for a $1.5 billion wind farm in Texas would be made in the United States.

headline: Watergate Becomes Sore Point at Nixon Library
text: YORBA LINDA, Calif.  The sign at the entrance to the largest exhibition room devoted to a single subject at the Nixon Presidential Library and Museum reads “Watergate.” But on Friday, the exhibit was nearly empty, dominated by a 30-foot blank slate of a wall that is testimony to a new battle set off by this still-polarizing former president: how to mark the scandal that forced him from office 36 years ago.

headline: President Obama and Iran
text: At first glance, President Obama’s policy on Iran and its illicit nuclear program is not all that different from President George W. Bush’s. They both committed themselves, on paper, to sanctions and engagement.

headline: A Snakeskin Where Insulation Should Be
text: A surprise discovery under the attic floor during an energy audit.

headline: Knicks Add Roger Mason, a Shooting Guard
text: The Knicks continued their roster overhaul on Friday by reaching an agreement with the shooting guard Roger Mason Jr., who played for the San Antonio Spurs the last two seasons.

headline: Congress’s Serial Hits on Food Stamps
text: With some shabby sleight of hand, Congress has begun tapping into the food stamp program for the hungriest Americans to help pay for lawmakers’ higher election-year priorities. The Senate approved two important measures this week  the $26 billion state-aid bill and the $4.5 billion school nutrition program  in part by shaving food stamp funds as a target of least resistance.

headline: Victory for Wolves
text: Donald Molloy, a Federal District Court judge in Montana, ruled Thursday that gray wolves in Montana and Idaho must be provided federal protection under the Endangered Species Act. This is a welcome decision. The immediate effect will be to spare the animals from hunts planned for this fall that are now illegal. The larger hope is that Washington will devise a protection plan ensuring the wolves’ survival not only in Montana and Idaho but across the northern Rocky Mountains.

headline: Adoption, Reunion, Connection
text: Listen: Lorraine Dusky has come unstuck in time.

headline: Zakaria Returns ADL Award Over Mosque Opposition
text: In an apparent protest this week, the CNN host and Newsweek columnist Fareed Zakaria returned a five-year-old first amendment award presented to him by the Anti-Defamation League in light of the Jewishgroup’s opposition to a mosque that may be built near ground zero.

headline: A Man With Muffin Secrets, but No Job With Them
text: Bite into a Thomas’ English muffin and, it turns out, you are about to swallow one of the most closely guarded secrets in the world of baking.

headline: Putting Our Brains on Hold
text: The world leadership qualities of the United States, once so prevalent, are fading faster than the polar ice caps.

headline: Yankee Doodle Daffy
text: Connecticut used to be the kind of place where you could predict election results by betting on the least-exciting outcome possible. But no more.

headline: Must-Read at Giants Camp? The Injury Report
text: ALBANY  After a quiet start to the Giants’ training camp, the pace has picked up recently. There is good news, and there is bad.

headline: Citizenship From Birth Is Challenged on the Right
text: At a breakfast on Thursday in Washington, Senator Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, tried to tamp down a controversy that started when Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, questioned the 14th Amendment to the Constitution, which grants the right to citizenship to anyone born in the United States.

headline: Zakaria Elaborates on Returning ADL Award
text: According to a transcript of his show “GPS”, Mr. Zakaria called the opposition to a proposed mosque near Ground Zero by the Anti-Defamation League “puzzling” and explained his decision to return an award he had received from the group:

headline: Then, He Turns His Wife Into a Lion
text: David DaVinci, 27, is an illusionist with a penchant for rock music and exotic birds, which he uses in his act for Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey. This summer he is living in a recreational vehicle on Coney Island with his wife and stage assistant, Jamieleigh, 23, and their black cat, Ninja. They have nine parrots and a toucan, which spend most of their time in outdoor aviaries nearby.

headline: No Wheat Shortage, but Prices May Rise
text: The price of wheat had been falling since the last great spike in 2008, but in April, Guy Lapointe seeded 2,200 acres of hard red spring wheat anyway on his rolling land in Alberta.

headline: Border Bill Aims at Indian Companies
text: PHOENIX  Indian high-tech workers do not typically sneak into the United States through Mexico, but beefing up the Southwest border may still make it tougher for them to migrate here.

headline: A Worthy Chip Deal
text: It took a long time, but the settlement between the Federal Trade Commission and Intel, the microchip company, on Wednesday stands a reasonably good chance of curtailing the company’s tactics to keep its dominance of the microprocessor market and of bolstering competition and innovation in this vital segment of the economy.

headline: A.I.G. in Talks to Pay U.S. Debt, Chief Says
text: The American International Group has begun talks with the federal government over how to finish repaying its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout, its chief executive said on Friday.

headline: Coverage Turns, Cautiously, to Spill Impact
text: And on the 106th day — after all the top kills and top hats and junk shots — the runaway oil well in the Gulf of Mexico finally seemed close to being tamed. Or was it?

headline: Veterans Sound Alarm Over Burn-Pit Exposure
text: WASHINGTON  When former Staff Sgt. Susan Clifford was stationed in 2004 and 2005 at Balad Air Base in Iraq, she was assigned to help dump her Army unit’s trash into a massive, open-air pit.

headline: Unwanted Filly Now 4-0
text: Lisa’s Booby Trap continued her rise from unwanted horse to promising filly with a six-length victory in the $70,000 Loudonville Stakes at Saratoga. Sent off as the 3-2 favorite, she came from off the pace under Kent Desormeaux to win going away for her owner and trainer, Tim Snyder, who bought her last winter. He said he had declined offers of as much as $500,000 for the filly, who is undefeated in four starts. “This story hasn’t ended yet,” he told reporters.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,200 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: Haiti’s (Would Be) Hip-Hop President
text: Wyclef Jean will be gone until November, if not longer. The hip-hop star officially announced in Port-au-Prince on Thursday that he’s running for president of Haiti. The election is scheduled for Nov. 28.

headline: First Lady’s Spain Vacation Draws Criticism
text: WASHINGTON  There is nothing like a little Mediterranean beach vacation to unwind. Unless you happen to travel with dozens of Secret Service agents, trailed by photographers and dogged by controversy.

headline: 6-Year Sentence for Guard in Rikers Island Beatings
text: A former Rikers Island jail guard was sentenced on Friday to six years in prison for orchestrating the beatings of teenage inmates.

headline: Bloggingheads: Information Obesity
text: Reihan Salam, left, of The Daily Beast and Lev Grossman of Time discuss the dangers of too much information.

headline: Contract in Hand, Minaya Plays Down Wilpon’s Quip
text: PHILADELPHIA  The sun rose as predicted Friday, so Omar Minaya went to work and expected to continue to do so for the next couple of years.

headline: Better Than Life
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Record-setting puzzles like this one sometimes elicit complaints along the line of “the constructor is just showing off.” Do constructors forget that they’re creating puzzles for the enjoyment of us, the solvers?

headline: How To Spot A Flimflammer
text: Ezra Klein says he agrees with me on my policy critique of Paul Ryan, but denies that he’s a flimflammer.

headline: A Premier Race, a Struggling Racetrack
text: The first horse that the trainer Greg Peck entered in the Hambletonian also became the fastest in the race’s 85-year history. Last year, Peck’s Muscle Hill set a record for the one-mile distance, and his winning margin of six lengths was a fraction short of the record. It was a superb performance in what is known as the Kentucky Derby of harness racing.

headline: The Economy Needs a Bit of Ingenuity
text: THE steps being taken by government officials to help the economy are based on a faulty premise. The diagnosis is that the economy is “constrained” by a deficiency of aggregate demand, the total demand for American goods and services. The officials’ prescription is to stimulate that demand, for as long as it takes, to facilitate the recovery of an otherwise undamaged economy  as if the task were to help an uninjured skater get up after a bad fall.

headline: Inmate Residency Law May Remap State Politics
text: The people who spend their nights at 639 Exchange Street in a rural slice of upstate New York have long officially been counted as residents of Wyoming County.

headline: China: Crackdown on ‘Vulgarity and Indecency’ Is Expected
text: Chinese officials are expected to start a crackdown soon on “vulgarity and indecency” in the media, including television dating shows, according to a report Friday in the English-language edition of the official newspaper Global Times. The report referred to a commentary by Xinhua, the official news agency, saying that the mass media are profit-driven, commercialism leads to vulgarity and officials must impose a long-term ban on indecency. In late May, officials issued a directive that called dating shows vulgar and moved to cancel or censor them. The Global Times article also pointed to criticism of a cross-dressing comedian, Xiao Shenyang.

headline: Mexico: 14 Die in Prison Fighting
text: A fight between two groups of inmates at the Santa Adelaida prison in the border city of Matamoros on Friday killed at least 14 prisoners, who attacked one another with homemade knives and sharpened objects, Tamaulipas state officials said. In March, 40 inmates  many with ties to drug cartels  escaped from the same prison with the help of guards. Mexico’s prisons are overflowing with suspects arrested in the country’s crackdown on drug cartels and organized crime, and riots occur regularly as the cartels exploit gangs to gain recruits and carry out illicit business from behind bars, said a security expert, Pedro Isnardo de la Cruz of the National Autonomous University of Mexico.

headline: Former Mandela Fund Official Says Model Gave Him Diamonds
text: A former director of the Nelson Mandela Children’s Fund charity, Jeremy Ractliffe, confirmed on Friday that he received “three small uncut diamonds” from the supermodel Naomi Campbell the day after she attended a 1997 dinner given by Mr. Mandela and attended by Charles Taylor, then the president of Liberia. Ms. Campbell testified at Mr. Taylor’s war crimes trial in The Hague on Thursday that after the dinner, two unidentified men gave her a pouch containing “very small, dirty-looking stones,” which she passed to Mr. Ractliffe in the hope that they might be used to help the charity. The prosecution has accused Mr. Taylor of trading in so-called blood diamonds, which are used to foment civil conflict  a charge he denies. In a statement, Mr. Ractliffe said he worried that the gift would damage reputations and that it might be illegal, so he kept the diamonds and did not tell anyone until he recently turned them over to South African authorities. Mr. Ractliffe is no longer the charity’s chief executive, but he is listed on its Web site as a trustee.

headline: With Yanks’ Help, Red Sox Edge Closer
text: A quick glance at the American League East standings reveals that no team has clinched the title  not the Yankees, not the Tampa Bay Rays and not the Boston Red Sox, who do not care about the injuries that have ravaged their infield, outfield, catching depth and rotation. The Yankees fully expect Boston to loiter in the division race, and they made it easy on the Red Sox on Friday night with a sloppy performance that undercut any plans of using this four-game series to pull away.

headline: Mets Unravel in 8th Inning and Beyond
text: PHILADELPHIA  The sun rose as predicted Friday, and Omar Minaya was back at work as the Mets’ general manager, expecting to be there for the next two years at least. Then the sun went down, and so did the fortunes of the Mets’ season.

text: A 71-year-old Queens man who was unable to escape a fire that consumed his apartment died Friday night, the authorities said.

headline: Airports Start Body Scans Next Month
text: Catching a flight in the New York region will soon include the prospect of taking a trip through a full-body scanner first.

headline: Lochte Edges Phelps
text: It is rare that a world-record holder is the underdog in his specialty, but that was Ryan Lochte’s lot in the 200-meter individual medley Friday at the USA Swimming national championships in Irvine, Calif. Overshadowed by Michael Phelps, who was gunning for his 51st United States crown, Lochte commandeered the spotlight by scoring his first significant head-to-head victory over his longtime nemesis.

headline: For Jim Gentile, a Long-Awaited Bonus
text: It took almost 50 years, and there was no interest added. But a promise is a promise, and Jim Gentile finally got his $5,000 bonus from the Baltimore Orioles.

headline: Joanna Steichen, Photographer’s Wife and Aide, Dies at 77
text: Joanna T. Steichen, who married the photographer Edward Steichen when he was 80 and who edited an important survey of his work, died on July 24 at her summer home in Montauk, N.Y. She was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Lorene Yarnell, Dancer and Half of a Comedy Duo, Dies at 66
text: Lorene Yarnell, who with Robert Shields formed the mime-and-dance comedy team Shields and Yarnell, a familiar presence on television in the 1970s, died on July 29 after suffering a brain aneurysm at her home in Sandefjord, Norway. She was 66.

headline: Martin Drew, British Jazz Drummer, Dies at 66
text: Martin Drew, a British jazz drummer who was a member of the pianist Oscar Peterson’s internationally popular group for three decades, died on July 29 in London. He was 66.

headline: Bank of Scotland Sells a Credit Card Unit
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group agreed to sell its credit card payment processing unit to the Advent International Corporation and Bain Capital for £1.7 billion ($2.7 billion), the companies said Friday. The Royal Bank could receive a further £200 million if the buyers’ returns hit certain targets, the bank said. The Royal Bank will keep a 20 percent stake. The Royal Bank is being forced to dispose of the unit to comply with the European Union’s state-aid rules after taking £45.5 billion ($72 billion) in a rescue packaged financed by taxpayers during the financial crisis.

headline: Gunmen Kill Medical Aid Workers in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Their last meal was a picnic in the forest in the Sharrun Valley, high in the Hindu Kush mountains of northern Afghanistan.

In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett writes about driving three collectible classics that will be auctioned next week.

headline: Kagan Is Sworn in as the Fourth Woman, and 112th Justice, on the Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON  Elena Kagan was sworn in on Saturday as the 112th person, and fourth woman, to serve on the Supreme Court, continuing a generational and demographic transformation of the nation’s highest bench.

headline: Tax Cuts And Spending (Very Wonkish)
text: Why would a temporary extension of the high-end Bush tax cuts be a highly ineffective form of stimulus? Coming into this economic crisis, I thought every macroeconomist understood why temporary tax cuts do little to boost demand, especially if those tax cuts are for people with high incomes. But as with so much else, this seems to be one of these economic insights that has been lost in our intellectual Dark Age. So what I thought I’d do is lay out, briefly, the basic logic.

headline: Prime Number
text: 40: The number of American billionaires who have pledged to give away more than half of their fortunes to charity as part of the Giving Pledge, a philanthrophic campaign targeting billionaires that was started in June by Warren Buffett and Bill and Melinda Gates. Much of the money might have been donated anyway, but Mr. Buffett said the value of the pledges lies in the examples they set and in the sentiments expressed by the contributors in letters posted on the campaign’s Web site. About 400 Americans are worth at least $1 billion, according to the latest estimate by Forbes magazine.

headline: Pop Maestro
text: Mitch Miller, who died last week, became a television celebrity in the early 1960s, leading a choral group in popular old songs like “Home on the Range.” Viewers were invited to sing along as the lyrics appeared on the screen. Some critics, including Jack Gould of The New York Times, groaned. But the ratings soared. Here’s what Mr. Gould had to say on Jan. 28, after the debut of the show:

headline: Summer Holiday Notes in Grand Prix Racing
text: The summer holiday period has existed for a few years now in Formula One. It used to be there was no break, but as teams took more and more mechanics and crew to races and there were more and more races in the season, the series decided to create a three week break in August to give everyone a rest. That three-week break is sometimes four weeks, as it is this year, but even a four-week break for F1 people is a three week break, since they usually leave a day or two after the preceding race and they arrive at the next race several days in advance.

headline: August Poli-Books Best Seller List
text: “The Obama Diaries” by Laura Ingraham debuts at No. 1. The conservative political commentator uses a satirical format full of fictitious entries in diaries by President Obama, his family and even Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to mock the administration’s policies and lifestyles.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: A Crowded Thanksgiving at the Taylors
text: Well, don’t go bringing a deep-fried turkey to Tami Taylor’s house for Thanksgiving. Because Tami has already bought a farm-raised natural one, and roasted it simply, and she doesn’t want your showboat turkey getting in the way. Are you listening, Buddy Garrity?

He was 62 and had lived in Manhattan.

headline: Epic Confusion: The Narrative of the Superathlete
text: A great many of the highest moments in sports these days come with an aftertaste of ambiguity, a feeling of: Really glad that I witnessed that, but what am I to make of it? The notion of looking up to the sports hero was always dubious. Now? Forget it. The new definition of a sports hero is someone whom we don’t yet have enough information on.

Bush dreamed of building a multiethnic party that would achieve dominance in a nation where the words “majority” and “minority” were losing their meaning. Mr. Bush was adamant, in the days after the terrorist attacks of 2001, that American Muslims not become the targets of public resentment, and he later pushed a plan to offer illegal immigrants a path toward citizenship.

headline: Exit Strategy, Meet Your Challenge: Iraq

headline: In a Word, Manuel Backs His Team, if Not Himself

text: 5:20 p.m. | Updated Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez was pulled from the lineup for Saturday’s game with a bruised lower left leg after he was hit by a sharp one-hopper off the bat of Lance Berkman during batting practice. Rodriguez had X-rays, which came back negative, and was to be examined by the team physician, Chris Ahmad.

text: ATLANTA  Early on in Beverly L. Hall’s 11-year tenure as superintendent of Atlanta Public Schools, she figured that the academic gains she intended to make with the city’s mostly poor, black students would face skepticism.

headline: Death Toll Rises in Iraq Car Bombing
text: BAGHDAD — A car bomb detonated a fuel tank in Iraq’s second-largest city, Basra, on Saturday, spreading fire through a crowded market, Interior Ministry officials said, in the worst attack of the day that marked five months since Iraqis voted for a new government that has yet to be created.

headline: Vast Ice ‘Island’ Breaks Free of Greenland Glacier
text: Greenland has for years been shedding ice faster than the rate at which accumulating snow adds to the overall bulk of its ice sheet. The calving of an enormous ice “island” from the Petermann Glacier several days ago created a photogenic “moment” in a long-term process.

headline: Sectarian Clashes Surge in a City in Pakistan’s Heartland
text: FAISALABAD, Pakistan — This industrial city, famous for its textile exports, has lately become renowned as the center of a new wave of sectarian violence that has gripped Pakistan as militancy and extremism have taken firm root here in central Punjab Province.

headline: Matching Innovators With Shoppers
text: ONE Sunday a month, this column seeks out creative thinkers and tells their stories. You might think that finding these folks would be easy, and we acknowledge that the Prototype in-box is often flooded by readers’ suggestions. But finding entrepreneurs whose sagas say something insightful about business culture  other than just “Buy my product!”  isn’t always a cinch.

headline: Rodriguez Sits After Being Hit by Ball in Batting Practice
text: Alex Rodriguez was standing beside third base during batting practice Saturday afternoon when he turned to greet the Fox broadcaster Joe Buck. Before Rodriguez could turn back, a sharp one-hopper off the bat of Lance Berkman drilled him on the inside of his left ankle, setting a scary scene at Yankee Stadium about two and a half hours before the start of the Yankees’ 5-2 defeat of the Boston Red Sox.

headline: E-Book Wars: The Specialist vs. the Multitasker
text: THE Kindle from Amazon.com is designed to let us do one thing very well: read. To survive, it must excel at this, not only by jostling to stay a nose ahead of other e-readers, but also by maintaining an enormous lead over the Apple iPad and its coming competitors. The multipurpose iPad can do thousands of things very well; used for reading book-length texts, it doesn’t excel, but it’s passable.

headline: Russia Accuses U.S. of Violating Old Arms Pacts
text: MOSCOW  Russia’s Foreign Ministry released a report on Saturday accusing the United States of violating dozens of provisions of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons treaties going back about a decade, apparently in a retort to American critics of a new arms treaty, who have been accusing Russia of violating past agreements.

headline: New Strength Atop the PGA Tour
text: AKRON, Ohio — An international surge is under way in golf, one that could shift the balance of global power away from the United States and toward Europe and the rest of the world. Led by seven first-time winners on the PGA Tour, international golfers are poised to expand the beachhead they established on American soil with victories in 17 of the 34 events played this year — including the last two major championships.

headline: My Heart’s Long Surprise
text: THE scar, I was told, would be only a few inches long. After three weeks, I would feel well enough to take that trip to Madrid my family had planned. And when my surgeon, whom I adored, explained that he would just have to “stretch” my sternum to get to my heart, I never guessed that the stretching would be done with a saw, that the scar would measure 10 inches and that Spain would be out of the question.

headline: Step Back Helps a Solo Climber Go Up Again
text: The southern Andean wind that had blown steady and strong all day gusted harder, transforming Althea Rogers’s tent into a kite. With fingers numb from the cold, she tried to anchor the shelter to the mountainside, but at barely 5 feet 4 inches and 115 pounds, she could not. In an instant, Rogers was swept off the exposed ledge and fell 20 feet onto the loose rocks below.

headline: Afraid of Deflation? Try Some Medicine
text: AS chatter has grown about the possibility of a double-dip recession, so, too, have fears about another “D” word: deflation.

headline: A Gift the Wealthy Don’t Need
text: A CENTRAL lesson of the Great Depression was that economies mired in deep downturns seldom recover quickly on their own. Consumers won’t spend because they’re worried about losing their jobs  if they haven’t lost them already  and are busy paying down debt. Companies won’t invest because they already have more than enough capacity to satisfy existing demand. That leaves government. It’s the only remaining actor with both the means and the motive to bolster total spending substantially.

He is 11 over  his worst score in relation to par through 54 holes since turning professional in 1996.

headline: In Search of a New Playbook
text: In less than 90 days, millions of irritable voters will go to the polls to choose a new House and much of the Senate. If Democrats hope to retain control of both chambers in a year of deep dissatisfaction with incumbents, they need a sharper and more inspirational playbook than the one they are using.

headline: Go Slow on the Moratorium
text: From the moment he imposed it on May 27, President Obama has been under pressure to lift the six-month moratorium on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. Louisiana politicians have argued that the shutdown has done more than the oil spill to cripple the local economy; economists have predicted mass layoffs; and industry has warned of an exodus of rigs to more drilling-friendly parts of the world. The drumbeat has grown louder now that the ruptured well has been plugged.

headline: How to Lose an Election Without Really Trying
text: COULD George W. Bush be a kind of Gipper-in-reverse and win yet one more for the Democrats? Clearly this White House sees him as the gift that will keep on giving. The 2010 campaign against the Bush administration is in full cry, with President Obama leading the charge. The Republicans are “betting on amnesia,” he confidently told the claque at a recent fund-raiser. “They don’t have a single idea that’s different from George Bush’s ideas.” It’s now the incessant party line.

headline: Russian Response to Fire Does Little to Calm Anger
text: OREKHOVO-ZUYEVO, Russia  The flames, bright orange and menacing, advanced steadily through a field of dried-out reeds, sending up coils of smoke and heading in the general direction of a village that, with its log homes, picket fences and gigantic haystacks, seemed to have been laid out by an arsonist.

headline: Steal This Movie
text: I just saw a remarkable new documentary directed by Shlomi Eldar, the Gaza reporter for Israel’s Channel 10 news. Titled “Precious Life,” the film tracks the story of Mohammed Abu Mustafa, a 4-month-old Palestinian baby suffering from a rare immune deficiency. Moved by the baby’s plight, Eldar helps the infant and mother go from Gaza to Israel’s Tel Hashomer hospital for lifesaving bone-marrow treatment. The operation costs $55,000. Eldar puts out an appeal on Israel TV and within hours an Israeli Jew whose own son was killed during military service donates all the money.

headline: Sunday: 3 x 8
text: I hope you like cross-reference clues, that is, clues that refer to other clues. Speed solvers tend to dislike them because all that checking back and forth slows them down, but for the rest of us, it’s just another puzzle dimension. Today, eight clues refer to the three circled letters in eight other clues. You solve the answer with the circles first. Then you look at the circled letters and they become the clue for the cross-referenced answer.

headline: Minerals Service Had a Mandate to Produce Results
text: NEW ORLEANS  On March 5, 1997, an obscure federal official with a puckish grin entered a hotel ballroom here and greeted 1,000 jittery oilmen on what would prove a landmark day.

headline: Slain Workers Undaunted by Risks, Friends Say
text: Tom Little raised three daughters with his wife in Afghanistan, avoided kidnappings during the Russian occupation, hid in his basement for months during the Taliban rule in the 1990s, survived rocket attacks and endured arrests for one reason, friends and family members said: to provide eye care for indigent Afghans.

headline: Fritz Teufel, a German Protester in the ’60s, Dies at 67
text: “The monthlong trial here of Fritz Teufel, a 24-year-old German student, on a felony charge of ‘grave sedition’ may become only a footnote when the histories of contemporary Europe are written,” a correspondent of The New York Times wrote in 1967 from West Berlin. “Yet the widely publicized case has become a symbol for the ‘seditious’ fringe among modern European youth, and beyond that, of the stirrings of an entire restive generation.”

headline: Lee Lockwood Dies at 78; Captured Life Under Communism
text: Lee Lockwood, an American photojournalist who had rare opportunities to capture political, military and civilian life in Communist countries  documenting the treatment of an American prisoner of war in North Vietnam and persuading Fidel Castro to sit for a long, discursive, smoke-filled and highly personal interview  died on July 31 in Tamarac, Fla. He was 78 and lived in Weston, Fla.

headline: You’ve Seen Their Faces in the Works of Rockwell
text: ARLINGTON, Vt.  They were plucked from Grange halls, school dances and the town green, regular people whose faces, by the brushstrokes of a neighbor, would come to embody Americana.

headline: Gay Couples Cheer Ruling on Marriage
text: PROVINCETOWN, Mass.  It is not that vacationers at the tip of Cape Cod were indifferent to news that a federal judge had struck down Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage. Far from it. But for many same-sex couples, the more pressing issues last week had to do with setting up play dates and getting sand out of diapers.

headline: Traffic-Camera Debate Heats Up Campaign Trails
text: It is a common consequence of having a car these days: a driver arrives home, opens the mail and  surprise!  finds a summons attached to a grainy photograph purporting to show the driver (or at least the driver’s vehicle) involved in a traffic violation.

headline: Sabathia’s Return to Form Lifts the Yankees
text: Ask any of the Yankees to describe the personality of C. C. Sabathia, and one term is invariably mentioned: even-keeled. Nothing seems to bother him, Andy Pettitte says. Yet Pettitte knows better than to mess with Sabathia, whose eventful week  a shaky start last Sunday against Tampa Bay, the birth of his fourth child on Thursday  would test the veracity of Pettitte’s claim.

headline: Back in His Hometown, James Remains Royalty, Whatever His Uniform
text: AKRON, Ohio  Standing on a street corner in downtown Akron, waiting for his hero to return, a pastor named Wayne Anderson reflected on the true meaning of basketball, business and betrayal.

headline: Across Nation, Mosque Projects Meet Opposition
text: While a high-profile battle rages over a mosque near ground zero in Manhattan, heated confrontations have also broken out in communities across the country where mosques are proposed for far less hallowed locations.

headline: With Long Roots in the Bay Area, Improv Comedy Is Thriving
text: If anyone should know about the local improv scene, it is Jamie Wright, the co-producer of the San Francisco Improv Festival and a member of the Crisis Hopkins improv and sketch-comedy group. Yet until recently, Mr. Wright had barely heard of The Committee, arguably the most important improvisational group to ever come out of the Bay Area.

headline: Race to Succeed Chris Daly Reflects a Transformed District
text: The Mission Hotel, home to poverty, despair and, residents said, a steady market for drugs and sex behind its faded green walls, has long been an improbable seat of political influence in San Francisco.

headline: Gigantic, Very Green and on Tap for Marin
text: Anders Swahn stays busy running a solar energy startup.

headline: Local Intelligence | Canals
text: A San Mateo County marsh until the ’60s, the community of Foster City is now a late-summer paradise for windsurfers who enjoy its 16.5 miles of navigable canals. Nicknamed the City of Blue Lagoons by residents, it has evolved from an uninhabited mudflat to a proud city of 30,000.

headline: Jeter Puts October Hits Above Milestone Ones
text: No big deal. The rush of daily baseball occurrences that beg Derek Jeter’s version of events or his expert opinion never seems to contort his mask of stoicism or alter his single-minded focus on the long journey to October.

headline: Far From the Poor, Real Estate Woes Nip at Lake Forest

headline: Blame Shows Potential, Winning Whitney Handicap
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Over the past 20 months, horse racing had pretty much turned into a girls game  or at least the slick filly Rachel Alexandra and the undefeated mare Zenyatta made it seem that way. But in the final strides of the 83rd running of the Whitney Handicap, a serious male horse finally showed himself.

headline: Mickelson in Range of Lead and No. 1

But to narrow them to the width of the fairways at Firestone Country Club, here are the top three that will be settled by the time the final putt falls Sunday night.

headline: A Political Consulting Firm Redefines the Word ‘Insurgent’

headline: Player Who Was Too Clever for the Health of His Game

headline: Under Madrid Skies, the Stars of Flamenco
text: Watching flamenco performed outdoors has be one of the most sublime experiences in dance. Though often associated with smoky cafes, the art form becomes all the more electrifying when the sounds of strumming guitars, pounding feet and plaintive voices fill the fresh evening air. That’s why every summer in Spain the greatest flamenco artists work their magic on stages under the stars. But even among all those superb festivals, the flamenco-related portion of the Veranos de la Villa festival in Madrid, which runs from Aug. 10 to 21, stands out.

headline: Emotional Speech From Emmitt Smith
text: Above, the one moment not to miss from the Pro Football Hall of Fame induction ceremony on Saturday night.

headline: Tip of the Week: Eating Lunch and Surfing on the Web
text: Surfing the Web while eating lunch at your desk is a good way to catch up on the news, but it can get messy trying to juggle forks, spoons and the mouse all at once. If you’d rather just sit back and dine while the headlines and news from your favorite blogs and Web sites automatically roll by on screen, try the ScrollyFox add-on for the Mozilla Firefox browser. Once installed and turned on, ScrollyFox gently scrolls down an open page and then back up again for each selected site. The add-on works on most Web pages, although it may get stymied occasionally by certain sites, and the scrolling speed is adjustable.

text: BEIJING  A landslide buried and flooded hundreds of homes over the weekend in a remote mountainous region of Gansu Province. Officials said Sunday evening that 127 bodies had been recovered and that nearly 2,000 people were missing.

headline: Advising Like It’s 1999
text: I’m saddened but not really surprised by Robert Rubin’s declaration that we don’t need more stimulus. It has seemed to me from early on in this crisis that Rubin and his disciples wanted to believe that this world crisis was something like the 1997-98 Asian crisis, and amenable to similar solutions.

headline: Perry Farrell on Fortress Lollapalooza
text: CHICAGO — Perry Farrell of Jane’s Addiction was the original visionary behind Lollapalooza, which began in 1991 as a package tour of alternative rock, stocked with side stages, art installations and freak-show diversions, and it became the model for all everything-but-the-kitchen sink American music festivals, from H.O.R.D.E. to Coachella. It ran for seven years and had a brief, troubled return in the early 2000s before an ambitious group of independent concert promoters in Austin, Tex., revived it in 2005 as a single weekend event Chicago.

text: Youth will be served in the classical music world these days, and the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center has become an important gateway. The weekend concerts of the festival orchestra featured two Frenchmen, one young, the other startlingly young.

text: Although women are still slightly in the minority among global Web users, they are closing ground with men and, once connected, spend about two more hours online a month on average.

headline: London Theatergoers Have Front-Row Seats at End of the World
text: LONDON  If you’re looking for a ringside seat at the apocalypse this summer, then the National Theater is your kind of place. I can’t remember a season in which a single institution has offered so many productions with a Götterdämmerung vibe, though of course I missed out on the Weimar Republic.

headline: Boss’s Stumble May Also Trip Hewlett-Packard
text: The events were billed as C.E.O. executive summit meetings, exclusive gatherings, often lasting several days, where Hewlett-Packard officials wooed top customers. When Mark V. Hurd, H.P.’s chief, appeared at them, he sometimes relied on Jodie Fisher, a 50-year-old former reality television contestant turned H.P. marketing consultant, who would introduce him to customers and keep him company.

headline: Happy Birthday, Mr. Taylor: Let’s Soar
text: In an interview a couple of years ago Paul Taylor, talking about how some of his friends had just died, told me: “Oh, they just drop off all the time. It’s just terrible. But I’m going to outlive everybody. Both my parents lived to be very old.”

headline: All the Right Stuff and the Gross Stuff
text: In conducting research into the physiology of astronauts in space, Mary Roach found out that one man on a Space Shuttle flight wore a sound monitor on his belly for the duration of his voyage. It is Ms. Roach’s style to be less interested in the belly-noise findings than in the freaky-deaky part of the story. “Don’t feel bad for him,” she writes in “Packing for Mars” about that awkwardly wired astronaut. “Feel bad for the Air Force security guy assigned to listen to two weeks of bowel sounds to be sure no conversations including classified information had been inadvertently recorded.”

headline: Making Music Out of Uncracked Codes and a Factory’s Din
text: John Zorn, the artistic director of the Stone, a small performance space in the East Village, has turned over the programming this month to his colleague Annie Gosfield. The series she has assembled, with two shows most nights, is a broad representation of the experimental music world. In her first week she devoted evenings to improvisation, bands that straddle rock and the avant-garde, composer-performer concerts, and recitals by the new-music pianists Sarah Cahill, Blair McMillen, Kathleen Supové and Anthony de Mare.

headline: Odors and Oddities of the Underground
text: As a topic for crowdsourcing, there could hardly be a better subject than New York’s subways. Who doesn’t have a story, or 10, to tell about something they’ve seen or someone they’ve been jammed next to down under?

headline: A Cruel Ex and Other One-Act Exercises
text: It may be hot outside, but at the 59E59 Theaters there is one heck of a cold heart on display in “Romance,” the best of the four works in Series A of “Summer Shorts 4,” the annual festival of new American short plays. And this affecting, carefully drawn piece, an excavation of a failed relationship, is by Neil LaBute, who is known more for brashness (“Fat Pig”) than for nuance.

headline: Ballet Adds Human Splendor to Wonders of Vail
text: VAIL, Colo.  The setting of the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater here is spectacular. Audiences can see the evergreens and ski slopes that cover the Rocky Mountains. And on Friday night, while taking our seats beforehand, we could watch star dancers practicing their steps on the uncurtained open-air stage. At work in front of us were dancers born in Japan, Russia, Spain and the United States who perform with the Royal Danish Ballet, the Royal Ballet, New York City Ballet, American Ballet Theater and Boston Ballet  a miniature United Nations of ballet.

headline: Nights of Dance
text: Images from the Vail International Dance Festival.

headline: A Magazine Tests Neuromarketing
text: Magazines have long used focus groups to tailor their package. New Scientist took another route for its latest issue, testing whether neuromarketing, which examines the brain’s response to products and brands, could help make the magazine more appealing.

headline: Excess Radiation From CT Scans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Will Ferrell Gets a Boost From ‘The Other Guys’
text: Will Ferrell, right, badly needed a hit  his last outing in theaters was the disastrous “Land of the Lost”  and he got one over the weekend with “The Other Guys,” a buddy comedy that took in about $35.6 million at the North American box office. “The Other Guys,” which cost Columbia Pictures about $90 million to make, was easily No. 1 for the weekend and represented one of the strongest openings of Mr. Ferrell’s career. It continued a winning streak at Columbia, owned by Sony, which was behind the hit remake of “The Karate Kid” and also scored with “Grown Ups” and “Salt.” In second place for the weekend was Christopher Nolan’s “Inception” with about $18.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. This Warner Brothers film has shown remarkable holding power over the last month, selling a total of $227.7 million in North America. “Step Up 3D,” the third in a series from Walt Disney Studios and Summit Entertainment, was a weak third, selling $15.5 million and marking a low point for the franchise, despite having the benefit of premium-price 3-D tickets for the first time. One reason may have been marketing: “Step Up 3-D” was backed by dark, difficult-to-decipher images that baffled many Hollywood veterans. “Salt,” the Angelina Jolie spy caper, was fourth with about $11.1 million, for a new domestic total of $92 million. The comedy “Dinner for Schmucks,” from Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks Studios, was fifth with $10.5 million ($46.7 million total.)

headline: In the Wings
text: The Classic Stage Company has announced the cast and dates for its production of “Orlando,” by Sarah Ruhl (“In the Next Room, or the vibrator play”). The show will feature Francesca Faridany (“The 39 Steps”), Annika Boras, Gibson Frazier, David Greenspan, Tom Nelis (“Enron”) and Howard W. Overshown (“Julius Caesar”) in a limited run at the East Village theater, from Sept. 8 to Oct. 17 (classicstage.org). ... The creators of the musical “[title of show]” are in the process of developing a new work at the Vineyard Theater. “And Now This Is Happening,” created by Hunter Bell, Michael Berresse, Susan Blackwell, Heidi Blickenstaff, Jeff Bowen and Larry Pressgrove, will have a run at the Vineyard next spring, with direction by Mr. Berresse and musical direction and arrangements by Mr. Pressgrove (vineyardtheatre.org).

headline: Videos of Animal Cruelty
text: To the Editor:

headline: 1st Irish Festival Plans 3rd Edition Here
text: Sixteen Irish playwrights will have their work featured in the 1st Irish 2010 theater festival in New York, beginning Sept. 7 across the city. The plays will include Owen O’Neill’s drama “Absolution” (about sexual abuse among the clergy) at 59E59 Theaters and Deirdre Kinahan’s dark comedy “Hue and Cry” (about two cousins reconnecting at a funeral) at the Irish Repertory Theater. The third edition of the festival, scheduled to run through Oct. 4, will also include a symposium on contemporary Irish theater on Sept. 25, with the Tony Award-winning director Garry Hynes (“The Beauty Queen of Leenane”) among the speakers and a staged reading on Sept. 27 of the poet Seamus Heaney’s translation of “Beowulf” into modern English. Details about the festival can be found at 1stIrish.org.

headline: Springsteen Documentary to Be Shown on HBO
text: HBO has announced plans to show “The Promise: The Making of ‘Darkness on the Edge of Town,’ ” a documentary that follows the making of Bruce Springsteen’s fourth album, Variety reported. Directed by Thom Zimny, who has made several films about Mr. Springsteen and his band, including the Emmy-nominated “Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band: Live in New York City,” the film chronicles Mr. Springsteen’s work on “Darkness” from 1975, after the release of his pivotal album “Born to Run,” until 1978, a time when he was prohibited from recording any music because of a pending lawsuit with Mike Appel, his former manager. The film mixes footage from rehearsals during that time with recent commentary from Mr. Springsteen and the band. (Above, Mr. Springsteen, right, with Southside Johnny.) “The fact that this footage has been sitting in a vault, and no one has seen it for more than 30 years is just extraordinary,” Richard L. Plepler, a co-president of HBO, said at a Television Critics Association meeting on Saturday. Mr. Plepler and Michael Lombardo, programming president for HBO, said the documentary would be shown on the network in October, after a premiere on Sept. 14, at the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Grading Restaurants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dance Companies Plan Tours and Premieres
text: The Mark Morris Dance Group’s weekend visit to the Mostly Mozart Festival was the kickoff to a 30th-anniversary season that will feature a tour of 20 cities and two new works. The premieres include “Petrichor,” to music by Villa-Lobos, in October in Boston, and a second work, as yet untitled, in March at the company’s Brooklyn home, the Mark Morris Dance Center. The troupe has already announced another New York engagement, “The Hard Nut,” Mr. Morris’s take on “The Nutcracker,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in December. ... The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company will begin a new tour at the Biennale de la Danse, in Lyon, France, in September, with the international premiere of “Fondly Do We Hope ... Fervently Do We Pray,” the company’s dance-theater work celebrating the bicentennial of Lincoln’s birth. (Above, Antonio Brown, in “Fondly Do We Hope.”) The tour continues with performances of “Fondly Do We Hope” in Creteil, France, and at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, around Presidents’ Day, as well as with other recent works, through April.

headline: Richard Price to Write Detective Series
text: The author Richard Price (“Clockers,” “Lush Life”) has signed a deal with Henry Holt & Company for a new series of detective thrillers set in New York, according to the blog Galleycat at Mediabistro.com. The first book in the series, as yet untitled, about a 40-year-old New York City police detective turned night-watch sergeant whose career was ruined after a controversial shooting, will be released in the fall of 2011 under Mr. Price’s pen name Jay Morris.

headline: Killings in Honduras

headline: India Asks, Should Food Be a Right for the Poor?
text: JHABUA, India  Inside the drab district hospital, where dogs patter down the corridors, sniffing for food, Ratan Bhuria’s children are curled together in the malnutrition ward, hovering at the edge of starvation. His daughter, Nani, is 4 and weighs 20 pounds. His son, Jogdiya, is 2 and weighs only eight.

headline: BlackBerry Security Stance Sows Anxiety
text: The 2008 terrorist attacks in Mumbai heightened concerns in India over the government’s inability to eavesdrop on encrypted communications. In the United Arab Emirates, similar concerns escalated this year after a Palestinian operative was killed in a hotel in Dubai, possibly by a team from the Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency.

headline: Security for Companies, Not for the Consumer
text: OTTAWA  In both form and function, a BlackBerry bought by a consumer for personal use and one handed to an employee by a corporation as a work tool appear to be pretty much the same thing.

headline: A Gamble on a Weekly That Paid Off
text: Let me get this straight: A very rich guy buys a financially and editorially beleaguered weekly magazine, saying he wants to preserve an important journalistic asset. That will never work, right?
