headline: Iraq’s Excuser-in-Chief Speaks Up
text: With only a little more than three weeks until the last American combat troops are scheduled to be withdrawn from Iraq, the fragile political standoff between the main population groups — Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds — is set to move into a more stressful phase, one that could strain the fragile peace achieved under American dominion as nothing has since the explosion of sectarian violence in 2006.

headline: Burnett Scratched From Red Sox Start
text: A.J. Burnett was scratched from his start against the Boston Red Sox on Sunday night after experiencing tightness in his back while throwing Saturday. Dustin Moseley will start in his place.

headline: The Economist Tends Its Sophisticate Garden
text: Its fire-engine-red logo peeks out of fashionable handbags and from the back pockets of designer jeans. Bankers read it in first-class seats. Hipsters read it on the subway on their way to work.

headline: U.S. Victims Identified as Bodies Arrive in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  After a three-day journey, the 10 bodies arrived back here on Sunday and were laid out in the morgue of the Afghan National Army’s military hospital. F.B.I. agents and their counterparts from Britain, Germany and Afghanistan confirmed that they were all members of an American-based relief group, the authorities said.

headline: Woods’s Finish Looks Like Rock Bottom
text: AKRON, Ohio  Tiger Woods circled a prospective 15-foot birdie putt on the 18th green at Firestone Country Club on Sunday, crouching and surveying the line from both sides of the hole. He appeared to be looking for some glimmer of hope, some small positive to take from a week at the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational that had already been, in many ways, his worst as a professional golfer.

headline: Investor Appetite for Bonds in a Tepid Recovery Weighs on Rates
text: Just how low can interest rates go?

headline: Division of Roles Could Help H.P.
text: Hewlett-Packard may find a silver lining in Mark V. Hurd’s resignation. The loss of its chairman and chief executive over alleged expense fiddling and sexual harassment will hurt, especially given all of the good he did for the technology company. Investors fretted, sending the shares down 10 percent in after-hours trading on Friday night after the news was announced. But the board could use this as an opportunity to split the roles of chairman and chief executive, and set Hewlett on an even better course.

headline: Lamont Moves to Center in Connecticut Race
text: When Ned Lamont waged an insurgent antiwar campaign in 2006 against Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, he electrified Hollywood celebrities, rattled the Democratic establishment, melted bloggers and was nicknamed “the darling of the left.”

headline: A Contact Lens Cleaner, With Nature as Inspiration
text: “TO bring you an entirely new contact lens solution, we thought outside the box, and found our true inspiration in your eyes,” a voice says in a commercial for Biotrue. The Biotrue carton opens, and from its interior sides hang two pieces of paper folded to resemble green shutters framing a window, which exposes, in the form of a paper collage, a view of an idyllic island.

headline: A Magazine Tests Neuromarketing
text: Magazines have long used focus groups to tailor their package. New Scientist took another route for its latest issue, testing whether neuromarketing, which examines the brain’s response to products and brands, could help make the magazine more appealing.

headline: Preserving History of U.S. Golf
text: Somewhat hidden in a New Jersey suburb is a treasure trove of golf history. The United States Golf Association Museum in Far Hills, N.J., is more than a collection of golf memorabilia, though it is an impressive gathering of artifacts, clubs, garments, trophies, works of golf art and hundreds of other meaningful and memorable objects associated with the game. The museum, however, does more than show you important pieces of golf history; it puts them together to tell you the story of golf in America.

headline: W Takes a New Direction
text: W, a magazine best known for ethereal photo spreads with dazed-looking models sporting Versace, Chanel, Prada and Ferragamo, is assuming a new look and editorial tone. It is becoming a place that its new editor, Stefano Tonchi, hopes readers will go to not only for high-end fashion but for profiles on cultural figures, travel essays and appraisals of art.

headline: Utopian Dream Becomes Battleground in France
text: GRENOBLE, France  A utopian dream of a new urban community, built here in the 1970s, had slowly degraded into a poor neighborhood plagued by aimless youths before it finally burst into flames three weeks ago.

headline: The New York Convention Con
text: It has become an easy campaign pitch in New York: clean up Albany in one big sweep with a constitutional convention.

headline: Vulnerable Refugees, Losing a Lifeline
text: In less than two months, unless Congress acts quickly, thousands of refugees who fled for their lives from places like Iran, Cuba, Russia, Somalia and Vietnam  and who are now elderly, disabled and poor  are about to learn the cold limits of compassion.

headline: A Times Square Aura for Pop-Tarts
text: Poor Pop-Tarts.

headline: India Swoons Over Its Chess Champ, and Even the Game
text: NEW DELHI — The girls gathered in a school auditorium here on a recent Saturday were beaming with pride and nervous with anticipation. They would soon have a chance to meet the star of their dreams: Viswanathan Anand.

headline: The Rigor of Love
text: Can the experience of faith be shared by those unable to believe in the existence of a transcendent God? Might there be a faith of the faithless?

headline: Docks for Apple Gadgets Help a Business Thrive
text: RAHWAY, N.J.  In the 1950s and 1960s, Realtone Electronics made transistor radios, one of the must-have gadgets of the era.

headline: Doubts Rise in Rwanda as Election Is Held
text: KIGALI, Rwanda  President Paul Kagame uses Twitter. He has lunched at Google. He started out as a skinny rebel fighter in the bush, marched into Rwanda’s capital in the midst of a genocide and then rose to make his country one of the developing world’s most orderly and crime-free societies.

headline: ‘Dora’ Special Explores Influence on Children
text: Dora the Explorer will always be 7 years old, but the animated Latina character who solves every challenge  in English and Spanish  will still celebrate her 10th anniversary on Sunday.

headline: City Program for Homeless Is Criticized
text: It was envisioned as a way to help more homeless families leave shelters behind for good. But a signature anti-poverty program of the Bloomberg administration is stumbling because of lax oversight, according to an audit by the city comptroller, John C. Liu.

headline: Koch, at 85, Wages a New Campaign
text: BUFFALO  Edward I. Koch, 85 years old, thirsty for a Dairy Queen milkshake and ready for a nap, was fuming.

headline: A Sprint to a Bridgestone Win as Mickelson Crumbles
text: AKRON, Ohio — For the second time this year and the third in his career, Hunter Mahan won a PGA Tour event by doing what he does best — overcoming the field with a furious Sunday rush from off the pace.

headline: Haitians Look to Family 1,500 Miles North for Help
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As Alourds Grandoit hitches her chair across the yard, following the spots of shade, her thoughts linger mostly on the dead: 10 relatives lost in the Jan. 12 earthquake. But sometimes they turn to a plastic barrel that is wending its way toward her, from her cousin’s two-family house in Queens to a ship moving down the Atlantic coast to  someday soon  a truck rumbling up the road to her brother’s cinderblock bungalow, where she moved when the cataclysm wrecked her home.

headline: South Korea’s President Reshuffles Cabinet
text: SEOUL, South Korea  President Lee Myung-bak appointed South Korea’s youngest prime minister in 39 years on Sunday in a cabinet reshuffle that retained a tough policy on North Korea.

headline: In Connecticut, a New Level of Intensity for Primaries
text: Democratic and Republican voters go to the polls in Connecticut on Tuesday to pick their party’s nominee for governor in tight primary contests that pit establishment politicians against wealthy candidates in both parties who are bankrolling their own campaigns.

headline: A Hidden Gem in the Catskills
text: The Rip Van Winkle Country Club is one of a dying breed, the family-owned nine-hole course.

headline: After Drought, Hope for Shows Made for Web
text: LOS ANGELES — When Illeana Douglas, long active in independent film, wanted to make a show about a Hollywood actress who becomes a cog in a blue-collar wheel, she turned to the Web and to an unusual ally, Ikea.

headline: After 50 Shots in Harlem, One Dead and 6 Hurt
text: The shooting in Harlem started after a fight broke out at a crowded party that had spilled from a park into the streets on Sunday morning. When it was over, 50 bullets had been fired, one man was dead, and six others, including two police officers, were wounded.

headline: On the Road with Ed Koch
text: Former mayor Ed Koch travels upstate to promote his latest campaign — cleaning up Albany.

headline: Early Struggles of Soldier Charged in Leak Case
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  He spent part of his childhood with his father in the arid plains of central Oklahoma, where classmates made fun of him for being a geek. He spent another part with his mother in a small, remote corner of southwest Wales, where classmates made fun of him for being gay.

headline: Jets’ Edwards Shows Smile and Growth on His Face
text: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Braylon Edwards has turned his beard into a person. Over the past week alone, The Beard traveled here to Jets training camp, conducted interviews and considered making T-shirts.

headline: Hall of Famer’s Slow Road to a Major League Bench
text: DES MOINES  The most exclusive dinner in baseball takes place at the Otesaga Resort Hotel in Cooperstown, N.Y., after the Hall of Fame induction ceremony on the last Sunday in July. Only Hall of Famers, the commissioner and the museum’s president may attend, and there are no assigned seats.

headline: As the Economy Slows
text: The economic news  on growth, consumers, housing and manufacturing  was bad enough before the jobs report for July, released last Friday. The report leaves no doubt that a slowdown is well under way. The odds of renewed recession remain uncomfortably high.

headline: China and the I.M.F.
text: A growing list of countries  from the United States to the European Union to Brazil  have complained that China has been cheapening its currency. So it is positive news  of a sort  that China agreed to submit this year to the International Monetary Fund’s annual review of exchange rate and economic policies.

headline: America Goes Dark
text: The lights are going out all over America  literally. Colorado Springs has made headlines with its desperate attempt to save money by turning off a third of its streetlights, but similar things are either happening or being contemplated across the nation, from Philadelphia to Fresno.

headline: A Slow Burn Over a Reluctance to Call High Strikes
text: Orel Hershiser is ready with his pitch, and it is a high, hard one. Hershiser, the Los Angeles Dodgers ace turned ESPN analyst, said the flurry of proposals for shortening games missed the target.

headline: The Marriage Ideal
text: Here are some commonplace arguments against gay marriage: Marriage is an ancient institution that has always been defined as the union of one man and one woman, and we meddle with that definition at our peril. Lifelong heterosexual monogamy is natural; gay relationships are not. The nuclear family is the universal, time-tested path to forming families and raising children.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: After Peter and the Wolf Comes Everyone and the Wolf
text: In the middle of a Manhattan cocktail party where young guests sniff that Pixar movies are “so brilliant, yet so necessarily empty,” Caleb (Josh Tyson) says he’s writing a novel, which he isn’t, and talks about being in love, which is not true either.

headline: A Failure to Feed
text: Corruption in India’s inefficient, decades-old food distribution system is raising questions about whether the government should issue food coupons or even cash to those in need.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Students Spared Amid an Increase in Deportations
text: The Obama administration, while deporting a record number of immigrants convicted of crimes, is sparing one group of illegal immigrants from expulsion: students who came to the United States without papers when they were children.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ryne Sandberg, at Wrigley’s Doorstep
text: DES MOINES – Ryne Sandberg was the starting second baseman for the National League in the 1989 All-Star Game in Anaheim. Twenty-one years later, he was back in Anaheim on All-Star weekend last month, working.

headline: Economic Slowdown Catches Up With Nascar
text: After years of jam-packed races, sky-high television ratings and record merchandise sales, Nascar has seen attendance at nearly every track slip this year as recession-weary fans continue to cut costs.

headline: In Superman’s Hometown, a Labor Dispute Over Health
text: Union workers at the nation’s only uranium conversion plant, in Metropolis, Ill., have erected 42 crosses nearby in memory of workers who died of cancer. Twenty-seven smaller crosses symbolize workers who have survived the disease.

headline: Appreciating Thomas as a Mentor
text: Isiah Thomas and his wife spent a pleasant afternoon in Central Park on Sunday.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the finances of Denver’s public school system reported incorrectly an earlier connection between Senator Michael F. Bennet, a former superintendent of the school system, and Thomas Boasberg, the current superintendent. Both once worked in finance in the private sector  Mr. Bennet for the Anschutz Investment Company and Mr. Boasberg in acquisitions at Level 3 Communications  but they did not work together. The article also failed to note that Jeannie Kaplan, a former member of the school board who was quoted as criticizing a financial transaction reached during Mr. Bennet’s tenure as school superintendent, is a fund-raiser and active supporter of Mr. Bennet’s opponent in Colorado’s Democratic primary race for the Senate. (Go to Article)

headline: Yanks’ Lineup Includes Late Drama
text: The Yankees took the field against the Boston Red Sox on Sunday night with an unfamiliar face in the infield  just not where the team might have expected.

headline: Rabbi Bruce M. Cohen, Is Dead at 65; Worked to Promote Peace
text: When five Israeli Arabs were killed by security forces during mass protests in Nazareth, Israel, on March 30, 1976, congregants of Mishkan Israel, a synagogue in New Haven, raised $10,000 so that their rabbi, Bruce M. Cohen, could go to Israel to promote peace.

headline: Plug in Gulf Well Is Declared a Success
text: BP said Sunday on its Web site that a cement plug had been successfully put in place after a procedure to seal the leaking well in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 8
text: A view of the day in sports, from swimming to surfing to horses on the beach.

headline: Help From the Other Side of the Water
text: Some relief comes, but it’s never enough, as the continuing disaster tests and remakes bonds between Haitians and their family in America.

headline: Putting Ruth and Red Sox in the Rearview Mirror
text: Derek Jeter has constructed a 16-year major league career out of clutch hits. So it was only fitting that he would provide several more examples on the night when he surpassed Babe Ruth with his 2,874th hit.

headline: First Signs of Puberty Seen in Younger Girls
text: A new study finds that girls are more likely today than in the past to start developing breasts by age 7 or 8.

headline: A Push for Bonds as Shares Fall
text: The bond market in the United States rallied on Friday and stocks retreated after a snapshot of the national job market came in weaker than expected, stoking concerns about the economy, Christine Hauser reports in The New York Times.

headline: Patricia Neal, an Oscar Winner Who Endured Tragedy, Dies at 84
text: Patricia Neal, who made her way from Kentucky’s coal country to Hollywood and Broadway, winning an Academy Award and a Tony, but whose life alternated almost surreally between triumph and tragedy, died on Sunday at her home in Edgartown, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard. She was 84.

headline: The First Church of Robotics
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: The Blame Game
text: Bill Pennington's bad golf game is everyone's fault but his.

headline: Word of the Day | resumption
text: resumption •\ri-ˈzəm(p)-shən\• noun

headline: Half the Holes, No Less the Charm
text: PALENVILLE, N.Y. — I am standing near the fifth green at the Rip Van Winkle Country Club, a public nine-hole golf course at the foot of New York’s Catskill Mountains. A few minutes ago, a dog lazily pursued a deer across the fairway. They passed two ducks that did not bother to look up.

headline: Technology’s Place in the Strike Zone
text: Calling more strikes may be a way to speed up games, but the strike zone, as Ted Williams once said, is “whatever that day’s umpire says it is.”

headline: Familiar Story in Nevada: Republicans on Offensive
text: Midterm election campaigns, by their nature, knit together a diffuse patchwork of story lines. But the Nevada Senate race distills the patterns of 2010 as well as any.

headline: Suspect Is Dead After Stabbings of Three People on Staten Island
text: A woman and two children were slashed with a knife in their Staten Island townhouse on Sunday night, the police said. Officers later found the woman’s companion in the home with a fatal knife wound.

headline: Radical Cleric Is Arrested in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  A radical cleric was arrested in Indonesia on Monday, accused of having ties to terrorist training activities and to militants plotting a series of attacks on Indonesian authorities and foreigners, police said.

headline: News Quiz | August 9, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: A.I.G. in Talks to Pay U.S. Debt, Chief Says
text: The American International Group has begun talks with the federal government over how to finish repaying its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout, its chief executive said on Friday.

headline: Oscar Winner’s Life of Highs and Lows
text: Patricia Neal, the molasses-voiced actress whose life alternated surreally between triumph and tragedy, died Sunday.

headline: Greenspan Calls for Repeal of All the Bush Tax Cuts
text: It was not enough, it seems, for Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman and a self-described lifelong Republican libertarian, to call for stringent government regulation of giant banks, as he did a few months ago, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Sells a Credit Card Unit
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group agreed to sell its credit card payment processing unit to the Advent International Corporation and Bain Capital for £1.7 billion ($2.7 billion), the companies said Friday.

headline: Ravenswood Bank Becomes the 109th to Fail This Year
text: Regulators seized the Ravenswood Bank of Chicago on Friday, bringing the number of closures this year to 109. The Wintrust Financial Corporation’s Northbrook Bank and Trust Company of Northbrook, Ill., will assume all of the deposits of the two branches of Ravenswood Bank, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.

headline: Wind Farm Deal Assures Bigger U.S. Role
text: The United Steelworkers and two Chinese companies announced Friday that they had signed an agreement assuring that major components of machines for a $1.5 billion wind farm in Texas would be made in the United States.

headline: BlackBerry Security Stance Sows Anxiety
text: The 2008 terrorist attacks in Mumbai heightened concerns in India over the government’s inability to eavesdrop on encrypted communications. In the United Arab Emirates, similar concerns escalated this year after a Palestinian operative was killed in a hotel in Dubai, possibly by a team from the Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency.

headline: Cohan: Still Paying for Lehman’s Demise
text: From William D. Cohan at Opinionator:

headline: Editorial: China and the I.M.F.
text: From the Editors on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times:

headline: American Students Abroad
text: WHO are choosing to study abroad in Middle Eastern countries?

headline: Slow Trading Pushes Emirates Brokerages to Close
text: Stock brokers in the United Arab Emirates are struggling to make ends meet as trading volumes tumble to the lowest in four years, forcing some to close, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Hurd’s Exit Raises More Questions for H.P.
text: The events were billed as C.E.O. executive summit meetings, exclusive gatherings, often lasting several days, where Hewlett-Packard officials wooed top customers. When Mark V. Hurd (left), H.P.’s chief, appeared at them, he sometimes relied on Jodie Fisher (right), a 50-year-old former reality television contestant turned H.P. marketing consultant, who would introduce him to customers and keep him company, The New York Times’s Ashlee Vance wrote regarding a relationship which led to Mr. Hurd’s ouster last week.

headline: Allied World Buys Back Stock From Goldman Funds
text: Allied World Assurance Holdings said it bought back $250 million worth of stock from funds that are its founding shareholders and affiliated with Goldman Sachs, Reuters reported.

headline: Goldman Derivatives Said to Be Up to 35% of Revenue
text: Goldman Sachs has informed the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission that 25 to 35 percent of its revenue was derived from the derivatives businesses, The Wall Street Journal said, citing a person familiar with the situation.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Gallinicide
text: Today’s word, in association with the superior Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Bondholders Show Confidence in U.S. Firms
text: Companies are taking advantage of the lowest borrowing costs on record to sell debt financing share purchases and acquisitions, signaling bondholder confidence the United States will avoid falling into another recession, according to a Bloomberg News report.

headline: Beautiful, Comfortable and Trapped
text: The women are like fearless goddesses, beautiful and untouched.

headline: Big Rewards Could Trigger More Whistle-Blowing
text: Whistle-blowers looking for a potential multimillion-dollar payday could start coming out of the woodwork with alacrity thanks to tip-off incentives included within the Dodd-Frank financial reform act, The Financial Times reported, citing comments from lawyers.

headline: Deal for Plastic Logic Could Fan British Fears
text: Plastic Logic of Britain is in discussions with Russia’s state-controlled Rusnano, a nanotechnology corporation, to sell a stake to the Russian firm. According to The Financial Times, the move is “likely to fuel fears about ownership of potentially world-beating U.K. technology being transferred to other countries.”

headline: International Power May Announce Takeover Tuesday
text: In a deal that would result in a windfall of up to £1.3 billion ($2.1 billion)  for its shareholders, International Power is poised to be taken over by GDF Suez, The Financial Times reported, citing a person familiar with the situation.

headline: Mosque Used by 9/11 Plotters Is Closed
text: BERLIN  The authorities in Hamburg said Monday that they had shut down the mosque where several of the hijackers involved in the Sept. 11 attacks had met, asserting that it remained a source of radicalization nearly a decade later.

headline: Picky Buyers Turning Their Noses Up at I.P.O.’s
text: Investors have lately been finicky when it comes to initial public offerings, The Wall Street Journal wrote, contending that the pickiness is likely to continue this week with those I.P.O.’s on deck lacking an “extra pinch of spice necessary to draw in buyers in the current market environment.”

headline: Goldman Lowers Growth Outlook for U.S. and Japan
text: Goldman Sachs lowered its economic growth outlook for Japan and the United States, citing the likelihood of a “significant falloff” from stimulus measures and slowing export growth for Japan. The American recovery is losing a “considerable amount of momentum,” it said.

headline: Female Entrepreneurs on the Rise
text: A new wave of female entrepreneurs is moving into position to break down the historic gender imbalance in high-tech entrepreneurship,   The Silicon Valley Mercury News wrote.

headline: Obama Calls for U.S. to Lead in Graduation
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  President Obama shared an enthusiastic handshake and a hearty clap on the shoulder with this state’s Republican governor, Rick Perry, when Air Force One touched down here on Monday.

headline: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: We’re asking this question every Monday this summer for our Summer Reading Student Challenge. You can post your answer here anytime until next Monday, August 16.

headline: Tebow Is Willing to Trim Ego
text: Is this blog post an excuse to run a picture of Tim Tebow’s new haircut?

headline: Memories of World War II on Display in London
text: A special treat will soon await World War II history buffs outside the front entrance to the Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms in London. In commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the Battle of Britain, an exact, full-size replica of a Spitfire fighter plane will be on display from Aug. 16 to 31, decked out in wartime camouflage and free for all to admire. Credited with holding back the Nazi invasion and changing the course of the war, the plane has come to symbolize the bravery of the Royal Air Force.

headline: Feminists at Fault?
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Icahn’s $1 Billion Energy Bet
text: Carl C. Icahn disclosed that his hedge funds invested almost $1 billion in energy stocks during the second quarter as they were pummeled by declining crude prices and the worst oil spill in American history, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Cromartie Dazzles, Giving Jets Leverage With Revis
text: Kristian R. Dyer covers the N.F.L. for FoxSports.com and is the publisher of the subscription site GreenAndWhiteReport.com, which covers the Jets. He can be reached at KristianRDyer@yahoo.com and followed at twitter.com/kdyer1012.

headline: On the Block: A Lehman Sign for £2,000
text: Paintings, tea caddies, cigar boxes and Chinese ceramics that decorated the London offices of Lehman Brothers are set to be auctioned at Christie’s in September. The sale is expected to raise about £2 million ($2.6 million), The Financial Times reported.

headline: CVC to Buy Autobar in $1.6 Billion Deal
text: CVC Capital Partners will acquire Autobar, a food and drink vending machine operator, from rival Charterhouse in a 1.2 billion euro ($1.6 billion) deal, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Zen and the Art of Lawn Mowing
text: Today’s idea: Not only does lawn mowing offer the pleasure of visible accomplishment in a workaday life devoid of it; it sets the mind free to hook those bigger thoughts lurking just beneath the surface.

headline: Falcone Seeking Wireless Investors
text: Philip A. Falcone has hired UBS to line up investors to finance the building of a high-speed wireless network, Reuters reports. Mr. Falcone’s hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, is pledging billions of dollars in stock, bonds, corporate loans and other assets as collateral for the deal.

headline: Morgan Stanley Stake to Result in Loss for C.I.C.?
text: A convertible equity stake in Morgan Stanley that was acquired by China Investment Corporation is now proving costly for the  sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Whitehaven Jumps on Takeover Report
text: Whitehaven Coal rose to a record in Sydney trading on Monday after The Australian newspaper said First Reserve Corporation, Whitehaven’s largest shareholder, is in talks for a 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) joint buyout of the coal producer.

headline: Haitong Securities Gets O.K. for Hong Kong Fund
text: Haitong Securities‘s Hong Kong unit has won regulatory approval to set up a fixed-income fund in the city that will invest in renminbi-denominated assets outside of mainland China, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Texts Be Gone
text: There are a number of text-blocking smartphone applications available that prevent the sending and receiving of texts in inappropriate situations, such as driving or attending class. Those products include tXtBlocker and ZoomSafer, among others.

headline: Taking the Bait: Lovers and Haters Unite
text: Every so often, we like to reply to comments. Sorry if I can’t get to all of them, but these seem representative of the response to recent posts on 100 haters, delayed openings and the joys of one wonderful workday. Thank you for following the journey and adding your priceless 2 cents. (I can use all the spare change I can find.)

headline: Q.&A.: When Google Says No
text: Q.

headline: I-Banks to Cut More Jobs in Japan, but Hire in China
text: Global investment banks will eliminate more jobs in Japan as they question growth prospects in the world’s second-biggest economy and deploy staff to expanding Asian markets including China, the Tokyo-based search firm Executive Search Partners said.

headline: Radical Cleric Is Arrested in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  One of Indonesia’s top radical Muslim clerics was arrested Monday on accusations that he played an important role in terrorist training and had links to militants plotting a series of brazen attacks on the Indonesian authorities and foreigners.

headline: Goldman Lost Over $100 Million on 3 Days in Quarter
text: Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street firm that makes the most revenue trading stocks and bonds, lost money in that business on 10 days in the second quarter, ending a three-month streak of loss-free days at the start of the year.

headline: Revenue Rises, and Chrysler Narrows Its Loss in Quarter
text: DETROIT  Chrysler on Monday said it lost $172 million in the second quarter, mostly because of the interest it was paying on its government loans, but its automotive operations were profitable for a second consecutive quarter.

headline: Afghan Aid Leader Recalls Talk of Risk
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The head of a relief group whose workers were massacred while returning from a medical mission said Monday he had been concerned there were too many foreigners on the trip, an overland trek to provide eye care to remote corners of northern Afghanistan.

headline: New York Magazine: A Gamble on a Weekly That Paid Off
text: From David Carr’s latest Media Equation column:

headline: Representatives Return From Break
text: The House makes an unscheduled return this week to approve a $26 billion package of aid to schools and states that cleared the Senate last week, though the fate of two other Senate measures on immigration and child nutrition remains uncertain.

headline: Debt Problem Has Museum Scrambling
text: The American Folk Art Museum, which has struggled financially almost since the day it opened the doors of its new building in 2001, is now facing a moment of reckoning, The New York Times’s Kate Taylor reported on Monday.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — The Chinese real estate bubble, compared in clear charts with its predecessors. When the chart goes vertical, you know it can’t last.

headline: Avoiding Undue Risks in Your Fantasy Draft
text: Jason Wood is a senior staff writer at Footballguys.com, an encyclopedic resource for fantasy football knowledge. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Corn Chowder
text: In late June, just as fresh sweet corn was coming into season, Patricia Williams, the 57-year-old executive chef at New York’s Smoke Jazz & Supper Club-Lounge, created a light, delicious corn chowder that is very simple to make. “I go by the season first, start with one ingredient, and then build up the flavor,” she said.

headline: North Korea Fires Artillery Near Disputed Waters
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea fired 110 artillery rounds at waters near a disputed western sea border with the South on Monday, escalating tensions already raised to a high pitch by aggressive South Korean naval exercises and the North’s seizure of a squidding boat.

headline: On Our Radar: A Climate Change App
text: The climate wars hit the iPhone. [The Guardian]

headline: Testimony Given by Supermodel Is Challenged at Hague Trial
text: PARIS — Did the supermodel Naomi Campbell know that diamonds delivered to her in the night, 13 years ago, were a gift from Charles G. Taylor, then the president of war-torn Liberia?

headline: What We’re Reading: History Lessons
text: Here are the things the tech reporters and editors of the New York Times saw on the Web:

headline: Monsoon Rains Continue in Flood-Ravaged Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Monsoon rains fell on several parts of Pakistan on Monday, causing landslides in the north, raising water levels in already bloated rivers and further hindering the government’s aid efforts.

headline: Shares Gain as Investors Await Fed Meeting
text: Stocks closed higher on Monday, but trading was light as investors were hesitant to act before the next Federal Reserve meeting.

headline: The Early Word: Trailblazer to Fund-raiser
text: President Obama travels to Texas for two Democratic fund-raisers this afternoon. But in a symbol of how the president’s role within the party has changed, Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican, will greet Mr. Obama while the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Bill White, sticks to the trail.

headline: App Smart Extra: Restricted Diets
text: Last Thursday’s App Smart column highlighted some good apps for grilling, like Weber’s On the Grill, Epicurious and BigOven, which help you pull together grocery lists, too.

headline: Numberplay: Hanging Over the Edge
text: You are on the Grand Canyon Skywalk, shown above, standing on the glass-bottomed structure that projects out 70 feet over the edge. You look down through the glass below your feet at the sheer fall into the Colorado River 4,000 feet below. Click here, to get a sense of the experience. You know you are safe, but suddenly you are stricken with fear: the perfectly normal feeling of mild acrophobia. It almost overcomes you — that tingling in your feet, that vague dread in the pit of your stomach, that imp in your mind insistently asking “What if I fell?” You brush away the feeling, trusting your rationality, trusting in the safety of physics and engineering. Today we’ll look at over-the-precipice engineering, and then I’m going to do my best to give you some acrophobia again.

headline: Houlihan Acquires Valuation Advisory Boutique
text: Houlihan Lokey, the investment bank, said on Monday that it had acquired Red Pine Advisors to bolster its services valuing structured debt products.

headline: Of Pop-Tarts and Former Mayors

headline: Behind Harbinger’s Deal for a Life Insurer
text: Harbinger Capital Partners’ $350 million acquisition of Old Mutual’s American life insurance unit is the latest in a string of acquisitions for the large hedge fund. The firm, run by the billionaire Phillip A. Falcone, believes it can add value by better managing the insurance company’s troubled assets. If successful, the unit could provide strong free cash flow to help fuel, among other things, Mr. Falcone’s ambitions to create a telecommunications empire.

headline: Chrysler Narrows Its Loss in Quarter, and Revenue Rises
text: From our colleagues at Business Day:

headline: Object Lesson | The Imperfectionists
text: As a design critic, I consider it my job to decide whether things are well designed and, if so, why. Because they’re environmentally sound? Ethical? Innovative? Emotionally expressive? All good reasons, sure, but sometimes we’re drawn to things simply because they give us a warm, fuzzy feeling, which is harder to explain. And I felt it recently when I spotted a set of strangely shaped water carafes at a design show in Milan.

headline: Netanyahu Speaks in Flotilla Inquiry
text: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday told an Israeli commission examining the deadly flotilla raid in late May that Israel had acted in accordance with international law, but he appeared to shift at least some of the responsibility for the bloody episode to the Turkish government and his own defense minister, Ehud Barak.

text: Reading Jon Hilsenrath’s column today, I was initially a bit skeptical about this assertion:

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: The most anticipated health care event of the week is a vote Tuesday in the House of Representatives on a bill to send aid to states to prevent cuts to Medicaid and teacher layoffs. The Senate approved the $26 billion measure last Thursday. Now House members are returning briefly to Washington from their August breaks to vote on the bill, which includes $16 billion for Medicaid.

text: What types of things might you find lying around Grand Central Terminal?

headline: A Labor Union’s Analysis of China
text: The United Steelworkers announced last week that it had signed a deal with two Chinese companies that are planning a $1.5 billion wind farm in Texas to assure that some of the high-value parts are made in this country.

text: Should it bother me that throughout Ian McDonald’s Brasyl, units of Brazilian currency are described as reis, when I know, as an old Latin American crisis hand, that the plural of real is reais?

headline: Monday Reading: Outrageous Airline Fees
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: In Crackdown on Energy Use, China to Shut 2,000 Factories
text: HONG KONG  Earlier this summer, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China promised to use an “iron hand” to improve his country’s energy efficiency, and a growing number of businesses are now discovering that it feels like a fist.

headline: Another View: It’s Time to Invest in America
text: Bill George, a Harvard business professor, argues that the government needs to provide incentives for businesses to invest in America.

headline: Apartment Sellers Insist on Exposure, of the Feet
text: Darren Sukenik has some basic requests of people who come to his open houses. They should make enough money and have sufficient assets to afford the apartments he is selling, which often go for several million dollars. They should be serious about buying a home and not just gawking.

headline: My Other Body is a Michelangelo
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the words and phrases they would have tattooed if they absolutely, positively no-excuses had to “get ink.”

headline: Shape Shifters
text: Before there was HGTV, there was Gaetano Pesce, the legendary Italian architect and designer who once espoused the joys of D.I.Y. in a column for French Elle and actually made good on it. His 1972 Golgotha chair, part of the permanent collection at MoMA, was the first of his many forays into the world of mass customization: its Dacron-filled seat assumed different shapes depending on who sat on it. Now, another clever bit of personalization: Pesce’s new shoe for the Brazilian company Melissa — an ankle bootie composed of interconnected PVC circles, whose form can change at the whim of its owner with a swift slice of the scissors. Cut once, and the boot becomes a bootie; cut again, and it’s a ballet flat, a peep toe, a sandal or even a flip-flop. ‘‘This is the future of mass production,’’ Pesce says. ‘‘With the technology we have today, we can give people something that is half done and ask them to finish it.’’ Go to melissashoes.com.

headline: Ask About College Theater Programs
text: For students who want to pursue a life in the theater, picking the right college could mean the difference between thanking their parents at the Tony Awards or moving back to their parents’ basement with Broadway dreams defeated.

headline: Leaving Your Shoes at the Front Door
text: In this week’s installment of The Appraisal, I explore the debate about whether visitors to open houses should be expected to take off their shoes. Brokers say that more sellers are making this request because they don’t want their children to be exposed to outside dirt; they want to protect their soft-wood floors; and, in some cases, they want to exert a smidgen of control on people who are in their home when they’re not. Some brokers agree with the sellers’ requests because they think that it makes apartments more desirable, and that these apartments often can be cleaner.

headline: Child Care Costs More Than College
text: Saving for college? First start saving for child care.

headline: Honda Recalls 384,000 Vehicles Over a Familiar Problem
text: Honda is recalling an additional 384,000 2003-4 models after a National Highway Traffic Safety Administration investigation into whether two earlier recalls for the same problem covered all the defective vehicles.

headline: A New Life for 'Scott Pilgrim'
text: The director Edgar Wright discusses bringing Bryan Lee O'Malley's "Scott Pilgrim" comics to the screen. The film is now on DVD.

headline: Inexperienced Companies Chase U.S. School Funds
text: With the Obama administration pouring billions into its nationwide campaign to overhaul failing schools, dozens of companies with little or no experience are portraying themselves as school-turnaround experts as they compete for the money.

headline: Plum Benefit to Cultural Post: Tax-Free Housing
text: In addition to her $877,000 compensation package, Ellen V. Futter, president of the American Museum of Natural History, lives rent free in a $5 million East Side apartment that the museum bought when she came aboard.

headline: New Negro Riots Erupt on Coast; 3 Reported Shot
text: Los Angeles, Aug. 12 -- Fierce rioting again gripped the Negro section of south Los Angeles tonight. Officials called it the worst racial incident in the city's history.

headline: Alex Haley, 70, Author of 'Roots,' Dies
text: Alex Haley, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," which chronicled his ancestors' origins in Africa and their passage from slavery to freedom in America, died yesterday at Swedish Hospital Medical Center in Seattle. He was 70 years old and had homes in Knoxville, Tenn., Norris, Tenn., and Seattle.

headline: War Suspended, Peace Assured
text: Washington, Aug. 12 -- The plenipotentiaries of the United States and Spain having the afternoon at 4:23 o'clock signed the protocol defining the terms on which peace negotiations are to be carried on between the two countries, President McKinley has issued the following proclamation:

headline: Cecil De Mille, 77, Pioneer of Movies, Dead in Hollywood
text: HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21--Cecil B. De Mille died of a heart ailment today in his home on De Mille Drive here. He was 77 years old.

headline: What We’re Reading: The Children Will Be All Right, or Better
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: East German Troops Seal Border With West Berlin to Block Refugee Escape
text: Berlin, Sunday, Aug. 13- East Germany closed the border early today between East and West Berlin.

headline: Alfred Hitchcock Dies; A Master of Suspense
text: Alfred Hitchcock, whose mastery of suspense and of directing technique made him one of the most popular and celebrated of film makers, died yesterday at the age of 80 at his home in Los Angeles. Mr. Hitchcock, ailing with arthritis and kidney failures, had been in declining health for a year.

headline: Japan Surrenders, End of War!
text: Washington, Aug. 14 -- Japan today unconditionally surrendered the hemispheric empire taken by force and held almost intact for more than two years against the rising power of the United States and its Allies in the Pacific war.

headline: Dr. A. J. Dempster, Physicist, 63, Dead
text: CHICAGO, March 11--Dr. Arthur J. Dempster, Professor of Physics at the University of Chicago and discoverer of uranium 235, an essential element of the atomic bomb, died today of a heart attack in Stuart, Fla., where he was spending a vacation. He was 63 years old.

headline: Britain Reels as Austerity Cuts Begin
text: LONDON  Last month, the British government abolished the U.K. Film Council, the Health Protection Agency and dozens of other groups that regulate, advise and distribute money in the arts, health care, industry and other areas.

text: Whenever an official admits an error and apologizes, it has a healing effect.

text: 1:48 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Eric Pfanner provides more details of Skype’s initial public offering.

headline: Schoolteachers Driving Cadillacs
text: Jonathan Chait Cohn tells us that public-sector employees are the new welfare queens. Quite: any time you try to talk about the fiscal plight of state and local government, you get spittle-flecked denunciations of unions and their crazy pay packages.

headline: Two Grenades and a Death at the Gym
text: SANGIN, Afghanistan — The Royal Marines at Patrol Base Airport Lounge rarely see the Taliban, but they can see the Taliban’s flags. White, with writing on them, they fly over certain neighborhoods in the mud-brick sprawl beyond the patrol base’s gates.

text: Images from the day in sports, with Tiger Woods back on the practice tees and the Saints in Washington to meet the president.

headline: Yankees and Red Sox Pick Up the Pace
text: On Saturday afternoon, the unthinkable happened: the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox played a game under three hours.

headline: Rwandan Leader Heads to New Term Under Shadow of Repression
text: KIGALI, Rwanda  Rwanda’s president, Paul Kagame, who has been in control of this country since 1994 and helped resurrect it from genocide into one of the most orderly nations in Africa, appeared to have been re-elected on Monday by an overwhelming margin, according to incomplete election results released early Tuesday.

headline: The Bailout’s Latest Critics: Will Ferrell and Crew
text: Macall Polay/The Associated Press Will Ferrell (left) and Mark Wahlberg (right) escort a shady investor (Steve Coogan, center) in “The Other Guys.”

headline: Kazakh Director Plans Answer to ‘Borat’
text: Kazakhstan was furious when Sacha Baron Cohen’s mock documentary comedy “Borat” became a worldwide hit in 2006 but has apparently decided, somewhat belatedly, that if you can’t beat ’em, join ’em.

headline: Quote Unquote | No Shirt, No Dice
text: –Prince Albert II of Monaco asked a reporter who wore a bright pink polo to the Midsummer Garden Fete hosted by Louis Vuitton instead of “white with a floral accent,” as requested in the invitation. Next question: “why are you anywhere near me?”

headline: 9/11 Settlements Bring Moment of Reckoning
text: The letter arrived on July 29. Four years after he filed a lawsuit, James Carrano learned how much compensation he was likely to receive for the stomach and respiratory problems he has lived with since he toiled in a dust cloud after 9/11: $60,000 to $80,000.

headline: TimesCast | August 9, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, floods in Pakistan worsen and the government asks for U.S. aid, the travails of Tiger Woods and ugly animals and our perceptions of beauty.

headline: The End of the World As We Know It
text: That REM lyric has come to mind several times in recent days as the occasional friend or Dot Earth reader has described the spate of devastating floods, heat waves and fires, giant icebergs and other disruptive events as a sign that some momentous unraveling is beginning.

headline: The Early End of an Apocalyptic Mural
text: In the mural, an enormous red cloud heaved over a spindly Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. In the foreground, people abandoned their vehicles and ran for their lives, while, above them, others fell prey to flying glow-in-the-dark jellyfish.

headline: Products of the Pros: Index Funds
text: In this installment of a new feature at Bucks, where we ask personal finance experts in a particular area to share the  strategies they use in their own lives, we turn to Richard Ferri. He is the founder of low-cost investment adviser Portfolio Solutions and a proponent of investing in index funds.

headline: A Cool Vegetable for a Sizzling Summer
text: If it’s tomato season, it’s cucumber season, too  a time to think about light summer salads, garlicky chilled soups, even cooked cucumber dishes.

headline: Q. and A.: The 9/11 Adjuster
text: In recent weeks, rescue and cleanup workers who sued the city over health damages they attribute to environmental hazards at the former World Trade Center site have been receiving letters explaining how much compensation they would receive under a recent settlement of their claims.

headline: Halibut With Cucumbers and Dill
text: When I lived in France, I made this dish with sole, but Atlantic sole is no longer an eco-friendly choice. If you live in California and can get sand dabs, they make a good substitute, as does Pacific halibut.

headline: A Famine Looms in Niger
text: Shawn Baker is the regional director for Africa of Helen Keller International. He has spent 25 years living and working in Africa, including nine years in Niger.

headline: Do Noises Wake You Up at Night?
text: Why can some people sleep through noises like a honking car or flushing toilet, while others are awakened by the lightest sound?

headline: Resources: Plagiarism and Academic Integrity
