headline: Creamy Cucumber Salad
text: The authentic French version of this dish is made with fromage blanc, a smooth, fresh farmer cheese that tastes like a cross between cottage cheese and yogurt. In this version, I blend the two together. Use lots of pepper to season this simple combination.

headline: Cucumbers Vinaigrette
text: Cucumbers tossed with a vinaigrette can be ordinary, but if you slice the cucumbers paper-thin, the dish is memorable. I first ate cucumbers prepared this way on a balcony in Lake Como, Italy. It was my first day in Europe, on my first trip, and I was 15. The recollection is still vivid.

headline: Iranian Tomato and Cucumber Salad
text: This is adapted from a recipe in the Iranian cookbook “New Food of Life,” by Najmieh Batmanglij. The emphasis here is as much on fresh herbs as on tomatoes and cucumbers.

headline: ‘Entourage’ to End Next Summer
text: The HBO series “Entourage,” that network’s longest-running show, will end in the summer of 2011, after a shortened eighth season that will consist of six episodes. Addressing the Television Critics Association summer press tour, Michael Lombardo, HBO’s president for programming, said he hoped that a movie version follows the series but acknowledged that it depends on whether Doug Ellin, the program’s executive producer and head writer, thinks it “makes sense for the story” and characters.

headline: Riding the Wave on Houston’s Party Corridor
text: Houston’s newest form of shared transportation, the Washington Wave, is a welcome addition to the city’s expanding party corridor along Washington Avenue. Operating since November, this privately owned jitney service picks up within the Washington Avenue district, Midtown and the Heights ($5 for one way or $10 for all night), making it easier to barhop (and restaurant-hop) along Washington Avenue’s three-mile strip.

headline: Government Forces Fight Militants in Northeast Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Government forces in the semiautonomous Somali region of Puntland have made two military offensives against allies of the Shabab militant group, trying to drive back insurgent fighters who have been gaining ground in a comparatively stable area of northeastern Somalia.

headline: Google and Verizon Announce Net Neutrality Proposal
text: 4:09 p.m. | Updated  Our article on this news has been posted.

headline: Skype, Going Public, Hopes for $100 Million From First Offering
text: PARIS  Skype, the popular Internet telephone service, said Monday that it hoped to raise $100 million in an initial public offering of stock.

headline: Vodka Brand Goes Edgy as It Reaches Out to Women
text: The denizens of Madison Avenue may have consumed a lot of vodka back in the “Mad Men” era, but their modern-day counterparts have them beat when it comes to creating campaigns for vodka brands.

headline: Will Congress Ease 1099 Requirements in Health Care Bill?
text: In their last week of summer legislating, Republicans and Democrats alike — on both ends of Capitol Hill — made gestures toward repealing a new tax-reporting requirement, raising hopes among small-business advocates who have lobbied fiercely against the measure. But with each side claiming the other’s maneuvers are just feints, the prospects for repealing, or softening, the new law are uncertain at best.

headline: Who Says the Administration Isn’t Tough on Undocumented Immigrants?
text: My colleague Julia Preston has an article today about how the Obama administration is not deporting undocumented immigrants who are enrolled as students in American institutions.

headline: The Right Strategy for Satisfying Spending
text: Over the weekend, our colleague Stephanie Rosenbloom produced a wide-ranging look at the science of spending. It asked, in essence, why so many people spend so much money and derive so little happiness from it.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Samurai Shopper | The Sunny Side of the Street
text: “There are eight million stories in the naked city, and this has been one of them.” That’s the kicker to “Naked City,” a 1948 film noir shot in the most naked of places, New York. The Samurai Shopper silently utters that line after hearing hard-luck subway pitches, after sympathizing with friends or suffocating in the endless news loop of doom and gloom. I grow inured to the sheer volume and depth of public suffering, those eight million calamities waiting for me or anyone else to lend an ear, a hand, a shoulder, a few bucks.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: The board of governors of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, North Hollywood, Calif., will present Governors Awards to the Advertising Council, New York, and Norman Brokaw, chairman emeritus of WME. The winners will be honored during the 2010 Creative Arts Emmy Awards on Aug. 21, which will be shown as a two-hour special on E! on Aug. 27.

headline: Washington Web Site Focuses on Local News
text: Allbritton Communications started its local news Web site, TBD.com, on Monday, creating a multimedia platform for news in the Washington D.C. area that can draw on the work of two television stations, 127 local bloggers and community sites and a staff of producers, reporters and editors.

headline: Montoya Breaks Winless Streak at Watkins Glen
text: After falling short of winning the last two races, Juan Pablo Montoya finally ended a 113-race winless streak on Sunday by winning the Heluva Good! Sour Cream Dips at The Glen race at Watkins Glen, N.Y.

headline: An Easy Cam for Home Security
text: In the past, setting up a full-featured Webcam to monitor your home (or your kids and pets) remotely was too confounding for the average user, what with the tweaks needed to network and router settings. Worse, your efforts often yielded blurry, low-resolution video with unreliable availability.

headline: Video: A New Life for ‘Scott Pilgrim’
text: The British director Edgar Wright has made a name for himself in cult film circles with movies like the horror-comedy “Shaun of the Dead” and the action-comedy “Hot Fuzz.” Now he helms his first studio project, “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World.” Dave Itzkoff profiled him this week in Arts and Leisure, discussing whether his latest film, an adaptation of Bryan Lee O’Malley‘s comic books, could reach beyond his fan base. In the video above, Mr. Wright discusses bringing Mr. O’Malley’s artwork to life on the big screen and his stylistic influences for the adaptation.

headline: The Hand That Pushes the Baby’s Stroller Rules the Heart
text: The polestars in Mona Simpson’s fiction have been family and home: how the expectations and dreams of mothers and fathers and children imprint our lives, and how we can escape or transcend them through accident or will. How attachments to people and places, and feelings of safety and belonging create the idea of home.

headline: Some Deals Get the Summertime Blues
text: For those who have been more focused on the big business events over the summer, including most recently Marc V. Hurd’s messy departure from Hewlett-Packard, there have been several interesting events occurring under the radar.

headline: Iceberg as a Metaphor for Inaction
text: Last week a vast block of ice broke off from the Greenland ice sheet, creating the largest iceberg to form off the country in nearly 50 years.

headline: Ethics Panel Outlines Charges Against Waters
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Maxine Waters violated House rules by allowing her chief of staff to grant “special favors” to a struggling Massachusetts-based bank in which her husband owned stock, the House ethics committee charged in documents released Monday.

headline: Player’s Young Son Brightens Red Sox Clubhouse
text: The Boston Red Sox may have found their newest prospect.

headline: New Name for Hilton Theater
text: The Hilton Theater on 42nd Street, originally the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, has a new name — Foxwoods Theater. Live Nation, the concert and theater presenting company that operates the theater, and the Foxwoods Resort Casino, the Connecticut gambling and show center owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, announced the multiyear agreement on Monday but did not disclose financial arrangements. The agreement for exclusive naming rights means that the Foxwoods name will appear not only on the theater’s marquee and tickets but also in advertising to promote the troubled multimillion-dollar musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” which is bound for the theater. The show, which has as its lead producer Michael Cohl, a former chairman of Live Nation, begins rehearsals next week. The theater, which has been empty since January 2009 waiting for the much-delayed “Spider-Man” musical, was last home to “The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein.”

headline: JetBlue Flight Attendant Uses Emergency Slide to Escape Dispute
text: A fuller version of this article is here.

headline: Aid Groups in Afghanistan Vow to Stay
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Aid groups who have stayed in Afghanistan through years of incessant fighting vowed Monday to continue their work, even after the slaying of 10 foreign relief workers renewed concerns about their safety in the face of a revived Taliban insurgency.

headline: Amid Heat and Smoke, Deaths Double in Moscow
text: MOSCOW  The daily mortality rate here has nearly doubled in recent days, the city’s chief health official said Monday, singling out the heat as the primary factor and not the culprit most people here suspected: the choking cloud of wildfire smoke.

headline: Coalitionspeak
text: Policy terms preferred by Britain’s new coalition government.In a BBC radio clip titled “The new world of ‘coalitionspeak,'” Dr Nicholas Ostler and Alistair Beaton discussed the alternative terms Britain’s Con-Lib coalition has adopted to differentiate it from the previous administration.

headline: Cuomo Offers 150 Pages of Views on Energy
text: ALBANY — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo‘s campaign released its second policy book last week, this time focusing on energy.

headline: N.B.A. to Play 2 Regular-Season Games in London
text: The N.B.A. said Monday that the Nets and the Toronto Raptors would play two games in London in March, the first regular-season contests to be held in Europe.

headline: Burnett Expected to Start Tuesday
text: A.J. Burnett played catch with the pitching coach Dave Eiland before Monday’s game, and Manager Joe Girardi said he expected him to make his start Tuesday against the Texas Rangers.

headline: How I Bargain on Hotel Rates
text: Last week’s column provoked a number of comments about my practice of seeking discounts on hotel rooms. I thought it would be helpful to explain my strategy a bit further, since it clearly didn’t come across as I intended.

headline: The Claim: Smoking Relieves Stress
text: THE FACTS

headline: The Insider | Sang Yoon
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

headline: A Different Take on Lehman’s Executive Fees
text: On the Opinionator blog of The New York Times, William D. Cohan writes that he finds it distasteful that former Lehman Brothers executives are asking to have some of their legal fees paid for by the fallen bank’s estate.

headline: MTV Names Its First ‘T.J.’
text: From those wonderful people who brought you the V.J. comes the “T.J.,” with a little help from a sponsor.

headline: Revis Makes a New Pitch to Jets
text: There was news on the Darrelle Revis contract negotiations front on Monday afternoon. Whether that constitutes actual progress remains to be seen.

headline: Statistics: Who Visits the Emergency Room? 20 Percent of Americans, Insured or Not
text: Americans, insured and not, make ample use of hospital emergency rooms: One out of every five visited an E.R. at least once in 2007, the latest year for which the National Center for Health Statistics has data.

headline: Pettitte Encouraged by Throwing Sessions
text: Andy Pettitte threw 20 pitches in a bullpen session Monday as he continued to recover from a left groin muscle strain he sustained on July 18.

headline: Breakthrough Award for New Novelist
text: With the publication this week of his first novel, “Bill Warrington’s Last Chance,” James P. King, 55, is living the dream of every hopeful writer who persists at his work despite rejection slips from publishing houses and agents. After Mr. King, who lives in Wilton, Conn., won the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award, in which more than 6,500 writers from 22 countries competed, his novel, a road story in which an elderly veteran who is developing Alzheimer’s disease travels across the country with his rebellious 14-year-old granddaughter, was acquired by Viking. “This is what reading is about, and what a good book is supposed to do,” the mystery writer Sue Grafton writes in a blurb for the novel, Mr. King’s fourth attempt at fiction.

headline: My Phone Is Shouting at Me
text: My new smartphone is very smart indeed. And, frankly, a little insecure. It knows its own name, and it keeps shouting it at me to get my attention.

headline: Tech Savvy Moms, Setting Rules
text: Much has been said about the downside of technology. It isolates family members from each other emotionally and physically. It keeps kids glued to chairs instead of running around in the fresh air. It shortens attention spans. It puts kids at risk for danger online.

headline: Behavior: Internet Use Tied to Depression in Youths
text: A large Chinese study suggests that otherwise healthy teenagers are much more vulnerable to depression if they spend too much time on the Internet.

headline: 'Fast, Cheap and Out of Control'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Errol Morris's innovative 1997 documentary.

headline: Bennett Street, Staten Island, 12:17 P.M.
text: State Senator Rubén Díaz led a group, including the New York Hispanic Clergy Organization, in prayer during a protest march against a recent rash of hate crimes against immigrants in the Port Richmond neighborhood. The sign behind him reads: “From Jehovah come the earth, its plenty the world and all those who live in it.”

headline: A Record Number of Children Are Dying in Hot Cars
text: Despite awareness campaigns from child safety advocates and substantial media coverage, the number of children dying in hot vehicles has continued to rise.

headline: Hazards: Salmonella Is Traced to Dry Pet Food
text: Dozens of salmonella infections in toddlers have been traced to dry pet food, the first time human infections have been linked to dry dog and cat food, health officials say.

headline: Added Fees Make It Hard to Compare Old Air Fares With New
text: If you thought airline tickets have been getting more expensive, you are right. But how much more expensive is difficult to say.

headline: Arizona Prison Escapee Is Captured
text: MAMMOTH, Wyo.  It was the biggest news for the tiny town of Meeteetse since the black-footed ferret, once thought to be extinct, showed up there back in 1981. On Monday, one of two Arizona prison escapees was captured after a resident spotted him at a church the previous day and notified the police.

headline: The Rise of the Permabears
text: The central question dividing economists these days is whether Western governments should spend more to ward off a potential second recession or retrench to hold down their ballooning debts in a bid to restore confidence among investors, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. reports from London.

headline: Pentagon Plans Steps to Reduce Budget and Jobs
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that he would close a military command, restrict the use of outside contractors and reduce the number of generals and admirals across the armed forces as part of a broad effort to rein in Pentagon spending.

headline: Allman Brothers to Return to the Stage
text: Less than two months after getting a new liver, Gregg Allman is ready to work again.

headline: News Corp. Sells Stakes in TV Units in China
text: SHANGHAI  The News Corporation said Monday that it would sell a controlling stake in three Chinese television stations and a movie library to a private equity fund that was formed with the backing of the Chinese government.

headline: Washington National Opera and Kennedy Center Discussing Future
text: The Washington National Opera and officials of the Kennedy Center, where it performs, are discussing their long-term relationship, the company said Monday in response to news reports that it might be merged into the performing arts center. The opera said the talks are part of regular negotiations over its contract with the center, which expires in 2013.

headline: Anesthetic Said to Aid Depression
text: A new study suggests that a 50-year-old drug commonly used as an anesthetic for humans and animals — and abused, as the drug called Special K — may deliver almost instant relief in some of the most troublesome cases of bipolar depression.

headline: Web Plan From Google and Verizon Is Criticized
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google and Verizon on Monday introduced a proposal for how Internet service should be regulated  and were immediately criticized by groups that favor keeping the network as open as possible.

headline: Bullet That Killed Man in Harlem Was Probably Fired by Police
text: Updated, Tuesday, Aug. 10 | A full version of this story can be read here.

headline: That Middle-of-the-Night Bellyache: Appendicitis?
text: Let’s start with “Madeline.” In that classic children’s story by Ludwig Bemelmans, published in 1939, the little French girl of the title is awakened in the night by severe abdominal pain, and the doctor races to get her to the operating table.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Fast, Cheap and Out of Control’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Pick, A. O. Scott looks at the 1997 Errol Morris documentary “Fast, Cheap and Out of Control.” The film digs deep into uncommon jobs of four men: an animal trainer, a topiary gardener, a robot scientist and a mole-rat specialist. Mr. Scott praises Mr. Morris’s unique filmmaking, saying that the director has “turned the talking head documentary into a vehicle for artistic expression and philosophical inquiry.” Have you seen “Fast, Cheap and Out of Control” or any of Mr. Morris’s films? Please share your thoughts.

headline: Arabian Nights | Dar al Mamlouka
text: Starting Aug. 15, visitors to Damascus, Syria, will have a new stylish hotel to check into after a long day of strolling the souks. Dar al Mamlouka, located in the historic Christian quarter of Old Damascus, is a 17th-century Ottoman-style palace that has been converted into a lush retreat by the owners of Beit al Mamlouka, the first Oriental-style boutique hotel in the area. Built around a tranquil central courtyard with wisterias, lemon trees and a fountain, it offers 10 luxuriously decorated rooms. Each room celebrates a particular figure from Arab history — from poets to warriors — in the ornate Damascene style, with plenty of inlaid mother-of-pearl woodwork, colorful mosaics and Persian rugs.

headline: Ugly Animals
text: Examples of animals few would choose as wallpaper for a Web browser.

headline: In Spinal-Fluid Test, an Early Warning on Alzheimer’s
text: Researchers report that a spinal fluid test can be 100 percent accurate in in identifying a signature level of abnormal proteins in patients with significant memory loss who went on to develop Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Battlegrounds in 6 States in Midwest
text: Who occupies the statehouse in a swath of states near the Great Lakes could prove crucial in the 2012 presidential campaign. A primer to some races to watch:

headline: With 2012 in Mind, Parties Focus on Governorships
text: CHICAGO  For all the talk of midterm elections and control of Congress, the political parties are obsessing this year more than ever over the nation’s 37 races for governor.

headline: ‘Entourage’ to End Next Summer
text: The HBO series “Entourage,” that network’s longest-running show, will end next summer after a shortened eighth season that will consist of six episodes. Addressing the Television Critics Association summer press tour, Michael Lombardo, HBO’s president for programming, said he hoped a movie version follows the series, whose stars include, from left Jerry Ferrara, Jeremy Piven, Adrian Grenier, Kevin Connolly and Kevin Dillon, but acknowledged that that depends on whether Doug Ellin, the program’s executive producer and head writer, thinks it “makes sense for the story” and characters. “We have a long-term relationship with Doug Ellin, and I’m sure you’ll soon see another series from him here,” Mr. Lombardo told the critics. “But next summer will definitely be the final season for ‘Entourage.’ ”

headline: Bolshoi Theater Names New Musical Director
text: The Bolshoi Theater, in flux since the end of the Soviet Union, has named a new musical director, according to the Interfax news agency. The composer Vassily Sinaisky, who has served as musical director and chief conductor of the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra and the Russian Symphony Orchestra, will replace Leonid Desyatnikov. Mr. Desyatnikov, who was appointed to the post last September, said from the beginning that he would spend only “an interlude” in the job, but had a contract that was to run through the end of next year. Mr. Sinaisky, 63, a graduate of the St. Petersburg Conservatory, has worked extensively as a guest conductor outside Russia, including for operas in San Francisco and Berlin and the BBC Philharmonic Orchestra.

headline: Vampires Rule at Teen Choice Awards
text: To the surprise of no one, movies and television shows about vampires dominated the annual Teen Choice Awards on Sunday in Los Angeles. “The Twilight Saga” film series walked away with a dozen awards, including those for villain and fantasy movie, and CW’s “Vampire Diaries” won seven in the television category. Voting online, youthful fans gave the actor Robert Pattinson, above, star of the ‘Twilight’ films, four awards, one of which was for a non-Twilight performance, in the drama “Remember Me.” In the music categories, Taylor Swift and Justin Bieber also won four awards each.

headline: Kazakh Director Plans Answer To ‘Borat’
text: Kazakhstan was furious when Sacha Baron Cohen’s mock documentary comedy “Borat” became a worldwide hit in 2006, but has apparently decided, somewhat belatedly, that if you can’t beat ’em, join ’em. Erkin Rakishev, a Kazakh director, has announced that he will soon begin shooting “My Brother, Borat,” as part of an effort to counter negative stereotypes about that oil-rich Central Asian country. In the new story an American fan of Mr. Cohen’s movie, which is banned in Kazakhstan, travels there and finds a prosperous and modern state. “We want to ride on the wave of success of Borat, to take advantage of this popular image in the West to show people the real Kazakhstan,” Mr. Rakishev told Kazakhstanskaya Pravda.

headline: Waist Size Linked With Longevity
text: Even if you don’t need to watch your weight, you still need to watch your waist.

headline: Breakthrough Award For New Novelist
text: With the publication this week of his first novel, “Bill Warrington’s Last Chance,” James P. King, 55, is living the dream of every hopeful writer who persists at his work despite rejection slips from publishing houses and agents. After Mr. King, who lives in Wilton, Conn., won the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award, in which more than 6,500 writers from 22 countries competed, Viking acquired his novel, a road story in which an elderly veteran who is developing Alzheimer’s disease travels across the country with his rebellious 14-year-old granddaughter. “This is what reading is about, and what a good book is supposed to do,” the mystery writer Sue Grafton writes in a blurb for the novel, Mr. King’s fourth attempt at fiction.

headline: Critics Blast Stricter Homeless Rules
text: Advocates for the homeless on Monday said they would seek to reverse an effort by the Bloomberg administration to make it harder for homeless families to qualify for a generous rent-subsidy program.

headline: Repertorio Español Season Announced
text: An adaptation of the Julia Alvarez novel “In the Time of the Butterfly” heads the 2010-11 season that Repertorio Español, New York’s main Spanish-language theater company, announced on Monday. The production will bring together the dramatist Caridad Svich and the director José Zayas, the same team that collaborated on a well-received version of Isabel Allende’s “House of the Spirits” in 2009. In addition to the adaptation of the Alvarez novel, about real-life sisters who ran afoul of the Trujillo dictatorship in the Dominican Republic in the 1950s, the ensemble will also be adding to its permanent repertory “Way to Heaven,” a drama by Juan Mayorga, one of the most distinguished younger Spanish playwrights.

headline: Football Fuels Victory For NBC
text: After a monthslong off-season, the return of football to Sunday night television helped lift NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on the night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, NBC’s broadcast of the N.F.L.’s annual “Hall of Fame” game delivered football’s best preliminary overnight ratings numbers in six years, finishing 30 percent better than last year’s first preseason game, which drew 7.9 million viewers when final ratings were released. CBS ranked second on the night, leading during the early part of prime time with “60 Minutes” at 7 p.m. (9.3 million) and posting the largest audience of the summer for “Big Brother” at 8 (7.5 million). From 9 to 11, CBS broadcast lower-rated reruns of “Undercover Boss” (6.2 million) and “The Good Wife” (4 million). ABC was third, garnering few viewers for “Scoundrels” at 9 (3.3 million) and “The Gates” at 10 (2.6 million), while Fox finished in fourth place with reruns of its comedy lineup.

headline: Hilton Theater Is Now Foxwoods Theater
text: The Hilton Theater on West 42nd Street, originally the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, has a new name  Foxwoods Theater. Live Nation, the concert and theater presenting company that operates the theater, and the Foxwoods Resort Casino, the Connecticut gambling and show center owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, announced a multiyear agreement on Monday but did not disclose financial arrangements. The agreement for exclusive naming rights means the Foxwoods name will appear not only on the theater’s marquee and tickets but also in advertising to promote the troubled multimilliondollar musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” which is bound for the theater. The show, which has as its lead producer Michael Cohl, a former chairman of Live Nation, begins rehearsals next week. The theater, which has been empty since January 2009 waiting for the much-delayed “Spider-Man” musical, was last home to “The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein.”

headline: Glimmerglass Recycles Its Sets, Not Its Ideas
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — It’s hard not to think of the current Glimmerglass Opera season as something of a footnote, though that is patently unfair to the artists doing consistently solid and frequently inspired work here this summer. In February came the news that the general and artistic director, Michael MacLeod, would be leaving at the end of the current season. With the impending arrival of Francesca Zambello, the seasoned opera and musical theater director who will take over in September, comes the promise of fresh energy and change that extends even to the name of this venerable organization. Next year it becomes the Glimmerglass Festival.

headline: Is That a Shoe on Your Head or Have You Been Styled?
text: “Hair Battle Spectacular,” a series beginning Tuesday on Oxygen, feels like the harbinger of something: if not the end of a thinking society and a decent pageboy, than at least the last stand of second-tier reality competition shows presided over by nobody hosts who make lame exit declamations. “Hair Battle Spectacular” is the coffin in which all similar ideas scheduled for future broadcast ought to be buried, no exhuming permitted.

headline: Bush to Make Another Trip to Haiti
text: Former President George W. Bush is scheduled to travel to Haiti on Tuesday to assess the country’s recovery from the devastating earthquake in January that displaced 1.5 million people and left an estimated 300,000 dead.

headline: A Masterpiece of Nature? Yuck!
text: A friend recently sent around an e-mail with the subject line “lost cat bulletin.” Open the message and — gack! — there was a head-on shot of a star-nosed mole, its “Dawn of the Dead” digging claws in full view and its hallmark nasal boutonniere of 22 highly sensitive feelers looking like fresh bits of sirloin being extruded through a meat grinder.

headline: Merrill’s Risk Disclosure Dodges Are Unearthed
text: It was named after a faint constellation in the southern sky: Pyxis, the Mariner’s Compass. But it helped to steer the mighty Merrill Lynch toward disaster.

headline: The Standby Star Who Stole Broadway’s Limelight
text: Iva Withers, 93, tapped her cane on the hardwood floor of her neat West 55th Street apartment with the ferocity of a dance instructor. She was about to describe a bit of Broadway musical history: the afternoon and night when she played the leads in what are now two classics.

headline: Lady Gaga Has a Told-You-So Moment
text: CHICAGO  If you’re Lady Gaga, you have lots of ways to quantify your success. Your two albums have sold nearly five million copies combined in an era of chronically low sales. MTV has nominated you for more Video Music Awards in one year than it has any other artist. You have more Facebook fans than any public figure except Michael Jackson.

headline: A Bit of Broadway History
text: At home with the 93-year-old actress Iva Withers.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gansu Province and Elsewhere
text: A landslide buried and flooded hundreds of homes over the weekend in a remote mountainous region of Gansu Province in China, Michael Wines reported. Officials said Sunday evening that 127 bodies had been recovered and that nearly 2,000 people were missing. Torrential rains began to fall on Saturday, a local official said. “Then there were landslides, and many people were trapped,” he said. “Now sludge has become the biggest hindrance to our operations. It’s too thick to walk or drive through.”

headline: Oracle Chief Faults H.P. Board for Forcing Hurd Out
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, denounced Hewlett-Packard’s directors on Monday for forcing the resignation of the H.P. chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, who is a friend of Mr. Ellison’s.

headline: Now Spinning | Victoria Aitken’s ‘Sunshine’
text: Victoria Aitken, the New York and London-based socialite songstress, has teamed up with the Scumfrog, a New York-based D.J., on her recent single “Sunshine,” which is currently No. 7 on the British dance charts. The light-spirited house track was inspired by a Latin loffer she met on holiday in Spain. “He was very charming, funny and interesting,” she says. “The only problem was that others thought so too, and they were girls who dressed up to the nines in diamonds and couture.” According to Aitken, the song is also a hit with her father, Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former Tory cabinet minister. (Dad wasn’t a big fan of her last video, “I’ll Be Your Bitch,” in which she danced suggestively while brandishing a whip and in preparation for which she took pole-dancing classes.) The jury is still out on whether Victoria is a card-carrying blue blood — Dutch newspaper reports earlier this year claimed that her grandmother, Lady Penelope Aitken, was the longtime girlfriend of Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands (husband of Queen Juliana) — but one thing is certain: The Scumfrog’s kiss has turned this sassy singer into a bona fide dance-floor princess. Her latest song, “Sexy Skirt,” just entered the charts at No. 34. To listen to “Sunshine” and “Sexy Skirt” go to myspace.com/victoriaaitken.

headline: K.K.R. Withdraws Stock Offering
text: 8:26 p.m. | Updated Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity giant now listed on the New York Stock Exchange, said that it was withdrawing a planned $500 million stock offering and reported a 29 percent drop in earnings for its second quarter.

headline: Is This Rehab or an Exorcism?
text: HARTFORD — The horrors are stacked to the heavens in Matthew Lombardo’s play “High” at Hartford TheaterWorks. The grisly list of crimes described in this dark drama about addiction and victimization includes rape, murder, child molestation and child prostitution.

headline: Stroke Patients Discontinue Medications
text: Within three months of being hospitalized for an acute stroke, nearly one-quarter of patients stop taking at least one of the drugs prescribed by their doctors to prevent further cardiovascular problems, according to a study published on Monday afternoon in the medical journal Archives of Neurology.

headline: Inspired by Flying, and Inspiring Others
text: I’VE loved airplanes ever since I was a child. In fact, my mom took me to my first air show when I was just a baby. She said I loved it.

headline: Showcasing Durability in a Soft Economy
text: RIPPING up the merchandise is not typically the first approach a company uses to promote its brand. But Dickies, the longtime maker of work wear, does just that in a new advertising campaign in which two motorcyclists, revving their engines, strain to tear apart a pair of its “Original 874” work pants that are suspended between them.

headline: For ‘Fighter,’ a Long Count Before Release
text: LOS ANGELES  Take a cast full of past Oscar nominees like Amy Adams and Melissa Leo, working for almost no pay in return for a piece of the future action. Throw in outside financing, a classic underdog story and a director with cachet, David O. Russell.

headline: Cheney Released From Hospital
text: Former Vice President Dick Cheney has been released from the hospital after doctors implanted a pump last month to help his heart.

headline: Matthew Simmons, Noted Energy Banker, Dies at 67
text: The death of Matthew R. Simmons, the founder of Simmons & Company International, a boutique energy investment bank, has stunned the tight-knit energy banking community.

headline: Now Screening | Quando, Quando Quando
text: Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce are the latest fashion designers to make the foray into filmmaking. The designing duo’s first feature length film, “Quando, Quando, Quando” comes out in September. The film’s preview shows a lace-clad, pump-wearing woman exploring the Trevi fountain in Rome as lecherous local men of all ages ogle her, gesticulating dramatically. The melodramatic soundtrack, R-rating and black and white cinematography could either add up to cinematic genius or fashion fluff. Tune in in September to find out which.

headline: Treatments: Drug Schedule Improves Survival Rate of Those With AIDS and Tuberculosis
text: People who are near death from a combination of tuberculosis and AIDS are more likely to survive if they get immediate TB treatment, followed two weeks later by antiretroviral drugs for AIDS, doctors are reporting.

headline: Red Sox Let Yankees Know Race Is Still On
text: It took until their last meeting of a four-game series, but the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox finally put together the sort of tense, postseason-worthy affair that they have made a regular summertime occurrence for the better part of the decade.

headline: The Drawing Center to Stay in SoHo
text: 6:01 p.m. | Updated After years of looking for a new downtown home, the Drawing Center has decided to stay put in its SoHo neighborhood. “The economy made us re-evaluate what scale of project we want,” said Brett Littman, the Drawing Center’s director, in an interview on Monday. “We’re like a nice small jazz club — the scale of what we do is intimate, drawings tend to be pretty small. The board leadership and myself have come to the conclusion that maybe the Drawing Center shouldn’t be 30,000 square feet. It’s not in the cards for us.” The move was first reported by Crain’s NY Business.

headline: Scoliosis Test Lets Children Avoid a Brace
text: For her 12th birthday in February, Marissa Levy of Oceanside, N.Y., received an unusual gift: a test that told her spine doctor she could give up her body brace.

headline: In a Video Game, Tackling the Complexities of Protein Folding
text: Gamers 1, computer 0.

headline: Where Millions Need Care, Starting With One
text: At dawn, an old woman in a bright but tattered dress picked her way along a muddy, trash-strewn path. She stopped at a pile of garbage and carefully removed the remains of a dirty onion. Then she sat and slowly began to eat it for breakfast.

headline: Hands-On Reassembly in Stripped-Down Gallery
text: There is much for New York art institutions of all sizes to learn from the extreme makeover lately visited upon Artists Space, the small and venerable, if long-moribund, pioneer of the downtown alternative art scene. Basically the place has been literally and spiritually swept clean by the new broom of Stefan Kalmár, the German-born former director of the Munich Kunstverein, who took over as executive director and chief curator in June 2009.

headline: Water Safety
text: Q. I’ve been saving gallons of water in unopened plastic jugs since 9/11. Does the water go bad for drinking and cooking?

headline: Merrill’s Downfall Provides a Disclosure Lesson
text: It was named after a faint constellation in the southern sky: Pyxis, the Mariner’s Compass. But it helped to steer the mighty Merrill Lynch toward disaster, The New York Times’s Louise Story reports.

headline: Where Anglers Rear Back and Let It Fly
text: LEXINGTON, Ky.  If one is aiming to make the longest cast with a fly rod in American history, the best attempts to make the record book are usually the first two casts.

headline: Share Your ‘Last Straw’ Stories
text: Updated, 4:00 p.m., Aug. 13 | The fracas on Monday aboard a JetBlue plane at Kennedy International Airport has us thinking at City Room — and wanting to hear from you.

headline: Water on Moon Unlikely, a New Study Indicates
text: In the long discussion of water on the Moon, a new study contradicts some recent reports that say the Moon had water at the time of its formation. A group of researchers reports in the journal Science that when the Moon was created, some 4.5 billion years ago, there was not much hydrogen on it, and therefore no water.

headline: Building a Framework to Read Animal Emotion
text: Pet owners might like to think they can judge the moods of their cats or dogs with ease, but finding true scientific methods to evaluate animal emotion is difficult.

headline: Crocodile Fossil Reveals Teeth of a Mammal
text: Modern crocodiles have conical teeth they use to grab at prey. Sometime the crocodiles rip off pieces of flesh from their prey, and sometimes they swallow their victims whole. They do not, however, chew their food, as humans and many other mammals do.

headline: Hezbollah Says Israel Took Part in Assassination
text: BEIRUT  In a two-hour long television appearance, Hezbollah’s leader, Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, offered Monday what he contended was evidence proving Israel’s involvement in the assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, in a 2005 bombing.

headline: Oracle Chief Faults H.P. Board for Forcing Hurd Out
text: Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, denounced Hewlett-Packard’s directors on Monday for forcing the resignation of the H.P. chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, who is a friend of Mr. Ellison’s, The New York Times’s Ashlee Vance reports from San Francisco.

headline: Is It Really Appendicitis?
text: In today’s “18 and Under” column, pediatrician Dr. Perri Klass explores the murky world of appendicitis. As often as 20 percent of the time, an operation to remove an appendix turns out to be unnecessary. (It’s called a “negative appendectomy, she explains.) But while new CT scans can improve diagnostic ability, it also exposes a child to radiation. Dr. Klass writes:

headline: For Travel Industry, Things Are Looking Up
text: HOUSTON

headline: Lessons From a Wounded ‘Star Pupil’
text: It was hard to look at her bruised and lacerated legs, but she insisted on showing me how her own limbs had become the enemy. At age 22, Sue was paralyzed from the waist down, unable to feel any sensation in her legs.

headline: Smokers Have More Stress
text: Smokers often reach for a cigarette to calm their nerves, but new research suggests that smoking is actually a source of a stress, according to today’s “Really?” column.

headline: New Jersey Halts Oyster Restoration Project
text: KEYPORT, N.J.  A decade of efforts to restore marine life to the polluted Raritan Bay suffered a serious setback on Monday when, under orders from the state, an environmental group pulled up the oysters it had cultivated there.

headline: David F. Dixon, Force Behind Saints and Superdome, Dies at 87
text: David F. Dixon, a New Orleans businessman who played a leading role in the founding of the National Football League’s Saints and the construction of the Louisiana Superdome, died Sunday at his home in New Orleans. He was 87.

headline: Fed Will Meet With Concerns on Deflation Rising
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve will meet on Tuesday faced with a pivotal decision about whether to abandon its presumption that the economy is gradually picking up steam and begin to consider new steps to keep the recovery from sputtering out.

headline: The Caucus With Reshma Saujani
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC interviewed Reshma Saujani, a Democratic candidate for New York's 14th Congressional District.

headline: Diet: Low-Fat vs. Atkins: Parallel Results
text: One of the longest trials to pit low-fat diets against Atkins-style diets found that participants lost the same amount of weight after two years, regardless of which diet they were on, though the Atkins dieters had greater increases in HDL, or “good” cholesterol. Previous studies have shown mixed results.

headline: Shea Gallante to Open Ciano This Fall
text: Shea Gallante, who has had a little trouble finding his niche since stepping down as chef of Cru about a year ago, has now found a place of his own. Teaming up with the restaurateur Stratis Morfogen, he will open Ciano this fall. The Italian restaurant, named for a Tuscan village, takes over the space at 45 East 22nd Street once occupied by Cesare Casella’s Beppe. It already has a Tuscan look, which the owners intend to enhance. Mr. Gallante even plans to bake hearth breads in the fireplace.

headline: DNA Test May Speed Colon Cancer Diagnosis
text: A new generation of DNA tests for colon cancer seems likely to improve the detection both of cancers and of the precancerous polyps that precede them. The tests, if validated, could reduce the burden of disease substantially by detecting tumors at an early stage, including those not picked up by a colonoscopy.

headline: A Key for Opening Stunted Egg Cells to Fertilization
text: For years, reproductive biologists were stymied by a mystery of egg cell development: What are the signals that tell immature egg cells  “primordial follicles”  to develop into mature eggs that can be fertilized?

headline: Via Listserv, Parents Clash in Harlem
text: Need a bouncy seat? Or a playgroup? Let me direct you to the Harlem4Kids.com listserv, a chatty resource that has been in place since 2006, building a community of parents and directing them to neighborhood resources like martial-arts classes and midwives.

headline: An Interview With Reshma Saujani
text: Reshma Saujani, a hedge fund lawyer and a Democratic candidate in the race for New York’s 14 Congressional District, sat down with John Harwood of  The New York Times and CNBC on Monday to discuss why she’s challenging Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a veteran incumbent, in next month’s Democratic primary.

headline: Canola, Pushed by Genetics, Moves Into Uncharted Territories
text: Genetically engineered versions of the canola plant are flourishing in the form of roadside weeds in North Dakota, scientists say, in one of the first instances of a genetically modified crop establishing itself in the wild.

headline: Butter Holds the Secret to the Latest Biodiesel Fuel
text: Butter is not the fuel of the future, but it is possible to churn perfectly good diesel fuel out of it.

headline: A Heart Pump Ticks Down, and a Stranger Steps In to Help
text: Christian Volpe was shopping with his wife when an alarm started beeping to warn that only 15 minutes of battery power were left on the implanted heart pump that was keeping him alive.

headline: Economic Pessimists Gain Cachet
text: LONDON  The central question dividing economists these days is whether Western governments should spend more to ward off a potential second recession or retrench to hold down their ballooning debts to restore confidence among investors.

headline: Arkansas: Doctor Found Guilty in Bomb Attack
text: A federal jury on Monday convicted a physician of conspiring to detonate a car bomb that badly injured the state medical board chairman. Dr. Randeep Mann faces the possibility of life in prison in the February 2009 bombing in West Memphis, Ark., which left the board chairman, Dr. Trent P. Pierce, badly scarred and partly blind. Prosecutors said the bombing was in retaliation after the board twice sanctioned Dr. Mann for overprescribing pain medication. Dr. Mann’s wife, Sangeeta, was convicted of conspiring to conceal evidence. Prosecutors say that they do not believe the Manns planted the bomb, but that Dr. Mann ordered an unknown person to do so.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,201 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: Excitement and Uncertainty After McNabb
text: The starting quarterback of the Philadelphia Eagles scooped a low shotgun snap from the grass, read the defense and fired a short pass along the right sideline to an open receiver. The pass was also low, but the receiver dropped to one knee, snagged the ball, and turned up the sideline for a long gain.

headline: Paul Milstein, City Real Estate Titan, Dies at 88
text: Paul Milstein, who used profits from the family flooring business to build a real estate empire in New York City, distinguished by major projects begun in uncertain neighborhoods and totaling 50,000 apartments, 8,000 hotel rooms and 20 million square feet of office space, died on Monday at his Manhattan home. He was 88.

headline: Mercury Limits Are Set for Cement Plants
text: The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday set the first limits for mercury emissions from cement factories. The rules will cut mercury emissions and particulate matter 92 percent a year starting in 2013, the agency said. Manufacture of Portland cement, the type most widely used, is the third-biggest source of mercury air pollution in the country, the agency. said. Mercury, which can harm childhood development of the brain and is linked to asthma, heart attacks and premature deaths, is released when cement components are heated in a kiln, according to agency documents. The E.P.A. estimated that the rules would yield $6.7 billion to $18 billion in environmental and health benefits and cost companies as much as $950 million a year.

headline: Maybe Bradley Should Make the First Move
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Arbitrator Rejects Kovalchuk’s Deal
text: Ilya Kovalchuk, the potent 27-year-old wing who thought only three weeks ago that he would play the rest of his career for the Devils, became an unrestricted free agent again Monday when an arbitrator agreed with the N.H.L. that his contract circumvented the league’s salary cap.

headline: Fatal Bullet in Harlem Probably Fired by Police
text: The bullet that killed a man early Sunday after a crowded Harlem party came from a semiautomatic weapon, ballistics tests have revealed, indicating that it was probably fired by one of four police officers who discharged 46 rounds after gunfire broke out.

headline: Skype I.P.O. Could Help Out Silicon Valley
text: Skype’s initial public offering may add a dose of healthy hype to Silicon Valley. The Internet telephone group’s $100 million float should be red hot. While there have been several tech offerings this year, investor reception has been uneven. A bit of justified excitement over Skype’s growth and its backers’ gains is just what the Valley’s capitalists — and entrepreneurs — need.

headline: Secretary General Defends Appointment of Corruption Official
text: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said on Monday that accusations by former officials that he had sought to subvert the independence of corruption investigations at the organization by appointing the body’s senior investigator were “unfair.” Responding publicly for the first time, Mr. Ban insisted that he had the right to make all senior appointments. He also said, “I’m the secretary general of the United Nations, dealing with so many global issues. Let us look at the broader picture.”

headline: Committed to Family, Dedicated to Basketball
text: The bruises come with Taj McWilliams-Franklin’s territory in the low post. More painful are the wounds opened by e-mails like the one from her husband saying a kindergarten classmate had punched their daughter in the nose and threatened to kill her.

headline: China Seizes on a Dark Chapter for Tibet
text: GYANTSE, Tibet — The white fortress loomed above the fields, a crumbling but still imposing redoubt perched on a rock mound above a plain of golden rapeseed shimmering in the morning light.

headline: For G.M., a Subprime Solution
text: There goes the General Motors pre-I.P.O. roadshow.

headline: Pre-Med Curriculums

text: To the Editor:

headline: Thomas’s Knicks Job Raises Questions
text: The announcement that Isiah Thomas will work as a consultant for the Knicks while still serving as the men’s basketball coach at Florida International University has raised questions among critics who worry that it smudges the line between professional and amateur sports.

headline: Plagiarism Is Not a Big Moral Deal
text: During my tenure as the dean of a college, I determined that an underperforming program should be closed. My wife asked me if I had ever set foot on the premises, and when I answered “no,” she said that I really should do that before wielding the axe.

headline: Hewlett Took a P.R. Firm’s Advice in the Hurd Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As the career of Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive Mark V. Hurd hung in the balance, a public relations specialist convinced the company’s directors that H.P. would endure months of humiliation if accusations of sexual harassment by a company contractor against Mr. Hurd became public.

headline: Guilty Plea Expected in Drunken-Driving Crash That Killed 11-Year-Old Girl
text: A Bronx woman is expected to plead guilty to manslaughter on Tuesday in the death of an 11-year-old girl who was killed when the woman drove drunk and crashed on the Henry Hudson Parkway in Manhattan.

headline: Fighting the Drug Cartels
text: To the Editor:

headline: Palin Dismisses Reports of Eye Rolling
text: Sarah Palin is criticizing news reports that she appeared to roll her eyes during a spirited videotaped conversation with an Alaska woman.

headline: 0.144 Leagues Under the Sea
text: Sunday, Aug. 8

headline: For Federer, His Ranking and His Age Are Nothing but Numbers
text: TORONTO  Roger Federer arrived at the Rogers Cup under unfamiliar circumstances. It marked his first tournament since Wimbledon, since turning 29, since hiring Paul Annacone as his new coach. This is also the first tournament since November 2003 in which Federer entered as the third seed. But Federer disagreed Monday with the notion of his imminent decline.

headline: Portugal Gives Itself a Clean-Energy Makeover
text: LISBON  Five years ago, the leaders of this sun-scorched, wind-swept nation made a bet: To reduce Portugal’s dependence on imported fossil fuels, they embarked on an array of ambitious renewable energy projects  primarily harnessing the country’s wind and hydropower, but also its sunlight and ocean waves.

headline: Fed-Up Flight Attendant Makes Sliding Exit
text: It has been a long time since flight attendant was a glamorous job title. The hours are long. Passengers with feelings of entitlement bump up against new no-frills policies. Babies scream. Security precautions grate but must be enforced. Airlines demand lightning-quick turnarounds, so attendants herd passengers and collect trash with the grim speed of an Indy pit crew. Everyone, it seems, is in a bad mood.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Health Exchanges
text: To the Editor:

headline: Talk vs. Real Talk (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Schools Are Given a Grade on How Graduates Do
text: Hunching over her notebook at Borough of Manhattan Community College, Sharasha Croslen struggled to figure out what to do with the algebra problem in front of her: x2 + 2x – 8 = 0.

headline: We’re All Marriage Ideologues
text: A few weeks ago, Noah Millman had an interesting post explaining why he had temporarily opposed gay marriage in the early 2000s, and why he ultimately changed his mind and now supports it again. His brief opposition, he wrote, was rooted in an attempt to embrace what he called “the ideology of marriage,” in the hopes that it would provide grounding and support during some of his own private marital difficulties. Here’s his sketch of this ideology, which he sees as an attempt to provide some kind of rationale for modern marriage that doesn’t just depend on the fickleness of eros:
