headline: Petraeus Scheduled to Start Spate of Media Interviews
text: WASHINGTON  Gen. David H. Petraeus has largely stayed out of the public spotlight since he took command of the military operation in Afghanistan on July 4 and began conducting a countrywide assessment. But that is about to change.

headline: Jerry Flint, Longtime Auto Journalist, Dies at 79
text: Jerry Flint, a nationally known automotive writer whose career began in the glory days of Bel Airs and Thunderbirds and ended in the Prius age, died on Saturday in Hudson, N.Y. He was 79.

headline: Nets and Raptors Will Play Pair of Games in London
text: The N.B.A. said the Nets and the Toronto Raptors would play two games in London in March, the first regular-season contests to be held in Europe.

headline: Jets’ Owner Pessimistic About Revis for Opener
text: Revis Island was vacant again Monday. The most ominous statement in Darrelle Revis’s nine-day holdout came from the Jets’ owner, Woody Johnson, who said he was not optimistic a deal could be reached before the season started, before adding, “My impression is no progress.”

headline: U.N. Chief Recommends Small Steps on Climate
text: UNITED NATIONS  Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said Monday that he doubted that member states would reach a new global climate change agreement in December at a conference in Mexico.

headline: Unusual Alliance Protests Execution
text: CINCINNATI  An unlikely array of Republicans and Democrats, attorneys general and federal and state judges and prosecutors has lined up to fight the execution of a death row inmate many believe to be innocent.

headline: Haiti: 33 File for Presidential Race
text: Wyclef Jean, the hip-hop performer, is not the only one who wants to be the next president of Haiti. With the registration now closed, Haiti has 33 other potential candidates, among them Mr. Jean’s uncle, Raymond Joseph, Haiti’s ambassador to the United States. Haiti’s electoral council is scheduled to issue the official list of candidates next Tuesday after determining the aspirants’ eligibility. Other candidates include: Mirlande Manigat, a former first lady and university administrator; Yvon Neptune and Jacques-Édouard Alexis, both former prime ministers; and Leslie Voltaire, Haiti’s special envoy to the United Nations and an architect active in reconstruction planning.

headline: A Shared Sense of Purpose
text: A closer look at the 10 medical workers who were killed in Afghanistan last Thursday.

headline: Slumdog Tourism
text: Nairobi, Kenya

headline: Confounding Hire Adds to Garden’s Image Problem
text: The byzantine, often inexplicable politics that guide Madison Square Garden produced last Friday’s announcement that Isiah Thomas, the Knicks’ disgraced former coach and president, was returning to consult.

headline: Pay Practices in Health Care Are Investigated
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is investigating pay practices throughout the health care industry after finding that many hospitals and nursing homes do not pay proper overtime to nurses and other employees who work more than 40 hours a week.

headline: Tuesday: Jersey Greeting?
text: PUZZLE NOTES — This is a cool idea that takes a word ladder and weaves it into a larger theme, all presented in elegant symmetry.

headline: Texting With Terrorists
text: WHEN the United Arab Emirates announced last week that it would suspend BlackBerry service within its borders starting this fall, business travelers who rely on the handheld devices reacted with understandable dismay. But the decision was greeted quite differently by the men and women who make a living hunting terrorists, smugglers, human traffickers, foreign agents and the occasional team of clumsy assassins. Among law enforcement investigators and intelligence officers, the Emirates’ decision met with approval, admiration and perhaps even a touch of envy.

headline: Defaults Fail to Scare Suitors for 2 East Side Complexes
text: Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling Manhattan apartment complexes headed for foreclosure after a record-setting $5.4 billion sale in 2006, still have an allure for some developers, investors and speculators.

headline: Slain Aid Workers Were Bound by Their Sacrifice
text: Their devotion was perhaps most evident in what they gave up to carry out their mission: Dr. Thomas L. Grams, 51, left a thriving dental practice; Dr. Karen Woo, 36, walked away from a surgeon’s salary; Cheryl Beckett, 32, had no time for courtship or marriage.

headline: Petraeus Begins a New Campaign With Words
text: General David Petraeus will start a public relations campaign  in which he is expected to cite examples of initial progress on the ground in Afghanistan and underscore that the full impact of the military’s counterinsurgency strategy will not take hold until the last of 30,000 additional American troops arrive in Afghanistan this month.

headline: A Sanctuary for Women, Even Today
text: LOS ANGELES — Of all the clichés about this town that are provably untrue — no one reads, or has the lips that God gave them — it is undeniable that Los Angeles has often been a poor guardian of its physical history. Scores of historical buildings have been razed or weirdly repurposed over the last century, and large areas of this young city have been plowed with nary a trace left to examine.

headline: Beltran May Be Playing Himself Out of Position
text: Carlos Beltran and Angel Pagan stood in the outfield during a pitching change Saturday night in Philadelphia and discussed a play earlier in the game. Beltran was explaining to Pagan the proper path to take on a ball, and Pagan listened closely, as he has in conversations with Beltran for more than a decade, since they first met in Puerto Rico while Pagan was still in high school.

headline: In 7th, Yanks Swing and Miss a Big Chance
text: There was an air of inevitability surrounding the Yankees on Monday afternoon. That made what ended up happening so surprising.

headline: The Horror Show
text: The employment situation in the United States is much worse than even the dismal numbers from last week’s jobless report would indicate. The nation is facing a full-blown employment crisis and policy makers are not responding with anything like the sense of urgency that is needed.

headline: In a Flurry of Calls to Prosecutors About a Rape Suspect, a Pattern Emerges
text: The request from prosecutors in Manhattan seemed routine: Anyone with information about Hugues-Denver Akassy, who was arrested two weeks ago on charges that he raped a Russian tourist in Riverside Park, was asked to come forward.

headline: New Wave of Iranians Seek U.S. Studies
text: WASHINGTON — Even as a teenager in Iran, Atefeh Fathi knew she would eventually study abroad. Now 30 and studying engineering at the University of Oklahoma, Ms. Fathi said that although she had applied to universities in Sweden and Canada, her first choice was the United States.

headline: A Welfare Check and a Voting Card
text: After years of deliberate neglect, the Justice Department is finally beginning to enforce the federal law requiring states to provide voter registration at welfare and food stamp offices. The effort not only promises to bring hundreds of thousands of hard-to-reach voters into the electorate, but it could also reduce the impact of advocacy organizations whose role in registering voters caused such a furor in 2008.

headline: Relief Well Nears Point of Intercept
text: The official in charge of the federal response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico said Monday that a relief well being drilled was within 30 to 40 feet of intercepting the well that poured millions of barrels of oil in the gulf.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: The Latest on Medicare and Social Security
text: It’s the time of year when the trustees of Medicare and Social Security release their annual reports on the programs’ financial health. And that means Americans are likely to be bathed in a fog of political rhetoric that makes it hard to sort out fact from fiction.

headline: Florida Starts Primary Vote Marathon
text: MIAMI  Nasty television ads and e-mail, campaign workers on street corners, and candidates emerging from the polls declaring imminent victory  is the Florida primary already here?

headline: Faint Progress on Drug Payoffs
text: Legislation that would end a devious tactic used by some pharmaceutical companies to delay the introduction of cheaper generic drugs squeaked by a Senate panel recently. Its prospects for ultimate passage remain cloudy unless Senate Democratic leaders aggressively seize the opportunity to save billions of dollars for the federal budget and hard-pressed consumers.

headline: A Destructive Epidemic
text: Since its discovery in a New York State cave in 2006, the fungus called Geomyces destructans has killed about a million cave-dwelling bats of several different species, including the most common Northeastern species, the little brown bat.

headline: City Buses to Get Ads Opposing Islam Center
text: City buses will soon carry a provocative advertisement that opposes the construction of a mosque near ground zero and depicts a plane flying toward a flaming World Trade Center, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said Monday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Progressive Faith
text: Mollie Ziegler Hemingway, left, of Christianity Today and Frances Kissling of RH Reality Check debate the impact of the religious left.

headline: China’s Trade Surplus Reaches $28 Billion
text: HONG KONG  The Chinese government announced on Tuesday morning the country’s biggest trade surplus in a year and a half, as an unexpected surge in Chinese exports and weakening of imports pointed to the prospect of renewed frictions with the United States and other countries over China’s international economic policies.

headline: China’s Trade Surplus Climbs to $28.7 Billion
text: HONG KONG  China’s trade surplus surged last month to its highest level in a year and a half, while real estate prices leveled off, according to government data released on Tuesday that pointed to possible trade frictions with the United States and slightly slower economic growth in China.

headline: Readers’ Photos of Ugly Animals
text: Some animals provoke in us a reflexive ugh, yuck or eeww. They are, to put it bluntly, ugly animals. Our readers sent in their best shots.

headline: Word of the Day | irrefutable
text: irrefutable •\ˌir-i-ˈfyü-tə-bəl; i-ˈre-fyə-tə-, ˌi(r)-\• adjective

headline: News Quiz | August 10, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: For G.M., a Subprime Solution
text: As General Motors heads toward an initial public offering and the eventual  repayment of government aid, it has taken the unsurprising step of acquiring a financing arm, AmeriCredit. After all, Ford and Toyota each have one, and loaning people money can seal the deal on a car sale.

headline: Fed Will Meet With Concerns on Deflation Rising
text: The Federal Reserve will meet on Tuesday faced with a pivotal decision about whether to abandon its presumption that the economy is gradually picking up steam and begin to consider new steps to keep the recovery from sputtering out, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: News Corp. Sells Stakes in TV Units in China
text: The News Corporation said Monday that it would sell a controlling stake in three Chinese television stations and a movie library to a private equity fund that was formed with the backing of the Chinese government, David Barboza reports in The New York Times.

headline: Freddie Mac Seeks More Aid After Big Loss
text: The government-controlled mortgage buyer Freddie Mac on Monday asked for $1.8 billion in additional federal aid after posting a larger loss in the second quarter, The Associated Press reports.

headline: For Cubs’ Zambrano, It’s a Start
text: SAN FRANCISCO – The last time Carlos Zambrano started a game, on June 25, he left in a storm of anger, stomping through the Chicago Cubs’ dugout during a game with the White Sox, raging at the world — and specifically at his teammate Derrek Lee. Zambrano’s outburst earned him a suspension from the team.

headline: Ackman on Path to Own Stuyvesant Town
text: William Ackman, the hedge fund investor, has bought a slice of debt on Stuyvesant Town Peter/Cooper Village and could become the next owner of the sprawling Manhattan apartment complexes, Reuters reports.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Epassyterotically
text: Today’s word, in association with the august Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Racing Slows Down
text: WHO founded Nascar? WHO is its current chairman?

headline: British  Banks Studying How to Prop Up Firms
text: A group representing the major British banks has written to George Osborne, chancellor of the Exchequer, to notify him that they had formed a task force to study how they might assure financing to the private sector.

headline: D.O.E. Charges Up Flywheels With $43 Million Loan
text: A little more than  a year since the Department of Energy announced that it would give a $43 million low-interest loan guarantee to the flywheel builder,  Beacon Power, it’s made good on the deal. The company will use the money to bring its 20-megawatt flywheel plant online by 2011, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Number of Diamonds Varies at War Crimes Trial
text: PARIS  The former Liberian president Charles G. Taylor has been on trial for war crimes for nearly three years. But for the moment, the testimony related to the charges of murder, conscripting child soldiers, and terrorizing and mutilating civilians has taken a back seat to a new riddle.

headline: Solazyme Bottles $52 Million for Algae-Based Fuel
text: San Francisco-based biofuel company Solazyme announced Tuesday that it has landed $52 million in a fourth round of venture capital to commercialize its algae-based fuel. Morgan Stanley joined its flock of backers, which also includes Chevron Technology Ventures, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Callvine Raises $4 Million for Group Calling
text: Callvine, a start-up run by eFax’s founder and former chief executive, Rudy Prince, announced Monday that it has raised $4 million for its group calling and texting iPhone app, according to VentureBeat.

headline: Madoff Investors Challenge Payback Formula
text: Dozens of people who recouped more than their investments in the business of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff have asked a federal court in New York City to force a trustee to include fictitious profits when considering how victims get paid back, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Inergy Restructures in All-Stock Deal
text: Inergy LP, a propane distributor based in Kansas City, Mo., said Monday that it would merge with Inergy Holdings in an all-stock deal that values the latter at $2 billion.

headline: Rwandan Leader Heads to New Term Under Shadow of Repression
text: KIGALI, Rwanda  Rwanda’s president, Paul Kagame, who has been in control of this country since 1994 and helped resurrect it from genocide into one of the most orderly nations in Africa, appeared to have been re-elected on Monday by a staggering margin, according to partial election results released early Tuesday.

headline: Ward by Ward, New Orleans Marches Back
text: Mario Tama, 39, has covered war in Iraq and Afghanistan. He has witnessed death and destruction on a grand scale. Yet he had never seen what he saw in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina. And it was not just the the people screaming for help from rooftops or the bodies that floated by him.

headline: GDF Suez to Take Control of International Power
text: 4:33 a.m. | Updated GDF Suez, the giant Franco-Belgian utility, said Tuesday that it had agreed to take over its smaller British rival International Power in a deal where the target’s shareholders will receive £1.4 billion ($2.2 billion) in cash in a special dividend.

headline: Saudi Arabia to Continue BlackBerry Service
text: Saudi Arabia’s telecommunications regulator says it will allow BlackBerry services to continue in the kingdom, citing ”positive developments” with the device’s manufacturer to find a compromise over security concerns.

headline: U.N. Reports Rising Afghan Casualties
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The number of civilian casualties in Afghanistan continued to climb in the first half of 2010, with an increasing number of children in the toll and a spike in the recently troubled northeast. More than ever, the deaths were caused by insurgents, the United Nations said in a report released Tuesday.

headline: Does Your Stuff Make You Happy?
text: Recent research on consumer habits shows that many Americans have moved from “conspicuous consumption” to “calculated consumption” – buying less, and being choosier about purchases – and that doing so may actually make people happier. What do you think makes you happy?

headline: Sara Lee Chief is Leaving After a Stroke
text: Sara Lee, the food maker, said Monday that its chairwoman and chief executive, Brenda Barnes, would step down permanently to focus on improving her health after a stroke, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Shareholders Block British Property Trust Merger
text: A merger of the U.K. Commercial Property Trust and F&C Commercial Property Trust has been blocked by independent shareholders, The Financial Times reported. The fusion would have created a £1.6 billion ($2.5 billion) property group.

headline: Japan Apologizes to South Korea on Colonization
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Naoto Kan of Japan offered a renewed apology to South Korea on Tuesday for Japan’s brutal colonial rule, as part of a statement marking the 100th anniversary of his nation’s annexation of the Korean Peninsula in 1910.

headline: Alibaba Takes Stake in Chinese Web Portal
text: The Chinese e-commerce firm, Alibaba Group,  will acquire a 16 percent stake of Sogou, the search engine of China’s second-largest Internet portal, Sohu, The Financial Times reported. Also participating in the stake acquisition is Yunfeng, a fund co-founded by Alibaba’s  founder and chairman, Jack Ma.

headline: Wise Moves From Morgan Stanley to Goldman
text: Goldman Sachs has hired Michael Wise to oversee the financial-institutions group in the bank’s equity capital-markets group, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing an internal memo.

headline: New Figure for 2010 Census: $1.6 Billion Under Budget
text: The census’ official count of the American population is not ready yet, but the Census Bureau is issuing a progress report.

headline: For the Housing Convulsion, Good Data Is Hard to Find
text: My post last week asked, “Did Low Interest Rates Cause the Great Housing Convulsion?” as I discussed my research with Joseph Gyourko and Joshua Gottlieb. It drew a hefty dose of comments from readers, along the lines of, “You idiot, don’t you know it was ridiculous lending with no down payments and no documentation?” Yet it is as hard to make a strong case that high approval rates and high loan-to-value ratios caused the boom as it is easy to opine that they obviously did.

headline: Two Kentridge Shows Come to Paris
text: “The past is never dead,” wrote William Faulkner, “it is not even past.” At “William Kentridge — Five Themes,” which runs until Sept. 5 at the Jeu de Paume in Paris, the past is a constant and ambiguous presence. Arriving in Paris after a well-received run at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the exhibition is a brief overview of the South African artist’s career, featuring 40 works completed in a variety of mediums — animated films, drawings, prints and models.

headline: Rice and Smith Inductions a Reminder of the Limits of 40 Times
text: As Hall of Famers, Jerry Rice and Emmitt Smith represent a rebuke to the stopwatches and tape measures that are wielded every year at the combine and pre-draft pro days.

headline: Investors Wary of Bullish Emerging Markets
text: Although emerging markets like Turkey, Indonesia and South Korea are making bullish headlines almost every day, The Financial Times reports that “just below the surface, lurks caution.”

headline: ‘Tourists’ Have Deep Pockets, Triago’s Drean Says
text: Fortune on Monday published an interview with Antoine Dréan, the founder of Triago, a placement agent that helps pension funds and endowments sell their unwanted positions on the secondary market. This year, secondary sales are on track to reach as much as $25 billion and Triago will handle around 20 percent of that making it the second-largest global broker behind Cogent Partners.

headline: Tropical Storm Bonnie’s Crude Joke
text: Hedge funds last week bolstered their holdings of crude oil futures and options to the highest level in 13 weeks in a bet that Tropical Storm Bonnie would delay imports to states along the Gulf of Mexico, reducing supplies, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Symantec Acquires VeriSign for $1.28 Billion
text: Symantec has completed its $1.28 billion purchase of the Web-authentification business of VeriSign, The Silicon Valley Mercury News reported.

headline: How Puritans Turned Capitalist
text: Today’s idea: When Boston’s dour Puritan preachers embraced markets as a moral good three and a half centuries ago, it was a watershed in the formation of the American economy and the national character.

headline: Goldman Under Investigation in U.S. and Britain
text: Goldman Sachs is under investigation by United States and British watchdogs over the timing of disclosures relating to the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s fraud charges against the firm, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Little Caesars Mogul Eyes Detroit Pistons
text: Mike Ilitch, the Little Caesars pizza mogul who already owns the Detroit Tigers and Detroit Red Wings, said Monday that he wanted to buy the Detroit Pistons in part to make sure another buyer doesn’t move the N.B.A. franchise out of town, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Do Salespeople Make Too Much Money?
text: Good salespeople can make very good livings. In some cases they can make as much or more than the owner of the business they work for. I was told a story of one such company — and a problem that it created.

headline: Q. & A.: Sharing the 21st-Century Mix Tape
text: Q.

headline: GLG’s Second-Quarter Loss Triples
text: The asset manager GLG Partners, which is in the process of being taken over by the Man Group, said on Monday that its second-quarter loss tripled as the company booked heavy charges related to various corporate combinations, The Associated Press reported.

headline: MediaMind Focusing on $73 Million I.P.O.
text: Digital advertising company MediaMind Technologies plans to raise about $73 million in an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Icahn vs. Lions Gate: Rambo to the Rescue
text: Can Sylvester Stallone and his band of mercenaries save Lions Gate Entertainment? The Los Angeles Times reports that the star, director and writer of the coming action movie “The Expendables” has fending off Carl C. Icahn on his mind even more than wondering whether audiences will show up for the movie and like what they see.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada Looking to Sell Liberty Life
text: Royal Bank of Canada, the country’s worst-performing bank stock this year, has approached potential buyers for a United States insurance unit it acquired for $650 million a decade ago, Bloomberg News reported, citing people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Toll from Landslides Raised to 702
text: HONG KONG  The death toll from landslides early Sunday morning in western China has climbed to 702, with 1,042 people still missing and 42 seriously injured, the state news agency, Xinhua, reported late Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Saudis Relent a Bit on Shutting Down BlackBerry
text: BERLIN — The Saudi government backed away Tuesday from a threat to shut down the BlackBerry corporate messenger service in the country, citing progress in talks with operators and the maker of the device, Research In Motion, over the ability to monitor encrypted messages for national security reasons.

headline: Katzenberg Blogs Meeting With TPG
text: Jeffrey Katzenberg, the DreamWorks Animation chief, has taken up blogging. According to Deadline.com, Mr. Katzenberg is sending out messages to the entire company detailing his days. One interesting nugget buried in the missive that Deadline published on Monday noted that Mr. Katzenberg hosted the owners of TPG who, he wrote, “want us to know they’re ready, willing, able to support us if there’s ever anything big we want to pursue.”

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — What the Goldman Sachs movie would look like if Ric Burns was helping to make it… oh wait, he is.

headline: QR National I.P.O. Forging Ahead
text: The Queensland government remains in talks with a group, including BHP Billiton, which has raised its bid for the state’s coal freight network to 5.2 billion Australian dollars ($4.8 billion), Bloomberg News said, citing a report in The Australian newspaper.

headline: Fantasy Rookies in Context: Part II, Pass Catchers
text: Although not as fantasy-friendly as rookie running backs, rookie receivers are frequently better values when it comes to your draft.

headline: Netflix to Stream Films From Paramount, Lions Gate, MGM
text: Updated: 4:52 p.m.: At a cost of nearly one billion dollars, Netflix on Tuesday said it would add films from Paramount Pictures, Lions Gate and MGM to its online subscription service.

headline: E.P.A. Cracks Down on Cement Pollution
text: Congress focuses on whether the Environmental Protection Agency should go where no federal regulators have gone before and regulate greenhouse gases. But the agency did something more prosaic on Monday, albeit something it has not done effectively for the last 15 years or so: it put more than 100 cement kilns on notice that they will have to spend almost $1 billion annually to clean up the pollution they put into the atmosphere.

headline: 10-Year Treasury Yields Slide on Fed’s Decision to Buy Debt
text: Yields on 10-year Treasury securities, a vital benchmark for home mortgages and corporate loans, tumbled to the lowest level in more than a year on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve said it would buy up government debt in an effort to bolster the nation’s increasingly fragile economy.

headline: A Data Card, Not a Phone, for a New Network
text: If you want to be one of the first to fully experience the speed of T-Mobile’s upgraded network – it’s called HSPA+ — you’ll have to have a phone that receives HSPA+. Only there aren’t any.

headline: Fatal Attack on Guesthouse in Afghan Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two suicide bombers wearing explosive vests and carrying firearms and grenades attacked a guesthouse frequented by foreigners in central Kabul, the police said, killing two Afghans.

headline: Pakistan Straining to Cope with Floods, U.N. Says
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Monsoon rains continued to fall across Pakistan on Tuesday as the United Nations and relief groups said the scale of the flooding was straining the ability of Pakistan’s government and international aid agencies to provide aid.

headline: Paper Swoon
text: If you happened by Jeffrey New York earlier this year, it was impossible not to have noticed the dramatic paper wigs that crowned the mannequins wearing Yves Saint Laurent and the like. The designers, Nikki Salk and Amy Flurry, of Paper Cut Project in Atlanta, say they were inspired by Gidget, the Supremes and Billie Holiday. The partners have also created a collection of textured paper masks that look a bit like what Oscar Wilde would have worn to a masquerade ball. Which is not to say they have no modern applications: ‘‘A bride in Japan wanted us to create a mask in a vintage Paris-meets-manga theme!’’ Flurry says. And the bride isn’t alone: ‘‘We’re currently working on an exclusive collection for Hermès and are very interested in designing a more elaborate series of masks and headwear for the runway.’’ Are you listening, John Galliano?

headline: Summer School and Working Moms
text: The Schumpeter’s Notebook blog at The Economist has another suggestion for helping the careers of parents, especially mothers: “persuade schools to stay open later, and abandon their absurdly long summer breaks, which were introduced at a time when children were expected to help with the harvest.” (The Economist ran a longer treatment of the subject last year, though you need to be a registered user on the site to read it.)

headline: Networked Storage That Could Be Simpler
text: The Verbatim MediaShare is a handsome, sturdy, polished aluminum box that holds tons—if you consider one terabyte more than a ton—of music, photos and other storage.

headline: The Schools’ Grades on How Graduates Do
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Go-Forward-Ive
text: Suggested substitute for the liberal-scaring term “progressive.”Citing a recent USA Today/Gallup poll which found that only one in four liberals would label themselves “progressive,” John McWhorter asked in an opinion column for The Times:

headline: 7 City Workers Accused of Fraud Involving Day Care Centers
text: Updated 12:16 p.m. | Seven city employees and four other people were arrested by federal authorities on Tuesday morning on federal charges of bribery and conspiracy, and accused of paying and taking bribes to improperly issue city permits to day care centers, approve vouchers for millions in services that were never provided and a range of other crimes, according to court papers.

headline: First They Came For The Climate Scientists
text: Everyone knows that the American right has problems with science that yields conclusions it doesn’t like. Climate science — which says that we face a huge global externality that requires not just government intervention, but coordinated international action (black helicopters!) has been the target of a sustained, and unfortunately largely successful, attempt to damage its credibility.

headline: On Our Radar: Russia’s Heat Wave
text: Russian officials call the ongoing heat wave the worst the country has seen in a millennium. “We have an ‘archive’ of abnormal weather situations stretching over 1,000 years. It is possible to say there was nothing similar to this on the territory of Russia during the last 1,000 years in regard to the heat,” the head of the Russian Meteorological Center says. [Ria Novosti]

headline: Obama Delivers a Clunker
text: For months, President Obama has said he doesn’t want to hand the keys to the economy back to the Republicans. At a fund-raiser in Austin, Tex., on Monday, he repeated a punch line he’s begun using recently, comparing the political parties to the gears on a car.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Last-Straw Stories Inspired by JetBlue Flight Attendant
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: An Old Dog’s New Tricks
text: As I continue to fine-tune my life after an aggressive case of prostate cancer, I admire how Bijou, our creaky, cranky crone of a miniature poodle, is hanging in there with me. At age 13, her hair is falling out, she looks more like a raccoon or an opossum than a dog, and she smells like a barnyard. But all of that doesn’t matter much when, in utter joy, she puts her little opossum tail on vibrate.

headline: Levi Johnston Pitches Reality Show
text: After a Playgirl shoot and a star turn on Kathy Griffin’s “My Life on the D-List,” one might think that Levi Johnston’s 15 minutes are up. But he apparently wants a half-hour each week.

headline: The Laffer Test (Somewhat Wonkish)
text: The renewal of claims that tax cuts pay for themselves has led to a revival of discussion about an old question: how high do taxes have to be before further increases actually reduce revenue?

headline: Where Could Hurd Go?
text: Ever since the Hewlett-Packard affair broke on Friday, people in the tech community have focused mostly on who might replace ousted chief executive Mark V. Hurd.

headline: Former Senator Ted Stevens Killed in Plane Crash
text: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  Former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska was among five people who died in a plane crash in remote southwest Alaska on Monday while on a fishing trip, their small plane weaving through the mountains in clouds and rain before hitting a mountainside.

headline: Let It Snow
text: It will be very hot today. Again. And humid. And sticky. And gross. While City Room does not yet have the power to do anything about the weather, we thought this flashback to the snows of yestermonth might cool you off a bit.

headline: The Early Word:  A Crash in Alaska and Pivotal Primaries
text: 11:58 a.m. | Updated  A plane believed to be carrying Ted Stevens and several others crashed in Alaska early Tuesday morning, but the former Republican senator’s status was not yet known.

headline: A Weekend in Shanghai
text: This city offers dizzying skyscrapers, diverse restaurants and emerging boutiques.

headline: Share Your Tales of ‘Flight Attendant Rage’
text: In September 2008, our Practical Traveler took a behind-the-scenes look at the other side of air travel: she became a flight attendant for two days. What she found — that the skies can also be unfriendly for those who work there — was illustrated by yesterday’s news of the fed-up JetBlue flight attendant who unleashed a tirade, pulled the emergency-exit chute and fled Kennedy Airport.

headline: Escape-Chute Attendant Heads to Arraignment
text: Steven Slater, the JetBlue flight attendant who cursed out a passenger on Monday and slid down an emergency evacuation chute from the plane, left the Port Authority Police Headquarters at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday morning en route to his arraignment on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal mischief.

headline: Clothes Lines
text: When the Munich gallery owner Joëlle Chariau began collecting fashion illustrations, “it was a field that no one had been interested in,” she says. “I could get the best artists without competition.” Thirty years later, the Design Museum in London will display her collection for the first time this November. “Drawing Fashion,” co-curated by the fashion historian Colin McDowell, brings together clothing by Poiret, Lanvin, Chanel, Alexander McQueen and others as drawn by Erté, Lepape, René Gruau, Antonio (left) and Mats Gustafson. In the digital age, Chariau says, drawing has new impact: “Today there are so many images that it’s almost impossible to find one that strikes the imagination. When people look at drawings, they say: ‘Oh, my God! It’s fantastic!’ ” The accompanying book will be published by Prestel.

headline: What Icahn May Want in Energy
text: What is Carl C. Icahn up to in energy?

headline: Beyond Fossil Fuels: Costs and Benefits
text: Wind turbines have become part of the landscape in much of Europe over the last five years. They dot roads in Sweden. You see them on the fast train from Madrid to Barcelona. I saw them last weekend as I drove through the heel of Italy on a brief vacation. Even the most ardent environmentalists here accept their white swirling presence as being worth it for the relatively cheap, clean energy they deliver.

headline: Consensus on New Energy Policy Eludes German Leader

headline: Lamont Loses Connecticut Primary for Governor
text: Republican and Democratic voters in Connecticut nominated their party’s candidates for governor and United States Senate on Tuesday, setting the stage for expensive and highly competitive general election contests that will make the state the focus of national attention heading into the midterm elections.

headline: Ad What?
text: A language thing: many people have been characterizing my attack on the Ryan roadmap as “ad hominem.” I think this represents a devaluation of the term.

headline: Obama’s Youthful Voters More Likely to Skip Midterms
text: Will all of those young, enthusiastic Obama voters turn out in 2010? If history is any guide, probably not. Older voters are historically more likely to cast ballots in midterm elections than are voters under the age of 30. And this year, they are already more enthusiastic than younger voters about the coming campaign.

headline: ‘Bruno’ Lawsuit Is Dismissed
text: Sacha Baron Cohen, who was sued last year for slander in connection with “Bruno,” his comedy-documentary about a gay fashion reporter, managed this week to get out of another sticky legal situation, Reuters reported.

headline: Pro-Creation | Levi’s Pop-Up Workshops
text: Once a bold guerrilla enterprise, the pop-up shop has lately become a dime-a-dozen marketing gimmick. A new series of pop-up workshops from Levi’s, however, aims to sell a spirit of community — and the occasional jean jacket — by bringing together bold names like Alice Waters, Craig Newmark and Stefan Sagmeister along with local nonprofits and businesses to explore artistic media, all in the name of creative and civic engagement.

headline: Lower East Side Has Less to Offer Jesuits Who Teach the Poor
text: The view from 204 Forsyth Street has gone from dilapidated to deluxe. Five stories above the bustling streets of the Lower East Side, the Rev. Jack Podsiadlo leaned over the rooftop cornice of this narrow, red-brick tenement and counted all the boutiques and nightspots that have moved in.

headline: Ex-White House Social Secretary to Lead Ebony and Jet Publisher
text: Desirée Rogers, who left her job as White House social secretary earlier this year after two fame-seeking party crashers made their way into a presidential gala, has been named chief executive of the world’s largest black-owned publishing company.

headline: Recycling Land for Green Energy Ideas
text: LEMOORE, Calif.  Thousands of acres of farmland here in the San Joaquin Valley have been removed from agricultural production, largely because the once fertile land is contaminated by salt buildup from years of irrigation.

headline: With New Confidence, Kljestan Takes Aim at Brazil
text: Few teams and players have much success against the supremely talented Brazilians, but Sacha Kljestan and his American teammates have had a particularly frustrating experience. That makes Tuesday’s international friendly at the New Meadowlands Stadium an important game for the United States, which is coming off an enthusiastic run at the World Cup, and for Kljestan, who has a newfound confidence after a promising start to his European career.

headline: Jobs for Kids
text: At what age should a child start working? Is it their “job” to pay for the extras, or even the necessities, in their lives? Or is their “job” to navigate school, get into (and out of) college and then support themselves?

headline: Charlie Chan: A Stereotype and a Hero
text: To many Asian-Americans, Charlie Chan is an offensive stereotype, another sort of Uncle Tom. Chan, the hero of six detective novels by Earl Derr Biggers and 47 Hollywood movies between 1926 and 1949, not to mention a 1970s Hanna-Barbera cartoon series, is pudgy, slant-eyed and inscrutable, and he speaks in singsong fortune-cookie English, saying things like, “If befriend donkey, expect to be kicked.” The California-born author and playwright Frank Chin, who has written essays denouncing Chan, would like to see him disappear altogether.

headline: No Deal With the Devils
text: There are some tough jobs in sports  and today we would include anyone attempting to do public relations/futile damage control for the Knicks, the Houston Texans or Albert Haynesworth  but being the N.H.L. arbitrator making the Ilya Kovalchuk decision is not among them.

headline: Detroit Band Wins Experian’s Ad Contest
text: Experts in personal finance have had their criticisms of the long-running campaign from Experian for freecreditreport.com, among them that the ads took advantage of consumer confusion between the Experian Web site, which sells a subscription service costing $14.95 a month, and the official Web site for free reports, annualcreditreport.com.

headline: TimesCast | August 10, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, a look at primary races in key battleground states, readers react to a flight attendant breakdown and the debate over who controls the internet.

headline: The Technology Imperative for Energy and Climate
text: 1:39 p.m. | Updated If you care about fostering prosperity in poor places while limiting the buildup of greenhouse gases in the globe’s shared atmosphere, it’s time to recognize the technology imperative that lies behind the world’s entwined climate and energy challenges. Without greatly intensified work to advance and disseminate energy choices that don’t come with heat-trapping emissions, there’s no smooth path as human populations and appetites crest in the next two generations.

headline: Law, Culture and Same-Sex Marriage
text: I’m going to try working my way through the many responses to yesterday’s column. The process may take a while (i.e. it may be next week before I have a response to Andrew Sullivan’s eloquent rebuttal), for which I apologize in advance. But let’s begin with Glenn Greenwald, who thinks that I’m wrong to suggest any necessary connection between the establishment of a legal order and the establishment of a cultural ideal. Treating gay unions and straight unions identically in law, he argues, in no way precludes the cultural recognition of the distinctiveness of lifelong heterosexual monogamy:

headline: Opening Date Set for ‘Spider-Man’ Musical
text: “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the much-anticipated, much-delayed musical, has been given a date for the start of preview performances at Broadway’s newly renamed Foxwoods Theater (formerly the Hilton Theater).

headline: Q&A: An Overnight From London to Durham and York
text: I will be based in London for about a month in September. I want to take an overnight trip to York and Durham to see York Minster and Durham Cathedral. Does it make sense to go to Durham first and then stop at York on my way back to London, or go to York and then make my way to Durham? Which is the better city to find inexpensive overnight lodgings?

headline: Nudibranchs, Corals and Readers’ Questions
text: After returning from the Philippines, I was thrust back into the realities of life at the California Academy of Sciences. It was nonstop catching up on e-mail, then dropping everything for several weeks to write a grant proposal to the National Science Foundation to support an even more extensive survey of the Philippines to determine whether the Verde Island Passage is the richest marine area for many different groups of marine plants and animals.

headline: For Those With Jobs, a Recession With Benefits
text: One of the distinctive features of the Great Recession has been the enormous number of people who have been out of work for months on end. Almost 45 percent of today’s unemployed workers have been without a job for at least 27 weeks. In no other downturn since World War II did the share exceed 26 percent.

headline: Can You Solve for X?
text: When I sat through a remedial math class at the Borough of Manhattan Community College one recent morning, I was a bit surprised and more than a little embarrassed to realize that it was tough for me to follow along. Quadratic equations? Line slopes? Scientific notation? My mind was dizzy.

headline: Phylicia Rashad and Anna Deavere Smith Are Set to Star in Washington Productions
text: Phylicia Rashad and Anna Deavere Smith will be the leading ladies in the inaugural productions at Arena Stage at the Mead Center for American Theater in Washington, D.C., Arena Stage officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Rights Groups Join Call for WikiLeaks to Censor Afghan Files

headline: Crisis-Shaken Executives Sharpen Focus on Risk
text: Corporate leaders are focusing more attention on risk management after excessive risk-taking during the boom times helped bring about the global financial crisis, according to a survey of senior executives by Korn/Ferry International, the world’s largest recruiting firm.

text: I am in the process of selling my flat in London, so I am starting to think about the next place. One of the items on my wish list is outdoor space, something that I never craved before but for some reason is now a must-have.

text: In today’s edition of TimesCast, New York Times editors Jim Roberts and Marcus Mabry discuss the plane crash in Alaska and the uncertainty over the fate of former Senator Ted Stevens, one of nine passengers, as well as Tuesday’s primary races in several key battleground states.

headline: Coach Decries Isiah Thomas’s Dual Roles
text: While the N.B.A. is investigating whether his two jobs violate their rules prohibiting contact with high school and college players, Isiah Thomas was criticized a fellow college coach. Katie Thomas reports on the Quad blog that, one of Thomas’s conference rivals weighed in Tuesday on the potential conflict raised by Thomas’s decision to keep his job as the men’s basketball coach at Florida International University while working as a consultant to the Knicks.

headline: Fed to Buy U.S. Debt, Saying Recovery Has Slowed

headline: Fed Move on Debt Signals Concern About Economy
text: WASHINGTON  Federal Reserve officials, acknowledging that their confidence in the recovery had dimmed, moved again on Tuesday to keep interest rates low and encourage economic growth. They also signaled that more aggressive measures could follow if the job market and other indicators continued to weaken.

headline: Herman Edwards’s Insight Into Revis’s Holdout
text: Herman Edwards played cornerback in the N.F.L. and coached the Jets from 2001 to 2005, two mileposts that give him insight into the Darrelle Revis contract standoff. So when I interviewed Edwards for another article on Tuesday morning, I asked him if he would meet Revis’s demands, if it were up to him, if it were his check.

headline: Rebirth of a City
text: Rick Destito knew exactly what he was getting into when he bought a rundown, three-story Victorian house in one of the poorest neighborhoods of Syracuse. Built in the 1890s but left abandoned for years, the place was in serious disrepair: graffiti and mold stained the exterior, the windows were gone and the roof needed to be replaced. But under an innovative local housing program, he paid only a dollar for the place — plus another $60,000, and his own skilled labor, to make it suitable for his family, including a one-year old girl and a baby on the way.

headline: Former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska Is Killed in Plane Crash
text: Ted Stevens, 86, was the longest-serving Republican senator until he lost his bid for a seventh term in 2008 after he was convicted of corruption charges. The charges were later thrown out.

headline: On House Floor, Rangel Vows to Stay in Office

headline: No-Fishing Area Shrinks in Gulf
text: With oil from the BP blowout continuing to dissipate, the federal authorities reopened more than 5,000 square miles of commercial and recreational fishing waters in the gulf on Tuesday. At their closest point, the reopened waters lie about 115 miles northeast of the now-capped wellhead. According to experts with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, testing showed fish from the area, off the Florida Panhandle, to be free from contamination from the spill.

headline: For a Million Dollars, Lotus Provides Racecar and Racing Lifestyle
text: This week, the rarest of Delahayes, Ferraris and Jaguars will adorn California’s Monterey peninsula for the annual collector car auctions, monopolizing desire wherever they turn up. Amid such magnetic company, only a handful of automakers each year elect to unveil new models — and even then they typically exile themselves to the Pebble Beach Golf Club’s concept lawn, a roped-off refuge removed from the withering glare of flawless Bugatti Type 57C’s.

headline: StoryCorps Radio Histories Coming to Television

headline: Leave the Vuvuzelas, Take the Kebabs
text: Soccer fans who arrive by train at the New Meadowlands Stadium in New Jersey for the Brazil-United States match on Tuesday night have been instructed to leave their vuvuzelas at home. To compensate, perhaps, they will be met by the aroma of steaks sizzling on gas grills inside the gate. It’s a twist on tailgating that the folks who run the stadium are calling “railgating.”

headline: As a Park Runs Above, Deals Stir Below

headline: And Representing Nicaraguan Cuisine: Quesillos
text: The negative view of Central American cuisine is that it’s like Mexican food without the spice. While there is some truth to that, I love Central American originals like pupusas from El Salvador (corn tortillas stuffed with pork, cheese, beans or a combination cooked inside, topped with pickled cabbage and tomato sauce), and baleadas from Honduras (wheat tortillas topped with beans, cream and cheese, then folded in half). So I maintained my optimism that there’d be a gem to find in Nicaragua as well.

headline: Chinese Investor Is Said to Be Bidding for English Soccer Club

headline: F.D.I.C. Takes Step Toward Cutting Use of Ratings

headline: The Insider | Jon Spencer

Still hot after all these years. Here, Spencer shares his insider picks.

headline: Early U.S. Tests Find No Toyota Flaw in Electronics
