headline: Societies May Fall, but Prices Do Not at Lanvin
text: WHENEVER the disparity between rich and poor becomes too obscene, as it did during the Victorian era or the Great Depression, a particular story line seems to reassert itself in literature and other media. A rich and cold-hearted magnate (e.g., Ebenezer Scrooge) is met by some lovely person or divine agency whose innate goodness forces the tycoon to realize that his life is miserable because it has been devoted to greed. The miser’s heart thaws, the weight of his priorities shifts. In the end, he places less value on the “wealth” part of his personal wealth and more value on the “personal.”

headline: Staten Island Armory and Church Are Named Landmarks
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission granted landmark status on Tuesday to two venerable complexes on Staten Island: the Staten Island Armory on Manor Road in Castleton Corners, and the neo-Gothic Christ Church and its rectory and parish house in the northeast corner of the island.

headline: The Fed Is Worried
text: It is clear that the Fed is much more worried than it has been about the strength of the economic recovery.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gansu Province and Elsewhere
text: The death toll from landslides early Sunday morning in western China has climbed to 702, with 1,042 people still missing and 42 seriously injured, the state news agency, Xinhua, reported Tuesday afternoon. Vice Premier Hui Liangyu ordered rescuers to step up efforts to find people trapped under the rubble in Zhouqu, in Gansu Province, and noted that these people had the best chance of survival if found within 72 hours of the disaster. The landslide obliterated a large section of the town and then poured into a river, damming the waterway and causing it to flood and submerge part of the devastated community. Soldiers have been using explosives to clear the blockage and drain the town.

headline: New Federal Aid for School Districts, States
text: The House interrupted its summer recess on Tuesday to approve $26 billion in aid to school districts and states to prevent large-scale layoffs of teachers and public employees and to engage in another partisan fight over policy priorities.

headline: Hurling Thunderbolts From the Floor
text: VAIL, Colo. — I don’t much enjoy watching dance on YouTube, but the scale of tango suits it better than any other genre. There you can see two ravishing clips of the Argentine tango dancers Natalia Hills and Gabriel Missé at the Vail International Dance Festival last year. (Search for their names and the Vail festival.)

headline: Barak Says ‘Friction’ Was Expected in Flotilla Raid
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, said Tuesday that Israel’s leaders were aware of the possibility that the military interception of a flotilla bound for Gaza in late May could turn violent, although lower level military officials had said at the time that the commandos were expecting only passive resistance.

headline: Homes for $500,000
text: Properties on the market in Pittsburgh, Seattle and Phoenix.

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: PITTSBURGH

headline: Russian Fires Raise Fears of Radioactivity
text: MOSCOW  As if things in Russia were not looking sufficiently apocalyptic already, with 100-degree temperatures and noxious fumes rolling in from burning peat bogs and forests, there is growing alarm here that fires in regions coated with fallout from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster 24 years ago could now be emitting plumes of radioactive smoke.

headline: 8,000 People? E.P.A. Defers Hearing on Fracking
text: After successfully holding hearings around the country on the impact of the natural gas drilling method known as hydraulic fracturing, officials with the federal Environmental Protection Agency ran into a hurdle this week in New York State: finding an acceptable site for a hearing and for the passionate crowds expected to show up for it.

headline: Incumbent Backed by Obama Wins Colorado Primary
text: DENVER  The predictions of doom for incumbents and establishment candidates this campaign season are proving to be more complex in the real world. On Tuesday, Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, a Democrat who had hitched his star to the fortunes of President Obama, survived a bitter primary challenge.

headline: Scientists See Links From Asian Floods to Russian Heat
text: Two climatologists, Peter Stott at the British Met Office and Kevin Trenberth of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, have separately described atmospheric dynamics that appear to link the extreme rains and flooding in Asia with Russia’s unrelenting, extraordinary heat and resulting conflagrations.

headline: Quote Unquote | Unzipped
text: –Marc Jacobs explains his nude fragrance ad, shot by Juergen Teller, to Harper’s Bazaar. As a frequent wearer of skirts and kilts, how could he find jeans and a shirt ridiculous?

headline: A Tool for Activists Is Simplified for the Less Tech Savvy
text: Software that has been hailed as a powerful tool in response to crisis has become accessible for low-tech activists. Ushahidi, a technology which allows users to create maps from data drawn from messages from cellphones, news reports and the Web, is now available through a Web-based application called Crowdmap.

headline: Video From an Embed With the Taliban
text: A video of Taliban fighters shot last October by a Norwegian journalist in eastern Afghanistan offers a rare glimpse of the war from the perspective of the Afghan insurgents.

headline: Keep It With the Committee, Please
text: White House officials and other top Democrats, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California, were not happy with the decision by Representative Charles R. Rangel, Democrat of New York, to take over the House floor during Tuesday’s emergency session to offer his personal defense against ethics charges.

headline: Rape Suspect Indicted
text: A man accused of raping a Russian tourist last month was indicted on Tuesday, a Manhattan prosecutor said in court.

headline: Beer Gardens Bloom Around the City
text: THERE is no drinking forum more compatible with summer than the beer garden. Until recently, New Yorkers wanting to raise a stein in dappled sunshine had one choice: Bohemian Hall & Beer Garden in Astoria, Queens, which turns 100 this year.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Ice Cream and Beer

headline: At the New Meadowlands Stadium, Grilling Stations
text: Fans who arrive by train at the New Meadowlands Stadium in New Jersey will be met by the aroma of steaks sizzling on gas grills inside the gate. It’s a twist on tailgating that the folks who run the stadium are calling "railgating." Lobel’s, the Madison Avenue meat purveyor, and Weber-Stephen, a maker of charcoal and gas grills, are partners with the stadium in two grilling stations, which made their debut at the Brazil-U.S.A. soccer match on Aug. 10, and will be in business throughout the football season.

headline: Pickle Chips With Hot Sauce
text: Demand for a spicy cucumber pickle led Rick Field to dump some sriracha Thai-style hot sauce into a batch of his straightforward pickle chips. Several trial runs later, Mr. Field believes he has nailed the balance of crisp, briny and hot  just what his fans had asked for. The pickles pack heat but not searingly so, and are a terrific accompaniment to sandwiches, charcuterie, cold noodle dishes and burgers. Chop them to start a tartar sauce for chilled or fried seafood.

headline: Recyclables Become Spoons and Spatulas
text: Take two or three plastic water bottles, let a green alchemist touch them with a magic wand and you have kitchen utensils: two generous spoons and two spatulas, plain or with a leaf pattern. The tools are made by turning the plastic into flakes that are compressed and shaped. The work is done in an upstate New York plant that uses wind energy and trucks that run on bio-diesel.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Traif
text: IN the valley of the shadow of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, where bearded Hasidim cross paths with mustachioed steam punks, stands the restaurant Traif.

headline: Just Looking | Head Trip
text: The fashion tribes descending on Paris for couture week in July might have done well to leave behind the elegant boutiques of the rue Boissy d’Anglas and the chic precincts of the Hotel Crillon and head instead toward La Bastille, where on a quay fringed with plumbing supply and carpet shops and overlooking the Canal Saint Martin, an extraordinary collection of accessories has taken up residence. There, the Maison Rouge, a nonprofit kunsthalle devoted to contemporary art, is showing more than 300 hats and headdresses from all over the globe, all of which belong to the institution’s founder, Antoine de Galbert.De Galbert, a former gallery owner better known as a collector of both outsider and contemporary art, acquired the first hat in his collection about 15 years ago — a small headdress, intended as a sculptural ornament, and adorned with cassowary feathers from Papua New Guinea. He was hooked. His collection now numbers more than 400 pieces. It includes brilliantly beplumed Amazonian bonnets; sumptuously beaded, cone-shaped royal crowns worn by Yoruba chieftains, adorned with birds (symbols, according to the show’s catalog, of “the mystical power of women”); a Burmese hunter’s horned headdress, designed to inspire terror, with a monkey’s skull posed atop a bit of bear fur; as well as more modest garments, like a simple cap from India, made of felted yak hair, to protect against the rain. There’s a diadem once worn by an Uzbek bride on her wedding day, and a headband covered in cowry shells that announced the birth of a first child to a woman in Indonesia.

headline: CBS Wins With Comedy
text: ABC’s latest “Bachelor” spinoff, “Bachelor Pad,” attracted a modest showing in the ratings on Monday, earning 6.4 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, enough to lift ABC to second place for the night. CBS led over all, garnering larger audiences with reruns of its comedy lineup, particularly “Two and a Half Men” (8.6 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (8.4 million). NBC and Fox finished in a virtual tie for third with NBC edging ahead with an “America’s Got Talent” rerun at 8 (4.9 million). Fox broadcast the 2010 Teen Choice Awards, which averaged 4.1 million viewers from 8 to 10.

headline: Arena Stage Lineup of Leading Ladies
text: Phylicia Rashad, below top, and Anna Deavere Smith, below bottom, will be the leading ladies in the inaugural productions at Arena Stage at the Mead Center for American Theater in Washington, Arena Stage officials announced on Tuesday. Ms. Rashad, whose Broadway credits include “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” will play Mother Sister/Sophia in the world premiere of “Every Tongue Confess” by Marcus Gardley (“On the Levee”). Directed by Kenny Leon, it will run Nov. 9 to Jan. 2. Ms. Smith, a stage, film and television actress, will begin a national tour of “Let Me Down Easy,” her one-woman show about health care and the body as a Second Stage production in the newly refurbished Kreeger Theater. That play, directed by Leonard Foglia (“Moby Dick”), runs Dec. 31 to Feb. 13. In addition, E. Faye Butler (“Trouble in Mind”) will play Aunt Eller in Rodgers and Hammerstein’s “Oklahoma!” Directed by Molly Smith, artistic director of Arena Stage, it runs Oct. 22 to Dec. 26.

headline: New York’s New Beer Gardens
text: Loreley in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and the Biergarten at the Standard Hotel in the meatpacking district in Manhattan are among the crop of new beer gardens opening around the city.

headline: Storycorps Histories Become Animated Shorts
text: Some of the stirring oral histories recorded by StoryCorps are being transformed into animated television segments. The PBS program “P.O.V.” announced on Tuesday that the first of six animated shorts would be shown alongside its feature films starting on Tuesday. The shorts illustrate some of the most memorable stories captured by StoryCorps since its founding seven years ago. The nonprofit group has recorded the oral histories of more than 60,000 participants. One recording is featured each week on NPR. “P.O.V.” said examples of the animated shorts include a conversation between a 12-year-old boy with Asperger’s syndrome and his mother; an infantryman’s memories of the Battle of the Bulge; and an interview of the author and radio host Studs Terkel, who died in 2008.

headline: Considering the Chute, in the Event of a Non-Emergency
text: As a veteran flight attendant for JetBlue, Steven Slater undoubtedly logged many hours in training how to evacuate a planeload of terrified fliers down the emergency chutes. On Monday, he put those skills to use — by quickly evacuating himself.

headline: Net Neutrality
text: Brian Stelter and David Gallagher discuss Google and Verizon.

headline: Eating Up Racing Season in Saratoga Springs
text: The movable feast in this city in upstate New York intensifies during the six-week track season at Saratoga Race Course.

headline: House Hunting in ... Corsica
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM TWO-BATH FORMER OLIVE MILL IN CORSICA

headline: Opening Date Is Set For ‘Spider-Man’ Musical
text: The much-anticipated, much-delayed “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” with music and lyrics by U2’s Bono and the Edge, has been given a date for the start of preview performances  Nov. 14  at Broadway’s newly renamed Foxwoods Theater (formerly the Hilton Theater). The show’s producers announced on Tuesday that they had also set an opening night, Dec. 21. The musical is estimated to have a $50 million budget, the largest in Broadway history. Directed by Julie Taymor, the Tony Award-winning creator of the long-running musical “The Lion King,” “Spider-Man” appears to have rebounded from a production delay that involved scuttling its original plan to start performances last February. According to executives involved with “Spider-Man,” the new producers have secured enough financing for the creative team to begin rehearsals next week and commit to performance dates and a box-office schedule. Tickets will go on sale in September; an exclusive presale to American Express cardholders begins on Saturday. People who previously bought tickets will be contacted by Ticketmaster and given priority access for tickets again.

headline: In Corsica, a Stone Olive Mill
text: A four-bedroom converted olive mill in Corsica’s Balagne region is on the market for 1.1 million euros ($1.5 million).

headline: In Saratoga Springs, Catering to the Horse Set
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

headline: ‘Bruno’ Suit Is Dismissed
text: Sacha Baron Cohen, who was sued late last year for slander in connection with “Bruno,” his comedy-documentary about a gay fashion reporter, managed this week to get out of another sticky legal situation, Reuters reported. On Monday a federal judge dismissed a copyright claim brought by a writer who said that a scene in the 2009 film was very similar to his own original script, titled “Himbos,” Reuters reported. John Musero filed suit against Mr. Baron Cohen, in character above, the director Larry Charles, the producers Mosaic Media Group and MRC and others in March. Mr. Musero had claimed that a scene in which “Bruno” wrecks havoc at a fashion show because he is stuck in a Velcro suit came from a script that Mr. Musero had pitched to Mosaic, which later rejected it. The court ruled that the idea of a man in a Velcro suit was not subject to copyright and that the two works were not that similar. The protagonist in “Himbos” is chased by a rabbit and cats after rabbit food gets stuck to the back of his suit. “Bruno” shows its title character crashing into a rack of clothes and falling onto a runway.

headline: The Drawing Center Will Stay In Soho
text: After years of seeking a new downtown home, the Drawing Center has decided to stay put in its SoHo neighborhood. “The economy made us re-evaluate what scale of project we want,” Brett Littman, the Drawing Center’s director, said in an interview on Monday. “We’re like a nice small jazz club  the scale of what we do is intimate; drawings tend to be pretty small.” The center has 2,500 square feet in its main gallery at 35 Wooster Street, which it owns, and about 500 square feet across the street at 40 Wooster Street, where it has a lease that must be renegotiated every two years. Mr. Littman said the center was looking at alternatives to its secondary space and considering ways to better utilize its main gallery with a possible redesign. Until recently, the Drawing Center had been exploring a wholesale move, a search that included ground zero and the South Street Seaport and Pier 18. But now SoHo has become even more of a cultural haven, fueled by an influx of commercial galleries and the opening of the New Museum on the Bowery. “There is a kind of understanding that the circumstances have shifted and maybe this is a good moment for the Drawing Center to reinvest in the neighborhood it built its reputation in,” Mr. Littman said.

headline: Levi Johnston Pitches Reality Show For Cable
text: After a Playgirl shoot and a star turn on Kathy Griffin’s “My Life on the D-List,” one might think that Levi Johnston’s 15 minutes are up. But he apparently wants a half-hour each week. Mr. Johnston, a bit player in the last presidential election, is pitching a reality television show to several cable channels. Producers are filming in Hollywood this week for the show, which would be called “Loving Levi: The Road to the Mayor’s Office.” That would be the mayor’s office in Wasilla, Alaska, where Sarah Palin got her start. According to the producers, the series would show Mr. Johnston campaigning to be the mayor of Wasilla, even though that job does not come up for election until 2012. Without a channel, though, the show is little more than an idea. Asked why Mr. Johnston’s show was publicized even though it lacks a channel, Canaan Rubin, an executive producer, said in an e-mail that “a pilot is in preproduction and several networks are interested.” The interested parties have not been identified.

headline: Bill to Halt Certain Sales of Artwork May Be Dead
text: A bill to prohibit cultural institutions from selling pieces from their collections to cover operating costs has all but died in the New York State Legislature, in the face of opposition from major cultural institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the withdrawal of support from the bill’s Senate sponsor.

headline: Guy Fieri, Chef-Dude, Is in the House
text: ATLANTIC CITY

headline: A Smooth-Sounding Line Between Jazz and Soul
text: Kem was scatting a bit Saturday night, even if he didn’t quite mean to. It was the Budweiser Superfest, at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater, and he was about three minutes away from climbing atop the grand piano at center stage for a triumphant dance.

headline: Strutting Versatility and a Wild Pack Mentality
text: Two companies  Gallim Dance and Camille A. Brown & Dancers  shared Monday’s bill at the Joyce Theater. Each made a strong impression (and won an ovation), with both choreographers displaying thoroughly stageworthy, professional pieces. The differences between the two were also striking, in ways that made the comparison stimulating for any audience.

headline: Disney Earnings Are Better Than Expected
text: LOS ANGELES  Profit soared nearly 40 percent at the Walt Disney Company in its most recent quarter, propelled by three blockbuster movies, strong merchandise sales and growth at ESPN.

headline: Jazz Duets, Onstage And in Spirit
text: Four years in the making, Hilary Kole’s new album, “You Are There” (Justin Time), whose release was celebrated at Birdland on Monday evening, is the equivalent of a jazz singer’s college education. On the recording Ms. Kole sings with 11 eminent jazz pianists: Monty Alexander, Kenny Barron, Alan Broadbent, Dave Brubeck, Freddy Cole, Benny Green, Steve Kuhn, Michel Legrand, Mike Renzi, Cedar Walton and Hank Jones (who died on May 16).

headline: Summoning the Spiritual With Just Enough Cowbell
text: If ever there was a time for a group of former Hare Krishna adherents to come to New York to make their way as a band, it would be now. Thanks to groups like Animal Collective and its peers, the shamanic impulse is as alive as ever in indie rock. The embrace of Eastern spirituality is at an apex. Tie-dye is making a comeback.

headline: Where to Eat in Saratoga Springs
text: TOURISTS spent $357 million in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., last year, and about a third of that sum, $114 million, went for food and drink in places that did more than half their annual business from June to Labor Day. Here are some peak-season options in the city of the spa, the horse and the menu.

headline: Netflix to Pay Nearly $1 Billion to Add Films to On-Demand Service
text: At a cost of nearly $1 billion, Netflix said on Tuesday that it would add films from Paramount Pictures, Lions Gate and MGM to its online subscription service.

headline: Hey, America, Take the Day Off
text: Gail Collins: Tim, thanks for taking the time to have this conversation while David Brooks is on vacation. I believe you’re coming back from some down time yourself. I’m so jealous.

headline: Krzyzewski Frowns on Thomas’s Situation
text: When Mike Krzyzewski speaks, people in the basketball world  college and professional  tend to listen. On Tuesday, Krzyzewski voiced his opposition to having a college coach double as a consultant for an N.B.A. team.

headline: Magazine Will Cater to Mobile Readers (and Freelancers)
text: A small group of former magazine journalists and editors, including a former president of Newsweek, plan to publish a weekly digital magazine this fall, seeking to create content specifically for mobile technology.

headline: 'Diners, Drive-ins and Dives'
text: In an excerpt from one of his three shows on the Food Network channel, Guy Fieri visits the Oinkster in Eagle Rock, Calif. (Video courtesy of the Food Network.)

headline: Iranian Prisoners Explain End of Hunger Strikes
text: Fifteen opposition activists in Tehran’s Evin prison explained why they ended their hunger strikes on Monday in a letter published on the Web site of the Iranian opposition leader Mir Hussein Moussavi.

headline: U.S. Lawmakers Aim to Block Lebanon Military Aid
text: WASHINGTON  Several members of Congress have moved to block United States aid to the Lebanese military, saying they are concerned that it may be working with Hezbollah in light of last week’s deadly skirmish between Lebanese and Israeli soldiers on the border between the two countries.

headline: The Magma Chart
text: Read any introductory economics textbook, and you’ll learn that the Federal Reserve has three primary benchmarks that it employs to control monetary policy: the federal funds rate, the discount rate and the reserve ratio. Today the Federal Reserve made history by adding a new benchmark: the size of its balance sheet.

headline: The Challenge of Traveling the Congo River
text: Thursday, Aug. 5: Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo

headline: The 'Real' Charlie Chan
text: Photographs of Chang Apana, the real-life detective who served as an inspiration for Charlie Chan, and others related to the character's history.

headline: American History, With Shakespeare as Inspiration
text: ASHLAND, Ore.

headline: Malware Infection Hits Russian Android Phones
text: The adage “Be careful what you wish for” has a modern-day counterpart: “Be careful what you download.” Especially on your mobile phone.

headline: Rarely but Glaringly Missing
text: SAN DIEGO  It is a pleasant, sunny day  the middle of summer  and Nate Kaeding seems at ease on a football field. Then again, in about five months, the gremlins will arrive, and with them perhaps the next chance for Kaeding to resolve who he really is.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,405 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,206 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: By One Measure, More Fans Hold a Negative View of Roethlisberger
text: Being a starting quarterback in the N.F.L. is one of the highest-profile jobs in sports, and Ben Roethlisberger has had one of the biggest profiles in Pittsburgh since he arrived there as a rookie in 2004.

headline: Text of the Federal Reserve Statement on Interest Rates
text: The following is the full text of the statement released Tuesday by the Federal Reserve:

headline: In a Gesture Toward Team Unity, a Jets Starter Steps Aside
text: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Bart Scott does not need much prodding to be fired up about almost anything. Scott was asked after the Jets practiced Tuesday morning what it meant that Dwight Lowery voluntarily handed his starting cornerback position this week to the rookie Kyle Wilson.

headline: Johnny Carson, Now Quipping Online
text: In one of his last “Tonight Show” monologues, in 1992, Johnny Carson informed his audience that a virus had struck the program’s computers, wiping out “29 years of our writers’ material.”

headline: Leaving a Job With a Bus, Not a Slide
text: How thrilling the ride off the back of a jet and down that inflatable emergency slide must have been for Steven Slater, flight attendant  cold beer in his hand, wind in his hair, the seat of his JetBlue uniform gliding merrily toward the runway. Woo-hoo!

headline: James Has a Date in Cleveland on Dec. 2
text: LeBron James’s homecoming game is set for Dec. 2.

headline: Dressing Artists’ Hub in Something Button-Down
text: BERLIN  For 20 years, a graffiti-covered ruin of a former department store here has housed studios and workshops for artists who occupied it and saved it from demolition shortly after the Berlin Wall fell.

headline: Yamauchi Joins Marathon Field
text: Mara Yamauchi of Britain, who caught Deena Kastor of the United States in the closing miles to win the NYC Half-Marathon in March, has entered this year’s New York City Marathon, the New York Road Runners announced Tuesday.

headline: Leaders Repair Colombia-Venezuela Ties
text: LIMA, Peru  Colombia’s new president, Juan Manuel Santos, and his Venezuelan counterpart, Hugo Chávez, moved on Tuesday to repair diplomatic relations after ties had sharply deteriorated in recent weeks over assertions by Colombia’s government that Colombian guerrillas were operating from Venezuelan soil.

headline: Scottish Government Pressed to Release Medical Advice That Led to Lockerbie Bomber’s Release
text: LONDON  Ten days before the first anniversary of the release of the Lockerbie bomber, the Scottish government on Tuesday came under fresh pressure to justify its decision to release the bomber, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, on medical grounds.

headline: Can O’Neal Ever Play a Supporting Role?
text: WALTHAM, Mass.

headline: S. Carolina Takes Stimulus Money
text: Early last year, while still a rising G.O.P. star, Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina led a chorus of Republican governors criticizing the federal stimulus package and vowing to reject at least some of the money being directed to their states.

headline: Reyes Disputes Manuel Over Reasons for Errors
text: Even on his worst days, when he has committed an error or gone hitless with three strikeouts, Jose Reyes can usually find a way to smile at least once through his troubles or express a humble acknowledgment that he has done something wrong.

headline: How to Achieve Workplace Equality
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turkey: Adviser Could Face Polygamy Charges
text: Ali Yuksel, an adviser to the Turkish prime minister’s office, could face up to two years in prison if he is charged with polygamy after describing his simultaneous relationship with three women in a recently published book. Mr. Yuksel cited Islamic law, which does not apply in secular Turkey, to defend the relationships. He is the father-in-law of Suat Kilic, a leading member of the governing Justice and Development Party whose attempt to pass a law legalizing polygamy a few years ago failed in the face of heavy secular opposition.

headline: Texas Nurses Fired for Alleging Misconduct Settle Their Suit
text: Two nurses agreed Tuesday to split a $750,000 payment from Winkler County, Tex., to settle the lawsuit they filed after being fired and criminally prosecuted for reporting allegations of improper medical treatment by a doctor at the county hospital, their lawyer said.

headline: Should U.S. Courts Look Abroad for Guidance?
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Judge in New Orleans Will Hear Gulf Spill Cases
text: NEW ORLEANS  Hundreds of federal lawsuits filed over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill will be handled by a single judge here, a judicial panel announced Tuesday.

headline: Outlawing ‘Crush’ Videos: A Bill in the Senate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rwanda: Voting Irregularities Seen in Lopsided Victory
text: President Paul Kagame’s landslide victory in Rwanda’s presidential election Monday was “largely accurate,” despite shortcomings and irregularities, electoral observers said Tuesday. The chairman of the Commonwealth Observer Group, Dr. Salim Ahmed Salim, said the vote was organized and peaceful but lacked “critical opposition voices.” “There are shortcomings, but not fundamental shortcomings,” he said.

headline: Job Subsidies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Day Care Operators Are Accused of Bilking City Program for Working Poor
text: A group of day care center operators bribed workers at three New York City agencies and exploited the complex social service bureaucracy to loot millions of dollars from a program that pays child-care expenses for poor parents so they can find work, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Is This Education Reform?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wells Fargo Loses Ruling on Overdraft Fees
text: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered Wells Fargo to pay California customers $203 million in restitution for claims that it had manipulated transactions to maximize the overdraft fees it charged.

headline: Argentina Faulted for Reproductive Policies
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  The government of Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, has reversed steps toward protecting women’s health and reproductive rights, and backtracked on its intention to guarantee access to legal abortions, according to a Human Rights Watch report released Tuesday.

headline: With Woods Out Searching, Others Sense an Opportunity
text: HAVEN, Wis. — During 10 long months of prodding and probing under the microscope of public scrutiny, more has been forgotten about Tiger Woods than has been revealed. Each question about the turmoil in his life — on and off the course — has made it easier to forget that Woods once was closer to a sure thing than any golfer in history.

headline: California Hospital’s Plans
text: To the Editor:

headline: President Abbas and Peace Talks
text: Making peace between Israelis and Palestinians is somewhat like solving a Rubik’s Cube. You get one colored square lined up but the next one just won’t fall into place. So it is now. After three months of American-mediated proximity talks, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has agreed to direct negotiations on a two-state solution; the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, is stubbornly resisting. It is time for him to talk.

headline: Mickelson Has Psoriatic Arthritis
text: HAVEN, Wis.  Phil Mickelson revealed Tuesday that he had been battling a potentially debilitating condition known as psoriatic arthritis since the Sunday before the United States Open in June.

headline: Early Detection of Alzheimer’s
text: Scientists are making steady gains toward developing tests that can predict whether patients with mild cognitive difficulties or even no symptoms at all are likely to progress to full-blown Alzheimer’s disease. The latest research, published this week in the Archives of Neurology, a journal of the American Medical Association, found that a test of spinal fluid performed exceptionally well in identifying patients with Alzheimer’s or on the way to developing it.

headline: Leaving the Lower East Side
text: After years on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, the Nativity Mission School, which serves poor children, is planning a move.

headline: Wrong Answer at Indian Point
text: Ever since New York State ruled in the spring that the obsolete cooling system at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y., pollutes the Hudson River and kills too many fish, the plant’s owner, the Entergy Corporation, has been seeking public support for what it calls a “smarter solution” to the problem.

headline: The Well-Grounded Senator
text: Every 15 minutes of a senator’s waking life in Washington is fully scheduled with meetings, hearings and votes, and much of the rest is devoted to a frantic search for money to fuel the next campaign. “Of any free time you have, I would say 50 percent, maybe even more,” is spent on fund-raising, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa told the New Yorker recently in a scathing portrait of an overstressed and utterly ineffective legislative body, one that measures acts of real significance in the single digits per term.

headline: Pulling an All-Nighter for the College Application
text: Cree Bautista’s application for next year’s freshman class at New York University isn’t due until Jan. 1, but Cree, an incoming high school senior from Pflugerville, Tex., was not taking any chances.

headline: The First Common Application for the Class of ’15
text: This year’s version of the Common Application was due to be posted online around 12:01 a.m. on Aug. 1 — it wound up going up a few minutes earlier — and I wondered: How soon had the first application been sent in, by whom and why?

headline: Flight Attendant’s Tale Resonates, and Evolves
text: So who was that man who slid down the inflatable chute, beer in hand? Was he a folk hero, a real-life Howard Beale who found a way to channel his workaday frustrations? Or was he wrong to have his say on the intercom and then turn an expensive piece of airline equipment into a personal ejection device, probably in violation of federal regulations?

headline: Mexican States Ordered to Honor Gay Marriages
text: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that each of the country’s 31 states must recognize same-sex marriages registered in Mexico City, potentially giving gay and lesbian couples full matrimonial rights nationwide.

headline: Left-Handers Proving Tough on Yanks Hitters
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Jon Lester of Boston dissected the Yankees on Monday, less than a week after one of the Blue Jays’ prized left-handers, Ricky Romero, silenced them. Call it the continuation of a trend that has dogged them throughout the season.

headline: The Phenomenology of Ugly
text: This all started the day Luigi gave me a haircut. I was starting to look like a mad professor: specifically like Doc in “Back to the Future.” So Luigi took his scissors out and tried to fix me up. Except — and this is the point that occurred to me as I inspected the hair in the bathroom mirror the next morning — he didn’t really take quite enough off. He had enhanced the style, true, but there was a big floppy fringe that was starting to annoy me. And it was hot out. So I opened up the clipper attachment on the razor and hacked away at it for a while. When I finally emerged there was a general consensus that I looked like a particularly disreputable scarecrow. In the end I went to another barbershop (I didn’t dare show Luigi my handiwork) and had it all sheared off. Now I look like a cross between Britney Spears and Michel Foucault.

text: FOR years, the stereotypical Comic-Con International attendees were male comic book fans who gathered every year in San Diego to dress as their favorite superheroes and debate esoteric topics like which Green Lantern is the best ring slinger and whether Darth Vader wears socks.

headline: U.S. and Iraqi Interests May Work Against Pullout

headline: Harlem Shooting Account Is Made Clearer in Inquiry
text: When the first two gunshots rang out in Harlem early Sunday, Police Officer Douglas Brightman did what most people would not: He ran toward the sound. He was soon confronted by an armed man, according to an account later provided by his colleagues, who opened fire on the officer.

headline: Wednesday: Want Badly

headline: Angling for a Mentor, He’ll Take What He Can Get
text: Watch as clichés collide in “Secrets of the Trade,” the new play by Jonathan Tolins that kicks off Primary Stages’ new season at the 59E59 Theaters. The ageless story of a young showbiz aspirant suffering disillusion is cross-pollinated with a coming-out saga set in the 1980s. Spritzed with laughs but hobbled by these familiar narrative arcs, Mr. Tolins’s Neil Simon-ish comedy-drama also suffers from an egregious instance of miscasting.

headline: Connecticut Senate Race Poses Test for Democrats
text: Richard Blumenthal, the longtime Democratic attorney general of Connecticut, has been winning elections handily in the state for nearly two decades and seemed destined for higher office. But the woman who emerged from the Republican Senate primary on Tuesday night, Linda E. McMahon, is unlike any challenger he has faced.

headline: For Mosque Sponsors, Early Missteps Fueled Storm
text: Joy Levitt, executive director of the Jewish Community Center on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, remembers her first conversation with Daisy Khan around 2005, years before Ms. Khan’s idea for a Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan morphed into a controversy about Sept. 11, Islam and freedom of religion.

headline: Seeking Prompt Hearing, Rangel Vows to Stay Put
text: WASHINGTON  Facing serious accusations of violating House rules, Representative Charles B. Rangel offered an extended defense of his conduct on the House floor on Tuesday. He demanded a prompt ethics committee hearing and vowed to remain in office

headline: BP Station Owners Face Long Road to Recovery

headline: Study Looks at Tax Cut Lapse for Rich
text: WASHINGTON  As debate heats up over President Obama’s proposal to let the Bush tax cuts expire for the wealthy but to extend them for everyone else, a nonpartisan Congressional analysis circulated on Capitol Hill on Tuesday provides a look at the impact the plan would have on high-income taxpayers.

text: COLMA, Calif.  Sixty-six years after riding a B-24J Liberator on a bombing mission over Berlin, John P. Bonnassiolle is finally home.

headline: Sex, Marriage and Upper Class Obligation
text: Continuing our discussion from yesterday, Noah Millman raises an important question: If pressing ahead with gay marriage is the wrong response to the problems of post-sexual revolution America, then what is the right response? And aren’t the very people who are most likely to support gay marriage — the affluent and highly-educated — already doing their part to prop up the flagging marital ideal?

headline: Starting Over After World Cup, Brazil’s Future Tops United States’ Present
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the fading afterglow of one World Cup, the United States and Brazil met Tuesday ready to start the next cycle anew.

headline: Possible New Coach Has Eyes on Woods

Championship practice round at Whistling Straits on Tuesday. If he actually gets the job, it will come as a surprise to almost no one.

headline: Assessing H.P. After Mark Hurd

headline: Phys Ed: Can Exercise Moderate Anger?
text: For years, researchers have known that exercise can affect certain moods. Running, bike riding and other exercise programs have repeatedly been found to combat clinical depression. Similarly, a study from Germany published in April found that light-duty activity like walking or gardening made participants “happy,” in the estimation of the scientists. Even laboratory rats and mice respond emotionally to exercise; although their precise “moods” are hard to parse, their behavior indicates that exercise makes them more relaxed and confident.

headline: In Mission With Afghan Police, Issues of Trust
text: CHAHAR DARREH, Afghanistan — On paper, the plan for the foot patrol looked perfectly safe. A stroll through a couple of villages. Introductions to a few village elders. A two-mile drive back to the guarded walls of the Afghan police headquarters. Easy.

headline: A Year at War, Part Two
text: A lot happens during the first few weeks of a deployment, even if there’s not much action. Soldiers learn what it’s like to live without family and friends. They adjust to the rhythm of life at the F.O.B. (one syllable, rhymes with mob, stands for forward operating base). And soldiers start going out on their first serious missions. They get a taste of how much adrenaline, boredom and uncertainty the rest of the year will bring.

headline: The Making of Andrew Cuomo
text: LAST MONTH, ANDREW Cuomo took some time off from his job as New York’s attorney general, rented a recreational vehicle and drove upstate with his three daughters on an 11-day campaign swing with a little family vacation mixed in: “Camp Campaign” is how Cuomo joked about it with me. The trip infelicitously coincided with what turned out to be a historic heat wave across New York, and he couldn’t get the R.V.’s air-conditioning to work. At his first stop, a community college in Rockland County, Cuomo emerged from the Gulf Stream, his blazer slung uncharacteristically over his shoulder and a bead or two of sweat on his forehead, calling his new vehicle “a toaster oven on wheels.”

headline: Lady Thriller
text: Arnold Scaasi’s mostly over-the-top creations have adorned everyone from Mamie Eisenhower to Louise Nevelson, from glittering trophy wives flush with 1980s money to an order of nuns in Pennsylvania. ‘‘Scaasi: American Couturier,’’ a survey opening Sept. 25 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, showcases his designs for four of his most loyal clients: the actresses Arlene Francis and Barbra Streisand, and the socialites Joetta Norban and Gayfryd Steinberg. Sitting beneath a late Picasso in his Manhattan living room, with a view of ships sailing leisurely along the East River in the background, the couturier (born Arnold Isaacs in 1930) talked to Leslie Camhi about his half century of making a very select group of women feel special.

headline: City Haul
text: The Place du Grand Sablon in Brussels is nothing like West 47th Street in Manhattan, although you can pick up a nice little brooch in either locale. The square and its surrounding streets are dominated by smart town houses occupied by dealers of sumptuous period furniture, chocolate, rare books and all manner of art, including one that’s rarely mentioned in the same breath as sculpture and painting but is every bit as rarefied: costume jewelry made for the haute couture.

headline: Why We Need An Inflation Target
text: Look at the lower left-hand corner: the real interest rate on 5-year inflation-protected securities is now negative. In other words, prospects for other investments are so poor that some investors prefer a safe asset that doesn’t quite keep up with inflation.

headline: For Beach Residents, a Summer Nearly a Century Long Winds Down

headline: 2nd Quarter G.D.P. May Be Revised Even Lower

headline: The F Word
text: Fashion, which has always been as much a narrative about the body as it is about clothes, has rarely taken kindly to the idea of flesh. Much as we may wax nostalgic about the Rubenesque ideal or the buxom, wide-hipped wenches of Restoration comedies, in its modern iteration fashion has steadily downsized the human scale. Flesh suggests messiness, privileging the indiscipline of life over the fierce control of art, the unaerobicized body spilling over the contours of an artificial silhouette, be it Christian Dior’s New Look in 1947 or Marc Jacobs’s New Look for Louis Vuitton this fall. Flesh also suggests the threateningly female, moistness and blood, the hothouse clutches of a heavy-breasted mother  off-putting images for male fashion designers, who are more often than not gay. (Think of Karl Lagerfeld’s withering disdain on hearing that a German magazine would now be using only regular-size women in its fashion spreads: “No one wants to see curvy women. . . . You’ve got fat mothers with their bags of chips sitting in front of the television and saying that thin models are ugly.”)

headline: Chernobyl, Fires and Radiation
text: 8:25 p.m. | Updated There are some heated headlines out there as fires spring up in the zone contaminated by the Chernobyl nuclear reactor disaster. The reality, according to specialists in environmental risk from fires and radiation, is that any radiation contained in the resulting smoke and other emissions is very unlikely to pose a significant health risk [*with one exception possibly being in firefighters working in the area; see below].

headline: Flotilla Activists Fired First, Israeli Army Chief Testifies

headline: The Meaning Of 2.71

As you can see from the chart above, this puts it back where it was in the early spring of 2009 — higher than it was during the Oh-my-God-we’re-all-gonna-die period of winter 2008-2009, but lower than anything else we’ve seen for decades.

headline: Flight Attendant Had Long Imagined Escaping Down Chute

headline: Theater Talkback: Arizona, Immigration and Outrage

The playwright Theresa Rebeck wrote about the perils of being too funny, the composer Jason Robert Brown discussed the ethics of downloading sheet music, and the actor Marc Wolf considered the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy.

headline: One of the World’s Most Expensive Coffees Now in New York (For Sale or For Free)

headline: From Scottish Waters, the Freshest Catch

headline: Dollar Hits Low Against Yen, Dealing Blow to Japan’s Economy

headline: Anxiety Over Carry-Ons Fuels Air Wars
text: Updated | Tuesday, Aug. 17 As my colleague James Barron reports, Steven Slater, the fed-up JetBlue flight attendant who on Monday used an aircraft’s emergency slide to escape an unruly passenger and, most likely, his job, has already become, for some fans, “a folk hero, a real-life Howard Beale who found a way to channel his workaday frustrations.” But was the specific cause of the altercation that caused Mr. Slater to snap — a shortage of space on board the jet for carry-on bags — a symptom of larger societal problems or merely a sign that the way the airline industry has a major flaw in the way it deals with luggage?

headline: Community Coalition Created to Challenge N.Y.U. Expansion
text: A coalition of Greenwich Village community, preservation and parent groups has formed to register concerns about New York University’s expansion plans, after a previous task force was suspended by Scott Stringer, the Manhattan borough president. (Mr. Stringer’s office said he decided to suspend the task force and delegate the process to an existing community board as the project begins a formal public review this fall.)

headline: A Caution on Acid-Reducers for Older Patients

The book was a mystery story of sorts, written in luminous prose, about wartime secrets and repressed family memories, but more than a few copies were probably sold because of the evocative title alone.

headline: Lucy’s Kin Carved Up a Meaty Meal, Scientists Say

headline: Concern Over Centrists as G.O.P. Leans Right

headline: Dan Rostenkowski, Lawmaker, Is Dead at 82

He was 82 and also lived in Chicago, in the house where he grew up.

headline: Bloomberg Brushes Aside Paterson Proposal for Mosque

The designs, which were due on Tuesday, will be presented on Aug. 21 at a public kite flying showcase on Pier I at 70th Street in Riverside Park South. The project was organized by the New York City office of Architecture for Humanity, the New York City Department of Parks & Recreation and Architizer LLC.

headline: Fewer Jobless Workers Per Opening in June
text: In June, there were fewer than five unemployed workers for each job opening, according to new Labor Department data. That is a less discouraging ratio than earlier this year, but the improvement may mainly be a result of workers who have given up looking for a job.

headline: Will FreshDirect’s Changes Work?
text: In a case study we’ve just published, Jessica Bruder writes about FreshDirect, the Internet grocer, and its struggle to overcome an employment crisis at a time when it was hemorrhaging money and customers. The article focuses on a decision made by Richard S. Braddock, FreshDirect’s chief executive, in early 2008. Mr. Braddock decided that his company’s customer service was so poor that it had to stop soliciting new customers — its biggest source of revenue — until it figured out how to serve them. The risk, of course, was that the company would run out of money before it solved its problems.

headline: Turning Sausage Into Toad in the Hole
text: One weekend morning last spring I felt like having pancakes. But my wife, Jackie, was away in England visiting her father and getting his vegetable garden started, and the idea of making and eating pancakes in solitude didn’t really fly. I can almost hear some feel-gooder cooing, “Oh, but you’re worth it.” Horsefeathers. Where’s the fun in a one-man pancake breakfast?

headline: Just Don’t Let a Panda Borrow Your Bicycle
text: BAMBOO is one of the world’s fastest-growing plants, adding as much as three feet in a single day. That growth rate, along with the giant grass’s sturdy hollow stalks (with a strength-to-weight ratio similar to that of steel) may explain why bamboo is being heralded by bikers, environmentalists and social entrepreneurs as a material with no carbon footprint and the potential to provide cheap wheels in poor countries. Serious spandex-clad cyclists like bamboo bicycles, as do tattooed bike messengers and thrifty Ghanaian shopkeepers.

headline: The Worst Ethics Scandal on Capitol Hill?

headline: Paul Simon’s ‘Capeman’ Stalks Another Chance
text: “The Capeman,” Paul Simon’s ill-fated foray into the Broadway musical, was so spectacular and costly a flop that when it closed in 1998 after only 68 performances, it was hard to imagine it could ever have an afterlife. But time passes, memories fade, and tastes change, and so for three nights beginning Saturday, the Public Theater will be presenting a new, streamlined version of the show outdoors at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

headline: Now Dishing | Yotam Ottolenghi’s Fresh Fare
text: Vegetarians might have great complexions, but the members of the different sects — frutarians, pescetarians, lacto-vegetarians, vegans until 6 p.m. — seem defined not so much by what they enjoy eating as by what they refuse to put in their mouths.

headline: On Dawkins’s Atheism: A Response
text: My August 1 essay, “Philosophy and Faith,” was primarily addressed to religious believers. It argued that faith should go hand-in-hand with rational reflection, even though such reflection might well require serious questioning of their faith. I very much appreciated the many and diverse comments and the honesty and passion with which so many expressed their views. Interestingly, many of the most passionate responses came from non-believers who objected to my claim that popular atheistic arguments (like popular theistic arguments) do not establish their conclusions. There was particular dismay over my passing comment that the atheistic arguments of Richard Dawkins are “demonstrably faulty.” This follow-up provides support for my negative assessment. I will focus on Dawkins’ arguments in his 2006 book, “The God Delusion.”

headline: Waiting for a New U.S. Hope in a New Tennis World
text: TORONTO  For some 37 years, more than 1,900 weeks, ever since the ATP World Tour introduced computer rankings, an American has been in the top 10. Sometimes, there were two, or three, or more. But always, there was one.

headline: Polish One Off While They Polish Your Nails
text: IT was nearly 6 p.m. on Friday, an hour when many New Yorkers need a drink, and Sera Chi, the owner of the Dashing Diva nail salon on the Upper West Side, was greeting her regulars. “It’ll be about 45 minutes for a manicure,” she told them, “but you can have a Cosmo now.”

headline: Births to Illegal Immigrants Are Studied

headline: Recreating a Classic Video Game With Radio-Controlled Cars

Now, a German art collective has rendered that thrill tactile, using defiantly analog components: cardboard, glue and vintage-video-arcade kitsch.

headline: The Game Score Within the Score of the Game

Morrow’s Game Score of 100, as ESPN’s Buster Olney wrote in his blog, is the highest since Randy Johnson recorded a 100 during his 2004 perfect game.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Punjab and Elsewhere
text: The United Nations is appealing for $459 million to provide immediate help to millions of flood victims in Pakistan, The Associated Press reported. What the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs calls ”the worst monsoon-related floods in living memory” have affected more than 14 million people, and at least 6 million require immediate humanitarian assistance, including food, clean water, shelter and medical care. It said more than 1,200 people have died and at least 288,000 homes have been damaged or destroyed in the flooding.

headline: The Originals | Alia Raza
text: She may not be a household name, but the filmmaker Alia Raza is a name to watch and to drop. Raza, 32, is the creative force behind obscure film and video projects with fittingly abstruse titles like “The Fragile White Blossoms Emit a Hypnotic Cascade of Tropical Perfume Whose Sweet Heady Odor Leaves Its Victim Intoxicated.” Her dazzling cast of subjects is equally enigmatic: the teen blogger Tavi Gevinson, whom Raza recently filmed constructing a dress out of black silk and bubble gum; the artist Terence Koh, whom she had perform surgery on a white cake; and the celebutante-around-town Julia Restoin Roitfeld, who appears in Raza’s coming video project for Six Scents, a feminist take on the mythological Medusa figure. “Their notoriety is an element in the work,” Raza says of the socially prominent actors she picks. “Someone said what I do is like ‘Francesco Vezzoli going downtown,’ which is funny because I live on the Upper East Side.”

headline: Hoop Dreams

headline: The Evangelists for Heirloom Vegetables
text: Seed catalogs are what sustain most gardeners in the pit of winter, the pictures of bright blooms and fleshy melons stoking their fantasies. When my mother-in-law sent me the beautiful Baker Creek Heirloom Seeds catalog in February, it reanimated me, but it befuddled me too. There was an “olde tyme” painting of a melon on the cover, while the editor’s letter — “Let’s rock the food supply in 2010!” it implored — showed an attractive young family whose father has a thing for overalls and loud shirts. What followed was the cutting edge of heirloom seeds: 1,400 varieties from 70 countries, including vegetables yet to appear in any canvas market bag.

headline: Benevolence During a Brewers Broadcast
text: MILWAUKEE — On Tuesday night, the Brewers’ game against Arizona was televised without commercials. Instead, the breaks were filled with messages about the team’s foundation and on-air fundraising auctions.
