headline: In Four-Team Trade, the Nets Find a Power Forward
text: The Nets acquired forward Troy Murphy from Indiana in a four-team, five-player trade that sent guard Courtney Lee to Houston, the teams announced Wednesday. Wing player Trevor Ariza went from the Rockets to New Orleans, and the Hornets sent point guard Darren Collison and James Posey to the Pacers.

headline: Aspen Art Museum Moves Forward
text: The Aspen Art Museum, which is proceeding with the purchase of land in downtown Aspen, Colo., for the construction of a new building designed by the architect Shigeru Ban, has made public the design concept and preliminary model of the 30,000-square-foot wood-and-glass structure, above. The land acquisition, which requires confirmation by the City Council, is expected to be final in about 30 days. On Friday the museum announced the start of the second phase of its capital campaign with matching gifts of $5 million, adding to $28.5 million in existing pledges. The new building will include 12,500 square feet of exhibition space, a roof-deck sculpture garden, a classroom, museum shops, cafe, offices and storage.

headline: Letters: The Age of Laura Linney
text: Kudos to Frank Bruni for his informative and insightful cover story about the actress Laura Linney. Linney is one of those actresses who prompt me to see anything they perform in, because she has consistently made interesting and wise choices throughout her career. I put her in that special class of actresses — along with Meryl Streep, Marisa Tomei and Julianne Moore — who choose the work because the role seems right for them at the time, not necessarily for the money.

headline: TwitPic’s Creator Has a New Project, Heello
text: Before Noah Everett started TwitPic, a photo sharing service for people who use Twitter, he had bigger plans in mind: he wanted to build tools that made the Web an easier place to work.

headline: Letters: Plus-Size Wars
text: Thank you to Ginia Bellafante for giving this strange purgatory a name, for I have been on “the bridge” between “regular” and “plus” for most of my adult life. My choices are between too-tight pants and the dreaded droopy crotch; crossing the divide from “women’s” to “plus” always seems to involve a humiliating trip through “maternity.” I hope Bellafante’s article is being passed around the apparel industry as a message: make me a stylish, form-fitting outfit of natural fibers, and I’ll give you my cold, hard cash.

headline: Letters: Unnatural Science
text: In The Medium, the usually fair-minded Virginia Heffernan excoriates the science-blogging community in because of some offensive or silly posts. Science blogs serve a valuable educational function, but they are uneven and cacophonous — just like the mainstream media. If some bloggers sound desperate and strident, it’s possibly because even into the 21st century, only 39 percent of Americans believe in evolution and one out of five believes the Sun revolves around the Earth.

headline: Letters: I Tweet, Therefore I Am
text: Connected? Or clamoring for attention? I fear as a parent, a therapist and a cranky 50-year-old that all this Twittering, texting, Facebooking and blogging neglects the No. 1 developmental task — to know thyself and not give much of a whit what others think.

headline: Bullock To Remain In Oil-Spill Campaign
text: Sandra Bullock, an Academy Award winner for “The Blind Side” and a New Orleans resident, has agreed to remain part of a celebrity video to draw attention to the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Last month she threatened to withdraw amid questions about the corporate sponsorship of the group organizing the campaign. “We are happy that Ms. Bullock has reviewed the facts of the RestoretheGulf.com campaign,” Anne Milling, founder of Women of the Storm, which began the effort, said in a statement. “She and the other celebrities have been instrumental in rallying national support for restoration of our beaches, wetlands and Gulf Coast environment.” The campaign’s first goal is to gather signatures demanding a fully financed, environmentally sustainable effort to restore the Gulf Coast; the group has collected more than 127,000 signatures. The video, called “Be the One,” in which performers who live in or are connected with the Gulf Coast, includes Wendell Pierce, Harry Shearer, Dr. John and Lenny Kravitz.

headline: Global Youth Unemployment Reaches New High
text: PARIS  Youth unemployment across the world has climbed to a new high and is likely to climb further this year, a United Nations agency said Thursday, while warning of a “lost generation” as more young people give up the search for work.

headline: Coalition to Challenge N.Y.U. Expansion
text: A coalition of Greenwich Village community, preservation and parent groups has formed to register concerns about New York University’s expansion plans, after a previous task force was suspended by Scott Stringer, the Manhattan borough president. (Mr. Stringer’s office said he decided to suspend the task force and delegate the process to an existing community board as the project begins a formal public review this fall.) The new coalition  called the Community Action Alliance on N.Y.U. 2031  is pushing to ensure that the recommendations of the original task force are adopted by elected officials and the local community board, which have not yet taken a position on the plan. The plan, known as N.Y.U. 2031, calls for adding six million square feet of classrooms, dormitories and offices over the next 20 years on the core campus and other locations. In letter sent Friday the new alliance urged elected officials to have the university consider alternative locations, like the financial district, insisting that the proposal “is too much” and would “inalterably destroy the quality of our community.” Above, a protest at N.Y.U. in April.

headline: Waiting in the Wings to Be Chief G.O.P. Dealmaker
text: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers head home this week for what remains of summer, one question transfixes Washington: Will Democrats lose control of the House and possibly even the Senate in November, or will they hang on to fragile majorities?

headline: Designers Donate Their Archives
text: The designers Massimo and Lella Vignelli have donated their archives to the Rochester Institute of Technology, where the collection will be available to professional designers and scholars. The archive contains original source materials, along with examples of finished work  including their corporate identity programs, jewelry, silverware and furniture. The Vignelli Collection will be part of the Vignelli Center for Design Studies, a three-story complex on the campus. The center officially opens with a ceremony on Sept. 16. The university is already home to the archives of the American Modernist graphic design pioneers Lester Beall, Will Burtin, Cipe Pineles, Alvin Lustig and William Golden, among others.

headline: Smackdown at P.G.A. as Gray and Pavin Trade Barbs
text: HAVEN, Wis. — A scene right out of a World Wrestling Entertainment event erupted at the staid P.G.A. Championship on Wednesday when Jim Gray of the Golf Channel called the United States Ryder Cup captain Corey Pavin “a liar” and told him, “You’re going down.”

headline: New York Kicks
text: New Yorkers missed out on the basketball superstar LeBron James flaunting his Nikes for the Knicks or Nets when the signed with the Miami Heat last month. However, arm-chair athletes in Manhattan and Brooklyn (the future home of the Nets), the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island can flaunt their own moves in sneakers honoring the five boroughs. Nike’s limited-edition Air Force 1 Borough Pack features different colors, logos and laces for each of the city’s boroughs.

headline: Social Security Madness
text: Has the Washington Post gone mad? asks Dean Baker, reading the Post’s latest editorial on Social Security. The answer is no: it has been mad all along.

headline: LED Bulb Edges Below $20
text: This week, Home Depot fired a new marketing salvo in what is expected to be a broader national effort to get home customers to adopt LED lighting.

headline: Jan Maxwell to Star in Revival of ‘Wings’
text: Jan Maxwell will star in the revival of Arthur Kopit’s 1978 play “Wings” at Second Stage Theater, the theater announced on Wednesday. The play, directed by John Doyle (“Sweeney Todd,” “Company”), begins previews on Oct. 5 and opens on Oct. 24. Mr. Kopit’s Tony-nominated play follows the adventures of Emily Stilson, a 1920s wing walker. The cast also includes Teagle F. Bougere, Beth Dixon, January LaVoy, Anne L. Nathan and Michael Warner.

headline: First in a Decade: Living Novelist on Cover
text: The issue of Time magazine on sale Friday will feature Jonathan Franzen on the cover, below, the first time that a living American novelist has garnered that honor since Stephen King, in 2000. The accompanying article, by Lev Grossman, is a profile of Mr. Franzen on the occasion of his fourth novel, “Freedom,” the story of an American family that is due to be published this month. In the past Time has featured Tom Wolfe, Toni Morrison, George Orwell, John Updike, John Le Carré, Norman Mailer and other writers.

headline: Sunny Scenes, Direct From Pyongyang
text: VIENNA

headline: NBC Wins Tuesday
text: NBC won the ratings race on Tuesday as the 10-year-old singer Jackie Evancho stunned audiences with a “Susan Boyle moment” on “America’s Got Talent.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.4 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. to the two-hour talent show. CBS placed second on the night, outpacing NBC’s repeat of “Minute to Win It” (5 million) in the 8 p.m. hour with a rerun of “NCIS” (8.6 million). Fox ranked third over all, earning 7.1 million viewers for the season finale of “Hell’s Kitchen” followed by 6.1 million for the third installment of “MasterChef.” Despite their modest audiences, the two culinary reality shows helped Fox win the night in the sought-after demographic of adults 18 to 49. ABC finished in fourth place with “Wipeout” at 8 (7.9 million), “Shaq Vs.” at 9 (3.9 million) and “Primetime” at 10 (4.2 million).

headline: Wanda Sykes to Watch Orphans in ‘Annie’
text: The comedian Wanda Sykes, below, is no stranger to theatricality. Best known for her ribald stand-up comedy and appearances on TV shows including “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” and as host of her own late-night talk show, Ms. Sykes is to take on a new, unexpectedly theatrical role: that of the orphanage matron Miss Hannigan in a revival of the musical “Annie,” beginning this fall at the Media Theater near Philadelphia. Ms. Sykes is scheduled to appear in the production from Nov. 23 through Dec. 12, and again from Jan. 12 to 16, leaving the role over the holidays to fill other commitments, according to a spokesman for the theater. “Having watched her with her stand-up, her timing and the inherent talent that she has with comedy, is something she can really use in the show,” said Jesse Cline, the theater’s artistic director. And if you have ever dreamed of performing onstage with Ms. Sykes  and who hasn’t?  now’s your chance. Auditions for the roles of the orphans will be held at the theater on Aug. 21. Auditions for the show’s adult roles will be held on Aug. 23.

headline: Details Emerge About Alaska Crash Rescue
text: Rescue workers, rain-soaked and mud-caked, had to hike through a dense Alaska forest to reach the four survivors of the small plane crash that killed the former Senator Ted Stevens and four other people Monday night, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said on Wednesday.

headline: Happy ‘Secular Pakistan Day’
text: As Pakistan’s government continues to vie with Islamist charities to provide relief to millions of its citizens affected by catastrophic flooding, two posts on Lahore’s Pak Tea House blog are worth reading.

headline: Producers Put a Theater in Their Own Backyard
text: FOURTEEN years ago, Barry and Fran Weissler took “Chicago,” a Broadway show that had done well at the box office but was received coolly by critics, and turned the revival into a hit that generated front-page reviews and drop-dead ticket sales.

headline: Amazon Digital Discount Helps Arcade Fire Hit No. 1
text: The indie kids made it to No. 1, with a little help from Amazon.com.

headline: The Mirthless Senate
text: The United States Senate, which still flatters itself with the misnomer “the world’s greatest deliberative body,” counts a former Major League Baseball player,  an organic wheat farmer, far too many lawyers and a member who  describes herself as a mom in tennis shoes among its select 100.

headline: Blagojevich Jury Tells Judge It’s Deadlocked
text: CHICAGO  Unable to reach a unanimous decision on several counts in the wide-ranging corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, jurors sent a note late Wednesday to the presiding judge asking for advice. It was the 11th day of deliberations, and the judge, James B. Zagel, told lawyers for the defense and prosecutors that he would advise the jury to keep working at reaching at least some consensus.

headline: After Uproar, Knicks and Thomas Call Deal Off
text: Five days after the Knicks startled the basketball world by announcing that Isiah Thomas would return as a part-time consultant to the team with which he had a disastrous run as president and coach, the whole arrangement was called off.

headline: A Family Legacy of Mental Illness
text: Family legacies are passed down in stories and keepsakes and history books and genes.

headline: Provocative Artist Fights for Return to P.S. 1
text: It’s Ann Liv Young versus P.S. 1, Round 2.

headline: Phillips Collection’s New Bonsai Sculpture
text: All wood products, when you think about it, are made of dead wood. But few have the poignancy of Phillips Collection’s new “end of life” Bonsai Sculpture Collection: dead bonsai trees or branches from Thailand that have been bleached and mounted on iron bases, and, as shown, can be placed in a shapely polished aluminum and resin vase.

headline: Tiffany Reinvents Vases From Its Archives
text: Tiffany & Company is introducing six small vases inspired by pieces made by Louis Comfort Tiffany and Tiffany Studios between 1906 and 1913. Four bone-china vases, above, were introduced last month; two sterling-silver ones will be available on Sept. 1.

headline: ‘Garden Guide: New York City’
text: The revised edition of Nancy Berner and Susan Lowry’s “Garden Guide: New York City” (W. W. Norton; $22.95) has the same number of gardens as the original 2002 edition (100) but 25 of them are new.

headline: Sales at Fred Flare and Michele Varian
text: Fred Flare, a clothing, gift and accessories boutique in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is discounting a selection of electronics, in the store and online, through Aug. 31 (the Keepsake USB Turntable, above, originally $165, is $149; the Crosley USB tech turntable, above right, regularly $150, is $129; the Lego digital camera, originally $102, is $75); 131 Meserole Avenue (Leonard Street), Brooklyn, (718) 349-1257 or fredflare.com.

headline: Paulo Mendes da Rocha’s Chaise Is Re-Released
text: It has been 25 years since Paulo Mendes da Rocha, a Brazilian architect, designed the PMR outdoor chaise.

headline: Portable Housing, Made in Montana
text: BOZEMAN, Mont.

headline: Quilts With Attitude
text: Boo Davis, a Seattle-based quilter, uses traditional techniques to create designs that feature skulls or a devil-horns hand sign.

headline: A Purple Martin Birdhouse Tour
text: The swallows depend on humans for their housing, which is designed to attract.

headline: Boo Davis, Alt-Quilter
text: Boo Davis likes to say that she makes quilts “just like your metal-loving, half-blind grandma would.” An Ozzy Osbourne, Metallica and all-around thrash-metal fan from way back, Ms. Davis, 36, became an alt-craft darling by using traditional quilting techniques to create head-banging designs featuring skulls or a devil horn’s hand sign, under the label Quiltsryche. After a flurry of press in Seattle, her hometown, and in magazines like ReadyMade and Bust, she got a book deal. “Dare to Be Square Quilting,” published this month by Potter Craft ($21.99), is the result. Eagerly rifling its pages for patterns like “God Bless the Children of the Beast” — the title of a Motley Crue classic that Ms. Davis built a quilt around — this reporter found instead a fairly tame handful of designs. There’s a fine skull, to be sure, but also an owl, a deer head and a clock face, among other patterns that “skew more cute than evil,” to borrow a phrase from Ms. Davis. It’s a sound quilting book, and readers will learn from it, but they may miss her subversive side.

headline: Birdhouses Designed for Repeat Visitors
text: AFTER a long day at work, Chuck Abare, 63, a computer designer, likes to sit on the porch of his two-story ranch house on the outskirts of Huntsville, Ala., drink a gin and tonic, and watch the antics of the purple martins winging around his backyard.

headline: Down the Aisle With the Help of Pocket Wedding Planners
text: Wedding planners are great for couples who have the money to hire a professional.

headline: A Home on a Slope, With Floors to Match
text: CERNIN, Czech Republic

headline: This Teenage Girl Uses Botox. No, She’s Not Alone.
text: LAST month, Charice Pempengco, the petite Filipino teenager whose knockout voice has wowed Oprah and millions worldwide, caused a stir of another kind.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: SHADOW ME, BABY American women love eye makeup: sales hit $1.08 billion in 2009, up 38 percent from 2004, versus an 11 percent increase in the overall color cosmetics market, to $2.52 billion, according to a new report from Mintel. Just in time for Estée Lauder, which is releasing the new 48-shade Pure Color EyeShadow line this month.

headline: Quick Change in Strategy for a Bookseller
text: In the movie “You’ve Got Mail,” Tom Hanks played the aggressive big-box retailer Joe Fox driving the little bookshop owner played by Meg Ryan out of business.

headline: Officer Sues to Block His Discharge Under Gay Ban
text: In early 2008, just eight days before he was to deploy in support of the war in Afghanistan, Lt. Col. Victor Fehrenbach, a decorated Air Force flight officer, was told he was under investigation on charges of sexually assaulting a civilian and of violating the military’s ban on homosexuality.

headline: Missing Buttons in Outlook
text: Q. I just upgraded to Outlook 2007 and there is no Send button on my e-mail toolbar. What do I do?

headline: Fantasy Football: The Flexible Draft Strategy
text: Jason and Justin Sablich, The Times’s in-house fantasy football experts, are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season and are now on Twitter.

headline: It’s Hard to Figure Out the Coaching Pioneers
text: Baseball is a game of statistics based on years of meticulous record-keeping. But one area of the game that is often overlooked is information on coaches.

headline: In State Primary, Few Clues About Voter Attitudes
text: NEW HAVEN — With each state primary being scrutinized for signs of what is to come nationally in November, Connecticut voters threw off few cues Tuesday night. Jobs? Yes, voters said. Anger? Yes. But throw out the status quo? Hardly.

headline: Georgia Congressman No Fan of Palin Endorsements
text: It seems fair to say that Representative Jack Kingston, a Georgia Republican, didn’t appreciate that Sarah Palin inserted herself into the G.O.P.’s gubernatorial primary in his state.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. JetBlue’s Steven Slater flees job site via inflatable slide. Disgruntled postal worker meets Nanny McPhee.

headline: The Caucus With Richard Blumenthal
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Democrat Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut's attorney general and a candidate for the open Senate seat.

headline: The Caucus With Linda McMahon
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Linda McMahon, a Republican candidate for the open Senate in Connecticut.

headline: Britain: Antiterror Commercial Banned
text: Britain’s advertising watchdog has banned an antiterrorism commercial that urged radio listeners to watch out for people who keep their curtains drawn, keep away from their neighbors and pay with cash instead of debit or credit cards, behavior that senior police officers said could “potentially be linked to terrorist activities.” The Advertising Standards Agency, an industry-appointed body, said it made the ruling after concluding that law-abiding people with similar habits could be offended. The advertisement, paid for by the Association of Chief Police Officers, featured a narrator saying: “The man at the end of the street doesn’t talk to his neighbors much because he likes to keep to himself. He pays with cash because he doesn’t have a bank card, and he keeps his curtains closed because his house is on a bus route.” The narrator concluded, “If you suspect it, report it.”

headline: Fund Managers Face a Conflict
text: It stands to reason that the more money flowing to a particular investment strategy, the more likely returns will diminish. By logical extension, fund managers should therefore occasionally say no to new cash to keep from hurting performance. But in the money business, that’s easier said than done, especially when considering the growing number of alternative asset managers that are publicly traded.

headline: The Caucus With Joe Sestak
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Representative Joe Sestak, the Democrats' candidate for the open Senate seat in Pennsylvania.

headline: China’s Economy, While Still Surging, Begins Showing Signs of Moderation
text: HONG KONG  In the latest signs that the Chinese economy is beginning to cool after setting a torrid pace in the first half of this year, several government indicators slowed slightly last month, Beijing announced on Wednesday.

headline: Lebanon: Tribunal Turns to Hezbollah
text: The international tribunal investigating the 2005 killing of a former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, requested Wednesday that Hezbollah turn over evidence that the militant group says implicates Israel in the assassination. On Monday, Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s leader, presented what he said were videotaped confessions, maps and previously unreleased Israeli spy videos that he said pointed to Israel as the culprit in Mr. Hariri’s killing. Mr. Nasrallah has said in earlier speeches that the tribunal was planning to indict Hezbollah members in the killing, and he has accused the tribunal of distorting its findings to suit a political agenda.

headline: Is Shredding Over? Not So Fast
text: AT a glance there is not much glamour in a coat or T-shirt that seems to have been run through a Cuisinart. But to Joie Reinstein, that sort of diced and shredded look, which she first glimpsed two years ago in a Rodarte show, represented the tatty quintessence of chic. The collection “featured those crazy clothes with holes in them,” she recalled. “When it was released on the runway, it felt different from everything else.”

headline: Antibiotic-Resistant Bacteria Moving From South Asia to U.S.
text: A dangerous new mutation that makes some bacteria resistant to almost all antibiotics has become increasingly common in India and Pakistan and is being found in patients in Britain and the United States who got medical care in those countries, according to new studies.

headline: Celebrating Scandal
text: THE crisp invitation, edged in a striped border and lettered in Art Deco capitals, arrived on a sultry summer afternoon. Dawn Davis, an editor at HarperCollins, was beckoning literary hedonists to a “Bolter” party, to celebrate the “scandalous life” of Idina Sackville  the aristocrat who shocked Britain in 1919 with her divorce from the most eligible bachelor of her generation, and then decamped to Kenya, leaving her two toddler sons behind. She went on to marry and divorce four other men (earning her the nickname the Bolter), while cavorting with countless others.

headline: Chinese Hospitals Are Battlegrounds of Discontent
text: SHENYANG, China  Forget the calls by many Chinese patients for more honest, better-qualified doctors. What this city’s 27 public hospitals really needed, officials decided last month, was police officers.

headline: First in a Decade: A Living Novelist on Time’s Cover
text: The new cover of Time Magazine, on sale Friday, will feature Jonathan Franzen on the cover, the first time in 10 years that a living American novelist has been on the cover since Stephen King, in 2000.

headline: Northeast Heat: The Harwood Interviews
text: 9:48 p.m. | Updated John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC caught up with candidates in some of the region’s most hotly contested Senate races. He asks Linda McMahon, the Republican nominee and former wrestling mogul, if her original support of the bailout would be a “kick in the groin” to Connecticut tax payers and draws out disagreements with President Obama of her Democratic opponent, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal. In Pennsylvania, Mr. Harwood grills Representative Joe Sestak, a Democrat, about whether Medicare and Social Security must face cuts, while his Republican opponent, former Representative Pat Toomey, discusses why he was against the bank bailouts during the financial crisis.

headline: The Age of Austerity Challenges Stonehenge
text: STONEHENGE, England  The prehistoric monument of Stonehenge stands tall in the British countryside as one of the last remnants of the Neolithic Age. Recently it has also become the latest symbol of another era: the new fiscal austerity.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,207 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: JetBlue’s Response to a Fed-Up Employee’s Exit
text: THE marketers and image-makers of Madison Avenue are asking each other, “What would you do if you were JetBlue?”

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Net Neutrality
text: On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast,  Brian Stelter, a Times media reporter, drops by to chat about Internet access regulation with J.D. Biersdorfer and Bettina Edelstein. The so-called net neutrality plan of Google and Verizon would exempt wireless and some other online services from rules for maintaining open access to the Internet, and Mr. Stelter says that while the two companies  appear to be staking out their ground now, other wireless carriers and media companies are watching and waiting as the Federal Communications Commission looks at ways of regulating broadband.

headline: Judges Reprise Testimony in Third Trial on Threats
text: Once again, one after another, three celebrated federal appeals judges from Chicago slid into the low seat just to the right of their usual, estimable perches.

headline: Antonio Pettigrew, Sprinter Who Doped, Dies at 42
text: Antonio Pettigrew, who gave up his 2000 Olympic sprint-relay gold medal after admitting to doping, was found dead Tuesday in his car near his North Carolina home. Pettigrew, an assistant track coach at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill for the past four seasons, was 42.

headline: ING Group Posts a Profit in the Wake of a Bailout
text: ING Group, the financial services company based in the Netherlands, said Wednesday that its net profit for the second quarter climbed to 1.09 billion euros, about $1.4 billion, more than 15 times the amount a year ago.

headline: Opposing Campaigns, With One Unlikely Link
text: ALBANY  One candidate for governor, Carl Paladino, is a staunch conservative and a self-styled Tea Party activist who is mounting a serious challenge for the Republican nomination.

headline: Farmers Lean to Truce on Animals’ Close Quarters
text: WEST MANSFIELD, Ohio  Concessions by farmers in this state to sharply restrict the close confinement of hens, hogs and veal calves are the latest sign that so-called factory farming  a staple of modern agriculture that is seen by critics as inhumane and a threat to the environment and health  is on the verge of significant change.

headline: For Fed, the Choices Get Harder
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The First Wave of Weary Aides Heads for the Exits
text: WASHINGTON  Linda Douglass slept nearly 12 hours the day after she left her job as a communications aide at the White House. And the day after that and the day after that. It took two weeks until she finally felt rested.

headline: Odds Defied? Malloy Knows the Territory
text: As a child, Dannel P. Malloy was not given much of a chance. “I was diagnosed as mentally retarded as late as the fourth grade,” he recalled. His mother, he added, would not accept that.

headline: Cousin Claudine Has New Stretch Bracelets
text: COUSIN CLAUDINE is making a new version of its popular stack of stretch bracelets, composed of multiple rows of beads. The brown beads look like wood but are dyed horn, interspersed with gold rings, beads and crystal balls (below, $145).

headline: Front Row: Souk-Seeing
text: Anna Sui takes a long shopping trip on "Man Shops Globe."

headline: Say Goodbye to Fannie and Freddie
text: Elkton, Md.

headline: Expert on Morality Is on Leave After Research Inquiry
text: Marc Hauser, a Harvard academic who gained prominence with the publication of a book on the origin of morality, has gone on leave after an investigation by the university into problems with his research.

headline: Anything to Declare? Well, Let’s Start With ...
text: CITING exotic travel destinations as a design inspiration is about as original as pinning a collection on “The Eyes of Laura Mars” or anything starring Tilda Swinton. But Anna Sui has a gift for mining fashion gold from her trips around the world, which makes her an ideal guest for a show like “Man Shops Globe,” the Sundance Channel series that follows Keith Johnson, the globe-trotting buyer at large for Anthropologie.

headline: Debts Rise, and Go Unpaid, as Bust Erodes Home Equity
text: PHOENIX  During the great housing boom, homeowners nationwide borrowed a trillion dollars from banks, using the soaring value of their houses as security. Now the money has been spent and struggling borrowers are unable or unwilling to pay it back.

headline: Too Big Not to Fail
text: THE Obama administration is set to discuss the future of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage giants that largely escaped reform in the financial overhaul of the Dodd-Frank law, at the Treasury Department on Tuesday.

headline: Beltran Clears Waivers
text: Carlos Beltran cleared waivers, as expected. An executive with a major league club who had knowledge of the transaction confirmed a report by FoxSports.com on Tuesday saying Beltran had gone unclaimed.

headline: The 30-Year Prison
text: Los Angeles

headline: The Shopping Urge Can Hit Anytime
text: OLIVE & BETTE’S, one of the pioneers of the Bleecker Street shopping corridor, has shuttered one store and is opening a new one at 1249 Third Avenue (at 72nd Street), (212) 206-0036, oliveandbettes.com.

headline: ‘Jersey’ Seems to Be the Word
text: Four questions for Joseph Quartana (above), buyer, Seven New York, sevennewyork.com.

headline: A Fortissimo First for the Philharmonic
text: Ever since the New York Philharmonic was founded in 1842, the orchestra’s brass section  horn, trumpet, trombone, bass trombone, tuba  had been a man’s world. Then Amanda Davidson auditioned. A graduate of the Juilliard School with a passion for Mahler, Brahms and ESPN, Mrs. Davidson, 28, became the brass section’s first female member last September, having previously been principal trombonist of the San Antonio Symphony. (She competed for the Philharmonic job with Mark Davidson, 27, whom she was dating and later married.) Her title is associate principal trombone, an instrument with which she is familiar. She has been playing it since she was 6.

headline: More American Idols
text: I have been thinking about the fact that Colorado Republicans rejected their front-running candidate for governor, Scott McInnis, apparently on the grounds that he committed plagiarism.

headline: Suit Sees Lead Risk in Bounce Houses
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It may be one of the most beloved activities of hyperactive children and the parents who love them: bouncing in a bounce house. But, according to Attorney General Jerry Brown of California, it may also be toxic.

headline: The Game and the Shoe
text: A POP-UP museum and store have opened in Harlem to celebrate basketball and sneaker heritage, as part of the World Basketball Festival hosted by Nike, Jordan and Converse. The store is selling T-shirts highlighting the national basketball teams competing in exhibition games (left, $30 off the rack, $35 customized).

headline: Out of Office, Ted Stevens Kept Influence
text: ANCHORAGE — In the spring of 2009, shortly after a federal judge threw out a guilty verdict in a corruption case against Ted Stevens, a longtime pollster for the senator conducted a quiet survey.

headline: Tour of Guantánamo Offers a Look, but Little Else
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba  Welcome to Guantánamo Bay, where your tour guide will never leave your side but may not be able to answer any of your questions.

text: There he goes again. What gets me is how unprofessional the whole thing is.

headline: U.S. Provides Additional Helicopters to the Relief Effort
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday that the United States would triple the number of military helicopters deployed to assist Pakistan in flood relief.

headline: Despite Scandal, Rangel Draws a Crowd
text: It was a dramatic but fitting start to an evening that brimmed with political defiance. About 5:45 p.m. Wednesday, as guests began strolling into the Plaza Hotel to celebrate Representative Charles B. Rangel’s 80th birthday, former Mayor David N. Dinkins turned to confront a heckler.

headline: For Attendant, Spotlight Is ‘Overwhelming’
text: Steven Slater, the JetBlue flight attendant who cursed out a passenger on the intercom and then slid out of the plane feet first, had long daydreamed about deploying an escape chute. But he never thought he would.

headline: Unrest Is Undermining Hopes for Afghan Vote
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Worsening insurgent violence in many parts of the country is raising concern about Afghanistan’s ability to hold a fair parliamentary election in little more than a month, a crucial test of President Hamid Karzai’s ability to deliver security and a legitimate government.

headline: Ryan Seeks Team Sit-Down With Revis
text: CORTLAND, N.Y.  After every morning practice, Jets Coach Rex Ryan, usually wearing green, strides into a small room in the Carl “Chugger” Davis Building near the prim fields and takes a spot behind a lectern with a State University of New York Cortland seal on the front.

headline: Tibetan Writer’s Intellectual Journey Leads to Trial
text: BEIJING  If Tragyal was surprised when the police showed up at his office in April, he did not show it, his co-workers say. If anything, he wondered what had taken them so long.

headline: NASA Tracks Pollution Flow from Russian Fires
text: .NASA has released video showing the pall of pollution spreading from the wildfires in and around Russia. (Here’s a satellite-generated map of the fires.) The animation was created using data from the Atmospheric Infrared Sounder instrument on NASA’s Aqua satellite. The colors reflect levels of carbon monoxide at an altitude of about 18,000 feet, with the gas providing an indirect indicator of other emissions.

headline: Posey Starts Even Better Than Giants Had Hoped
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When Buster Posey was a junior at Florida State, Mike Martin Jr., the assistant coach, told scouts what to expect if they drafted him.

headline: A Redacted View of Guantánamo Bay
text: Before they are allowed to take pictures inside the detention camps at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, photographers must consent to have all their photos reviewed by military public affairs officials.

headline: Bloggingheads: Beating Childhood Obesity
text: Dana Goldstein, left, of The Daily Beast and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate the role of schools in fighting childhood obesity.

headline: When the Fed Speaks
text: It was a statement of the obvious heard around the world. The Federal Reserve policy committee said on Tuesday that the economy had slowed recently and was not expected to improve anytime soon. Together with evidence of slower growth in China and Europe, the “news” sparked a global sell-off in stocks on Wednesday. At the same time, prominent private forecasts for growth in the second quarter were revised downward from a preliminary reading of 2.4 percent in the United States to less than 2 percent.

headline: President Kagame’s Win in Rwanda
text: There were no surprises in Rwanda’s election this week. Not the winner  President Paul Kagame  or the overwhelming nature of his victory, which official figures put at 93 percent. He made it impossible for the results to be anything different.

headline: Listen to Congressman Rangel
text: Representative Charles Rangel may have given ethics reform an unintended boost when he took the House floor on Tuesday to attack the ethics committee and ended up underlining the pervasive power of money in politics. “I am not going away,” declared the once-powerful New York lawmaker as fellow Democrats winced.

headline: Unneeded Bureaucracy at Ground Zero
text: As the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan moves ahead with renewed energy, there is one dismal exception to the progress at the former World Trade Center site. That is the muddle at the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, an extra layer of bureaucracy originally set up to get the rebuilding started. Nine years later, the corporation has become an impediment. It needs to finish its few remaining tasks and disband.

headline: Bookseller Seeks Deal With Investor
text: Barnes & Noble is close to a deal with the investment vehicle of the billionaire Ronald W. Burkle over a potential settlement that would avoid a protracted fight over the board at the bookseller, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: Bystander Injured in Harlem Episode Cites ‘Contagious Shooting’ in Plan to Sue
text: A Bronx man wounded in Harlem on Sunday in a fatal shooting involving the police suggests in legal papers filed Wednesday that he was a victim of “contagious shooting” by officers, evoking dark chapters in the New York Police Department’s recent history.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Immune Disorder Could Be an Enduring Test for Mickelson
text: HAVEN, Wis.  Bob Murphy won the Canadian Open in 1986 without playing a single hole of practice beforehand. Instead, he spent all his time in the whirlpool and steam room, popping ibuprofen and wondering what part of his body would hurt when he awoke the next day.

headline: Faltering Harlem Housing Deal Won City Cash
text: In the early 1990s, with New York City eager to find creative ways of rehabilitating its troubled neighborhoods, it struck a multimillion-dollar deal with the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce: The city sold the chamber a collection of dilapidated Harlem apartment buildings for a nominal amount, and arranged for close to $10 million in low-cost loans to help fix and restore the buildings.

headline: Barnes & Noble Nears Deal to Avert Proxy Fight
text: 10:50 p.m. | Updated Barnes & Noble is near a deal with Yucaipa to avoid a proxy fight, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday night. If a deal is not reached, Yucaipa would be prepared to file materials for a proxy fight as soon as Thursday morning.

headline: Thursday: Facts
text: “NOW, what I want is, Facts. Teach these boys and girls nothing but Facts. Facts alone are wanted in life.” — Hard Times by Charles Dickens

headline: Rubin to Join Centerview, a Young Firm
text: Robert E. Rubin is returning to Wall Street.

headline: A Stage Full of Abes: Are Any of Them Honest?
text: Heaven knows a seductive title can be tempting. “Abraham Lincoln’s Big, Gay Dance Party,” for example. Granted, this grabber would not be much of a draw in American burgs that prefer tea at their parties, figuratively speaking. But for certain subsets of the culture — New Yorkers with puckish senses of humor, say — it’s likely to be pure catnip.

headline: Thomas Deal Succumbs to Full-Court Pressure
text: The Isiah Thomas-New York Knicks caper is over.

headline: Mets’ Closer Is Arrested in Assault After Loss
text: Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez was charged with third-degree assault after an altercation with his father-in-law at Citi Field on Wednesday, the police said.

headline: Red Bulls Display Some of Their Star Power in Victory
text: HARRISON, N.J.  Global soccer stars have been shuttling into the United States all summer, some playing exhibitions for national teams or foreign clubs, others as designated players in the domestic league.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 11
text: A view of the day in sports, including swimming, diving, soccer and preparations for the P.G.A. Championship.

headline: David L. Wolper, Producer of Groundbreaking ‘Roots’, Is Dead at 82
text: David L. Wolper, an award-winning movie and television producer best known for the groundbreaking mini-series “Roots,” died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Attacks on Afghan Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Feel as if You’re Playing on the Moon? It Must Be Whistling Straits
text: HAVEN, Wis.  First impressions can be deceiving, but it would be impossible for a golfer to misconstrue what awaits behind the gates at Whistling Straits, the site of the P.G.A. Championship, which begins Thursday. The narrow driveway is a hard right turn off the T-junction of two Sheboygan County roads, with three chicanes that twist their way to the clubhouse through dunes bordered with tall fescue and a hillside that has one bizarre piece of foreshadowing cut into it like a billboard.

headline: Girardi Being Even More Cautious With Posada
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The occupational hazards of catching are found all over Jorge Posada. He has missed time with an achy right knee, a balky right calf, a broken right foot and a cyst behind his left knee. His right shoulder felt a bit cranky Tuesday night, so his manager, Joe Girardi, kept him out. The injuries nag at Posada, costing him playing time that he will never get back.

headline: Term Limits to Go on Ballot Again in the City
text: Come November, New York City voters will be asked to decide one of the most contentious issues in recent political history: whether city leaders should be limited to two terms in office, or to three. A commission responsible for proposing changes to the city’s charter voted Wednesday evening to place the issue on the Nov. 2 ballot.

headline: Baking the White House Snack Bars
text: Ever since I stumbled across a cookbook at the Nixon presidential library, I’ve been enthralled by the culinary secrets of the White House.

headline: Word of the Day | astral
text: astral •\ˈas-trəl\• adjective

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: After Yankees’ Big Rally, Rivera Bounces Back
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — After the Yankees struck out 17 times, after they overcame a five-run deficit, after Mariano Rivera put the tying run on third base in the bottom of the ninth with no outs, Austin Kearns made a shoestring catch in right field. On the mound, Rivera exhaled.

headline: Nadal Kicks Off His Hardcourt Season
text: TORONTO — The last time Rafael Nadal played a professional tennis match, he battered Tomas Berdych at Wimbledon on July 4. That victory gave Nadal his eighth Grand Slam championship and second in a row. After a victory somersault, he carried the trophy around as if it were glued to his hand.

headline: First In a Decade: Novelist On Time Cover
text: The issue of Time magazine on sale Friday will feature Jonathan Franzen on the cover, below, the first time that a living American novelist has garnered that honor since Stephen King, in 2000. The accompanying article, by Lev Grossman, is a profile of Mr. Franzen on the occasion of his fourth novel, “Freedom,” the story of an American family that is due to be published this month. In the past Time has featured Tom Wolfe, Toni Morrison, George Orwell, John Updike, John Le Carré, Norman Mailer and other writers.

headline: News Quiz | August 12, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Market Drop Worldwide Signals Fears on Recovery
text: As economic recovery wavers in the United States, evidence is mounting that growth abroad is also slowing and may be unable to sustain the fragile rebound here, Graham Bowley and Christine Hauser report in The New York Times.

headline: For Fed, the Choices Get Harder
text: Six months into his second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke is finding it tough to get ahead of the curve, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: A.I.G. Talking to Big Investors on AIA I.P.O.
text: American International Group has started talks with potential investors to sell stakes in its Asian life insurance business,  AIA ahead of AIA’s planned initial public offering, sources with direct knowledge of the matter told Reuters.

headline: Panel Calls for Bigger Thinking on ‘Flash Crash’
text: Securities regulators in the United States said Wednesday that they are moving forward with technical fixes to the still-unexplained May “flash crash,” but some market players say they want a more wholesale review of high-speed trading, Reuters reported.

headline: Safety Board Says All Children on Flights Should Be in Seats
text: Airlines should no longer allow children under the age of 2 to fly in the laps of adults, according to a recommendation by the National Transportation Safety Board sent to the Federal Aviation Administration on Wednesday. The group urged the F.A.A. to require that every occupant of an airplane, regardless of age, have a seat on all flights — commercial, charter and private planes. In the letter, the board cited several accidents in which young travelers were injured or killed. While the N.T.S.B. says children under the age of 2 “should be afforded the same level of protection as all other persons,” the F.A.A. has rejected the recommendation several times, saying that parents unable to afford tickets for their young children would opt to drive rather than fly, resulting in more highway fatalities.

headline: Union Official to Leave 2 Posts
text: Anna Burger announced Wednesday that she was retiring from her positions as secretary-treasurer of the Service Employees International Union and chairwoman of Change to Win, the breakaway labor federation. When she took that federation’s helm in 2005, she became the highest-ranking woman in organized labor’s history. She did not give reasons for retiring, but said she would work as a consultant to the union and toward promoting economic justice. She had campaigned to succeed Andy Stern as the union president when he announced his retirement last April. She dropped her campaign when many S.E.I.U. leaders rallied behind Mary Kay Henry, a union executive vice president. Upon Ms. Henry’s election in May, many union officials said it was only a matter of time before Ms. Burger stepped down.

headline: Credit Suisse Follows Barclays in Layoffs
text: Credit Suisse Group, the giant Swiss bank, said it will follow Barclays in making staff cuts.

headline: Mumbai Restoration Includes Art
text: MUMBAI  When terrorists stormed this city nearly two years ago, killing at least 163 people, they also dealt a blow to the Taj Mahal Palace hotel, an architectural landmark that has played a critical role in nurturing and housing Indian art.

headline: Kenyan Holding Company Has Strong Debut
text: TPS Eastern Africa, the Kenyan holding company of the Serena Hotel chain, said it got bids for 59 percent of the shares on sale in the first day of its rights offer, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Chess Federation Election Seems to Be Tightening
text: If the fight for the votes of the chess federations of Cyprus and the United Arab Emirates is an indicator, then the election for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fédération Internationale des Échecs), could turn out to be a nail biter.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Satisdiction
text: Today’s word, in association with the lofty Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Portfolios Improve, but Funding Pipeline Runs Low
text: A survey of the venture capital industry released Wednesday shows that the valuation of start-up companies underwritten by V.C. firms improved in the second quarter over the first, but the amount of money raised by V.C. firms to finance those companies declined in the same period.

headline: Soldiers at War
text: WHOSE stories in the interactive feature A Year at War do you find most compelling?

headline: PetroAlgae Chances Weak Green I.P.O. Market
text: PetroAlgae, a company claiming that it has found a cheap way to convert algae into fuel — a goal chased by formidable competitors like Sapphire Energy and Solazyme — just filed for a $200 million initial public offering despite a weak public market for green companies. Early signs suggest that this move could do more damage to the burgeoning algae industry than good, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Restructuring Helps Legg Mason Find Its Feet
text: Following its May restructuring, money manager Legg Mason has pared expenses, improved its funds’ performances and now appears well-positioned relative to its peers, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: GreenVolts Nabs $7.5 Million
text: GreenVolts has raised $7.5 million in debt funding. The company expects to eventually raise $11.3 million, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Financial Planner Gets About 7 Years for Fraud
text: A Kirkland, Wash., financial planner who looted her clients’ investment accounts of $12 million was sentenced Wednesday to six years and eight months in prison by a federal judge who praised her for cooperating after she got caught, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Deutsche and Craigs Form Strategic Alliance
text: Craigs Investment Partners of New Zealand and Deutsche Bank have completed a strategic alliance giving the latter a 49.9 percent equity interest in the wealth and investment firm. The remaining 50.1 percent stays with existing Craigs Investment Partners shareholders, Deutsche Bank said.

headline: Philanthropy a New Status Symbol for Wealthy
text: As dozens of American  billionaires pledge their fortunes to charity and the country struggles to shake off recession, philanthropy is a growing status symbol of the rich, experts say.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Leap Into Government Bonds
text: According to an investor survey from Greenwich Associates, The Financial Times reports that hedge fund managers now account for one-fifth of all trading volume in the $10,000 billion U.S. Treasury bond market.

headline: Beautiful Photos, if Barely Photography
text: Barely photography. That’s how Sasha Frere-Jones, 43, characterized the images he takes and shares on his blogs, Songs You Taught Me (on Tumblr) and S/FJ, and through Twitter.

headline: Hou Wins Fifth Women’s Chess Grand Prix
text: In the final round on Wednesday, Hou Yifan drew Antoaneta Stefanova, her closest rival, and secured first place.

headline: Warren Calls for ‘War Games’ to Soften Crises
text: 11:32 p.m. | Updated In a study of the international repercussions of America’s $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program, the Congressional Oversight Panel, the body monitoring bailout money, said Thursday that regulators should engage in “war games” to prepare for the next global crisis.

headline: The Man Group Blues
text: Man Group is having a spot of bad luck. The Financial Times reported that the habitually “most prominent symbol of the growth of London’s hedge fund sector” is now facing accusations that its flagship fund is “broken,” following a period of poor performance.

headline: Rubin to Join Centerview, a Young Firm
text: More than a year after he left Citigroup amid a firestorm of criticism over his role as a senior adviser to what was then the world’s biggest bank, Robert E. Rubin is planning to join a much smaller firm, the boutique investment bank Centerview Partners.

headline: Macquarie India Fund Takes 1st Big Stake
text: A fund controlled by Macquarie Group and State Bank of India has made its first big investment, putting $340 million into Viom Networks, a mobile tower business.

headline: Are Your Friends Too Similar to You?
text: A Times columnist wrote this week about the value of having friends who are different from us. Do you tend to seek friends who are a lot like you, or do you have a variety of friends with different personalities and tastes?

headline: The Bush Tax Cuts and Fiscal Responsibility
text: Simon Johnson and James Kwak are the authors of “13 Bankers: The Wall Street Takeover and the Next Financial Meltdown.”

headline: Will the Sue Sylvester Hoodie Have a Pouch for a Megaphone?
text: The cast of “Glee” did not make it into the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day parade in November, but merchandise based on the popular Fox television series is making it into Macy’s.

headline: A Cure for the Summer-in-Paris Blues
text: For those feeling lonely in deserted-in-August Paris, here’s a solution: why not join a summer camp for grown-ups? Colonie de Vacances(Summer Camp), a series of camp-themed parties aimed to entertain bored grown-ups began last week at Chez Moune (54, rue Pigalle; 33-1-45-26-64-64), an Art Deco cabaret in the city’s historic red light district, Pigalle.

headline: ‘Hard Knocks,’ Episode 1: The Ryan and Revis Show
text: Editor’s note: For those who don’t have HBO, and for those who do and would like to discuss the “Hard Knocks” series, we will review every episode. In a somewhat twisted decision, a Patriots fan, the longtime reader/commenter Jess Faneuf of Manhattan, has been selected to do the honors. We welcome your thoughts on the show. Toni Monkovic

headline: MetLife and Prudential Under Scrutiny in Georgia
text: MetLife and Prudential Financial, the two biggest life insurers in the United States, are being investigated by Georgia state regulators for earning investment income by retaining death benefits, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Mervyn Davies Joins Corsair Capital
text: Mervyn Davies has taken a full-time post at the private equity house Corsair Capital, The Telegraph reported. The former Standard Chartered chairman will become a partner in the firm.

headline: Disgraced C.E.O.? Try Private Equity
text: Mark V. Hurd, forced to resign last week as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, may have a career ahead of him in private equity rather than as head of a publicly held company, analysts and executive recruiters told Bloomberg News.

headline: China Kanghui Holdings Makes Debut
text: Shares of Chinese medical device maker China Kanghui Holdings slid early in their market debut Wednesday as the broader markets tumbled, but regained ground before midday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Prudential P.l.c. Revises Down Cost of Busted Deal
text: Prudential P.l.c., the British insurer, said Thursday that it had reduced the cost of its failed bid for American International Group‘s Asian unit and confirmed it had no further appetite for mergers and acquisitions as it reported forecast-beating half-year profit, Reuters reports.

headline: Prisoners of White Guilt
text: Today’s idea: Self-serving white guilt impedes human progress because it distorts the true causes of many of the world’s problems, an essayist argues.

headline: QS Investors Splits From Deutsche
text: QS Investors has split off from Deutsche Bank. The $11 billion asset management firm made the announcement on Wednesday. It had been part of Deutsche Asset Management for over 10 years, MarketWatch reported.

headline: New Flood Warnings Raise Fears in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan issued new flood warnings on Thursday that could last into the weekend as government and relief agencies strained to confront the toll from a growing humanitarian disaster.

headline: Credit Suisse Clients Questioned in Germany
text: Credit Suisse‘s clients in Germany are being questioned by prosecutors as part of an inquiry into allegations that employees of Switzerland’s second-biggest bank may have helped customers evade taxes, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Q.&A.: Suddenly, System Shuts Down
text: Q.

headline: Do I Owe My Employees a Career Path?
text: As sales pick up, I’ve been trying to build our production capacity proportionally. This has been hard for me to accomplish in the past. During the last big expansion, between 2003 and 2008, I found myself in the position of hiring willy-nilly, throwing warm bodies at production bottlenecks. In the rush to get work out the door, we never set up a training program and we didn’t do a good job of increasing productivity with technology. This was a disastrous mistake. More than anything else, an inflated payroll drained cash from the company and kept us from making a profit.

headline: The Baker’s Apprentice: Corn Muffins
text: Emily Weinstein, who wrote a series on this blog about learning to cook, is now learning to bake with the food writer and cookbook author Dorie Greenspan.

headline: Madoff Trustee Investigating UniCredit Unit
text: UniCredit’s Pioneer Alternative Investment Management unit, which invested $1.1 billion of client money in funds that fed Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, is being investigated based on possible legal claims by the trustee liquidating the conman’s business, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Reliance Power Needs Cash Infusion
text: Reliance Power is seeking approval to raise more funds, including through overseas securities, after spending half the $2.5 billion it received in India’s biggest initial share sale, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Severstal Said to Put U.S. Mills Up for Sale
text: Severstal, Russia’s largest steel maker, has put some of its loss-making American mills up for sale, Reuters reported, citing several sources quoted in an American Metal Market article.

headline: Profit Strong, G.M. Names a New Chief
text: DETROIT  General Motors reached two significant milestones on the road to its corporate turnaround on Thursday, reporting its best quarterly earnings in six years and announcing that its chief executive, picked by the Obama administration last year to lead it after bankruptcy, would step down next month.

text: — Paul Graham writes a post-mortem for Yahoo’s former grandeur: “Hacker culture often seems kind of irresponsible. That’s why people proposing to destroy it use phrases like ‘adult supervision.’ That was the phrase they used at Yahoo. But there are worse things than seeming irresponsible. Losing, for example.”

headline: Slate Enters the iPad World
text: Earlier this year, Jacob Weisberg, editor in chief of the Slate Group, the Washington Post Company unit that owns Slate.com, wrote an article titled “Apple’s Way: Why publishers should beware the App Store.” Mr. Weisberg offers words of caution to publishers optimistically believing that applications built exclusively for the iPad will offer windfalls of money and in a sense, save the publishing industry.

headline: The Last Stand? Rallying Behind a Primeval Forest
text: In the opening chapter of his best-selling 2007 book “The World Without Us,” the journalist Alan Weisman ruminated on a trip to the Bialowieza forest, the last remaining stand of primeval forest in all of Europe, which straddles the border between Poland and Belarus:

headline: Russia Breathes Easier as Moscow Skies Clear
text: MOSCOW  The skies cleared and air quality significantly improved for a second straight day in Moscow on Thursday, bringing the skyline of gothic, Stalin-era skyscrapers back into focus after a trying week when the city was choked with wildfire smoke.

headline: Woman Sentenced to Death by Stoning Reportedly Appears on Iranian Television
text: Updated | 3:36 p.m. Sakineh Ashtiani, an Iranian woman whose sentence of death by stoning for the crime of adultery has sparked an international campaign to save her, reportedly appeared on state television in Iran on Wednesday night.

headline: Paterson Aide Charged With Assault
text: David W. Johnson, one of Gov. David A. Paterson’s closest aides, surrendered to Bronx prosecutors Thursday morning to face misdemeanor assault charges, a person briefed on the matter said.

text: Stephen Sondheim turned 80 on March 22, and the celebrations in New York and around the world have been extensive and classy.

headline: A Third Down Day on Wall Street
text: A decline in technology shares and weak jobs data sent Wall Street indexes down on Thursday, as traders were confronted with more signs that the global economy was slowing.

headline: The Price Stability Trap
text: There’s an important new paper from the IMF about inflation in the face of Prolonged Large Output Gaps — yes, PLOGs. You can think of it as a careful, multi-country version of the quick-and-dirty analysis of US experience I did recently, with an assist from Tim Duy. What the analysis shows is that prolonged periods of economic weakness are, with almost no exceptions, associated with falling inflation rates.

headline: Nigerianwadi
text: An area of Mumbai nicknamed after a gang of resident Nigerian e-mail scammers.

headline: India and Pakistan Become Nations; Clashes Continue
text: NEW DELHI -- India achieved her long sought independence today through the transfer of British power to the two dominions into which that land of 400,000,000 persons has been divided, India and Pakistan.

headline: Ethel Barrymore Is Dead at 79; One of Stage's 'Royal Family'
text: HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18--Ethel Barrymore, last of the trio known to Broadway and Hollywood as "The Royal Family" of acting, died here today of a heart ailment. She would have been 80 years old on Aug. 15.

headline: Menachem Begin, Guerrilla Leader Who Became Peacemaker
text: Menachem Begin, the Israeli Prime Minister who made peace with Egypt, lived much of his life in the opposition. A Jewish underground leader before Israel gained independence in 1948, he openly fought the established Zionist leadership of the struggle against British rule.

headline: ELVIS PRESLEY DIES; ROCK SINGER WAS 42
text: Elvis Presley, the first and greatest American rock-and-roll star, died yesterday at the age of 42. Mr. Presley, whose throaty baritone and blatant sexuality redefined popular music, was found unconscious in the bedroom of his home, called Graceland, in Memphis yesterday at 2:30 P.M.

headline: Tired Rock Fans Begin Exodus
text: Bethel, N.Y., Monday, Aug. 18 -- Waves of weary youngsters streamed away from the Woodstock Music and Art Fair last night and early today as security officials reported at least two deaths and 4,000 people treated for injuries, illness and adverse drug reactions over the festival's three-day period.

headline: Marcus Garvey, Negro Ex-Leader
text: LONDON, June 11 (UP)--Marcus Garvey, West Indian Negro, who once set himself up as "Emperor of the Kingdom of Africa" in New York's Harlem and later appeared before the League of Nations as representative of "the black peoples of the world," died here yesterday.

headline: Clemente, Pirates' Star, Dies in Crash Of Plane Carrying Aid to Nicaragua
text: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 1--Roberto Clemente, star outfielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates, died late last night in the crash of a cargo plane carrying relief supplies to the victims of the earthquake in Managua.

headline: Mississippi Gives Meredith Degree
text: Oxford, Miss., Aug. 18 -- James H. Meredith received a degree from the University of Mississippi today. He thus became the first Negro alumnus in the 115-year history of the school.

headline: Chanel, the Couturier, Dead in Paris
text: PARIS, Jan. 10--Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, one of the greatest couturiers of the 20th century, died tonight in her apartment at the Ritz Hotel. She was 87 years old.

headline:
Hitler Endorsed by 9 to 1 in Poll on his
Dictatorship, but Opposition Is Doubled
text: Berlin, Monday, Aug. 20 -- Eighty-nine and nine-tenths per cent of the German voters endorsed in yesterday's plebiscite Chancellor Hitler's assumption of greater power than has ever been possessed by any other ruler in modern times. Nearly 10 per cent indicated their disapproval. The result was expected.

headline: Benjamin Harrison Dead
text: Benjamin Harrison, the twenty-third President of the United States, was born in North Bend, Hamilton County, Ohio, on Aug. 20, 1833. His father, John Scott Harrison, was the third son of William Henry Harrison, ninth President of the United States and the grandson of Benjamin Harrison of Virginia, who was one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence.

headline: Count Basie, 79, Band Leader And Master of Swing, Dead
text: Count Basie, the jazz pianist whose spare, economic keyboard style and supple rhythmic drive made his orchestra one of the most influential groups of the Big Band era, died of cancer yesterday morning at Doctors' Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Freeport, the Bahamas.

headline: Thursday Reading: The World’s Most Expensive Coffee
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: BMW Gran Coupé Is a Go

headline: John Rooney May Come to M.L.S.
text: Thierry Henry made his “official” home debut Wednesday night when the Red Bulls defeated Toronto, 1-0, in what was the French star’s third actual game for the club. He will soon be joined by Rafael Márquez, the Mexican defender who is the latest foreign star to join Major League Soccer in a summer seasoned with designated player signings. But another famous name has come across the Atlantic to consider M.L.S.: Rooney. As in John Rooney, Wayne’s younger brother, who is on trial with the Seattle Sounders.

headline: A Breast-Feeding Guru Who Uses Formula
text: As Katie Allison Granju is the first to say, she knows as much as anyone about nursing a newborn. “I wrote a book about breast-feeding (among other things),” she wrote over at Babble.com this week. “And over the past 15 years, I’ve been published pretty widely in all kind of publications on breastfeeding-related topics. I’m even credited in some quarters with having been the first person to use the word “lactivist” in a published piece (I’m pretty sure that’s not true, though).”

headline: Backlot Beauties
text: On a recent Friday morning, lit white by the California sun, Nigel Dare was sitting in his shop, fielding calls from a movie set. “Is that a Japanese line?” he asked the makeup artist on the other end. “Never heard of it. But you’ll have it by Monday.” Dare is the ultimate Hollywood candy man — a warm, personable guy who can procure Fria, an Italian makeup remover, if that’s what you need, or Collyre Bleu (1) for the hungover actor with bloodshot eyes. Nigel’s Beauty Emporium, along with Naimie’s Beauty Center and Frends Beauty Supply, is perhaps the San Fernando Valley’s best-kept secret: a treasure trove of rarefied cosmetics brands where Hollywood makeup artists go to keep the likes of Sandra Bullock, Megan Fox and George Clooney powdered and buffed. Here they can scour hundreds of global brands, including ones you don’t see everywhere (Embryolisse (2), La Peau (3) ) and the Japanese lines much beloved by the pros (KohGenDo, Kanebo). Here they can ask for and get Kate (5), the ultrathin Kanebo eyeliner that is barely detectable on the eye. Or the French — and much stronger — version of Anthelios, the sunscreen by La Roche-Posay. Or, for that matter, Labello lip balm (4), from Germany. Frends is the granddaddy of the bunch: founded in 1940, it catered to makeup artists who were stuck on a set for 18 hours straight and running on empty. Today all three stores are about turnaround, finding products anywhere they can and even picking them up at a competitor’s if they have to — which, for the right client, they will.

headline: Popcast: José González With Junip and More
text: With his soft voice and hypnotically gentle acoustic guitar, José González — who was born in Sweden to Argentine parents — has been described as playing “don’t-wake-the-baby music.” But as Mr. González shows on this week’s Popcast, The Times’s music podcast, he also rocks. Sort of.

Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: On Assignment: The Isle of Skye
text: My wife and I spent a lot of time driving on the Isle of Skye, off the west coast of Scotland, where I recently was reporting a story. That posed a few problems. First, I’d never driven on the left side of the road. (Let’s just say it took a few days for me to adjust.) Second, Skye is full of single-lane roads with “Passing Places” — you end up playing a friendly little game with oncoming cars as to who will pull over. (Don’t forget to wave as you pass by – it’s considered rude not to.) And then there was the livestock. Sheep, it turns out, will move when you honk (though we did hear stories of horned rams doing some damage upon seeing their reflection in car doors); cows are a bit more stubborn. But when you’re surrounded by vistas as beautiful as those on Skye, you don’t mind the occasional break in your journey.

headline: Restaurant Review: Orlando di Castello in Vienna
text: “This won’t last in Vienna,” said my fellow diner, a native of the city, gazing at the over-the-top décor at Orlando di Castello. The restaurant opened last September in the city’s First District, an area dominated by old-school coffeehouses filled with dark wood and supercilious bow-tied waiters.

headline: Marriage in Thick and Thin
text: Continuing my slow march through responses to my gay marriage column, I want to take up two somewhat-related critiques of my argument for holding up lifelong heterosexual monogamy as a distinctive legal and cultural ideal: First, that this ideal is too essentialist, and second, that it’s too complicated. The too-essentialist critique has been raised by The American Prospect’s Adam Serwer, among others, who scoffs at my suggestion that there’s anything distinctive about heterosexual relationships as heterosexual relationships: Every intimate relationship, he suggests, is “‘distinct’ in its ‘challenges and potential fruit,'” and so there’s no reason why heterosexual marriages as a category deserve to be singled out or idealized in any way. The too-complicated critique was raised by Matt Feeney, who writes (well, “tweets”) that “if there’s an Ockham’s Razor/Parsimony standard for ‘ideals,'” then my marriage ideal “doesn’t meet it,” because “any marriage ideal strong enough to function qua ideal, as Ross uses the term, would have to be parsimonious enough to allow gay marriage.”

headline: Seattle’s New Food Market
text: PIKE PLACE MARKET in Seattle gets all the press and the kudos from out-of-towners for its produce stands and food stores. But the crowds and limited parking options generally keep residents away.

headline: 36 Hours in Montreal
text: FRENCH or English? One of the beautiful things about Montreal is that you never know in what language you will be greeted. Which brings up a second thing: Maybe it’s the good food, the open skies or the free-spirited students who call this city their campus, but the folks of Montreal are friendly. Ask someone for directions in the Métro, part of the vast Underground City that stays toasty during the winter, and you may end up making drinks plans later. That’s not a bad thing, bien sûr. With the city’s music-charged night life, slaughterhouse-chic restaurants and post-industrial revival, it helps to have a guide.

headline: The Pull of an Idyll as Years Pass By
text: I DISCOVERED the Datca Peninsula, in the southwestern corner of Turkey, purely by accident. This was in 2005. I’d never been to Turkey and was trying to find a rental house somewhere  anywhere on any coast of the country  where my husband and I could spend the month of June. I was trying to finish writing a novel that took place above the Arctic Circle in midwinter, and a waterfront town in Turkey in the summer seemed about as far away as I could get from the setting of that book, as well as from the day-to-day distractions of my life in San Francisco. I envisioned a month of solid writing in a country where I knew no one and where the water and people were warm. So I typed the words “Turkey,” “water,” “rental” and “cheap” into a search engine.

headline: ‘Deathtrap’ Trailer Takes a Cue From Hollywood

headline: Globe-Trotting and Soul-Searching
text: The double standard in Hollywood may be stronger than ever. Men are free to pursue all kinds of adventures, while women are expected to pursue men. In a typical big-studio romantic comedy the heroine’s professional ambition may not always be an insurmountable obstacle to matrimony, but her true fulfillment — not just her presumed happiness but also the completion of her identity — will come only at the altar.

headline: Report From a Pashtun Teen: Facebook Protests in Pakistan
text: Sher Bano is a 17-year-old Pashtun girl from Pakistan who spent last year as an exchange student in Evanston, Illinois, as part of the Youth Exchange and Study (YES) Program. She is now back in the city of Peshawar in the northwest of Pakistan. The following post, about protests in Pakistan last May against Facebook, was submitted just a few days before intense flooding struck her area. She intends to write about how her family has been affected by the floods and subsequent heavy rains in her next post.

headline: When the Doctor Doesn’t Look Like You
text: One night during my training, over dinner in the hospital cafeteria, a fellow resident and I had a discussion about the situation of one of our professors. Known for his blistering teaching sessions, this senior surgeon possessed the uncanny ability to sniff out lapses in memory or judgment among doctors-in-training. Early on in my internship, I showed up at one of his practice trauma resuscitations blissfully unprepared. I left an hour later with his booming and rapid-fire admonitions still ringing in my ears. “You call yourself a doctor?” he had thundered. “This patient may just be a dummy, but you are killing her!”

headline: Doctors Who Study Outside the U.S.
text: In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about doctors who receive their education in other countries before practicing in the United States. While the common perception is that an American-educated doctor is best, a new study shows that where the doctor receives his or her education isn’t related to the quality of care patients receive.

headline: Letter: Bicycle Touring
text: To the Editor: Having just returned from a six-day bike tour, I was delighted to read “Four Corners, Two Wheels” (Aug. 1). It seems that every bike tour The New York Times writes about is a pampered affair with participants crowing about the “25 miles” they rode that day. How refreshing to read about a tour where you actually ride hard while enjoying the scenery. Although my bike tour was not as fancy as this one (we camped at schools and ate burritos prepared by community groups raising money for a trip to Washington, D.C.) nor as remote (much sharing of roads with semis), nothing beats riding a hard 85-plus day, getting to a small town, finding a beer, complaining about the ride and the weather, then starting all over the next day.

headline: Artifacts | Feats of Clay
text: Artists make so many mash-ups of painting, sculpture and drawing these days that when one turns up with work in a traditional form, it seems almost radical. Shio Kusaka is such an artist. No two of the carved ceramic vessels in her current exhibition at the Anton Kern Gallery are alike. Yet they don’t stray very far from those of a typical potter. Then again, Kusaka, 38, is not trying to reinvent the wheel. “I like ceramics because it hasn’t changed for a long time,” she says. “And I think that’s amazing, what people can do with the hands. It’s the same, and still they make it new.”

headline: The 1980s vs. Now, Cont.
text: Brad DeLong, an economist at the University of California, Berkeley, points out that the unemployment rate was considerably higher in 1980 (the first year of the early 1980s downturn) than in 2008 (the first year of our slump). It’s a fair point. He then uses it to disagree with me and to suggest that 2010 is likely to look as bad as 1982 on another job-market measure: the share of workers that are unemployed at any point during the year.
