headline: Pleats, Please!
text: “I call it ‘the death of sex look,’ ” the T editor Sally Singer says with a laugh when asked about the recent resurgence of pleated skirts both on the runways and in reality. “I absolutely love them. They’re in my closet.” Granted, even a potato sack conjures up nubile images on the likes of the buxom models Lara Stone and Adriana Lima, but for most civilians, fall’s fuller, ’50s below-the-knee skirts are the complete antithesis of sexy. “It’s the Mary Tyler Moore, the young, naïve and happy working girl who will wear the right button-up blouse with an A-line skirt,” Singer elaborates.

headline: Screen Test: Marion Cotillard
text: The Oscar winning star of "La Vie en Rose" discusses her film career and what it is like to die on screen.

headline: Chicken Pasta Salad
text: A recipe from the actress Tracee Chimo.

headline: American Soccer Is Hitting the Right Notes
text: Harrison, N.J.

headline: Past Errors to Blame for Russia’s Peat Fires
text: ELEKTROGORSK, Russia  For two weeks, soldiers with chain saws felled every tree in sight.

headline: Green Light and Delay on Same-Sex Marriage
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Same-sex marriage is legal again in California. Sort of.

headline: Australia’s Appleby Back at the Scene of the Crime
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Every golfer has days in his career that he would very much like to forget, and for Stuart Appleby, one of them came the last time the P.G.A. Championship was played here at Whistling Straits, back in 2004.

headline: Patti LaBelle Joins Cast of ‘Fela!’
text: The Broadway musical “Fela!” may be closing in January, but it is going out in style. The Grammy winner Patti LaBelle is planning to join the cast at the Eugene O’Neill Theater on Sept. 14 as Fela’s mother, Funmilayo Anikulapo-Kuti, a spokesman for the show said on Thursday.

headline: Joint Custody — of the Kids and the Blog
text: Once upon a time, a mommy blogger was married to a daddy blogger, and they had two babies. The mommy gave advice to other parents at AskMoxie.org. The Daddy lost his job and blogged about being a stay-at-home father at LaidOffDad.org.

headline: Fringe Festival: The Edge, the Center and the Kitchen Sink
text: With almost 200 shows in more than a dozen downtown spaces, the 14th annual New York International Fringe Festival, which runs Friday through Aug. 29, is an almost-anything-goes assemblage of theatrical events: surrealism, music, magic, dance, burlesque, stand-up comedy, nudity, puppetry, drag performance and more will be on view.

headline: Marching, but to Different Beats
text: I WAS never a fan of group exercise classes. I’m a regular guy, a caveman, so when it came to fitness, I preferred to do my own thing. This changed once I discovered Boot Camp at the West Side Y.M.C.A. The class delivered on its promise of “an efficient circuit-training workout that challenges your entire body.” But in addition to the usual crunches and calisthenics, Boot Camp introduced me to an unexpected array of characters.

headline: Making Peace with the Heat
text: It’s August, and there “doesn’t seem to be a shadow in the city,” to quote the Lovin’ Spoonful. So this week the Miser suggests that you make peace with this hot town.

headline: Summer Retreats When Old Money Was New
text: UPPER ST. REGIS LAKE, N.Y.

headline: Android Beefs Up Hands-Free Commands
text: Android cellphone screens could soon have fewer finger smudges.

headline: The F.D.I.C.’s Suggestions on Overdraft Fees
text: Should financial institutions be responsible for watching out for, and offering alternatives to, customers who chronically overdraw their accounts?

headline: Quote Unquote | God is My Stylist
text: -Sofia Vergara, an actress on Modern Family, discusses her religious beliefs with Esquire. Hopefully posing for a men’s magazine isn’t a deal breaker either.

headline: ‘Race’ to Close on Aug. 21
text: David Mamet’s moral fable of pride and prejudices, “Race,” has announced it will close its Broadway run at the Barrymore Theater on Aug. 21 after its 320th performance. The drama, which currently stars Eddie Izzard, Dennis Haysbert, Afton C. Williamson and Richard Thomas, is the longest running play of the 2009-2010 season. Productions are planned for next year in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Milwaukee, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. There are also plans for the play to be featured in London.

headline: Stirrings of a Stick Shift Crusade
text: The manual transmission — an object of love and affection among many drivers, and an example of passé automotive technology to many more — is getting some serious props from Eddie Alterman, the editor of Car and Driver.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Lenny & John’s
text: The pizza shop, on Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, is an area favorite, and has been operating since 1969.

headline: Think Globally, Compromise Locally
text: Bill McKibben, whose 1989 book, “The End of Nature,” helped coalesce and spread worry about climate change, views the national environmental groups’ strategy of winning support for energy and climate legislation by compromising with industry as a complete failure. “The result: total defeat, no moral victories,” he wrote at the environmental news site Grist, speaking of the Senate’s inaction on climate legislation.

headline: Theater Listings: Aug. 13 — 19
text: Theater

headline: Look Around. That’s Loyalty.
text: THERE doesn’t seem to be anything special about the wood-framed photographs of Flatbush Avenue from 1946 hanging on the walls of Lenny & John’s Pizza, or the floor-to-ceiling stack of pizza boxes. The clear plastic containers of garlic, red pepper and oregano look the same as the ones at the pizzeria down the street, or across town. A slice costs $2, a pie $13 (except on Tuesdays, when it’s on special for $8).

headline: Eat an Apple (Doctor’s Orders)
text: The farm stand is becoming the new apothecary, dispensing apples  not to mention artichokes, asparagus and arugula  to fill a novel kind of prescription.

headline: The Tech Jam: Anything Can Happen, and Usually Does
text: ON most Sunday nights Issue Project Room  a dark, narrow performance space less than a block from the ever-festering Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn  is occupied by a cabal of tinkerers. Crates of equipment in tow, they snake cables across the floor, joining laptops, projectors, video-game consoles, synthesizers and other devices into a throbbing, multimedia web.

headline: Mariah Carey and Missy Elliott at Singapore Grand Prix
text: As I reported last year from Singapore, Beyonce and Gwen Stefani of No Doubt — oh, and let’s not forget ZZ Top — played at the F1 Rocks concert at the Singapore Grand Prix. The only problems were that the walk was a little far from the circuit to the stage, and the hours of the performances overlapped so that you had to choose between the racing and the music.

headline: The Caucus With Tom Perriello
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Representative Tom Perriello, Democrat of Virginia, about his campaign to be re-elected for the state's 5th Congressional District.

headline: Taxes No Longer So Certain
text: Death may still be certain, but taxes have never been less so.

headline: Films From Another Dimension
text: A look at some of the offerings in Film Forum’s Classic 3-D series.

headline: It Leaps (Gasp!) Off the Screen
text: DOES 3-D represent the future of the movies?

headline: Look Around. That’s Loyalty.
text: There doesn’t seem to be anything special about the wood-framed photographs of Flatbush Avenue from 1946 hanging on the walls of Lenny & John’s Pizza, or the floor-to-ceiling stack of pizza boxes. The clear plastic containers of garlic, red pepper and oregano look the same as the ones at the pizzeria down the street, or across town. A slice costs $2, a pie $13 (except on Tuesdays, when it’s on special for $8).

headline: A Playground for the Arts, With Island Breezes
text: What kind of culture develops on an island? It is a place that requires a special effort to visit and a special effort to leave. It can keep people out or corral them in. It might serve as an escape, or (like Alcatraz) as a prison. It incubates and isolates. And its culture might become both ingrown and wildly experimental, maybe a bit like Manhattan’s.

headline: Culture on Governors Island
text: A look at some of the cultural events on the island.

headline: Ristretto | Cool Beans
text: New York is still deep in iced-coffee season, and while home methods like cold brew and Japanese iced coffee process are becoming more familiar, most of the discussion seems to be about techniques and gadgets instead of what coffees taste best when served on the rocks.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gansu Province and Elsewhere
text: It is nothing new to observe that sometimes the most affecting photos of hugely scaled disasters are those that focus on individuals. That said, there may be few situations even on an intimate scale that don’t leave viewers thinking, “As awful as the moment is, I’ve seen this depicted before.” The photograph leading today’s report, of a man carrying his niece’s coffin, by the Color China Photo agency, may be an exception.

headline: Malebo, and Fishes, at Last
text: Wednesday, Aug. 11

headline: The Caucus with Robert Hurt
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Robert Hurt, a state senator and the Republican candidate in the race for Virginia's 5th Congressional District.

headline: Gansevoort 69 Closes Permanently
text: What was originally to be a temporary closing of Gansevoort 69 (formerly Florent) last month is now permanent.

headline: 264 Japanese Carvings, Revealing Family History
text: The British ceramicist Edmund de Waal will promote his memoir, “The Hare With Amber Eyes: A Family’s Century of Art and Loss” (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), during a two-week tour of the United States this fall. But he will be able to bring along only a few of his favorite pocket talismans: Japanese carvings called netsuke, the size of walnuts, depicting animals, fruit, peasants, samurai and erotica.

headline: Galaxies of Wire, Canvas and Velvety Soot
text: One of the thrills of watching “Mad Men” is seeing the early 1960s as an alternating current of oppression and optimism: the cold war, the space race, the escalation of the Vietnam War, the sexual revolution. The art of Lee Bontecou, as it’s presented in a one-room show at the Museum of Modern Art, delivers a similar jolt.

headline: Johan Santana: A Pleasant On-Field Distraction
text: For at least one game, questions about how the Mets would close games without their star closer didn’t have to be answered.

headline: What, Federer Worry?
text: TORONTO –- On Thursday afternoon, Roger Federer did not sound, look or act like a player concerned with his age (29, as of last Sunday), or his ranking (No. 3 since Wimbledon, for the first time since late 2003).

headline: Town House Surrounding Jones Wood Garden for Sale
text: THE rumble and bustle of New York City can leave even the staunchest city supporter aching for a reprieve, especially in the dense air of August. For a lucky few, the reprieve can be found in a large shared private garden, carved into the middle of a city block, invisible from the sidewalk and accessible only to people who live in the surrounding buildings.

headline: Caucus Video: A Look at Virginia’s 5th District Race
text: One of the most competitive races for a House seat this fall is expected to be in Virginia’s 5th Congressional District. John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC interviewed the two candidates battling it out: Representative Tom Perriello, the Democrat incumbent, and Robert Hurt, a Republican state senator.

headline: The Impresario of Islam
text: The Cairo-based music video channel 4Shbab combines the aesthetics of western music programming with the morals of more devout Muslim channels.

headline: When Life in Cuba Was Elegant and Sweet
text: The glamorous, slightly risqué picture many of us have of prerevolutionary Cuba comes from the movies or the theater. Havana is the racy, romantic getaway where the prim and proper Sarah Brown begins to fall for the raffish charms of the high-rolling gambler Sky Masterson in “Guys and Dolls.” Havana is also where Michael Corleone in “The Godfather: Part II” goes to meet fellow mobsters to divvy up control of the lucrative casino business. It’s the Paris of the Caribbean, the Monte Carlo of the Americas, a place where, in the words of “The Godfather” character Hyman Roth, the hotels were “bigger and swankier than any of the rug joints we’ve put in Vegas,” where American tourists could down exotic drinks, take in live sex shows and carouse in one of the greatest party towns on earth.

headline: ‘The Sugar King of Havana’
text: Introduction

headline: This Girl Has a Lot of Baggage, and He Must Shoulder the Load
text: There are some movies about youth that just make you feel old, even if you aren’t. “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World,” based on a series of sprightly graphic novels by Bryan Lee O’Malley, has the opposite effect. Its speedy, funny, happy-sad spirit is so infectious that the movie makes you feel at home in its world even if the landscape is, at first glance, unfamiliar.

headline: Money Money Money Money
text: Video here.

headline: Islam’s Answer to MTV
text: The Egyptian entrepreneur Ahmed Abu Haiba isn’t having a good day. A Saudi columnist has accused him of corrupting the country’s youth. A music video he has been working on for months is behind schedule. He hasn’t had time to prepare for his weekly talk show, an Islamo-Egyptian version of “Dr. Phil.” Worse, one of the program’s financiers has become upset because there was to be a woman on the show — unchaste behavior, to some. We’re driving along Sheik Zayed Road in the desert outside Cairo on a bright day as the radio plays Sami Yusuf, a saccharine-sweet Muslim pop star based in London. Abu Haiba theatrically throws his arms in the air to perform his frustration. At the age of 42 he is tubby and, as a sign of his deep faith, has a large zabiba — a dark smudge on his forehead born of rubbing his head repeatedly on a prayer mat. And yet he is not a conventional man and certainly not a conventional Muslim. Today he looks more like a hip-hop mogul, with a black knit golf cap on backward and a suit of all black. And a pink tie.

headline: The Banks Behind G.M.’s $5 Billion Loan
text: As General Motors continues in its march toward an initial public offering, perhaps filing for one as soon as Friday, the automaker has taken big steps to bolster its financial health as much as possible.

headline: So Where Exactly Is Whistling Straits?
text: There is no question that this year’s P.G.A. Championship is located at Whistling Straits. But where Whistling Straits is located is a more complicated matter.

headline: A Return to Video Is Moving
text: With her latest show of new work at the Marian Goodman Gallery, the Dutch artist Rineke Dijkstra takes up the video camera for the first time in a dozen years, building on an early triumph that seemed destined to be an isolated event.

headline: Vietnamese Voices Against a Whir of War
text: In slumberous mid-August thousands of visitors fidget and drift through the Museum of Modern Art, finding almost everything worth photographing and almost nothing worth more than a point-and-shoot glance. But in one gallery  basically a wide glorified corridor  people tend to stop, focus, even settle down in front of a three-channel video by the Vietnamese-American artist Dinh Q. Le projected across a long wall.

headline: Dispatch | Paris in August Redux
text: Every August, Parisians heed the call of la plage, leaving their city to the tourists and tumbleweeds. Even though some of the biggest restaurants and galleries, and most petit boulangeries and boutiques, may be closed, there’s plenty left to do. T first tackled the problem last year; a few fresh options for this year are after the jump.

headline: Viewing a Vegas Casino Show by Scuba
text: No matter what you’ve encountered while scuba diving, chances are you’ve never seen anything as dramatic as a firsthand view of 14 underwater stagehands navigating 630 cues for a Las Vegas show with synchronized swimmers.

headline: Political Points: Signed, Sealed, Delivered? Not Quite
text: Click Below to Listen

text: HOW MUCH $550,000. Taxes: $5,678.

headline: Club-Crawling
text: A photographic tour of Brooklyn club buildings.

headline: Switzerland Takes Loss in Vain Attempt to Keep the Franc in Check and Aid Exports
text: ZURICH — While the rest of Europe struggles to rein in government debt, there is no talk of forced austerity in prudent Switzerland. Instead, the country is looking forward to growth of at least 2.5 percent this year, thanks to booming exports.

headline: The Two Churchills
text: Winston Churchill is remembered for leading Britain through her finest hour — but what if he also led the country through her most shameful one? What if, in addition to rousing a nation to save the world from the Nazis, he fought for a raw white supremacy and a concentration camp network of his own? This question burns through Richard Toye’s superb, unsettling new history, “Churchill’s Empire” — and is even seeping into the Oval Office.

headline: ‘Churchill’s Empire’
text: Prologue

headline: A Matriarch in Melbourne and Her Band of Warped Partners in Crime
text: With a bleached-blond mane, a glittering blue-eyed stare and a ferocious smile, Smurf Cody (Jacki Weaver) is the mama lion to a criminal brood of armed robbers and drug dealers in the mostly terrific Australian gangster film “Animal Kingdom.” The opening images of the movie, the directorial and screenwriting debut of David Michôd, are statues and drawings of lions. Although the Codys live in bland-looking suburban Melbourne, it might as well be the jungle, for all they care about law and order.

text: 4:42 p.m. | Updated Noting the $19.90 annual subscription fee that comes with WaveSecure app, now owned by McAfee.

headline: Setbacks in Diet Pill Study
text: One of the great hopes for weight-loss drugs is that they will be more than just cosmetic, that they will also reduce the risk of serious health conditions associated with obesity, like diabetes and heart disease.

headline: Social Clubs, Long Gone, Left Their Meeting Places Behind
text: THE five-borough consolidation of 1898 was a bitter pill for many in Brooklyn, who correctly foresaw the eclipse of their influential city by the powerhouse of Manhattan. Few things document that change as well as the collapsed network of men’s social clubs in Brooklyn, at least four of whose clubhouses survive.

text: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  Late Sunday night, after six days on life support with a bullet in his brain, Fida Nabi, a 19-year-old high school student, was unhooked from his ventilator at a hospital here.

headline: Temperamental Opposites Attract Attention
text: Both the choreographers sharing the Joyce Theater’s second program this week are idiosyncratic, original, theatrically striking. On at least one level, though, they seem temperamental opposites. To Kate Weare you want to say: “Lighten up! Can’t you ever see the humor of a situation?” Conversely, you’re tempted to ask Monica Bill Barnes, “Aren’t you ever serious about anything?” And so they make an interestingly provocative double bill.

headline: Guitarist of Broad Range, With Lots of Friends
text: Deference and dexterity are steadfastly correlated for the guitarist Lee Ritenour. Over the course of a 35-year solo career, he has personified a carefree sort of prowess, making no secret of his enthusiasms: slinky funk, Brazilian pop, the softer side of hard bop. Because of his breezy sincerity, he’s the rare guitar-geek hero seemingly free of an outsize ego, though that impression may also stem from his warmly ingratiating music, which has often been filed under the category of smooth jazz.

headline: Hot Spots: Lockboxes and Audio Books
text: This year’s dramatic, erratic midterms have ads to match. And they’re coming out with increasing frequency as the incumbents go home to campaign and the races solidify after primaries. Here’s what we’ve been watching this week:

headline: Manly Gore and Brawn, Not Tragedy or Poetry
text: On the very weekend that his younger sister Julia undertakes a spiritual and culinary quest around the globe in “Eat Pray Love,” Eric Roberts, also well within his actorly comfort zone, plays an especially despicable villain in “The Expendables,” the new film by Sylvester Stallone. Mr. Roberts is James Munroe, a renegade C.I.A. guy holding the strings on a Latin American puppet dictator named Garza (David Zayas), whose regime is so awful that his own daughter, Sandra (Giselle Itié), has turned against him. Munroe dismisses this family drama in what strikes me as a remarkably versatile and useful two-word phrase: “Bad Shakespeare.”

headline: Paralysis at the Fed
text: Ten years ago, one of America’s leading economists delivered a stinging critique of the Bank of Japan, Japan’s equivalent of the Federal Reserve, titled “Japanese Monetary Policy: A Case of Self-Induced Paralysis?” With only a few changes in wording, the critique applies to the Fed today.

headline: Is the Husband Going to Be a Problem?
text: I FIRST met Brendon at a student watering hole called the Dutch Goose. The name  at least the part about going halves-ies  would prove prophetic, as we turned out to be equals in so many ways. We were both Ph.D. students in the humanities: I wooed him with Shakespeare quotations, and he took my breath away with his readings of ancient Greek. It was true geek love.

headline: Bloggingheads: Eat, Write, Love
text: Elizabeth Gilbert, left, author of "Eat, Pray, Love," and Susan Orlean of The New Yorker discuss the pros and cons of being a female writer.

headline: A Long, Hot Summer in Mississippi That Still Burns
text: “Neshoba: The Price of Freedom,” a documentary by Micki Dickoff and Tony Pagano, focuses on one of the most notorious and terrible incidents of the 1960s and on its long aftermath.

headline: Patti Labelle Will Join the Cast of ‘Fela!’ in September
text: The Broadway musical “Fela!” may be closing in January, but it is going out in style. The Grammy winner Patti LaBelle is planning to join the cast at the Eugene O’Neill Theater on Sept. 14 as Fela’s mother, Funmilayo Anikulapo-Kuti, a spokesman for the show said on Thursday. “After seeing the show, I was struck by the choreography and work of Bill T. Jones, and the passion and joy that overflows from the stage,” Ms. LaBelle said in a news release. Fela Kuti, a musical superstar in his native Nigeria, used his popularity to oppose the repressive military dictatorship there during the 1970s and ’80s. The musical is set in the nightclub where Fela (played alternately by Sahr Ngaujah and Kevin Mambo) regularly performed his pioneering Afrobeat music. Ms. LaBelle reunited last year with the members of the group Labelle, Sarah Dash and Nona Hendryx for an album, “Back to Now.” But she has also been taking care of business. She has written five books, including three cookbooks, and sells her own collection of wigs and a line of signature sauces and marinades called  what else?  Lady Marmalade.

headline: Footnote
text: David Mamet’s play “Race” has announced it will close its Broadway run on Aug. 21 after its 320th performance. The drama, now starring Eddie Izzard, Dennis Haysbert, Afton C. Williamson and Richard Thomas, will also be traveling across the country next year to San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Milwaukee, Philadelphia and Washington.

headline: ‘Talent’ Puts NBC on Top
text: Four YouTube acts advanced to the semifinals on “America’s Got Talent” on Wednesday as that NBC reality show topped the ratings in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.5 million viewers tuned in to the show’s weekly results episode at 9 p.m., helping to lift NBC to No. 1 for the night over all. CBS, in second place, won both the 8 and 10 p.m. hours. CBS’s “Big Brother” drew 7 million viewers at 8, finishing ahead of both NBC’s “Minute to Win It” (6.4 million) in the time slot and the first half of Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance,” which averaged 6.1 million viewers from 8 to 10. ABC lagged well behind its network competitors to finish in fourth place for the night, averaging 3.8 million viewers from 8 to 10 for repeats of the network’s comedy lineup, followed by a low-rated rerun of “Castle” at 10 (3.9 million).

headline: Love, Travel, Sell
text: MOST husbands call their wives to ask what cut of steak to bring home from the grocery store. Elizabeth Gilbert’s husband rang her from Vietnam and asked, “Do I have permission to buy a 7,000-pound marble Buddha?”

headline: Why Imitation Is the Sincerest Form of Fashion
text: NEW YORK CITY is one of the world’s great centers of fashion. So it’s not surprising that New York’s senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, would take an interest in fashion designers. Last week he introduced legislation that would rewrite copyright law to cover their designs. But his bill could hurt the fashion industry more than it would help, and raise consumer prices along the way.

headline: When the Devil on Your Shoulder Wins
text: For 20 years as a flight attendant with one airline or another, Steven Slater lived with it.

headline: Pakistan’s President Stays Away From Devastated Region
text: Updated | Friday | 1:53 p.m. As Pakistanis continue to post video on the Internet documenting the terrible devastation caused by floods in the country’s northwest, their president, Asif Ali Zardari, was filmed on an inspection tour of flood defenses in the country’s southern Sindh Province on Thursday.

headline: Moscow Express
text: If Russia’s Tourism Ministry keeps a blacklist of undesirables, Martin Cruz Smith has to be near the top, underlined and starred. Though the Soviet Union that once banned Smith’s ground­breaking 1981 novel, “Gorky Park,” no longer exists, 29 years later the land he depicts in his seventh Russian mystery, “Three Stations,” looks no more inviting. While the enemies once were K.G.B. agents, Soviet corruption and American capitalists, now they’re power-hungry bureaucrats, Russian corruption and Russian capitalists — those trading in public utilities, as well as those trading in human flesh. At times it’s even less inviting than the old police state. “You know what’s tragic about all the money floating around?” one character says. “A bottle of vodka used to cost 10 rubles, just the right sum for three people to share.

headline: New Android O.S. and Features
text: Google released Android 2.2, the next iteration of its phone operating system that is chockablock with new features. Unfortunately, it is being introduced only to the HTC Evo  and the original Droid at the moment, but it also comes already installed on the new Droid 2, which is available in stores on Thursday.

headline: AMC Picks Up New Crime Drama
text: The cable network AMC, home to “Mad Men” and “Breaking Bad,” is hoping to continue its hot streak with a new original series. The untitled show’s pilot  originally called “The Killing”  is by the writer and executive producer Veena Sud, a producer and writer for “Cold Case” on CBS. This new crime drama is based on a popular Danish television series, “Forbrydelsen.” The American version, produced by Fox Television Studios, is set in Seattle and follows the investigation of a murdered girl. Production is scheduled to begin this fall in Vancouver with a premiere in 2011. Mireille Enos, who plays a polygamist wife with big hair on HBO’s “Big Love,” stars as the lead homicide detective. The cast also includes Billy Campbell, Michelle Forbes, Joel Kinnaman and Brent Sexton.

headline: A World Loses Balance, and an Allegory Appears
text: Stolid and humorless, larded with windy speeches about keeping Earth’s balance and other virtuous platitudes, “Tales From Earthsea,” a Japanese animated adaptation of Ursula K. Le Guin’s “Earthsea” fantasy novels, feels a little like a science-fiction Sunday school pageant. If this starchy, nearly two-hour allegory about human hubris bluntly addresses a historical moment when global warming threatens the planet and pollution is fouling the seas, its chilly, formal tone keeps you at an emotional distance.

headline: New iPhone O.S. Upgrade Provides Better Security
text: Android wasn’t the only operating system with an update Thursday.

headline: And ‘Work of Art’ Winner Is
text: “Technically, you have an amazing hand, but it was your heart that really moved us tonight.” Those words, spoken by the gallery owner Bill Powers, are not ones you’d be likely to hear uttered in the real art world without a thick protective coating of irony. But “Work of Art,” the Bravo reality show whose first season came to a close Wednesday night, never exactly operated in the real art world. After 13 other aspiring art stars were dispatched with the line “Your work of art didn’t work for us,” Abdi Farah, 22, a smiling, sideways-cap-wearing painter and sculptor and probably the show’s nicest guy, won the grand prize of $100,000 and an exhibition of his work at the Brooklyn Museum, along with the accolades of Mr. Powers and the show’s other judges. (In true nice-guy fashion Mr. Farah said he would give his cash winnings to his mother.) The 10-episode show, partly produced by Sarah Jessica Parker, drew a little more than a million viewers at its height  not in the league of Bravo’s “Top Chef” but not bad for a start-up. The network has not announced whether the show will be picked up for a second season.

headline: ‘Glass Menagerie’ Revival Is Moving to Los Angeles
text: The Wingfield family is taking its collection of glass animals and heading west. The acclaimed production of Tennessee Williams’s “Glass Menagerie,” which started last season at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven and then moved to the Roundabout in New York, is opening at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles next month. Three members of the original cast  Judith Ivey as Amanda, Patch Darragh as Tom, and Keira Keeley as Laura  will be appearing in the production. Ben McKenzie is joining the cast as Jim O’Connor, the Gentleman Caller. This fresh interpretation is directed by Gordon Edelstein.

headline: Win Wars? Today’s Generals Must Also Politick and Do P.R.
text: WASHINGTON  After nine years of fighting in the deserts and mountains of the Middle East, the military has concluded that the traditional, hard-earned combat skills that allowed generations of “muddy boots” commanders to protect American interests around the world simply are not enough to assure victory in today’s wars  or career advancement through the top ranks of the armed forces.

headline: Dell Accused of Concealing Evidence in PC Suit
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Dell has been accused of withholding evidence, including e-mails among its top executives, in a lawsuit over faulty computers it sold to businesses, according to a filing made Thursday.

headline: After 34 Years and Many Diets, ‘Cathy’ Comic Strip to End
text: Readers who have been following the exploits of the slightly overweight and somewhat insecure comic strip character Cathy for 34 years will soon find themselves going through withdrawal. Cathy Guisewite, the strip’s creator, announced on Wednesday that she is ending the popular cartoon’s run, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Guisewite, 59, said that the autobiographical strip has been “the most astonishing form of therapy,” but that her “creative biological clock” was ticking, and she wants to try something else — although isn’t sure what. The urge to spend more time with her 18-year-old daughter and her parents was also a motivation, she said. Carried in about 700 newspapers, “Cathy” is syndicated by Universal Uclick. Although the cartoon Cathy, above, is often frustrated by her overly loving mother, in real life Ms. Guisewite credits her mother with first urging her to write and draw comics. The final strip is scheduled for Oct. 3, after the end of the swimsuit season.

headline: Movie Listings and Film Series
text: Movies

headline: Succession Timing at G.M. Raises Questions
text: It’s more management on the fly at General Motors. That’s certainly the impression left by its chief executive switcheroo. Swapping Daniel F. Akerson for Edward E. Whitacre Jr. may be a better long-term solution. But clumsily announcing it on the eve of a potential initial public offering filing feeds into the notion the company isn’t ready for prime time.

text: Art

headline: Rock and Pop Listings

text: Classical

headline: Chronicling the Cliburn Amateur Contest
text: This movie has been designated as a Critics' Pick.

text: Dance

headline: Jazz Listings
text: Jazz

headline: How the West Won Me
text: Some homes away from home, whether owned or rented, are extensions of people’s primary residence that allow them to carry on as usual in a refreshingly different location. Thus, chic, striving Manhattanites become chic, striving Hamptonites, and suburbanites enjoy flipping burgers at the lake or in the mountains instead of in their usual backyards. Other vacation homes, however, are so radically different that they become labs for experimenting with another way of life altogether. Our house in Dubois (DOO-boyz), Wyo., which is a small cowboy town southeast of Yellowstone National Park, falls into that category.

headline: A Regular-Guy Approach to Entice Men to Shop for Jeans
text: MIKE ROWE, the star of “Dirty Jobs” on the Discovery Channel, has tackled some arduous tasks, among them shark repellent tester and septic tank cleaner. But now he confronts perhaps the dirtiest job of all: persuading shoppers to buy a new product when the economy appears to be weakening again.

headline: Spare Times Listings
text: India Day Parade and Festival (Sunday) Lower Madison Avenue will be teeming with the sights, sounds and tastes of India on Sunday at the 30th India Day Parade and Festival, commemorating the 64th anniversary of India Independence Day. The fun begins at 11 a.m. with a street fair from 23rd to 26th Streets. The first of more than 300 performers from India and the New York area will take to the stage at 2 p.m., among them dancers from the local group Aatma Performing Arts, a two-year-old troupe of male and female dancers that will perform a fusion of contemporary, hip-hop, Bollywood and traditional Indian dance (shown above at last year’s celebration). The group’s name comes from the Hindi word for soul, explained Amit Shah, its founder and president. But before the show starts, 40 floats, 5 marching bands and hundreds of marchers will step off at 1 p.m. at 38th Street for a procession down Madison Avenue. It is all presented by the Federation of Indian Associations, which is celebrating its 40th anniversary this year. (Anne Mancuso)

headline: For Children
text: ‘ECO-FLOWERS FOR KIDS’

headline: Optimist Me
text: One of the odder criticisms I get is from people accusing me of endorsing the Obama administration’s very optimistic forecasts about unemployment. What makes this strange is that during the euphoria of spring-summer 2009, when everyone was saying that we were about to see a V-shaped recovery, I was … well, let’s just look at The New Yorker from May 25, 2009:

headline: Ambassador Leaves Iraq With Much Still Unsettled
text: BAGHDAD  Christopher R. Hill, the ambassador to Iraq charged with reshaping the American role here, on Thursday ended his 16-month tenure in an anxious, unsettled country, with a military withdrawal afoot but a key task not done: the formation of a government that will inherit the country.

headline: Asylum Granted to Mexican Woman in Case Setting Standard on Domestic Abuse
text: The Obama administration has granted asylum to a Mexican woman who was sexually abused and severely battered by her common-law husband. The decision, in a closely watched case, clarifies the exacting standard that domestic abuse victims must meet to win asylum.

headline: A Sendup of India Politics and News
text: What do you if you’re a debt-ridden farmer about to lose your land? If you’re the brothers Naatha (Omkar Das Manikpuri) and Budhia (Raghubir Yadav), you opt to take a politician’s advice: one of you — Budhia chooses Naatha — will commit suicide, thus guaranteeing your family a government subsidy.

headline: Keeping Score: Running the Races Through the Computer
text: Just under 50 games remain on the schedule for each major league team, and the playoff races are coming into focus. Through Wednesday, six teams (the Yankees, Tampa Bay, Chicago, Minnesota, Texas and Boston) in the American League and six teams (Atlanta, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, St. Louis, San Diego and San Francisco) in the National League were within four games of a playoff position.

headline: Hiding in Plain Sight
text: The intense public and media attention to Judge Vaughn R. Walker’s decision in the California same-sex marriage case led me to wonder how the media responded 40 years ago to another Federal District Court ruling — the decision that declared the Texas criminal abortion law unconstitutional, in a case called Roe v. Wade.

headline: Tales of a Trashy Bachelorette
text: “A slut is just a woman with the morals of a man,” proclaims Angela (Karin Anna Cheung), and she should know. Young, promiscuous and proud of it, Angela snaps post-coital candids of her studs (“to remind me where I’ve been”) and, in the rare periods when she’s vertical, makes flash cards recording age, ethnicity and penile dimensions. Don’t judge: every girl needs a hobby.

headline: New G.M. Chief Known as a Pragmatic Leader
text: DETROIT  For the last year, General Motors has been under the leadership of a former telecommunications executive with no tolerance for indecision or distractions, Edward E. Whitacre Jr.

headline: Diving for Pearls, and a Connection to the Past
text: KUWAIT CITY  It was not like the old days: This time, the ships were smaller, the journey was shorter, the work was easier and these young sailors were surely softer.

headline: In Kabul, a Service for Slain Aid Workers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Memorial services inevitably have their awkward moments. So did Thursday’s gathering of Kabul’s international community to remember the 10 slain aid workers, held at the old British Cemetery in Kabul, around the corner from Chicken Street.

headline: A Raw Look at Corruption in the Dominican Republic
text: Pig killing is a recurring motif in “La Soga”, a Dominican Republic-based thriller crawling with abused livestock. Goats, lizards, cockerels and drug dealers jostle for space and screen time, but the pig reigns supreme. Whether gazing limpidly as a knife is twisted in its heart or gamboling in blissful ignorance of its fate, the porker is always in peril.

headline: Canada Stops Ship Carrying 490 People
text: OTTAWA  The Canadian Navy and Coast Guard intercepted a ship off the coast of British Columbia Thursday afternoon that was thought to be carrying hundreds of Tamil migrants from Sri Lanka.

headline: To Cut Demand for Electricity, Some Customers Agree to Unplug
text: Electricity use is up sharply this summer, but in a windowless room near Albany that is the nerve center of New York State’s grid, controllers have noticed that something else is not rising: peak load.

headline: Exploring the Israel-Palestine Standoff
text: Annemarie Jacir’s drama “Salt of This Sea,” about a Brooklyn woman who travels to the West Bank and Israel to recover her roots — not to mention her Palestinian grandfather’s house and bank account, lost in the 1948 war — is a sad and engrossing look at a haunted landscape. Soraya (Suheir Hammad) and the two Palestinian men she befriends, Emad (Saleh Bakri) and Marwan (Riyad Ideis), spend much of the film negotiating both physical barriers — walls, fences, checkpoints, holding cells — and ritual humiliations to move about the rocky, scrubby country in which Emad and Marwan are trapped.

headline: Stepping Out of Jordan’s Shadow, Pippen to Enter Hall
text: On the eve of Scottie Pippen’s induction into basketball’s highest society, Phil Jackson recalled him as “the ultimate team player.” Quite the homage from Jackson, the former Chicago Bulls coach who once watched incredulously as Pippen sat down with 1.8 seconds left in a deadlocked playoff game against the Knicks and refused to get up.

headline: Communication Problems May Have Delayed Search Following Alaska Plane Crash
text: The search for the plane that crashed on an Alaska hillside Monday night, killing former senator Ted Stevens and four others, may have been delayed by hours due to communication breakdowns on the ground and a problem with the plane’s emergency beacon, the chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board said on Thursday.

headline: Learning to Walk in the Slippers of a High-Wire Artist
text: Amye Walters tried not to look down. Her feet gripped a cable less than an inch thick that stretched 21 feet in front of her. Sweat dampened her long dark hair, black tank top and spandex pants.

headline: Iran Shows What It Says Is Murder Confession
text: TEHRAN — Iranian state television has broadcast what it portrayed as a murder confession by a woman who had been sentenced to death by stoning on adultery charges, in an unusual effort to deflect criticism of a case that has drawn international protests and an offer of asylum from the president of Brazil.

headline: The ’20s Roar Back, Without the Prohibitions
text: A speakeasy suggests a clandestine locale, so it was perhaps a misnomer that Wednesday night’s event at the Museum of the City of New York, held in the open-air courtyard in front of the grand building for all the world to see, was called one.

headline: Mets Season Coming Apart at Seams
text: Johan Santana was on the mound Thursday afternoon, providing the Mets with a determined performance just when they needed it most. Francisco Rodriguez, meanwhile, was sitting in the pen, only not the one at Citi Field.

headline: After Layoffs, Yonkers Trims Curriculum
text: YONKERS  Students here will return this fall to bigger classes, limited Advanced Placement options and a dearth of electives in drama, music, cooking and industrial arts because there are fewer teachers to go around.

headline: Would You Coach Your Mother With That Mouth?
text: Shortly after HBO’s “Hard Knocks” was broadcast on Wednesday night, the star of the show, Jets Coach Rex Ryan, called his mother. The episode opened with a parade of profanity by Ryan, and he knew he was in trouble.

headline: Billionaire Investor Nominates 3 Directors in Fight Over Barnes & Noble
text: War broke out over control of Barnes & Noble on Thursday as the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle nominated three directors to the company’s board after efforts to reach a settlement between the sides faltered earlier in the day.

headline: Aide to Paterson Is Charged With Assault
text: David W. Johnson, one of Gov. David A. Paterson’s closest and longest-serving aides, surrendered to prosecutors in the Bronx on Thursday and was charged with misdemeanor assault and five other offenses, the latest chapter in a domestic violence case that entangled the Paterson administration and led the governor to abandon his candidacy.

headline: Mayor’s Stance on Muslim Center Has Deep Roots
text: Michael R. Bloomberg is a former Wall Street mogul with a passion for the rights of a private property owner. He is a Jew whose parents asked their Christian lawyer to buy a house and then sell it back to them to hide their identity in an unwelcoming Massachusetts suburb. And he is a politician who regards his independence as his greatest virtue.

headline: Deal to Put Slots at Aqueduct Paves Way for a New York City Casino
text: After nearly a decade of false starts, squabbling and investigations, Gov. David A. Paterson and legislative leaders have approved a deal to bring casino gambling to New York City.

headline: Ruing Exile, Russian Says He’s No Spy
text: LONDON — Call him the spy who wants to go home again. Except that Igor Sutyagin insists he is not a spy. And his friends warn him not to go home again.

headline: Despite Costs, ‘Clean Coal’ Remains Obama Priority
text: Aug. 13, 8:20 a.m. | Updated The vast remaining deposits of coal in the world guarantee that this fossil fuel will remain a big part of the global energy mix for decades to come. And that reality guarantees that countries with a lot of this resource will remain hopeful that coal can be burned without adding substantially to the atmosphere’s building heat-trapping blanket of carbon dioxide.

headline: Wrongly Convicted Man Gets $7.95 Million Settlement
text: LOS ANGELES  A man who spent 24 years imprisoned for a murder he did not commit will receive $7.95 million from the City of Long Beach after he sued the police there for withholding evidence in his 1980 trial.

headline: Jay Larkin, Theatrical Producer of TV Boxing, Dies at 59
text: Jay Larkin, who brought a theatrical background and hard-nosed negotiating to producing Showtime’s boxing telecasts, ultimately helping the network rival HBO in televising pay-per-view prize-fighting, died Monday in Nyack, N.Y., He was 59.

headline: Cleared, and Pondering the Value of 27 Years
text: HOUSTON  Since a judge let him out of prison for a rape that prosecutors now say he did not commit, Michael A. Green has had trouble sleeping.

headline: E-Mails Show State Officials’ Skepticism About Willets Point Project
text: Even as the Bloomberg administration promotes the $3 billion development of Willets Point in Queens as one of its signature projects, state officials whose approval is needed have privately raised concerns over highway ramps crucial to the proposal and have questioned whether the development will ever get off the ground.

headline: The State of the War
text: We believe that the United States has a powerful national interest in Afghanistan, in depriving Al Qaeda of a safe haven on either side of the Afghanistan-Pakistan border. This country would also do enormous damage to its moral and strategic standing if it now simply abandoned the Afghan people to the Taliban’s brutalities.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Lower Scores Sprout on Rain-Soaked Greens
text: HAVEN, Wis.  Michael Lee, who oversees maintenance at Whistling Straits, has a simple dream: that rain stay away in the weeks before his course hosts a championship tournament.

headline: Eyeing the Same Prize, Two Jets Guards Are Leaning on Each Other
text: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Just before the biggest challenge of his career, a Jets offensive lineman named Matt Slauson, an intimidating 315-pound giant with a spiky beard and tattoos covering his biceps, told Vladimir Ducasse that he would not regard him as his enemy.

headline: Withholding Water and Hoping for the Best
text: HAVEN, Wis. — No one argues that Whistling Straits has the aesthetics of an old coastal links course in the British Isles. But whether it acts like one is another matter.

headline: India Faces Broader Revolt in Kashmir
text: For decades, India maintained hundreds of thousands of security forces in Kashmir to fight an insurgency sponsored by Pakistan, which claims the border region, too. But protests, which have erupted for a third straight summer, have led India to one of its most serious internal crises in recent memory.

headline: Under the Radar, on Top of the N.L.
text: SAN DIEGO  Heath Bell was born in Oceanside, Calif., near San Diego, but he grew up in Tustin, where most people rooted for the Angels or the Dodgers. Bell liked the Padres, and he was 7 when they reached the 1984 World Series. His friends could not share his excitement, though  they did not know who the Padres were.

headline: Sharing of Data Leads to Progress on Alzheimer’s
text: In 2003, a group of scientists and executives from the National Institutes of Health, the Food and Drug Administration, the drug and medical-imaging industries, universities and nonprofit groups joined in a project that experts say had no precedent: a collaborative effort to find the biological markers that show the progression of Alzheimer’s disease in the human brain.

headline: An Interview With Pat Toomey
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with former Representative Pat Toomey, the Republican candidate for the open Senate seat in Pennsylvania.

headline: Spending Posts Now a Liability for Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON  Membership on the Appropriations Committee used to be a first-class ticket to Congressional success, guaranteeing lucky lawmakers the ability to campaign on the federal money they had lavished on the folks back home. But the era of the appropriator appears to be on the wane.

headline: Friday: The Great Manny Nosowsky
text: It’s Friday the 13th and we’re lucky enough to get a puzzle by the great Manny Nosowsky. This is his 246th New York Times crossword in the Shortz Era. Nobody else is even close. Only six other constructors have as many puzzles as he has on Fridays alone.

headline: Call-Up Rings Up $300 Taxi Fare
text: Reliever Ryota Igarashi may have brought new meaning to the phrase taxi squad with his scrambling efforts to get to Citi Field on Thursday, an amusing affair on a grim day for the Mets.

headline: Failing to Block Vans, Union Wants to Run Them
text: Late last month, the city’s leading transit workers’ union sued the Bloomberg administration to stop a plan that would replace discontinued bus routes with privately run commuter vans.

headline: Ah, Dominatrix: I Knew You Way Back in High School
text: Is it all right if I go ahead and award Zach Braff the prize for the best New Yorker cartoon of the year? I don’t mean that Mr. Braff, who was the star of the sitcom “Scrubs,” has taken up drawing for magazines (though, for all I know, he may have). It’s just that playing a reluctant millionaire named Harry in “Trust,” a slender new comedy by Paul Weitz, Mr. Braff is the unmistakable, flesh-and-blood avatar of hundreds of pen-and-ink drawings that have appeared in The New Yorker since its inception.

headline: Pettitte’s Simulated Outing Must Wait a Day
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Joe Girardi called Andy Pettitte around noon on Thursday, wanting to hear how Pettitte felt in his simulated outing. Pettitte had other news instead.

headline: Pessimism in Asia Despite a Strong Earnings Season
text: HONG KONG

headline: They’ll Do It for Nothing
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Politicians seeking to placate angry voters this election cycle might take a cue from Robert Bentley, a retired dermatologist and the Republican nominee for governor in Alabama.

headline: Inquiry on Harvard Lab Threatens Ripple Effect
text: Harvard’s slow-motion inquiry about the laboratory of Marc Hauser, one of its star academics, has cast a shadow over the several different fields in which Dr. Hauser and his students published papers.

headline: WePay Wants to Simplify Group Payments
text: The hardest part of helping organize my coming high school reunion — aside from devising ways to break the ice with old crushes and rivals — is collecting money from the alumni for tickets.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: For the Everglades, a Dream Loses Much of Its Grandeur
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  In the end, Gov. Charlie Crist’s effort to buy huge swaths of sugar company land for the Everglades restoration was just too much: too much money, too much land to handle, and too much of a fight with critics and the courts.

headline: Stars Turn Out for USA Basketball Showcase
text: For those walking into Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, it was strange to see the storied stage transformed into a basketball court for the USA Basketball Showcase. But what made the scene even more unusual was that on the far sideline, from left to right, sat Dwyane Wade, Chris Paul, Carmelo Anthony, Amar’e Stoudemire and finally, LeBron James.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 12
text: A view of the day in sports, including the European swimming championships in Hungary and the United States gymnastics championships in Hartford.

headline: Alfas, Auctions and Racing Action on the Monterey Peninsula
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,208 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Sabathia Wins His 15th as Yankees Add to Their Lead
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  C. C. Sabathia started drinking water before the Yankees’ game Wednesday in steamy Texas, downed several cups on the team plane, and in his hotel room on Thursday he mixed in some Gatorade. He did not know precisely how much liquid he had consumed  enough, he guessed, to keep a man listed at 6-feet-7 and a generous 290 pounds hydrated on a hot night.

headline: Alcatraz’s Newest Star, the Melancholy Dane
text: For any director, putting on a full-scale “Hamlet” is notoriously intense.

headline: Bloggingheads: Billionaire Leeches
text: Journalist Maureen Tkacik, left, and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate the societal value of the very wealthy.

headline: New Mudslides Raise Death Toll in China
text: Rain-triggered mudslides across China have pushed up the death toll from China’s worst flooding in a decade and left thousands trapped, state media reported on Friday. In southwestern Sichuan Province, a mudslide killed at least five people and trapped more than 500 others, the Xinhua state news agency reported. Farther north in Gansu Province, the number of dead and missing was raised after new floodwaters surged through the region, Xinhua reported. In the city of Longnan 10 people died, 12 were reported missing and 10,000 trapped by floodwaters, the local government said in a statement, Xinhua reported. In Tianshui, four people died and eight were missing, Xinhua said.

headline: Vacation Apartment Rentals: Lucrative and Largely Illegal
text: Summer in San Francisco brings in gusts of chilly winds and bursts of tourists. Instead of staying in hotels, a growing number of visitors opt to live like the locals, renting apartments in the city’s colorful neighborhoods.

headline: In Oakland, Private Force May Be Hired for Security
text: In a basement office that serves as a police headquarters and community center, Oakland Chinatown leaders pored over maps of the neighborhood with representatives from a private security firm last week.

headline: China: Government Investigates Reports of Problems With Milk Powder Diet
text: Reports that three infant girls in south-central China have developed premature breast growth while on a diet of milk powder have drawn national attention in China and a government investigation, but the Chinese manufacturer of the powder denies any problem with its product. The Health Ministry said Thursday that it had appointed a panel of nine experts to investigate the reports. The reports have suggested that the powder may contain hormones that could set off premature puberty. The formula’s manufacturer, Synutra International of Qingdao, said in a statement on Wednesday that there was no scientific evidence to link its product to the infants’ premature development.

headline: Urban Farming for Cash Gains a Toehold in San Francisco
text: Brooke Budner and Caitlyn Galloway are a common sight on the streets of the Mission district  covered in dirt and carrying baskets of salad mix from their backyard farm to Bar Tartine, a stylish upscale restaurant.

headline: Many Chicago Charter Schools Run Deficits, Data Shows
text: Even as the Obama administration promotes charter schools as a way to help raise the academic performance of the nation’s students, half of Chicago’s charter schools have been running deficits in recent years, an analysis of financial and budget documents shows, calling into question their financial viability.

headline: China: Tibetan Writer’s Trial Postponed
text: The trial of a Tibetan writer who has criticized Chinese policies in Tibet in a recent book may be postponed, according to the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group. The group said in a statement on Thursday that it was unclear whether a postponement of the trial for the writer, whose name is Tragyal, would suggest that the authorities were questioning the premise of the trial or whether they were looking for more evidence. Mr. Tragyal was detained in April in Xining, after the publication of his book, “The Line between Sky and Earth.”

headline: Uganda: Suspect in Bombings Says He Wanted to Kill Americans
text: The confessed mastermind of terrorist attacks that killed more than 70 people during the World Cup finals last month said Thursday that the attacks were aimed at Americans. The suspect was one of four Ugandans presented to the public on Thursday who confessed to planning the bombings in Kampala, said Kale Kayihura, Uganda’s inspector general. “I was reluctant to pick on Ugandans,” the man identified as the group’s leader, Issa Ahmed Luyima, left, 33, told journalists in Kampala, according to Reuters. “My rage was with the Americans, whom I deemed responsible for all the suffering of Muslims around the world.” The suspects said they were working with the Shabab, an Islamist insurgency in Somalia, which has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

headline: A Candidate Takes an Unlikely Green Path
text: As a boy growing up in the long shadow of the Ida B. Wells public housing development, LeAlan Jones, the Illinois Green Party candidate for the United States Senate, learned at an early age to ignore naysayers.

headline: France: U.N. Body Raises Rights Issues
text: A United Nations human rights body strongly criticized France this week, denouncing what it deemed a marked growth in racism and xenophobia. Meeting with French representatives on Wednesday and Thursday, the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, based in Geneva, expressed particular concern over a government-led “debate on the national identity,” President Nicolas Sarkozy’s proposal to withdraw citizenship from certain foreign-born criminals, and a recent decision to dismantle 300 unauthorized Roma encampments. “It’s time you made your dreams of equality and fraternity a reality,” said the committee’s vice chairman, Pierre-Richard Prosper, Le Monde reported. On Thursday, Pierre Lellouche, French minister for European affairs, said the government’s actions were meant to guarantee the “first of human rights, which is the right to safety.”

headline: California Cruising: A Week of Magnificent Machines
text: Here are some of the cars that will go on auction this weekend at events in Monterey, Calif.

headline: Rostenkowski, Master Politician and Benefactor
text: The one time I dined with Dan Rostenkowski in Washington, we didn’t go to his red-meat favorite, a Morton’s steak house in Georgetown. There he’d routinely hold court with legislative chums at a table with his name affixed to a nearby metal plate.

headline: With N.L.’s Best Record, the Padres Head North
text: SAN DIEGO – Heath Bell does not wait for the middle innings, the way a lot of closers do, to join his fellow relievers in the San Diego Padres’ bullpen. He gathers the brigade after the national anthem for the walk across the Petco Park grass, with the youngest member, Ernesto Frieri, lugging a Chewbacca backpack.

headline: Prosecutor Is Changed in the Trial of a Senator
text: The assault trial of State Senator Kevin S. Parker was thrown into turmoil on Thursday, as a judge granted a request by the Brooklyn district attorney’s office to have two special prosecutors appointed.

headline: The Pulse: A Cooling Trend on Cap and Trade
text: Like much of the Northern Hemisphere, Chicago is suffering through one of the hottest summers in recent memory, raising more discussion about global warming.

headline: The Pulse: Antiviolence Ritual From a Faraway Land
text: After years of frustration, Cheryl Graves was ready to consider a different solution to Chicago’s problem of youth violence.

text: ambivalence •\am-ˈbi-və-lən(t)s\• noun

headline: Raúl Martínez: ‘Eagerly Awaiting’
text: Magnan Metz Gallery

headline: Jennifer Dalton: Making Sense
text: FLAG Art Foundation

headline: News Quiz | August 13, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: ‘Shred’
text: Perry Rubenstein

headline: Burkle Proposes Directors in Barnes & Noble Fight
text: War broke out over control of Barnes & Noble on Thursday as the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle nominated three directors to the company’s board after efforts to reach a settlement between the sides faltered earlier in the day.

headline: Switzerland Tries to Check Franc and Aid Exports
text: While the rest of Europe struggles to rein in government debt, there is no talk of forced austerity in prudent Switzerland. Instead, the country is looking forward to growth of at least 2.5 percent this year, thanks to booming exports, Jack Ewing writes in The New York Times.

headline: A Third Down Day on Wall Street
text: A decline in technology shares and weak jobs data sent Wall Street indexes down on Thursday, as traders were confronted with more signs that the global economy was slowing, Christine Hauser reports in The New York Times.

headline: Greek Recession Deepens Amid Spending Cuts
text: Greece’s recession deepened in the second quarter, according to official estimates released Thursday, as the country felt the painful consequences of the government’s drive to reduce its debt load with aggressive austerity cuts, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Indiana Lawmaker Wants Donations Returned
text: A Democratic lawmaker wants Indiana politicians and campaign organizations to return contributions they received from an Indianapolis businessman whose dealings are being investigated by the F.B.I.

headline: The Hidden Income of China’s Wealthy
text: China’s households hide as much as 9.3 trillion renminbi of income that is not reported in official figures, with 80 percent accrued by the wealthiest people, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Dell Accused of Concealing Evidence in PC Suit
text: Dell has been accused of withholding evidence, including e-mails among its top executives, in a lawsuit over faulty computers it sold to businesses, according to a filing made Thursday, Ashlee Vance reported in The New York Times.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Pigwidgeon
text: Today’s word, in association with the glorious Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Norris: Taxes No Longer So Certain
text: From Floyd Norris’s latest High and Low Finance column:

headline: With New Chief Planned, G.M. I.P.O. Looms
text: For the last year, General Motors has been under the leadership of a former telecommunications executive with no tolerance for indecision or distractions, Edward E. Whitacre Jr.

headline: Emergent to Acquire Trubion for $96.8 Million
text: Trubion Pharmaceuticals, a Seattle biotech firm, agreed to be acquired by Emergent BioSolutions for $96.8 million in cash and stock and a potential later payment of as much as $38.7 million, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: In Retrospect, Most Big Deals Were Bad Ideas
text: More than half of the 100 biggest takeovers made during the last mergers-and-acquisitions boom have something in common: By one measure, they never should have happened, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: U.S. Firms Paying Down Loans in Double Time
text: Speculative-grade companies are doubling the rate at which they are repaying leveraged loans, as they try to curb the likelihood of rising defaults amid signs the American economy is slowing, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Mahindra of India Has Top Bid for Ssangyong
text: Ssangyong Motor, the South Korean automaker, named Mahindra & Mahindra, the top sport utility vehicle maker in India, as its preferred buyer Thursday, demonstrating the growing clout of manufacturers from emerging markets.

headline: Utah Investor Seeks Comeback in Idaho
text: A Utah investor who lost a $5 million private jet, a luxury car and his membership in the Utah Jazz‘s premier fan club in a bankruptcy said his company will resurrect a moribund central Idaho ski and golf resort, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Warner Chilcott Prices $750 Million Debt Issue
text: Warner Chilcott, the Irish drug maker, said Thursday its subsidiaries sold $750 million of senior notes in a private placement, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Vedanta in Talks to Take Control of Cairn India
text: Vedanta Resources is in talks to buy a controlling stake in Cairn Energy’s Indian subsidiary, The Financial Times reported. Cairn India‘s stock rose 1.6 percent on the Bombay Stock Exchange in morning trading Friday following the disclosure. In separate statements, both Vedanta and Cairn confirmed talks were ongoing.

headline: Cosmetic Treatment Controversy
text: By CARRIE MONTGOMERY

headline: Korean Oil Concern Could Go Hostile in Bid for Dana
text: Korea National Oil Corporation has indicated it is willing to start a hostile takeover bid for Dana Petroleum after the British company formally said that K.N.O.C.’s £1.7 billion offer did not reflect the value of its oil exploration program.

headline: Are You Cool or Hot Under Pressure?
text: The story of a flight attendant escaping from an airplane down an inflatable chute after an altercation with a passenger has attracted a lot of attention. The City Room blog compared the response of Steven Slater, the attendant, to a difficult situation with that of pilot Chesley Sullenberger, who famously landed a plane in the Hudson River. City Room suggests that we all look inside and ask, “Am I a Sully? Or am I a Slater?” Which are you?

headline: Report Says Buyout Sector Doesn’t Beat Markets
text: New research into the private equity sector could prompt a new debate about whether buyout firms add value to their investments, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Och-Ziff Said to Be Part of Lehman Rumors
text: Dick Fuld may have been right after all.

headline: Hedge Fund Investment Gets July Boost
text: Hedge funds stabilized somewhat in July as investors poured more money into the sector amid rebounding stock markets, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing estimates published by HedgeFund.net.

headline: Li Adds to His Stake in Hutchison Whampoa
text: Billionaire Li Ka-shing made his biggest investment in Hutchison Whampoa shares in at least seven years, boosting a stock that has already been the best performer of the month in Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: In Hong Kong, Where to Get Well-Heeled
text: For Hong Kong fashion mavens, shoes are often not an accessory, but the main item. So it’s not surprising that shoe boutiques of all styles and prices proliferate across the city. But fans of luxury footwear have been making a special pilgrimage to the recently opened Rupert Sanderson boutique, the brand’s flagship store in Asia.

headline: Health Care, Uncertainty and Morality
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Authorities Say Ponzi Had Ties to Christian Chat Show
text: The Ontario Securities Commission has named two sons of David Mainse, the founder of the Canadian Christian talk show, “100 Huntley Street,” in a case involving a $15 million Ponzi scheme, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Myanmar Junta Sets Election Date
text: BANGKOK  Myanmar will hold its first elections in two decades on Nov. 7, the ruling junta announced Friday, setting a date for a vote that has been denounced by opponents as a means of legitimizing military power within the format of civilian rule.

headline: Citigroup Helps Scions Manage Their Allowances
text: Citigroup is helping the kids of its wealthiest clients to manage their allowances. The bank, Bloomberg News reported, is testing a Web site to let millionaires’ children manage their money, while alerting parents and bankers when scions blow through cash too quickly.

headline: Li & Fung Offers $901 Million for Distributor
text: Li & Fung, the biggest supplier to retailers including Wal-Mart Stores, is offering about 7 billion Hong Kong dollars ($901 million) for a distribution company to gain a network in China. Both companies’ shares rose in Hong Kong on the news.

headline: Will Voice Recognition Hurt Literature?
text: Today’s idea: In the annals of writing, women taking transcription were the dominant form of voice-recognition software for centuries. But no longer. Will literature itself suffer?

headline: Pakistan Leader Faces Fury Over Floods
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  With Pakistanis bracing for more rain and floods, President Asif Ali Zardari struggled Friday to confront a barrage of criticism over his recent visit to Europe, undertaken while rivers gorged by monsoon rains ravaged large portions of the country  a trip that critics have derided as “insensitive” and a “joy ride.”

headline: How Do Giants Fans Feel About the Jets’ Publicity Push?
text: In New York, if not the nation, the Jets are the team people are talking about. That’s the way the Jets like it, and their publicity push far predates “Hard Knocks.”

headline: Growth of Euro-Area Economy Beats Forecasts
text: The euro-area economy grew 1 percent in the second quarter, a much better rate than had been expected, due largely to Germany’s best quarterly performance since reunification, according to data released on Friday.

headline: Stray Questions for Richard Toye
text: Richard Toye’s book “Churchill’s Empire” is reviewed in this Sunday’s Book Review.

headline: Tip of the Week: Getting Rid of Duplicate Songs
text: Have you accidentally imported the same CD twice, or do you have duplicated songs in your iTunes library? A built-in feature of iTunes lets you easily weed out doubles. Just open the iTunes program and click on the icon for your Music library on the left side of the window. Next, go to the File menu and choose the Display Duplicates option.

headline: Funds ‘Getting an Education’ in MGM Auction
text: With Spyglass Entertainment poised to become part-owner of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, The Hollywood Reporter examines why the venerable but debt-ridden studio would go with the independent production company rather than other options it’s had during the auction process.

headline: A Hollywood-Wall Street Smackdown
text: In what The Hollywood Reporter Esquire blog called “a real Hollywood-vs.-Wall Street smackdown,” Goldman Sachs has fired back at producer Joel Silver’s $30 million lawsuit, trying to have the claims thrown out of court.

headline: Wall Street Tries to Sort Through Economic Reports
text: Stocks fell for a fourth straight day Friday after new economic statistics reinforced a picture of a sluggish recovery in the United States.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — The Dutch have made one of the best documentaries on quants so far, starring, among others, Emanuel Derman and an oysterman. (Hat tip to Felix Salmon)

headline: AgBank’s I.P.O. Proceeds Said to Hit $22 Billion
text: Agricultural Bank of China has fully exercised an over-allotment option for the Shanghai portion of its initial public offering, taking the total proceeds from the offer to $22.1 billion, making the I.P.O. the world’s biggest, Reuters reported.

(By the way, the Times does allow me to delete a comment simply because it’s an attack on the author. But I never have.)

headline: Social Security Finances
text: Sadly, it looks as if we’re going to have to fight the Social Security fight all over again, with the same old disingenuous arguments making the rounds. So let me return to an oldie but baddie: the there-is-no-trust-fund nonsense.

headline: In the Mayor’s Mailbag: Applause and Anger
text: The letters and e-mails have poured in to City Hall.

headline: A Scientific Shift Yields New Insights Into Alzheimer’s
text: The Times reports this morning that a shift in research strategy among scientists is beginning to yield insights into how Alzheimer’s disease begins. The key to the Alzheimer’s project was an agreement as ambitious as its goal: not just to raise money, not just to do research on a vast scale, but also to share all the data, making every single finding public immediately, available to anyone with a computer anywhere in the world.

headline: Vain Glorious | Setai Spa Signature Massage

headline: Your Photos From Monterey
text: Last week, Wheels put out a call for submissions from readers who are attending any of the auctions, races or other collector car events surrounding the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance. With just a couple days of events so far, we’ve gotten a handful of submissions, including the photos illustrating this post, from Thomas Chavez and Coby Mendoza.

headline: I.B.M. to Buy Unica for $451.7 Million
text: 11:11 a.m. | Updated I.B.M. said Friday that it had agreed to buy Unica, a seller of marketing software, for $451.7 million in cash, the latest in a string of bolt-on acquisitions for the tech services giant.

headline: Working Nights, Sleeping Poorly
text: What happens when your work schedule interferes with a good night’s sleep and you find yourself growing increasingly exhausted? One reader asks the Consults blog.

headline: The Early Word: Observing Ramadan
text: President Obama is scheduled to host an iftar dinner — the meal that breaks the daily fast during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan — at the White House on Friday evening.

headline: Phone Cameras Fuel Kashmir’s ‘Intifada’
text: Updated |1:40 p.m. As my colleague Lydia Polgreen reports, in Kashmir, India faces “an intifada-like popular revolt against the Indian military presence,” in which images of stone-throwing youth are celebrated on Facebook pages and in YouTube videos.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Hey There, Pilgrim!
text: For a 20-something slacker from Toronto, Scott Pilgrim is looking very ambitious. Tuesday saw the release of the soundtrack of “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World” and the film version, starring Michael Cera, opens on Friday. This week also saw the premiere of the Scott Pilgrim video game. A review at Comics Alliance called it “fun” and “old school.” The character’s quest to be the king of all media has also landed his publisher, Oni Press, a deal with comiXology to create an application that make the six volumes of the comic available for purchase on iTunes. Those six volumes can also be found in the top seven of our softcover list this week. (The latest volume of “The Walking Dead” enters our list at No. 2.)

headline: When Fame Mingles With Atrocity
text: LONDON — In the last few weeks, an unlikely image from the archives has created a commotion, raising questions about celebrity and justice, and where they could possibly intersect.

headline: Complaint Box | Smartphones and Dumb Parents
text: For children, the playground means a chance to stretch their legs and imaginations, while their parents, in increasing numbers, exercise their thumbs. With a so-called smartphone seemingly at every adult’s fingertips, many parents are finding playtime to be the ideal time for answering e-mails, firing off text messages and browsing the Web — leaving their children to cavort about virtually unattended at playgrounds, pools and kiddie gyms.

headline: Russia Sets Date for Crucial Step in Iranian Nuclear Start-Up
text: MOSCOW  In a move sure to disappoint United States diplomats trying to halt Iran’s nuclear program, the Russian state nuclear power company said Friday that it would take a crucial step later this month toward starting Iran’s first nuclear power plant.

headline: Deadly Clashes Continue in Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI  Kashmiris demanding independence from India flooded the streets in protests across Kashmir on Friday, clashing repeatedly with the police and Indian security forces, the authorities said.

headline: Friday Reading: Tipping for Free Drinks and Food
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Student Challenge Favorite | Deconstructing Materialism
text: And we thought we had a hard time choosing a favorite last time!

headline: Governors Island: A Critics’ Roundtable
text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asks Edward Rothstein in today’s Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On ArtsBeat today, critics from several disciplines will be discussing the island’s role as a cultural destination. Check back for regular updates throughout the day and share your own thoughts about the island, too.

headline: How to Hide From Friends You Don’t Like
text: With more than 500 million people now on Facebook, it’s inevitable that you’ll be friended by someone you know, but with whom you don’t want to share your online life. Once you’ve accepted them as a friend, how do you avoid them without the awkwardness of unfriending them?

headline: Suspect in Hamas Killing in Dubai Is Freed by Germany
text: BERLIN  A man suspected of being an Israeli spy involved in the killing of a Hamas leader in Dubai last January was released on bail by a German judge on Friday.

headline: The Increasing Role and Influence of Military Spouses
text: I am leaving active duty this month, and the biggest fan of this change is my wife. The decision to leave the military did not come easily. During required counseling sessions with my battalion and brigade commanders, these senior officers sought to persuade me to stay on active duty.

headline: Anti-Age Spot
text: Serums are the workhorses of the skin-care world. Best applied under moisturizer, serums are said to penetrate more deeply than creams, delivering ingredients that promise anti-aging benefits, like brighter complexions and renewed volume. Among the multitudes, here are our new favorites. (Related article: Am I Young Yet?)

headline: On Our Radar: Fealty to Kentucky Coal
text: Kentucky Senate candidates attempt to one-up one another on their allegiance to coal. “I’m going to judge any energy legislation by four criteria,” says Jack Conway, a Democrat. “Number one: does it do the right thing by Kentucky coal?” [Talking Points Memo]
