text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asks Edward Rothstein in today’s Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On ArtsBeat today, critics from several disciplines will be discussing the island’s role as a cultural destination. Check back for regular updates throughout the day and share your own thoughts about the island, too. Read previous entries here.

headline: Glaxo Censures Sale of Supplements
text: Is it unethical — or a conflict of interest — for pharmaceutical executives to have their own side venture selling a compound as a dietary supplement while the drug company they work for is running a clinical trial of the substance as a potential cancer treatment?

headline: A Global Graveyard for Dead Computers in Ghana
text: The unexpected consequences of shipping computers to the developing world.

headline: Gravestone Removals Add Fuel to Jerusalem Museum Dispute
text: JERUSALEM  The latest skirmish in the war for every inch of this coveted city focused this week on the dead. Did Israeli government bulldozers, working in the middle of the night, destroy hundreds of historic Muslim graves? Or were the removed tombstones outrageous fakes placed on parkland in a ruse?

headline: Inside the List
text: READING FOR MARS, I: Mary Roach’s jaunty exploration of space travel, “Packing for Mars,” plants its flag at No. 6 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Will any astronauts be tossing it in their carry-ons? Some books have been launched into space. Ron Garan, a NASA astronaut who is preparing to fly to the International Space Station in March, has been posting Twitter updates about the books he’s taking along, including “The Blue Sweater: Bridging the Gap Between Rich and Poor in an Interconnected World,” by Jacqueline Novogratz, and Muhammad Yunus’s “Creating a World Without Poverty.” He may also find some books left behind by previous travelers, including Goethe’s “Faust” and Robert A. Heinlein’s sci-fi classic “The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress,” carried up by the former Microsoft executive Charles Simonyi during his two self-financed voyages.

headline: Something’s Burning
text: Anna Pigeon, the stalwart National Park Service ranger in Nevada Barr’s rugged wilderness novels, has been feeling her age lately (she was “coming up on 50” six years ago in “High Country”), and she’s giving serious thought to a job change. BURN (Minotaur, $25.99) might be considered a step in that direction, since it takes place mostly in the French Quarter of New Orleans and restricts its animal studies to acts of cruelty committed by bipeds who consider themselves human.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: CYBER WAR  The Next Threat to National Security and What to Do About It.  By Richard A. Clarke and Robert K. Knake.  Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.99.

headline: Up Front: Olen Steinhauer
text: In the mid-1990s, Olen Steinhauer recalled in a recent e-mail from his home in Budapest, he spent a few drunken months in Prague trying to write like James Joyce.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE DEATH OF THE ADVERSARY, by Hans Keilson. Translated by Ivo Jarosy.  (Farrar, Straus & Giroux; paper, $14.) COMEDY IN A MINOR KEY,  by Hans Keilson. Translated by Damion Searls.  (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.)  These two novels, set in Nazi-occupied Europe, are midcentury masterpieces by the centenarian Keilson, who was in the Dutch resistance.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BRIGHT-SIDED: How Positive Thinking Is Undermining America,  by Barbara Ehrenreich (Picador, $15.) When Ehrenreich learned she had breast cancer in 2000, she was appalled by the pink-ribboned positive-thinking culture that surrounds patients — especially by the admonition to “consider your cancer a gift.” In her 17th book, she traces the history of American positive thinking to the reaction against Calvinism, and explores its current manifestations in cancer treatment, corporate retreats, megachurches and the real estate bubble.

headline: Sex and the New Parent
text: Every once in awhile someone does a poll to tell you what you could have already told them — new parents are not having a whole lot of sex.

headline: Cool Summer Cucumber Dishes
text: During a tour of Scotland in 1773, the British author Samuel Johnson famously dissed the lowly cucumber.

headline: Nurse Tells of Storied Kiss. No, Not That Nurse.
text: It is a defining image of the American century, one that expressed the joy of a nation at its moment of greatest triumph: on the day the Japanese surrender was announced, a sailor grabbed a nurse in the middle of Times Square, bent her back and kissed her.

headline: Chilled to the Bone
text: “I had no name, no home in time,” thinks Arvid Jansen, the narrator of Per Petterson’s slender, subtly incisive new novel, “I Curse the River of Time.” It’s a statement that could apply to most of Petterson’s lonely Scandinavian souls. In his books — the best known is probably “Out Stealing Horses” — Petterson depicts a literal and figurative geo­graphy that, to American readers, might feel a little like the starker reaches of the West, a little like the stonier shores of Maine, a little like Edward Hopper, a little like Raymond Carver. His characters are decent, laconic and perpetually, possibly existentially, chilled. They just can’t get warm, can’t stay warm, no matter how hard they try. At the risk of perpetrating a geographical cliché, I have to say that Petterson’s world feels Far Northern to the core — windswept, dimly lit, its summers and romances hard-won, deeply felt, reluctantly left behind. Memory, in this unregenerate landscape, is often the only thing these people have to get them through the winter of their discontents. They hoard it, hide it, keep it close at all times. Petterson’s narratives tend to unspool in the first person, in hushed, confidential tones. Tight-lipped with one another, his characters open their hearts to the reader, making us witnesses to their most private selves. He makes the reader lean in, out of the wind, to listen closely.

headline: Age of Innocence
text: Any dreamy or bookish girl who once loved “Harriet the Spy” should immediately take up this lively new biography of Edith Wharton by Connie Nordhielm Wooldridge. “The Brave Escape of Edith Wharton” tells the story of a strong-willed, unconventional and smart girl who escaped the stifling life of upper­-crust New York around 1880. It includes lush photographs of that faraway time and a pencil drawing Wharton did of herself at 14 reading a book.

headline: Filling In the Insurance Gap for Adult Children
text: TAMAR ZAIDENWEBER, a 24-year-old graduate student at Georgetown University, lost her insurance coverage under her father’s health plan in 2008 because she was no longer financially dependent on him. Because of the new health care law, she will be able to rejoin his policy.

headline: Returning to a Parent’s Health Plan
text: This fall the new health care law will allow young adults under the age of 26 to return to a parent’s health plan, regardless of their student status or whether they are financially dependent on their parents.

headline: N.F.I.B. Opposes Small-Business Owner in Congress
text: Representative Betsy Markey, the Democrat who represents Colorado’s Fourth District, may have owned and operated two small businesses but that didn’t keep the National Federation of Independent Business from calling her Republican opponent “the only choice for small-business owners in this Congressional race.”

headline: Ackman Lays Out His Plan for Stuyvesant Town
text: The billionaire hedge fund manager William A. Ackman has great ambitions for Stuyvesant Town, but he is also taking considerable risks. The sprawling apartment complex on the East Side of Manhattan could end up being either a cash cow or a huge headache for Mr. Ackman, who runs Pershing Square Capital Management.

headline: Medical Care Prices Fell for First Time in 35 Years
text: Then again, maybe the deflationary apocalypse really is upon us: For the first time in 35 years, the one sector of the economy always guaranteed to get more expensive suddenly became a bit cheaper in July.

headline: Survey Says: Next H.P. CEO to Come From H.P. or I.B.M.
text: The C-Suite has spoken and called for a Hewlett-Packard or I.B.M. executive to end up as H.P.’s next chief executive.

headline: August Historical Events Fill-In
text: From Hiroshima and the 19th amendment to Woodstock and Elvis Presley, here are 31 historical events that took place in the month of August. How many of the fill-in-the-blanks can you get right?

headline: Monserrate Down, but Not Out of Sight
text: Hiram Monserrate was convicted of domestic abuse. He was the first lawmaker in Albany expelled from office since Calvin Coolidge was president. He is persona non grata among New York Democratic Party leaders. His campaign war chest is half as big as his opponent’s, and he has no paid staff members. His campaign office has the look of an abandoned storefront.

headline: What Does W Stand For?
text: THE newly revamped W now comes with a slanted logo, as if to say, “Let’s go!” The energized logo might be the most promising thing about the magazine, which has a new editor, Stefano Tonchi, formerly the editor of T: The New York Times Magazine, as well as a new creative director, Jody Quon. I’ve been a reader of W since its broadsheet days, when it was driven by the curiosity and often deliciously snippy tongue of its founder, John Fairchild. In 2000, I wrote a profile of its then creative director, Dennis Freedman, and the way he cultivated photographers and helped bring to life sometimes-difficult ideas in fashion and art. In its long history W, at its best, was a scrappy journalistic player with a knowing sense of the people it covered.

headline: P.G.A. Play Resumes After Second Day of Fog
text: 12:19 p.m. |First Round Resumes on Second Day

headline: Mercedes-Benz G-Class Involved in 2 Recalls
text: Mercedes-Benz is recalling some of its G-Class sport utility vehicle, but owners of the automaker’s deluxe off-roader may have second thoughts about complying.

headline: Smile, Everyone!
text: My daughter is marrying a wonderful young man whose parents we’ve met just once. We enjoyed their company and seemed compatible with them. But the mother of my soon-to-be son-in-law has horrible teeth. The ones in front are twisted and blackened, and some are missing. There must be a psychological issue that keeps her from seeking dental help. But I’m concerned about the wedding pictures. It’s my daughter’s big day, and I think everyone should make an effort to look their best. How do I communicate my concern without seeming like a monster?

headline: Governors Island: When the Visit Is Better Than the Dance
text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asks Edward Rothstein in today’s Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On ArtsBeat today, critics from several disciplines will be discussing the island’s role as a cultural destination. Check back for regular updates throughout the day and share your own thoughts about the island, too. Read previous entries here.

headline: Eat, Pray, Spritz | Food Stylist Susan Spungen
text: Susan Spungen has had many careers: restaurant cook and caterer, Martha Stewart’s culinary right hand for a dozen years, food stylist (for T Magazine and others). In recent years, she’s brought the meals in the top food movies to life, from the duck en croute for “Julie & Julia” (even Jacques Pépin approved) to the plot-advancing croissants in “It’s Complicated” and now the Roman feasts in “Eat Pray Love,” which opens today. The Moment caught up with Spungen over a cappuccino at Bluebird Coffee to find out how she kept her pasta from outshining Julia Roberts, and to get her tips for dining in Rome.

headline: German Real Estate Lender Still Deep in the Red
text: Gift is the German word for poison, and Hypo Real Estate, the troubled lender nationalized by the German government, is the gift that keeps on giving.

headline: Upstairs, Downstairs, Jersey Style
text: From “Jane Eyre” to “The Nanny Diaries,” literature is rich with stories about the domestic lives of the privileged, as observed by their domestics. Marina Budhos offers a further twist in her novel “Tell Us We’re Home”: Now the children of the privileged are observed by the sharp-eyed daughters of their nannies and housekeepers, as they mingle in the school hallways of an affluent New Jersey suburb.

headline: Not Like the Other
text: Science tells us that identical twins are not actually identical. And the longer they live in the world, influenced by their surroundings, the less alike they prove to be. If you have any doubt, ask Ling and Ting, who are experts on the subject.

headline: Children’s Bookshelf
text: BLOCKHEAD  The Life of Fibonacci.  By Joseph D’Agnese.Illustrated by John O’Brien.  Holt. $16.99. (Ages 6 to 9)

headline: The Waters Are More Still, but Just as Dark
text: The Goodman household has calmed down since the last time I hung out there. Sure, Mom is still certifiably bipolar and delusional; Dad is suffocating on his own denial; and the kids  well, let’s just say they’re definitely not all right. Yet in the newly recast “Next to Normal,” the musical that won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in April, nobody is bouncing off the walls anymore or threatening to pull the audience into one collective meltdown of extreme feelings.

headline: Start the Presses
text: “The humanist mythology of print.” With this phrase the British scholar Andrew Pettegree indicates the cultural story his book amends, and to some extent transforms. In an understated, judicious manner, he offers a radically new understanding of printing in the years of its birth and youth. Print, in Pettegree’s account, was never as dignified or lofty a medium as that “humanist mythology” of disseminated classics would suggest.

headline: Pledging Fortunes Takes Extra Effort in Shaky Recovery
text: Warren Buffett and Bill and Melinda Gates gave billionaires a jolt of positive publicity last week with the  unveiling of the Giving Pledge  a promise by 40 individuals and couples to donate at least half of their fortunes to charity. Their commitments were outlined in individual letters explaining their reasons.

headline: Digg Patriots
text: Conservative members of the Web site Digg  who, allegedly, attempt to “bury” liberal content on the site.

headline: Bob Uecker Returns to the Booth
text: MILWAUKEE  Bob Uecker was urging 7-year-old Joseph Knapp to show his scar from kidney cancer surgery. “Come on, man, where is it?” Uecker said the other night in the Brewers’ radio booth at Miller Park.

headline: On the Road With, or Without, Elderly Parents
text: It’s August, time for a vacation from everything stressful — work, commuting, heat, congestion. But what about caregiving? Do adult children of elderly parents deserve a break from them, too?

headline: Coping Mechanisms
text: The women in Suzanne Rivecca’s first story collection, “Death Is Not an Option,” are looking for salvation, though not the kind that involves Jesus. You’d be forgiven for making that assumption, considering that so many of these antiheroines are the products of Catholic schooling. But in fact, most of Rivecca’s ruthlessly frank and lonely characters have left religion, and the saving they seek in this modest, engaging and disquieting collection is from the plague of isolation — or it is, anyway, when they’re not themselves trying to be the rescuers, saving others from any number of ­scourges.

headline: Under the Big Sky
text: The four central characters in Kevin Canty’s new novel, “Everything,” call Montana home, and though they love where and how they live, they all have reasons to want something else — lives other than the ones they’ve fashioned. And so they all make terrible, destructive but perhaps ultimately romantic decisions about love.

text: The NH Tournament pits five younger players against five veteran players. After two rounds, the youngsters have a small lead.

text: Highlights from a film capital’s wealth of classics.

headline: Slumdog Cuisinier
text: Don’t let the title fool you. A lot of ground is covered in Richard C. Morais’s first novel, “The ­Hundred-Foot Journey”: close to 25 million feet, by my count, from India to England and then France, the last leg via a tricolor caravan of used Mercedes-Benzes that chugs through much of Western Europe. This is to say nothing of the psychological distance traversed by the narrator, Hassan Haji, a Muslim boy born on the edge of a slum in what was still called Bombay and then catapulted to Paris’s temples of haute cuisine. One moment he’s stirring a caldron of curried fish heads, the next he is feeding Siberian ptarmigan — roasted with herbs cut out of the bird’s own crop — to the likes of Christian Lacroix.

headline: ‘The Social Network’ Spawns Parodies
text: It remains to be seen whether or not “The Social Network,” the highly fictionalized retelling of the origins of Facebook, will be a box-office hit.

headline: Smellbound
text: One overcast afternoon last May I sat in a small atelier in a tiny town in the hills of Rimini, Italy. Across from me sat a man in royal blue robes and a matching blue turban, with a long gray beard and kohl-rimmed eyes; on his desk, and on the shelves behind him, in a cabinet by the door  all over the room  there were small amber-tinted glass bottles, scores of them, and as we spoke he would take one up, open the top, hand it to me and invite me to smell the contents. This went on for hours. It was why I’d come: to meet Dominique Dubrana, a 54-year-old Frenchman living in Italy, a Sufi convert, a grand eccentric and a genius of sorts.

headline: Mike Tanier’s Training Camp Tour
text: What if there was open competition at quarterback and nobody came? Or a bunch of nobodies came?

headline: I Love Paris in the Movies
text: “We’ll always have Paris,” Rick says to Ilsa at the end of “Casablanca,” and for movie lovers this is certainly true. Even as genre preferences shift and digital technology messes with our cinematic sense of place, and even among viewers allergic to subtitles or indifferent to the antique glories of the Nouvelle Vague, Paris is durable, indispensable, infinitely photographable.

headline: Are Liberals More to the Right Than They Think?
text: The Gist: People think they’re more liberal than they really are.

headline: The Departed
text: Christie Hodgen’s second novel offers a twist on the contemporary coming-of-age story: Her smart, mordant heroine, Mary Murphy, narrates in the second person rather than the first, piecing together the story of her life through a series of odes to five characters who shaped it, sometimes in the most accidental ways. If the philosophical and psychological notions behind the approach of “Elegies for the Brokenhearted” seem obvious or clichéd — that an individual’s identity is formed by the people who surround her — its execution proves deeply, satisfyingly original.

headline: Little-Used Law Gives Condo Buyers a Way Out
text: During the real estate boom a couple of years ago, developers were buying up lots and preselling condo units for buildings that had yet to be built. And people were scooping up these units at premium prices.

headline: TimesCast | August 13, 2010
text: Today, President Obama signs the Border Protection Bill into law, West Virginians debate the long-term impact of mountaintop removal mining, and the marketing blitz surrounding Eat Pray Love.

headline: Japanese Sushi Students Aim for a Job Overseas
text: TOKYO — At the sound of the buzzer, Kensuke Aoki starts furiously pressing rice into shape in his left palm. Adding dabs of bright green wasabi paste and quickly placing slices of mackerel on top of the rice, he completes each nigiri one after another. Three minutes and 18 nigiri later, time is up, and his instructor comes around to sort the well-shaped ones from the ill-shaped, as Mr. Aoki wistfully looks on. Just 12 have made the grade.

headline: Sushi Chefs Look Abroad
text: Many young chefs in training in Tokyo plan to seek jobs abroad as the traditional sushi restaurant industry faces increasing challenges from fast-food sushi outlets.

headline: Governors Island: Not Yet a Destination for Visual Arts
text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asks Edward Rothstein in today’s Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On ArtsBeat today, critics from several disciplines will be discussing the island’s role as a cultural destination. Check back for regular updates throughout the day and share your own thoughts about the island, too. Read previous entries here.

headline: Kuchar Leads a Crowd Atop Leader Board at P.G.A.
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Thick fog engulfed Whistling Straits on Friday, leaving the course along Lake Michigan hard to recognize through the haze. But after the fog cleared, the leaders at the P.G.A. Championship were still hard to recognize, and not because of the weather.

headline: The Insider | Max Osterweis
text: Max Osterweis, the chief executive and creative director of the fair-trade clothing line SUNO, has been making trips to Kenya’s Lamu Island long before glamorous Euros attempted to replace plodding donkey rides with a few modern conveniences, like the automobile. A favorite of Michelle Obama and Sofia Coppola, SUNO has been known since its birth in 2008 for its progressive approach to factory labor in Kenya as well as for its vivid multicolored garments inspired by traditional kangas. Here the filmmaker-turned-designer provides us with his local Lamu favorites. Seafood lovers, get ready to salivate.

headline: Experts Warn of a Weak Link in the Security of Web Sites
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Computer security researchers are raising alarms about vulnerabilities in some of the Web’s most secure corners: the banking, e-commerce and other sites that use encryption to communicate with their users.

headline: Dancers Adopt a City and Vice Versa
text: BOISE, Idaho

headline: Dancing in Boise
text: Images of the Trey McIntyre Project in their new home.

headline: Making Lunch a Social Networking Game
text: Thursday night I had dinner in the future, and the hamburgers were shaped like doughnuts.

headline: The Angst of an Accidental Sitcom Star
text: A FEW weeks into shooting on the Comedy Central series “Big Lake”  Chris Gethard said things were going more smoothly than he had imagined.

headline: Federal Reserve Official Sees Chance of a New Boom-and-Bust Cycle
text: WASHINGTON  A lone dissenter on the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee warned Friday that the central bank’s monetary strategy could backfire and touch off a new boom-and-bust cycle.

headline: Will the Billionaires’ Pledge Inspire Others to Give?
text: In this week’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about the billionaires’ Giving Pledge. Warren Buffett, along with Bill and Melinda Gates, unveiled the charitable oath last week, with 40 superwealthy families and individuals promising to donate at least half of their fortunes to charity.

headline: A Classicist of Rap, and a Crossover Crosses Back
text: Freddie Gibbs

headline: More Willing to Wait, Redskins Bet on Shanahan
text: ASHBURN, Va.  Albert Haynesworth trudged off the field after his first full day of practice last week, 10 days of headlines and jokes departing silently with him into the locker room. His will-he-or-won’t-he struggle with a rudimentary conditioning run, and by extension with Coach Mike Shanahan, might have threatened to hit the rewind button on the latest reinvention of the Washington Redskins.

headline: Rescuing 1970 From the Remainder Bin
text: JAMES TAYLOR wraps up a tour with Carole King. A new Jimi Hendrix album makes its debut in the Top 5. Elton John has joined forces with one of his heroes, the extremely hirsute singer-pianist Leon Russell. Fans think music should be free for the taking.

headline: Prince of Tides: A Mammoth Turbine
text: What is being described as the world’s largest tidal power turbine was unveiled this week in Scotland. Dubbed the AK1000 by its developer, the Atlantis Resources Corporation, the one-megawatt turbine weighs 1,430 tons, stands nearly 75 feet tall and has six 60-foot diameter blades that can produce enough electricity to supply more than 1,000 homes.

headline: Did the Stimulus Help? A New View
text: When an economist named Saving writes about fiscal policy, it’s hard not to listen. But we digress…

headline: The Stories Speak for Themselves, but Pictures Help
text: THEY are conversations broadcast every Friday morning on NPR’s “Morning Edition”: snatches of lives recorded by StoryCorps, often poignant, sometimes profound and utterly captivating for many listeners. But they have never made the leap from radio to television, until now.

headline: Rising Profits Are Good, but There’s a Catch
text: PROFITS of corporate America have been rising at an impressive clip. But sales have not risen nearly as rapidly.

headline: In Some Classes, Buyers Are Not Ready to Give Up Their V-8s
text: CARS around the world are making do with fewer cylinders to save fuel; the engine of the Tata Nano, to cite one extreme case, has just two.

headline: TimesCast: The Border Bill
text: The Times’s Marcus Mabry and Julia Preston discuss how the new $600 million border-security law is both about national security and national politics, in the latest edition of TimesCast.

headline: Weekend Competition: Free Parking, Fresh Air and Other Retronyms
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to propose retronyms suitable for these fast-moving times.

headline: Four-Cylinder Engines Are Smaller, Quieter and Gaining New Respect
text: AS automotive earth saviors go, electric cars and hybrids are widely presumed to be the chosen ones.

headline: Tucson Sticks to the Recipe
text: THE 1998 Subaru Forester was a tall wagon with all-wheel-drive and a 2.5-liter 165-horsepower 4-cylinder engine. While other compact car-based utility vehicles existed at the time, the Forester established a powertrain formula for its genre.

headline: Kicking Up a Little Dirt in a Debate Over Shoes
text: The comments came in fast and furious following this week’s City Room post off my column, The Appraisal, about whether real estate brokers should make prospective buyers take off their shoes before entering a home for sale. More than 200 readers quickly steered the dialog toward a broader discussion of shoes-on and shoes-off experiences. It was a battle between manners and safety, whether to put the homeowner or the visitor first, and what can be more dangerous for precious floors: dirty shoes or dirty feet.

headline: No Love Lost Between Ehrlich and Palin
text: Former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin last week waded into another Republican primary — this time in Maryland, where she endorsed Brian Murphy, a businessman and  little-known conservative challenging former Gov. Robert Ehrlich Jr. for the party’s gubernatorial nomination.

headline: Marriage and the VCR Analogy
text: Responding to my post on “thick” versus “thin” understandings of marriage, Ezra Klein offers an analogy:

headline: Surprise Senate Candidate Faces Charges of Obscenity
text: Alvin M. Greene, the unemployed veteran who surprisingly won the Democratic Senate primary in South Carolina in June, was indicted Friday on two obscenity charges by a Richland County grand jury, according to the state solicitor’s office.

headline: Am I Young Yet?
text: To celebrate the start of the football season, I’m volunteering to take one for the team  no, for all teams, major and minor  by coming clean about my doping. Throughout the fall and winter of 2009, I gave myself daily shots of somatropin, the manufactured form of human growth hormone, or H.G.H., which is believed to build muscle and rev up the recovery time from injuries. Hence the drug’s allure to professional athletes. In my case, I had a torn ankle tendon that required surgery, and at 48, I began to wonder whether my post-op rebound might benefit from the supposed boost of H.G.H. juice?

headline: Dr. Laura Apologizes for On-Air Epithet
text: Dr. Laura Schlessinger, the conservative talk radio commentator, has again found herself backpedaling for remarks she made on air — this time for repeatedly using a common racial epithet for African-Americans.

headline: Daughter of Independence
text: Like a true revolutionary, I was born on Bastille Day (July 14), 1960, in Dahomey, which was then a part of the French Empire in West Africa. A few days later, on August 1st, 50 years ago this month, my country was declared independent: I was French for just 18 days! It is not easy for me to judge the 50 years of independence of my small country, now called Benin. I feel that my life has been shaped in many ways by the political tribulations of West Africa. I consider myself a true daughter of my country’s recent independence.

headline: More From a ‘Diary of a Very Bad Year’
text: From autumn 2007 to autumn 2009, when things looked like they were falling apart, Keith Gessen, one of the founders of the New York literary magazine n+1, had a series of conversations with an anonymous hedge fund manager known as just H.F.M.

headline: If You’re Going to Be Edited, Be Sure the Result Is Still You
text: A WHILE back, I mentioned in a column that I had agreed to edit the college admissions essays for the daughter of a friend of mine.

headline: Lessons in Resilience From New Orleans
text: [Aug. 15, 1:28 p.m. | Update  I’m trying to take something of a break this week and have very limited Internet access, so posts and comment moderation will be somewhat intermittent.]

headline: Live Long And Prosper
text: But actually it’s the other way around. And the fact that, to a growing extent, the less prosperous don’t live as long has important implications.

headline: Fed Official Warns of a Cycle of Boom and Bust
text: In a sharply worded dissent to the Federal Reserve’s decision to help ease the supply of credit to the economy, a member of the Fed committee that sets interest rates said Friday that the recovery would take time and that the central bank risked touching off a new boom-and-bust cycle, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: Social Security: A Minor Fiscal Issue
text: Given the apocalyptic rhetoric we’re hearing, once again, about Social Security finances, it comes as something of a shock — even to me — to look at the actual projections in the latest Trustees’ Report. OASDI is projected to rise from 4.8 percent of GDP now to about 6 percent of GDP in 2030, and level off. That’s not trivial — but it’s not huge either.

text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asks Edward Rothstein in today’s Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. headline: Book Review Podcast: Martin Cruz Smith
text: This week: Martin Cruz Smith on his latest Russian thriller, “Three Stations”; Sara Ivry discusses Suzanne Rivecca’s story collection, “Death Is Not an Option”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: When Battles Are Lost
text: Next week, I hope to have a long response — or possibly even two — to Andrew Sullivan’s ongoing commentary on my marriage arguments. (And after that, this blog will hopefully return to a more diverse array of topics.) Before the weekend, though, let me quickly address a critique from the right — from Matthew Lee Anderson at First Things, who criticized my column for implying that the heterosexual abandonment of the marital ideal could eventually justify giving up on the battle over the public, legal definition of marriage.

headline: Relief Well to Be Completed in Gulf
text: HOUSTON  Although tests of BP’s blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico appear to show that it is fully sealed, the government said Friday that work on a relief well would continue to complete the job of permanently plugging the gusher.

text: -Kimberly, a 20-year-old contestant on Australia’s Next Top Model (YouTube link), wondering who Brooke Shields is. Way to make us feel old.

text: President Obama is planning a trip to New Orleans on Aug. 29, to mark the five-year anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, the White House announced on Friday.

headline: Fleeing Floods in Pakistan, but Facing More Rain
text: As the government tried to deliver aid and medical care to the victims of the flooding, the country faced more rain and floods as well as the threat of illnesses spreading among displaced villagers.

headline: Galleon Founder Wins Hearing on Wiretaps
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Friday ordered an evidentiary hearing over a government wiretap application in the insider trading case of Raj Rajaratnam, the founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund, Reuters reports.

headline: V-J Day. Times Square. A Nurse.
text: Alfred Eisenstaedt and Victor Jorgensen photographed the same moment 65 years ago. But only Mr. Jorgensen captured the face of Gloria Bullard, now 84 and living in South Carolina. She offered a new perspective to our colleagues at City Room: “From Photo’s Periphery, an Eyewitness to a Timeless Kiss.”

headline: School Space Emergency? Not for Now
text: Last week, Education Department officials announced that Chancellor Joel I. Klein intended to invoke his little-known emergency powers to place Girls Preparatory Charter School inside Public School 188 on the Lower East Side, disregarding a ruling from the state’s education commissioner.

headline: In the Everglades, the Miracle That Wasn’t
text: The aging environmentalist with the Abe Lincoln beard ambled to the podium on Thursday to tell water managers that he could no longer support their plan to buy land for the Everglades from United States Sugar. He sounded sad.

headline: Fairway Set to Open New Store on Upper East Side
text: Howard Glickberg, a partner in the Fairway megastores, has announced that the next link in the chain will be at 240 East 86th Street, formerly Barnes & Noble. Mr. Glickberg said the new store, the seventh in the group, would open in about six months and be on three floors. It would have about the same amount of selling area as the flagship at Broadway and 74th Street.

headline: Ads
text: Some people have wondered about the ads appearing next to this blog, which often seem to feature the very ideas and people I’m attacking. I’m pretty sure that we’re watching algorithms at work — the ads are being placed based on keywords. Put it this way: Bill O’Reilly is probably getting a lot of ads hawking Jennifer Aniston beauty products right now.

headline: Barnes & Noble vs. Burkle Goes Into Round 2
text: The battle for Barnes & Noble is moving ahead with full force.

headline: Browsing Guatemala’s Markets
text: There are two kinds of travelers who go to the sprawling, bustling markets that pop up all over Latin America: the buyers and the gawkers.

headline: The Office Is Over, but the Executives Linger On
text: Two former senior executives at the BBDO Worldwide office in Troy, Mich., which closed after losing its huge Chrysler Group accounts, have found new jobs in Detroit-area automotive advertising.

headline: From Photo’s Periphery, an Eyewitness to a Timeless Kiss
text: It is a defining image of the American century, one that expressed the joy of a nation at its moment of greatest triumph: on the day the Japanese surrender was announced, a sailor grabbed a nurse in the middle of Times Square, bent her back and kissed her.

headline: Week in Pictures, Aug. 13
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: An Updated Guide for Low-Carb Dieters
text: A recent study of low-fat versus low-carbohydrate diets confirmed what followers of the Atkins diet have long believed: a low-carb diet can be good for your heart.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Martin Cruz Smith
text: This week: Martin Cruz Smith on his latest Russian thriller, “Three Stations”; Sara Ivry discusses Suzanne Rivecca’s story collection, “Death Is Not an Option”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Degree of Disclosure
text: I attended a top-tier acting program at a large state university, completing all my theater classes but not acquiring enough credits for my B.F.A. I left after my fourth year and now work as an actor. No degree is required for acting jobs, but potential employers might see my not having graduated as an inability to complete a task. The head of my program, with good intentions, has enlisted friends and colleagues to urge me to complete my degree. By disclosing that I did not graduate, doesn’t she infringe the confidentiality of my academic records? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Letters: The Yoga Mogul
text: Mimi Swartz’s recent article (July 25) intersperses some of John Friend’s philosophical and practical perspectives on yoga. It did not, however, do justice to who Friend is, what he stands for and how he is transforming the practice of yoga into an experience that connects people to the core of their own goodness and expanded sense of self. He has maintained the highest standards possible in his teaching and training and has inspired thousands of people to embrace yoga practice and ethics as a way to live life filled with joy, integrity and balance. Drawing upon the wisdom and skill of his own teachers and his extensive personal studies, Friend has created a style that honors the past while forging ahead with innovative and brilliant principles of alignment and philosophical tenets.

headline: The Origins of ‘Relatable’
text: Jane E. Wohl writes: "I have noticed among my students a growing use of the word 'relatable,' as in 'I like Sarah Palin. She's relatable' (meaning, 'I can relate to her'). Do you know the origins of this usage? It turns the verb 'to relate to' into a very odd adjective."

headline: Sharing Demons With Hank Williams
text: A month or so ago my husband, Charlie, and I left our home in the Shenandoah Valley and headed West on a summer driving trip. Our first stop was just a couple of hours away: a gas-station parking lot in Oak Hill, W.Va., where Hank Williams was found dead in his Cadillac convertible on New Year’s Day in 1953.

headline: Defying Others, Germany Finds Economic Success
text: BERLIN  Germany has sparred with its European partners over how to respond to the financial crisis, argued with the United States over the benefits of stimulus versus austerity, and defiantly pursued its own vision of how to keep its economy strong.

headline: Letter: Questions for Barney Frank
text: Deborah Solomon’s interview was enlightening. That a Democrat, Barney Frank of Massachusetts, is working with a Republican colleague, Ron Paul of Texas, to introduce legislation shrinking the size of government, legalizing marijuana and bringing home troops from nations with no current military threats makes sense.

headline: Buyer, Be Aware
text: During the great housing bubble and bust, journalists spent a fair amount of time searching for the perfect mortgage victim. This victim would be someone who played by the rules, took a conservative approach to his finances and simply wanted a decent place to live. He made his monthly payments on time, right up to the day that the bank informed him that his payments would balloon because of a fine-print technicality that no borrower could have understood. Just like that, the homeowner was facing foreclosure.

headline: Letter: The Middle of Somewhere
text: Laura Munson’s essay (July 25) was the latest in an almost unbroken string of diverse, well-written articles that have appeared in the Lives column over the past few years. Though I have been remiss in not writing sooner, I was determined to let Munson know how much I was affected by her description of what is lost as our children grow into those unrecognizable, technologically proficient semiadults and what it means to a parent to find that the seemingly lost sensitivity to nature still exists under the layers of wireless devices. This was an encouraging piece for parents and grandparents who may not yet have had such an experience.

headline: The Promise and Peril of ‘Smart’ Keyboards
text: Analog culture is stored in our muscle memories. Even as artifacts of the predigital world disappear, we haven’t forgotten the moves. How to crank up a car window. How to ease up on a clutch. How to put a needle on a record.

headline: Letter: Summer Growmance
text: I had an urge to write in after reading Christine Muhlke’s article (July 18). The face of American farming is definitely disappearing. As I look around in St. John’s County, Fla., it becomes more and more apparent: development and urban sprawl continue to push our agricultural community out, little by little. Teenagers like Alexandra Reau are a breath of fresh air. Whether it is passed down from generation to generation or cultivated through organizations like 4H, the love of the land and our farming history is an important part of America’s heritage. Thanks to Alexandra and all C.S.A. supporters and America’s farmers.

headline: Tracing Darwin’s Path in Tierra del Fuego
text: Before he got to the Galápagos Islands, Charles Darwin spent two years studying the distinct flora and fauna of the southern tip of South America, making observations that came to influence his groundbreaking theory of natural selection. Though the Galápagos typically draw Darwin tours, two  cruises aim to shadow the H.M.S. Beagle’s less celebrated time in Tierra del Fuego.

headline: The Language of Fakebook
text: I HAVE a feeling that if Andy Warhol were alive he would be spending the summer writing a novel that takes place in real time on Facebook. In that spirit, Lauren Mechling and Laura Moser have been writing a clever serialized novel on Slate called “My Darklyng.” Their innovation: the plot unfolds not just in text but on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Internet Radio Host Guilty of Threatening Judges
text: Harold C. Turner, the incendiary Internet radio host, was found guilty on Friday afternoon of threatening to assault or kill three federal judges in Chicago because he was angered by an opinion they had issued supporting a local handgun ban.

headline: Paolo Canevari | Playing With Fire
text: If not for his massive rubber sculptures and short films of burning skulls, Paolo Canevari, 47, may have only been known as the ex-beau of a certain Yugoslavian performance artist. “For me, Marina has always been first a woman, my companion, and then an artist,” says Canevari, who separated from Marina Abramovic in 2009. Born into a family of classically trained Italian painters and sculptors, Canevari came to New York in the 1980s to assist the South Korean experimental video artist Nam June Paik. Since his first New York show in 1989, Canevari has produced politically responsive artworks in a diverse array of mediums: sculptures made of car tires, video installations and photographs. He even dipped a toe into the slightly more frivolous world of fashion after meeting Riccardo Tisci in 2007 to collaborate on a project for AnOther magazine. “He gave me a Givenchy haute couture dress and said, ‘Do what you like with it.’ … I burned it on a wooden cross.” As for the clothing he doesn’t set aflame, Canevari sticks to vintage. “I have a collection of vintage suits and several vintage motorcycle jackets … around 35!” Concerning the overall inspiration behind his works, including his 2007 Venice Biennale entry, “Bouncing Skull,” the artist is very frank. “Life and death have been a source of inspiration for centuries for artists,” he says. “I’m not an exception.”

headline: Introducing the Hall of Fame Presenters …
text: Here are the presenters for the 2010 Naismith Memorial Hall of Fame inductees Friday night in Springfield, Mass.:

headline: Waters Defends Herself Against Ethics Charges
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Maxine Waters went on the offensive Friday, holding an unusual Capitol Hill news conference for nearly 90 minutes to contest ethics charges against her, repeating that any appeals she made to Treasury officials in late 2008 were to get minority banks access to decision makers, not to protect a family investment.

headline: Wheelies: Jonas Brothers Edition
text: Weird car news from around the Web…

headline: From Jewish Roots in Brooklyn, a Sizzling Salsa Star
text: Little in Larry Harlow’s lineage suggested that he would someday become one of the most important figures in the history of salsa. But for more than 40 years now, Mr. Harlow has been affectionately known in the Latin music world as “El Judío Maravilloso” (“the marvelous Jew”), a pianist, songwriter, producer and arranger with an unerring feeling for clave, Latin music’s five-stroke beat, and an ear for hits.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: The flooding in Pakistan, which began in late July, has killed an estimated 1,600 people and affected a total of 14 million, Salman Masood and Waqar Gillani reported. Aid agencies and the United Nations warned Friday that the disaster was still mounting, with outbreaks of water-borne disease an additional likelihood. “We want to warn everyone that the crisis facing Pakistan is enormous,” said Mengesha Kebede, a representative of the United Nations refugee agency. “There continues to be massive destruction as the bloated rivers flow inexorably southwards across the plains.”

headline: Sidewalk Entrepreneurs Grow Up
text: IT’S an indelible image of summer: lemonade and cookies on a folding table on the sidewalk, a jar crammed with dollars, passers-by smiling politely.

headline: Living in Fair Haven, N.J.
text: A waterfront community in Monmouth County that offers diversity and easy access to New York City.

headline: Half a Century of Making Cars Into Stars
text: A MOVIE crew had taken over the elliptical cobblestone courtyard of the Bloomberg Building in Manhattan on a late July day, and the star had just arrived on the set.

headline: New Rules on Finance to Be Done in the Open
text: WASHINGTON  The meeting in the back room may not be over, but at least the public can peek inside.

headline: Drug Companies Face Federal Inquiries
text: At least a dozen major drug and device makers are under investigation by federal prosecutors and securities regulators in a broadening inquiry of bribery allegations as to whether the companies may have made payments to foreign doctors and health officials.

headline: Consulting American Soldiers and Yakuza Gangsters on Video Game Violence
text: In an essay on the Kotaku blog published in June headlined, “Who Cheers For War?” Leigh Alexander, a journalist who writes about video games, asked: “Are games our escapist fantasies, or our outlets for dealing with reality? Either way, why is our most common gameplay choice the pursuit of war?”

headline: Americans Hold Their Ground at P.G.A.
text: HAVEN, Wis. — The PGA Tour has felt more and more like an international affair of late, and there is no shortage of metrics to show as much.

headline: Pharmacists Take Larger Role on Health Team
text: Eloise Gelinas depends on a personal health coach.

headline: New Roles for a Family of Pharmacists
text: Thirty years ago in pharmacy school, Barry S. Bryant learned how to dispense prescription drugs and talk to customers about their medications. Now, he works alongside his three daughters, all of whom graduated from pharmacy school within the last decade, at Barney’s Pharmacy in Augusta, Ga., where their experiences illustrate how much the family’s chosen profession is changing, one generation to the next.

headline: West Dangles a Fatal Finesse Before Declarer, but in Vain
text: James Rosenbloom, one of the most likable bridge-playing New Yorkers, died on July 31 at 56 after a long battle with cancer.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Aug. 13
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: After Fog, Concerns and Forecasts of Rain
text: 9:42 p.m. |Update:

headline: Grilled Chicken Breasts With Herb Butter
text: Mark Bittman uses a special technique to keep grilled chicken breast juicy.

headline: James Turrell Settles Fight With Former Art Gallery
text: A long-running battle between the artist James Turrell and his former London gallery  a fight that raised the specter of an artist’s being legally compelled to produce art  has ended in a settlement.

headline: One Pianist and Many Composers, All in a Night’s Work
text: The pianist Peter Jablonski, born in Sweden to a Polish father and a Swedish mother, has had an active and successful career in Europe. But his itinerary has not brought him to New York often in recent years.

text: But will he go in the water?

headline: Dynegy Gives Blackstone a Big Bet on Energy
text: The Blackstone Group’s deal to acquire Dynegy, an energy company, is an aggressive move into a troubled sector of the economy. The private equity firm is paying top dollar for power-generation assets in a struggling company, buying its outstanding common stock for more than $540 million and assuming $4.65 billion in debt.

headline: First-Round Leader Gives Ryder Cup Captains a Pass
text: HAVEN, Wis. – The Ryder Cup has gotten more than its fair share of attention this week at Whistling Straits, largely because of the much-publicized smackdown between Corey Pavin and Jim Gray over whether Tiger Woods would be one of Pavin’s captain’s picks for the American team.

headline: For Moister Chicken, Tuck the Flavor Inside
text: EVEN the best white-meat chicken has two main drawbacks, both stemming from its low fat content: it’s not particularly flavorful, and it dries out as you cook it. Grilling helps with the first problem by contributing smoky flavor and a nicely browned exterior, but unfortunately it makes the dryness problem even worse.

headline: Three Ways to Keep Grilled Chicken Moist
text: I’d like to meet someone who hasn’t overcooked chicken breasts while grilling; it can happen in an instant. This week’s Minimalist column explores three strategies to keep those babies moist.

headline: Governors Island: A Special Space
text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asks Edward Rothstein in today’s Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On ArtsBeat today, critics from several disciplines will be discussing the island’s role as a cultural destination. Check back for regular updates throughout the day and share your own thoughts about the island, too. Read previous entries here.

text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC interviewed a former Maryland governor, Robert Ehrlich Jr., who must first win a Republican primary in order to take on the current Democratic governor, Martin O'Malley, who beat him four years ago.

Dr. Casas, who has offices in Chicago and New York, is active in restructurings, including one involving 610 Lexington Avenue, the former Shangri-La Hotel site.

text: WHILE attending Auburn University in Alabama, David Fudge spent his summers in New York, first taking a film course at New York University, and then securing internships at two media companies.

headline: Solutions to Dorm Crowding
text: KYLE HARRY, a 21-year-old student about to begin his fourth year at Iona College in New Rochelle, was content living in a dormitory as a freshman and sophomore, but by his third year, he said, “I was ready to step into more adult shoes and negotiate the challenges of the outside world.”

text: CASH-OUT refinancing, in which borrowers pull out equity from their homes to finance everything from vacations to sports cars, were all the rage during the housing boom.

headline: Fair Haven, N.J.
text: ONE day each June, the principal of Fair Haven’s middle school marches up Third Street to the elementary school, gathers up all the third graders, and escorts them on bicycles to the school they’ll be attending the following year. Parents line the street to wave to their children on what is appropriately called “Transition Day,” a cherished event in a Monmouth County town that puts great stock in its rituals and traditions.

headline: Gods, Goddesses and Elephants for Luck
text: BHARATI SUKUL KEMRAJ, a 27-year-old reporter and producer for the public access television channel Bronxnet, lives with her parents and three of her five siblings in a brick and stucco house near Sound View Park in the Bronx. Her two older sisters, who have their own families, live nearby. Especially with five grandchildren coming and going, the premises bustle with lively family meals and youngsters underfoot.

headline: City Cemeteries Face Gridlock
text: THOSE of us among the living all know New York City can be maddeningly expensive, whether one is shopping for a $40 million mansion on Fifth Avenue or a $2,500 studio walk-up in a former tenement on the Lower East Side.

headline: Fog Dissipates, Revealing Americans at Top of Leader Board
text: HAVEN, Wis. — The PGA Tour has felt more and more of an international affair of late, and there is no shortage of metrics to show as much.

text: YOU wear organic T-shirts. You hang your clothes to dry. You recycle your unloved suits and dresses.

headline: Swathed in a Sea of Color, and an Electronic Chill
text: These are the things that were pointing skyward during Thursday night’s performance of Francis and the Lights at S.O.B.’s: the popped collar of Francis’s white shirt; the popped collar of Francis’s black jacket; Francis’s hair, molded into a prism. His ego too.

headline: How Kim Novak Mixed Glamour With Gutsy
text: BY the time Marilyn Pauline Novak arrived in Hollywood in 1953, the industry’s once highly efficient star-making machinery was beginning to break down. A former model whose hourglass figure had earned her a walk-on in the Jane Russell musical “The French Line,” Ms. Novak was recruited by Columbia Pictures to be groomed as its answer to Marilyn Monroe, whose breathy sexuality was seducing the nation.

headline: Fun With Mortality Tables
text: Hoo boy, if Social Security is the big thing in the next few months — which is starting to look possible — it’s going to be like old times again, shooting down all the usual fallacies one more time.

headline: An Actress Wielding a Dancer’s Intuition
text: If, at the same time, you could meet the shy, expressionless Lauren, mumbling into the wall of her red hoodie, and the glittering, claws-extended Regan, the meanest predator on the hunt, it would be hard to believe that they are the same person underneath. And maybe they aren’t — even if the actress Tracee Chimo channeled those characters to critical acclaim in two Off Broadway plays this season.

text: WASHINGTON

text: A look at some of the cars outfitted by George Barris.

headline: Love Is a Battlefield: Rihanna Brings Big Weapons
text: The theme of Rihanna’s “Last Girl on Earth” tour, as suggested by its recurring video images of computers downloading her dreams, is the subconscious, which is always more interesting than the conscious. Isn’t it?

headline: Follow the Bees to the Sweetest Fruit
text: “Follow the bees,” said Franca Tantillo, owner of Berried Treasures Farm, one recent afternoon at the Greenmarket in Union Square, Manhattan, as she shopped for peaches. “They know the fruit that has the most sugar, even if it’s only a fraction of a percent more.”

headline: An Interview With Martin O'Malley
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talked with Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley on unemployment rates, the state budget and other issues worrying voters this election year.

headline: Girls, Uninterrupted
text: PITTSFIELD, Mass.

headline: At DuArt, an End to Film Processing
text: Al Young, a film editor, and his partner, Arthur Gottlieb, started the DuArt film laboratory in 1922, during the era of silent movies. Now, after 88 years, Young’s son Irwin has announced that the company will process its last roll of film this month. “I grew up with film, so I’m sad to see it go,” Irwin Young, chairman of DuArt Film & Video, said in a statement. “But most of our clients have moved to digital image acquisition, and we’re moving with them.” The president of DuArt, Bob Smith, said the company was responsible for one of the first continuous-processing machines in 1927 and the first processing of Eastman Color negatives in 1951. The lab received an Academy Award for technical achievement in 1979 for the development of a frame-cueing system. Closing the processing lab, Mr. Young said, will enable the company to expand its digital work.

headline: Contestant for Judge on ‘Idol’? Shania Twain
text: The judges’ chairs on “American Idol”  which have become increasingly musical of late, with the departure first of Simon Cowell and then of Ellen DeGeneres this month  may soon have at least one high-profile new occupant. People magazine reported that the show, preparing to enter its 10th season, is negotiating with the country star Shania Twain, above, to join the panel with the power to mint new pop stars. Nigel Lythgoe, who recently returned to the show as its executive producer, said in an interview with USA Today that he thought that she would make an authoritative judge. “She’s turned country music into pop music,” Mr. Lythgoe said. Ms. Twain declined to comment about the negotiations. Talks with at least one other potential superstar judge, Jennifer Lopez, have fallen apart, People reported, but Steven Tyler, the lead singer of Aerosmith, is still considering joining the show.

headline: In Its Finale, ‘Dance’ Is Second to ‘Brother’
text: The seventh season of “So You Think You Can Dance” ended on Thursday night as the 18-year-old contemporary jazz dancer Lauren Froderman, above, took home the $250,000 cash prize as this year’s champion. That Fox reality show’s finale episode drew an average of 7.2 million viewers from 8 to 10, enough to put the network in second place in the night’s ratings over all, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS placed first, drawing 7.9 million viewers at 8 for “Big Brother,” followed by repeats of “CSI” (7.6 million) and “The Mentalist” (8.1 million) at 9 and 10. ABC was third, earning 6.1 million at 8 for a repeat of “Wipeout,” and 6.2 million for “Rookie Blue” at 9. In the 10 o’clock hour, ABC’s final installment of “Boston Med” delivered a more modest audience of 4.7 million viewers. NBC finished a distant fourth with a lineup of reruns.

headline: Kanye West to Return to MTV Awards Show
text: Maybe someone will lock the microphone to a stand this time  and bolt the stand to the stage. Kanye West, right, who notoriously relieved Taylor Swift of her mike during the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards so that he could suggest that Beyoncé Knowles should have won the statuette for best female video that Ms. Swift was holding, will return to the ceremony this year to perform, on Sept. 12 in Los Angeles, the music network has announced. After the 2009 outburst Mr. West took a break from his music career, but now has said he plans to release a new album in November. He apologized in his own fashion to Ms. Swift for the hijacking, writing on his blog shortly after the incident: “I feel like Ben Stiller in ‘Meet the Parents’ when he messed up everything and Robert De Niro asked him to leave.” But MTV has decided to ask him back, motivated probably more by ratings than by forgiveness. “Fans will be glued to the screen to see what the rapper has in store for the audience,” the network’s statement said.

headline: NBC Pulls Emmy Ads After Complaints
text: Spoofing is the sincerest form of flattery. Or at least it would seem so in the world of television. And networks competing against AMC’s “Mad Men” for an Emmy or three were not amused when NBC, which will carry the awards on Aug. 29, released the first in a series of joking “Mad Men”-theme promotional ads this week for the Emmy show. The first ad  in which Jimmy Fallon,  wearing a skinny tie, does his best Don Draper, above, with the actress Christina Hendricks as Joan Harris, her character in the series  was broadcast on Wednesday night. But after complaints by other networks, it was pulled from television and the Web, and two more ads have been delayed, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The spots  all featuring Mr. Fallon, who will host the Emmys  will be kept under wraps until after voting for the awards has ended on Tuesday. “Are they kidding?” an unidentified official from one network told the publication. “They’re running basically ads for ‘Mad Men’ in the middle of the voting process. That’s like having a presidential campaign and running an ad for one candidate.” NBC told The Hollywood Reporter that the ads had been released prematurely.

headline: Caucus Video: The Race for Maryland Governor
text: In Maryland this election year, one former Republican governor wants his old job back. But he must first win a primary that includes a challenger with the backing of Alaska’s former governor, Sarah Palin, and then prevail over an incumbent Democratic governor who beat him four years ago.

headline: Runaway Train Leaves London Scrambling
text: LONDON  It was the stuff of urban nightmare and Hollywood action film: a runaway maintenance train on London’s Underground system speeding downhill for 13 minutes  four miles  toward the heart of the city as the authorities worked frantically to clear its path of trainloads of unwitting commuters.

headline: Tale of Ansel Adams Negatives Grows Hazy
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It was a dream come true, straight out of “Antiques Roadshow.” In 2000 Rick Norsigian, a painter in a school maintenance department, bought a box of photo negatives at a garage sale in Fresno, Calif., for $45. Last month, a decade later, he stood in a Beverly Hills art gallery to announce that a team of experts had concluded “beyond a reasonable doubt” that Ansel Adams had taken the pictures.

headline: A City That Knows Long Odds
text: ATLANTIC CITY

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: LEVI MEISNER’S SHOFAR SHOP is really the corner of the living room of his third-floor apartment on 12th Avenue, and it is open for browsing for the Hebrew month of Elul. That month leads into Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, which this year begins at sundown on Sept. 8. Mr. Meisner, 27, has a full-time office job, but every fall he sells about 100 shofars, the ram’s horns turned into musical instruments that are a signature of High Holy Day services. His customers, often rabbis, come through word of mouth and fliers posted on streets. Mr. Meisner’s horns, purchased from a dealer in Israel, are made under rabbinic supervision — hologram stickers affirm they are kosher — according to biblical and Talmudic law: softened by heating and partially straightened before a hole is drilled in the tip. They range in price from $30 to $300. On Wednesday, Mr. Meisner selected a huge spiral horn from dozens in a Dole banana box and blew a series of long and short blasts that sounded like an operatic ram stuck in a trap. “It’s not an impulse purchase,” he said.

headline: A Deadly Heat Wave and a Roosevelt’s Rise
text: HOT enough for you? In 1896, a blazing 10-day heat wave killed nearly 1,500 New Yorkers and, arguably, burnished the progressive and populist credentials of a young police commissioner named Theodore Roosevelt.

headline: Readers’ Questions Answered
text: Viewing Ground Zero

headline: Romance and Puppets, in Postwar France
text: “Is that really from this?” my husband whispered in my ear as the final notes died down and blissed-out applause erupted all around us. The “that” was the wistful, delicately lilting waltz “Love Makes the World Go ’Round”; the “this” was the sweet-and-sour 1961 musical currently in revival at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, “Carnival!”

headline: 5,000 Years of Chinese Music and Dance, in One Night
text: WHEN Shen Yun Performing Arts arrives at the State University of New York at Purchase this month, it will have played on four continents since January, bringing tales spanning five millennia of Chinese music, dance and folklore to nearly 130 cities.

headline: Trickle-Up Economics?
text: You’ve probably heard of trickle-down economics: the idea that tax cuts for the wealthy manage to also help the middle class and poorer. Well, in the world of marginal tax rates, welcome to trickle-up economics: the idea that tax cuts for the middle class and poorer also help the rich.

headline: A Curator Goes With Her Gut
text: CROTON FALLS, N.Y.

headline: Dolly! (Modestly)
text: Leslie Alexander doesn’t bat her eyes or belt her lyrics with abandon as Dolly Gallagher Levi in the Gateway Playhouse production of “Hello, Dolly!” at the Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts. She doesn’t invite applause for making an entrance, even when she appears at the top of that red staircase in the title number. She stays in character, a widow trying to make a living as a matchmaker and self-described “meddler.”

headline: Surfing Since Before He Was Born
text: Sean MacPherson, 45, is a co-owner and developer with Eric Goode of a cache of hip hotels including the Jane, the Bowery and the Maritime, as well as V.I.P.-friendly hangouts like the Waverly Inn. His solo ventures include a reinvention of the Crow’s Nest restaurant, a waterfront oldie in Montauk, N.Y., where his weekend “surf shack” in Ditch Plains is scant steps from the Atlantic. He lives in the West Village and Montauk with his English bulldog puppy, Stanley.

headline: Arts Festival Stresses Connectivity
text: UNITY and connections are the themes of the new Southampton Arts Festival, taking place at the Southampton Cultural Center from Monday to Aug. 28, Elena Baksht, one of its founders, said.

headline: Shakespeare in the Great Outdoors
text: Petruchio and Katharina will spend a few happy hours in Ridgefield on Saturday when the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival presents a free production of “The Taming of the Shrew.” It will be part of an afternoon event, HSBC Presents: Shakespeare on the Green and Green Expo, which will include a showcase of local environmentally friendly businesses. The performance of the Shakespeare comedy will follow the expo on the baseball field next to the Ridgefield Playhouse.

headline: An Artist’s Revelation in a Walking Canvas
Marc Kramer Out as Daily News C.E.O.
text: The Daily News has shaken up its top ranks for the second time in less than a month.

headline: A Fresh Success in a Light White
text: For most of Jamesport Vineyards’s 29 years its sauvignon blanc has been one of Long Island’s best. The 2009 version shows why, beginning with its inviting herbal scent and ending with an extended finish. This light signature white ($23.95), tangy and somewhat tropical, is creamy and mouth-filling.

headline: A Japanese Menu and a Hip Clientele
text: AJI 53 opened in Bay Shore in the fall of 2007 and quickly earned a reputation as a Japanese restaurant of high quality. In the latest Zagat Survey of Long Island restaurants, it is tied with Kotobuki for first place among Japanese entries for food.

headline: Visiting the Fish Market, Ready to Eat
text: IT can be frustrating to visit a fish market at the Shore if, like many vacationers, you don’t have a kitchen handy. Some markets, though, will cook the seafood for you, offering take-out counters and full-fledged restaurants on the premises.

headline: A Sweets Lover’s Eden
text: The black awnings and brick facade of Sweet Rexie’s exterior belie the many colors within. A long row of acrylic cylinders hangs from one wall dispensing, for $3 a quarter pound, all kinds of treats  from candy necklaces and malted milk balls (both milk and dark chocolate) to cherry rock candy and chocolate-covered potato chips. The M & M’s alone come in two dozen shades.

headline: Festive Mexican, Theatrics on the Side
text: OLITA Cucina and Tequila Bar, which opened last summer in the Byram section of Greenwich, next door to Port Chester, is the kind of place that is most enjoyable when visited with a group. Its loud, spirited atmosphere, to the beat of exuberant taped music, is not conducive to solitary dining. Don’t even try to have a tête-à-tête — just dig into the food, sip a margarita and join the high-decibel chatter.

headline: Mixed Views on Blagojevich
text: CHICAGO  The jury is still out in the wide-ranging corruption trial of the ousted former governor, self-proclaimed political martyr and sometime Elvis impersonator Rod R. Blagojevich. But across Chicago, there is some evidence that the court of public opinion has already rendered its verdict.

headline: Only Beckham Can Say How Much Time He Has Left
text: LONDON

headline: Hot Dogs, Griddled and Spicy
text: Summer is probably the best time to enjoy that great American classic, the hot dog. And if you aren’t in the mood to fire up your own grill, there are some terrific frankfurters to be had at So Dam Hot, a storefront operation in Valhalla that serves mainly takeout.

headline: A Northern Outpost of Eastern Traditions
text: TRAVELING throughout Asia as a young woman, Marnie Henricksson was captivated by the food and learned how to cook much of it. After returning home and finding it difficult to obtain some of the more exotic ingredients she had used abroad, she simplified and tweaked the recipes, making them her own. The result was a repertory of uncomplicated, absolutely delicious dishes that became a cult hit soon after Ms. Henricksson opened Marnie’s Noodle Shop in Greenwich Village in the early 1990s.

headline: City Critic | Taking the City by Boat
text: Ariel Kaminer cruises the city on two river boat tours to take in the view from the water.

headline: Top Goldman Executives Earn Millions From Options
text: Goldman Sachs disclosed in regulatory filings late Friday that several top company executives, including Lloyd C. Blankfein, left, its chairman and chief executive, exercised stock options this week and earned millions of dollars in profits by selling the firm’s shares, Reuters reports.

headline: B Chatfield and Samuel Howard
text: LAST weekend, Abigail McIntosh Chatfield, known to all as B, married her man of letters.

headline: Blackstone to Pay $4.7 Billion for Dynegy
text: The Blackstone Group, the private equity giant, agreed on Friday to buy Dynegy, the Houston power company that once sought to buy Enron, for $4.7 billion including debt, in the largest leveraged buyout so far this year.

headline: A Singular Perspective on the Urban Mosaic
text: Up the Harlem River, past the saltwater marshes of Swindler Cove, beyond the Sherman Creek Nature Trail and the quaint gingerbread boathouse, the bucolic landscape gives way to a sinister hive, where the higher machine species are breeding for their eventual takeover of the earth.

headline: Preaching About a Mosque
text: The personal is still political. “Michael R. Bloomberg is a former Wall Street mogul with a passion for the rights of a private property owner,” reports The Times’s Michael Barbaro. “He is a Jew whose parents asked their Christian lawyer to buy a house and then sell it back to them to hide their identity in an unwelcoming Massachusetts suburb. And he is a politician who regards his independence as his greatest virtue.”

headline: Color Wars
text: In Torrington, Conn., campers at Wah-Nee take each other on to claim bragging rights.

headline: Judges Divided Over Rising GPS Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — The growing use by the police of new technologies that make surveillance far easier and cheaper to conduct is raising difficult questions about the scope of constitutional privacy rights, leading to sharp disagreements among judges.

headline: Vaani Garg and Shaunik Panse
text: Dr. Vaani Garg, a daughter of Usha Garg and Dr. Kabul S. Garg of Orange, Conn., was married Saturday to Shaunik Ramanand Panse, the son of Padma R. Panse and Dr. Ramanand V. Panse of Freehold, N.J. Pandit Harish C. Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Hyatt Regency Jersey City on the Hudson.

headline: Sri Lanka Convicts Ex-General
text: NEW DELHI  The runner-up in Sri Lanka’s last presidential election, the retired Gen. Sarath Fonseka, was convicted in a court-martial of politicking while still in uniform and sentenced to a dishonorable discharge, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Obama Signs Border Bill to Increase Surveillance
text: President Obama signed into law a $600 million bill on Friday to pay for 1,500 new border agents, additional unmanned surveillance drones and new Border Patrol stations along the southwest border.

headline: Judge Revokes Approval of Modified Sugar Beets
text: A federal district court judge revoked the government’s approval of genetically engineered sugar beets Friday, saying that the Agriculture Department had not adequately assessed the environmental consequences before approving them for commercial cultivation.

headline: As the Haze Rolls In, Golfers Engage in a Waiting Game
text: HAVEN, Wis.  When a shroud of soupy fog postponed the beginning of the P.G.A. Championship on Thursday morning, Bubba Watson killed time by playing a popular puzzle video game called Angry Birds on his iPhone. At other points, he threw things at his fellow golfer Rickie Fowler as he tried to sleep.

headline: Obama Strongly Backs Islam Center Near 9/11 Site
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama delivered a strong defense on Friday night of a proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero in Manhattan, using a White House dinner celebrating Ramadan to proclaim that “as a citizen, and as president, I believe that Muslims have the same right to practice their religion as anyone else in this country.”

text: WASHINGTON  Federal drug regulators on Friday approved a new form of emergency contraceptive pill that prevents pregnancies if taken as many as five days after unprotected intercourse.

text: Why is it a job when a person takes care of someone else’s children, but not when the parent does it herself?

headline: Jacqueline Strasser, Neal Higgins
text: Jacqueline Laura Strasser, a daughter of Linda V. Nizel of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Dr. Harold S. Strasser, was married Saturday evening in Santa Ynez, Calif., to Neal Leigh Higgins, a son of Priscilla J. Higgins and Roger W. Higgins of Santa Ynez. The Rev. Charles H. Stacy, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Three Creek Ranch, a vineyard owned by the bridegroom’s parents, with Rabbi Jayne Simon taking part.

headline: Jaime Eng, Christian Mariano
text: Jaime Cui-Yi Eng and Christian Gerard Mariano were married Saturday afternoon at St. Patrick’s Church in Richmondtown, Staten Island. The Rev. Joseph V. Arenas, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: An Unwritten Rule of Politics: Domestic Vacations
text: WASHINGTON — Forget the lush beaches of Bora Bora or the Campari-soaked cafes along the Côte d’Azur. And don’t even think about Rome or Paris. Astute Washington politicians have long known that when it comes to politically palatable summer vacations, it is best not to cross any oceans. Or even seas.

headline: From Obscure Task to a Public Curiosity
text: As the lactic acid began to pool in Jay Alford’s thighs and a searing sensation deepened in his lungs, his mind started to drift as he pushed his way through what for decades has been a staple of football training camps  the conditioning test.

headline: Gretchen Scharfe, Kirk Forsyth
text: Gretchen Elizabeth Scharfe and Kirk Haskell Forsyth were married Saturday at St. Paul Lutheran Church in Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. Marie C. Jerge, the bishop of the Upstate New York Synod of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America and an aunt of the bride, performed the ceremony in which the Rev. James N. Jerge, an uncle who is also Evangelical Lutheran, took part.
