headline: David Herszenson, Alan Pierson
text: Dr. David Scott Herszenson and Alan Emanuel Pierson are to affirm their partnership in Chicago Sunday morning at the Columbus Park Refectory, an event space in the Chicago Park District. Rabbi Julie Pelc Adler is to lead the commitment ceremony.

headline: Jacqueline Lance, Jonathan Vogel
text: Jacqueline Bell Lance and Jonathan Elias Vogel were married Saturday at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Charles Z. Gardner, a minister of the United Methodist Church, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

headline: A Son of Jazz Royalty Chooses a Life on the Streets
text: To any regular at DeWitt Clinton Park in the Hell’s Kitchen section of Manhattan, he is a familiar sight, holding court from his spot on the park bench  incense burning, pipe in his mouth.

headline: Galleon Founder Wins a New Hearing Over Wiretaps
text: The Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, won a new hearing on his claim that prosecutors filed a misleading application to wiretap his conversations and that recordings should be excluded from his insider trading trial. The ruling was made by Judge Richard J. Holwell of United States District Court in Manhattan in an opinion released Friday. Prosecutors said the government secretly recorded about 2,400 conversations that the hedge fund executive had with more than 130 friends, business associates and supposed accomplices. Mr. Rajaratnam is the central figure in two overlapping prosecutions in which 21 people have been charged. He was accused of earning millions of dollars from stock trades made with inside information from corporate officials and hedge fund executives. He has denied wrongdoing.

headline: Susan Dempsey, Gerald Halloran
text: Susan Elizabeth Dempsey and Gerald Halloran III were married Saturday. The Rev. Peter DeSanctis, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Isle Church in Shelter Island, N.Y.

headline: Ann Buchsbaum and Glenn Zorn
text: Ann Leslie Buchsbaum and Glenn Allen Zorn are to be married Sunday at the Doral Arrowwood in Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Mitchell M. Hurvitz is to officiate, with Cantor Asa Fradkin taking part.

headline: Recognized for a Layup, Inducted Too Late
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  It made sense that the doors to the Naismith Memorial Hall of Fame would eventually open for the man known as D. J., Dennis Johnson. The sad and unfathomable part was that he would not be around to walk through them.

headline: Rachel Style, David Zindel
text: Rachel Style and David Zindel were married Saturday evening at Lyndhurst Castle, an event space in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. David James, a retired Episcopal priest, officiated, with the Rev. Dr. Andrew Rienstra, a senior pastor of the Reformed Church in America, taking part.

headline: Jillian Best, Jacob Adler
text: Jillian Sue Best and Jacob Brodie Adler were married Monday at the Full Moon Resort in Big Indian, N.Y. Rabbi Steven C. Kushner officiated, with Cantor Meredith Greenberg taking part in the ceremony.

headline: Elizabeth Accles, Lisa Hardaway
text: Elizabeth Accles and Lisa Hardaway were married Saturday at the Thoreau Center, an event space in Des Moines. Robert B. Hanson, a judge of the Polk County District Court, officiated.

headline: Detroit Goes From Gloom to Economic Bright Spot
text: DETROIT  After a dismal period of huge losses and deep cuts that culminated in the Obama administration’s bailout of General Motors and Chrysler, the gloom over the American auto industry is starting to lift.

headline: In Harvard Lab Inquiry, a Raid and 3-Year Wait
text: Marc Hauser’s academic career was soaring when suddenly, three years ago, Harvard authorities raided his laboratory and confiscated computers and records.

headline: Gwyneth McClendon and Scott Hartman
text: Gwyneth Calvert McClendon and Scott Andrew Hartman were married Saturday evening at St. Paul’s Chapel at Columbia University in New York. The Rev. James Ross Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Fire and Imagination
text: The Obama administration seems to be feeling sorry for itself. Robert Gibbs, the president’s press secretary, is perturbed that Mr. Obama is not getting more hosannas from liberals.

headline: U.S. Sees North Korea as Rattling Sabers for Heir
text: WASHINGTON — In the 16 years since he assumed his father’s role as North Korea’s sole leader, Kim Jong-il has been denounced by the United States as a vicious dictator who starves his people, runs gulags, sets off nuclear tests and orders attacks on South Korean ships.

headline: A Decade of Wooing Wins a Harlem Store for Target
text: Target’s first Manhattan store opened late last month in Harlem with great fanfare. The chain’s mascot, a miniature bull terrier, rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange. Miss New York, Doug E. Fresh and Jerry Seinfeld attended a pre-party. Crowds lined up outside the store, the largest single investment the company has made in any of its retail properties.

headline: Kristin Williams, Todd McClutchy
text: Kristin Michelle Williams, the daughter of Sheryl Lynn Williams and Tim A. Williams of Wilton, Conn., was married Saturday to Todd Daniel McClutchy, the son of Janet D. McClutchy and John H. McClutchy Jr. of Darien, Conn.

headline: Meagan Crowley, Alan Hsu
text: Meagan Elizabeth Crowley, a daughter of Diane S. Crowley and Thomas A. Crowley Jr. of Spring Lake, N.J., was married on Saturday to Alan King Hsu, a son of Celia Hsu and Dr. Yao-King Hsu of Baltimore. The Rev. Kris von Maluski, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Chapel at Salve Regina University in Newport, R.I.

headline: My Favorite August
text: The story in American history I most like to tell is the one about how women got the right to vote 90 years ago this month. It has everything. Adventure! Suspense! Treachery! Drunken legislators!

headline: Renegade Priest Leads a Split St. Louis Parish
text: ST. LOUIS  Some say he is on a mission from God. Others say he is the devil. But no matter whom you ask in this city’s tight-knit community of Polish Catholics, the name of Marek Bozek is seldom met with a shrug.

headline: Jill Kalish, Matthew Levy
text: Sharon Jill Kalish, the daughter of Harriet Kalish and Mark L. Kalish of Woodmere, N.Y., is to be married Sunday evening to Matthew I. Levy, a son of Donna Wiener Levy and Gary J. Levy of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner is to officiate at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

headline: The Other Hamptons, Born and Bred
text: Tara Israel has begun a project to document her Hamptons and the people who call it home.

headline: Reid’s ’93 Immigration Plan in News Again
text: Discussion about the 14th Amendment and its granting of citizenship to anyone born in the United States heated up again on Friday, this time focused on an attempt made by Harry Reid more than 15 years ago to end so-called birthright citizenship.

headline: On the Street | Seaside
text: During Vintage Dance Week in Newport, R.I., participants spent part of their daytime hours in character, going to tea dances and touring mansions while dressed as visitors would.

headline: Town Fights Suit for Namesake
text: The town of Jim Thorpe, Pa., will fight a lawsuit seeking the remains of Jim Thorpe, the athlete, filed by one of his surviving sons. By a 6-0 margin, with one member absent, the borough council voted on Thursday night to try to keep the body of Thorpe, a famous Native American athlete who has been interred at a roadside mausoleum in the eastern Pennsylvania town for more than 50 years.

headline: Mattie Thompson and Daniel Mattingly
text: Mattie Lou Ming Thompson and Daniel Christopher Mattingly were married Saturday evening at the bride’s family farm in Pounding Mill, Va. Dr. Lloyd LeGrand Thompson III, an uncle of the bride who was appointed by the Tazwell County Circuit Court as a one-day officiant, performed the ceremony.

headline: Elena Lalli, Guillermo Coronado
text: Elena Marie Lalli, a daughter of Marigrace E. Lalli and Michael A. Lalli of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married Saturday afternoon to Guillermo Alejandro Coronado, the son of Alba O. Coronado and Marco A. Coronado of Davenport, Fla. The Rev. Anthony B. Lalli, a Roman Catholic priest who is not related to the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Paul’s Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

headline: Alysia Patterson and Matthew Mueller
text: Alysia L. Patterson and Capt. Matthew J. Mueller were married Saturday evening at the Evergreen Museum and Library in Baltimore. The Rev. Theodore Bowers, a minister of the United Church of Christ and a retired United States Navy chaplain, officiated.

headline: Lindy Davis, Steven Altmayer
text: Dr. Lindy Lockwood Davis, a daughter of Sally Lockwood and Lee Davis of Manlius, N.Y., was married Saturday in Ludlow, Vt., to Dr. Steven Andrew Altmayer, the son of Janis I. Altmayer and Dr. Stewart R. Altmayer of Guilderland, N.Y. Bruce Lockwood Davis, a brother of the bride, received permission from the State of Vermont to officiate at the ceremony, at Castle Hill Resort and Spa.

headline: Low Loan Repayment Is Seen at For-Profit Schools
text: Adding new fuel to the growing controversy over regulating for-profit colleges, the Department of Education on Friday released data on student-loan repayment rates at the nation’s colleges and universities, listing the institutions by name.

headline: Jaclyn Cashman, Cyrus Childs
text: Jaclyn Fox Cashman, a daughter of Linda Cashman-Belton of Marshfield Hills, Mass., and Jay M. Cashman of Boston, was married Saturday to Cyrus Trevor Childs, a son of Laurie Jones Childs and C. Frederick Childs of New York. The Rev. Brian McGurk, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Christopher’s by the Sea Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass.

headline: U.S. Inquiry of Drug Makers Is Widened
text: At least a dozen major drug and device makers are under investigation by federal prosecutors and securities regulators in a broadening bribery inquiry into whether the companies made illegal payments to doctors and health officials in foreign countries.

headline: Cleaner, Healthier Air
text: Earlier this year, the Environmental Protection Agency proposed a stricter nationwide health standard for smog-causing pollutants that would bring substantial benefits to millions of Americans. With a final rule expected by the end of this month, crucial senators, mainly from industrial and oil-producing states, are pushing back. They say investments required to produce cleaner air are too expensive and not scientifically justified.

headline: Anne Catherine Savage, Zachary Podolsky
text: Anne Catherine Savage was married in Austin, Tex., Saturday night to Zachary Samuel Podolsky. Rabbi Rachel Kobrin officiated at the Driskill Hotel.

headline: Sarah Mandel, Derek Rodenhausen
text: Sarah Hope Mandel and Derek Albert Rodenhausen were married Saturday on Shelter Island, N.Y., at the home of Dr. Edith Langner, a friend of the bride’s family. William A. Sulahian, a Shelter Island town justice, officiated.

headline: Down on the Social Farm
text: There is nothing virtual about the latest round of acquisitions in the world of social gaming  collaborative games played on networks like Facebook. Yet there is something genuinely disorienting about it. In the past few weeks, the Walt Disney Company has purchased Playdom, one of the biggest makers of social games, and sold Miramax Films, the kind of entertainment company  a movie studio  we used to think of as “real.”

headline: The Google/Verizon Payment Plan
text: For months, the Federal Communications Commission’s efforts to guarantee nondiscriminatory access to broadband Internet have met opposition from the companies that provide broadband service and from their allies in Congress. On Monday, Verizon and Google created a stir by jointly proposing an alternative set of rules as the basis for new legislation governing the Internet.

headline: U.S. Rules Bar Banks That Violate Iran Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department released new regulations on Friday that could bar foreign banks or companies from accessing the financial system in the United States if they did business with entities or people subject to United Nations and United States sanctions.

headline: Katie Lacey, David Berson
text: Katie Lacey and David Berson were married Saturday evening at the Avon Old Farms Hotel in Avon, Conn. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated, with the Rev. R. John Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: Elizabeth Ong, Stephen Witthuhn
text: Elizabeth Qi Tien Ong and Stephen Michael Witthuhn were married Saturday evening at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in New York. Dr. Anne Klaeysen, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Cultural Calendar, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Caroline Lopez, Nicholas Miranda
text: Caroline Dao Lopez, the daughter of Nga Vinh Dao Lopez and Michael Sabatino Gilbert Lopez of Washington, was married Saturday in New Haven to Nicholas George Balaschak Miranda, the son of Susan Balaschak Herak of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Fernando Miranda of Brooklyn. The Rev. Ian B. Oliver, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Battell Chapel at Yale, where he is a pastor of the University Church.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Heather Paulson, Samuel Dodge
text: Heather Rose Paulson and Samuel Barclay Dodge were married Saturday evening at the Mountain Meadow Inn in Helena, Mont. Benjamin Martin, a cousin of the bride and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns @nytimes.com.

headline: Justin Bieber for President
text: Maybe we should just let the children run the country, at least until the recession is over. They appear to be the only people not bubbling over with anger, anxiety and frustration.

headline: Premier League Watch: Balotelli Joins Man City on Eve of New Season
text: With the English Premier League set to begin Saturday, contenders for the title are shoring up their teams and none more ambitiously than Manchester City. The club signed the Italian striker Mario Balotelli from Inter Milan after more than a month of negotiations. Balotelli, a talented but enigmatic 20-year-old, cost City a reported $35 million and has signed a five-year deal to play for Coach Roberto Mancini, the former Inter manager.

headline: Radio Host Is Convicted for Comments on Judges
text: A right-wing Internet radio host was convicted on Friday by a federal jury in Brooklyn of threatening three federal judges who had issued a ruling he disagreed with.

headline: Mickelson Finishes Strong in Second Round
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Phil Mickelson warned before the start of the P.G.A. Championship that he felt that he was only at 90 percent, and he seemed to play like it for much of Thursday and Friday.

headline: Few Guarantees for Revis, and That’s the Problem
text: The constant chatter surrounding the Darrelle Revis contract negotiations quieted down Friday. There were no radio interviews, no television segments. Even Jets Coach Rex Ryan declined to comment.

headline: Bachelorette Cooking Parties (Girls Gone Mild!)
text: CHEFS and private cooking-class instructors say they are seeing a spike in requests for bachelorette cooking parties. Why are brides trading in their shot glasses for aprons and recipes?

headline: Gay Community Center in Queens Is at Crossroads
text: The Queens Pride House might go unnoticed if not for the rainbow flag that sways from one of its windows over 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights. It sits upstairs from an Indian restaurant, a Korean deli, an Italian bakery owned by Colombians and a driving school named Hawaii that is run by a man from Bangladesh  a snapshot of Queens’s ethnic jumble, which the organization has embraced.

headline: Your Card Has Been Declined, Just as You Wanted
text: Coming soon: credit and debit cards that cut you off when you disregard your own monthly budget.

headline: Saturday: Pound of Flesh
text: Someone told meIt’s all happening at the zoo.I do believe it,I do believe it’s true.

headline: Using Cards to Cut Off Your Spending
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I introduce an idea so simple and yet so potentially far reaching that you have to wonder why it didn’t occur to someone sooner.

headline: Mets’ Rodriguez Agrees to Treatment for Anger
text: Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez has agreed to have anger-management treatment after his arrest Wednesday night on charges that he assaulted the father of his common-law wife. The players union will help him find a therapist or counselor.

headline: Grace Lee and Al Kim
text: Grace Hee Lee and Al Yong Kim were married Saturday at Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Linda Tarry-Chard, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

headline: David Dolby, Hero in Vietnam Battle, Dies at 64
text: David C. Dolby, who was awarded the Medal of Honor in the Vietnam War for a single-handed attack on enemy positions that saved the lives of fellow soldiers during a four-hour firefight, died Aug. 6 in Spirit Lake, Idaho. He was 64 and lived in Royersford, Pa.

headline: Birthright of a Nation
text: DESPITE persistent calls for comprehensive immigration reform, the hot debate today is about an old issue: birthright citizenship.

headline: Lou Smit, Detective in JonBenet Ramsey Case, Is Dead at 75
text: Lou Smit, a longtime police detective who was called out of retirement to help investigate the 1996 slaying of JonBenet Ramsey, the 6-year-old beauty pageant winner, but resigned after concluding that the police had wrongly focused on her parents, died Wednesday in Colorado Springs. He was 75.

headline: Russia: Official Says Wildfires Have Not Raised Radiation Levels
text: Wildfires in territories contaminated by the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster have not led to a rise in radiation levels in Russia, the head of Russia’s nuclear energy agency said Friday. “There are no departures from normal radiation levels anywhere in the country,” said the official, Sergei Kiriyenko, Russian news agencies reported. Officials and environmentalists had warned that fires in irradiated regions could send up plumes of radioactive smoke, spreading contaminants into populated areas. The head of Russia’s Emergency Situations Ministry urged the police to investigate who was responsible for spreading what he called earlier rumors about increased radiation levels.

headline: Shutouts Are Curing All That Ails the Mets
text: The Mets had to play their past two games without their closer, Francisco Rodriguez, who was placed on the restricted list after being arrested Wednesday night. It was assumed the Mets would be challenged to find ways to get by without him, but as it turned out they did not need a relief pitcher, let alone a closer, in either game.

headline: Real Reason for Ousting H.P.’s Chief
text: The resignation of Mark V. Hurd last week from his seemingly secure post as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard has got to be one of the great head-scratchers in recent times.

headline: Somalia: 5 Soldiers in Puntland Are Killed in Battle With Militants
text: At least five government soldiers in the semiautonomous region of Puntland were killed Friday in a gun battle with Islamist militants near the area of Galgala, Puntland’s security minister said. In a radio interview with Horseed Media, an insurgent warlord, Sheik Mohamed Said Atom, claimed credit for the killings and vowed to “continue our fight until we overthrow the Puntland administration.” In response, the police arrested the director of Horseed Media in Boosaaso, Abdifatah Jama Mire, stoking fears about the curtailment of press freedom in the region.

headline: Discomfort Interrupts Pettitte’s Progress Toward a Return
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A minor setback turned into something more serious Friday for Andy Pettitte, who was unable to push off the mound at full strength during a 50-pitch simulated outing in Tampa, Fla. The day after pushing back his outing because of tightness in his hip flexor, Pettitte told Manager Joe Girardi that his left groin did not feel completely healed.

headline: Cuba: Articles by Castro Laud Ex-Candidate From Mexico
text: Comments by Fidel Castro in support of the runner-up in Mexico’s 2006 presidential election, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, threaten to revive diplomatic tensions between Cuba and Mexico, which was once one of its staunchest allies in Latin America. In articles on Thursday and Friday in the Communist Party newspaper Granma, Mr. Castro quoted from Mr. López Obrador’s new book, which accuses the Mexican elite of improperly increasing its fortunes from 2000 to 20006, during President Vicente Fox’s tenure. Mr. Castro supports the claim by Mr. López Obrador, a former Mexico City mayor, that the 2006 presidential election was rigged. Mr. Castro said he had never spoken with or befriended Mr. López Obrador, who is expected to run for president again in 2012.

headline: In Defense of Marriage
text: On Wednesday, unless there is an order from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, gay and lesbian couples in California once again will be able to marry. Like other couples around the world, they will be able to pledge to support each other, buy some dishes, raise families, argue about the bills, maybe sit on a park bench years from now and chuckle at the hysterical old claims that their lives together would destroy the institution of marriage.

headline: New China Search Engine Will Be State-Controlled
text: SHANGHAI  In an apparent bid to extend its control over the Internet and cash in on the rapid growth of mobile devices, China plans to create a government-controlled search engine.

headline: Strong German Growth Lifts European Output
text: FRANKFURT  The euro area economy grew 1 percent in the second quarter of this year, a much better rate than had been expected, as Germany’s best quarterly performance since reunification compensated for slow growth in Spain and Italy and a sharp decline in Greece, according to data released Friday.

headline: In Lower Manhattan, 2 Mosques Have Firm Roots
text: The Masjid Manhattan occupies a narrow basement with bare pipes snaking along the ceiling. The congregants who filled up the mosque near City Hall on Thursday night were mainly men, from South Asia, West Africa and the United States, and a few women  who prayed behind a partition. The feast provided for breaking the Ramadan fast, spicy curry over rice, came in plastic takeout containers from a nearby restaurant.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Leon Breeden, Jazz Educator, Dies at 88
text: Leon Breeden, the longtime director of jazz studies at the University of North Texas, who half a century ago transformed the program from a clandestine enterprise into the international Mecca for jazz training it remains today, died on Wednesday in Dallas. He was 88.

headline: Big Win for Federer — but Not That Big
text: TORONTO — Late in the third-set tie break, the Rogers Cup crowd that filled every seat at Center Court rose in unison. They stood for Roger Federer, chanted for Federer, whistled for Federer, imploring him toward the completion of a classic comeback.

headline: For Yankees, Two Bursts of Rain, Only One of Runs
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Yankees’ game began Friday evening in bright sunshine and 98-degree heat, and it ended more than five and a half hours later, on Saturday morning, with lightning crackling around Kauffman Stadium and temperatures in the low 70s. When Boone Logan came in to pitch in the seventh inning, it was no longer his birthday, and it was just as well.

headline: 10 Situations to Monitor in Your Fantasy Football Draft
text: Sigmund Bloom writes for Footballguys.com and hosts a podcast there with Cecil Lammey.  You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: In Address, Obama Defends Social Security
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has taken the lead in a Democratic offensive on Social Security, warning that Republicans will revive efforts to privatize what is perhaps the government’s most popular program if they seize control of Congress in the November elections.

headline: The Job Market for Immigrants
text: A few months back, we observed that last year, and for the first time since 2003, foreign-born workers were more likely to be unemployed than their counterparts born in the United States. The unemployment rate was only slightly higher for immigrants to the United States than for American natives, however; immigrants in other industrialized countries did not fare so well.

headline: Rivalry as Stand-Up Paddlers Head to Bigger Surf
text: Our colleagues in Styles recently featured an article describing the serenity of stand-up paddling on Sagaponack Pond, including a scene where a merry band of surf-paddling yogis glided into a glassy state of bliss.

headline: Ryan On Medicare
text: I’m kind of Ryaned out at the moment, so I’m not going to do a detailed analysis of his WaPo op ed.

headline: Disease Threatens Flood Victims in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Indus River breached its banks again on Saturday, bringing further devastation to southern Pakistan, as health officials confirmed the first cases of cholera caused by the worst flooding in Pakistan’s history.

headline: The Saturday Word: Gulf Coast and Social Security
text: The First Family (minus Malia) takes in Panama City, Fla., on Saturday, where in the afternoon the president and the First Lady will take part in a discussion on rebuilding the Gulf Coast economy in the aftermath of the BP oil spill.

headline: More On Mortality
text: I see from comments on this post that some readers are missing the point, in a couple of ways.

headline: Bart Simpson Not Welcome Here
text: Or at any rate, not his initials. Keep it clean, please.

headline: Blue Skies at P.G.A. Championship
text: HAVEN, Wis. — The P.G.A. Championship has finally caught a break. The treacherous thunderstorms that were predicted to arrive overnight here on Lake Michigan’s western shore never came, and golfers awoke Saturday morning to blue skies and a dry course (relatively speaking, of course).

headline: Playing for Columbus, but Fighting for the Lands Back Home
text: Growing up in the small southern Louisiana town of Gonzales, Jason Garey did not venture far for family vacations. Many of them were spent down in the marshes, where Garey and his three siblings learned to fish, shrimp and crab in the bountiful brackish waters.

headline: Fighting Words
text: The debate over the Islamic center and mosque near ground zero continued, unabated:

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Prime Number
text: 8: The percentage of babies born in the United States in 2008 who had at least one parent who was an illegal immigrant, according to a study published last week by the Pew Hispanic Center. The study also found that 80 percent of mothers who were illegal aliens had been in the country for more than a year, a statistic that seemed at odds with a recent assertion by Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, that many illegal immigrants “come here to drop a child” and immediately leave. Mr. Graham has stirred controversy by proposing a reconsideration of the 14th Amendment, long interpreted as granting citizenship to anyone born in the United States.

headline: No Reveling for Democrats, Despite Achievements
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who played a pivotal role as the 111th Congress passed several major pieces of legislation, said his party had a fundamental problem.

headline: With Elite Skills and Humble Bearing, Durant Prepares to Lead U.S.
text: The major theme of the United States basketball team heading to Turkey for the world championships this month is the unknown.

headline: Back Then
text: Last week, golf fans buzzed over the declining performance of Tiger Woods — heralded by Forbes magazine just last fall as the first athlete to earn $1 billion.

headline: Acrostic Around the Arc de Triomphe
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you’re a regular crossword solver but you haven’t yet caught the acrostic bug, this is a good one to start on. Who knows, you may join the long list of fans who look forward to new acrostics every second week. If you can’t wait, there are 285 more in the archives. That should keep you busy for a while. Also, and I know I say this every time, these puzzles are best solved electronically. You can print them out but the tracking of which letters go where can get tedious and it’s too easy to make mistakes with a pencil and eraser.

headline: ‘Star Wars’ Films Coming to Blu-ray Next Year
text: Though nearly 35 years of “Star Wars” fandom have yielded all kinds of memorabilia inspired by George Lucas‘s outer-space epic, including light saber lookalikes and wearable replicas of Princess Leia’s slave costume, one holy grail has lately eluded fans: a video version of the “Star Wars” films that takes the fullest advantage of their top-of-the-line home theater systems.

headline: Keep Moving, Slouchers
text: And now, the chair that nags you to sit up straight.

headline: Diplomatic Doubles Team Is a Contender, Too
text: TORONTO  One recent morning in Los Angeles, a taxi driver turned to the professional tennis doubles team in his back seat. The driver asked where they were from. Pakistan, Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi answered. India, Rohan Bopanna replied.

headline: Another Try at the Cuba Swim, 32 Years Later
text: From 1968 to 1979, Diana Nyad, a long-distance swimmer, set several world records, including circling Manhattan in 7 hours 57 seconds in 1975. Before this month is out, Nyad, 60, plans to step off the shores of Cuba, near Havana, and swim 103 miles to Key West. In August 1978, Nyad tried the same swim and was pulled from the raging seas after nearly 42 hours. While waiting for the arrival of a license from Cuba, which she needs to start on its soil, Nyad sat for an interview in Los Angeles.

headline: Dolan, Man of Few Words, Says the Wrong Ones
text: The last time James L. Dolan spoke at length about the Knicks  on the record, off the cuff, with reporters present and notebooks open  was on March 12, 2007. It was a momentous day.

headline: U.S. Offers Aid to Rescue Pakistanis and Reclaim Image
text: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration continues to add to the aid package for flood-stricken Pakistan  already the largest humanitarian response from any single country  officials acknowledge that they are seeking to use the efforts to burnish the United States’ dismal image there.

headline: A Place for a Fan and the Giants to Start Fresh
text: Two escalator runs were the last structures standing at Giants Stadium. They’re gone, too; the demolition is complete; New Meadowlands Stadium is ready to host its first football game on Monday night. I thought it would be slow, but the old stadium came crashing down quickly, huge sections at a time. As my father used to say, “Sometimes that’s the way the cookie crumbles.”

headline: Letters to the Editor: A Nine-Hole Course Is Not Always Charmed
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Abbey Lincoln, Bold and Introspective Jazz Singer, Dies at 80
text: Abbey Lincoln, a singer whose dramatic vocal command and tersely poetic songs made her a singular figure in jazz, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 80 and lived on the Upper West Side.

headline: Giants and Padres Cross Paths, Chasing Title in the West
text: "One hundred and three games," Bud Black says, wistfully and ruefully, before a game at Petco Park last week. Black is the manager of the San Diego Padres, but in 1993 he pitched for the San Francisco Giants, who won 103 games but lost the National League West title to the Atlanta Braves on the final day.

headline: A Battle in Mining Country Pits Coal Against Wind
text: ROCK CREEK, W.Va.

headline: Obama Says Mosque Upholds Principle of Equal Treatment
text: PANAMA CITY, Fla.  President Obama said on Saturday that in defending the right of Muslims to build a community center and mosque near Ground Zero he “was not commenting” on “the wisdom” of that particular project, but rather trying to uphold the broader principle that government should “treat everybody equally” regardless of religion.

headline: Christopher Hitchens, Not Going Gently
text: Two fierce battles are being waged this summer — one against esophageal cancer, by the irreverent columnist, commentator and critic Christopher Hitchens (who scorns the use of the word “battle” in this context), and the other for his soul, by those who hope to persuade him to convert to Christianity in extremis. It’s a paradox that Mr. Hitchens, a confirmed atheist and the author of “God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything,” can appreciate, if not relish. The country’s best-known scoffer has spurred one of the most heated discussions of belief, religion and immortality in years.

headline: A Hit Record, and an Indie-Rock Identity Crisis
text: In January 1992, Nirvana’s “Nevermind” replaced Michael Jackson’s “Dangerous” as No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, and the S-word began to fly, from critics, old fans and anyone else whose favorite underground band had been scrubbed and neutered on its way to the top: “sellout.”

headline: Sun Shines on Watney in P.G.A. Third Round
text: HAVEN, Wis.  Nick Watney strolled around Whistling Straits on Saturday seemingly intent on enjoying his first real turn controlling a major. He was hitting dazzling shots, grinning almost constantly as he collected birdies as if they were butterflies.

headline: Fadeout for a Culture That’s Neither Indian Nor British
text: CALCUTTA  Entering the crumbling mansion of the Lawrence D’Souza Old Age Home here is a visit to a vanishing world.

headline: A Fight for a Mountaintop
text: As mountaintop removal mining has become increasingly controversial across Appalachia, the debate over the fate of Coal River Mountain has become something of a symbolic line in the sand.

headline: A Widower Presses On, a County Fair at a Time
text: It was hot the other day at the Effingham County Fair in Illinois, and Leo Burns, a veteran harness driver, does not like the heat. Getting out on the racetrack and competing on a day like that can wear a lot of people out, Burns among them, but he has a pretty good excuse. He is 95.

headline: A Tale Of Two Expenses
text: Social Security outlays are projected to rise from 4.8 percent of GDP now to 6 percent of GDP in 20303 2030 (yes, Doris put her paw on the Fcat button). This is a huge crisis, requiring complete overhaul of the system.

headline: In Iraq, Western Clocks, but Middle Eastern Time
text: BAGHDAD — There was an exchange some months ago about the notion of time that said a little bit about Iran, something about Iraq, but probably most about the United States.

headline: Singh Shoots Into Contention
text: HAVEN, Wis. – On Saturday, there emerged a championship contender from the P.G.A. Championship’s marquee threesome of Tiger Woods, Y.E. Yang and Vijay Singh.  He just was not the golfer most people probably expected.

headline: Man Is Charged in Fatal Shootings in Buffalo
text: BUFFALO  Four people, including a man celebrating his first anniversary, were shot to death early Saturday as a crowd left a popular downtown restaurant here, the police said.

headline: ‘Our Job Is Not Finished,’ President Tells Gulf Coast
text: PANAMA CITY, Fla.  President Obama on Saturday called the capping of the well that has spewed tens of millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico “an important milestone,” but vowed to maintain an intense government response until the environment is cleaned up and businesses and communities are made whole.

headline: Obama Enters Debate With Mosque Remarks
text: PANAMA CITY, Fla.  Faced with withering Republican criticism of his defense of the right of Muslims to build a community center and mosque near ground zero, President Obama quickly recalibrated his remarks on Saturday, a sign that he has waded into even more treacherous political waters than the White House had at first realized.

headline: 3 Republicans Criticize Obama’s Endorsement of Mosque
text: WASHINGTON  Three leading Republicans reacted negatively to President Obama’s statements in favor of a mosque and Muslim community center whose construction has been proposed for a building near the site formerly occupied by the World Trade Center.

headline: Moscow, Through a Cloud of Smoke
text: BREATHE in, breathe out. Breathe in, breathe out. I concentrate on breathing through the surgeon’s mask, and that becomes an effort in itself. Not a simple effort, but difficult and all-important. After a while I am busy doing only that: breathe in, breathe out.

headline: Times Square, 11:33 A.M.
text: On the 65th anniversary of V-J Day, couples in Times Square on Saturday re-enacted the famous kiss that became an iconic image (images, actually) of the end of the World War II. Like a nurse who witnessed the original kiss, you too can share the love.

headline: Mr. Gates Makes a Start
text: Defense Secretary Robert Gates has pledged to restrain military spending. Predictably, members of Congress, industry lobbyists and military commanders are all pushing back. This is a battle well worth fighting. If anything, he needs to be even more ambitious.

headline: As Arizona Went, So Goes Virginia
text: Virginia has long had localized tensions over immigration: places like Prince William County and towns like Herndon where influxes of day laborers and other immigrant Latinos have been followed by police crackdowns, anti-solicitation ordinances and laws empowering the police to check people’s immigration status.

headline: Are You Ready for Some Football?
text: The millionaire players of professional football are suiting up for the new season with a startling caution on their locker room walls. A poster headlined “CONCUSSION” warns players that lifelong brain damage can result if they persevere with macho gallantry through multiple head injuries.

headline: The Ugliest Catch
text: The second annual Garbagefish.com fishing tournament is over. Carmen, Joe and Rocco are the first-place winners, respectively, in the three divisions: sea robin, dogfish and skate.

headline: Lehman Hits a Hole in One at P.G.A. Championship
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Tom Lehman won the Senior P.G.A. Championship in May, but he probably will not win the P.G.A. Championship, too. Halfway through the third round, he was tied for 49th at one under.

headline: Ethics in Congress
text: To the Editor:

headline: Moseley Studies Tape, Too Little and Too Late
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A hallmark of Dustin Moseley is his efficiency. He works quickly, he throws strikes, and, when his sinker is sinking, he spends little time on the mound. In four starts, Moseley has averaged 14.4 pitches per inning, fewest among Yankees starters, according to Stats LLC. These are all traits the Yankees admire, especially with Andy Pettitte’s return from the disabled list unclear.

headline: Free Parking Comes at a Price
text: IN our society, cars receive considerable attention and study  whether the subject is buying and selling them, the traffic congestion they cause or the dangerous things we do in them, like texting and talking on cellphones while driving. But we haven’t devoted nearly enough thought to how cars are usually deployed  namely, by sitting in parking spaces.

headline: G.O.P. Hypocrisy Over the Workers at Ground Zero
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Love From the Lefties
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Angels in America
text: TO appreciate how much and how unexpectedly our country can change, look no further than the life and times of Judith Dunnington Peabody, who died on July 25 at 80 in her apartment on Fifth Avenue in New York.

headline: Double Dip? A Tipping Point May Be Near
text: LIKE a car spinning its wheels, the American economy hasn’t been getting much traction. Many financial indicators are issuing worrisome signals, millions of people are still out of work, and growth is slowing.

headline: The Tax Cut We Can Afford
text: UNLESS Congress and President Obama act soon, Americans’ taxes will increase in 2011, when the cuts enacted under President George W. Bush are due to expire. Almost everyone agrees that this makes little sense given the economy’s fragility. But consensus ends there. The president supports permanently extending the current tax rates for all except the highest-income households, while Congressional Republicans want the entire basket of cuts to be made permanent. The prudent middle ground would be to forestall any tax increases in 2011 and to phase in higher rates on upper-income households in 2012, when the economy will be on firmer ground.

headline: My Kind of Technocracy
text: Chicago

headline: Misled on Medicare
text: FROM 1990 to 1995, we served as public trustees for Social Security and Medicare. As a Democrat and a Republican (now an independent), we worked together on a professional and nonpartisan basis with the other trustees  the secretaries of health and human services, labor and Treasury  to ensure the integrity and credibility of the annual reports on these critically important social insurance programs.

headline: Lehman, the Longer View
text: AS the global economy struggles to recover from its crisis, here comes yet another dissection of a Wall Street firm  this one of Lehman Brothers, whose collapse helped set off the mess. But this very readable book, “The Last of the Imperious Rich: Lehman Brothers, 1844-2008” (Portfolio, $27.95), by Peter Chapman, takes a unusually long view of the situation. It looks at the bank in the context of one and a half centuries of financial evolution.

headline: From Lawyer to Vintner
text: I’M a fifth-generation native of Sonoma County. My parents divorced when I was 5, and my mother raised my brother and me. She worked full time in a doctor’s office, but she always had dinner on the table for us, even when I worked late as a teenager. We’d eat together and talk about our day. It’s a cherished memory.

headline: Academic Bankruptcy
text: WITH the academic year about to begin, colleges and universities, as well as students and their parents, are facing an unprecedented financial crisis. What we’ve seen with California’s distinguished state university system  huge cutbacks in spending and a 32 percent rise in tuition  is likely to become the norm at public and private colleges. Government support is being slashed, endowments and charitable giving are down, debts are piling up, expenses are rising and some schools are selling their product for two-thirds of what it costs to produce it. You don’t need an M.B.A. to know this situation is unsustainable.

headline: Finding a Bridge Over the Void
text: THEY’RE known as the 99ers  laid-off people who have gone 99 weeks without finding work, at which point their jobless benefits expire. More than 1.4 million Americans have been unemployed for at least that long  victims of an economy that has not been creating many jobs.

headline: A Workers’ Revolt Endures in Peru
text: A long-running conflict in a desolate mining town does not square well with China’s portrayal of its rising profile in Latin America.

headline: Tensions Over Chinese Mining Venture in Peru
text: SAN JUAN DE MARCONA, Peru  In its worldwide quest for commodities, China has scoured South America for everything from Brazilian soybeans to Guyanese timber and Venezuelan oil. But long before it made any of those forays, China put down stakes in this desolate mining town in Peru’s southern desert.

headline: Is There an Echo in Here?
text: Congratulations to Jeffrey Harris, winner of Lollapuzzoola 3! Joon Pahk was runner up and Jon Delfin finished third. The Local (junior) division was won by Jeffrey Dubner.

headline: NATO Strike Cited in Afghan Civilian Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  There is a “fair chance” that a NATO jet inadvertently killed five Afghan civilians during a shootout with Taliban fighters in a village in southern Afghanistan earlier this week, an American official said Saturday.

headline: Red Bulls Honor Mathis
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The Red Bulls honored Clint Mathis, who retired this month after a colorful 13-year career in professional soccer, in an on-field ceremony before their game Saturday night against the Los Angeles Galaxy.

headline: Japan, Checking on Its Oldest, Finds Many Gone
text: TOKYO  Japan has long boasted of having many of the world’s oldest people  testament, many here say, to a society with a superior diet and a commitment to its elderly that is unrivaled in the West.

headline: With Keepers Obsolete, Lighthouse Duties Fall to New Set of Stewards
text: ST. HELENA ISLAND, Mich.  MaryAnn Moore and Pan Godchaux had eager smiles and the to-do list ready when their guests arrived for a four-day stay. “Sweep sidewalks and dock,” it said. “Wash tower windows. Pump water.”

headline: New Stress Added to the Heart of Los Angeles Gridlock
text: LOS ANGELES  The intersection of Interstate 405 and Sunset Boulevard, cutting through a prosperous stretch of rolling Los Angeles hills and estates, is notorious for its knots of traffic and frustrating delays. Traffic is so bad that it is hard to figure out how it could get any worse.

headline: Sweat | 1! (Stroke) 2! (Stroke) Sit Up! Stop Chatting!

headline: Pakistan Floods
text: A case of the deadly waterborne disease cholera has been confirmed in Pakistan’s flood-ravaged northwest, and aid workers expect there to be more, the U.N. said.

headline: Some States Are Lacking in Health Law Authority
text: WASHINGTON  Faced with the need to review insurance rates and enforce a panoply of new rights granted to consumers, states are scrambling to make sure they have the necessary legal authority to carry out the responsibilities being placed on them by President Obama’s health care law.

text: Nonprofit groups and volunteers have taken over care and restoration of old lighthouses.

headline: Fighting Tooth and Nail, Unions Overstep
text: Michael Moritz, one of Silicon Valley’s most successful venture capitalists, keeps a low profile. An early backer of Yahoo and Google, Mr. Moritz avoids the press, though he was himself once a journalist. You never see him at industry conferences. While he has given money to President Obama and a few other politicians of both parties, he has no discernible political ambitions.

headline: Where the Camaraderie and Shimmer of Sweat Is Enough
text: Rock Hard Gym is not a sleek and shiny temple of sweat, coaxing in patrons with air-conditioning, lap pools and rock-climbing walls. No, Rock Hard Gym is a dump.

headline: Chicago River? Nature Preserve? An Alderman Presses the Affirmative
text: Alderman James Balcer’s chest swelled with pride one recent morning as he stood in a weedy lot between a train viaduct and the murky South Branch of the Chicago River.

headline: Block Club Carries on, but Fear and Frustration With City Persist

headline: Uninvited Guest at Buddhists’ Idyllic Retreat: Upkeep Woes
text: Perched high on a wild ridge in the Marin Headlands, solitary Hope Cottage has for decades been the unlikeliest of refuges.

headline: Condor Club | North Beach, San Francisco
text: An infamous bar on the Broadway Strip, the historic Condor Club broke sexual boundaries when it became known as the world’s first topless bar in 1964. The lascivious customs of the old Barbary Coast are maintained here with naughty drink names, striptease, lap and pole dancing and nearly naked hostesses.

headline: Director Striving to Open Vast Collection of Artifacts
text: Phoebe Hearst, the mining heiress and matriarch of the University of California, Berkeley, was not a woman of modest ambition, as her personal quest to create a world-class anthropology collection demonstrated.

headline: Paul Ryan Rudd, Actor of Stage and Screen, Dies at 70
text: Paul Ryan Rudd, an actor of the 1970s and ’80s who came to his profession late and left it early but in between drew critical praise for his work on Broadway and in the New York Shakespeare Festival, died on Thursday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 70.

headline: For Top Seeds, No Guarantee of Victory, or Success
text: In a sport like tennis, it is not unusual to see a top seed win a tournament. But in chess, the margin between a No. 1 seed and most of the field is often small, and the top player is usually not the prohibitive favorite.

headline: Bruno S., Street Musician Turned Lead Actor in Herzog Classics, Dies at 78
text: He wrote songs and sang them on the streets of Berlin. One told of a poor boy who grows up wishing for a little horse. The horse arrives years later pulling his mother’s hearse.

headline: Voter Anger No Surprise to Democrats This Time
text: NEVADA, Mo.  A year ago, dozens of protesters gathered outside the district office of Representative Ike Skelton, a Democrat who has represented a wide stretch of western Missouri since 1976. The anger they directed at health care legislation  and by extension most Congressional Democrats  left the party in a state of near panic.

headline: On His Favorite Surface, Murray Hammers Nadal
text: TORONTO — For Andy Murray, the great equalizer in his rivalry with Rafael Nadal is not equipment, momentum, mood or skill, but rather surface. On hardcourts, against tennis’s top-ranked player, Murray has dominated recently.

headline: For Pettitte, Frustration Before Recovery

headline: Kevin Towers Left His Imprint on The Padres

headline: Veterans Take On Grueling Race Around Manhattan
text: The 79th Street Boat Basin Café buzzed Saturday morning with brunchgoers nibbling on omelets and sipping Bloody Marys under a sunny sky. On the pier below, the participants in the fifth annual Mayor’s Cup Kayak Championships launched their boats into the Hudson River for the start of an arduous, 28-mile race around Manhattan.

headline: Yankees Pull Further and Further Away
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The first baseball landed deep into the left-field stands, but that was only the beginning. The next one caromed off a concrete wall beneath the batter’s eye, and the third one shot off Alex Rodriguez’s bat with such authority and conviction that the Royals’ left fielder, Alex Gordon, did not even look up to follow the flight path as it soared above a waterfall and into a section of Kauffman Stadium previously deemed safe for human occupation.

headline: A Man of Few Words, Dolan Says the Wrong Ones

headline: Vows: Ann & Glenn
text: Ann Buchsbaum and Glenn Zorn were introduced at a Christmas party in 2008. Soon after their first few dates, Glenn could not stop thinking of her while he was away on a cruise. He brought her back a figurine of a penguin, one of the few animals that mate for life.

headline: Correction
text: The Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Anne Stephens and Preston Lloyd, misstated the ages of the couple. She is 27, and he is 28 (not 28 and 29, respectively).

headline: Scissors, Glue, Pencils? Check. Cleaning Spray?
text: When Emily Cooper headed off to first grade in Moody, Ala., last week, she was prepared with all the stuff on her elementary school’s must-bring list: two double rolls of paper towels, three packages of Clorox wipes, three boxes of baby wipes, two boxes of garbage bags, liquid soap, Kleenex and Ziplocs.

headline: Corrections
text: The Practical Traveler column on Aug. 1, about ways to avoid high phone bills when traveling abroad, referred imprecisely to a Boingo Wireless plan for travelers who sign up for a $7.95 monthly fee. While the fee for that service, called the Boingo Mobile plan, includes Wi-Fi access for smartphones and mobile devices in hotels, restaurants, airports and more in over 70 countries, it does not provide access for computers. (A $59 plan called Boingo Global includes Wi-Fi access for both mobile devices and computers.)

headline: Galleon Founder Wins New Hearing Over Wiretaps
text: The Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, won a new hearing on his claim that prosecutors filed a misleading application to wiretap his conversations and that the recordings should be excluded from his insider trading trial, Bloomberg News reported on Saturday.

headline: A Penalty and a Playoff Cap a Wild P.G.A.
text: HAVEN, Wis. — One contender fell victim to a rules technicality, another was done in by a poor decision. When all the controversy had settled and the chaos emptied into dusk Sunday, Martin Kaymer kept his wits about him, played the percentages and won the P.G.A. Championship at Whistling Straits.

headline: ‘Freedom’
text: The news about Walter Berglund wasn't picked up locally-he and Patty had moved away to Washington two years earlier and meant nothing to St. Paul now-but the urban gentry of Ramsey Hill were not so loyal to their city as not to read the New York Times. According to a long and very unflattering story in the Times, Walter had made quite a mess of his professional life out there in the nation's capital. His old neighbors had some difficulty reconciling the quotes about him in the Times ("arrogant," "high-handed," "ethically compromised") with the generous, smiling, red-faced 3M employee they remembered pedaling his commuter bicycle up Summit Avenue in February snow; it seemed strange that Walter, who was greener than Greenpeace and whose own roots were rural, should be in trouble now for conniving with the coal industry and mistreating country people. Then again, there had always been something not quite right about the Berglunds.

headline: 50 Shots and One Week Later, an Arrest Is Made

Browne, the chief spokesman for the Police Department.

headline: Not a Top 15 Finish, but Still a Memorable Ending for Club Pro
text: HAVEN, Wis. – Rob Labritz walked off the 18th green at Whistling Straits on Sunday to a hero’s welcome, posing for pictures and holding court with members of the news media outside the clubhouse.

headline: Muscular ‘Expendables’ Enlivens Battle for Studio
text: LOS ANGELES  After months of being chased by Carl C. Icahn, Lions Gate is chasing a box office hit.

headline: ‘The Internet’ — Webbies in Love, or Trying
text: Despite Prince’s recent proclamation of its demise, the World Wide Web is alive and worthy of scrutiny in “The Internet,” a busy but compact production of the Everywhere Theater Group at St. Mark’s Church. The show, as befits its subject, incorporates digital media  video, music samples  as well as those trusty analog standbys, movement and dialogue.

headline: A Family Full of Unhappiness, Hoping for Transcendence
text: Jonathan Franzen’s galvanic new novel, “Freedom,” showcases his impressive literary toolkit  every essential storytelling skill, plus plenty of bells and whistles  and his ability to throw open a big, Updikean picture window on American middle-class life. With this book, he’s not only created an unforgettable family, he’s also completed his own transformation from a sharp-elbowed, apocalyptic satirist focused on sending up the socio-economic-political plight of this country into a kind of 19th-century realist concerned with the public and private lives of his characters.

headline: Reclaiming the Imagination
text: Imagine being a slave in ancient Rome. Now remember being one. The second task, unlike the first, is crazy. If, as I’m guessing, you never were a slave in ancient Rome, it follows that you can’t remember being one — but you can still let your imagination rip. With a bit of effort one can even imagine the impossible, such as discovering that Dick Cheney and Madonna are really the same person. It sounds like a platitude that fiction is the realm of imagination, fact the realm of knowledge.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Jazz Quartet Finds Clarity and Chemistry Together
text: Ralph Alessi has never had a problem with precision or grappled publicly with the mechanics of his art. His trumpet tone conveys a rounded luminescence, like the moon in full phase, and his technique is an astonishment of fluency. The challenge for him, at least as a bandleader, revolves around emotional expressiveness, along with the issue of purpose. At times it can seem as if Mr. Alessi favors open-endedness because he doesn’t trust his own conclusions or his means of making them felt by an audience.

headline: Pungent Harmonies Drawn From Ancient Traditions
text: When the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center was being revamped a decade or so ago, some thought that it should give its overworked hero a rest and do something else entirely. Instead the festival has deftly continued to serve Mozart, if a bit more judiciously, and done things that are completely different.

headline: Less Web Access Among Chronically Ill
text: Although the number of “cyberchondriacs”  people who research health information online  is at an all-time high, those who are afflicted with chronic conditions are less likely to have Internet access, according to data from Pew.

headline: Unpredictable Sort
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This Monday puzzle by Andrea Carla Michaels and Jennifer Nutt could come with its own theme music. The last theme answer spells out what the first four have in common; each ends with the name of a TV DETECTIVE. William Conrad played Frank CANNON in the 1970s. Jack Webb started playing Joe FRIDAY on radio but added television in 1951. Don Johnson was Nash BRIDGES and Adrian MONK is played by Tony Shalhoub.

headline: Five and Five: No. 24, Boston College
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 24, is Boston College. You can find a larger Boston College preview here.

headline: Tapping the Web, 22,000 Miles Up
text: Satellite companies have been the also-rans of Internet providers.

headline: Broadway’s New Desirée, Learning as She Goes Along
text: There is a lot of audience impatience at the Walter Kerr Theater these days. From the moment the curtain comes up on Trevor Nunn’s revival of the Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler musical “A Little Night Music,” everyone is awaiting Bernadette Peters and her already famous performance of “Send In the Clowns,” the show’s great second-act signature number.

headline: Vergne Wins British F3
text: One of the great pleasures of this job is meeting young drivers and watching their careers develop over the years. The case of Jean-Eric Vergne is not just a case in point, but an exceptional example. The Frenchman, 20 years old, won his 12th race in British Formula 3 on Sunday and thereby became the first Frenchman to win that series.

headline: Paying Tribute in Deep Shadow
text: For a half hour before Tom Krell went onstage at Glasslands Gallery in the early hours of Saturday morning, associates were setting up a white backdrop on which videos would be displayed during his set. All the while, Mr. Krell’s beloved 1990s R&B, from which he draws so much inspiration  Shai, Keith Sweat and so on  played over the room’s speakers.

headline: Start-Up Aims to Slay Chip Goliath
text: A group of investors, including companies from the United States, Europe and the United Arab Emirates, has formed in a bid to disrupt one of Intel’s most lucrative franchises.

headline: You Are Your Own Instrument — Slap-Happy at Lincoln Center
text: “Music becomes dance, and dance becomes music,” Bill Bragin announced to the crowd gathered at Damrosch Park Bandshell on Thursday night. “It all becomes one.”

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Producer Price Index for July, housing starts for July, and industrial production and capacity utilization for July (Tuesday); and weekly jobless claims, Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for August and leading economic indicators for July (Thursday).

headline: Finnish Conductor and Pianist Give Mozart a Rigorous Workout
text: The Finnish conductor Osmo Vanska arrived as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra in 2003 with high ambitions, and by any measure he has achieved great things there. But his success in raising the orchestra’s level of playing to international standards and winning enthusiastic support from audiences in the Minneapolis area has come from long periods of hard, focused work.

headline: Obamas Visit Gulf Coast
text: The Obamas and their daughter Sasha visited Panama City, Fla., in a trip intended by the White House to spotlight the oil-stricken Gulf Coast as a recreational venue.

headline: The Subject Is Heartache, but the Music Is Sweet and Light
text: The dancing began early Saturday afternoon at Central Park SummerStage. From almost the first drop of music, couples in the crowd paired off in intimate embraces, sashaying side to side in four-count steps, raising the foot on the fourth beat, the signature flourish of bachata dance.

headline: Entering a Sorority’s Forbidden Precincts
text: Be honest: is there a straight man in America who hasn’t wondered, perhaps even fantasized, about what really goes on in college sororities?

headline: Barred Muslim Scholar Back in U.S.
text: ATLANTA  After being denied entry at Kennedy Airport without explanation nearly four years ago, the South African Muslim scholar Adam Mahomed Habib was in Atlanta this weekend to give a talk at a sociology conference. His subject? Making democratic governments more accountable to the people.

headline: Snooki and Snooky: Reality TV Star and Cartoon Cat
text: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has rejected a request from Nicole Polizzi, a k a Snooki from MTV’s “Jersey Shore,” to trademark her nickname. According to a Trademark Office document published on the Web site TheSmokingGun.com, Snooki cannot be held as a trademark by Ms. Polizzi because of the “likelihood of confusion” with a 2004 trademark belonging to Brian J. Publishing, publisher of the children’s book “Adventures of Snooky: Under the Sea,” by Karen Monaghan-Arnone and Maureen Monaghan-Faber, about a cat lost at sea. Ms. Polizzi filed her request on Feb. 7 for the purpose of “entertainment in the nature of personal appearances by a television personality,” according to the Trademark Office documents. Ms. Polizzi may appeal the decision if she chooses.

headline: Green Day to Serenade in the Jets’ New Season
text: Green Day is lending some of its star power to the New York Jets: these punk musicians (and Broadway composers) will perform during the halftime show of the Jets’ opening game against the Baltimore Ravens on Sept. 13, The Associated Press reported. The group will be enlisting the help of the cast of the Broadway musical  “American Idiot,” which revolves around Green Day songs, and Gang Green, a hardcore punk band from Boston. And if that isn’t enough musical inspiration for the Jets, Nicole Scherzinger of the pop group the Pussycat Dolls will sing the national anthem and perform in a pregame concert, which will also feature the guitarist Slash, outside the New Meadowlands Stadium. The halftime show will, of course, end with fireworks.

headline: Books and Authors, in New York and Abroad
text: The Brooklyn Book Festival will once again fill Borough Hall Plaza in Brooklyn Heights with all things literary on Sept. 12. This year, its fifth, the festival will partner with local clubs, bookstores and cultural institutions, like the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Bell House and St. Ann’s Warehouse, to present additional book-related events. The festival will bring more than 200 authors to Brooklyn for discussions and book signings. Among them will be Salman Rushdie, Mary Gaitskill, Colson Whitehead, Rosanne Cash, Russell Banks and Gary Shteyngart, to name a few. A complete schedule can be found at brooklynbookfestival.org. ... The Edinburgh International Book Festival in Scotland is featuring appearances from 10 of the 13 authors on the long list for this year’s Man Booker Prize, Britain’s most esteemed literary award, BBC News reported. Christos Tsiolkas (“The Slap”) opened the festival on Saturday, with other Booker-nominated writers, including David Mitchell (“The Thousand Autumns of Zacob de Zoet”) and Emma Donoghue (“Room”), among others, to come during the next two weeks. More news from the festival, which continues through Aug. 30, is at edbookfest.co.uk.

headline: Director Is Lined Up for Justin Bieber Film
text: Paramount Pictures has found a director for its new documentary about Justin Bieber. Jon M. Chu, whose latest film, “Step Up 3D,” was recently released, has been hired to direct the 3D film chronicling Mr. Bieber’s rise to the top of the music charts and into young girls’ hearts, Reuters reported. In a statement, Mr. Chu, above, said, “Most people don’t know that his is a true underdog story, and I hope to tell it in a compelling, genuine way, using all source materials available to convey his tale of becoming an icon for this digital age.” A release date has been set for Valentine’s Day weekend. ... Danny Boyle, the Oscar-winning director of “Slumdog Millionaire,” will soon be releasing a film based on the true story of the rise of another underdog of sorts. “127 Hours,” which stars James Franco as the mountain climber Aron Ralston, who amputated his arm to escape being trapped by a boulder at the bottom of a canyon in Utah, will close the London Film Festival, BBC News reported. The full schedule for the festival, which runs from Oct. 13 to 28, will be announced next month.

headline: Internet Proposal From Google and Verizon Raises Fears for Privacy
text: WHEN elephants fight, the saying goes, only the grass gets trampled.

headline: Teller Tries His Hand at Off-Broadway Thriller
text: In the mood for a little darkness? The New York premiere of “Play Dead,” a new Off-Broadway thriller written by Teller (of Penn & Teller), and Todd Robbins, is to open Oct. 21 at Players Theater on MacDougal Street. Mr. Robbins will perform the one-man show, which explores “themes of death, darkness and deception” — at least according to a press release, which also warns of “ethereal sights, sounds and even touches of the returning dead.”

headline: Caramoor Schedules Yo-Yo Ma, Patti Lupone
text: Yo-Yo Ma and Patti LuPone are to headline this year’s Caramoor Fall Festival, its producers have announced. The festival at the Caramoor Center for Music and Arts in Katonah, N.Y., begins its second season with the jazz guitarist Bill Frisell on Sept. 24, playing with his trio, which features the bassist Tony Scherr and the percussionist Rudy Royston. On Sept. 25, Ms. LuPone presents her solo concert “The Gypsy in My Soul,” singing songs associated with her career on Broadway, and on Sept. 26 Mr. Ma will play two concerts with the Knights, a New York City chamber orchestra conducted by Eric Jacobsen. The festival continues on Oct. 2, with a 1920s-themed benefit soirée and on Oct. 3, “The Future Is Now,” a concert of youthful works by Mozart presented by the young musicians from Caramoor’s mentoring programs.

headline: Five and Five: No. 23, Houston
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 23, is Houston. You can find a larger Houston preview here.

headline: Fun, Fun, Fun With Porgy, Bess and George
text: BRIAN WILSON

headline: Down the River, Into the Brain
text: Five neuroscientists go on a rafting adventure to see how the brain reacts when in a natural environment.

headline: With Summer, Big Cable Channels Keep Getting Bigger
text: Thirty-one percent ratings growth is the kind of history that the History channel likes to make.

headline: Aura Lopez
text: Aura Lopez takes part in the Unplugged Challenge.

headline: Google Plan With Verizon Disillusions Some Allies
text: SAN FRANCISCO  On Friday at lunchtime, as Google employees dined al fresco, a hundred protesters descended on the company’s Silicon Valley campus. A group called the Raging Grannies sang a song called “The Battle Hymn for the Internet,” and others carried signs reading, “Google is evil if the price is right.”

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Broadway Danny Rose'
text: A. O. Scott looks at Woody Allen's nostalgic meditation on small-time show business in New York City.

headline: Will You Still Need Me, Will You Still Feed Me
text: When I’m sixty-four 65 66 67 70?

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Big Splash for a Prohibition Drama
text: WHAT does a cable channel do after losing a virtual monopoly on critically lauded, highly rated programming? How about taking a walk on Boardwalk?

headline: Dating Site Marks 10 Years With Ad Campaign
text: Lonely hearts take heed  love may be as close as your next click of the mouse. The dating Web site eHarmony turns 10 on Monday, and it is celebrating the anniversary with an advertising campaign called “Love Begins Here.”

text: To the Editor:

text: Accounts

headline: U.S. Basketball Team Trimming Roster
text: The question Kevin Durant hears most these days is how it feels to be the go-to player for the United States national team on its way to the world championships in Turkey. Modest as an N.B.A. star can be, Durant begs to differ, saying it is all about the team and, lest anyone forget, he was not even invited to play on the 2008 Olympic team in Beijing.

headline: Activists Take Fight on Immigration to Border
text: HEREFORD, Ariz.  No migrant would have dared cross from Mexico into this particular stretch of Arizona on Sunday.

headline: Souvenirs From War: Stay Back
text: Many veterans of World War II, the Korean War and Vietnam brought home tales of heroism and valor and, unbeknownst to their loved ones, potentially explosive war souvenirs.

headline: Metro-North Is Considering Double-Decker Trains
text: Some commuters who take the railroad to Manhattan may soon enjoy an amenity more common to Paris than Ossining: the double-decker ride.

headline: Bay’s Concussion May Signal Need for Change in Mets’ Protocol
text: When Mets outfielder Jason Bay ran full speed into the padded outfield wall at Dodger Stadium last month after catching a long fly ball, then crumpled to the ground, it appeared he had hit his head, face first, against the blue padding.

headline: In Premier League, Widening Gap Between Rich and Poor
text: LONDON

headline: Swimsuit Season’s Over. For Good.
text: The woman coming of age in the 1970s tiptoed on platform shoes into an ambiguous world for her sex. Sure, she was grateful for the cultural and political gains delivered by her older sisters. But if the stage was set for her to conquer it all  a family, a career, equal footing in society with men  she was not quite sure how to go about it.

headline: The Sun Also Surprises
text: Los Angeles

headline: Searching for New York’s Oldest, and Finding Them
text: Since Evelyn Kozak was born on the Lower East Side on Aug. 14, 1899, she has outlived two husbands and survived the Spanish flu and two strokes. She ran a boardinghouse in Miami until she was 90 and avidly played Scrabble until she was 95. In January, she moved in with a granddaughter  and eight great-grandchildren under 13  in the Kensington section of Brooklyn, where she gets manicures, gives precise instructions on how to prepare her breakfast, and recently asked relatives to survey the planet for older eligible bachelors.

headline: With Powerful Serve and Message, Murray Tops Federer
text: TORONTO  When the final ended, Andy Murray waded into the crowd and wrapped his mother in a bear hug. It was a touching moment amid a mostly muted celebration before an underwhelmed audience at Murray’s second straight Rogers Cup championship.

headline: Beach Modesty for the President
text: The last time the news media snapped pictures of a shirtless President Obama, tabloids, blogs and gossip magazines were agog.

headline: Agrium Makes $1.1 Billion Bid for AWB of Australia
text: Agrium may have lost one takeover battle in the last year, but the Canadian fertilizer company is going to try again.

headline: It’s a Battle for the Soul of New ... Stadium
text: The Jets play the Giants on Monday night in each team’s first preseason game.

headline: Attacking Social Security
text: Social Security turned 75 last week. It should have been a joyous occasion, a time to celebrate a program that has brought dignity and decency to the lives of older Americans.

headline: Rates Fall as Market Fears Economic Weakness
text: As 2010 began, there was nearly unanimous agreement in financial circles on at least one thing: Interest rates were sure to rise during the year.

headline: China Passes Japan as Second-Largest Economy
text: SHANGHAI  After three decades of spectacular growth, China passed Japan in the second quarter to become the world’s second-largest economy behind the United States, according to government figures released early Monday.

headline: Workers Let Go by China’s Banks Are Putting Up a Fight
text: BEIJING  These are heady days for China’s state-controlled banks. Last month, the Agricultural Bank of China made its stock market debut, bringing in $22 billion for the largest public offering ever. A sister government-run bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, now has the highest stock market value of any bank in the world.

headline: Japan’s Cabinet Shuns Shrine on Anniversary of War’s End
text: TOKYO  Angering his nation’s conservatives, Japan’s left-leaning new prime minister marked the 65th anniversary of the end of World War II on Sunday by shunning a religious shrine linked to Japan’s militaristic past and instead expressing regret for the suffering the war caused across Asia.

headline: Uneven Season Shouldn’t Dislodge Woods From Ryder Cup
text: HAVEN, Wis.  Even before Tiger Woods’s final-round charge foundered Sunday at Whistling Straits, his chances of winning the P.G.A. Championship  and thus playing his way onto the United States Ryder Cup team by cracking the top eight on the points list  were as good as his chances of not being on the team at all.

text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 23, is Oregon State.
