headline: Islam in Two Americas
text: There’s an America where it doesn’t matter what language you speak, what god you worship, or how deep your New World roots run. An America where allegiance to the Constitution trumps ethnic differences, language barriers and religious divides. An America where the newest arrival to our shores is no less American than the ever-so-great granddaughter of the Pilgrims.

headline: Overnight Sensation Took Time to Develop
text: More than two hours before the scheduled start of the Mets’ game with the Philadelphia Phillies on Sunday night, a light rain fell on Citi Field, the tarp covered the infield and batting practice was canceled.

headline: Ban Looming, Holmes Is Appreciating Camp
text: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Santonio Holmes had taken off his helmet and was standing 15 yards behind the line of scrimmage when Emanuel Cook, a Jets safety, intercepted a pass and took off for the end zone. Eleven Jets on offense chased after Cook. So, just for fun, Holmes did as well.

headline: The Unplugged Challenge
text: The New York Times asked for volunteers who were willing to give up technology for a period of time and tell us about the experience. Here is a selection of their stories.

headline: Bypassing Resistance, Brazil Prepares to Build a Dam
text: ALTAMIRA, Brazil  For Raimunda Gomes da Silva, the impending construction of a huge hydroelectric dam here in the Amazon is painful déjà vu.

headline: Horror at Desert Ritual as Racer Flips Into Crowd
text: LUCERNE VALLEY, Calif.  They came at dusk, more than 1,000 fans driving pickups and off-road vehicles down eight miles of dirt road, to celebrate an annual rite of summer that draws an intensely loyal group of followers: night racing deep in the Mojave Desert by a fleet of souped-up trucks tackling a barely marked 40-mile track of rocks, ruts, sand and sagebrush.

headline: The Unplugged Challenge: Readers Respond
Outdoors and Out of Reach, Studying the Brain
text: GLEN CANYON NATIONAL RECREATION AREA, Utah  Todd Braver emerges from a tent nestled against the canyon wall. He has a slight tan, except for a slim pale band around his wrist.

headline: Drowning Today, Parched Tomorrow
text: Washington

headline: Liang’s Success Flies Under the Radar at Home
text: Although Liang Wenchong’s accomplishments at the P.G.A. Championship turned heads among golf fans in the United States, they have been far less visible in his home country of China.

headline: Triumph Fades on Racial Gap in City Schools
text: Two years ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, testified before Congress about the city’s impressive progress in closing the gulf in performance between minority and white children. The gains were historic, all but unheard of in recent decades.

headline: Soviet Legacy Lingers as Estonia Defines Its People
text: TALLINN, Estonia  Oleg Bessedin’s main travel document is called an “alien’s passport,” as if it were a gag item. But it is all that he has when he ventures abroad  a reminder of his conflicted relationship with this country, and of the explosive ethnic tensions that endure across the former Soviet Union, nearly two decades after Communism’s fall.

headline: Paterson Signs No-Fault Divorce Bill
text: Gov. David A. Paterson signed into law a package of bills on divorce on Sunday, including one making New York one of the last states to allow couples to dissolve marriages by mutual consent.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sports Replay: August 15
text: Images from the day in sports.

headline: Chinese Health Ministry Clears Milk Powder in Latest Scare
text: HONG KONG  China’s health ministry announced Sunday that it had found no clinical evidence that milk powder had been responsible for apparent breast development in three infant girls in south-central China.

headline: Return of the Killer Trade Deficit
text: The world economy is falling back on very dangerous habits. The United States is tentatively emerging from recession but is still at risk of another dip. Yet trade statistics released last week indicate that American consumers are sucking in large quantities of imports as spending recovers, while weak demand in the rest of the world is crimping American exports.

headline: Fly Fishers Serving as Transports for Noxious Little Invaders
text: For fly fishers who pride themselves on a conservationist ethic, it hurts to discover that they may be trampling on that ethic every time they wade into a trout stream.

headline: Investing Made Easy — If Only
text: Investing is scary these days. Is it safe to go back in the stock market? Is the bond market the place to be? With so much uncertainty, how can investors know where to put their money? Morningstar, the mutual fund research service, is on to an answer, but it might not make you feel better about your financial advisers.

headline: Free the Medical Isotope Bill
text: A single senator  Christopher Bond, Republican of Missouri  is blocking a bill that would ensure a reliable supply of medical isotopes while reducing the risk of nuclear terrorism. The Senate leadership needs to pry it loose.

headline: Another Round in Same-Sex Marriage Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In all of the legal maneuvering surrounding the challenge in federal court to Proposition 8, California’s 2008 voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage, one thing has seemed all but certain: the case would eventually head to the Supreme Court.

headline: In Brooklyn Store, Everything Is Always 100% Off
text: April Gariepy, 30, wheeled her bike beneath the white tent on Saturday afternoon looking for a wire basket she could attach to her handlebars. A moment later, Sharika Barrow, 17, approached, gazed at the shelves of books, clothing and other items displayed beneath the tent, then wondered aloud what sort of place she was visiting.

headline: Air-Conditioners That Run When Nobody’s Home
text: In a handsome prewar building in Greenwich Village, a tenant struggled to remember the last time she turned off her air-conditioner. Upstairs, a young couple admitted to having let the window unit run for four days while they went out of town for a funeral, thinking it would be nice, amid the July heat wave, to return to a cool apartment.

headline: Troubled School District Is on Road to Recovery
text: ROOSEVELT, N.Y.  The day before classes ended in June in the long-troubled Long Island school district here, 300 high school students were called to the auditorium to see the superintendent. Only this time, no one had done anything wrong.

headline: Police Arrest Man Hurt in Shootout in Harlem
text: The 23-year-old man who was shot upward of 20 times by the police during a shootout in Harlem on Aug. 8 was arrested on Saturday upon his release from the hospital. He was expected to be arraigned Monday morning.

headline: Bobbing and Weaving to Avoid Taking the Hits
text: Stimulus spending, government bailouts and a complex health care law can be heavy bricks in the backpacks of Democratic Congressional candidates.

headline: CBS’s Penalty Explanation Comes Up Short
text: It is a simple rule in golf: the club can’t touch the sand in a bunker before hitting a shot. And it is that rule that Dustin Johnson ran afoul of on the 18th hole of the final round of the P.G.A. Championship on Sunday, ending his chance to advance to the playoff.

headline: Times Co. Property to Charge Web Users
text: The Telegram & Gazette, a newspaper in Worcester, Mass., that is owned by The New York Times Company, said it would begin charging readers to view some of the local news articles that appear on the paper’s Web site.

headline: A Manhattan Crossing
text: New Yorkers like to say they can walk faster than the crosstown bus. That’s pushing it a bit. On 34th Street, according to New York City Transit surveys, buses average about four miles an hour. For those in a hurry, pretty much everyone here, it’s a glacial pace for a crosstown trip. Janette Sadik-Khan, the city’s transportation commissioner, is proposing an intriguing fix for 34th Street.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Victim of a Course’s Bunker Mentality
text: HAVEN, Wis. — It is not easy to talk about Whistling Straits without mentioning the bunkers — hundreds of them, in all shapes and sizes, that produce a visual cacophony that is any golfer’s nightmare.

headline: Bank of America Weighs Sale of BlackRock Stake
text: As Bank of America trims away its asset-management businesses, one big question remains: What will it do with the 34 percent stake in BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager, that it inherited from Merrill Lynch?

headline: On Another Night Their Bats Are Quiet, the Mets Drop Below .500 Again
text: Having scored only nine runs in a six-game homestand, the Mets were probably fortunate to win half of those games.

headline: Word of the Day | dogged
text: dogged •\ˈdȯ-gəd\• adjective

headline: G.M. Said to Add Bank of America and Citigroup as Underwriters
text: General Motors has added Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Citigroup to the slate of its lead underwriters for its initial public offering, two people with lnowledge of the situation told Reuters on Friday.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Bleach Spill Shuts Part of Times Square
text: Thirty gallons of bleach spilled on the top floor of a Times Square skyscraper on Sunday night, prompting a flood of emergency vehicles and the closure of six blocks on Seventh Avenue for about an hour.

headline: Wind Turbines Are Coming to New York, and Not Just Offshore
text: For years, New York officials have envisioned powering the region from a set of huge wind turbines in the Atlantic Ocean off Long Island. But well before an offshore wind farm would be up and running, giant turbines may soon be spinning much closer to the city.

headline: Stanley Simon, Who Assisted Veterans, Is Dead at 93
text: They had fought in Italy and Normandy and North Africa and left pieces of themselves behind. At war’s end, few employers would touch them. So one by one, the men made their way to New York — to a red-brick schoolhouse in Woodside, Queens, built expressly for them — to become watchmakers.

headline: Denis E. Dillon, Prosecutor on Long Island, Dies at 76
text: Denis E. Dillon, the longtime district attorney of Nassau County, N.Y., who quietly oversaw high-profile prosecutions while using his office as a bully pulpit against abortion, died on Sunday morning at his home in Rockville Centre. He was 76.

headline: Variable Pricing and Net Neutrality
text: It is easy to frame the debate over net neutrality as an ideological battle between forces who want unfettered Internet access and those who would prevent it. In reality, as with most good fights, it is largely a dispute over money. Some pretty basic numbers illustrate the point — and provide an idea of where the debate should logically wind up.

headline: Hulu Is Said to Be Ready for an I.P.O.
text: Hulu, the rapidly growing hub for online television and movies, aims to go public through an offering that could value the company at more than $2 billion, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: News Quiz | August 16, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Not Top 15, but Finish Satisfies Club Pro
text: HAVEN, Wis.  Rob Labritz walked off the 18th green at Whistling Straits on Sunday to a hero’s welcome, posing for pictures and holding court with reporters outside the clubhouse.

headline: Like 3rd-Round Leader, Round of 81 Is Lost in Shuffle
text: HAVEN, Wis.  There are bad days, and then there is what happened to Nick Watney on Sunday.

headline: Australia Leader Points to Economy Ahead of Vote
text: SYDNEY, Australia  With less than a week remaining in the tightest federal election campaign here in decades, Prime Minister Julia Gillard used a speech to party loyalists on Monday to highlight her economic credentials and try to widen the narrow lead she holds in the polls over her conservative rival.

headline: Hulu Prepares for an I.P.O.
text: Hulu, the rapidly growing hub for online television and movies, aims to go public through an offering that could value the company at more than $2 billion, according to people briefed on the matter, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times.

headline: A Chip Start-Up Aims to Slay Intel
text: A group of investors, including companies from the United States, Europe and the United Arab Emirates, has formed in a bid to disrupt one of Intel’s most lucrative franchises, The New York Times’s Ashlee Vance reported Monday.

headline: Workers Let Go by China’s Banks Put Up a Fight
text: These are heady days for China’s state-controlled banks. Last month, the Agricultural Bank of China made its stock market debut, bringing in $22 billion for the largest public offering ever. A sister government-run bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, now has the highest stock market value of any bank in the world, Andrew Jacobs reports in The New York Times.

headline: How to Set Your Child’s Allowance
text: Over the years, parents have often used the dollar (or half a dollar) a week for each year of age formula to set a child’s allowance.

headline: Morgenson: In This Play, One Role Is Enough
text: From Gretchen Morgenson’s latest column in The New York Times:

headline: Color War!
text: WHAT is Color War?WHAT are some Color War traditions described in this article?

headline: Battle in Mining Country Pits Coal Against Wind
text: Lorelei Scarbro’s husband, Kenneth, an underground coal miner for more than 30 years, is buried in a small family cemetery near her property here at the base of Coal River Mountain. The headstone is engraved with two roosters facing off, their feathers ruffled. Kenneth, who loved cockfighting, died in 1999, and, Ms. Scarbro says, he would have hated seeing the tops of mountains lopped off with explosives and heavy machinery by mining companies searching for coal.

headline: Book Review: Lehman, the Longer View
text: As the global economy struggles to recover from its crisis, here comes yet another dissection of a Wall Street firm — this one of Lehman Brothers, whose collapse helped set off the mess. But this very readable book, “The Last of the Imperious Rich: Lehman Brothers, 1844-2008” (Portfolio, $27.95), by Peter Chapman, takes a unusually long view of the situation. It looks at the bank in the context of one and a half centuries of financial evolution.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Begin War Drills
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Tens of thousands of South Korean and United States troops began a new round of war games on Monday, as North Korea threatened a “merciless counterblow” amid heightened tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

headline: Muscular ‘Expendables’ Enlivens Battle for Studio
text: After months of being chased by Carl C. Icahn, Lions Gate is chasing a box office hit. Now the question becomes: Can a ministudio with a corporate raider on its tail make a real winner out of its weekend wonder?

headline: Facebook Buys Chai Labs for Over $10 Million
text: Facebook has purchased search firm Chai Labs for more than $10 million, according to All Things Digital.

headline: Google Deal for Like.Com Is Said to Be Near
text: Google is in the final stages of acquiring visual search and e-commerce firm Like.com for more than $100 million, VentureBeat said, citing a report from Techcrunch.

headline: ‘Super Angel’ Senkut Raises $40 Million Fund
text: Felicis Ventures, the firm created by a former Google manager,  Aydin Senkut, just announced that it has raised $40 million. It’s the firm’s first institutional fund, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Merger Creates Largest Latin American Airline
text: TAM Airlines of Brazil and LAN of Chile announced plans for a merger that would create Latin America’s largest airline, The Associated Press reported over the weekend.

headline: Face Value
text: If you’ve paid close enough attention to folding money to have noticed — say — the arrival of clouds above the Lincoln Memorial, you’ll gladly pore over “Money Talks,” by the Japanese-Italian photojournalist Naoki Tomasini, 35. Fascinated by the symbols of power that appear on paper currency worldwide, Mr. Tomasini has produced a series of extreme close-ups of the intricate artwork on bills. “We all need to believe that what we receive in exchange for our work is value,” he said, “not mere paper.”

headline: Vedanta to Buy Cairn India Stake in $9.6 Billion Deal
text: Vedanta Resources said Monday that it would buy from Cairn Energy a stake in Cairn’s Indian subsidiary for up to $9.6 billion in cash, acquiring with the deal Cairn’s huge Rajasthan oil field with plans to bolster India’s domestic oil production.

headline: Chinese Consortium May Bid for 30 Percent of AIA
text: A consortium of Chinese companies including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and China Life Insurance plans to bid for a 30 percent stake in American International Group‘s Asian life insurance business, AIA, Reuters said, citing a report by the 21st Century Business Herald.

headline: Aviva Investor Says RSA Deal Had Synergies
text: One investor in Aviva, which recently rejected a £5 billion bid from RSA for its general insurance unit, said there were potential synergies in a deal of that nature.

headline: Paternoster Is Said to Be Looking for a Buyer
text: Paternoster, a specialist pension business, has been put up for sale, The Financial Times has reported. Backers in the company, founded by the former Prudential executive Mark Wood, are facing a potential loss of more than half of their £500 million equity investment, the newspaper said.

headline: Why Glen Coffee Quit Football
text: Some people are still shaking their heads that Glen Coffee, the former star running back at Alabama, announced his retirement from football on Friday. He had played one season for the 49ers.

headline: Advent Said to Prepare Sale of Takko Fashion
text: Advent International,  the private equity firm, will sell or spin off  Takko Fashion, the German discount retail chain, The Financial Times reported. The fast-growing firm would have a stock market value of about 1.25 billion euros ($1.6 billion).

headline: Buyback Window Opened by Dodd-Frank
text: A 90-day securities buyback window has been opened by the new financial reform bill. This will allow banks to buy back $118 billion in high-cost securites and to replace the instruments with cheaper capital, The Financial Times reported.

text: All too often, we fall prey to faulty analysis, simply because it has been repeated over and over. Behold some of the top fantasy football misconceptions.

headline: Why Girly Jobs Don’t Pay Well
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: First Features and Student Fare at Prague Film Festival
text: A student film festival with international clout is coming to Prague, fueling the city’s already vibrant community of cinema enthusiasts. The seventh annual Fresh Film Fest, running  Aug. 25 to 29, offers more than 200 works submitted by students from 60 countries. Professional theatrical performances, retrospectives and feature film debuts will round out the program.

headline: Marshall Wace Investors to Vote to Delist Fund
text: Investors in the $311 million listed investment fund of $6 billion London hedge fund Marshall Wace are expected to vote Monday for the delisting of the vehicle, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Ike, J.F.K. and Today
text: Today’s idea: Five decades later, dueling speeches by two presidents delivered within three days of each other still frame the unresolved debate about American military power.

headline: Norris: Rates Fall on Fears of Weak Economy
text: As 2010 began, there was nearly unanimous agreement in financial circles on at least one thing: Interest rates were sure to rise during the year.

headline: Obama Warns on ‘Whims of Wall Street Traders’
text: President Barack Obama said Republican proposals to have people invest Social Security benefits in private accounts in the stock market would increase the budget deficit and put retirement money at risk to “the whims of Wall Street traders,” Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Finra Urged to Look at Its Madoff Ties
text: American brokerages want to weigh in on how much the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority pays its senior executives and urged the watchdog to hire outsiders to investigate any possible ties between it and the convicted money manager Bernard L. Madoff, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Buffett Aims to Corral Chicago Billionaires
text: After the recent announcement that more than 30 billionaires would give more than half their wealth to charity, some remain elusive according to Warren Buffett. In an interview with The Chicago Tribune, Mr. Buffett proclaimed, “You can be sure that Chicago hasn’t escaped us. But we don’t want to say who has turned us down.”

headline: Peltz’s Trian Loses Taste for Kraft Foods
text: Nelson Peltz has apparently lost his appetite for Kraft Foods. The activist investor has sold his shares in the company which he once sought to influence through his holdings, MarketWatch reported.

headline: An App-Powered Music Dock
text: In my recent article about iHome, the largest manufacturer of  iPhone/iPod speaker docks, I pointed out that Apple’s strict design regulations make it easier for accessories makers to create products, secure in the knowledge that they won’t quickly need to reposition one feature or another in response to an Apple design change.

headline: Harrah’s Stock Sale to Benefit Paulson, Mostly
text: Harrah’s Entertainment said in a Thursday regulatory filing that it planned to sell up to $710 million in common stock and to have the shares listed on a major stock exchange again. But, rather than primarily help the casino operator, it will instead mainly benefit the hedge fund firm Paulson & Company.

headline: What Exactly Is a Social Entrepreneur?
text: I understand social. I understand entrepreneur. But when you put the two words together, I have to pause.

text: In a bid to combat proposals aimed at raising taxes on private equity firms, the Private Equity Council, which represents the biggest United States buyout firms, is urging members to find their “grassroots.”

headline: Rival Bidders May Be Lining Up for Dana
text: As Korea National Oil Company considers a hostile takeover bid for Dana Petroleum, rival bidders are lining up, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Discovery to Give Oprah’s OWN $89 Million More
text: Oprah Winfrey’s new network, OWN, will receive a further $89 million in funding from Discovery Communications, Variety reported, citing a Friday regulatory filing.

headline: Floods Could Have Lasting Impact for Pakistan
text: KARACHI, Pakistan  Even as the government and international relief workers struggle to get food and clean water to millions of flood-stricken Pakistanis, concerns are growing about the enduring toll of the disaster on the nation’s overall economy, food supply and political stability.

headline: Dell to Buy Data Storage Company for $1.15 Billion
text: Dell said Monday that it has agreed to buy 3PAR, a data storage company, for about $1.15 billion in cash, as the computer giant races to expand beyond its core PC-making business.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Salade Niçoise
text: Ian Pasquer, a chef at L’Orange Bleue in Manhattan, serves a salade niçoise whose basic ingredients — potatoes, haricots verts, tomatoes and eggs — are classic, but whose preparation has subtleties that make it especially appealing.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — Nouriel Roubini racks his brain for ways to nip young Gordon Gekkos in the bud. “Greed cannot be controlled by any appeal to morality and values. Greed has to be controlled by fear of loss, which derives from knowledge that the reckless institutions and agents will not be bailed out.”

headline: Paying for College Without Loans, Scholarships or Looting Your Parents’ Retirement
text: On Aug. 31, Portfolio will publish “Debt-Free U: How I Paid for an Outstanding College Education Without Loans, Scholarships or Mooching Off My Parents” by Zac Bissonnette.

text: Medco Health Solutions said Monday that it had agreed to buy United BioSource, a medical research company, for about $730 million in cash.

headline: The Nation’s Greenest Colleges
text: One way to measure environmentalism on college campuses is to size up their efforts to cut energy use or to recycle garbage. In rankings released on Monday, the Sierra Club’s Sierra Magazine anoints Green Mountain College in Vermont, which gets heat and electricity by burning locally sourced wood chips and methane from cow manure, as the nation’s greenest college.

headline: Air-Conditioning Without Pause
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Vain Glorious | Matchy Matchy
text: With his latest line for Dior Beauty, Tyen, the company’s creative makeup director, takes the concept of matching your lipstick to your dress to a whole new level. Each color in his new 32-shade Rouge Dior Lipcolor range ($30 each at Dior counters) was inspired by the hues of haute couture ensembles from the atelier’s archives. ‘‘I tried to find shades that brighten life and make sadness disappear,’’ Tyen says. The formula is an haute concept, too, containing hyaluronic microspheres that promise to soften, replenish and plump lips into a perfect pucker.

headline: Hand-Made Retronyms
text: This weekend, despite some confusion, co-vocabularists have generously shared retronyms.

headline: Judging Rodriguez’s Productivity
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — How do you best judge production? By how many runs a player scores? By how many runs he drives in? By a different statistic – or combination thereof – entirely? Such questions came to mind Sunday, the day after Alex Rodriguez bashed three homers and flogged himself for not being productive enough this season. This is his exact quotation: “It’s definitely frustrating that I haven’t been able to hit for more productivity this year.”

headline: Eastwood’s ‘Hereafter’ Will Close New York Film Festival
text: One year after A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times that the 47th edition of the New York Film Festival had “distinguished itself as the grimmest in memory,” the latest feature announced for the festival’s 48th run is not particularly indicative of a sudden turn toward sunshine and happiness.

headline: Alternative Remedies for Migraine
text: A number of readers had questions for the Consults blog about magnesium, feverfew and other alternative and nutritional therapies for the prevention or treatment of migraine symptoms. Dr. David Dodick of the Mayo Clinic responds.

headline: Microlender, First in India to Go Public, Trades Higher
text: MUMBAI, India  The first microfinance company to sell stock to the public in India got a strong endorsement from investors on Monday when its shares closed up 10.5 percent on the first day of trading.

headline: Monday Reading: Paying for College Without Debt
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Swan Song
text: When fashion editors were given an intimate viewing of Alexander McQueen’s final collection in Paris this past spring, this dress was not part of it. Perhaps the last piece touched by the designer’s hands, it was made by McQueen especially for his longtime friend Annabelle Neilson, and its only outing has been to Elton John’s White Tie and Tiara Ball in June. Neilson was notorious for wearing McQueen’s clothes and she did so with a fierceness befitting her status as his muse. A sheer black jumpsuit from 2006, a mere figment of McQueen’s imagination that left nothing to anyone else’s, generated reams of chatter and flaunted the designer’s devilish streak. Indeed he was often heralded as fashion’s enfant terrible No. 1. But in this simply elegant silk charmeuse gown with its collar of silvered feathers, Neilson appeared as the vision of an angel.

headline: Governors Island: A Place for Pop and a Plea for More Adventurous Art
text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asks Edward Rothstein in the Weekend section on Friday. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On ArtsBeat, critics from several disciplines will be discussing the island’s role as a cultural destination. Check back for regular updates throughout Monday and share your own thoughts about the island too. Read previous entries here.

headline: Holy Bond Yield, Batman!
text: I was sorely tempted to break the NYT rules on obscenity when I fired up my notebook this morning and saw the 10-year bond yield: 2.59 percent. We’re now almost back to the Oh-God-we’re-all-gonna-die yields at the height of the financial crisis.

headline: New York Send-Off | Of Honky-Tonks and Supper Clubs
text: Jan Benzel is an editor at The Times who is being reassigned to Paris. Before she leaves, she is attempting to do all the things in the city that every New Yorker should do, at least once.

headline: France Asked to Return Money ‘Extorted’ From Haiti
text: In an open letter to President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, published on Monday in the Paris newspaper Libération, an international group of scholars and activists called on France to repay Haiti, its former colony, more than $20 billion that had been “extorted” in the 19th century.

headline: Numberplay: The Relativity of Probability
text: The determination of probabilities is a well-established branch of mathematics. Very often probability calculations are simple and yield exact values that seem absolute and objective. Not so! Today I give you three scenarios with questions whose calculations are mostly simple. They are meant to show two things: first, that probability is relative – the probability of something may be very different depending on the way it is measured; and second, that probability is a measure of our ignorance. Any piece of knowledge, no matter how seemingly irrelevant, can change the probability for us.

headline: A Consumer Reports for the Cheap
text: Back in late 2008, Max Levitte was looking for a vacuum to clean up the one rug in his New York apartment.

headline: Rossi Signs With Ducati for Two Years
text: Valentino Rossi, the great Italian motorcycle rider, confirmed recent rumors that he will be joining Ducati in 2011.

headline: Where’s My Generator, Spy?
text: The captain had finished his lunch and was lounging on a twin-size mattress in the corner of his command post — and by command post, I mean a small room with a single hand-held radio, a desk, a chair and his bed.

headline: Lawyer Battles Back Against DC Comics in Superman Dispute
text: Marc Toberoff, the lawyer who has represented heirs to the Superman creators Jerome Siegel and Joseph Shuster in their fight to reclaim copyrights from DC Comics, a division of Warner Brothers Entertainment, asked a court in Los Angeles on Friday to dismiss the complaint filed against him personally last May in connection with the long-running legal battle. In its complaint, DC Comics claimed that Mr. Toberoff had manipulated the heirs for years in an effort to capture a huge share of the copyrights for himself. In asking the United States District Court for the Central District of California to dismiss the complaint, Richard B. Kendall, a lawyer for Mr. Toberoff, called it “an absolutely meritless attack” that was meant to undermine Mr. Toberoff’s relationship with the Siegel and Shuster heirs in the wake of a previous victory in court over DC Comics. A hearing in the case is set for Oct. 18.

headline: Postgraduate School Buses: Call Them Camionetas
text: It is common practice in most of Central America to import old American school buses, (sometimes) repaint them, and use them as public transportation. It’s not the most comfortable way to travel: luggage is tied to the roof; leg room is a lost cause for anyone taller than 5-foot -8, and each bump in the road becomes a  jolt — misery for anyone with even a hint of a bad back.

headline: Not Just for Dieters
text: When I lived in France there was only one American food that I missed: cottage cheese. Most days, I make a quick, no-nonsense lunch out of cottage cheese and vegetables — tomatoes and cucumbers in the summer, avocado and/or leftover cooked vegetables (roasted sweet potatoes are a favorite) when summer gives way to fall. Friends have accused me of eating “diet food,” but I take great pleasure in these lunches. Besides, I’m never on a diet.

headline: Porsche Gave 918 Spyder a Secret Shakedown Before Pebble Beach
text: Porsche has been having some fun with its sexy 918 Spyder plug-in hybrid, starting with its surprise debut at the Geneva auto show in March.

headline: Fighting Long-Term Unemployment
text: Liz Alderman, the International Herald Tribune senior business correspondent, looks at Denmark's generous unemployment benefit system as the country fights long-term joblessness.

headline: Cottage Cheese and Herb Loaf
text: This savory, high-protein bread is great for sandwiches. It only requires one rise, right in the pan. Don’t let it rise for too long, or it will puff so much that it will be difficult to slice. The dough is sticky, but if you keep your hands floured you won’t have trouble working with it.

headline: Raspberry Cream
text: This simple dessert is a perfect destination for frozen raspberries, which throw off a lot of juice when they thaw. Serve it as a dessert, a breakfast, a topping for toast or a snack.

headline: Lasagna With Spinach and Cottage Cheese
text: I’m substituting cottage cheese here for the ricotta used in the classic version of this lasagna. In a pinch, you could make it with prepared marinara sauce, and it then becomes a quick and very satisfying dinner.

headline: Cottage Cheese Pesto
text: Use this pungent mixture as a vegetable dip, a spread or a pasta sauce. When you use it as a sauce, thin it with a spoonful of the pasta cooking water.

headline: Denmark’s Generous Safety Net in Question
text: With the global recession exposing chinks in its armor, Denmark is making efforts to find a new balance between job market flexibility and security for workers.

headline: Gates Looking at His Own 2011 Departure
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates is looking to step down sometime in 2011.

headline: When Personal Style Impedes a Sale
text: John Blesso feels as though he has made plenty of compromises to try to sell his Morningside Heights apartment. Before every open house over the past five months, he has hidden away his toaster, cocktail shaker, vinegar, olive oil, salt, pepper, remote controls, shaving cream and loofah, and even taken his towel off the towel rack.

headline: Deadliest for Walkers: Male Drivers, Left Turns
text: It has never been easy to safely navigate the streets of New York, where today automobiles zip inches away from smartphone-carrying pedestrians and the footrace across an intersection seems like a human version of the arcade game Frogger.

headline: Why Denmark Is Shrinking Its Social Safety Net
text: Denmark has long held the title of the best place on earth to be laid off. With an expensive, generous welfare state, and the world’s most lavish unemployment insurance scheme, virtually no one falls through the cracks upon losing a job.

headline: Conductor in Mostly Mozart Festival Is Held for Nonpayment of Child Support
text: En route to Alice Tully Hall from Copenhagen, the conductor Paul Hillier made an unusual detour before leading the ensemble Ars Nova Copenhagen at Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival on Friday night: he spent part of last week in a New Jersey jail, after he was arrested on an outstanding warrant for criminal nonpayment of child support.

headline: James J. Kilpatrick, Conservative Voice in Print and on TV, Dies at 89
text: James J. Kilpatrick, a prominent conservative voice for half a century as a newspaper editor and columnist, author and television personality, died Sunday in Washington. He was 89.

headline: We’d Buy the Place, but the Décor Is Weird
text: For brokers trying to sell apartments, the last thing they want is to show off anything that distracts buyers. In this week’s installment of my column, The Appraisal, we explore how some brokers have trouble trying to persuade sellers to remove or hide such potential distractions — from machete collections to noisy exotic birds to views of large clocks looming outside the window. While some buyers can look past these features and make offers, others find it far too difficult to picture these apartments as homes until they are pretty much turned into blank slates.

headline: Comparing Nursing Homes, and Seeing Stars
text: To follow up on recent posts about what matters in selecting nursing homes and other care facilities, and how confounding the whole question can become, let’s talk for a moment about stars.

headline: Geithner’s Ex-Landlord Moves to JPMorgan
text: The former government official who let Timothy F. Geithner stay at his home shortly after becoming Treasury secretary has moved on to JPMorgan Chase.

headline: White House Reaffirms Afghan Strategy, Despite Petraeus Remarks
text: MENOMONEE FALLS, Wis. — President Obama remains committed to beginning a withdrawal of American troops from Afghanistan next July, a White House spokesman said on Monday, playing down recent remarks by the American military commander in Afghanistan that he might recommend a delay if conditions warrant.

headline: Go for Broke | Hervé Leroux at Colette
text: While perusing some images from the latest photography installation at Colette in Paris (the work of Trujillo/Paumier and Nick Meek), I was blindsided by a mannequin wearing the most perfect dress I’ve seen in a while — a beautifully draped one-shoulder number in a divine shade of emerald green. I called the store immediately for more information in the hopes that the price was somewhere in the realm of my Amex limit. As it turns out the dress is by Hervé Leroux, who you may remember as Hervé Leger, the king of bandage. The bad news? 4,630 euros. If this weren’t enough to bring a tear to my covetous eye, I was immediately reminded of another dress I couldn’t afford, in my fashion fledgling days back in the early ’90s, modeled by a smoldering Karen Mulder on the Leger runway. I kept a photo of it pinned to the bulletin board of my cubicle for at least a year. To be sure, a lot has changed since my first Leger obsession, but what hasn’t changed is that the man still has a way with elastic. And a girl can still dream, right?

headline: The Claim: More Sugar Leads to More Cavities

text: Now’s the time to grin and bear it.

headline: Fears of Disease Grow in Flood-Ravaged Pakistan
text: With flooding affecting a fifth of Pakistan, United Nations officials said Monday that a shortage of aid money was leaving some six million people at risk of potentially lethal water-borne diseases.

headline: Man Shot by Police Is Charged With Gun Possession
text: A man shot roughly two dozen times in a storm of police gunfire in Harlem last week was charged Monday with criminal possession of a weapon. But prosecutors said they were not at the moment pursuing more serious charges, including attempted murder, brought by the police when he was arrested on Saturday.

headline: Ads Locate This Building on Gay, Straight or Whatever Street
text: For more than a decade, the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan has been known as a destination for gay men. Now, a new apartment building there is aiming advertising at gay tenants in what might possibly be a new twist in real estate marketing.

headline: Schminternet
text: Portmanteau term reflecting concerns over a two-tier Internet.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Portia Badham joined the Four A’s, New York, as senior vice president for communications. She succeeds Kipp Cheng, who left to join G2 Worldwide, New York, part of the Grey Group unit of WPP, as group director for corporate communications. Ms. Badham had most recently been president at BadWyn Communications, an agency she started in 1999.

headline: Amanda Peet and Laurie Metcalf Join MCC Theater Productions
text: It may not be Mulder and Scully back together, but an “X-Files” reunion of sorts will be coming to the New York stage this fall. MCC Theater said on Monday that Amanda Peet, the star of  films like “Please Give” and “The Whole Nine Yards,” will be re-teamed with David Duchovny in its production of Neil LaBute‘s “Break of Noon.” (As all dedicated X-philes know, Ms. Peet previously appeared opposite Mr. Duchovny in the 2008 film “The X-Files: I Want to Believe” and shares some scathing tongue-in-cheek thoughts on him in the film’s making-of documentary.) Mr. Duchonvy was previously slated to play a man who sees the face of God during an office shooting; Ms. Peet will do double duty as that man’s wife, Ginger, and Ginger’s cousin, Jesse. The play, to be directed by Jo Bonney, will begin previews at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Oct. 28 and open on Nov. 15; its limited run is scheduled through Dec. 12.

headline: Video of Deadly Off-Road Race Crash
text: Raw video shot near the scene of a deadly crash at an off-road race on Saturday evening in the Mojave Desert has been posted online by CBS News. The images were shot by a spectator, Jonathan Davy, who started filming just before the crash during a race known as the California 200.

headline: Jets Versus Giants: It’ll Be Fun Until Someone Gets Hurt
text: The opening of their stadium for the first N.F.L. game makes Monday night special for the Giants and the Jets (8 p.m. Eastern, ESPN, also Ch. 9 locally).

headline: Wood Is Good for Headphones
text: When I was in college, I had an enormous pair of stereo speakers housed in wood cabinets. Back then, most speaker makers favored wood because it radiated a rich, warm sound.

headline: In Bold Display, Taliban Order Stoning Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban on Sunday ordered their first public executions by stoning since their fall from power nine years ago, killing a young couple who had eloped, according to Afghan officials and a witness.

headline: Rescuing a Lost Era of Jazz History
text: Between 1936 and 1940, Bill Savory, a studio engineer and jazz fan, recorded about 1,000 discs of live performances of leading jazz bands. An audio engineer is now cleaning and restoring the music.

headline: Moscow Acts on Governor’s Lack of Support
text: MOSCOW  Russia’s leaders appeared to make a rare bow to popular pressure on Monday, denying a second term to a governor on the grounds that he lacked public support in a region where a huge antigovernment protest broke out this year.

headline: Assisted Living
text: "This is a new life...and each day I'm more accustomed to it."

headline: Bits Pics: A Global Graveyard for Dead Computers
text: In Sunday’s New York Times Magazine, the photographer Pieter Hugo documented the garbage dumps in Ghana, where computers are burned and ripped apart for their rich minerals.

headline: When Repeat Injuries Can’t Dim an Athlete’s Passion
text: When Dr. Michael Joyner, an exercise researcher at the Mayo Clinic, heard I’d gotten a second stress fracture, high on my fibula, less than two years after recovering from my first one, in a metatarsal bone in my foot, he sent me some advice by e-mail.

headline: Old Battle Rejoined Over Michelangelo’s ‘David’
text: A longstanding tug of war has resumed between the city of Florence and the Italian state over Michelangelo’s “David,” after a report by state-appointed lawyers was made public. The document argues that although the statue was commissioned by the Florentine Republic in 1501, Italy became the rightful titleholder after its unification in the 19th century.

headline: Risks: A Warning on Asthma and Acetaminophen
text: Young teenagers who use acetaminophen even once a month develop asthma symptoms more than twice as often as those who never take it, a large international study has found. And frequent users also had more eczema and eye and sinus irritation.

headline: Resources on Service Learning and Community Service
text: Your school, club, community group or family may be considering a service learning program, or perhaps you’re already part of a robust service initiative. In the spirit of giving, here are useful New York Times resources for complementing your efforts.

headline: Cover Boy
text: As you’ve probably heard by now, Jonathan Franzen is on the cover of this week’s Time magazine, the first living novelist in a decade to be so honored.

headline: Cover Boy
text: As you’ve probably heard by now, Jonathan Franzen is on the cover of this week’s Time magazine, the first living novelist in a decade to be so honored.

headline: The New Droid2 Looks Familiar
text: The Droid2 inspires a sense of familiarity. Physically, it is almost identical in size and weight to the first Droid released nine months ago, and has the same 3.7-inch screen and a slide-out keyboard configuration. But there is a big difference under the hood. The new Droid is almost twice as fast, and promises longer battery life.

headline: On Our Radar: The Meatless Hot Dog
text: Rating meatless hot dogs. “A lot of the meat analogs have come a long way,” one taste tester says. [Grist]

headline: Brushes With Scandal May Inform Koch’s Reform Effort
text: The parking meter bandits of 1988, a group of collection agents who pilfered thousands of dollars from the city, taught Edward I. Koch the critical lesson of corruption.

headline: Bangladesh Arrests 21 After Rallies
text: MUMBAI, India  The police in Bangladesh have arrested three garment industry labor leaders and 18 other people on charges that they organized and participated in violent protests last month.

headline: For Hotels, Eco-Friendly Ideas Await a Friendlier Economy
text: Hotels eager to satisfy the growing desire of business travelers for eco-friendly lodging are finding that their environmental ambitions have run headlong into the harsh realities of the recession.

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Richard Olney
text: If you were lucky enough to be invited to Richard Olney’s for lunch in the dry and scratchy hills outside Sollies-Toucas, north of Toulon in Provence, two things were certain: That you would have a meal you would never forget, and that he would greet you in his herb and vegetable garden in a pair of beat-up espadrilles, a ravaged shirt left completely unbuttoned and a tiny excuse for a bathing suit. Because he was always running back and forth between the garden and kitchen to check on whatever was on the hob, a dish towel hung in his waistband.

headline: Museum Acquires Storied Trove of Performances by Jazz Greats
text: For decades jazz cognoscenti have talked reverently of “the Savory Collection.” Recorded from radio broadcasts in the late 1930s by an audio engineer named William Savory, it was known to include extended live performances by some of the most honored names in jazz  but only a handful of people had ever heard even the smallest fraction of that music, adding to its mystique.

headline: Jazz Lost and Found
text: Audio excerpts from “The Savory Collection,” considered one of the greatest finds in the history of jazz.

headline: Barclays Agrees to Pay $298 Million for Violating U.S. Trade Law
text: Barclays has agreed to pay $298 million to settle accusations that the bank facilitated illegal transfers of dollars for countries that were sanctioned by the United States including Iran, Cuba, Libya, Sudan and Myanmar, according to documents filed Monday in federal district court in Washington.

headline: What About Clean Coal?
text: An interview with Don Blankenship.

headline: Moose Arthritis
text: A study of arthritis in moose leads to new information about human nutrition in childhood.

headline: On Being Vilified By Environmentalists
text: An interview with Don Blankenship.

headline: On Wind Turbines and Jobs
text: An interview with Don Blankenship.

headline: Jet Crash on Colombian Island Kills 1
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  A downpour was drenching the island of San Andrés, an idyllic speck of Colombian territory in the Caribbean. The Boeing 737-700, operated by the Colombian airline Aires, had taken off from Bogotá shortly after midnight, and it was 1:49 a.m. on Monday when passengers stirred awake as the jetliner prepared to land.

headline: Afghan Leader Sees Plan to Ban Private Guards
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai is planning to sign a decree this week ordering the disbanding of all private security forces by the end of the year, his spokesman said Monday.

headline: Uh-Oh Canada?
text: My trip yesterday was actually to Niagara Falls, to talk to the Canadian Bar Association. In preparation, I did some homework; and to be honest, I came away a little less sanguine about Canada than I started.

headline: Community Opposition
text: An Interview with Don Blankenship

headline: Alternative Energy
text: An interview with Don Blankenship.

headline: Bloomberg Is Supporting Sestak in Pennyslvania
text: Representative Joe Sestak, the Pennsylvania Democrat trying to keep a Senate seat in his party’s hands this November, is scheduled on Tuesday to receive the backing of a prominent independent: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York.

headline: Hazards: Nipple Piercings Add to Risk of Abscesses
text: Nipple piercings may be in fashion these days, but women who have them are at much higher risk for developing painful, recurrent breast abscesses, a new study reports.

headline: Old Maxim of Fertility and Stress Is Reversed
text: Even as more and more fertility clinics adopt stress-management programs like yoga, cognitive therapy and biofeedback, the role of stress in infertility remains a matter of debate. Some experts still recite an old maxim: while infertility undoubtedly causes stress, stress does not cause infertility.

headline: Ford’s New Mustang Boss 302: A Bit Like the Old Boss
text: Of all the high-performance Fords, past and present, perhaps none is more loved by fans of the brand than the 1969-70 Boss 302 Mustang. Engineered to compete in the Trans Am series, the Boss 302 won the championship in 1970. The street version was similar to the race-going machine, and it was embraced by those for whom a lot of performance makes up in full for a bit of discomfort and inconvenience.

headline: The Rigors of a Globe-Trotting Shopper and Reluctant Bag Checker
text: I SPEND a lot of months out of the year away from home. I’ve traveled to 16 countries for the Sundance Channel show, “Man Shops Globe.” Also, I do a lot of trips to markets in France, the United Kingdom, Belgium and the Netherlands for my work with Anthropologie.

headline: The Consequences of Mountaintop Removal
text: An interview with Don Blankenship.

headline: In First Request, Blagojevich Jury Asks for Tusk Testimony
text: CHICAGO – Jurors deliberating in the federal corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, told the judge Monday that they wanted to review the testimony of one witness: Bradley Tusk, a former deputy governor for Mr. Blagojevich.

headline: Out of Grief Sprouts a Life-Saving Legacy
text: You don’t have to be rich, famous or even an adult to leave a memorable legacy that can change lives.

headline: Dynegy and the Evolving Nature of Deals
text: “It’s not a suicide pact. It’s a merger agreement.”

headline: Governors Island: Some Final Thoughts
text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asks Edward Rothstein in the Weekend section on Friday. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On ArtsBeat, critics from several disciplines will be discussing the island’s role as a cultural destination. Check back for regular updates throughout Monday and share your own thoughts about the island too. Read previous entries here.

headline: Coping With Crises Close to Someone Else’s Heart
text: Over the last few years, my family has weathered our share of crises. First our younger daughter was hospitalized for a week with Kawasaki disease, a rare condition in children that involves inflammation of the blood vessels, and spent several months convalescing at home. Soon after she recovered, our older daughter landed in the hospital with anorexia, which proved to be the start of a yearlong fight for her life.

headline: General McChrystal Accepts Teaching Post at Yale
text: WASHINGTON – Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the top officer in Afghanistan relieved of command for comments to Rolling Stone magazine, has been appointed a senior fellow in global affairs at Yale University beginning this autumn.

headline: 100 Years of Baseball in Birmingham
text: Rickwood Field, in Birmingham, Ala., is touted as America’s oldest baseball park. It was built on Aug. 18, 1910, and will celebrate its 100th anniversary this year.

headline: Patterns: Medicare Coverage Drives Antibiotic Use
text: Now that older people have prescription drug coverage from Medicare, they are using more antibiotics, a new study has found.

headline: Birmingham Ballpark Lives to See 100
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Mitch Earnest, an 18-year-old catcher from Decatur, Ga., was reaching for his bat to go out on deck at Rickwood Field when he was told Babe Ruth also reached for his bat in this same place during an exhibition game. Earnest paused for a moment to consider his next at-bat.

headline: Fed Adopts Rules Meant to Protect Home Buyer
text: The Federal Reserve on Monday moved to end a controversial lending practice that had helped propel the housing boom to unsustainable heights and then accelerated its collapse.

headline: White-Shoe Shuffle
text: White leather lace-ups, as recently worn by Mark Ronson, are associated with mimes and ’80s tribute bands, but they actually have a stylish past. In the early 1970s, Serge Gainsbourg, France’s patron saint of cool, was looking for “gloves for his feet,” and his sex-kitten lover Jane Birkin turned him on to white Repetto jazz shoes. The shoes became one of Gainsbourg’s signature flourishes, with the singer famously going through 30 pairs a year until his death in 1991.

headline: Questions Linger as Shrimp Season Opens in Gulf
text: ABOARD THE KRISTY MISTY, in the Gulf of Mexico  Well before dawn on Monday, Nicky Alfonso set out down Bayou Terre aux Boeufs in his 38-foot shrimping boat, heading for open water.

headline: Killer Trade Deficits
text: I agree with everything this NYT editorial has to say about the economics of widening international imbalances. Where I disagree is on the issue of negotiating strategy. My colleagues believe that we should lecture the Chinese on what a bad thing they’re doing, but not actually threaten sanctions, lest we start a trade war. My belief is that this gets us nowhere.

headline: Where All That Money Went: The H.P. Case
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: New Law Allows Sex Trafficking Victims to Clear Names
text: Gov. David A. Paterson has signed a law that will allow victims of sex trafficking to clear prostitution convictions from their criminal records. Advocates for sex workers said the bill, signed on Friday, is the first of its kind. It allows an individual to have a conviction vacated if she was forced into prostitution, and it also applies to related crimes like loitering.“It’s a hard reality that trafficked people are often arrested, convicted, and released without the justice system realizing what’s really going on,” Sienna Baskin, co-director of the Sex Workers Project at the Urban Justice Center, which helped write the bill, said in a statement.

headline: Cancer: Expert Panel Calls for Aggressive Fight Against Cancer in Poorer Countries
text: A panel of prominent figures in global health called on Monday for an end to the assumption that cancer is a “disease of the rich” and for both poor and donor countries to place the same emphasis on fighting it that they now do on infectious diseases like AIDS and malaria.

headline: German Pop Singer on Trial for Concealing H.I.V. Status From Sexual Partners
text: A German singer charged with causing grievous bodily harm to a man who contracted H.I.V. after having unprotected sex with her admitted in court on Monday that she had concealed the fact that she was infected with the virus from the man, and from two other sexual partners.

headline: Ex-Israeli Soldier’s Photos Condemned
text: TEL AVIV  An Israeli woman who completed her military service last year posted photographs of herself from the army posing with blindfolded and bound Palestinian prisoners under the title “The Army ... The Most Beautiful Time of My Life,” producing enraged commentary on the Internet and condemnation from the military.

headline: New York Send-Off | Line-Reading in Central Park
text: Rain slicker? Check.

headline: Analysts: Lilly Faces Growing Financial Pressure
text: The Indianapolis drugmaker Eli Lilly & Company is facing growing pressure from Wall Street to make a deal with another company as it heads toward the biggest “patent cliff” in the industry.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: No, this is not another picture of hungry flood victims in Pakistan. Shakil Adil of The Associated Press has created something different: a picture of increasingly frenzied desperation. It’s not in the outstretched hands at the center of the frame. It’s what’s in the right hand of the solitary figure at the right edge of the picture. Take another look.

headline: Fringe Festival Journal: ‘South Pathetic’
text: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival began over the weekend. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors.

headline: Choosing a Coach: Maradona Over Bradley?
text: Diego Maradona — through his agent — offered his managerial services to Aston Villa, citing his love of the English countryside and the country’s respect for privacy as good reasons the English Premier League club should hire him. And if that isn’t enough to persuade Villa’s owner, Randy Lerner, the agent points out: Maradona is available.

headline: Drilling Permits for Deep Waters Face New Review
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Monday that it would require significantly more environmental review before approving new offshore drilling permits, ending a practice in which government regulators essentially rubber-stamped potentially hazardous deepwater projects like BP’s out-of-control well.

headline: When Friends Disappear During a Health Crisis
text: During times of crisis, we often depend on our friends for support. Now, psychologists are just beginning to explore why some friends seem to disappear during difficult times, unable to cope with other people’s trauma.

headline: The Great Wellfleet Croissant Invasion
text: Not since the Great Portland Gale of 1898, the Pendleton Shipwreck of 1952 or perhaps the Red Tide Scare of 2005 has Cape Cod been in such a tizzy. This time, however, the calamity is entirely man-made, flaky and delicious. The Great Wellfleet Croissant Invasion of 2010 has divided communities, polarized families and added substantial girth to throngs of well-heeled summer tourists.

headline: A Wild Man Grows Up (Just Enough)
text: SHANE SMITH, a founder of Vice, the streetwise, testosterone-fueled culture and fashion magazine, still chugs canned American beer. He still listens to Bad Brains. And he still favors tattered Vans skateboard shoes and black T-shirts. That much is the same.

headline: Switch Sports After Injury? Never!
text: In today’s Personal Best column, Gina Kolata writes about her own passion for running and why some athletes, including herself, stubbornly refuse to switch sports, even after repeat injuries.

headline: Solid Sound Festival
text: The music and arts festival at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams, Mass., was curated by the indie rock band Wilco.

headline: Apple Hires Expert on Mobile Payments
text: Over the last decade Apple has expanded into a number of industries besides computers, including music, mobile phones, movies and books. Now Apple could be going after something else: cash.

headline: Step 1: Post Elusive Proof. Step 2: Watch Fireworks.
text: The potential of Internet-based collaboration was vividly demonstrated this month when complexity theorists used blogs and wikis to pounce on a claimed proof for one of the most profound and difficult problems facing mathematicians and computer scientists.

headline: A Flight Attendant’s Lot Is Not a Happy One
text: RIGHT after a JetBlue flight attendant, Steven Slater, plunged down an emergency chute last week with beers in hand, Rene Foss started thinking about working the escapade into a song for the next edition of her musical revue, “Around the World in a Bad Mood.”

headline: A Quest to Make the Morgan Seaworthy
text: MYSTIC, Conn. — The shipbuilders are long dead, their knowledge gone. The shipyard no longer exists. No blueprints survive, nor ship’s models.

headline: Restoring the Last Wooden Whaler
text: Restorers are spending $10 million to make the world’s last surviving wooden whaling vessel, the Charles W. Morgan, seaworthy.

headline: Do Arts at Governors Island Need Governing?
text: “What kind of culture develops on an island?” asked Edward Rothstein in Friday’s Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan’s shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, Mr. Rothstein wrote, which he characterized as eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On the ArtsBeat blog, New York Times critics from several disciplines discussed the island’s role as a cultural destination: Mr. Rothstein, a cultural critic at large; Jon Pareles, the chief pop music critic; Charles Isherwood, a theater critic; Alastair Macaulay, the chief dance critic; and Ken Johnson, an art critic. Here are excerpts from the conversation; the full text is at nytimes.com/artsbeat.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Broadway Danny Rose’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Pick, A. O. Scott looks at Woody Allen‘s show-biz comedy “Broadway Danny Rose,” starring Mr. Allen as a washed-up talent agent.

headline: History Repeats Itself: Antigone, Then Snooki
text: In “Long Story Short,” a snappy recap of human civilization as seen through the skeptical eyes of a standup comic, Colin Quinn traces the roots of various contemporary phenomena, including the economic crisis, the Middle East conflict and “Jersey Shore,” back through the centuries to the Greeks and beyond.

headline: Wilco Builds a Festival for Itself
text: NORTH ADAMS, Mass. — In the final stretch of the Solid Sound Festival on Sunday, under light rainfall and a darkening sky, Jeff Tweedy augmented his solo acoustic set with reinforcements. He enlisted members of the Autumn Defense, Pronto and the Nels Cline Singers, three very different groups that had played here over the previous three days. Or, to put it another way, he was leading a slightly modified version of Wilco, his steadfastly ambitious rock band. The patrons of this first-time event, held at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, were primed to appreciate the distinction.

headline: Icahn Pushes Ahead With Energy Investments
text: The filings are out and it looks like the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has set his sights on four energy companies, two of which are heavily involved in exploration and production: Anadarko Petroleum and Chesapeake Energy. Mr. Icahn’s stakes in these companies could mean that he is thinking about a major shakeup in their capital structures.

headline: Mets’ Rodriguez Injured Thumb in Altercation
text: The Mets’ 2010 season continued in its downward spiral on Monday with the disclosure that Francisco Rodriguez tore a ligament in his right thumb last week while he was in an altercation with the father of his common-law wife.

headline: Pairings: Poblano Peppers With Smoky Filling and Mezcal Salsa
text: You do not have to serve smoked salmon with Scotch or fried chicken with bourbon. But mezcal is so deeply rooted in the heart of Mexico that whatever you serve alongside begs for chilies and cilantro at the very least.

headline: Mezcal, Tequila’s Smoky, Spicy Cousin
text: I FEEL almost as if I have to whisper my feelings about mezcal. It is so immersed in legend and colorful misrepresentation that it’s a shame to spoil it all with truth. And yet the truth can be so richly rewarding that I may as well shout it out.

headline: Old Battle Rejoined Over Michelangelo’s ‘David’
text: A longstanding tug of war has begun again between the city of Florence and the Italian state over Michelangelo’s “David,” after a report by state-appointed lawyers was made public. The document argues that although the statue was commissioned by the Florentine Republic in 1501, Italy became the rightful titleholder after its unification in the 19th century. At stake are both pride of ownership and millions of dollars in annual ticket sales. Florence’s mayor, Matteo Renzi, sought to rebut the claim, saying, according to news reports, that a decree issued shortly after unification granted the city ownership of the building where “David” was displayed. The national government’s lawyers replied that the decree made no mention of the statue itself. With its representation of Goliath’s slayer, “David” was a symbol of the freedom and autonomy of the Florentine Republic and an important source of civic pride. At a press conference on Monday, Mayor Renzi declared that “Michelangelo’s ‘David’ belongs to Florence  there are no legal doubts, all the documents confirm it.” Italy’s culture minister, Sandro Bondi, meanwhile, issued a statement on Monday describing the battle over the statue as “absurd and inopportune.”

headline: Conductor Arrested on Child Support Charge
text: En route to Alice Tully Hall from Copenhagen, the conductor Paul Hillier made an unusual detour before leading the ensemble Ars Nova Copenhagen at Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival on Friday night: He spent part of last week in a New Jersey jail after he was arrested on an outstanding warrant for criminal nonpayment of child support. The Oregonian reported that Mr. Hillier, above, who was born in England and lives in Denmark, was indicted on Aug. 5 by an Oregon grand jury on four felony counts of criminal nonsupport for failing to make approximately $90,000 in payments for his two daughters who live in that state. He was apprehended at Newark International Airport on Wednesday and taken to Essex County Jail. In addition to serving as the chief conductor of Ars Nova Copenhagen, Mr. Hillier has also been the principal conductor of the Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir and won a Grammy Award in February. The Oregonian reported that Mr. Hillier wired the money to an account in the Support Enforcement Division of Oregon’s Multnomah County. Jennifer James, a deputy district attorney there, said Mr. Hillier has “been fairly cooperative, once we got his attention.”

headline: Golf Is Good to CBS
text: “60 Minutes,” “Big Brother” and professional golf lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday. The network’s afternoon coverage of the P.G.A. Championship ran well into the start of prime time, earning CBS more than 10 million viewers from 7 to approximately 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. NBC ranked a distant second place on the night, with three back-to-back episodes of “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” which averaged 5 million viewers from 8 to 11. ABC was third with low ratings for “The Gates” at 10 (2.6 million), while Fox finished in fourth place with comedy reruns.

headline: Lawyer Fights Back Against DC Comics
text: Marc Toberoff, the lawyer who has represented heirs to the Superman creators Jerome Siegel and Joseph Shuster in their fight to reclaim copyrights from DC Comics, a division of Warner Brothers Entertainment, asked a court in Los Angeles on Friday to dismiss the complaint filed against him personally last May in connection with the long-running legal battle. In its complaint, DC Comics claimed that Mr. Toberoff had manipulated the heirs for years in an effort to capture a huge share of the copyrights for himself. In asking the United States District Court for the Central District of California to dismiss the complaint, Richard B. Kendall, a lawyer for Mr. Toberoff, called it “an absolutely meritless attack” that was meant to undermine Mr. Toberoff’s relationship with the Siegel and Shuster heirs in the wake of a previous victory in court over DC Comics. A hearing in the case is set for Oct. 18.

headline: Theater News
text: Amanda Peet will join David Duchovny in MCC Theater’s production of Neil LaBute’s “Break of Noon,” the theater announced on Monday. Mr. Duchovny was previously slated to play a man who sees the face of God during an office shooting; Ms. Peet will do double duty playing that man’s wife, Ginger, and Ginger’s cousin, Jesse. The play, to be directed by Jo Bonney, will begin previews at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Oct. 28 and open on Nov. 15; its limited run is scheduled through Dec. 12. MCC Theater’s second production of the 2010-11 season will pair Laurie Metcalf (“Roseanne,” “Brighton Beach Memoirs”) with her “November” director, Joe Mantello for the world premiere of Sharr White’s “Other Place.” In this thriller, Ms. Metcalf will play a woman who finds herself at the center of a mystery just as she hits upon a potential breakthrough in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. It is to begin at the Lortel on March 10 and open on March 28, with a limited run through April 24. ... Mos Def, Jeffrey Wright and Paul Dano are among the cast members in Lincoln Center Theater’s coming production of John Guare’s play “A Free Man of Color,” the theater announced on Monday. Mr. Guare’s drama, set in New Orleans in the early 19th century, will be directed by George C. Wolfe. Previews begin on Oct. 21, with opening night set for Nov. 18 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

headline: Eastwood’s ‘Hereafter’ To Close Film Festival
text: Clint Eastwood’s “Hereafter,” a movie about the intertwining experiences of people who have dealt with death, near-death and the afterlife, will be the closing-night selection of the New York Film Festival, on a program that will also feature new works by Jean-Luc Godard, Mike Leigh and Kelly Reichardt, among other directors, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Monday. “Hereafter,” directed by Mr. Eastwood, above, and written by Peter Morgan (“The Queen,” “Frost/Nixon”), chronicles the gradual connections of an American psychic (played by Matt Damon), a French journalist (Cécile de France) who has a brush with death in the 2004 tsunami and a London schoolboy who loses his twin brother (Frankie and George McLaren). It is scheduled to be shown on Oct. 10 at Alice Tully Hall. The festival will also present Mr. Godard’s “Film Socialisme,” Mr. Leigh’s “Another Year” and Ms. Reichardt’s “Meek’s Cutoff,” among the 25 additional main-slate features that were announced, as well as programs on the movies of Masahiro Shinoda, Fernando de Fuentes and Olivier Assayas. The festival, which starts on Sept. 24, has announced that it will open with David Fincher’s “Social Network,” and its centerpiece film will be Julie Taymor’s adaptation of “The Tempest.”

headline: A Tribute to Alban Berg and His Viennese Influences
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — “My job tonight is to allay any residual fears you might have,” the conductor Leon Botstein said from the stage of the Sosnoff Theater at the Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College here on Friday night.

headline: Mos, Jeffrey Wright To Reunite in New Guare Play
text: Lincoln Center Theater’s production of John Guare’s play “A Free Man of Color” will reunite Mos Def, who is going by the name Mos for this production, and Jeffrey Wright, who appeared together in the 2002 Broadway production of Suzan-Lori Parks’s “Topdog/Underdog.”

headline: Cultures Converge on Battery Park
text: With singular generosity, the Battery Dance Company each summer presents a free outdoor festival, giving most of the attention to guest troupes. These Downtown Dance Festivals have included weekend performances under the trees in Battery Park. Few New York settings are lovelier: The stage and most of the audience are in shade, with marvelously dappled sunshine through the leaves; the audience sees the light over the Hudson shimmering behind the dancers.

headline: Beyond the Congo: Fishing for Different Species in Smaller Rivers and Tributaries
text: Saturday, Aug. 14

headline: Barclays to Pay $298 Million for Violating Trade Law
text: 8:09 p.m. | Updated Barclays has agreed to pay nearly $300 million to settle accusations that the bank facilitated illegal transfers of dollars for countries that were sanctioned by the United States including Iran, Cuba, Libya, Sudan and Myanmar, according to documents filed Monday in Federal District Court in Washington, The New York Times’s John Eligon reports.

headline: Bookstore Arrives, and Sides Are Taken
text: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, N.Y.  Ever since Books & Books opened its doors on Main Street here last month, it has missed out on some of the adulation usually reserved for new independent bookstores in the age of Amazon.

headline: Mets’ Closer Facing Season-Ending Surgery
text: HOUSTON  The Mets came to Texas to escape. They had scored all of nine runs in a six-game homestand, had endured the humiliation of watching their top reliever marched in handcuffs into a Queens courthouse and had become irrelevant bystanders in the battle for playoff spots.

headline: Israeli Bloggers Copy Controversial Images From Facebook
text: Israeli bloggers moved quickly on Monday to make copies of a pair of controversial images posted on Facebook by a former Israeli soldier — showing her posing next to blindfolded Palestinian prisoners — before she blocked access to her photographs, which were shown and discussed on Israeli television before the day was out.

headline: From Driving a Maserati to Sleeping on Dad’s Sofa
text: “Big Lake,” a comedy beginning on Tuesday night, counts among its producers Will Ferrell and his creative partner Adam McKay, who with virtually each project seem to hoist a big, frosty cold one to the American thirst for schadenfreude and say, “Drink up.” Together they have given us “Talladega Nights,” “Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy” and the HBO comedy “Eastbound & Down,” among other ventures, which all involve the pummeling of egomaniacal jackasses into so many bits of ground chuck. In the best-case scenarios, we see the entitled moron’s descent all the way down, but “Big Lake” (Comedy Central) starts at the bottom after the beating is over and most of the fun is long gone.

headline: Vaccination Is Steady, but Pertussis Is Surging
text: For four weeks, my 11-year-old daughter has been coughing. It is not your run-of-the-mill summer cold, but a violent, debilitating cough that takes over her body, usually at night.

headline: Drawing Room Drama
text: Behind a bright green gate on a tiny street in Paris sits a magical pink house. A fig tree dominates the summer garden. The winter garden, across a narrow gravel walk, is anchored by a pine tree.

headline: Letting a Flying Hairy Arm Take It Away
text: Following a dedication page that offers his fifth novel to the memory of Kurt Vonnegut  implicitly announcing as his goal to employ Vonnegut’s shades of dark comedy and fluorescent farce  Rick Moody turns things over in “The Four Fingers of Death” to one Montese Crandall. This character is not the narrator of the novel but the “author” of a slab of sci-fi horror hack work coextensive with it. This is to say that Mr. Moody here undertakes an extended impersonation of a long-winded ham, convincingly so.

headline: Steep Drop Seen in Circumcisions in U.S.
text: Despite a worldwide campaign for circumcision to slow the spread of AIDS, the rate of circumcision among American baby boys appears to be declining.

headline: Cohen Moves Deeper Into Oil
text: Carl C. Icahn was certainly not alone on Monday in disclosing his growing interest in the oil industry. Steven A. Cohen, left, the prominent hedge fund manager, has also raised his bets on oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and BP — even though the latter has taken a severe hit to its finances and reputation because of the oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: LISTENING. To the Patient (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Andrew Roth, American-Born Chronicler of British Politics, Dies at 91
text: LONDON  Andrew Roth, a New York-born journalist with left-wing ideals who fled the McCarthy-era America of 1950 for a new life as a meticulous and often abrasive chronicler of the foibles, business links and private lives of British politicians, died in London on Thursday. He was 91.

headline: Felony Indictment in Chess Federation Case Is Dismissed
text: A felony indictment against a member of the United States Chess Federation, the game’s governing body, has been dismissed. But the defendant still faces 34 misdemeanor counts for allegedly breaking into the e-mail account of a former federation board member.

headline: Nonprofits Review Technology Failures
text: WASHINGTON — At a gathering last month over drinks and finger food, a specialist at the World Bank related the story of how female weavers in a remote Amazonian region of Guyana had against all odds built themselves a thriving global online business selling intricately woven hammocks for $1,000 apiece.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug 16
text: Images from the day in sports, including a look at the Youth Games in Singapore.

headline: G.O.P. Seizes on Mosque Issue Ahead of Elections
text: WASHINGTON  Republican Congressional candidates on Monday intensified efforts to inject the divide over construction of an Islamic center near ground zero into the midterm campaigns while the Senate’s top Democrat said he objected to the mosque being built there.

headline: Judge Seeks More Data on Citigroup Settlement
text: A federal judge said Monday that she was not ready to approve the government’s $75 million settlement with Citigroup of charges that it misled investors about billions of dollars in potential losses from subprime mortgages, The Associated Press reports.

headline: The Ontology of Plagiarism: Part Two
text: The huge number of negative comments on my column arguing that plagiarism is more a professional than a moral infraction fall mainly into two groups: those who criticize me for an argument I don’t make and those who offer as a rebuttal an argument I do make.

headline: The Appendix, Inner Beauty and Listening to the Patient (4 Letters)
text: When the Appendix Calls

headline: A One-Man Show Rich With Southern Flavor, and Humidity
text: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival began this weekend. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors:

headline: Energy Costs Push Prices Up Sharply in Europe
