text: Higher energy prices drove inflation in the euro area to an annual rate of 1.7 percent in July, the highest level in 20 months but still within the range considered acceptable by the European Central Bank.

headline: Looking This Way and That, and Learning to Adapt to the World
text: The infants and toddlers resemble cyborgs as they waddle and crawl around the playroom with backpacks carrying wireless transmitters and cameras strapped to their heads. Each has one camera aimed at the right eye and another at the field of view, and both send video to monitors nearby. When the video feeds are combined, the result is a recording in which red cross hairs mark the target of a child’s gaze.

headline: A Calcium Quandary
text: Q. I’ve been told that vitamin C and calcium from milk cancel each other’s benefits if taken together. So how come orange juice is fortified with calcium?

headline: In New Jersey, a Park’s Spring Water Is Prized. Polluted, Too.
text: MILLBURN, N.J.  In a densely populated place, people prize their slivers of nature and links to a pastoral past. Which might explain why David Giannakopoulos disregarded the signs, rounded the fence, stuck his head under a rock and took a drink.

headline: Ex-ConAgra Unit Settles With U.S. Over Artificial Oil Trade
text: WASHINGTON  As 2007 came to a close, oil prices were hovering close to $100 a barrel and many analysts were expecting prices could exceed that in the new year.

headline: A Reason for Diversity of Ants May Not Hold
text: There are more than 300 species of nocturnal velvet ants (actually wasps that resemble ants) in the Southwestern deserts of the United States. The easy explanation for the incredible diversification is that as the Rocky Mountains emerged millions of years ago, multiple, isolated deserts formed, leaving ample opportunity for speciation to occur. But the easy explanation may not be the right one.

headline: To Enjoy Champagne, Treat It Like Beer, Study Says
text: Champagne may be a symbol of life at the top, but it is best poured into a tilted glass just like that other sparkling beverage, the plebeian beer, according to a new study.

headline: Wide Variety of Breeds Born of Few Genes
text: Spaniels have notably floppy ears, basset hounds have extremely short legs, and St. Bernards are large and big boned. Not to mention Chihuahuas.

headline: An Indian Church’s Colorful Tribute to Mary
text: WEST SAYVILLE, N.Y. — Without doubt, many more people line the sidewalks to see the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in Manhattan than to watch the St. Mary Malankara Indian Orthodox Church’s annual Assumption Day Parade, which began here on Sunday with the usual blowing of the kumbu horn and the dancing of the koladi by the congregation’s teenage girls, dressed in saris and banging sticks.

headline: No Charges Against DeLay in Abramoff Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  Tom DeLay, a Texas Republican and former House majority leader who resigned from Congress in June 2006 in a spectacular fall from political power, will not face federal corruption charges over his dealings with the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff.

headline: Judge Not Ready to Decide on Citigroup Settlement With S.E.C.
text: Citigroup failed on Monday to win a judge’s approval to pay $75 million to settle claims by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the bank misled investors by understating subprime-related holdings.

headline: For Knicks’ Dolan, a Fine Line Between Contrarian and Chaos
text: It has been four long years since James L. Dolan issued his “significant progress” edict to Isiah Thomas, with Thomas stewing alongside him, like a child being warned to make all gone with the veggies on his plate.

headline: Levels Plummet in Crucial Reservoir
text: Water levels in Lake Mead, the Colorado River reservoir, fell sharply again this summer and are nearing an elevation that would set off the first-ever official water shortage on the river, The Arizona Republic reported last week.

headline: Court Extends Stay on Allowing Gay Marriage
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal appeals court has extended a stay on same-sex marriages in California until it decides whether a ban on such unions is constitutional.

headline: Who Visits the Emergency Room? 20 Percent of Americans, Insured or Not
text: Americans, insured and not, make ample use of hospital emergency rooms: One out of every five visited an E.R. at least once in 2007, the latest year for which the National Center for Health Statistics has data.

headline: P.G.A. Draws a Line in the Sand
text: It is not every day that someone loses a golf tournament and becomes the nation’s most popular player overnight. But Dustin Johnson, denied a chance to win the P.G.A. Championship on Sunday because he accidentally violated a rule, appears to suddenly have the biggest fan club in the sport.

headline: Are Poverty Tours Demeaning?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Clarion Call on Energy: Our Goals Can Be Achieved
text: To the Editor:

headline: It’s All About You, and Millions of Others
text: MORE than four decades ago, Cass Elliot advised, "Make your own kind of music." Since then, exhortations by advertisers to express individuality — by, oddly enough, consuming mass-market products — have grown louder.

headline: Arrival of the Tigers Puts Granderson’s Struggles in Sharp Relief
text: The flip side to the Johnny Damon coin Monday night was Curtis Granderson, and a legitimate question was this: Which team  the Detroit Tigers or the Yankees  is better off with the two high-profile players having switched sides?

headline: Irish Stories
text: P. O’Neill — not the former Treasury Secretary — has a great blog post about Ireland, its banks, and its mess. Strangely comforting for an American; we’re not alone, it turns out, in our policy morass.

headline: Reality of G.O.P. Rhetoric
text: To the Editor:

headline: Teenager Is Held in India After His Mother Is Killed
text: CECIL, Pa.  A teenage boy from Pennsylvania was being held in a juvenile center in India on Monday, awaiting a hearing after being accused of murdering his mother last week as they were vacationing at a luxury resort, according to news media reports in India.

headline: Bedbugs in Flight
text: To the Editor:

headline: High in the Andes, Keeping an Incan Mystery Alive
text: SAN CRISTÓBAL DE RAPAZ, Peru  The route to this village 13,000 feet above sea level runs from the desert coast up hairpin bends, delivering the mix of exhilaration and terror that Andean roads often provide. Condors soar above mist-shrouded crags. Quechua-speaking herders squint at strangers who arrive gasping in the thin air.

headline: Should New York Hold a Constitutional Convention?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reluctantly, Court Upholds a Sexual Abuse Conviction
text: Proclaiming itself bound by technicalities, a federal appeals court on Monday upheld a lower court’s decision not to overturn the conviction of Jesse Friedman, a Long Island man who served 13 years in prison for sexually abusing several children in a 1980s case later made famous by the movie “Capturing the Friedmans,” a documentary that questioned his guilt.

headline: Old West Showdown Is Revived
text: SANTA FE, N.M.  Billy the Kid is dead and buried. So is the lawman who shot him. But in this city of adobe homes and historical plaques, the past and present are sometimes as hard to separate as the Kid’s finger was from his trigger.

headline: Fans in Green and Blue Give Life to Drab Stadium
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Obama Stumps for Democrats and Economic Agenda
text: MILWAUKEE  President Obama excoriated Congressional Republicans on Monday for seeking to stymie his economic agenda, delivering a harsh critique of what he said was obstructionism that put political calculations ahead of the welfare of average Americans.

headline: Repair Made, Space Station Heads Back to Normal
text: With a replacement cooling pump successfully installed Monday, the International Space Station could be back to almost normal by Tuesday.

headline: Officer Gets More Time to Fight Discharge Under ‘Don’t Ask’ Policy
text: Lawyers for an Air Force officer facing possible discharge under the military’s ban on homosexuality, Lt. Col. Victor J. Fehrenbach, have reached an agreement with the government that will give him time to fight a discharge in federal court. Under the agreement released Monday, the Air Force said that it would not make a decision on Colonel Fehrenbach before Aug. 27 and that if it decided to discharge him, it would take no action for 21 days after notifying him of that decision. Colonel Fehrenbach asserts that discharging him under the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy would violate his rights and cause him irreparable harm.

headline: Despite H.P.’s Efforts, Spectacle of a Chief Goes On
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Even after a former actress in erotic films had accused Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, of sexual harassment, the company’s board stood behind him.

headline: The Muslims in the Middle
text: New Delhi

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Ghost Stroller Puzzles Park Slope
text: If you sit on the front stoop of your building practically every day for 25 years, the way James Rudnick has, people expect you to know what is happening on the block. So every day, people stop and ask Mr. Rudnick  Jimmy from Union Street, as he’s known here in Park Slope  what he knows about the white-painted stroller that has been padlocked to a parking sign on the corner of Union Street and Sixth Avenue since the beginning of the month.

headline: No Attempted Murder Charge for Suspect in Police Shootout
text: A man who was shot nearly two dozen times by police in Harlem on Aug. 8 was charged on Monday with criminal possession of a weapon, but avoided an attempted murder charge that had been brought by the police upon his arrest.

headline: Damon Made Stay in Bronx Memorable
text: For Johnny Damon, the list is committed to memory: Babe Ruth, Ramiro Mendoza, Mike Lowell, Eric Hinske and him. By his research, those are the five players who have won World Series rings with the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox. But really, since the others were bit players to a degree, Damon stands together with Ruth.

headline: Economy Led to Cuts in Use of Health Care
text: WASHINGTON  The economic crisis in the United States has reduced the use of routine medical care, and the cutbacks here are much deeper than in countries with universal health care systems, researchers say in a new report.

headline: Denmark Starts to Trim Its Admired Safety Net
text: COPENHAGEN  How long is too long to be paid to go without a job?

headline: Judge Orders Man Freed in a Three-Strikes Case
text: LOS ANGELES  A judge here ordered the release Monday of Gregory Taylor, who was serving a near life sentence under the state’s three-strikes law for trying to break into a soup kitchen 13 years ago.

headline: Rodriguez Leaves Game
text: Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez, who leads the major leagues in runs batted in with 97, left Monday night’s game with Detroit in the fifth inning after going hitless in his first two at-bats at Yankee Stadium.

headline: British Mining Company Buying Stake in Oil Business in India
text: Vedanta Resources, a mining company based in Britain, said Monday that it would buy a stake in an Indian energy company for $9.6 billion in a move intended to bolster India’s domestic oil production.

headline: Murder Suspect Wasn’t on Suicide Watch
text: BOSTON  There were no signs that Philip Markoff, the former medical student accused of killing a woman he met through Craigslist, was planning to commit suicide, the authorities said Monday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,211 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the death of the following Americans:

headline: A Retired Tanker, a Home and a Summertime Stage
text: On a muggy evening this month, Erik Frampton made his way to the Brooklyn waterfront to sit aboard a retired oil tanker and listen to a salty, gay sailor read from his memoir.

headline: 2 Zombies to Tolerate for a While
text: Representative Barney Frank was furious.

headline: Exclusive Golf Course Is Organic, So Weeds Get In
text: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  Standing alongside the 13th green at the Vineyard Golf Club on Martha’s Vineyard, Jeff Carlson spotted a small broadleaf weed between his feet. As the superintendent charged with maintaining the club grounds, he instinctively bent to pluck it, then stopped.

headline: No ‘Graceful Exit’
text: In his book, “The Promise,” about President Obama’s first year in office, Jonathan Alter describes a brief conversation between the president and Vice President Joe Biden that took place last November at the end of Mr. Obama’s long deliberation about what to do in Afghanistan.

headline: U.S. Said to Plan Easing Rules for Travel to Cuba
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is planning to expand opportunities for Americans to travel to Cuba, the latest step aimed at encouraging more contact between people in both countries, while leaving intact the decades-old embargo against the island’s Communist government, according to Congressional and administration officials.

headline: A Self-Analysis Likely to Surprise
Panel Urges Hudson Cleanup Be Improved and Extended
text: A cleanup of toxic chemicals in the Hudson River has failed to consistently meet performance standards and needs to undergo “substantive changes” in its next phase, a panel of independent scientists said in a draft report released on Monday.

headline: Star’s Candidacy in Haiti Puts Focus on Charity
text: CROIX DES BOUQUETS, Haiti  A few months before Wyclef Jean, the hip-hop star, declared his candidacy for president of Haiti, the representative of a struggling tent camp made a pilgrimage to the new headquarters of Mr. Jean’s charity. He arrived, hat in hand, at the eight-acre compound the charity leased after a fund-raising bonanza in response to the Jan. 12 earthquake.

headline: After Another Close Call, Transocean Changed Rules
text: Four months before the Deepwater Horizon explosion in the Gulf of Mexico, another oil rig owned by the same company faced a strikingly similar emergency in the North Sea that was contained only because its safety equipment functioned properly, according to confidential internal documents.

headline: Paying Tribute to Mary
text: The Assumption Day parade of an Indian Orthodox church on Long Island is a welcome sight in the neighborhood.

headline: Man Gets 2 ½ Years for Breaking Iran Embargo
text: An Iranian immigrant who had earned a Ph.D. from Princeton and aspired to a career in biotechnology was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Monday for violating the Iran trade embargo by using an informal money-transfer system known as hawala to move millions of dollars between the United States and Iran.

headline: With Luxury Hotel-Apartment Complex, Williamsburg Continues Its Evolution
text: Glassy towers already line the waterfront, and shiny new European cars snuggle the curbs. But the transformation of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, from gritty blue-collar redoubt to trendy nocturnal playground is taking another leap forward with the development of high-end apartments and a boutique hotel where guests can check in at the bar.

headline: Mysteries Woven Into Peru's Past
text: In a town high in the Peruvian Andes, the Quechua people guard the mysterious records of their past: ancient weavings called khipus.

headline: Haiti’s Schools
text: A plan to build a new education system in Haiti is one of the most encouraging things to emerge from the rubble of the Jan. 12 earthquake. It is expected to be endorsed at a meeting on Tuesday of the Interim Haiti Recovery Commission, the joint Haitian-international body created to guide the country’s rebuilding.

headline: Some Strauss Compositions
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We have a debut puzzle today from Prof. Michael Sharp, a new constructor from Binghamton, N.Y. I have an interview with him at the end of this post. Wait a second. Does that name sound familiar? It may well. Mr. Sharp is better known in the puzzle community by his alter ego, the blogger Rex Parker. Congratulations, Rex!

headline: The Constitution and the Mosque
text: President Obama showed his understanding of the Constitution, and his respect for the American people, last week when he defended the right of a Muslim community group to build a mosque and Islamic center two blocks north of ground zero in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Colon Cancer Prevention
text: A provocative new analysis suggests that the colonoscopies many people get to detect and eliminate colon cancer before it can kill them may be no more effective than a less invasive (and cheaper) procedure would be. The analysis, more thought-provoking than conclusive, illustrates the kind of evidence scientists will need to develop as leaders of the American health care system struggle to define which treatments are more effective  and more cost-effective  than others.

headline: Gaza: Fatal Cross-Border Clash
text: A Palestinian militant was killed and an Israeli soldier was lightly wounded Monday in cross-border clashes in the southeast Gaza Strip, the Israeli military said. The military added that Israeli troops spotted a group of militants planting explosives and shot at them, killing at least one. Palestinian medics said they were trying to reach the area in the east of Khan Younis city to search for possible casualties. The armed wing of the Islamic Jihad movement said that its fighters exchanged fire with an Israeli force that pierced through the security fence between Gaza and Israel, and that “communication with one of the gunmen had been cut.”

headline: Swallows Afield
text: By the time I’ve made the first few passes across the middle pasture, the barn swallows have found me out. They came shooting out of the hayloft when I appeared at the barn door but lost interest once I drove the tractor up the road. I make the turn into the pasture — bucket raised high to give me clearance through the gate — and send power to the big mower trailing behind me. The tractor shudders, and I shift into third, mower blades thrumming. Down go the burdock and milkweed and curly dock. Down go the thistles.

headline: Russia: Artist Had Unknown Son
text: The Russian artist Kazimir Malevich, known for painting the Black Square and espousing an artistic philosophy that held geometric forms supreme, had a previously unknown son in a town in Russia before he went on to join the avant-garde in Moscow and Paris, the chief archivist in Kursk, Margarita Litvinova, told Russian news agencies Monday. An entry in a state registry indicates Mr. Malevich was the father of a boy named Georgy, born in 1902, she said. Biographers had formerly known only of two other children, she said.

headline: Pentagon Cites Concerns in China Military Growth
text: WASHINGTON  China has increased spending on a military that is becoming larger and more effective even as Beijing has rebuffed exchanges with the Defense Department that could improve stability, according to a Pentagon study released Monday.

headline: Youth Ascendant
text: Midway through the NH Tournament in the Netherlands, the team of young players leads the more experienced group by two game points.

headline: North Korea Takes to Twitter and YouTube
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has taken its propaganda war against South Korea and the United States to a new frontier: YouTube and Twitter.

headline: Paterson Is Urged to Empower Prosecutor to Investigate Public Officials
text: If there is one thing all the candidates for attorney general this year seem to agree on, it is that the office they are seeking needs far broader powers to investigate corruption in Albany and restore public confidence in state government.

headline: Giants’ Manning Needs 12 Stitches After a Collision
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was a single hit so jarring that it shook the Giants’ franchise — and the franchise quarterback.

headline: Political Meddling Harms Public Authorities, Albany Panel Finds
text: ALBANY  Governors and mayors should stop meddling in the affairs of public authorities, according to a new report from a state task force reviewing the state’s sprawling authority system.

headline: Promising Start for Sanchez, but a Bloody One for Manning
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As backups fought for roster spots in the second half Monday night, Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez watched from the sideline with an ice bag on his left knee.

headline: Car Collectors Gather at Pebble Beach
text: The Concours d’Elegance is an alternate universe in which California car culture and the sort of people who can afford to buy, restore and maintain a 1938 Jaguar SS100 Roadster converge on a verdant fairway.

headline: Anthony May Be Next to Move
text: The N.B.A. summer that refuses to break for a news-and-speculation blackout continued Monday with an ESPN report that Carmelo Anthony is trying to force the Denver Nuggets to trade him by the start of the 2010-11 season and possibly to the Knicks.

headline: ‘Besotted’ at Pebble Auto Show, Perfectly the Norm
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — On the eve of the 60th annual Concours d'Élégance, a tribal gathering of the world’s richest and most serious vintage car collectors, Keith Bowley, an automobile restorer from the Cotswolds, was pondering the glittering rock star in his midst: a limited-edition $2.5 million Bugatti Veyron 16.4 Super Sport.

headline: As Parents Protest, Chancellor and Panel Leave
text: Angry parents protested a falloff in test scores at a meeting of a citywide education panel on Monday night, prompting its members and the schools chancellor to walk out.

headline: Bernard Knox, 95, Classics Scholar, Dies
text: Bernard M. W. Knox, an authority on the works of Sophocles, a prolific scholar and the founding director of Harvard’s Center for Hellenic Studies, died July 22 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 95.

headline: Rally Fails, but Yankees Lose More Than a Game
text: In the Yankees’ clubhouse Monday afternoon, almost three hours before the start of their game with the Detroit Tigers, the lights suddenly went out because of a power failure.

headline: Dimitrios Ioannidis, Greek Coup Leader, Dies at 87
text: Dimitrios Ioannidis, a Greek military officer who twice helped plot successful coups in his own country, and once in Cyprus, prompting the 1974 invasion of that island nation by Turkey, died in Athens on Monday. He was 87.

headline: Mets Start Trip on a Good Note, and Also Sign Their Top Pick
text: HOUSTON  On a day when the Mets grappled with the loss of closer Francisco Rodriguez to injury, the team’s management also had an eye on the future, agreeing to terms with their first-round pick just before the deadline expired at midnight Monday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Fighting Islamophobia
text: The Rev. Dr. Welton Gaddy, left, of the Interfaith Alliance and Rabbi Brad Hirschfield of Clal discuss combating Islamophobia through religious teachings.

headline: Arbiters to Hear Lawsuit Against World Chess Federation
text: A lawsuit against the World Chess Federation will be heard by arbiters at the Court of Arbitration for Sport on Sept. 15 and 16, two weeks before an election for the presidency of the federation.

headline: Aisle by Aisle, an App That Pushes Bargains
text: It’s like the most persistent sales clerk you’ve ever encountered.

headline: Word of the Day | nocturnal
text: nocturnal •\näk-ˈtər-nəl\• adjective

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: On a Day of Ryder Cup Talk, Johnson Is King
text: MILWAUKEE  About an hour south and one day removed from Whistling Straits, memories of Dustin Johnson’s P.G.A. Championship nightmare spilled over into a hotel ballroom where the United States Ryder Cup captain, Corey Pavin, sat at a dais with two of his assistants.

headline: The Death of a Building
text: Most of my work as a photographer centers on urban development in the sense of construction and expansion. But not all development succeeds, and not all construction lasts. In recent years a number of cities in Britain have recognized that some of the large public housing projects built during the postwar era have been failures; what were supposed to be new residential communities have been overtaken by crime and drug use. In several cases, particularly unmanageable buildings have even been torn down.

headline: Zimbabwe: Some Diamonds Banned
text: The Rapaport Diamond Trading Network, which says it has listings of more than 700,000 individual stones with asking prices of $4.9 billion, issued an alert Monday warning traders that it would not allow the sale of diamonds through its site that were mined in the Marange fields of Zimbabwe. Human rights groups have reported that the army committed extreme violence to seize control of the fields, then ran diamond-smuggling syndicates from there. RapNet, as the network is known, said it would expel members that knowingly offered Marange diamonds and publicly name them. Almost 900,000 carats of Marange diamonds were sold to international buyers earlier this month.

headline: Harper, Top Pick, Signs With Nationals
text: The Major League Baseball first-year player draft held little suspense two months ago, for there was no doubt that the Washington Nationals would select the slugger Bryce Harper with the first overall pick.

headline: Giants Rookie Cruz Shines With Three Touchdown Catches
text: With three touchdown receptions Monday in a 31-16 preseason win over the Jets, the Giants rookie Victor Cruz introduced himself to New York. He did so more formally moments after the game.

headline: News Quiz | August 17, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Fed Adopts Rules to Protect Home Buyers
text: The Federal Reserve on Monday moved to end a controversial lending practice that had helped propel the housing boom to unsustainable heights and then accelerated its collapse, David Streitfeld reports in The New York Times.

headline: Microlender, 1st to List in India, Trades Higher
text: The first microfinance company to sell stock to the public in India got a strong endorsement from investors on Monday when its shares closed up 10.5 percent on the first day of trading, Vikas Bajaj reports in The New York Times.

headline: Sorkin: 2 Zombies to Tolerate for a While
text: Is Washington sitting on its hands instead of addressing the problem of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac? Maybe, but sometimes it’s best to do nothing for a while, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Despite H.P.’s Efforts, Spectacle Goes On
text: Even after a former actress in erotic films had accused Hewlett-Packard‘s chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, of sexual harassment, the company’s board stood behind him, Ashlee Vance writes in The New York Times.

headline: Goldman: A Self-Analysis Likely to Surprise
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: Reshaping the Global Economy
text: WHAT is the world’s largest economy? WHAT is the second largest economy?

headline: Soros Favored Gold, May Have Sold Petrobras
text: George Soros, the billionaire investor, in the second quarter stuck with his big bet on gold but may have sold his holdings in Petróleo Brasileiro, also known as Petrobras, Reuters reported.

headline: Desperation Grows Over Pakistan Flood Damage
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  With disastrous flooding spreading yet more widely in Pakistan, reports of looting and protests over food on Tuesday deepened the sense of desperation across Punjab Province, the country’s most populous region and its agricultural hub.

headline: Rank Expected to Acquire Pactiv
text: Pactiv is poised to announce a deal to be acquired by New Zealand’s Rank Group, a person familiar with the matter told The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Deadly Suicide Attacks in North Caucasus
text: MOSCOW  A suicide bomb attack on a police checkpoint in Russia’s violence-plagued North Caucasus region on Tuesday killed at least one officer and wounded several others, investigators said.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills Dozens in Attack on Iraqi Army Recruits
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber penetrated apparently lax security measures at an Iraqi Army recruiting office in Baghdad on Tuesday, killing dozens of recruits in the first major bombing of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan. The attack comes in the fraught period just ahead of the Aug. 31 deadline for American forces to reduce their numbers.

headline: How Much Pressure Is There in ‘Girlworld’?
text: “Girls, Uninterrupted” is about a special camp where eighth and ninth grade girls spend two weeks learning “Girlworld survival tactics.” Do you think there’s a need for a course like this where you live? Do you–or did you–find the social world of girls at this age to be “harsh” and “savage,” as some describe it in this article?

headline: Buffett Filing Shows Details of Holdings
text: Berkshire Hathaway partly rebuilt the stake in Johnson & Johnson it had reduced in the last two years to raise cash for other investments, and increased its investment in Wal-Mart Stores in the second quarter.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Simplicitarian
text: Today’s word, in association with the phenomenal Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: A123’s Spin-Off, 24M, Lands $16 Million
text: 24M Technologies, a new venture spun off from the advanced battery company, A123Systems, has raised $10 million in a first round of venture financing and a $6 million grant from the U.S. Department of Energy’s ARPA-E program, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Storage Appliance Socks Away $15 Million
text: In a third round of financing, Storage Appliance has raised $15 million, VentureBeat reported. The inventor of Clickfree automated backup hardware will use the cash to expand its sales and marketing worldwide.

headline: G.M. Said to Mull ‘Cornerstone’ Sales in I.P.O.
text: General Motors is considering selling a chunk of the carmaker’s stock to institutions who would commit to buy and hold major stakes as the company prepares for its initial public offering, people familiar with the discussions told Reuters on Monday.

headline: Clouded Visions of Change in China
text: Correction Appended | There is something almost timeless about Ian Teh‘s photographs of China. And yet, they are shrouded in the darkness of the country’s burgeoning energy industry. They explore the emergence of an industrial machine.

headline: E.U. Proposes New Rules for Finance Groups
text: The European Commission proposed Monday that financial conglomerates — like those combining bank, insurance and securities businesses — be more strictly regulated.

headline: Santander and M&T Bank Said to Re-Open Talks
text: In its continuing drive for overseas growth, Santander has renewed talks to merge its American operations with New York regional lender M&T Bank, Reuters reported citing a news article  in The Financial Times.

headline: Nielsen Plans to Raise $2 Billion in I.P.O.
text: Private equity-owned Nielsen plans to raise up to $2.01 billion through an initial public offering, more than the $1.75 billion it was originally aiming for, it said in a  regulatory filing on Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: Gartmore Still Smarting Post-Rambourg
text: Gartmore, the British investment manager, said Tuesday that investors pulled cash out of its funds in the first half of the year in the wake of the departure of the star fund manager Guillaume Rambourg.

headline: Dungy Is Not a Fan of Rex Ryan and His Cursing
text: News item from Monday, via ProFootballTalk.com: On the Dan Patrick Radio show, the former Colts coach Tony Dungy said he wouldn’t hire a coach like Rex Ryan if given the chance because of his frequent use of profanity. Dungy said he had not seen the first episode of HBO’s “Hard Knocks” but had heard reports on it, and he said Commissioner Roger Goodell should do something about it.It’s hard to argue with Tony Dungy’s success as a coach and as a man, but  blasphemy can be in the eye of the beholder.

headline: Interest Rates and House Prices: A Murky World
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: At a London Gallery, Returning to the New Wave
text: A London gallery is taking a look back at one of the golden moments in cinema history — the emergence of the French New Wave — through the lens of a single photographer, Raymond Cauchetier.

headline: Victories for Jets During a Preseason Defeat
text: Nobody likes to lose, and some Jets defensive backs will no doubt cringe when they watch film of Victor Cruz’s three second-half touchdowns for the Giants on Monday night.

headline: G.I.C. to Hit the Road With $3 Billion I.P.O.
text: GIC Real Estate, the real-estate arm of the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, plans to start global roadshows in late September for an initial public offering of its overseas assets, people familiar with the situation told The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Credit Suisse Enlists Lesley Goldwasser
text: Credit Suisse, has hired Lesley D. Goldwasser to oversee a new effort to offer capital-markets financing to hedge funds along with advice and services, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Aspen to Acquire Sigma Unit
text: Aspen Pharmacare Holdings, Africa’s largest drugmaker, agreed to buy a unit of Sigma Pharmaceuticals for $806 million in cash to gain assets from a company that’s lost about half its value in the past year, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: It’s a Shark’s World After All
text: Today’s idea: Sharks and other scary nature-documentary fare are the new inarticulate action figures that export well to foreign entertainment markets.

headline: Aegon Strikes Deal to Repay State Aid
text: Aegon, the Dutch insurer, said Tuesday that it had finally reached a deal with European Union regulators on repaying 2 billion euros ($2.56 billion) in support it received from the Dutch government at the height of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Bootstrapping a Start-Up in Silicon Valley
text: Burned by a previous experience running a venture-capital-backed technology start-up, Elizabeth Charnock vowed to do things differently the next time. Despite challenges, Ms. Charnock, 43, is now making good on her promise as chief executive and founder of Cataphora, a bootstrapped, 60-employee firm that makes software used to track and analyze computer users’ online activity and communications.

headline: Q.&A.: When Entourage Meets iPad
text: Q.

headline: Ellison Jr. in Paramount Deal
text: David Ellison, pilot, actor, producer, can now add Hollywood financier to his resume. Mr. Ellison, the son of the Oracle founder and chief executive Larry Ellison,  has raised $350 million to co-finance movies with Paramount Pictures, The Los Angeles Times reported on Monday.

headline: Potash Rejects $38.6 Billion Offer From BHP
text: 2:41 p.m. | Updated with BHP’s Letter Potash, the Canadian fertilizer giant, said on Tuesday that it has rejected a $38.6 billion unsolicited merger offer from BHP Billiton, setting the stage for a potentially big takeover fight.

headline: Potash Producer Rejects Bid by BHP Billiton
text: OTTAWA — Rising demand for food from the fast-growing economies of the world has provoked a staggering $38.6 billion cash offer for a Canadian fertilizer company.

headline: Everything Old Is Hip Again
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Everything Old Is Hip Again
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Getting That Grilled Corn Feeling, Indoors
text: A couple of weeks ago, the Minimalist was about grilled corn. But city dwellers don’t always have that option, obviously.

headline: In Wal-Mart and Home Depot Results, a Worried Consumer
text: For two major retailers reporting quarterly results on Tuesday, consumers appeared to be holding back.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — Fox Business News’s Charles Gasparino is baying at the heels of the former Lehman Brothers team again, saying the S.E.C. could file charges as soon as this week.

headline: Nocturnalist | Spellbound in Brooklyn
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Eli Manning Accepts Blame for Bloody Injury
text: In the category of “Could Have Been Much, Much Worse ….”

headline: Facebook ‘Dislike’ Button Is a Scam
text: If only we could register our “dislike” of scams on Facebook.

headline: A Coal Executive Pushes Back
text: As energy executives go, few manage to stir controversy and elicit vitriol from environmentalists with as much relish as Don L. Blankenship, the mustachioed chief executive of Massey Energy, one of the largest coal companies in Appalachia.

headline: Shares Post Sharp Gains, Helped by Earnings Reports
text: Stocks rose on Tuesday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to its biggest gain in two weeks, after some good earnings from retailers and news of a $39 billion bid for the Potash Corporation.

headline: Good News for Pencil Pushers
text: Here’s my 2010 back to school wish list: a new word processor.

headline: A Drawing Tablet for the Wii
text: The versatile Wii Remote can be snapped inside a steering wheel or guitar, so why not a graphics tablet? The uDraw GameTablet ($70) is a 4 inch by 6 inch drawing tablet that rests on your lap. When used with uDraw Studio, the included disk, children can draw pictures with charcoal or opaque water colors.

headline: Producer Prices Rose in July, Easing Concerns of Deflation
text: Producer prices for finished goods rose slightly in July, the first such increase in three months, according to government data released on Tuesday, helping to ease some concerns about the possibility of deflation.

headline: NokiaLeaks
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber has killed more than 40 people in an attack on Iraqi Army volunteers lining up outside a recruiting station in central Baghdad, as The New York Times reports.

headline: Put Yourself Out There and Do Something Crazy
text: Beginning your freshman year at college is daunting. At least for me it was. I had no idea what to expect, and no words of advice comforted me or clarified the situation.

headline: Calls to Expand Attorney General’s Powers
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: The Woman Who Was Cast in ‘The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo’
text: After a walk to Trovill and back, and devoting themselves to the plain old noncommittal sex that they engaged in every few chapters when the narrative action started to flag, Mikael Blomkvist and Lisbeth Salander put on an Elvis CD. While she tried to analyze her feelings, he decided to engage her in a thought experiment.

headline: Vain Glorious | Twice as Nice
text: What: M.A.C’s new mascara, “Haute & Naughty Lash.”

headline: Study Says Brain Trauma Can Mimic A.L.S.
text: In the 71 years since the Yankees slugger Lou Gehrig declared himself “the luckiest man on the face of the earth,” despite dying from a disease that would soon bear his name, he has stood as America’s leading icon of athletic valor struck down by random, inexplicable fate.

headline: Karzai Orders Guard Firms to Disband
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai ordered a four-month phaseout of all private security companies in Afghanistan, domestic and foreign, a move that, if carried out, would create an extraordinary shift in the country’s security, likely slowing many foreign projects and potentially delaying some day-to-day military activities.

headline: Makwerekwere
text: Derogatory term used by black South Africans to describe other Africans.

headline: The Early Word: The Mosque and the Midterms
text: At least for now, the proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero in New York City is playing a role in midterm election campaigns across the country.

headline: Nasser: A Familar Name in Potash Battle
text: 4:34 p.m. | Updated The takeover battle that has erupted over Potash puts a name from 1990s corporate America back in the limelight.

headline: U.S. Circumcision Rates on the Decline
text: The rate of circumcision among American baby boys appears to be declining, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Roni Caryn Rabin reported for The New York Times that the new numbers were released without fanfare last month at the International AIDS conference in Vienna by Charbel E. El Bcheraoui, a C.D.C. researcher.

headline: Fringe Festival Journal: ‘Running’
text: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival began last weekend. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors.

headline: From the Streets To Old Trafford
text: LONDON

headline: Tuesday Reading: More People Skipping Checkups
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Mother in South Carolina Killed 2 Children, Police Say
text: A financially desperate woman in South Carolina has confessed to smothering her two children with her bare hands, then driving a car with their bodies into a river, the police said on Tuesday morning.

headline: Year After Storm, Central Park Sees Its Original Vision
text: The brevity of the storm belied its destructive strength: in just over half an hour, it felled more than 500 trees in Central Park and damaged hundreds more so badly that they had to be removed in the months that followed. That was one year ago on Wednesday.

headline: France Bars Anelka for 18 Games
text: The fallout from France’s World Cup fiasco continues: Nicolas Anelka was suspended for 18 games for his frustrated rant at the former coach Raymond Domenech.

headline: India May Soon Resolve BlackBerry Dispute
text: MUMBAI, India  Indian officials and Research In Motion, the maker of popular BlackBerry devices, appear to be making progress toward resolving a battle over the government’s ability to monitor encrypted e-mail and instant messages.

headline: Lo and Behold: Exhibition of Dylan’s Art Will Include New Paintings
text: We suppose an exhibition of paintings by Bob Dylan could depict anything from Einstein disguised as Robin Hood to a fight between Ezra Pound and T.S. Eliot – and that’s just if he sticks to the lyrics of his song “Desolation Row.” So what will visitors to Mr. Dylan’s show at the Danish National Gallery in Copenhagen actually see when it opens there next month? As Kaspar Monrad, the museum’s curator and director, told Agence France-Presse, the works will include paintings of Brazil, containing “scenes from daily life in the cities, the slums and the countryside in Brazil where Bob Dylan has been several times.”

headline: Tommy’s Tunes
text: One of the perks of being a famous fashion designer is getting to hang out with the Rolling Stones or Britney Spears and cast David Bowie in your ad campaigns. And it’s true that when it comes to his musical inspirations, Tommy Hilfiger doesn’t just talk the talk — he rocks the rock. A new book from Assouline, celebrating Hilfiger’s 25th anniversary, covers these greatest-hit moments and more. (You may not be invited to the anniversary bash, but you can tune in with his playlist, below.) Here is Hilfiger, in a photo from the book, with his wife, Dee, on their way to Kid Rock’s wedding. Shine on you crazy diamond, indeed!

headline: Notes On Koo (Wonkish)
text: I’ve just finished rereading Richard Koo’s The Holy Grail of Macroeconomics, as part of a multi-book review project. It’s one of the few books out there that talks about what you should do in the aftermath of a burst bubble — almost everyone else obsesses on the causes of the bubble, and possibly on how to prevent the next bubble, neither of which is the clear and present issue.

headline: Liquidity Preference And Loanable Funds, Revisited
text: A brief revisiting of the issues I raised more than a year ago regarding alternative views of interest rates.

headline: G.M. Recall for Seat Belts Affects 243,000 Crossovers
text: DETROIT  General Motors said Tuesday that it was recalling 243,000 large crossover vehicles to check for a problem that could prevent their rear seat belts from latching safely.

headline: A Second Frugal Budget Update
text: It’s time for a second report on the nitty-gritty of my frugal budget. During the middle five weeks of my trip, I once again averaged well under my $500-a-week (about $70 a day) maximum. Here’s how it breaks down, including transportation costs this time.

headline: Would I Please Respond?
text: I get a lot of comments along the lines of “Would you please respond to the criticism of your work in ______?”

headline: Lilly Halts Alzheimer’s Drug Trial
text: In yet another setback in efforts to treat Alzheimer’s disease, Eli Lilly & Company announced on Tuesday that it had halted development of an experimental treatment after the compound actually made patients worse in two late-stage clinical trials.

headline: Deciding to Home-School
text: Chandra Hoffman has decided to home-school her 8-year-old son Hayden once this school year ends. She certainly didn’t make this choice to fill her “free” time — her first novel, “Chosen,” is coming out this fall, and most authors clear their calendars for an event like that. But her overstuffed calendar — and her son’s — is precisely the reason she is making this choice.

headline: Israeli Ex-Soldier Defends Her Facebook Snapshots
text: Updated | 3:07 p.m. In an interview with Israeli Army radio on Tuesday, a former Israeli soldier said, “I still don’t understand what’s wrong” with photographs she posted on Facebook of herself posing next to blindfolded Palestinian detainees.

headline: Fringe Festival Journal: ‘The Hurricane Katrina Comedy Festival’
text: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival began last weekend. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors.

headline: Raoul’s
text: This is the New York place people are looking for when they walk off the campus at State and make the move east.

headline: Roman’s
Mortgage Role for U.S. Is Affirmed
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has been barraged with ideas for reworking the government’s role in housing finance, spanning the spectrum from guaranteeing all mortgage loans to eliminating all federal subsidies for homeownership.

headline: Museum Restaurants: Robert and the Wright
text: Visitors to Manhattan museums have three new places to eat.

headline: Brooklyn Cafes: Bakeri and Iris Cafe
text: Here are three possibilities for finding a satisfying bite to eat, with some of the best coffee in the city.

headline: An Israeli Finds New Meanings in a Nazi Film
text: For almost half a century, an unfinished Nazi propaganda film of the Warsaw Ghetto, simply titled “Das Ghetto” and discovered by East German archivists after the war, was used by scholars and historians as a flawed but authentic record of ghetto life. Shot over 30 days in May 1942 — just two months before deportations to the Treblinka extermination camp would begin — this hourlong silent film juxtaposed random scenes of Jews enjoying various luxuries with images of profound suffering.

headline: Quote Unquote | Suri You Must Be Kidding
text: –Katie Holmes finally explained the bizarre blue heels she wore with her red gown at the 2008 Costume Institute Gala at New York Magazine. Maybe Katie should hire a stylist who isn’t a toddler.

headline: What New New Yorkers Need to Know
text: The end (of summer) is near!

headline: American Apparel Plummets as Woes Mount
text: Shares in American Apparel, the clothing choice of urban hipsters, plummeted more than 13 percent as the company disclosed receiving a federal subpoena over its change in accounting firms.

headline: Weather Extremes and Climate Change
text: In an article on Sunday, I outlined the relationship between climate change and a rise in extreme weather. Scientists cite several statistical indicators that suggest the number of extreme events like heat waves and floods is rising. This evidence has taken on a new meaning in this summer of weather disasters, especially the floods in Pakistan and the heat wave in Russia. The United States has not been spared from weather extremes, notably deluges like the disastrous downpour in Tennessee that led to extensive flooding in May.

headline: 1933 Delage Wins Best of Show at Pebble Beach
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — A week of intense automobile worship on the Monterey Peninsula concluded with more than $100 million worth of classic cars changing hands at auctions, several new models being introduced by manufacturers and a 1933 Delage winning the coveted title as Best of Show.

headline: New Zealand Billionaire to Buy Maker of Hefty Bags
text: The Reynolds Group, part of the global packaging business owned by New Zealand’s richest man, said Tuesday that it would pay about $4.4 billion for Pactiv, the maker of the Hefty brand trash bags. With debt included, the acquisition is valued at about $6 billion.

headline: Walken and Talking: Christopher Walken Hosts ‘The Leonard Lopate Show’ for a Day
text: Listeners who tuned in Monday to “The Leonard Lopate Show” on WNYC expecting to hear its regular host got an unusual surprise: Christopher Walken, the “Deer Hunter” and “Behanding in Spokane” star, loaned his lifelong interest in broadcasting and burgeoning skills (not to mention his unmistakable stop-and-start delivery) to the program, where he acted as guest host for the afternoon, and conducted interviews with friends and colleagues like Jack O’Brien and Richard Easton; his “Behanding” co-star Zoe Kazan; the chef Lidia Bastianich and her mother, Erminia Motika; and the dancer and choreographer Jacques d’Amboise, who shared his airtime with a couple of surprise guests.

headline: Between Cuomo and Lazio, a Contentious History
Mets Look to Fight Back
text: Whatever goes wrong for you today, you can take solace in the fact that you are not the New York Mets. And if you are the New York Mets, all we have for you is at least you are not the golfer Dustin Johnson.

headline: Were Officials Wrong, or Just Doing Their Jobs?
text: An interesting phenomenon of the Dustin Johnson rules controversy is that Monday seemed to be the day that most defended Johnson and blamed the rules officials. On Tuesday, however, the tide seems to have turned in favor of crediting the rules officials with simply doing their jobs.

headline: Deng Xiaoping: A Political Wizard Who Put China on the Capitalist Road
text: Like Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai before him, Deng Xiaoping was among the small group of revolutionary elders who fought as guerrillas for the Communist cause and then dominated the leadership of the People's Republic they proclaimed on Oct. 1, 1949.

headline: New England Welcomes President Roosevelt
text: Hartford, Conn., Aug. 22 -- President Roosevelt began his tour of New England today amid scenes of remarkable enthusiasm. Landing from the yacht Syiph, at New Haven, shortly after 1 o'clock in the afternoon, his progress to this city was a continued ovation. This evening he addressed an audience of more than 5,000 persons in the Coliseum here.

headline: Gene Kelly, Dancer of Vigor and Grace, Dies
text: Gene Kelly, the dancer, actor, director and choreographer who brought a vigorous athleticism, casual grace and an earthy masculinity to the high romance of lavish Hollywood musicals, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.

headline:
Sacco and Vanzetti Put to Death Early This
Morning
text: Charlestown State Prison, Mass., Tuesday, Aug. 23 -- Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti died in the electric chair early this morning, carrying out the sentence imposed on them for the South Braintree murders of April 15, 1920.

headline: Shell Shock | Oystering on Cape Cod
text: The best-tasting oyster I will ever consume came at 8 a.m. on a warm late-July Wednesday in the middle of Wellfleet Harbor. I was attempting to remove the mollusk’s various attachments with a small Estwing drywall hammer when its shell accidentally cracked open. With few viable options, I selflessly did the humane thing: I slid it down my gullet. It was delectable — rich, creamy and absurdly fresh — and no more than 30 seconds between sea and belly.

headline:
Hurricane Rips Through Florida and Heads
Into Gulf
text: One of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes of the century slammed into South Florida yesterday, causing at least nine deaths, leveling thousands of houses south of Miami and all but destroying an Air Force base.

headline: Jorge Luis Borges, A Master of Fantasy and Fable, is Dead
text: Jorge Luis Borges, the Argentine short-story writer, poet and essayist who was considered one of Latin America's greatest writers, died yesterday in Geneva, where he had been living for three months. He was 86 years old.

headline: Tasting a Variety of Mezcals
text: As you might be able to tell by my column this week, I love mezcal. Even more so than its cousin tequila, which I love as well, mezcal is the most under-recognized great spirit on the planet.

headline: Where Geese Were Thinned, Their Population Thickens
text: Five weeks after wildlife authorities rounded up Prospect Park’s geese and gassed them, provoking the ire of residents and wildlife advocates alike, legions of new, death-defying geese continue to move into the prime real estate that is Prospect Park Lake.

headline: What We’re Reading: The Ground Zero Economy
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: TimesCast | August 17, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, Did Lou Gehrig have Lou Gehrig's disease?, faltering aid to flood ravaged Pakistan and the media's role in the debate over plans to build an Islamic center near ground zero.

headline:
Allied Forces Help French to Rid Capital of
Nazis
text: SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 25 -- The Paris radio announced late tonight that the French capital had been liberated and that the German commander had signed a document ordering his troops to cease fire immediately.

headline: Leonard Bernstein, 72, Music's Monarch, Dies
text: Leonard Bernstein, one of the most prodigally talented and successful musicians in American history, died yesterday evening at his apartment at the Dakota on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

headline: Albert Sabin, Polio Researcher, 86, Dies
text: Dr. Albert B. Sabin, the pioneering researcher on viruses and viral diseases who developed the vaccine that is the main defense against polio in the United States and much of the rest of the world, died yesterday at Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. He was 86 years old and lived in Washington.

headline: Colby Proclaims Woman Suffrage
text: Washington, Aug. 26 -- The half-century struggle for woman suffrage in the United States reached its climax at 8 o'clock this morning, when Bainbridge Colby, as Secretary of State, issued his proclamation announcing that the Nineteenth Amendment had become a part of the Constitution of the United States.

headline: On Our Radar: Pakistan’s Climate Debate
text: In Pakistan, there is rising debate over whether climate change is to blame for the country’s devastating floods. “Global warming results in catastrophic weather events,” a Pakistani geographer and water specialist says. “The recent floods are a result of climate change, undoubtedly.”  [Inter Press Service]

headline: Venus Probe Is Believed Succeeding
text: Pasadena, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Early fears that Mariner II might be woefully off course were dispelled today as the 447-pound spacecraft hurtled at 8,000 miles an hour toward the planet Venus.

headline: Lyndon Johnson, 36th President, Is Dead; Was Architect of 'Great Society' Program
text: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 22--Lyndon Baines Johnson, 36th President of the United States, died today of an apparent heart attack suffered at his ranch in Johnson City, Tex.

headline:
200,000 March for Civil Rights in Orderly
Washington Rally; President Sees Gain for
Negro
text: Washington, Aug. 28 -- More than 200,000 Americans, most of them black but many of them white, demonstrated here today for a full and speedy program of civil rights and equal job opportunities.

headline: Tolstoy Is Dead; Long Fight Over
text: ASTAPOVA, Sunday, Nov. 20.--Count Tolstoy died at 6:05 this morning.

headline: Mock Ad Sees Levi Johnston as Wasilla Mayor
text: As my colleague Brian Stelter reported last week, Levi Johnston, “a bit player in the last presidential election, is pitching a reality television show to several cable channels. He and his producers are calling the show ‘Loving Levi: The Road to the Mayor’s Office.’ That would be the mayor’s office in Wasilla, Alaska, where Sarah Palin got her start.”

headline: News Corp. Donates $1 Million to G.O.P. Governors
text: The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, contributed $1 million to the Republican Governors Association this summer, the Bloomberg news service reported this week.

headline: For the Class of 2014, No E-Mail or Wristwatches
text: Every year the administrators at Wisconsin’s Beloit College put together a list of information about incoming freshmen that is shared with the school’s professors. It’s not a list of student names, or the books they’ll need to order for class. Instead, professors are told about the “cultural touchstones that shape the lives of students entering college this fall.”

headline: Why BHP Wants Potash
text: BHP Billiton’s $38.6 billion play for Canadian fertilizer producer Potash Corporation is a bet on the ever-increasing demand for food.

headline: Mazda Recalls 215,000 Cars for Power Steering Problem
text: Mazda is recalling about 215,000 of its 2007-9 Mazda 3 and Mazda 5’s because of a steering problem that could increase the chance of a crash, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The agency says the problem is a loss of power assist which reduces “the driver’s ability to steer the vehicle as typically expected.”

headline: Franzen in Webster Groves
text: A common thread running through the fiction of Jonathan Franzen is the author’s preoccupation with the Midwest, specifically with its cities and suburbs: St. Louis (“The Twenty-Seventh City”), Evanston, Ill. (“Strong Motion”), St. Louis again (called “St. Jude”) in “The Corrections” and now St. Paul, Minn. (in “Freedom,” to be published later this month). As it happens, Franzen, though he grew up in the St. Louis suburb Webster Groves, has been an East Coaster for 30 years or more. He attended Swarthmore College (class of 1981), worked briefly in Cambridge, Mass., and is today a more or less entrenched Manhattanite.

headline: Franzen in Webster Groves
text: A common thread running through the fiction of Jonathan Franzen is the author’s preoccupation with the Midwest, specifically with its cities and suburbs: St. Louis (“The Twenty-Seventh City”), Evanston, Ill. (“Strong Motion”), St. Louis again (called “St. Jude”) in “The Corrections” and now St. Paul, Minn. (in “Freedom,” to be published later this month). As it happens, Franzen, though he grew up in the St. Louis suburb Webster Groves, has been an East Coaster for 30 years or more. He attended Swarthmore College (class of 1981), worked briefly in Cambridge, Mass., and is today a more or less entrenched Manhattanite.

headline: ‘Capeman’ Outdoors, Starring the City

The title character from “The Capeman,” Paul Simon’s musical retelling of a street-gang murder from 1959, seemed anything but at home when he showed up on Broadway in 1998 in a big, stultifying musical that seemed both overdirected and directionless. You had seldom seen a man or a show look so damned uncomfortable, and uncomfortably damned.

It would be hard for anyone’s work to eclipse the combined output of Lucian Freud and Robert Lowell. (The trio of husbands was rounded out by Israel Citkowitz, a composer and protégé of Aaron Copland.)

headline: Online-Only VIP Art Fair Set for January
text: The conventional art fair — for which collectors, dealers and other art-world professionals jet into a city for several days of looking, buying, partying and networking — is about to face a challenge. The online-only  VIP Art Fair, which will take place for the first time in January, is similarly time-limited (at a week long), but different in almost every other way from a normal fair. The “booths” are virtual; conversation (and haggling over prices) will take place by instant messaging, phone or Skype; and no one will get sore feet. The event is the brainchild of two couples, the art dealers James and Jane Cohan and the Internet entrepreneurs Jonas and Alessandra Almgren, who are neighbors and friends in Park Slope.

Not being a sports photographer, or anything close to it, I wasn’t sure what to expect. I thought the surfing would be cool, which it proved to be, but that really was the least of it.

headline: On Assimilationists and Nativists
text: There’s been a lot of criticism of my column’s suggestion that the idea of America as a distinctive culture — English-speaking, Anglo-Saxon and/or Western, Protestant and then “Judeo-Christian” — has driven both a positive assimilationism and a darker nativism over the years, and indeed that these two impulses are often intertwined. Many writers seem convinced that that assimilation and nativism aren’t intertwined at all, but rather diametrically opposed. “Nativism in the late 19th century was preoccupied with keeping foreigners out of the United States,” not assimilating them, Jamelle Bouie writes. “The pro-assimilation forces are on the progressive side, in the first camp Douthat mentions,” objects Phoebe Maltz, rather than having anything to do with cultural conservatives. “The assimilationists and the exclusionists aren’t and haven’t been the same people,” Jacob Levy tweets. And so forth.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Baghdad and Elsewhere
text: A suicide bomber struck early on Tuesday at an army recruiting office in Baghdad, Stephen Farrell reported, killing dozens in the first major bombing during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan — a period made more fraught than in previous years by the looming deadline for American forces to replace their combat mission in Iraq with a training role. Moises Saman was on the scene, photographing for The Times.

headline: Le Fooding Returns
text: This year the French are returning on Sept. 24 and 25 with the second edition of Le Grand Fooding, their tasting of food and drink to benefit Action Against Hunger. It will be held at MOMA PS 1, 22-25 Jackson Avenue (46th Avenue), Long Island City, Queens. Starting at 6 p.m. both days there will be a Champagne reception and preview of the food for those who buy $80 tickets. General admission, $50, starts at 7 p.m. The theme this year is New York vs. San Francisco, with chefs from both cities, including Richard Torrisi and Dan Barber from New York, Brian Leth and Jeremy Fox from the West Coast, preparing food. The lineup of chefs is not the same for each night. Tickets include food and limited alcoholic beverages and are available now at a special Web site for Diner’s Journal readers.

headline: In Mott’s Strike, More Than Pay at Stake

headline: The Savory Collection Likely to Hold More Surprises for Jazz Fans

There are nearly 1,000 discs in the collection, recorded by the audio engineer William Savory in the late 1930s and into 1940, the height of the swing era, but barely 10 percent of them have been digitized. What about all those other records?

Recently, a bevy of cool men’s shops have sprung up on the streets of Shoreditch, in London’s East End, including Hostem, where customers are welcomed into an olde-world interior designed by the eccentric duo at Jamesplumb. The front desk is made from an old church pew, the ceilings are draped in Swedish linen, and vintage lighting swings from long cables, allowing customers to maneuver the lights for closer inspection of the duds.

But after a few gasps from the audience, the bug flew back into the trees, and a beautiful new adaptation of a Kunqu opera masterpiece ended on a sultry summer night.

headline: Met’s Picasso Exhibition Is One for the Record Books
text: Pablo Picasso, you still got it! The Metropolitan Museum of Art said on Tuesday that its recent exhibition of works by that 20th-century titan of creativity was its seventh-highest-attended show in the museum’s history. The exhibition, called “Picasso in The Metropolitan Museum of Art,” drew 703,256 visitors during its 17-week run from April 19 through Aug. 15, making it the museum’s best-attended show since 2001. The Met said that the exhibition, which featured the museum’s complete Picasso holdings of some 300 examples of the artist’s painting, drawing, sculpture and ceramics, attracted as many as 10,000 visitors on some busy Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Still, it wasn’t enough to top the Met’s sixth-most-attended exhibition, “The Horses of San Marco,” which drew 742,221 visitors over seven months in 1980. Maybe next time, Picasso.

headline: ‘Dragon Tattoo’ Actress Chosen For U.S. Version
text: Brace your dermis: The Hollywood adaptation of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo” has found the actress who will play its title character. Rooney Mara, above, a 25-year-old actress whose film credits include “Youth in Revolt” and the 2010 remake of “A Nightmare on Elm Street,” will don the (hopefully nonpermanent) ink of Lisbeth Salander in David Fincher’s film version of the first book in Stieg Larsson’s best-selling Millennium trilogy, The Associated Press reported. The furloughed James Bond star Daniel Craig has already been chosen to play the journalist Mikael Blomkvist in the film, which Sony Pictures plans to release on Dec. 21, 2011. All three Millennium novels, including “The Girl Who Played With Fire” and “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest,” were previously adapted into Swedish-language films, the first two of which have been released in the United States.

headline: Christopher Walken, Radio Host For a Day
text: Listeners who tuned in Monday to “The Leonard Lopate Show” on WNYC expecting to hear its regular host got an unusual surprise: Christopher Walken, below, the “Deer Hunter” and “Behanding in Spokane” star, lent his lifelong interest in broadcasting and his growing skills (not to mention his unmistakable stop-and-start delivery) to the program, where he acted as guest host for the afternoon, and conducted interviews with friends and colleagues like Jack O’Brien and Richard Easton; his “Behanding” co-star Zoe Kazan; the chef Lidia Bastianich and her mother, Erminia Motika; and the dancer and choreographer Jacques d’Amboise, who shared his airtime with a surprise guest, Eddie Izzard. After taking the rest of Monday to recuperate from his debut, Mr. Walken said on Tuesday that the experience was “pretty intense” and “very thrilling.” “I’m a nervous person,” Mr. Walken said in a telephone interview. “But of course, it was completely unknown territory. And really being on the other side of the interview.”

headline: From Darfur to Brooklyn
text: Dave Sanders, a photojournalist, has been documenting the growing enclave of immigrants from the war-torn Darfur region of the Sudan who now live in the Kensington neighborhood of Brooklyn.

headline: ABC To Announce New ‘Dancing’ Stars
text: “Dancing With the Stars” is taking the show’s promotion to a new extreme, with plans to announce its new contestants in a prime-time news conference on ABC later this month. The event  with actual reporters in attendance  will be shown live during the reality show “Bachelor Pad” on Aug. 30, the network said on Tuesday. If any show can get away with such a stunt, it’s “Dancing,” which recruits celebrities for the competition twice a year. Last spring was the show’s most-watched season. The new season starts on Sept. 20. The co-hosts of the competition, Tom Bergeron and Brooke Burke, above, will host the news conference, ABC said. There will even be a question-and-answer session with the new cast members, although that part of the event may not be televised live on ABC, a network spokeswoman said. The announcement will be presented in its entirety the next day on ABC.com.

headline: ‘Bachelor Pad’ Draws Few
text: The second week of ABC’s spin-off “Bachelor Pad” drew only modest interest in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 5.4 million viewers tuned in to the reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., about a million less than the show’s premiere a week ago (6.4 million). ABC finished in a virtual tie for second place on the night with NBC, which broadcast a two-hour repeat of last week’s YouTube performers on “America’s Got Talent” (4.7 million). At 10, CBS’s “CSI: Miami” rerun (5.6 million) outperformed both “Dateline” on NBC (5.2 million) and “Dating in the Dark” on ABC (3.8 million). CBS led the night over all, despite broadcasting all repeats, including the sitcom reruns “Two and a Half Men” (8.3 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (8 million) in the 9 o’clock hour. Fox finished in fourth place with a new episode of “Lie to Me” at 9 (4.9 million), following a rerun of “House” at 8 (3.6 million).

headline: Online-Only Art Fair Set For January
text: The conventional art fair  for which collectors, dealers and other art world professionals jet into a city for several days of looking, buying, going to parties and networking  is about to face a challenge. The online-only VIP Art Fair, which will take place for the first time in January, is similarly time-limited (a week long), but different in almost every other way from a normal fair. The “booths” are virtual; conversation (and haggling over prices) will take place by instant messaging, phone or Skype; and no one will get sore feet. The event is the brainchild of two couples, the art dealers James and Jane Cohan and the Internet entrepreneurs Jonas and Alessandra Almgren. So far several major galleries have signed up, including Gagosian, David Zwirner, White Cube, Hauser & Wirth and L&M Arts. The cost to galleries in the most elite category is $20,000, which Mr. Cohan said the founders estimated to be about a fifth the cost of doing a conventional art fair (including booth, transportation, hotels and shipping). Asked whether people would be willing to spend money on art they hadn’t seen in person, Mr. Cohan said that buyers most likely would be people already familiar with a given artist’s work. The fair will take place Jan. 22 to 30. Anyone can browse, but to interact with dealers, you will have to be invited by one of the exhibiting galleries or pay a fee of $20 or $100.

headline: Dylan’s Art Exhibition To Feature New Paintings
text: We suppose an exhibition of paintings by Bob Dylan could depict anything from Einstein disguised as Robin Hood to a fight between Ezra Pound and T. S. Eliot  and that’s just if he sticks to the lyrics of his song “Desolation Row.” So what will visitors to Mr. Dylan’s show at the Danish National Gallery in Copenhagen actually see when it opens there next month? As Kaspar Monrad, the museum’s curator and director, told Agence France-Presse, the works will include paintings of Brazil, like the one above, containing “scenes from daily life in the cities, the slums and the countryside in Brazil where Bob Dylan has been several times.” The exhibition, which will run at the museum (known locally as the Statens Museum for Kunst) from Sept. 4 through Jan. 30, was announced last year. The museum said on Monday that it would include 40 acrylic paintings and 8 drawings created by Mr. Dylan specifically for the show. Mr. Monrad said the paintings, whose subjects also include a familiarly Dylan-esque array of gypsies, gangsters and politicians, were “inspired by American realism from the start of the 20th century” and a “deep affinity” with painters like Matisse. In a statement Mr. Dylan simply said, “It was an honor to be asked and a thrilling challenge” to create the works.

headline: A Veteran of the Seas, With a Crew Full of Actors

headline: Scientists Tussle Over Gulf Oil Tally
text: When the Obama administration released scientific findings early this month estimating that roughly three-quarters of the oil from the BP spill in the Gulf of Mexico had been captured, burned, dispersed, evaporated, degraded or dissolved in the water, a number of independent scientists cried foul, describing the report as premature and suggesting that it was portraying the ecological impact of the spill in an unduly rosy light.

headline: Inventive Back and Forth Between Old and New

Here, as a highlight of this summer’s Mostly Mozart Festival, was a top-notch contemporary-music ensemble, under the brilliant direction of the fast-rising French conductor Ludovic Morlot, in a program featuring three audaciously modern scores by three living composers. The hall was packed; the audience gave cheering ovations to each work.

headline: A New Fruit Soft-Serve
text: Frozen confections come every which way this summer. The latest is a soft-serve, lightly sweetened fruit purée called Fruizo. Four partners, devoted to fitness and healthful food for their children, founded the business after experimenting for more than a year at home and then hiring consultants. The result, in a debut of mango, strawberry and banana flavors, all made from freshly puréed fruit rather than commercial purées, comes swirled into cups, by itself or accompanied by diced fruit, nuts, granola or other toppings. There are also smoothies and sundaes sold in this store, the partners’ first, which has a weathered country look even though much of the fruit comes from farms far away. Apple Fruizo will be added in the fall.

headline: The Popover Café Offers Mini Version
text: Carol Baer has been serving big, crusty popovers, the signature of her Upper West Side restaurant, Popover Café, since 1981. From time to time, she has made miniature ones for catered events, mainly for hors d’oeuvres and desserts, but also for dinners. “They’re more delicate and less filling,” she said. Now, the mini-popovers are on the cafe menu; diners can choose four of them instead of one big one, or a basket of a dozen in place of three. Her Web site now sells a kit for baking the minis at home, including mix, a pastry brush, raspberry jam or apple butter and two pans, each making 12. There is enough mix to make many more than the 24 popovers the two pans can hold.

headline: At Chelsea Market, Refills on Olive Oil
text: A few places around the city, including Fairway and Stonehouse, decant olive oils from large containers into reusable ones, but none are as dedicated as the new Filling Station in Chelsea Market. Besides extra virgin olive oils — more than a dozen from different countries, dispensed from drums called fustis — vinegars, sea salts and sugars are sold in containers of several sizes provided by the store, which customers can then have refilled at a 10 percent discount. “We feel this is also a way of helping the environment with automatic recycling,” said Laura Nuter, an owner of the new store and of Grab Specialty Foods in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Her partner is Megan Joan Cariola, the owner of Provisions in South Street Seaport. There are dark and white balsamic vinegars, many infused with fig, peach and other fruits. Salts come flavored or unflavored; sugars include Demarara and caster. The partners hope to have a liquor license in the fall and will then begin selling beer in refillable growlers.

headline: Touching Lives Instead of Bases

Lang, 67, and blind since birth, wore a Derek Jeter T-shirt, Yankees sneakers and a commemorative cap from the last World Series, embroidered with a home plate graphic. She explained to the passenger next to her that she never knew the shape of the plate until tracing it with her fingers.

headline: Former Aide Says Paterson Rejected Advice on Tickets

Paterson repeatedly urged him to pay for World Series tickets he had requested from the Yankees last year, but his concerns were brushed off by Mr. Paterson and others who insisted that the governor was entitled to get them free, the aide testified on Tuesday.

headline: Pakistan: A Trade Deal to Help Rebuild
text: One of the best long-term ways to help Pakistan  and improve America’s image there  is to help Pakistanis help themselves. That is why President George W. Bush and now President Obama have pushed for slashing protective tariffs on the textiles and apparel products that are Pakistan’s biggest exports to the United States.

headline: Given Money, Schools Wait on Rehiring Teachers
text: As schools handed out pink slips to teachers this spring, states made a beeline to Washington to plead for money for their ravaged education budgets. But now that the federal government has come through with $10 billion, some of the nation’s biggest school districts are balking at using their share of the money to hire teachers right away.

headline: Immigration Bait and Switch
text: Secure Communities, an immigration enforcement program created under President George W. Bush and now being greatly expanded by President Obama, is billed as an effort to catch and deport “the worst of the worst,” the violent criminals, drug and gun smugglers, gang members and other dangerous aliens. That would be excellent, if true. It doesn’t seem to be.

headline: Pakistan: An Urgent Call for Aid
text: The magnitude of Pakistan’s current tragedy is almost more than the mind can take in. A fifth of the country flooded by torrential monsoon rains. Fifteen million to 20 million people driven from their homes or otherwise affected. Six million in need of emergency assistance, such as food and clean water. Millions of acres of the country’s best cropland underwater. Livestock drowned. Medical clinics destroyed. Cholera threatening the survivors.

headline: Tea Party Choice Scrambles in Taking On Reid in Nevada
text: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev.  Sharron Angle leaned across a table in her campaign office here, defending her suddenly embattled campaign to defeat Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, under the gaze of a half-dozen advisers and an official videographer packed into the room.

headline: Anglers and the Diatom
text: As a rule, invasive species do not invade on their own. They do so with human help. A good example is Didymosphenia geminata, a diatom that reproduces quickly and can grow in huge blooms and mats. In the past few years, it has spread widely from its native habit  cool mountain lakes and streams in North America and Europe  to waters where it was previously unknown or had only limited growth. It can alter stream ecology, affecting insect life and spawning habitat.

headline: Continued Inflation Is Called Temporary
