headline: On Motorcycle, European Pilgrims Race Toward God
text: PORCARO, France  The inhabitants of Brittany, on Europe’s rain-soaked western edge, are said to love the church as much as they love a party. Which perhaps makes this tiny Breton village a less improbable locale for the wholly improbable happening it hosts each year.

headline: Curious Person
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — “Add a letter” themes are nothing new, but Alex Boisvert ups the ante by selecting X as his addition of choice. That can’t be easy. Then he somehow manages to pull off this thematic stunt five times. It’s an impressive grid. All the theme answers are very good. “Curious person’s video game console” for PANDORA’S XBOX is outstanding.

headline: Israel: Ex-Soldier Speaks on Photos
text: A former Israeli soldier who posted photographs on Facebook of herself posing next to blindfolded Palestinian prisoners told Israeli Army radio on Tuesday that she did not “understand what’s wrong” with the photographs, which were taken while she was on active duty. The former soldier, Eden Abergil, who is now a reservist, said that the “pictures were taken in good will, there was no statement in them.” An Israeli military spokesman denounced Ms. Abergil’s snapshots as “disgraceful.” Breaking the Silence, an Israeli human rights group, added one of her images to a new Facebook album of similar photographs taken over the past decade. The group wrote, “This picture is not the ugly behavior of one person, but a norm throughout the army.” Ghassan Khatib, a spokesman for the Palestinian Authority, told the BBC that the images illustrated “the day-to-day life of the Palestinian people under occupation,” and suggested “that occupation also corrupts the Israelis.”

headline: Manuel Stands by His Closer, Even as Teammates Quietly Back Away
text: HOUSTON  One of the more perplexing side stories surrounding Francisco Rodriguez’s arrest and injury has been the reaction of the Mets’ manager, Jerry Manuel.

headline: Israel: Turkish Embassy Break-In
text: A West Bank Palestinian who once collaborated with Israel’s Shin Bet security service and said he was being persecuted by the Palestinian Authority broke into the Turkish Embassy in Tel Aviv on Tuesday and demanded political asylum, an Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman said. The intruder, who tried to take a consular official hostage, was shot by Turkish guards, lightly wounded in the leg, and was questioned by Turkish officials. The man was later identified as Nadim Injaz, of Ramallah, The Associated Press reported. He was removed from the embassy and turned over to Israeli authorities, The A.P. said. The Israeli spokesman added that the man had tried to break into the British Embassy in Tel Aviv four years ago, ended up in prison and was then released.

headline: Investors Chide Michael Dell
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Dell’s shareholders delivered a sharp rebuke of Michael S. Dell, the company’s founder and chief executive, when a fourth of the investors withheld support of Mr. Dell in a recent vote.

headline: Cape Cod Waterways Face Pollution Crisis
text: ORLEANS, Mass. — Rising nitrogen levels are suffocating the vegetation and marine life in saltwater ponds and estuaries on Cape Cod, creating an environmental and infrastructure problem that, if left unchecked, will threaten the shellfishing industry, the tourist economy and the beaches that lure so many summer visitors.

headline: An Honor for Dr. King That Leaves Few Satisfied
text: ANCHORAGE  The new Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Avenue here is a fine-looking road. Spruce and birch trees line both sides. The Chugach Mountains rise in the distance. It feels, and it is, far away from the struggling streets that bear the civil rights leader’s name in many other cities.

headline: Picking a Spot, Any (Undiscovered) Spot, in Mexico
text: In “The Last King of Scotland,” which I watched dubbed in Spanish on the bus from Tapachula to Oaxaca, Mexico, last week, the Scottish character Nicholas Garrigan comes up with a travel plan: to spin a globe, to place his finger down randomly, and to go wherever it lands. His destination: Uganda. Unfortunately, it was 1971, and the brutal dictator Idi Amin had just seized power. Things do not go well.

headline: Image and Text Collide at Amsterdam Show
text: In Charlotte Salomon’s art, text and image meet in an exuberant burst of joy and anguish. Brooding, fluid figures are drawn with a line that seems ready to disappear into the vortex of color on the page. Tight columns of text are piled one atop the other like hieroglyphs in an Egyptian relic. An exhibition at the Jewish Historical Museum of early gouaches by the artist, who was killed at Auschwitz during World War II, examines this mix of text and image, and the explicitly lyrical nature of her work.

headline: Welcome Back | John Derian for Target
text: September is almost here, with its cooler temperatures (at least we in New York hope they’re cooler) and, even better, the arrival of a new John Derian collection for Target. The East Village master of decoupage plates, trays, lamps and other decorative items has followed his 2008 effort for the design-centric retailer with a bigger, more varied collection that includes stationery, home décor, housewares and storage — all at I’ll-take-10-of-those prices. Signature designs run through the collection: for example, a silhouette that adorns the cover of a composition book ($2.50) also appears on a ceramic mug ($4.99). Storage bins covered in geranium-leaf or moth prints are too pretty to hide in a closet, and there are plastic trays for every possible use. My favorites among the latter are the Tapered Tray ($19.99, shown here in pale geranium), which is large enough to carry drinks outside, or to stack books or magazines. A smaller tray ($12.99) is perfect for organizing jars of cotton swabs and makeup brushes in the bathroom or for putting your keys on near the front door. Its image of a pink room (called House-Mouse in the collection), taken from a late-19th-century German print, is one of Derian’s favorites. “It’s so conceptual,” he said, “as if you’re putting your things down in a room.” And the oval tray ($12.99), with its Home Sweet Home motto (based on a print that Derian found when he bought an old frame), would look great hanging on a wall, with its old-fashioned, almost camp sensibility. Derian particularly likes the way that these pieces work in modern as well as more traditional rooms. “They all cross over, which is cool,” he added. The collection will be available beginning Sept. 5, but as always with Target’s designer collaborations, supplies are limited.

headline: Adulthood Can Wait?

We have often discussed, here on Motherlode, the fact that our children seem to be growing up so so much more quickly in some ways — 15 is the new 25 — and so much more slowly in others — 25 and still living at home. In her provocative and thought-provoking article, Robin Marantz Henig posits that the 20s weren’t and aren’t a part of childhood or adulthood, but an in-between stage, separate and distinct.

headline: Joe Sestak, the 60th Democrat
text: Joe Sestak stepped out of a Chevy Suburban on the morning of July 3 and met up with a group of 15 campaign volunteers gathered in the parking lot of a drugstore in Canonsburg, Pa., just southwest of Pittsburgh. The town is the birthplace of Perry Como. It is also said to have the largest Independence Day parade in western Pennsylvania. Sestak and his supporters walked across an intersection and took their assigned place near the back of a procession amid firetrucks, dune buggies, a horse-drawn carriage, a bagpipe band and an S.U.V. ferrying Junior Miss Mid Mon Valley, an 8-year-old beauty queen sitting on top of the vehicle with her legs dangling through the sunroof. Sestak, a Navy admiral turned politician, surveyed the scene, then turned to me and said: “I heard this parade was gigantic and wonderful. But look at this!”

headline: How Do You Pick a Watermelon?

headline: Letters: My Life in Therapy

Merkin knows more about herself than any therapist possibly could. Hopefully when she walks in the next therapist’s door, it won’t be because she feels she is addicted — but because she has chosen to return to a relationship that she knows can lend support and care, no matter what she says.

text: I’m off to Sweden, where I’ll be hanging out with tattooed Goth hackers regional scientists. I don’t know how much posting, if any, I’ll be doing.

headline: Arnold Odermatt: Photographing the Calm After the Crash
text: On a snow-covered Alpine roadway, tire tracks veer from the worn ruts and continue down a slope. They disappear before abruptly re-emerging at a tree, where the fated vehicle lies on its back, wheels to the sky, with the silhouettes of two bystanders near the wreckage. On closer scrutiny, what appears to be a perfunctory archival accident photo adopts qualities of fine-art photography: intersecting planes, rich grays and a pervasive sense of downward motion, as if the landscape would, if allowed, slide out of frame.

headline: Noeud Papillon | Twisted Misters
text: Like that of most men, York Wu’s first experience with a bow tie involved a wedding. “My cousin was getting married, and I hated the tie that came with my tuxedo,” Wu recalls. “So I decided to make my own.” From that moment, he was a convert, showing up at the Toronto design firm where he worked sporting a different handmade bow tie every day. With his new line, Noeud Papillon — French for “butterfly knot,” the double Windsor of the bow tie world — Wu has elevated the geekiest of accessories to I-want-one status. His designs range from a studded black leather version to a white chiffon confection that does double duty as a Wildean boutonniere. (Female friends have been known to borrow it as a hair ornament.) The attention he lavishes on them — each one is handmade from couture-grade fabrics and individually numbered, with no visible stitches — rivals that which Alber Elbaz of Lanvin, Wu’s design hero and himself a bow tie man, devotes to his frocks. “I want Noeud Papillon ties to be the equivalent of Lanvin,” he says, “structured and strong on the inside, elegant and effortless on the outside.”

headline: Former Martial Arts Manager Buys PBS ‘Nightly Business Report’
text: “Nightly Business Report” on PBS, by some measures the nation’s most-watched business newscast, has been acquired from its owner, public station WPBT-TV in Miami, by a private company headed by Mykalai Kontilai, a former manager of mixed martial artists and distributor of instructional television programs.

headline: Pension Fraud by New Jersey Is Cited by S.E.C.
text: Federal regulators accused the State of New Jersey of securities fraud on Wednesday for claiming it had been properly funding public workers’ pensions when it was not.

headline: Reader Response: ‘Womanly’ Jobs and Low Pay
text: I loved the variety of responses to my post “Why Girly Jobs Don’t Pay Well.”

text: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival began last weekend. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors.

text: A day after he was barred from the France team for three games, Franck Ribery was challenged by the president of Bayern Munich to repay the club’s loyalty.

headline: Amin al-Hindi, Former Palestinian Intelligence Chief, Dies at 70
text: JERUSALEM  Amin al-Hindi, an associate of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and a former Palestinian Authority intelligence chief who was widely suspected of having played an organizing role in the deadly attack on Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics, died Tuesday in Amman, Jordan. He was 70.

headline: When Life Lived Online Is Sanitized, Do We Lose Something?
text: When reports first began to surface about Steven Slater’s sliding departure from his job as a JetBlue flight attendant, there was one crucial detail in the coverage that leaped out at me as the most arresting.

headline: Some Ways to Thwart an Online Bully
text: TODAY’S bullies are not restricted to cafeterias, gym class and schoolyards. With technology, they can appear in every digital corner of a modern child’s life. But parents and children can take heart. Technology can also be harnessed to combat online bullies.

headline: Mexican Air Travel Rating Is Downgraded
text: The Federal Aviation Administration has announced  that it was downgrading its rating of Mexico’s oversight of civil aviation from Category 1 to Category 2 because Mexico had failed to meet the international safety standards of the United Nations agency for civil aviation.

headline: Pricing Violations Found at City Supermarkets
text: In a sweep of more than 700 supermarkets across the city, inspectors from the Department of Consumer Affairs found pricing violations in more than half of them, the agency announced on Wednesday.

headline: Joe L. Brown, Built Pirates’ Championship Teams, Dies at 91
text: Joe L. Brown, the Pittsburgh Pirates general manager who built two World Series championship teams and five National League division winners in the 1960s and ’70s, died Sunday in Albuquerque. He was 91.

headline: Finding New Ways to Fill the Tank
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Most research on renewable energy has focused on replacing the electricity that now comes from burning coal and natural gas. But the spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the reliance on Middle East imports and the threat of global warming are reminders that oil is also a pressing worry. A lot of problems could be solved with a renewable replacement for oil-based gasoline and diesel in the fuel tank  either a new liquid fuel or a much better battery.

headline: The Sea and the English Who Tried to Master It
text: WASHINGTON  We know well the hazards latent in the sea. For months, we have watched millions of barrels of oil erupting from the ocean floor, just after its explosive force claimed the lives of 11 workers who toiled on precarious platforms perched above the waves. We have also, in recent years, watched waters engulf the shores and dwellings of New Orleans, wreaking havoc as in ancient tales.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Newt Gingrich on ground zero: “Nazis don’t have the right to put up a sign next to the holocaust museum in Washington.” And Newt shouldn’t be allowed within 50 yards of a Dunkin’ Donuts.

headline: Eminem Sends the Arcade Fire Packing from Top of Album Chart

headline: Looking for Baby Sitters: Foreign Language a Must
text: When Maureen Mazumder enrolled her daughter, Sabrina, in a Spanish singalong class a year ago, she hoped it would be the first step in helping her learn a second language. But the class did not seem to do the trick, so Ms. Mazumder decided to hire a baby sitter, one who would not only care for her daughter but also speak to her exclusively in Spanish.

A hand truck with a flat tire, a dirty sink. A rocking horse. This he dates to the 1930s and offers to sell for $20. Or $10. It’s negotiable.

text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York released its quarterly report on household debt and credit on Tuesday. It showed that for the first time since early 2006, total household delinquency rates declined last quarter.

headline: American Ordered to Return to Prison in Peru
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  A Peruvian court said Wednesday that it had struck down a decision granting parole to Lori Berenson, the New Yorker imprisoned in the 1990s on charges of collaborating with a Marxist revolutionary group. The court ordered her to be returned to prison to complete the five years left in her 20-year sentence.

The Kangol Deerstalker is a stripped-down, non-plaid version made in Japanese jersey, slowly spun on antique machines for a softer quality (pictured, $72). It may be just the look for Bushwick denizens, looking for their fixies after a night of swilling ironic peppermint schnapps.

headline: Virtual Target Previews Fall
text: GILT GROUPE and Target are collaborating on a virtual pop-up store that will feature select items by Tucker, John Derian and Mulberry, before the collections hit the chain’s shelves in the fall. The sale starts Aug. 20 on Gilt, the online shopping site, and will last until noon, Aug. 23 (new members can sign on at Gilt.com/Target). The Tucker for Target collection (pictured) includes a button-front dress in a painted-flowers print ($34.99) and a butterfly print camisole ($22.99), shown with a brocade skirt in gold and navy ($39.99). Gaby Basora, the designer, models the line’s fleece jumpsuit ($44.99). “A jumpsuit is always a staple in my collections,” Ms. Basora said. “Many jumpsuits feel vintage. This feels modern.”

headline: A Shoe With Meow
text: THEY’RE not kitten heels in the strict, Audrey Hepburn sense, but lower heels are emerging as a welcome alternative to tottering at a four-inch incline. Some wearers are updating the look with socks, perhaps inspired by Marc Jacobs’s runway, left.

headline: Carl Pavano Gives Twins His Best
text: MINNEAPOLIS  In his reinvention as elder statesman and guiding light of the Minnesota Twins’ pitching staff, the former Yankee Carl Pavano often shows off something he rarely exhibited in four injury-filled years in the Bronx: a biting wit. Pavano needles his teammates about their weaknesses on the field, and they in turn tease him about his inability to hold base runners.

text: After Tuesday’s double dose of bad news for Eli Lilly, the pharmaceutical company bought a full-page advertisement in The Indianapolis Star on Wednesday to reassure its hometown supporters of a brighter future.

Neil MacFarquhar reports that aid organizations and the United Nations itself have expressed alarm that the plight of millions of Pakistanis flooded from their land has yet to strike a sufficiently sympathetic nerve among donors, with aid trickling in far more slowly than needed.

headline: The New Adventures of Old Elaine
text: ON a recent August night, young women in stilettos teetered precariously through the cobblestone streets of the meatpacking district in Manhattan. Appropriately for the neighborhood, they were squeezed into minidresses that were as snug as sausage casings. But a few blocks south, far away from the blare of Hummer limousine horns, at the fashionable opening of the Algus Greenspon Gallery on Morton Street, a more demure look prevailed.

headline: Palliative Care Extends Life, Study Finds
text: In a study that sheds new light on the effects of end-of-life care, doctors have found that patients with terminal lung cancer who began receiving palliative care immediately upon diagnosis not only were happier, more mobile and in less pain as the end neared  but they also lived nearly three months longer.

text: Today they are suits  pro basketball executives  but once upon a time they were kids, looking for a game.

headline: Ephemeral Magic Mirrors the Life of a Bronx Center
text: For nearly 25 years, the Bronx River Art Center has been organizing exhibitions, art classes and public school programs out of a funky, century-old building in a battered neighborhood called West Farms. Beginning in September, the building will undergo an overhaul, leaving the center to float for two years in temporary locations.

headline: Judge Approves $298 Million Barclays Settlement
text: A federal judge on Wednesday afternoon allowed the British banking giant Barclays to continue with a $298 million settlement of claims that it had violated American trade sanctions, a day after he criticized the agreement as a “sweetheart deal,” Reuters reports.

headline: U.S. Sends Muslim Center Imam to Arab World to Promote Religious Tolerance
text: As the fierce debate continues over plans to build a Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan near the site of terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, one of the project’s central figures, Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, is on a mission from the United States government to promote religious tolerance in the Arab world.

headline: Dimming the Skyline to Save the Birds
text: More New York City skyscrapers are turning their lights off this fall in an effort to save the lives of migrating birds who might crash into them while on their way to warmer climes.

headline: Mellowed by the Harmonies, and Surfing Repetitive Refrains
text: “Where is your direction?” sang Evan Koga near the end of Chief’s show at Joe’s Pub on Tuesday night. He repeated the question, and then answered it himself: “Your direction is nowhere but here.” He didn’t mean to sound pushy, really. The song, “Your Direction,” is about the comfort of two people bridging their emotional distance and finding each other in the moment. “I know where you are, and I know that I am here,” Mr. Koga offered later in the tune, his band mates singing behind him. “That I am here,” he sang again, several times.

headline: Eating Locally in the Berkshires
text: Food-savvy tourists enjoy a vibrant food-producing region in western Massachusetts.

headline: In the Berkshires, Dinner’s Not Far Away
text: IT’S hard to dismiss the current locavore boom in the Berkshires as mere fashion. In fact, the national enthusiasm for eating farm-to-table has roots in western Massachusetts. The nation’s first agricultural fair was held in Berkshire County in the early 19th century, and in 1986, when the country’s first two community-supported agriculture farms were established, one was in the southern Berkshires.

headline: Mozart Takes the Stage at His Festival
text: In recent years the Mostly Mozart Festival has swung its programming lasso across diverse terrain, rounding up resident composers and attractive new works and creating intriguing thematic connections. From Bach to Birtwistle, there has been a variety this summer as well, but Mozart has seemed a more frequent visitor at his own party.

headline: New Girl Enters Stale Dating Pool
text: It is never pretty to see the movie industry devour its young, but “Vampires Suck,” a limp lampoon of the “Twilight” series, seems especially redundant. Aside from the difficulty of spoofing a saga that has always been winkingly aware of its own angsty excesses, there is the inadvisability of angering a tweeniverse whose emotional investment in the originals borders on pathological.

headline: Fringe Festival in Review
text: New York Times writers review five shows that made their debuts in the early days of this year’s New York International Fringe Festival, which runs through Aug. 29. Visit the ArtsBeat blog, nytimes.com/artsbeat, for reviews of more shows. For more information, visit fringenyc.org or call (866) 468-7619.

headline: Fete Accompli | The Couture Council Summer Party
text: Tall white candles in even taller glass receptacles line the marble staircase of the French embassy on Fifth Avenue for the Fashion Institute of Technology’s Couture Council Summer Party; there’s a smattering of white rose petals as if to herald the arrival of Madame de Sevigne. But no, these glories are intended to greet me and the other guests unlucky enough to be in town during the last two weeks of August, a fortnight when everyone else is rumored to have fled the city.

headline: The Independent 529 Rebrands Itself
text: In an effort to attract more accounts, the Tuition Plan Consortium has changed the name of its Independent 529 plan product to the “Private College 529 Plan.”

headline: Picasso Show Makes the Met’s Top 10
text: Pablo Picasso, you still got it! The Metropolitan Museum of Art said on Tuesday that its recent exhibition of works by that 20th-century titan of creativity was its seventh highest-attended show in the museum’s history. The exhibition, called “Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art,” drew 703,256 visitors during its 17-week run from April 19 through Sunday, making it the museum’s best-attended show since 2001. The Met said that the exhibition, which featured the museum’s complete Picasso holdings of some 300 examples of the artist’s painting, drawing, sculpture and ceramics (above is his “Seated Harlequin from 1901), attracted as many as 10,000 visitors on some busy Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Still, it wasn’t enough to top the Met’s sixth most-attended exhibition, “The Horses of San Marco,” which drew 742,221 visitors over seven months in 1980. Maybe next time, Picasso.

headline: ‘Dr. Laura’ Retreats After Use of Epithet
text: Following criticism and the loss of advertisers after her use of a racial epithet 11 times on her long-running radio talk show last week, Laura Schlessinger said on Tuesday night that she would not renew her contract for the show when it expires at the end of the year.

headline: Betty White Gets Busier
text: Betty White may be 88, but she’s certainly not finished acting. And she’s not finished writing books, either. Ms. White — the “Hot in Cleveland” star, who will also be seen on “Community” and just about anywhere else that a television set or computer monitor is on — just signed a deal to write two books for G. P. Putnam’s Sons, the publisher announced on Wednesday. The first book, “Listen Up!,” is about “life lessons learned during her incredibly varied and long career in Hollywood, with an emphasis on the extraordinary past 15 years of the star’s life,” according to a statement, and is scheduled for release in spring 2011. The second book, scheduled for publication in 2012, is called “The Zoo and I,” and will have stories about Ms. White and the animals at the Los Angeles Zoo. (She is on the board of trustees of the Greater Los Angeles Zoo Association and an animal rights advocate.) She has written two books and was a co-author of three. In a statement, Ms. White said, “Much as I love what I do for a living in show business, I love writing even more.”

headline: A Classic Cookbook Returns, Canned Soup and All
text: Who says there isn’t still an appetite for Hootenholler Whisky Cake?

headline: ‘Talent’ Wild Cards Win
text: “Wild Card” night on “America’s Got Talent,” in which 12 previously eliminated acts got a second chance in the competition, helped NBC top the ratings on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.1 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour talent program from 9 to 11 p.m., more than any other show in prime-time. NBC did not lead the 8 p.m. time slot, however, as a rerun of “Minute to Win It” (5.2 million) could not compete with ABC’s “Wipeout” (8.9 million) or CBS’s repeat of “NCIS” (8.7 million). Despite a line-up of all reruns, CBS ranked second on the night, earning 7.6 million at 9 for “NCIS: Los Angeles” and 5.2 million at 10 for “The Good Wife.” ABC was third with “Shaq Vs.” (5.1 million) and “Primetime” (4.5 million) from 9 to 11 while Fox placed fourth with back-to-back repeats of “Glee” (3.8 million).

headline: Despite Scandals, Indian Mining Bosses Thrive
text: BELLARY, India  Janardhana Reddy insists he is not a king. No, no, no, he protested, as a servant trotted across the courtyard to deliver a cup of cooled water. Men with machine guns stood outside. An architect waited to discuss the new mansion, while another man hovered nearby, sitting in the grass.

headline: She Said, They Said: Ms. Tequila Vs. Juggalo
text: Juggalo Gathering LLC, the company that produces the Gathering of the Juggalos concerts, said on Wednesday that neither it nor the band Insane Clown Posse was responsible for an incident in which Tila Tequila, right, the reality television star and singer, was attacked by fans after taking the stage at the festival on Saturday. In a statement, the company said: “Ms. Tequila was made aware, in advance, of her unpopularity with many Juggalos at the Gathering, but she insisted on performing. She was even paid in full before her performance, and was told that she did not have to perform, but if she did decide to perform, she could leave the stage the minute that she felt uncomfortable.” Juggalo Gathering LLC added that the performer exacerbated the situation when she “removed her top, exposing herself, which seemed to mock and further antagonize the crowd.” Tila Tequila, whose real name is Tila Nguyen, filed a complaint with law enforcement officials in Hardin County, Ill., where the festival was held. She has said that she required stitches after audience members pelted her with rocks, glass bottles, firecrackers and waste from portable toilets.

headline: Eminem Reclaims Charts
text: It was bound to happen. Although the Arcade Fire had its moment in the spotlight when it beat out Eminem for the No. 1 spot on the Billboard album chart last week, the natural order of the pop universe has been restored, with Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) retaking No. 1 by a wide margin. “Recovery” sold 133,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, landing the album at the top of the chart for the sixth time in eight weeks. The Arcade Fire’s album, “The Suburbs” (Merge), fell to No. 2 with 52,000 sales, a 66 percent decline from the week before. (Although sales for “Recovery” have dropped since it was released, they have held steady in the mid-100,000’s, and the album has sold a total of 2.1 million copies so far.) The soundtrack to the Disney Channel movie “Camp Rock 2: The Final Jam” (Disney), with songs by Demi Lovato and the Jonas Brothers, opened at No. 3 with 41,000 sales. Black Label Society, led by Zakk Wylde, Ozzy Osbourne’s former guitarist, is No. 4 with its new “Order of the Black” (E1), which sold 33,000.

headline: Strange Second Life of ‘Life and Times of Tim’
text: A few weeks ago, Steve Dildarian appeared to be as down-and-out as the perpetually troubled protagonist on his HBO animated series “The Life and Times of Tim.” That was in June, when the network told him it would not be picking up a third season of that cartoon comedy, on which he serves as creator, writer, producer and the voice of its title character. Then, before Mr. Dildarian had time to gather his belongings or shop the show to another network, HBO reversed course and told him a few days ago that “The Life and Times of Tim” would be resurrected for Season 3. So why the sudden reversal of fortune? “Honestly, I don’t know,” he said in a phone interview. “Sometimes I’m the last to know these things.” In a statement, Mike Lombardo, the president of HBO programming, said simply that the show “has a passionate fan base both in terms of viewers and within the company,” and the network was “convinced that ‘Tim’ should be part of our plans for 2011.” Given that it takes about 10 months to a year to create new episodes of the show, Mr. Dildarian said he hoped to get back to work quickly. “The last thing I need is more breathing room,” he said.

headline: The Real Jerry Lee Lewis Will Be In the House
text: Levi Kreis has earned praise, and a Tony Award, for his portrayal of the rebellious rocker Jerry Lee Lewis, below, in the Broadway musical “Million Dollar Quartet,” but come next month he’s going to have a little competition for that role. Mr. Lewis  the Killer himself  plans to attend the Sept. 10 performance of the musical at the Nederlander Theater and will play onstage with its cast in a special post-show jam session, publicists for the production said on Wednesday. During its Broadway run, “Million Dollar Quartet” has had musical artists like Melissa Etheridge, Larry Gatlin and Guy Davis perform with its cast, but this guest shot is unique: Mr. Lewis, 74, the Louisiana-born performer of “Great Balls of Fire” and “Whole Lotta Shakin’ Goin’ On,” is the last surviving member of the real-life Million Dollar Quartet, the serendipitous assemblage at which he, Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and Carl Perkins recorded together at Sun Records in 1956. Mr. Lewis and Mr. Kreis are also to duet on a song that will appear on a deluxe version of Mr. Lewis’s album “Mean Old Man.”

headline: Yummy, Yummy, Yummy, I’ve Got Bears That Are Gummi
text: “As happy as a kid in a candy store” is still a familiar expression, even if candy stores are becoming scarce. But how would a child holding an executive position behave in the board room of a candy company?

headline: School’s In
text: Knock, knock.

headline: Hindu Deities Conjure Magic in Movement Downtown
text: As surprising New York juxtapositions go, none surpass those provided each August by the Erasing Borders festival of Indian dance in its contributions to the Downtown Dance Festival. Here is a downtown plaza surrounded by skyscrapers, with people coming and going at lunchtime and a soundtrack that includes the harbor and city traffic; and here in the open air are dancers in full Indian costume performing traditional forms that derive from the opposite side of the world.

headline: Campaigning for Democrats, Including Himself
text: President Obama completed on Wednesday a three-day campaign swing intended to shore up the fortunes of Democratic candidates still willing to stand beside him and his deteriorating approval ratings.

headline: A Faded Baseball Phenom Gets a Visitor
text: You’ve got to admire the range of emotions mined by Series B of the annual Summer Shorts festival at the 59E59 Theaters. At intermission you’ll be basking in a pleasant seasonal glow. At the end you’ll be thoroughly rattled.

headline: Prosecutor’s Unusual Step Puts Off Indictment of Suspect in a Police Shooting
text: The case against a suspect arrested after a shooting in Harlem involving the police, in which one man was killed amid a hail of 46 police bullets, will not be immediately presented to a grand jury, according to law enforcement officials familiar with the decision.

headline: Why Johnny’s College Isn’t What It Used to Be
text: Andrew Hacker and Claudia Dreifus have written a lucid, passionate and wide-ranging book on the state of American higher education and what they perceive as its increasing betrayal of its primary mission  for them, the teaching of undergraduates. That both are academics  one a well-known professor (Mr. Hacker) and the other consigned to the adjunct, or what they call “contingent,” faculty (Ms. Dreifus, who is also a frequent contributor to The New York Times)  provides them with memorable, often acerbic anecdotes that neatly offset their citations of statistics and (it must be said) their sometimes rather sweeping generalizations.

headline: Lady Libertine
text: In the early 1970s, Robert Mapplethorpe gave Maxime de la Falaise McKendry and her husband, John, the gift of a box he had made, à la Joseph Cornell, that held a doll with two smaller ones in its stomach. Attached to the larger doll was a camera bellows. The subject was nurturing.

headline: Reviewing the Druckenmiller Decades
text: As the summer winds down, it’s now Stanley F. Druckenmiller’s turn to head for the beach — permanently.  Mr. Druckenmiller’s departure from the hedge fund industry, after 30 years in the business, surely surprised some fund managers and underscored the difficulties that investors are having in these treacherous markets.

headline: G.M.’s Risks: Management, Pay and More
text: 6:30 p.m. | Updated section on internal financial controls In its huge initial public offering filing, General Motors included a litany of potential risks that it had to disclose to investors.

headline: Frank Kermode, a Critic Who Wrote With Style, Is Dead at 90
text: Frank Kermode, who rose from humble origins to become one of England’s most respected and influential critics, died Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, England. He was 90.

headline: Excerpts From Frank Kermode’s Writing
text: From “A New Era of Shakespeare Criticism” in The New York Review of Books:

headline: Medicare Drug Plans Rise $1 a Month
text: The average Medicare drug benefit plan will cost $30 a month next year, a $1-a-month increase from this year’s average premium, federal officials said Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Abrupt End For Concert Series In Brooklyn
text: On Sunday, music fans will flock to the East River State Park in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to hear the 1980s-loving electro-funk band Chromeo, the latest in the free Pool Parties concert series that, over five years, has become a summer indie-rock institution.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Moves to Ensure Drug Safety
text: Beset by a series of recalls of Tylenol and other popular over-the-counter drugs, Johnson & Johnson said Wednesday that it planned to revamp its quality controls, creating a single framework for its drug, medical device and consumer health care divisions.

headline: Notable New Yorkers, Imported From Scotland
text: The Staten Island Scot left us on Monday. Bobby Thomson died at age 86, almost 59 years after hitting the “shot heard round the world” out of the Polo Grounds and sending the New York Giants to the World Series.

text: MONTHS after stirring up the pizza category with promotional price cuts, Pizza Hut is putting its products on sale.

The winners of the 0 to 5,000 master point flight were Morrie Kleinplatz of Windsor, Ontario; Mark Leonard of Ypsilanti, Mich.; John Boyer of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.; and Robert Stayman of New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: A New Playground for the Rich

headline: Montenegro Reaches for Respectability With Port
text: TIVAT, Montenegro — “This is better than St. Tropez,” Milo Djukanovic, the prime minister of Montenegro, exclaimed as he took in a display of yachts berthed in this mountain-shrouded bay on the eastern shore of the Adriatic Sea.

headline: Visualizing the Wikileaks War Logs
text: Last month, The New York Times ran a package of articles called “The War Logs,” based on a trove of military documents made public by the Web site WikiLeaks. The documents brought into question the military’s handling of the war in Afghanistan.

headline: On a Five-State Swing, Obama Takes Aim at Republicans
text: MIAMI  President Obama threw his weight behind Democratic governors in the battleground states of Florida and Ohio on Wednesday, while leveling blistering critiques of Republican policies that he said would put the country in further economic peril.

headline: Obama’s Struggles: Answers From Matt Bai, Part II
text: In his Political Times column published on Wednesday, Matt Bai offers one theory behind President Obama’s fading popularity, which has divided and somewhat puzzled Democrats in Washington. He answered reader questions on what he calls the “legislative box” strategy and other top Washington issues this week.

headline: In Milan, an Old Textile Factory Transformed
text: Iron sculptures spring from every corner of an architect’s cavernous home in Italy.

headline: Tai Chi Reported to Ease Fibromyalgia
text: The ancient Chinese practice of tai chi may be effective as a therapy for fibromyalgia, according to a study published on Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Stories of crime and misdemeanors — gritty, comic, fantastic and true-life — make their bid for the beach reader this month. The locations may vary, from Mumbai to Manhattan to Bad Münstereifel (it’s in Germany), but as always, the plots thicken.

headline: Huge Mortgage Bill Seen for 4 Big Banks
text: The four largest commercial banks in the United States could face as much as $42 billion in losses if they are forced to repurchase troubled mortgages from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, according to Fitch Ratings, Reuters reports.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Inside the Motorola Droid 2
text: Motorola’s new Droid 2 phone landed in stores late last week, and Kyle Wiens and the gang at iFixit.com snapped one up immediately — just to take it apart and see how all the components fit together. The iFixit site’s famous teardowns serve two purposes: to see how a device is designed from an engineering standpoint, and to see just how easily the device can be fixed and put back together — all for the purpose of writing one of the hundreds of free do-it-yourself gadget repair manuals available at iFixit.com.

headline: India’s Mining Magnates
text: Janardhana Redy and his brothers are India’s most powerful mining bosses at a time when illegal mining has become a national scandal.

headline: Attempts to Tame Indus River Contributed to Disaster in Pakistan, Expert Says
text: In a radio interview broadcast on Wednesday, Daanish Mustafa, a scholar who studies the intersection of development and water resources, told the BBC that attempts to tame the Indus River, beginning during British rule in the 19th century, laid the foundations for the deadly floods that swept Pakistan this month.

headline: The Age of Aquariums
text: Six-figure aquariums are the status symbol for some wealthy homeowners.

headline: Duncan Opponents on Hunger Strikes
text: Rep. Duncan D. Hunter’s challengers want to debate him so badly they can taste it – probably because they haven’t eaten anything for days.

headline: In Italy, a Factory Becomes an Eclectic Home

headline: From Japan, Portable Vases
text: The Hope Forever Blossoming vase, portable and made of tough but lightweight vinyl, is ideal for entertaining outdoors. It folds up for easy transport but maintains its shape when filled with water, and can hold up to eight flowers.

headline: Waterworks Introduces Bathroom Lighting Fixtures
text: Waterworks, a company known for its bathroom fittings and fixtures, is introducing an expanded range of lighting to help illuminate all that porcelain and chrome. “We wanted people to feel like they could complete their bath experience at Waterworks,” said Barbara Sallick, one of the company’s founders.

headline: Fish in the Furniture
text: IF spending five or six figures on an aquarium is not for you, there are plenty of other options guaranteed to impress friends and neighbors.

headline: At Bergdorf Goodman, Jean Boggio Furnishings
text: Bergdorf Goodman’s seventh floor recently got a major injection of color, with an installation of furniture and accessories by Jean Boggio, the French designer. Mr. Boggio, who built a following around his jewelry designs, teamed up with the manufacturer, the Franz Collection, three years ago. It is not his first foray into home furnishings — he has also created pieces for Baccarat, Haviland and Roux-Marquiand — but it is his most comprehensive collection, and this is the first time the collection has been shown in the United States. “A lot of new, exciting furniture tends to be very contemporary, and although this is contemporary in feeling, it also has a very traditional and classic element to it,” said Nicholas Manville of Bergdorf’s.

headline: Rhett Butler, Hardware Fanatic
text: Behind a fairly unassuming door on Prince Street sits a trove of hardware: about 25,000 pieces of meticulously crafted, often jewel-like hinges, locks, levers, escutcheons, pulls and the like, precisely arranged and presided over by Rhett Butler, hardware fanatic. (His first name is Edward, after his father, but he goes by his middle name, which was not inspired by “Gone With the Wind.” His mother is German, and Rhett was her second choice, when his father wouldn’t agree to Wolfgang.)

headline: Nautical Décor
text: KATHERINE RASMUSSEN, a graphic designer who owns a Brooklyn company called Reiter8, grew up in Concord, Mass., but spent summers on Cape Cod, where she learned to sail. It wasn’t until five years ago, though, that her life took a nautical tack.

headline: Sales at the Container Store, Future Perfect and Others
text: During the Container Store’s shelving sale, Aug. 23 to Oct. 17, all shelving is discounted 25 percent (left); for information and locations: (888) 266-8246 or containerstore.com.

headline: Nightwood’s Pop-Up Store Opens in Brooklyn
text: Nadia Yaron, 31, left, and Myriah Scruggs, 34, right, the owners of Nightwood, a Brooklyn furniture and textile design studio, have created a pop-up shop at be@schermerhorn, a new condominium in downtown Brooklyn.

headline: The Six-Figure Fish Tank Catches On
text: KARIN WILZIG has a hard time choosing a favorite color from among the 64 that she and her husband can use to illuminate the 14 1/2- foot, 450-gallon aquarium in their TriBeCa town house. The default is fuchsia, which turns the dozen koi a deep pink.

headline: Fish With Grilled Salsa Verde
text: 2 pounds filleted mackerel, bluefish or other oily fish, cut into 4 pieces

headline: Cooking With Dexter: Bait and Wish
text: First we’ll get the grill going hotter than a blacksmith’s forge. We’ll strip the papery wrappers from the tomatillos and lay them above the coals alongside planks of onion and a chili pepper, maybe two. I’ll flip the vegetables as they sear, and as usual, the tongs won’t be long enough to keep my hands from scorching like bare feet on the beach parking lot. The onions will char, then the peppers. The tomatillos will fight the heat, blistering in anger and spitting juice at the hissing coals, then they’ll give up and collapse in on themselves. They go back indoors, into the blender. Quickly, before the coals dim, I’ll chop the peppers and onions and a bunch of cilantro. Stir it all together, and there’s a salsa. Now to cook the fish. It’s a bluefish, an entire side, big enough to feed the whole family and some stray friends. Onto the grill it goes, skin up. We’ll close the lid so the smoke insinuates itself into the oily fillet. Turn it once. My sons will hover like thirsty mosquitoes. Now it will be time to spoon grilled salsa verde over our dinner, the freshest bluefish we’ve ever eaten and the first one landed by Dexter, our proud 6-year-old.

headline: Who Elected Me Mayor? I Did
text: ALEXANDRA HARCHAREK will never forget the first time she was anointed the “mayor” of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge in Philadelphia. It was an overcast Wednesday in April and she was driving to the city on her last day of an internship.

headline: Rebels Kill 3 in U.N. Force in Congo
text: GOMA, Democratic Republic of the Congo — A group of commandos from a Congolese rebel group ambushed a United Nations peacekeeping base hours before dawn on Wednesday, killing at least three Indian members of the base’s force with swords and spears, United Nations officials said.

headline: Leather Door Pulls and Handles From Britain
text: Woven leather, long a staple of European fashion accessories, has found its way into home furnishings. Turnstyle Designs, a British hardware company, is selling leather door pulls and handles.

headline: Palin Celebrates 19th Amendment
text: Sarah Palin didn’t have the best batting average with her endorsements on Tuesday. But that didn’t stop her from announcing her support for a new crop of candidates on Wednesday.

headline: A Pattern
text: Rod R. Blagojevich appears to favor a variation on the same look: dark suit, white shirt and medium blue ties.

headline: After a Storm, a Garden Is Remade
text: Five months after a storm sent the Hudson River surging over the garden of Joan Dye Gussow, a pioneering nutritionist and and matriarch of the eat-locally-think-globally food movement, the plot reflects changes she had long wanted to make.

headline: When Opposites Influence
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Injury Isn’t Too Deep, but Neither Are the Giants at Quarterback
text: ALBANY  Some members of the Giants’ offensive line wore bandages on their foreheads as they walked to lunch at training camp Wednesday. Instead of protecting injuries, they were poking fun at quarterback Eli Manning and the most famous three-inch cut in New York.

headline: Three Low-Key Birthdays at White House
text: The White House hasn’t had a lot to celebrate on the economic front lately, so you’d think the shared birthday on Wednesday of three members of President Obama’s economic team would provide some excuse for staff festivity.

headline: Debating the Claims Behind Wrinkle Creams
text: BEFORE StriVectin’s stretch-mark cream became an anti-wrinkle blockbuster sold in Sephora and Bloomingdale’s, it made its debut in 2002 at GNC, a retailer better known for its muscle-building supplements.

headline: Favre Returns to Vikings
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Near the end of a rambling news conference to discuss his return to the Minnesota Vikings, Brett Favre said something Wednesday that was easy to scoff at: this season will be his last in the N.F.L.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: SMELLS GOOD TO OPRAH Call it rookie luck. My Life, the first fragrance by the singer Mary J. Blige, recently went on sale exclusively at HSN, and it became the network’s No. 1 perfume debut in a 24-hour period. More than 60,000 units of the fragrance, which has hints of pear, gardenia and jasmine, sold in less than six hours. It couldn’t have hurt that Oprah Winfrey called to lend her support, even though it was “so far past her bedtime,” as Ms. Winfrey put it. A 1.7-ounce bottle is $55 at hsn.com. CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

headline: It’s More Caution Than Concern With Pettitte
text: In Andy Pettitte’s head, it all worked out. He knew exactly where he would pitch, how many he pitches would throw and when he would throw them. The gradual progression did not bother him, for in the end he expected to be pitching for the Yankees 10 days ago. Or, at the very latest, last weekend against Kansas City.

text: IRVINE, Calif.  At the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, Bob Bowman was standing nearby as Ryan Lochte regaled reporters with his balanced diet: McDonald’s for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

text: CHICAGO  This state’s long, troubled, expensive episode with Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor, appears far from over.

headline: Constant Gardens for New York
text: “THE best place to find God is in a garden,” George Bernard Shaw wrote. “You can dig for him there.” Anyone who has ever cleared his mind while clearing weeds from a flower patch, or enjoyed a quiet moment while watering plants, knows what Shaw meant.

headline: Civilians to Take U.S. Lead as Military Leaves Iraq
text: WASHINGTON  As the United States military prepares to leave Iraq by the end of 2011, the Obama administration is planning a remarkable civilian effort, buttressed by a small army of contractors, to fill the void.

text: The combat mission in Iraq doesn’t officially end until Aug. 31 but viewers and readers could be forgiven for thinking it ended tonight.

text: After her mastectomy in April, Alantheia Pena cried for the loss of her breast. Her partner told her not to worry about the flat spot on her chest, but she could tell it bothered him when he looked away as she took off her shirt.

text: COTONOU, Benin  It started as a tip between friends, an unheard-of chance to pile up riches in a poor land. How could you go wrong with a good-works company, apparently tight with the government, promising interest of 50 and 100 percent, maybe even higher?

text: BOSTON  Sheriff Andrea Cabral of Suffolk County on Wednesday defended procedures at the jail where a former medical student accused of murder committed suicide using a scalpel he fashioned out of a pen and piece of metal.

text: OTTAWA  Less than 24 hours after being bluntly rebuffed by the board of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, BHP Billiton took its $38.6 billion offer directly to shareholders on Wednesday.

text: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Facebook introduced a long-anticipated service called Places on Wednesday that could help the company tap local and small-business advertisers and sharpen its competition with Google.

text: The Giants began selling single-game tickets without personal seat licenses on Wednesday, making them available first to current license holders and then to fans on the team’s waiting list before the public can buy them.

headline: In Afghanistan, More Attacks on Officials and a Protest Over a Deadly NATO Raid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Violence struck southern Afghanistan on Wednesday, with attacks on government and security officials. There were also allegations that NATO forces had killed two civilians in a night raid in the northeast, although the military sharply disputed that.

headline: Voter (and Customer) Beware
text: The Target Corporation has a well-earned reputation for hiring and advancing the rights of people who are gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender. But a controversial political donation has stirred the nationwide wrath of gay and lesbian groups that previously had praised the retail chain. Target apologized after its $150,000 contribution to an organization supporting Tom Emmer, the aggressively antigay Republican candidate for governor of Minnesota, was publicly disclosed, as required by Minnesota law.

headline: In Defining Obama, Misperceptions Stick
text: WASHINGTON  Americans need only stand in line at the grocery checkout counter to glimpse the conspiracy theories percolating about President Obama. “Birthplace Cover-Up,” screams the current issue of the racy tabloid Globe. “Obama’s Secret Life Exposed!”

headline: No, He Did Not Invent the Publicity Stunt
text: IF Edward Bernays was the philosophical father of public relations, Mortimer Matz might be considered the godfather of pragmatic press agentry. Mr. Matz, 86, is working on his 50th year as a full-time (10 years earlier, part-time) inventive yet veracious mastermind of promotion and protector of reputations (of unions, developers, lawyers, seven congressmen and Mario M. Cuomo, among others). Early clients included the developers Seymour Durst and Harry Helmsley, both of whom opposed the original World Trade Center. He still advises the Durst Organization, which just bought a stake in 1 World Trade Center.

headline: Decision on Minaya Will Be Telling for Mets
text: The Mets have every reason to be furious about their season. They are buried in the standings. Attendance is down by more than 5,000 fans a game. Their low-cost players are producing, but most of their expensive players have flopped. They did not expect to hover around .500 all summer.

headline: Protests in Kashmir Test India’s Inclusive Ideals
text: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  It is hard these days to find a far-flung corner of the world’s largest democracy that is not caught up in some fractious struggle. On India’s northeastern fringes, ethnic minorities agitate for independence. In its forested heartland, a Maoist uprising seeks to overthrow the government. Caste, religion, gender and poverty  these are all fault lines that tear at India’s fabric.

headline: Venture to Operate TV in India
text: The CBS Corporation is entering the fast-growing television market in India in a joint venture with the Reliance Broadcast Network.

headline: Parents Need to Know
text: Parents in New York City are understandably worried about the performance of students on this year’s state math and reading tests. But an angry, jeering community group, equipped with a bullhorn, did children no favor when it disrupted a meeting this week where city education officials tried to calm fears about the new approach to testing.

headline: The Candidate and the Charity
text: Haiti’s election commission has been vetting the applications of nearly three dozen aspiring presidential candidates. The list of who has qualified for the Nov. 28 ballot is due on Friday, and there is a lot of buzz  here and there  about whether Wyclef Jean, the hip-hop star, philanthropist and entrepreneur, will be on it.

headline: U.S. Strategy in Pakistan Is Upended by Floods
text: WASHINGTON  The floods in Pakistan have upended the Obama administration’s carefully honed strategy there, confronting the United States with a vast humanitarian crisis and militant groups determined to exploit the misery, in a country that was already one of its thorniest problems.

headline: Founder Terminating Hedge Fund
text: Stanley F. Druckenmiller, the hedge fund titan who led George Soros’s famous bet against the British pound, told clients on Wednesday that he was quitting the business and shutting down his investment firm, Duquesne Capital, after 30 years.

headline: In Race for an Assembly Seat, a Challenger Courts the Bangladeshi Vote
text: Like most New York State lawmakers, Peter M. Rivera, a nine-term Democratic assemblyman, has never had to worry much about job security. He has won his last two races with more than 10 times as many votes as his rivals.

text: PHILADELPHIA  They made an impressive display of America’s seafaring might, the aging maritime stars moored along both sides of the Delaware River.

text: PORTLAND, Me. — Even as this city has evolved into a showplace for locavore restaurants and edgy designers, its working waterfront has remained a point of pride.

text: CHICAGO  As the jurors in the corruption case against Rod R. Blagojevich, the former Illinois governor, entered a 25th-floor conference room here, one problem was instantly clear: They were overwhelmed.

text: Stock-car race tracks outside Los Angeles and Atlanta each lost one of their two annual races in the 36-race 2011 Sprint Cup Series schedule, which was released Wednesday. Kentucky Speedway got its first top-series race, and Kansas Speedway will host a second race.

text: CHICAGO — The Chicago Cubs hosted the San Diego Padres on Wednesday, but judging from the team they put on the field, they might as well have been playing at their spring-training home in Arizona.

headline: Few Precedents for Mets’ Attempt to Rework Rodriguez’s Contract
text: When the Mets announced Tuesday that they would no longer guarantee the remainder of Francisco Rodriguez’s contract, they were taking a step that was virtually unprecedented in Major League Baseball.

text: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, the leader of the Roman Catholic Church in New York, said Wednesday that he would gladly help mediate between the proponents and critics of an Islamic center and mosque planned for a site two blocks from ground zero.

headline: Fraud, Theft and Other Charges for Operators of a Queens Bingo Hall
text: The bingo hall operated out of an old theater in Jackson Heights, Queens. “Win big money,” a mural inside said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mets Are Getting Younger, but Older Pitcher Has Been a Key
text: HOUSTON  The Mets appear to be getting younger as they spend less on free agents and more on draft picks and use more rookies in place of high-priced veterans.

headline: South Africa: Public-Sector Strike
text: Nurses, teachers and other government employees began a strike on Wednesday, demanding an 8.6 percent raise. The government has said it can afford only 7 percent.

headline: Mexico: Mayor’s Body Is Found
text: The body of a small-town mayor who was kidnapped Sunday was found dumped by the side of a road on Wednesday, officials from the northern state of Nuevo León said. The mayor, Edelmiro Cavazos, had been fighting corruption in the police force of his town, Santiago, south of Monterrey.

headline: ‘Nightly Business Report’ Sold by PBS Station
text: “Nightly Business Report” on PBS, by some measures the nation’s most-watched business newscast, has been acquired from its owner, the public station WPBT-TV in Miami, by a private company headed by Mykalai Kontilai, a former manager of mixed martial artists and distributor of instructional television programs.

headline: John P. Fishwick, Railroad Executive, Dies at 93
text: John P. Fishwick, a retired railroad executive who paved the way for a merger that created one of the nation’s top railroad companies, Norfolk Southern, died on Aug. 9 in Roanoke, Va. He was 93.

headline: High-Tech Knee Holds Promise for Veterans
text: John Loosen has worn a prosthetic leg long enough  four decades  that it is second nature. But there are still simple movements that are struggles against gravity: walking down hills or up stairs, stepping backward or over obstacles, swinging a golf club.

headline: Kerry Wood Holds Fort in Yankees’ Victory
text: There is not a ballpark  or, for that matter, a pitcher  capable of silencing Miguel Cabrera, a reality that struck the Yankees two times Wednesday night but not a third. His first time up, Cabrera homered. His second time up, Cabrera homered again. As the Detroit Tigers, trailing by three runs, loaded the bases in the seventh inning, Cabrera was well on the mind of Manager Joe Girardi.

headline: Killings of Homeless Rise to Highest Level in a Decade
text: WASHINGTON  Killings of homeless people have risen to their highest level in a decade, with 43 people killed last year and many more injured in often brutal attacks that are raising concerns among law enforcement officials, rights advocates and politicians, according to new data due to be released this week.

headline: A Town Touched by Scandal Withholds Judgment
text: RIDGEFIELD, N.J.  Much of the nation seems to have a “throw the bums out” approach to politics these days, even when the bums in question have done little harm. But in this corner of this ethically challenged state, where the mayor refused to leave City Hall even after getting indicted, the prevailing view seems to be more like “not so fast.”

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 18
text: A view of the day in sports, including the Youth Olympic Games in Singapore.

headline: Chelsea Handler Will Host MTV Video Music Awards
text: She’s already the rare woman on the roster of late-night comedy hosts, and now Chelsea Handler, the star of the E! network series “Chelsea Lately,” is about to join another mostly male club. On Wednesday, she was officially announced as the host of the 2010 MTV Video Music Awards, which will be shown on Sept. 12. That makes Ms. Handler the first woman to get the gig since 2007 (when the program was hosted by Sarah Silverman) and only the fourth female M.C. to come from outside MTV’s walls (the awards program was hosted by Roseanne Barr in 1994, and Bette Midler was a co-host in its 1984 debut.)

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Friday about a new untitled crime drama coming to AMC next year misstated the contribution of Veena Sud, a writer and executive producer on the new series, to the recently canceled CBS show “Cold Case.” She was a producer and a writer for “Cold Case,” not the creator. (Meredith Stiehm created the series.)

headline: Insurers Feeling Pain of Dog Bites
text: Dog bites cost American home insurers 6.4 percent more in 2009 than in the previous year, with the average claim exceeding $24,000 for the third straight year, an industry group said Wednesday. The injuries cost $412 million in 2009, compared with $387.2 million a year earlier, the fifth straight increase, the Insurance Information Institute said. The number of claims increased 4.8 percent to 16,586.

headline: Florida: Alternatives to Relief Well Considered
text: BP engineers and government scientists are evaluating alternatives for proceeding with a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in the Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico, the leader of the federal response to the disaster said Wednesday in Cedar Key. The official, Thad W. Allen, a retired Coast Guard admiral, said there was no timetable for completing the relief well. But he said that in the meantime, BP was preparing to replace the damaged blowout preventer on the Macondo well with a new one, which could be used to help manage pressure within the well. BP has estimated that there are about 1,000 barrels of oil in the Macondo well, trapped between seals at the top and cement at the bottom that was pumped in this month. One concern is that using the relief well to pump more cement into the Macondo well could raise the pressure within that well, damage the seals and, potentially, result in a spill of the oil.

headline: WikiLeaks and Pentagon Disagree About Talks
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon on Wednesday rebutted statements by the WikiLeaks organization that the Defense Department had expressed a willingness to discuss reviewing a trove of classified documents before public release.

headline: Georgia: Governor Wants Inquiry Into Cheating
text: Gov. Sonny Perdue of Georgia said Wednesday that he would appoint a special investigator with subpoena power to look into possible cheating on standardized tests in two public school systems. A state review this year found an unusually high number of erasures on tests taken in 2009, suggesting teachers might have corrected students’ answers. The two school systems, in Atlanta and Dougherty County, in southern Georgia, have conducted investigations, but Mr. Perdue said those were “woefully inadequate.” Atlanta investigators have already turned over the names of 109 teachers and administrators to the school district for further review.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,212 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

headline: Notable New Yorkers, Imported From Scotland
text: The Staten Island Scot left us on Monday. Bobby Thomson died at age 86, almost 59 years after hitting the “shot heard round the world” out of the Polo Grounds and sending the New York Giants to the World Series.

headline: Preliminary Tests Find Elevated PCB Levels in 3 Public Schools
text: Elevated levels of toxic chemical compounds were found in the first three New York City public school buildings tested in a pilot study meant to assess the risks posed by PCBs, according to preliminary results.

headline: Chelsea Handler to Host MTV Awards
text: She is already the rare woman on the roster of late-night comedy hosts, and now Chelsea Handler, the star of the E! network series “Chelsea Lately,” is about to join another mostly male club.

headline: Violations on Pricing at Groceries
text: In a sweep of more than 700 supermarkets across the city, inspectors from the Department of Consumer Affairs found pricing violations in more than half of them, the agency announced on Wednesday.

headline: Finding New Ways to Fill the Tank
text: Most research on renewable energy has focused on replacing the electricity that now comes from burning coal and natural gas. But the spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the reliance on Middle East imports and the threat of global warming are reminders that oil is also a pressing worry. A lot of problems could be solved with a renewable replacement for oil-based gasoline and diesel in the fuel tank — either a new liquid fuel or a much better battery, Matthew L. Wald reports in The New York Times.

headline: Och-Ziff Says S.E.C. Inquiry Went Nowhere
text: Och-Ziff Capital Management Group was a subject of a regulatory probe surrounding Lehman Brothers‘ 2008 collapse but the investigation went “nowhere,” a lawyer for the fund company said Wednesday, Reuters reported.

headline: With Ruling, Madoff Feeder Faces Fewer Claims
text: A federal judge refused to dismiss an investor lawsuit against Fairfield Greenwich Group, a hedge fund firm accused of funneling money to the now-imprisoned Bernard Madoff for his massive Ponzi scheme.

headline: Hewlett Taps Firm to Lead C.E.O. Search
text: Hewlett-Packard on Wednesday named executive search firm Spencer Stuart to lead the search for a new chief executive following the stunning ouster of Mark Hurd this month, Reuters reports.

text: Facebook introduced a long-anticipated service called Places on Wednesday that could help the company tap local and small-business advertisers and sharpen its competition with Google, Miguel Helft and Jenna Wortham report in The New York Times.

headline: What Artists Do You Consider ‘Sellouts’? Why?
text: The new album by indie band Arcade Fire is currently No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Music critic Ben Sisario writes about those who say this band, “the current standard-bearer for do-it-yourself musical virtue,” has “sold out.” What do you think? What does it mean to be “indie”? Should artists in general do whatever they have to do to survive in today’s economy, whether it’s making lucrative deals with Amazon or selling their songs for use on commercials?

headline: Bank Capital Rules May Eventually Foster Growth
text: New international regulations on how much capital banks must hold will initially make borrowing more expensive and dampen economic growth, according to two studies released Wednesday by the central bankers and regulators who are writing the new rules, Jack Ewing reported for The New York Times.

headline: Despite Negative Result on Fischer Paternity, Lawyer Keeps On Fighting
text: The Filipino lawyer for a woman who filed a paternity lawsuit claiming that Bobby Fischer, the late chess champion, was the father of her daughter, has criticized how tissue samples were obtained to perform the DNA tests. The test, which reportedly came back negative on Tuesday, was ordered by the Supreme Court of Iceland as part of a dispute over Mr. Fischer’s estate.

text: A derelict building has a kind of haunting beauty, appealing to the casual viewer and the student of history. When the photographer Matt McDonough began exploring abandoned mental asylums, however, he sought to transcend the architectural mystique.

headline: Cooling Down on a Roman Night
text: When it’s hot in Rome, survival instincts kick in. City dwellers tend to stay indoors, with their shutters closed tight against the blazing sun. When they do venture outside during the day, there is fierce competition for shade and it’s every man for himself. Evenings are much more civil, however, as Rome wakes up from its heat-induced slumber and people hit the local piazza or neighborhood bar. This ritual, called aperitivo, is a sort of Italian happy hour in which drinks are consumed sparingly and always in the company of snacks.

headline: Mandela Aide Quits Over Diamonds
text: PARIS  The tangled saga involving the supermodel Naomi Campbell, Nelson Mandela and the former Liberian dictator Charles G. Taylor claimed a victim on Thursday when a trustee of the Nelson Mandela Children’s Fund resigned over his decision to remain silent about receiving uncut diamonds from Ms. Campbell 13 years ago.

headline: The Battle for Stuyvesant Town: First Shots Fired

headline: The New Urban Era
text: Today’s idea: In something of a throwback to the Middle Ages, the 21st century will not be dominated by America or China, Brazil or India, but by the city, an article says. “This new world is not — and will not be — one global village, so much as a network of different ones.”

headline: Jennifer Egan: Gallery of a Writer’s Impulses
text: At dinner with a friend recently, the subject of writers’ Web sites came up, and this friend mentioned Jennifer Egan’s Web site, which she said was “incredible” or “amazing” or some such superlative. As this friend is not the sort to indulge in reckless superlative tossing, I went home and, as soon as I had a spare moment, looked up Egan’s site. That “moment” turned into at least an hour.The site isn’t your standard author-Web-site fare. Yes, there are the usual pages cataloging books, interviews, other writings, reviews. There are several examples of the “standard ‘grinning mug,’” as Egan herself describes her author photos. But these requisites are handled discreetly. The bolder elements, the first to catch the reader’s eye, are the names of places and dates.

headline: MasterCard to Buy DataCash for $520 Million

headline: Serenity Now: Lewis Black Protests ‘Eat Pray Love’
text: Predictable: Lewis Black, the volatile “Daily Show” commentator, was not a fan of the film version of “Eat Pray Love,” which stars Julia Roberts as the globe-trotting, enlightenment-seeking author Elizabeth Gilbert. Not predictable: Mr. Black says — at least for the sake of the above comedic rant — the movie didn’t do justice to “the book that made me the spiritually fulfilled vessel of inner peace that you see before you.” We’re, like, 99 percent sure the guy is joking, but those tremors in his hands as he narrates his disappointment with the crass commercialization of the “Eat Pray Love” franchise seems very, very real.

headline: Tress Test
text: Would Catherine Deneuve have made as convincing an ice maiden had she been a brunette? That question gets explored in depth in ‘‘Brune/Blonde,’’ an exhibition by Alain Bergala opening this October at the Cinémathèque Française in Paris. Blondes, as it turns out, were most often cast as housewives until the 1930s, when flaxen-haired women became typecast as sultry and dangerous. A book of the same name will be released concurrently and include essays by film and cultural historians like Michelle Perrot, Dominique Païni and Stéphane Guéguan, along with an interview with Deneuve herself. And to get to the root (pun intended) of the issue, ‘‘Brune/Blonde’’ looks beyond cinema to the significance of women’s hair color in art (Alphonse Mucha, Francesca Woodman) and mythology. Somehow we already knew Rapunzel couldn’t have pulled off a Louise Brooks.

headline: The Stealth Debt Restructuring: Inflation
text: Europe’s sovereign debt crisis seems to have gone on holiday along with most of the rest of the Continent during August. But many economists warn that the underlying debt problem is merely in remission and could recur at any moment, once again upsetting world markets.

headline: Brooklyn Museum to Extend Hours
text: Beginning Oct. 6, the Brooklyn Museum will keep later hours, the museum announced, staying open until 6 p.m. on Wednesdays and 10 p.m. on Thursdays and Fridays. (It is currently open until 5 p.m. on those days.) To offset the change, the museum will open an hour later, at 11 a.m. Weekend hours, from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., will remain the same.

headline: Two Running Stars Train While Pregnant
text: Runners Paula Radcliffe and Kara Goucher are famous for standout performances in the marathon and other events. Now both women, pregnant and due on the same day in September, are also training together during pregnancy.

headline: Helping a Toddler Grieve
text: Daniel Cho was a cellist. He said good-bye to his wife, Julia, and his 22-month-old daughter, Audrey, when he left on a European tour in June — a few weeks of touring with Regina Spektor. He was making his mark in the music world after years of working two jobs and chasing a dream. The day before he was to appear with Spektor at the Montreux Jazz Festival in Switzerland, he went to Lake Geneva, showed friends some videos of Audrey that he carried on his iPhone, left his phone and wallet on a towel and went for a swim. What happened next is not clear, perhaps never will be, but somehow Dan, who was a strong swimmer, drowned. He was 33.

headline: A Man With a Memorial: Vonnegut Library to Open in the Fall
text: Though he may or may not continue to exist in the Tralfamadorian sense of the word, a part of Kurt Vonnegut will live on in an Indianapolis library dedicated to him that will contain artifacts from his life and career. The Associated Press reported on Wednesday that the Kurt Vonnegut Memorial Library will have its opening in November, where it will display first-edition books by the “Slaughterhouse Five” and “Sirens of Titans” author, who died in 2007, as well as a replica of his writing studio, items he collected during his service in World War II and numerous rejection letters he received before achieving his literary fame.

headline: From ‘Idol’ to Broadway: Justin Guarini Joins ‘Women on the Verge’ Musical
text: Months before the official opening of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,” theatergoers have thrilled to each incremental casting announcement for this musical adaptation of the Pedro Almodóvar comedy, as celebrated Broadway stars like Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott and Laura Benanti were added to its ensemble. Who, these impatient observers wondered, would be cast in the final principal role of this production? Now they have their answer.Justin Guarini, the runner-up on the first-ever season of “American Idol,” has joined the musical’s cast, Lincoln Center Theater said on Thursday. Mr. Guarini, who was edged out by Kelly Clarkson for the “Idol” crown in 2002, will play the role of Carlos, the son of Ivan (Mr. Mitchell) and Lucia (Ms. LuPone). It will be the Broadway debut of Mr. Guarini, who previously appeared in a workshop version of the Beach Boys musical “Good Vibrations” and with Ms. Clarkson in the film “From Justin to Kelly.”

headline: Mailbag: Meet the Tolstoys
text: In last Sunday’s Book Review, we published a letter from Peter Crane of Seattle commenting on Jay Parini’s recent review of “Sophia Tolstoy: A Biography.” Crane’s great-grandfather Raphael Löwenfeld , who was Tolstoy’s German translator and biographer, had visited the Tolstoys at their estate, Crane writes, and he was distressed by Sophia’s ill-treatment by Leo Tolstoy’s disciples — one subject of the book Parini reviewed. It was an interesting story, and we asked him to expand on it.
