headline: Seeing Things | Free City Goes Hollywood
text: Free City, Nina Garduno’s creative enterprise that is equal parts shop, gathering place and artistic outpost, recently vacated its storefront in the Malibu Country Mart in preparation for a move to Hollywood. I visited Garduno last week at Free City’s workshop, just around the corner from its new space under construction on Highland Avenue, for a sneak peek at what will be on offer in the new Free City Supershop Supermat.

headline: Chase’s New Robbery Deterrence Trick
text: It’s hard to look forward to a visit to the bank, especially if the bank teller behind the window turns out to be terse or, worse, just walks away.

headline: Berkman Placed on Disabled List
text: Yankees designated hitter Lance Berkman said Thursday that his sprained right ankle was still swollen and still tender, but “if there was a doberman chasing me, I think I could be all right.” Maybe so, but the Yankees think otherwise.

headline: Clay Mates
text: Animals often pair up with humans in Nathalie Djurberg’s Claymation videos, so it wasn’t a surprise to see a blue snake bat yellow goo-goo eyes at a naked yogi in the Swedish-born artist’s latest work, “Snakes Know It’s Yoga.” What was strange was the setting for the installation: the basement of the Natural History Museum in Basel, Switzerland, this past June. Then again, a storeroom full of animal bones was appropriate for an artist whose territory lies somewhere between the grotesques of Goya and the darker regions of Pee-wee’s Playhouse.

headline: Geraldine Brooks Wins Literary Peace Prize
text: Geraldine Brooks, a novelist and journalist who covered conflicts in the Balkans, the Middle East and Africa, was named the recipient of the 2010 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for Lifetime Achievement, its organizers said on Thursday. Sharon Rab, the founder and a chairwoman of the Dayton Literary Peace Prize Foundation, said that Ms. Brooks “reveals to her readers what their political leaders try to hide — the ugly realities of conflict and its destructive effects even on those far from the frontlines.” She continued, “We are delighted to be honoring a writer whose skill, imagination, and unique background allow her to create vivid characters whose stories help people understand the vital importance of fostering peace throughout the world.” Ms. Brooks, 54, also the winner of the Pulitzer Prize in fiction in 2006, for her novel “March,” will receive a $10,000 prize.

headline: Quote Unquote | Stuff It
text: –Model Elle Macpherson discusses her diet, or lack there of. Makes women everywhere hate her.

headline: Lloyd Blankfein Sells Park Avenue Co-op
text: AS the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Lloyd C. Blankfein has drawn an unusual amount of publicity for a leader of a financial firm. He has been on countless front pages and has had a front-row seat at more than a few Senate hearings. So one might wonder when he has time to buy and sell Manhattan real estate.

headline: Glaxo Memo on Avandia Is Questioned
text: Federal drug regulators ordered GlaxoSmithKline to send a letter to key doctors describing a July expert advisory panel that discussed the risks of Avandia, the company’s controversial diabetes medicine. But the company’s letter is misleading and could endanger patients, a federal official and some members of the panel said. (Text of the letter.)

headline: Clemens Lied About Doping, Indictment Charges
text: Roger Clemens, the larger-than-life pitcher who appeared destined for the Baseball Hall of Fame, was indicted by a federal grand jury in Washington on Thursday on charges that he lied to Congress when he said he never used performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Time Poll: Many Americans Have Suspicious Views of Islam
text: A poll released on Thursday by Time magazine found that many Americans express suspicious views of Islam, and more say that building a Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero in New York City would be an insult to the victims of 9/11 than say it would serve as a symbol of religious tolerance.

headline: Fete Accompli | Target at The Standard
text: “Look up” might have been the catch phrase of last night’s Target Kaleidoscope Fashion Spectacular at the Standard Hotel but there was plenty to dazzle the eye everywhere you turned. Even before the entire south side of the hotel was transformed into a neon spectacular featuring 66 models in 155 rooms, a visual feast that hinted at artist In Sook Kim’s “Saturday Night” voyeuristic hotel series, the Standard’s biergarten was a light show of flashing rave rings and bright psychedelic bellinis. Holding court in the middle of the colorful fray were “Gossip Girl” sweetheart Penn Badgley, Prabal Gurung, Richard Chai, Marchesa’s Georgina Chapman and hubby, Harvey Weinstein. Elsewhere, little Langley Hemingway and Leigh Lezark, who dominated in a game of table tennis earlier in the night, huddled in a secluded corner. In other words, plenty of eye candy for the onlookers on Washington Street craning their necks to spy on the invited peeping Toms.

headline: Q&A: A 10-Year-Old American in Paris
text: Q.

headline: Bill O’Reilly Distances Himself From Investment Scheme
text: Updated throughout: This summer Bill O’Reilly, the biggest star on Fox News Channel, lent his name — inadvertently, he claims — to a dubious financial scheme peddled by Newsmax, the right-wing Web site.

headline: When Doctors Admit Their Mistakes
text: One afternoon, I overheard a nurse asking another physician how she was feeling. The physician, a young woman known throughout the hospital for her cheery disposition and sunny bedside manner, looked ashen. She smiled weakly in response and insisted that nothing was wrong.

headline: Talking to Patients After a Medical Mistake
On 42nd Street, a Rare Double Rat Sighting
text: Tourists shuffling out of Grand Central Terminal would be forgiven for wondering what the heck kind of low-rent horror movie about giant rats is being filmed on East 42nd Street. Immobile, fat and grinning with big yellow teeth — yikes!

headline: Kia to Reveal Pop, a Zero-Emissions Concept Car, in Paris
text: Kia has offered a preview of a zero-emissions city car concept that it will unveil at the Paris auto show on Sept. 30. The Pop concept, as it is called, is about a foot longer than a Smart Fortwo and offers seating for three.

headline: TimesCast | August 19, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on how much longer the U.S. will need to stay in Iraq, misperceptions of President Obama and the benefits of laughing yoga.

headline: Shrinking ‘Quant’ Funds Struggle to Revive Boom
text: They were revered as the brightest minds in finance, the “quants” who could outwit Wall Street with their Ph.D.’s and superfast computers.

headline: Basking in Energy-Efficient A.C.
text: Of all the things I could spend $8,800 to buy, a new central air-conditioning system is not near the top of my most-wanted list. But that’s what I did this week, and I actually feel pretty good about it.

headline: As Airgas Meeting Nears, Deal Battle Continues
text: With Airgas‘s shareholder meeting nearing — it’s scheduled for Sept. 15 — the battle between the industrial gases company and its unwanted solicitor, Air Products and Chemicals, is heating up.

headline: Bill Millin, Scottish D-Day Piper, Dies at 88
text: LONDON  Bill Millin, a Scottish bagpiper who played highland tunes as his fellow commandos landed on a Normandy beach on D-Day and lived to see his bravado immortalized in the 1962 film “The Longest Day,” died on Wednesday in a hospital in the western England county of Devon. He was 88.

headline: A High School Student Reviews a Smartpen, the Livescribe Echo
text: Each summer, I’m joined by a summer intern, a high school or college student who, for some reason, has become fascinated by the inner workings of a tech critic’s life. This year, it was high school senior Matt Gibstein, who hails from Miami and made my life a lot easier this summer.

headline: There May Be No Business Like Shoe Business to Help Businesses That Help the Poor
text: The luxury goods maker Salvatore Ferragamo is teaming up with a nonprofit organization that invests in businesses that helps the world’s poor — i.e., the billions of folks who cannot afford luxury goods.

headline: City Employee Raped in Playground
text: A Parks Department employee was sexually assaulted by a man armed with a box-cutter in a Brooklyn playground on Thursday morning, according to the police.

headline: Motor City’s Woodward Dream Cruise Remains a Suburban Affair
text: In southeastern Michigan, the third Saturday of August is reserved for car worship. Lawns go unmowed and errands are postponed as some 1.5 million people descend on one of the Detroit area’s best-known thoroughfares, Woodward Avenue, for an ad hoc parade of vintage automobiles that pays tribute to Detroit’s glory days.

headline: Giuliani Says Mosque Near Ground Zero Is Offensive
text: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said Thursday that a proposed Islamic cultural center and mosque near ground zero would “horribly offend” families of 9/11 victims and should be built elsewhere.

headline: What We’re Reading: Tracking Sales From the Sky
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: How a Life Insurance Consultant Set Up His Own Policies
text: Peter Katt, a fee-only life insurance consultant based in Mattawan, Mich., has bought $6 million worth of life insurance, as much as insurers will allow him to get based on his income and net worth.

headline: Another Take on Crostini
text: I based Tuesday’s column on a peach crostini I tasted at Roman’s in Brooklyn last month. More recently, I returned to the restaurant. The crostini was off the menu, and in its place was a special of figs nestled on a bed of ricotta, topped with spiky arugula. It was reminiscent of the crostini – the sweet fruit, creamy cheese and tangy greens – but without the crunch of toasted bread. I liked the dish a lot, especially the luscious figs, which were grown as locally as you can get: in the Bushwick backyard of Scarlett Lindeman, one of the cooks.

headline: A Pop Cartoon Springs Out of the Playbook
text: KATY PERRY was sinking. It was a listening party for her new album, “Teenage Dream,” and there was a beach theme, with palm trees, surfboards and gallons of sand trucked in to decorate a Midtown event space. If she were Lady Gaga she might have required a walkway built of trellised stuffed animals or prostrate assistants; instead there were just models in bikinis, eating cotton candy and tossing a beach ball: postcard Americana. Ms. Perry wasn’t happy when she saw the small desert between her and her seat  “I don’t want sand in my stilettos,” she said, pouting, echoing one of her lyrics  but she is just a regular girl gone big, so she gamely tottered across the sand in her four-inch platforms, the heels disappearing with each step. Wearing flip-flops isn’t really in the pop star playbook.

headline: Popcast: Is Katy Perry for Real?
text: On this week’s Popcast, The Times’s music podcast, Melena Ryzik discusses Ms. Perry’s persona as a playfully hypersexual pop star who has never fully discarded what she calls the “pick-and-choose” Christian beliefs she grew up with.

headline: Public Confidence in Health Care Dips
text: The American public’s confidence in the health care system rose markedly after passage of the sprawling legislative package this year, according to a survey released on Wednesday by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

headline: Police Sergeant Says Suspect Shot First in 50-Shot Gunfight in Harlem
text: Updated, Friday | A later and more complete version of this story can be read here.

headline: Teaching Steinbeck and ‘The Grapes of Wrath’ With The New York Times
text: “The bank is something more than men, I tell you. It’s the monster. Men made it, but they can’t control it.”–From “The Grapes of Wrath,” Chapter 5

headline: Par-Dons
text: People who divide their time between Paris and London.

headline: Excerpt: 'Power Balladz'
text: Mary Mossberg sings "Alone," a song by the band Heart, in the new Off Broadway show "Power Balladz," at the Midtown Theater. (Video courtesy of Applause Video Productions)

headline: Wheat Farmers Ponder the Future
text: As Russia faces a devastating drought, farmers in Baca County, Colo., perhaps the most fragile and history-fraught corner of the United States’s breadbasket, are scared.

headline: U.S. Farmers Wary of Gaining From Russia’s Woes
text: SPRINGFIELD, Colo.  Russia’s ban on grain exports, in response to a devastating drought, has sent prices shooting up all over the world. But farmers here in wheat country, far from seeing the spike as an unexpected blessing, are wary.

headline: Flood Brings Chaos Back to Pakistan’s Swat Valley
text: JARAY, Pakistan  Life in the Swat Valley had been torn apart long before floodwaters poured through, toppling homes and destroying crops, livestock and livelihoods.

headline: Federer Coy on Trick Shot Video
text: MASON, Ohio — Did Roger Federer really do it? The tennis champion was decidedly coy about the stunt where he apparently hit a metal bottle off someone’s head with a serve during a commercial shoot. The video has been viewed on YouTube about 2.3 million times, and people have been busily trying to determine if it was real or was the latest sleight-of-mouse trick of video editing. If it’s fake, then the person who put it together should be getting some credit.

headline: Meanwhile, in Other Big News From McAfee. . .
text: At 8 a.m. on Thursday, McAfee, the antivirus software maker, issued an eye-catching news release: “Cameron Diaz Named Most Dangerous Celebrity in Cyberspace by McAfee Inc.; Justin Timberlake’s Ex Knocks Current Girlfriend Biel to #3 Spot.”

headline: Reanimated ‘Junk’ DNA Is Found to Cause Disease
text: The human genome is riddled with dead genes, fossils of a sort, dating back hundreds of thousands of years — the genome’s equivalent of an attic full of broken and useless junk.

headline: A Response to Andrew Sullivan (I)
text: To round out my comments on gay marriage, I’m going start by taking up the second half of Andrew Sullivan’s criticism of my original column, because that’s where you’ll find his most powerful argument: Namely, that opponents of gay marriage are ignoring the reality of gay lives, the integration of gay couples into mainstream American culture, and the fact that homosexuality isn’t going to (and shouldn’t have to) slip back into some kind of closet in order to keep lifelong heterosexual monogamy safely on its pedestal. What’s more, by ignoring these realities and failing to offer gay couples any institutional support, we are guilty of … well, I’ll let Sullivan take over from here:

headline: A Packer Hears Cheers Instead of Leading Them
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Quinn Porter, a rookie running back for the Green Bay Packers, was toweling off in front of his locker at Lambeau Field after practice when two of his teammates turned from their own lockers, their faces painted with grins.

headline: Design a Better Ballot
text: In the September primary, civic-minded New Yorkers will be greeted with new ballots and voting machines. The familiar quaint curtains and squeaky levers have been relegated to antiquity. In their place are multiple-choice ballots evoking SAT bubbles and A.T.M.-like stations that will scan your votes and retain hard copies of them.

headline: Obama’s Struggles: Answers From Matt Bai, Part IV
text: 3:51 p.m. | Updated In his Political Times column published on Wednesday, Matt Bai offers one theory behind President Obama’s fading popularity, which has divided and somewhat puzzled Democrats in Washington. He answered reader questions on what he calls the “legislative box” strategy and other top Washington issues this week.

headline: Oil Plume Is Not Breaking Down Fast, Study Says
text: New research confirms the existence of a huge plume of dispersed oil deep in the Gulf of Mexico and suggests that it has not broken down rapidly, raising the possibility that it might pose a threat to wildlife for months or even years.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A fisherman casts his line into the River Coquet, near Rothbury, England.

headline: Unemployment Rate Dips Again
text: New York City’s unemployment rate dipped to 9.4 percent in July, continuing a gradual but steady improvement as hiring rebounded faster locally than in the rest of the country, the state Labor Department said Thursday.

headline: Poetry Comes to Newark
text: Newark will be turned into a Poetry Village in October, when the Dodge Poetry Festival, the largest of its kind in the nation, comes to town. Opening Oct. 7, the 13th biennial will feature an impressive lineup of poets, including four poets laureate — Billy Collins, Rita Dove, Kay Ryan and Mark Strand — as well as other acclaimed wordsmiths like Galway Kinnell, Amiri Baraka, Bob Hicok, Martín Espada, Dunya Mikhail, Joseph Millar, Nancy Morejón, Sharon Olds, Marie Ponsot and Claudia Rankine. More than 20,000 people are expected to attend the four days of readings and discussions. The festival is usually held at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., but it ran into financial difficulties this year. That is when the City of Newark and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center agreed to help sponsor the festival with the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation.

headline: Well to Be Sealed After Labor Day
text: The final sealing of BP’s stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico will be delayed until after Labor Day, officials said on Thursday, so that the company can replace equipment that contributed to the well’s failure.

headline: Club For Growth Endorses Four Republicans for House
text: The powerful antitax fund-raising group, the Club for Growth, endorsed four Republicans vying for  House seats in November: Todd Young in Indiana, Mick Mulvaney in South Carolina, Stephen Fincher in Tennessee and Tim Griffin in Arkansas.

headline: Warming Seas Threaten Coral Off Indonesia
text: A striking rise in sea temperatures in waters off Indonesia may be responsible for one of the most rapid and destructive coral bleaching events on record, a marine conservation group reported this week. Large swaths of coral reef in the Andaman Sea off the north coast of Sumatra are now up to 80 percent bleached, with more colonies expected to die off in the coming months, according to marine biologists who conducted extensive surveys of the area.

headline: Warner TV Unit in Deal for Online Video Syndication
text: The Studio 2.0 division of the Warner Brothers Television Group, part of Time Warner, is to announce on Thursday an agreement with AlphaBird, an online video syndication company, for a distribution partnership.

headline: ‘Quant’ Funds Struggle to Revive Boom Times
text: They were revered as the brightest minds in finance, the “quants” who could outwit Wall Street with their Ph.D.’s and superfast computers. But after blundering through the financial panic, losing big in 2008 and lagging badly in 2009, these so-called quantitative investment managers no longer look like geniuses, and some investors have fallen out of love with them, The New York Times’s Julie Creswell reports.

headline: Backup Quarterback Sorgi to Miss 2 to 3 Weeks
text: ALBANY — The Giants do not know how long quarterback Eli Manning will be unable to wear a helmet because of the stitches in his forehead, but the team will be thin at quarterback for the next few weeks.

headline: Barnes & Noble’s Directors: A Tale of the Tape
text: Barnes & Noble on Thursday nominated two new directors to its board alongside its chairman, Leonard S. Riggio, as it seeks to fend off a proxy challenge from the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle.

headline: Peace and War
text: Jonathan Franzen’s new novel, “Freedom,” like his previous one, “The Corrections,” is a masterpiece of American fiction. The two books have much in common. Once again Franzen has fashioned a capacious but intricately ordered narrative that in its majestic sweep seems to gather up every fresh datum of our shared millennial life. Franzen knows that college freshmen are today called “first years,” like tender shoots in an overplanted garden; that a high-minded mom, however ruthless in her judgments of her neighbors’ ethical lapses, will condemn them with no epithet harsher than “weird”; that reckless drivers who barrel across lanes are “almost always youngish men for whom the use of blinkers was apparently an affront to their masculinity.”

headline: Playlist: Sleigh Bells
text: A year ago, Derek Miller and Alexis Krauss were struggling Brooklyn musicians; now they're playing for tens of thousands at festivals around the world.  Melena Ryzik reports.

headline: Dickey an Unexpected Bright Spot in Mets’ Dim Season
text: HOUSTON – With three-quarters of the season over, the Mets have provoked just about every emotion possible in their fans. They have excited them, frustrated them, perplexed them.

headline: Quote Unquote | De-Luxe
text: –Simon Doonan discusses his similarities to the Jersey Shore star: both are petite and neither can get discounts on Gucci.

headline: More Americans  ‘Completely Satisfied’ With Their Pay
text: Nearly a third of workers say they are “completely satisfied” with the amount of money they earn, according to a recent Gallup poll. That is as high a level of pay satisfaction as Gallup has recorded in  two decades.

headline: At Treasury, Geithner Struggles to Escape a Past He Never Had
text: WASHINGTON  Timothy F. Geithner has been misidentified as a former Wall Street insider from Goldman Sachs so many times since he became the Treasury secretary that he and his advisers had taken to joking about it. Then the joke backfired.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Approves Use of Antidepressant for Pain
text: A federal advisory panel on Thursday voted narrowly to recommend allowing Eli Lilly to market its blockbuster antidepressant, Cymbalta, for some chronic pain conditions affecting millions of Americans, particularly lower back pain.

headline: Giants’ Loss Is Bomar’s Opportunity
text: ALBANY — Quarterback Rhett Bomar needed a minute to contemplate the question: Did he remember the last game he started?

text: Michael Shaoul of Oscar Gruss & Son makes a good point today:

text: David Pogue explains OpenDNS, a free, alternative D.N.S. service that works better than your Internet provider’s.

text: Dance

headline: Our Lesser-Known Allies in Afghanistan
text: KABUL — What do the Greek, Mongolian, Latvian and British Armies have in common? They’ve all been in Afghanistan before: the Greeks under Alexander; the Mongols under Genghis Khan; the Latvians as part of the Soviet Union; and the British more than a few times. They are also current members of the International Security Assistance Force, and contribute troops to the coalition mission in Afghanistan.

headline: 36 Hours in Portland, Me.
text: PORTLAND, Me., is known for three L’s: lobster, lighthouses and L. L. Bean (O.K., make that four L’s). Here’s another: local. In recent years, this city on the coast of Maine has welcomed a wave of locavore restaurants, urban farms and galleries that feature local artists. Abandoned brick warehouses are being repurposed as eco-friendly boutiques. In the main square, a 19th-century building has been refashioned into a farmers’ market. And everywhere you look, this once-sleepy industrial town is showing signs of rejuvenation — usually by keeping things local.

headline: A Weekend in Portland, Me.
text: This once-sleepy industrial town is showing signs of rejuvenation.

headline: Yankees Continue Their Offensive Resurgence
text: The simmering that started a night earlier never reached a boil Thursday afternoon as the focus shifted from flaring tempers to the Yankees’ hot offense.

headline: Going Places: Backstory
text: For the fashion story “Going Places,” the stylist David Vandewal and the photographer Mark Segal took fall’s nomadic trend and ran with it. Their concept? A woman who travels the world and wears her souvenirs on her sleeves. Think of it as fashion without borders.

headline: 34 Laps, and Time to Reflect
text: Everyone knows swimming is excellent exercise, but it is also terrific therapy. Nothing frees my mind as dependably as the rhythm of my arms and legs propelling me from one end of the pool to the other. Also, as I have discovered in the 18 months since the death of the man I loved, in the pool, no one can tell the water running down your face is tears.

headline: North Little Rock Finds its Cool
text: Once called Dogtown, this neighborhood is now home to an arts district.

headline: In Estonia, Jiggling and Bog-Trekking
text: BEFORE us was a pleasant enough expanse of forest and meadow near the coast of Estonia. Lazy breeze, piney scents, distant chirping. A decent place for an afternoon stroll with the family.

headline: Trekking Through Bogs in North America
text: For adventurers not able to make it to Estonia, here are a few of North America’s most interesting bog-trekking options.

headline: Viva la Independencia in Mexico
text: Mexico commemorates its bicentennial in three historical towns.

headline: Mexico’s Freedom Trail
text: MY earliest political memory is of an elementary-school trip five decades ago to the Angel of Independence, the golden winged statue atop a soaring marble column in the heart of Mexico City, where my parents had recently moved from New York. Though I can’t remember the exact year of the outing, it was certainly on Sept. 16, the day Mexico celebrates the beginning of its long War of Independence (1810-21) from three centuries of Spanish colonial rule.

headline: An Ancient City in Turkey Finds New Life in Modern Art
text: ON a searingly hot Saturday in early June, a small crowd of residents and tourists stood inside the entryway of the 14th-century Zinciriye Medresesi, a mosque and former medrese, or center of Islamic study, in Mardin, an ancient town in southeastern Turkey. Hanging in a row on a wall beneath the narrow room’s vaulted ceiling were front pages from recent issues of Turkish, French and British newspapers. Each was missing a headline, and visitors took turns inscribing their own on strips of paper stacked beneath the display.

headline: No Dog Days in Deal Land
text: Another day, another billion-dollar deal … or two.  Hey, people! Don’t you know it’s August?

headline: Theater Talkback: The Replacements’ Greatest Hits
text: Strange but true: the best new show in town this summer isn’t a new show at all, technically. I’m speaking of the revival of “A Little Night Music,” which sings with new subtlety and emotional force now that the celebrated Broadway veterans Bernadette Peters and Elaine Stritch have taken over the key roles of Desirée Armfeldt and her caustic mum.

headline: ‘Bed Intruder’ Rant Earns Family a New Home
text: Updated | 7:46 p.m. It began with unlikely fodder for music, comedy or pop culture stardom: a local news report about an attempted rape. But then the victim’s brother stepped before the camera and delivered a lecture to the stranger who had tried to attack his sister one night last month in Huntsville, Ala., that somehow managed to be both deeply angry and oddly compelling.

headline: For H.P. and Dell, Troubles at the Top Have Yet to Hurt the Bottom Line
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Executives from Hewlett-Packard and Dell, America’s two largest computer makers, ought to be rejoicing when parents open their wallets in August to arm their offspring with shiny new computers for the school year.

headline: When Heroism Means Finding Truth
text: What soldier, anticipating his death in combat, wouldn’t want to be remembered as a fallen hero who gave his life for his comrades? What grieving family wouldn’t accept the official account, however fraudulent, of a son or daughter’s heroism, stifle their doubts, keep their mouths shut and be content to find some comfort in the ritual honors?

headline: Celebrating 100 Years of Alfa Romeo at the Concorso Italiano

Outside, a summer fog hangs like a thin, gray curtain over the low marshland. I tell myself it is a good thing. The old vehicles run better in damp air.

headline: The Challenge of Estimating Closing Costs for a Home
text: If you’re buying a new home this year, the initial estimate from your lender of closing costs is likely to be closer to what you’ll ultimately pay than it would have been in the past.

headline: Ladies, Feel Free to Let Loose
text: IN a room no different from many rehearsal spaces — small, bare, air-conditioned — some 20 women dance as if no one is watching.

headline: The ‘Reality’ Tradition
text: It may be tempting to view some reality TV series as unprecedented cultural lows, but observing the lives of indolent exhibitionists is nothing new.

headline: ‘Step Forward’ in Limiting Smoking Scenes in Films
text: LOS ANGELES  The figures are in: Hollywood has actually been snuffing the smoke out of movies.

text: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, takes on three bespoke cocktail experts in an experiment in improvised mixology.

headline: Outsiders in French Society, Battling Occupiers and Collaborators
text: The closest person to a protagonist in the gripping historical mosaic “Army of Crime” is the eminent Armenian poet Missak Manouchian (Simon Abkarian). A militant Communist and hero of the French Resistance, executed by the Nazis in 1944, he is the noblest figure in a sprawling, semifictional movie that has enough characters to fill an entire neighborhood.

headline: Name Your Potion: Bourbon, Cardamom, Twinkies?
text: It wasn’t a question so much as a setup, a taunt. “You can make a drink with anything?” the young man asked.

headline: Heat on the Rocks
text: Drinks — even drinks with recipes — are fickle, changeable things. I learned this in the course of coming up with my own cocktail, and the price I paid for the lesson was a fleeting sensation that my lips were on fire.

headline: Who’s a Joker? Steve Miller to Teach at U.S.C.
text: Up until now, we’d always believed that Steve Miller‘s rhyming of Texas, “facts is,” justice and taxes in “Take the Money and Run” was the most surprising turn he’d taken in his pop-music career. But the man who some call the Space Cowboy, others describe as the Gangster of Love, and still others simply call Maurice may have outdone himself by becoming an instructor at the University of Southern California.

headline: For $30 a Month, Serenity
text: Everyone knows swimming is excellent exercise, but it is also terrific therapy. Nothing frees my mind as dependably as the rhythm of my arms and legs propelling me from one end of the pool to the other. Also, as I have discovered in the 18 months since the death of the man I loved, in the pool, no one can tell the water running down your face is tears.

headline: Banks Stuck With Bill for Bad Loans
text: If nobody does their job right, and disaster ensues, who should pay for the sins of all?

headline: Delta Sells Tickets Through Facebook
text: Delta Airlines recently added a feature on its Facebook page that allows users to book travel through the social networking site. The application, the Delta Ticket Window, offers a pared-down version of the booking service on Delta’s own (also recently retooled) Web site. There is no option to book a multicity trip or to buy a ticket using rewards, for example. But there is one crucial add-on: you can share your travel plans with friends of your choice.

headline: From Luxury to Necessity, and Back Again
text: For years Americans had been labeling more and more appliances and other purchases as “necessities,” rather than “luxuries.” Microwaves, computers and other wonders of modern civilization, upon being adopted in greater numbers, became more likely to be considered need-to-haves instead of nice-to-haves, according to surveys conducted by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Ludwig and Amadeus, Meeting for a Nightcap
text: The members of any string quartet will tell you that it takes a great deal of disciplined work to achieve technical finesse and control. The four young Parisian men who form the Ebène Quartet have certainly worked hard, which partly explains why they are increasingly viewed as one of the standout quartets of the new generation.

headline: Exposed Wounds, and a Family Wielding Salt
text: Christophe Honoré’s radically unsentimental family portrait, “Making Plans for Léna,” takes on a formidable challenge: How do you prevent viewers from losing patience with a central character whose neurotic, self-destructive behavior is so infuriating that the impulse is to flee?

headline: Yes, They’re Sleazy, but Not Originals
text: It is tempting to view “Jersey Shore” or any Kardashian sister as the knell of civilization’s end.

headline: When an Actor Casts Himself as an Artist
text: The art world prefers its artists to start out destitute and unknown, working from inside the system toward increasing visibility and renown. Early deprivation and obscurity count as dues paid, reflecting seriousness and a willingness to sacrifice. This familiar progression assures us that an artist is one of us.

headline: One Restaurant’s History, Spiked Desserts and All
text: Spaghetti, spinach and French fries, all smothered in cream sauce: the menu at Soul Kitchen, a decrepit restaurant in a converted warehouse in an industrial section of Hamburg, Germany, may not be to everyone’s palate. But the place attracts a scraggly following of regulars who exit in a huff after its manager, Zinos Kazantsakis (Adam Bousdoukos), hires Shayn (Birol Ünel), a snooty culinary prima donna, as its new chef.

headline: Turn On (MP3s), Tune In and Ride
text: BIKE riders in New York have a secret, a communal understanding about the pleasures of navigating the urban landscape, flowing through traffic and observing the city in a way that pedestrians and drivers can’t. That secret is often expressed in a smile or a nod to another rider while passing on a bridge or stopped at a light, a conspiratorial acknowledgment of a shared moment with strangers in a city that can seem impervious to them.

headline: Grim Reapers Slicing and Dicing Society’s Foibles
text: Taking sketch comedy long-form, as many who’ve seen “Wayne’s World 2” will almost certainly acknowledge, comes with considerable risk. All creative efforts assume some, but this particular shape-shift threatens to turn cultish devotion to bored dismissal. It’s as dangerous as the alienation of thousands of 15-year-old boys who, alone in their rooms with their beer bongs, have been happily regurgitating every line of a favorite act as if Olivier reciting Shakespeare, only to become resentful once the sacred has been bastardized by big-budget Hollywood jerks. Sometimes you don’t want the foie gras entrée, just the amuse-bouche.

headline: How to Use Facebook’s New Location Feature
text: 8:00 p.m. | Updated Fixing information about Places and non-iPhone users.

headline: Home Grown
text: Lizzie Owens likes to keep things close to home. So when the 27-year-old designer of the Highland men’s-wear label moved to Manhattan from her hometown of Salt Lake City, she set up shop on the outskirts of TriBeCa and enlisted two childhood friends, Mike Franks and Cramer Tolboe, to be her business partners. “We’ve known each other all our lives,” Owens says. “Even our dads are business partners.”

headline: Hendrix and Handel but Mostly Hendrix
text: Jimi Hendrix died 40 years ago on Sept. 18, after ingesting too many sleeping pills and too much red wine at a girlfriend’s apartment in London. To commemorate the anniversary, the Handel House Museum in London is reuniting artifacts from his last performances and from his tiny apartment, next door to Handel’s Georgian town house on Brook Street in the upscale Mayfair district.

headline: Inside the Knockoff-Tennis-Shoe Factory
text: A shopkeeper in Italy placed an order with a Chinese sneaker factory in Putian for 3,000 pairs of white Nike Tiempo indoor soccer shoes. It was early February, and the shopkeeper wanted the Tiempos pronto. Neither he nor Lin, the factory manager, were authorized to make Nikes. They would have no blueprints or instructions to follow. But Lin didn’t mind. He was used to working from scratch. A week later, Lin, who asked that I only use his first name, received a pair of authentic Tiempos, took them apart, studied their stitching and molding, drew up his own design and oversaw the production of 3,000 Nike clones. A month later, he shipped the shoes to Italy. “He’ll order more when there’s none left,” Lin told me recently, with confidence.

headline: The Lights of Big Brother’s Eyes, Blinking in the City
text: If you’re walking along East 52nd Street at night, you might notice a medium-rise building that’s developed a kind of nervous tic. It’s the glass-fronted Austrian Cultural Forum, where inside the lights flash on and off at unpredictable intervals.

headline: Heady Intersections of Ancient and Modern
text: Wandering around the Rubin Museum of Art, which specializes in traditional art of the Himalayas, you happen upon a case containing a set of curious, cylindrical, silvery objects. Looking closely, you discover they are not antique artifacts but beer cans with their printed surfaces sanded away. More scrutiny reveals that their bottoms have been perforated by a pointed instrument, and that if you examine the other end and peer in through the drinking hole, you see a glowing, dotted-line image of a Tantric deity.

headline: Glaxo Memo on Avandia Is Questioned
text: Federal drug regulators ordered GlaxoSmithKline to send a letter to crucial doctors describing a hearing in July where an expert advisory panel discussed the risks of Avandia, the company’s controversial diabetes medicine.

headline: African Art World Nestled in Tenafly
text: TENAFLY, N.J.  You can count the number of American public museums devoted entirely to African art on a few fingers.

headline: All You Can Jet Passes Sold Out
text: According to the JetBlue Web site, both types of All You Can Jet passes are sold out.  Sun Country Fall Free For All passes seem to still be available. (If you missed it, we compared the passes yesterday.) Did anyone out there scoop one up? Where do you plan to fly?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Tim Wimborne of Reuters is one of the agency photographers who have distinguished themselves in bringing the world’s attention to the unabating misery in Pakistan. His work can be seen in the slide show, “Pakistan Flood Relief.” Kevin Frayer and Shakil Adil of The Associated Press are also doing exceptional work. Another compelling image by a Reuters photographer (Slide 4) comes from Bob Strong in Afghanistan. And Corentin Fohlen is shooting in Paris for The New York Times (Slide 9).

headline: Our Buildings, Ourselves
text: My husband and I were not pioneers in loft living, although we had good friends who were, and our eventual move to downtown Manhattan had probably been set in motion by the long evenings spent in their large, unconventional spaces in Tribeca.

headline: Excerpt: 'Death Comes to Town'
text: The short IFC series reunites the Kids in the Hall comedy troupe.

headline: My Brother’s Keeper (Assembly Required)
text: TEN years ago my mother died in my arms, propped up on plush, monogrammed Laura Ashley pillows with Frank Sinatra singing “My Way” through Sony Walkman earphones strapped to her head. The Walkman didn’t fit the décor, and neither did I. My mother and I were not close, and it was somewhat ironic that, of her four children, I would be the one rubbing her spongy forearms and kneading her ice-cold feet as she prepared to lay her burden down.

headline: Actress Didi Conn Lists Rockland House
text: IT’S been decades since the world was introduced to the high school kids of “Grease”  first the musical and then the movie  yet the songs still get stuck in your head. Only last month, Didi Conn, the actress who played Frenchy, the beauty school dropout, in the 1978 movie, hosted a sing-along of “Grease” tunes at the Hollywood Bowl.

headline: A Tenuous Existence
text: The French government has begun cracking down on illegal camps of Roma, immigrants mostly from Romania or Bulgaria.

headline: Expulsion of Roma Raises Questions in France
text: LA COURNEUVE, France  About 100 French riot police officers swooped down on an encampment of Roma here at 7 a.m. Thursday, taking names and filling out expulsion orders. Fully padded, but without helmets, the officers were aggressive but polite, accompanied by a Romanian policeman and three interpreters.

headline: Speyer Daughter Sells Co-op
text: Real Estate Runs

headline: Atlantic Hurricane Season Set to Intensify
text: Brian McNoldy, a meteorologist at Colorado State University who maintains a useful Web site on tropical storms in the Atlantic Ocean, has distributed an alert about a particularly noteworthy wave of low pressure moving west from Africa that appears likely to become a hurricane within a week. His note also dispels any notions that this has been a sleepy Atlantic and Caribbean storm season:

headline: Living With the Aches That Won’t Go Away
text: For the fortunate, pain is temporary and finite, with a clear beginning, middle and end. But for more than 70 million Americans, including Melanie Thernstrom, pain is chronic, and the primary reason that they seek medical care. The medical profession has been slow to recognize this development. There is currently one board-certified pain specialist in the United States for every 25,000 patients, she writes in her new book, “The Pain Chronicles.” That number, however, is likely to grow as pain is redefined not as a symptom but as a disease that “can eventually rewrite the central nervous system, causing pathological changes to the brain and spinal cord, and ... greater pain.”

headline: The Art of James Franco
text: Images from a new exhibit at the Clocktower Gallery.

headline: Out on a Limb
text: Freida Pinto is not one to shy away from a grand gesture. “As my friends and family are quick to remind me, I have always been a big drama queen,” Pinto, 26, recalls over breakfast in a Midtown hotel suite. “As a child, I would stand in front of the mirror and pretend I was this or that person from television. All I needed to do was realize it and recognize what I wanted to do.”

headline: Geithner Haunted by a Goldman Past He Never Had
text: Timothy F. Geithner has been misidentified as a former Wall Street insider from Goldman Sachs so many times since he became the Treasury secretary that he and his advisers had taken to joking about it. Then the joke backfired.

headline: Hot Spots: Threats and Responses
text: This week, we were especially taken with campaign ads that prompted unusual responses, like a Florida spot drawing an unusual rebuke from a normally neutral party and a Minnesota campaign that has attracted a boycott drive against Target.

headline: In W.P.S., a Job, an Adventure, a Challenge
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog during the defending champions’ 2010 season.

headline: Democrats Meet, With an Eye on November
text: ST. LOUIS – The Democratic National Committee opened its summer meeting here on Thursday, with party leaders taking a moment to bask in legislative achievements on health care and financial regulation even as they braced for the prospect of deep losses in the fall elections.

headline: A Paris House and a Playful Street Link
text: IT seems appropriate to say I love the new Hermès scarf site, jaimemoncarre.com, which the Paris company just introduced. I’ve been a fan of the main Hermès site, but this is a clever addition for a house that is known for silk scarves and derives a lot of revenue from them. Hermès focuses on young women in Paris, London, New York and Tokyo, offers brief bio sketches and then shows how they wear scarves — which are having a comeback. The photographs are a cut above street-fashion images, and yet not as glossy-perfect as those found in magazines.

headline: Ford’s Models
text: The agency that set the standard for American beauty in the ’50s is getting an overhaul. Is there a Ford in your future?

headline: 2011 Ferrari 458 Italia
text: The Italia says that beauty doesn’t have to be sacrificed to modern performance.

headline: Covering Its Tracks Paid Off Handsomely
text: IT’S a common hobby, searching for surviving pieces of the 1910 Pennsylvania Station, like ironwork, brass handrails and other fragments, amidst its vulgar replacement of the 1960s.

headline: The Body Shop
text: The year was 1958. Eileen Ford was traveling through Europe, hoping to discover a new face or two for the Ford Model Agency, the company she ran back in New York with her husband, Jerry. Though Eileen didn’t find any potential stars abroad, she was far from discouraged when she returned. A Long Island-raised, Barnard-educated woman driven by a surplus of weapons-grade ambition, Eileen was already well known in the industry for being immune to emotions like discouragement. Also, she had noticed something pleasing about the style of the European girls — a reminder of how and why her company had already become the most successful of its kind. Long regarded for their sophisticated, heroically unapproachable beauty — an aesthetic that had been the dominant face of fashion throughout the ’50s — many of the girls now seemed to embrace a more wholesome look. They were pert and welcoming, bright-eyed and often blond-haired: eager, in short, to project a kind of dewy innocence. “Everyone there,” Eileen noted when she got back, “wants to look American.” Which was one way of putting it. Were she less a believer in the power of modesty, Eileen could just as easily have said everyone wanted to look like a Ford model.

headline: Streetscapes | Terminal City
text: There are still remnants of what was conceived as Terminal City, a unified matrix of development on the new real estate created when the tracks surrounding Grand Central Station were covered.

headline: New to America, Discovering Its Glitter
text: “Mao’s Last Dancer” is the story of a young and flexible Chinese man who comes to America, where he’s seduced by disco, creative freedom and a honey-haired Houston virgin, and decides to stay.

headline: Giants’ Phillips Is Looking Forward to His Return
text: ALBANY — Giants safety Kenny Phillips is good-humored, almost kid-like, by nature, often wearing a smile and munching Gummi Bears after lunch at training camp. Since he arrived here, though, his impatience to return has been obvious.

headline: Your Ex Has a Problem. It’s You.
text: I live with a former boyfriend who is one of my closest friends. Recently, he began sleeping with our new next-door neighbor, whom I have not yet met. I’m not interested in rekindling our romance, but this situation makes me feel icky. Here are my ground rules: never sleep with your ex’s sister, her friends or her next-door neighbors. I’ve encouraged his seeing other women, just not the ones who live right here! But my ex doesn’t understand the problem. Do you?

headline: Supercalifragi — Oops, Wrong Nanny
text: Emma Thompson is back, warts, snaggletooth and all, to teach unruly children lessons in self-reliance and to remind parents that they’re basically useless if sometimes amusing appendages in “Nanny McPhee Returns.”

headline: Off-Road Racing Promoter’s Permits Suspended
text: The Bureau of Land Management acted on Thursday to suspend the permits for Mojave Desert Racing, the promoter of last weekend’s deadly off-road race near Lucerne Valley, Calif.

headline: Up Front: Linda Robinson
text: The book Linda Robinson reviews on the cover of this week’s Book Review, Eliza Griswold’s “Tenth Parallel,” is about some of the most troublesome of the world’s trouble spots.

headline: Christians and Muslims
text: The influential political scientist Samuel P. Huntington theorized about the “clash of civilizations.” The journalist and poet Eliza Griswold takes on the same topic in a much more visceral way: she traveled through the “torrid zone” to see, smell, taste and write about it. Her book “The Tenth Parallel” is a fascinating journey along the latitude line in Africa and Asia where Christianity and Islam often meet and clash. Since Americans commonly equate Islam with the Arab Middle East, this book is a useful reminder that four-fifths of Muslims live elsewhere. It’s also an intimate introduction to some of those who live in places like Nigeria, Sudan, Somalia, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines.

headline: In a Baste and Switch, a New Father Is Born
text: The moment the scatterbrained romantic comedy “The Switch” loses its last shred of common sense occurs on a New York City bus. A stranger admiring the little boy accompanying Wally (Jason Bateman), the neurotic bachelor who narrates the story, comments that he looks just like his father.

headline: Young Lawyers Turn to Public Service
text: WASHINGTON  In August 2008, Nathan Richardson committed to following in the footsteps of so many young lawyers before him: a summer position with a big law firm, followed by a job offer before he ever cracked open a third-year textbook. And then everything changed.

headline: Imam Behind New York Project Starts Mideast Tour
text: CAIRO  Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, the organizer of the planned Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan, arrived in Bahrain on Thursday to begin a three-country tour of the Persian Gulf sponsored by the United States State Department.

headline: A Bull Market in Sketchy Art
text: When you’ve really made it on Wall Street, you fill up your Fifth Avenue co-op with expensive art, just as surely as snow is followed by little boys on sleds (to paraphrase Arthur Okun, the legendary Yale economist).

headline: Blagojevich Items Go Up for Bid, Including Elvis
text: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill.  A bad week for Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, got a little worse on Thursday when a moving company here auctioned off his personal items to the highest bidder because he failed to make payments on a storage unit.

headline: G.M. Chief Sees I.P.O. As Exit Sign
text: DETROIT  Since he became chief executive of General Motors in December, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. has lived for the day that G.M. would become a public company again and shed the stigma of government ownership.

headline: Census Survey Asks Too Much, G.O.P. Says
text: The Republican National Committee is demanding that the Census Bureau stop being so nosy, or at least stop requiring that Americans comply.

headline: Is It Normal Grief, or Depression?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making a Game Out of Beating Expectations
text: MADRID  Of all the coaches who overlooked Stephen Curry as a young player, Mike Krzyzewski acknowledges that his missed evaluation may be the most glaring. Curry attended Duke’s basketball camp as a youngster, making Krzyzewski and his staff among the first who labeled Curry as too short, too thin and too one-dimensional.

headline: Access at Guantánamo
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Manning Already Out, Giants Lose His Backup
text: ALBANY  The Giants do not know how long quarterback Eli Manning will be unable to wear a helmet because of the stitches in his forehead, but the team will be thin at quarterback for the next few weeks.

headline: The Best Eggs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Australia’s Labor Party Faces a Fight for Survival
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia has not had a recession in nearly 20 years. It is one of the few industrialized countries to have emerged unscathed from the global downturn, riding the wave of China’s insatiable demand for raw materials. Gross domestic product grew by 2.7 percent last year, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia, and unemployment was an enviable 5.3 percent in July, about half the rate of the United States.

headline: The Unraveling of America
text: To the Editor:

headline: PGA Says Viewership Decline Shouldn’t Be Costly in TV Talks
text: Drama is not always enough to sell viewers on golf. Sometimes these devotees seem to disappear into an Irish mist as if they were waiting for Tiger Woods to become Superman again.

headline: Parks Worker Is Raped at Playground in Brooklyn
text: A parks department employee was raped on Thursday morning by a man armed with a box cutter at a playground in Brooklyn, according to the police.

headline: Fish’s Strong Play Continues
text: 10:50 p.m. | Updated

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,214 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Don’t Drop Out of School Innovation
text: HOW much evidence does the government need before trying something new in the troubled realm of public education? Should there be airtight proof that a pioneering program works before we commit federal money to it  or is it sometimes worth investing in promising but unproven innovations?

headline: Moscow Weather Back to Normal After Fires
text: MOSCOW  The warm voice of a tenor rehearsing at the open window of an opera house here floated out over a breezy courtyard filled with people doing what until Thursday was downright unpleasant and at times potentially life threatening: relaxing outdoors.

headline: Covering the Bases
text: There are hundreds of baseball movies, but the truly good ones pretty much begin and end with Ron Shelton (“Bull Durham” and, to a lesser extent, “Cobb”). Gary Lundgren’s debut feature, “Calvin Marshall,” aspires to that league but doesn’t rise above Class A.

headline: Over a Billion Years, Scientists Find, the Moon Went Through a Shrinking Phase
text: The Moon is shrinking.

headline: Government Gadfly in Teaneck, N.J., Is Killed
text: TEANECK, N.J.  Not everyone in town knew Joan Davis, but it seemed that way. Her never-failing presence at various township meetings was the stuff of local lore.

headline: O’Reilly Distances Himself From a Video Promotion
text: This summer Bill O’Reilly, the biggest star on the Fox News Channel, lent his name  inadvertently, he says  to a Web ad that lured viewers to sign up for a financial newsletter sold by Newsmax, the conservative Web site.

headline: Fatalities on the Job Fell in 2009
text: The total number of fatal workplace injuries fell by 17 percent last year, to 4,340, down from 5,214 in 2008, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported on Thursday.

headline: Bow Wow Hits It Big
text: The comedy “Lottery Ticket” may be the video director Erik White’s first feature, but the prevailing presence in this crowd-pleaser is Ice Cube, whose evolution from hip-hop threat to screen paterfamilias is now complete. (Was he really once one of gangsta rap’s founding fathers in N.W.A.? I guess he’s been busy masterminding the “Friday,” “Barbershop” and “Are We There Yet?” franchises — and being an executive producer here.)

headline: Screen Test | Freida Pinto
text: Freida Pinto discusses her childhood aspirations, her career thus far and her thoughts on the film industry.

headline: Math Lessons for Locavores
text: Leesburg, Va.

headline: Blagojevich Trial Ends Fitzgerald’s Successes
text: CHICAGO  Around here, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney for the Northern District of Illinois and, lately, the overseer of the prosecution of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, has been called a modern-day Eliot Ness. His name has been tossed about, without his participation, as a future mayor or governor or something. A radio host once introduced him as “the biggest Chicago guy or gal there is,” aside, maybe, from Oprah Winfrey.

headline: Appeasing the Bond Gods
text: As I look at what passes for responsible economic policy these days, there’s an analogy that keeps passing through my mind. I know it’s over the top, but here it is anyway: the policy elite  central bankers, finance ministers, politicians who pose as defenders of fiscal virtue  are acting like the priests of some ancient cult, demanding that we engage in human sacrifices to appease the anger of invisible gods.

headline: Now Playing: A Short Film Starring Branded Content
text: IN “Charley,” a nine-minute film by Dee Austin Robertson, a young couple visiting New York for a romantic weekend, Courtney and Ryan (played by Alexia Rasmussen and Brian McElhaney), are first seen through a glass door with an Ace Hotel sign painted on it. Ryan pulls along a suitcase with a strap that bobs behind him like a leash leading a dog, a scene that foreshadows the pet-related tension between the couple: Courtney proceeds to talk obsessively about her cat, Charley, ruining the weekend.

headline: New Afghan Intelligence Chief Aims to Build Trust
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s new intelligence chief said this week that the Taliban appeared to have the upper hand in the insurgency but could still be defeated with better cooperation between Afghan and coalition forces and a stronger government effort to build trust in the rural communities.

headline: Culture Collisions in the Andes
text: In “Altiplano,” primitivism and modernism collide when bereaved women from opposite ends of the socioeconomic spectrum ignite a self-consciously spiritual tale of ecological exploitation.

headline: California: Company Banned From Racing
text: The federal Bureau of Land Management on Thursday suspended off-road racing events run by Mojave Desert Racing Productions, the corporation responsible for a race last Saturday in which eight people were killed when a truck rolled into spectators. Races organized by other groups will be reviewed and approved on an individual basis, said a spokesman for the agency. The suspension will stay in effect while San Bernardino County officials investigate the fatal accident at the California 200 off-road race in Lucerne Valley.

headline: Pettitte’s Words and Character Carry Weight
text: The moral to this story is, be careful whom you choose as your training partner. It’s almost as dangerous as pillow talk, the kind of shop talk that goes on when two buddies lift weights and run laps.

headline: California: Police Group Backs Marijuana Measure
text: A national group of African-American law enforcement officers has endorsed Proposition 19, a ballot measure that would tax and regulate marijuana in California. The National Black Police Association, which has more than two dozen chapters across the country, announced the endorsement in Sacramento, where the organization is holding a national conference. In a statement, Neill Franklin, the executive director of Law Enforcement Against Prohibition, which supports Proposition 19, said that “prohibition takes a toll on people of color across the country.” He added: “Californians finally have an opportunity to do something about it.” The measure would allow possession of up to an ounce of marijuana for personal use.

headline: Foreclosures Grind On
text: There is a lot of grim economic news out there, including Thursday’s report that initial claims for unemployment insurance rose to half a million people last week. The news on housing  where the financial crisis began  is also bad. And the government’s response to high foreclosure rates continues to fall far short of what is needed to help Americans hold on to their homes and to stabilize home prices.

headline: Screen Test | Cheryl Tiegs
text: Ms. Tiegs on her modeling career, her body image, and her definition of beauty.

headline: Islamic Center Exposes Mixed Feelings Locally
text: In the storm of anger and accusation over an Islamic center and mosque planned near ground zero, one thing seems clear to Laique Khan: His fellow Muslims have a right to build the project.

headline: People Magazine Subscribers to Receive Free Access on iPads
text: The iPad application for People will be free to readers who subscribe to the magazine, the first step toward what Time Inc., the world’s largest magazine publisher, hopes is a model for the bundling of print and digital sales for all its publications.

headline: Democrat Keeps Pelosi at Arm’s Length
text: Representative Joe Donnelly really wants to tell voters that he’s independent.

headline: Once Bound for Cooperstown, Now Headed to a Courtroom
text: Days before Roger Clemens was to testify before a House committee in February 2008, Congressional leaders gave him one final chance to change his mind and not speak publicly.

headline: U.S. Assures Israel That Iran Threat Is Not Imminent
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, citing evidence of continued troubles inside Iran’s nuclear program, has persuaded Israel that it would take roughly a year  and perhaps longer  for Iran to complete what one senior official called a “dash” for a nuclear weapon, according to American officials.

headline: At the Far Edge
text: For months, it has been clear that Republican Congressional candidates would benefit from independent voters’ dissatisfaction with President Obama. With the Republican field now largely in place, all voters might want to take a close look at who those candidates are.

headline: Mental Illness in New Jersey, Secretly
text: The independent film “Hiding Divya” wants to shine a light on a social problem: the covering up or ignoring of mental illness among South Asians. And while the movie has its heart in the right place, the first-time writer-director Rehana Mirza doesn’t yet have the skills to shape the narrative into something moving or revealing.

headline: For Digital Artists, Apps Provide New Palette
text: Publishers were not the only ones drooling when Apple unveiled its iPad to great fanfare in the spring. Digital artists also marveled at the device’s potential.

headline: Appearance on TV Show Is Request From Beyond
text: It is like a message from the afterlife.

headline: A Nurse as Dominatrix
text: Midway through “Modern Love Is Automatic,” a scruffy film by Zach Clark about a nurse who decides to log time as a dominatrix, someone asks the nurse, Lorraine (Melodie Sisk), why she wants to try this new career. She has no answer. And at that moment, you may think that Mr. Clark, too, has no answer to the question of why he wanted to make a movie about a dominatrix. After all, he adds nothing to the whips-and-leather cinematic clichés.

headline: Lilly Moves Closer to Approval to Market Cymbalta for Chronic Pain
text: A federal panel on Thursday voted narrowly to recommend allowing Eli Lilly to market its blockbuster antidepressant Cymbalta for some chronic pain conditions like lower back ailments that affect millions of Americans.

headline: Meeting the Man Who Made Him the (Mistaken) Messiah
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Behind Fraud Charges, New Jersey’s Deep Crisis
text: New Jersey got in trouble with federal regulators this week for misrepresenting the health of its pension funds. But the bigger problem may be what the state was trying to hide: a long-brewing crisis in its ability to pay retirees.

headline: Inquiry Into Ex-Sheriff’s Motor Pool
text: New Jersey authorities are investigating whether the Passaic County Sheriff’s Department motor pool repaired the vehicles of donors to the campaign of the former sheriff, according to people briefed on the inquiry.

headline: Newsom Steps Away From Limelight on Same-Sex Marriage
text: On the night of Aug. 4, after a federal district judge struck down Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage, a gaggle of San Francisco politicians worked their way up the City Hall steps to rally the jubilant crowd of 800 that was roaring its approval for the landmark ruling.

headline: Economy in Britain Shows Signs of Strength
text: LONDON  The British economy showed signs of strengthening Thursday after reports that the country’s budget deficit shrank at a faster pace than expected in July and retail sales posted the biggest gain in five months.

headline: First Niagara to Acquire Rival Bank for $1.5 Billion
text: Bank deal makers have been all but dormant the last two years, with few lenders willing to contemplate a merger in the aftermath of a financial crisis.

headline: No Names, Please
text: A rare bipartisan move is afoot to crimp one of the clubby abuses of the United States Senate  the “secret hold” that lone lawmakers employ anonymously to block worthy bills and nominees. Secret holds have been used by both parties to halt progress and extort concessions, even after a measure has been enthusiastically approved for advancement by committee majorities.

headline: Giants May Pass on Another Summer in Albany
text: ALBANY  The mileposts in Giants history since 1996 can be traced to the University at Albany, the host of the team’s training camp for the last 15 years.

headline: Google and Yahoo Win Appeal in Argentine Case
text: BUENOS AIRES — In a rare victory for Google and Yahoo Argentina, an appeals court has cleared the companies of defamation for including sex-related Web sites in their search results for an Argentine entertainer.

headline: Frank Kermode
text: I met Frank Kermode, who died Tuesday at age 90, more than 20 years ago over coffee at Columbia University, where he was teaching. I had come to propose writing a profile about him, a project that went nowhere mainly because the magazine I had hoped to write for didn’t write about literary critics in those days. Kermode didn’t dismiss the idea, and so I heard, that afternoon, about the Isle of Man, where he was born in “a herringless winter,” as he later wrote.

headline: A Simple Gesture Between Husband and Wife Says More Than Words
text: Journalists see many things in high-profile court cases that never get reported. Jurors fall asleep. Lawyers roll their eyes. Family members shake their heads.

headline: Program Offers Support for Victims of Domestic Violence, but It Is Challenging
text: For any first-time visitor, Cook County’s Domestic Violence Courthouse  with its unmarked hallways and frequently abandoned information desk  presents a navigational challenge. For an abuse victim, who may be terrified and injured, the blank walls and empty corridors are just the first bewildering step in a long, convoluted and impersonal process.

headline: With Martz in the House, Playoffs Beckon
text: In Alaska, where I recently visited, it’s hard not to notice the bears. Black bears, grizzly bears, Kodiak bears, Chicago Bears. Yes, even 2,912 miles from their Bourbonnais, Ill., training camp, word reaches a traveler that this simply has to be the Bears’ year.

headline: Judge Sees Evidence to Tie Man in Shootout to Felony
text: Citing “extremely strong” circumstantial evidence, a judge ruled on Thursday that there was reasonable cause to believe that a man who had been hit numerous times during a shootout in which the police had fired 46 rounds committed a felony.

headline: In Iraq War, Soldiers Say They Had a Job to Do
text: BAGHDAD  Staff Sgt. Lucas C. Trammell, a tank gunner with the Third Infantry Division, fought his way into Baghdad in 2003. He was back in 2005, abandoning the tank for foot patrols in a very unsafe Ramadi, and again in 2007 as bodyguard for a battalion commander in Baghdad.

text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Someone should open a HASE stadium in Queens just to really confuse solvers. Maybe not; this Friday puzzle is a typical Brad Wilber construction, meaning it’s tough enough already. It’s so full of trickery that it’s hard to know where to start.

headline: Despite Risks, an Addictive Treat Fuels a Chinese City
text: XIANGTAN, China — If the residents of this city seem a bit lively on even the hottest days or most frigid nights, check their mouths. That minty scent and cracking sound come from a fragrant pick-me-up that men, women and even children chew from breakfast until bedtime.

headline: In Monterey, Classics Turn Bankable
text: MONTEREY, Calif.

headline: A Met Who Is Forgotten but Not Gone
text: HOUSTON  The Mets’ clubhouse these days is a mix of apprehension and business as usual. The team is perilously close to playoff irrelevance, so the players know every game counts. But they try to remain loose by joking with one another, playing cards and sipping beers after games.

headline: From Houston to the Bronx, Some Divisions on Clemens
text: HOUSTON  Roger Clemens went to high school here, played college baseball at the University of Texas a few hours away and led the Astros to two playoff appearances in his three years on the team. A seven-time Cy Young Award winner, Clemens still lives in the area, and his son Koby is now in the Astros’ farm system.

headline: Russia: More Evidence in Crash That Killed Poles
text: Russia on Thursday gave Poland’s chief military prosecutor 11 volumes of new evidence in the April 10 plane crash that killed President Lech Kaczynski of Poland and 95 others, many of them top-ranking officials in the Polish government. The evidence included interviews with witnesses, photographs of the crash site, results of forensic testing of victims’ bodies and amateur video of the wreckage made shortly after the Russian-built Tu-154 aircraft crashed into a wooded area near Smolensk, in western Russia, Russian news agencies said. Polish officials have complained that Russia was slow in handing over the evidence. The Polish military prosecutor, Gen. Krzysztof Parulski, said Thursday that charges could be filed on the basis of the evidence, but he did not elaborate.

headline: South Africa: Rubber Bullets Wound Striking Workers
text: A strike for higher wages by more than one million public employees  teachers and health care workers among them  entered its second day on Thursday. At least five strikers were wounded when a police officer fired rubber bullets at a crowd trying to block the exit ramp of a Johannesburg highway, the police said.

headline: The Netherlands: Witness-intimidation Inquiry
text: A judge at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has ordered an independent inquiry into complaints by defense witnesses and associates of the Serbian nationalist leader Vojislav Seselj, that investigators working for the prosecution in the past had pressured or intimidated witnesses for Mr. Seselj. Mr. Seselj, a former leader of the Serbian Radical Party, surrendered to the court in 2003 to face charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity in the former Yugoslavia. He has frequently disrupted proceedings and threatened the court while acting as his own lawyer. Although the trial is continuing, Mr. Seselj was recently sentenced to 18 months’ imprisonment for contempt of court and revealing the names of protected witnesses.

headline: For Intel, a Merger Of Fish and Fowl
text: Intel’s $7.7 billion deal to buy the security firm McAfee is a surprising gamble. Mobile devices are the chip industry’s future, and Intel has fallen behind. It is betting that combining McAfee’s security software with its hardware will give it a leg up. But investors who knocked down Intel’s shares are rightly skeptical the chip maker can pull it off.

headline: Harold Connolly, Who Beat Odds in Olympics and Romance, Dies at 79
text: Harold Connolly, who overcame a withered left arm to win the hammer throw in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics and who then, after a storybook cold war romance, married the women’s discus champion, Olga Fikotova of Czechoslovakia, died on Wednesday in Catonsville, Md. He was 79.

headline: North Korea: South Korea Boat Broke Law, North Says
text: North Korea confirmed Thursday that it was holding a South Korean fishing boat and its seven-man crew, 11 days after its navy detained the craft in the Korean Peninsula. The crew members  four South Koreans and three Chinese  “confessed” to fishing illegally in North Korean waters on Aug. 8, the North’s state-run news agency, KCNA, said. It did not clarify whether or when North Korea would release the crew, which South Korea has been requesting.

headline: Fish Defeats Gasquet to Advance to Quarterfinals
text: Just as one American tennis player is surging, another may miss the United States Open. Mardy Fish continued his blistering summer play, winning for the 14th time in his past 15 matches, beating Richard Gasquet, 7-5, 6-2, Thursday to advance to the quarterfinals at the Cincinnati Masters in Mason, Ohio.

headline: Israelis and Palestinians to Resume Talks, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton is expected to announce Friday that Israel and the Palestinians will return to direct negotiations for the first time in 20 months, delivering the Obama administration a small victory in its protracted effort to revive the Middle East peace process, two officials briefed on the situation said Thursday evening.

headline: Rising Stars Open up a Lead at NH Tournament
text: Behind two consecutive wins by Hikaru Nakamura, including a demolition of Loek Van Wely on Thursday, the youngsters lead the experienced team by three points.

text: HOUSTON  It was like Groundhog Day in August on Thursday. Once again, the Mets got solid starting pitching and excellent fielding, and once again, they failed to string together enough hits to win.

headline: Arms Suspect Vows to Win Case in U.S. After Extradition Order
text: BANGKOK  Viktor Bout, a Russian businessman who is expected to face gun-running charges in the United States following his extradition from Thailand, expressed confidence on Friday that he would ultimately be exonerated.

headline: Talks on Opening Clinic in St. Vincent’s Building Are Stalled Over Birth Control
text: Negotiations to open an urgent-care center at the shuttered St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village have been stalled by a dispute over financial terms and by demands by former officials of the institution, a Roman Catholic hospital, that birth control not be made available there, officials close to the negotiations said on Thursday.

headline: Fan Jumps From Balcony
text: A young man jumped from the balcony at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, N.Y., on Wednesday night and plunged 25 feet to the seats below, the New York State Park Police said. The man fell shortly before 10 p.m., during a sold-out Phish concert, and was airlifted to the Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, N.Y., where he was treated for his injuries, the police said in a statement. Several news reports said the man was 25, but the police said his identity was still being confirmed; a spokeswoman for the hospital said a man had been taken there by helicopter from the theater on Wednesday night and was in critical but stable condition. His name was not released. Live Nation Entertainment, the promoter of the concerts at Jones Beach, and representatives of the band did not respond to requests for comment.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Justin Guarini of ‘idol’ Joins Musical Cast
text: Months before the official opening of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,” theatergoers have thrilled to each incremental casting announcement for this musical adaptation of the Pedro Almodóvar comedy, as celebrated Broadway stars like Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott and Laura Benanti were added to its ensemble. Who, these impatient observers wondered, would be cast in the final principal role of this production? Now they have their answer. Justin Guarini, above, the runner-up on the first season of “American Idol,” has joined the musical’s cast, Lincoln Center Theater said on Thursday. Mr. Guarini, who was beaten by Kelly Clarkson for the “Idol” crown in 2002, will play the role of Carlos, the son of Ivan (Mr. Mitchell) and Lucia (Ms. LuPone). It will be the Broadway debut of Mr. Guarini, who previously appeared in a workshop version of the Beach Boys musical “Good Vibrations” and with Ms. Clarkson in the film “From Justin to Kelly.” “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” is directed by Bartlett Sher with a book by Jeffrey Lane and music and lyrics by David Yazbek. It is to begin previews at the Belasco Theater on Oct. 2 and open on Nov. 4.
