text: maim •\ˈmam\• verb

headline: And So It Goes: Vonnegut Library to Open
text: Though he may or may not continue to exist in the Tralfamadorian sense of the word, a part of Kurt Vonnegut, below, will live on in an Indianapolis library dedicated to him that will contain artifacts from his life and career. The Associated Press reported on Wednesday that the Kurt Vonnegut Memorial Library will have its opening in November, where it will display first-edition books by the “Slaughterhouse Five” and “Sirens of Titans” author, who died in 2007, as well as a replica of his writing studio, items he collected during his service in World War II and numerous rejection letters he received before achieving his literary fame. “We have boxes of rejection letters,” Edie Vonnegut, the author’s oldest daughter, told The A.P., “letters saying, ‘You have no talent and we suggest you give up writing.’ He did not have an easy time of it, and I think for anyone who wants to be a writer, it will be important for them to see how tough it was for him.” The 1,100-square-foot space will also feature the Purple Heart that Vonnegut was awarded for a wound he received as a soldier, as well as a gallery of his line art and his cigarette-stained Smith Corona typewriter.

headline: Geraldine Brooks Wins Literary Peace Prize
text: Geraldine Brooks, a novelist and journalist who covered conflicts in the Balkans, the Middle East and Africa, was named the recipient of the 2010 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for Lifetime Achievement, its organizers said on Thursday. Sharon Rab, the founder of the Dayton Literary Peace Prize Foundation, said Ms. Brooks “reveals to her readers what their political leaders try to hide  the ugly realities of conflict and its destructive effects even on those far from the frontlines.” She continued, “We are delighted to be honoring a writer whose skill, imagination, and unique background allow her to create vivid characters whose stories help people understand the vital importance of fostering peace throughout the world.” Ms. Brooks, 54, also the winner of the Pulitzer Prize in fiction in 2006, for her novel “March,” will receive a $10,000 prize.

headline: Brooklyn Museum to Extend Hours
text: Beginning Oct. 6 the Brooklyn Museum, above, will keep later hours, the museum announced, staying open until 6 p.m. on Wednesdays and 10 p.m. on Thursdays and Fridays. (It is now open until 5 p.m. on those days.) To offset the change, the museum will open an hour later, at 11 a.m. Weekend hours, from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., will remain the same. “Clearly there’s a need for more opportunities post-5 o’clock, whether it’s families with kids getting out of school, or people coming from work, or younger people going on dates,” the museum’s director, Arnold L. Lehman, said in a phone interview. “We wanted to make a change that would better accommodate a very broad-based audience.” He said the museum would organize programs for Thursday and Friday evenings, like lectures and films. The museum will hire a few extra people in visitor services and the store to accommodate the new hours, he said, “but in both instances our hope is that our suggested admission will more than cover whatever costs we have.” The museum, which suggests that adults contribute $10, has struggled over the last decade in its attempts to increase attendance and to navigate between serving established museum audiences and attracting new audiences with populist fare. (Attendance in 2009 was 340,000, down 23 percent from the year before.)

headline: Ex-Morgan Wealth Chief on Primerica Board
text: Ellyn McColgan, the former head of wealth management at Morgan Stanley, has joined the board of financial services firm Primerica, the company said Thursday.

headline: Correction

She has written three, not two. (In addition to the two mentioned, “Are You There, Vodka? It’s Me, Chelsea,” and “Chelsea Chelsea Bang Bang,” she wrote an earlier memoir, “My Horizontal Life: A Collection of One-Night Stands.”)

headline: Keeping Score: Growing Complexity for Cooperstown
text: The National Baseball Hall of Fame’s election system is heading for a meltdown. With an abundance of qualified candidates becoming eligible and the cloud of steroid accusations and perjury indictments, the elections for the classes of 2013 and 2014 appear likely to cause the kind of Hall of Fame ballot gridlock we haven’t seen since the Hall’s creation in 1936.

headline: Expansionary Austerity?

I didn’t have space to deal with the other part of the austerity cult: the belief that the gods will reward austerity with economic expansion. But it’s equally unfounded in any actual evidence.

headline: N.Y.C. Start-Ups Have Area Code Envy
text: Ever since New York City began incorporating the dreaded 646 area code, Manhattan-ites have been divided into the haves and have-nots — with the coveted, and traditional, 212 area code transformed from an afterthought into a three-digit status symbol. Mostly the issue was relegated to one’s home phone. Now, tech start-ups are find themselves suffering what The Wall Street Journal called “212 lust.”

headline: Conductor Speaks Out After His Arrest
text: Paul Hillier, below, the conductor who was arrested en route to his appearance at the Mostly Mozart Festival for nonpayment of child support, said he was withholding the money from his former wife because she did not allow his daughters to visit him, The Daily Mail of London reported on Wednesday. Mr. Hillier, the chief conductor of Ars Nova Copenhagen, was indicted on Aug. 5 by an Oregon grand jury on four felony counts of criminal nonsupport for failing to make approximately $90,000 in payments for his two daughters, who live in that state. Last week he was apprehended at Newark Liberty International Airport, taken to the Essex County Jail and released  after wiring the money he owed  in time to attend his ensemble’s performance at Alice Tully Hall last Friday. In a statement, Mr. Hillier, 61, told The Daily Mail that he had been treated “with great courtesy and understanding” by the Department of Homeland Security officials who detained him. He added that he had paid his child support to his daughters, now 24 and 19, regularly “for several years,” but despite the visitation rights he had been granted in his divorce, “the visitation was totally and very effectively prevented by the girls’ mother.” Mr. Hillier wrote: “I feel this loss very deeply, and I feel that my rights as a father have been comprehensively trampled into the ground.”

headline: Essar Looking Outside India for Acquisitions
text: This has been a week of heightened interest in India’s power companies, with Blackstone taking a chunk of Moser Baer Projects Private and indicating it would invest $4 billion in the country over the next 5 years. Now, The Financial Times reports, India’s Essar Energy is considering its own acquisitions off the subcontinent.

text: Citic Securities and China Merchants Securities are injecting money into their Hong Kong units as China prepares to allow more foreign investment in its stock and debt markets.

headline: Moore’s Mystery Fund Manager Unveiled?

headline: In Hong Kong, Exploring Hitchcock’s Early Days
text: Hong Kong continues to prove itself as a city with a large population of cinema lovers, with a smartly curated retrospective on the eternal master of suspense, Alfred Hitchcock. What sets this retrospective apart is that it has dedicated half of the screenings to his early period as a director in Britain, including some lesser-known films, starting on Sept. 10. A series of his American films begins on Nov. 5.

text: After losing about $3.43 billion on bad loans in Ireland in the first half of 2010, Lloyds Banking Group is pulling out of the country. A review of its Irish business-lending operations “concluded that there was little opportunity for scalable growth in the future,” the bank said.

headline: Becoming a Family of Four

She’d hoped to be past the morning sickness by now, she writes, but it is lingering, just like last time, and that isn’t helping her feeling that everything is out of control.

headline: Swiss Tourism Suffers as Franc Value Rises
text: Exporters in any country are susceptible to currency fluctuations, but in Switzerland the effect is particularly extreme. The strong franc, which has risen more than 10 percent against the euro this year, has made Swiss chemicals, machinery and watches—the country’s three most important exports–more expensive for foreign buyers.

headline: Student Challenge Favorite | A Right to Eat
text: This week, as Katherine and I discussed our lists of favorites from last week’s Summer Reading challenge, it became clear that we needed another voice. So we enlisted the help of B. J. Jacobs, a New York Times digital marketing intern and college student (and a fan of The Learning Network). B. Although the book is attributed to the fictitious authors George Beard and Harold Hutchins, it’s really the work of Dav Pilkey, the writer and illustrator of the mildly naughty, wildly popular “Captain Underpants” series for younger readers.

headline: Dust Bowl Haunts Wheat Farmers
text: Wheat got a bad rap in the 1930s, and has been faulted in environmental retrospectives ever since as the crop that caused the Dust Bowl in the Great Depression. It’s only partly true, of course –- it could have been any of a number of other crops that boomed too hard in the go-go 1920s, causing too many small farmers on the high plains to plant too much on land too fragile to sustain the load. Drought and the collapse of farm prices did the rest. A newly vulnerable landscape peeled up from its moorings and blew away before the eyes of a horrified nation.

headline: Revisiting the Russian Name I Changed
text: The day I decided to change my name was the day a letter arrived addressed to Alina Vileskin. I remember staring at the envelope, wondering how I’d never noticed that by replacing just one letter, my last name, Vilenkin, became Vile Skin. It was easy to take this as an omen. Vilenkin was a fine last name, I thought, for Russian physicists or hockey players. For aspiring indie rock singers? Not so much.

headline: Evaluating the Potential of a Business
text: Over the past 28 years, SRC has acquired or invested in more than 60 different ventures. We think of these expansions as ways to fuel not only our company’s growth but also the careers of our associates. Practicing open-book management helps us cultivate leaders throughout the organization, and we like to create opportunities for those leaders either by acquiring outside companies or investing in companies that our associates start.

headline: The Charitable-Giving Divide
text: With the battle over whether to extend the Bush tax cuts for the wealthy shaping up as the major political event of the fall, opponents of repeal were handed a bounteous gift this summer when Bill Gates, Warren Buffett and 38 others announced that they formed a pact to give at least half their wealth to charity. After all, what better illustration could there be of the great social good that wealthy people can do when the government lets them keep their hard-earned dollars to spend as they please?

headline: Friday Reading: Open House Horror Stories
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The In-Law
text: Although you are a woman of accomplishment — a former member of Congress from Pennsylvania, the head of a nonprofit called Women’s Campaign International and the mother of a combined family of 11 children — you seem destined to be known as Chelsea Clinton’s mother-in-law. How do you feel about your new title?  I made a promise that I will not talk about this, and I’m sticking to my guns. Today my passion rests with Women’s Campaign International. I am convinced that in order to have a world that works, we need more empowered women at the table worldwide.

headline: What ‘Fact-Checking’ Means Online
text: The day I became a fact-checker at The New Yorker, I received one set of red pencils and one set of No. 2 pencils. [FC: There used to be a training period before the pencils.] [[VH: O.K. for “the day I became a fact-checker” to designate end of training period?]]

headline: Disheartening Talk
text: While preparing to give me a stress test, a technician checked my resting heart rate. I could see the EKG and hear my heart in action. As I was wired up and moved to the treadmill, the technician said that she was fascinated with the heart, had studied it and knew that “there is no way it came from an ape.” Then she added, “Only divine creation could have created such an organ.” I didn’t want to hear her religious views, but I felt vulnerable, because I was having a test performed in a doctor’s office, and said nothing. Should I speak to her boss? P.W., PASADENA, CALIF.

headline: Leaks
text: When is a leak not a leak? Last month’s release of the Afghan war logs — tens of thousands of classified documents unveiled by the Web site WikiLeaks — stretched the semantics of leak to a bursting point.

headline: Objects of Desire
text: Hips are practically vestigial on models, like fingers on whales. Ditto for busts, although implant technology has occasionally produced runway bodies resembling cantaloupes on stilts. But the fall 2010 shows from Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, Prada, Miu Miu and others were all about the womanly clothes of the 1950s and early ’60s. Cleavage spilled. Full skirts flared. Women’s Wear Daily labeled the trend ‘‘the voluptuous model moment’’ and virtually hailed it as an affirmative-action program for the curvy girls who usually only get to work the lingerie catalogs.

headline: A Design Campaign for Bananas
text: If you’ve ever wondered why it seems impossible to fill a grocery cart without adding at least one item whose packaging has been redesigned, the answer to your question is the fact that you’ve asked it. “New look! Same great taste!” openly confesses the blatant goal of catching your eye for no substantial reason. Humans have always noticed novelty, but it’s harder to get our attention in the multicolored and abundant context of a megamart, where one heap of bananas looks much like another.

headline: Colbert to Welcome Home Iraq Troops in Special Broadcasts
text: As American troops return from concluding combat operations in Iraq, some of them will soon be deployed to a friendlier front:  the studio audience of “The Colbert Report.” On his Comedy Central broadcast Thursday night, Stephen Colbert, the stubbornly opinionated alter ego of the comedian Stephen Colbert, announced that he would devote two of his shows, on Sept. 8 and 9, to celebrating and thanking American service members. Announcing the special series, “Been There: Won That: The Returnification of the American-Do Troopscape,” Mr. Colbert said: “No matter how you felt about this war, we Americans sent them off to fight it. And now that it’s over, we should thank them. And quickly, because I think a lot of them are getting sent to Afghanistan.”

But what puzzles me is this: why do the priests have such influence? Never mind the victims (we never do); anyone who listened to the priests has lost a lot of money.

headline: The Poetry of Prose
text: We English speakers have been terribly insecure about our ability to communicate in our native tongue for at least 200 years, if the number of books aiming to correct errors in our speech and writing released during that time is any measure. Basic grammar books have existed since the 16th century, but it wasn’t until the 18th that guides like Robert Baker’s “Reflections on the English Language” (1770) and James Elphinston’s charmingly titled “Inglish Orthoggraphy, Epittomized” (1790) began specifically addressing common mistakes of usage. It was in the 1800s, though, that anxiety over usage really started to mount, with hundreds of grammars and polemics finding their way to print: 1829 saw “The Vulgarities of Speech Corrected: With Elegant Expressions for Provincial and Vulgar English, Scots, and Irish; for the Use of Those Who are Unacquainted With Grammar”; in 1841 there was “Decline of the English Language: The Cause and Probable Consequences”; and “A Plea for the Queen’s English” came out in 1863. For the most part these were pragmatic and steely-eyed affairs, not the kinds of books to employ excess humor or display too-great charity regarding the vicissitudes of usage.

headline: Inside the List
text: FRANZEN COMES ALIVE! “Freedom,” Jonathan Franzen’s long-awaited follow-up to “The Corrections,” is almost certain to make the best-seller list, so let’s just get our coverage out of the way now. Like its predecessor, “Freedom” is set mainly in the Midwest, and Franzen’s own Midwesternness has drawn plenty of commentary. Sam Tanenhaus, who calls the new novel “a masterpiece of American fiction” on our Aug. 29 cover, recently wrote in a blog post, “Franzen is attuned to the differences between the Eastern Seaboard’s voluptuary pleasures and indulgences, and the midland’s homelier values.” Meanwhile, Sam Anderson of New York magazine, in his rave, scored the Midwestern literary metaphor of the year, saying that some of Franzen’s sentences “are so well written you want to pluck them out, stab them with little corn holders and eat them.”

headline: Birth Control Doesn’t Have to Mean the Pill
text: THERE was a time when Becky Thurmond Fowler neglected to take her birth control pills for days on end. But she didn’t worry, because she and her husband, Dan, wanted to have a child at some point. “It wouldn’t have been the end of the world if I got pregnant,” she said.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THREE STATIONS,  by Martin Cruz Smith (Simon & Schuster, $25.99.) In Smith’s seventh Russian mystery, the villains are corrupt bureaucrats and capitalists, and the hero, as ever, is Arkady Renko, investigator.

headline: Paperback Row
text: GENEROSITY: An Enhancement,  by Richard Powers (Picador, $15.) What if there were a gene for happiness? In his 10th novel, Powers presents a young Algerian refugee who is cheerful and optimistic despite having lived through horrors. A teacher and a counselor at her college attempt to understand her and eventually introduce her to a Craig Venter-like geneticist; she becomes a celebrity, with mixed results. Powers “manages the difficult feat” of making the young woman “plausible and even fascinating,” and the book is “an excellent introduction to Powers’s work,” our reviewer, Jay McInerney, said.

headline: Soul Deep
text: Earlier this year, I watched someone close to me die. A raw couple of weeks later, with the kind of timing that leaves you unsure whether to laugh or cry, our family dog suddenly had to be put down. In the days and weeks that followed, I heard myself trying to explain the awful, numbing collision of these two deaths, and I worried that I sounded at best ludicrous, at worst callous.

headline: She Remembered, He Remembered
text: In fiction as in life, you can’t save people from themselves. Although that never keeps anyone from trying, as Rosecrans Baldwin’s amiable first novel demonstrates. Dr. Victor Aaron is 58 years old, a research scientist specializing in Alzheimer’s disease at a small (but well endowed) college on Mount Desert Island in Maine. Almost three years earlier, he lost his wife, Sara, in a car accident. They had no children. Everyone around Victor is concerned about him, and with good reason. His response to Sara’s death is not so much stoic as anesthetized. He goes about his routines of healthy breakfast, swimming, work and more work, seeming increasingly numb and remote. As another character puts it, “Your wife had died and everyone knew but you.”

headline: Now Online | T Women’s Fashion Fall 2010
text: At T, we strive to make every issue a well-rounded one. And this season, fashion is actually on the same page, with its embrace of women who literally bust the mold. Suzy Menkes contemplates the sudden appearance of breasts on the runway. Our cover star, Freida Pinto, of “Slumdog” fame, a rare beauty with a candor to match, throws a few curve balls at Horacio Silva — and a glass of wine at the photographer Ryan McGinley. Linda Yablonsky encounters the artist Nathalie Djurberg, whose twisted, animated feats of clay celebrate bodies emaciated, voluptuous and obese; Christopher Petkanas delves into Maxime de la Falaise‘s smoldering unpublished memoirs and discovers a true lady Libertine; and Holly Brubach rediscovers the work of Caroline Blackwood, a brilliant writer whose talents are often eclipsed by her status as muse to Lucian Freud. Elsewhere, Daphne Merkin wonders if a couple of bosomy looks on the Louis Vuitton runway can conquer our much larger social fear of flesh (probably not); Ford Models revs up its engines with a more diverse lineup of faces and bodies; and the actress Laetitia Casta fills Brigitte Bardot’s shoes — and everything else. See all related posts »

headline: Beyond the Paper
text: Reading about the mass unemployment of tens of thousands of reporters and editors in the unfolding print apocalypse, or talking with nervous, demoralized friends and former colleagues in various newsrooms and magazine offices (“I almost took this latest buyout”), I sometimes recall the opening lines of John Updike’s “Rabbit Redux,” with its ghostly procession of hot-metal type­setters streaming out of a Linotype printing plant in the twilight of the 1960s. Their jobs are about to be rendered obsolete as offset printing, with its keyboard entry and computer tape, ushers in an era of electronic publishing that will ultimately lead to the World Wide Web and beyond. “You learned the skill and now the bottom’s dropping out,” Rabbit’s boss at the plant says as he lays him off. The novel’s premo­nition of concomitant joblessness and ink­lessness seems like an eerie prophecy of print journalism’s current disruptions.

headline: ‘View With Favor’
text: On November 2, 1917, the British government expressed its sympathy with Jewish Zionist aspirations and announced that it would use its “best endeavors” to facilitate “the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people.” The announcement came in a letter from Foreign Secretary Arthur James Balfour to Lord Rothschild, the unofficial leader of the British Jewish community. The Balfour declaration became the diplomatic foundation stone of the state of Israel; it is considered the original sin by Israel’s opponents.

headline: What’s Left Behind
text: Kim Dana Kupperman seems obsessed with her relatives’ ashes. Those of her mother, who killed herself. (“What kind of person keeps her mother’s ashes on a shelf in the closet like a sweater that’s too tight or a handbag that requires repair?”) Of her father, who had long since moved on to other wives. (“I did not want to parcel out my father’s ashes. I felt superstitious about dividing a man loved and hated by his two surviving children.”) Of her brother, who died of AIDS. (“I take the Métro home with what is left of my brother, in a bag that now hangs from my shoulder.”)

headline: Popcorn Reverie
text: Scratch a film critic, and you’re likely to find a jazz buff. That the opposite is also true was suggested as far back as the 1930s by Otis Ferguson, the startlingly prescient critic who covered jazz, when it was a genuinely popular art, along with Hollywood movies, then entering their classical phase, for The New Republic. It’s demonstrated again by Gary Giddins, the eminent jazz critic of The Village Voice from 1973 to 2003, and more recently the DVD columnist of The New York Sun (which ceased publication in 2008).

headline: Forms and Functions
text: In 1847, Oliver Byrne, “surveyor of Her Majesty’s settlements in the Falkland Islands and author of numerous mathematical works,” wrote and designed an illustrated book so far ahead of its time that, with the exception of a few passé typographical details, it could have been published today. In fact, it has been published today, as a stunning boxed facsimile edition. Given its “less is more” layout and primary-color palette — red, blue, yellow, black — THE FIRST SIX BOOKS OF THE ELEMENTS OF EUCLID: In Which Coloured Diagrams and Symbols Are Used Instead of Letters for the Greater Ease of Learners (Taschen, $59.99) prefigures the art and design of 20th-century avant-garde movements. Yet although the illustration on the title page is the spitting image of a de Stijl and Bauhaus design, the mid-19th-­century publishing date disqualifies it from being “modern” in the Museum of Modern Art sense of the word. Now, that’s obtuse.

headline: For a Change, U.S. Debt Is Staying in the U.S.
text: NEARLY a decade ago, when budget deficits ballooned in the United States, it was widely said that Washington  like Blanche DuBois in “A Streetcar Named Desire”  “depended on the kindness of strangers.” In Washington’s case, foreigners  mostly foreign governments  stepped in to buy most of the new Treasury securities being issued.

headline: Now Showing | VPL in Action
text: Clothes don’t really come to life until they are on a living — moving — body. So whatever you want to make of the proliferation of electronic media, it makes sense that a lot of fashion designers are gravitating toward film and video as a way of presenting and promoting their collections. “I feel videos are much more liberating in that they show movement and action,” says the designer Victoria Bartlett. “In my eyes it’s a more modern way of capturing an image. There is a natural ease that comes with video — it’s more spontaneous and produces more surprising results.” For her fall collection, which she says is “all about fracturing, fragmenting and re-assembling,” she teamed up with the artist Jessica Mitrani and the dancer Maria Hassabi to create a video that explores Siamese twinning with graphic, optical effects created in post-production, and also with a pair of doubled underwear.

text: 4:38 p.m. | Updated Paolo Pellegrini, the hedge fund manager best known for helping John A. Paulson earn billions by betting against subprime mortgages, plans to return outside investor capital in his firm by Sept. 30.

headline: U.S. Mortgage Relief Effort Is Falling Short of Its Goal
text: The Obama administration’s mortgage relief program, originally intended to shield three million households from foreclosure, now looks as if it will permanently help as few as one-sixth of that number.

headline: National Team Gives Chicago’s Rose Bigger Stage to Prove He Can Lead
text: Derrick Rose grew up on the South Side of Chicago, so he has a keen appreciation of Michael Jordan’s Bulls. Those teams were far different from the more recent incarnations, and Rose, who was 9 when Jordan was in his final season in Chicago, has seen many players come and go since then.

headline: The Littlest Redshirts Sit Out Kindergarten
text: AFTER all those attentive early childhood rituals — the flashcards, the Kumon, the Dora the Explorer, the mornings spent in cutting-edge playgrounds — who wouldn’t want to give their children a head start when it’s finally time to set off for school?

headline: It’s Actual Life. No, It’s Drama. No, It’s Both.
text: JEAN-LUC GODARD once observed that every fictional film is a documentary of its actors. Jacques Rivette finessed the aphorism, proposing that every film is a documentary of its own making, not only a record for posterity of the people in it but also a window into the culture that produced it.

headline: In Atlantic Debris, Good News and Bad
text: Global production and disposal of plastics of all kinds has grown roughly five-fold since the early 1980s, but that increase is not reflected in the amount of plastic debris found in the western North Atlantic, according to a study published Friday in the journal Science.

headline: Hamburger Helper | Fatih Akin
text: With “Head-On” (2004) and “The Edge of Heaven” (2007), Fatih Akin made two important films that mine the politically charged frontier between Turkey, the country abandoned by Akin’s immigrant parents, and Germany, where the director was born and raised. These stories, by turns exuberant, brooding and violent, are the first parts of what Akin calls his “love, death and the devil” trilogy. “Soul Kitchen,” which opens in New York today, is Akin’s latest film but it is a break from the trilogy, not its finale. The devil, Akin says, will have to wait.

headline: Gumbo Along the Hudson
text: IT was another scorching day in New York, but in his short-sleeve shirt, black jeans and snakeskin shoes, Dr. John, the piano-playing, politically assertive singer and songwriter from New Orleans, was quite comfortable.

headline: Bank of America’s Ex-Chief Denies Fraud Charges
text: 6:43 p.m. | Updated  Kenneth D. Lewis, the former chief executive of Bank of America, responding to a lawsuit filed early this year by the attorney general of New York, denied allegations of fraud in connection with the bank’s merger with Merrill Lynch, The New York Times’s Louise Story reports.

headline: The Disease: Fatal. The Treatment: Mockery
text: “WHAT can you say about a 25-year-old girl who died?”

headline: D.I.Y. Music Labels Embrace D.I.Y. Film
text: ON a midsummer night a few dozen people, many in glasses and with messenger bags, gathered at Zebulon, a bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to watch a new low-budget movie called “The Builder.” The story of a contemplative Irish immigrant, it moved slowly, driven by atmosphere rather than dialogue, but the audience watched patiently at small candle-lit tables, beers in hand. It was the antithesis of a typical summer-movie outing, but that was sort of the point.

headline: A Case for Carrying an Extra Wedge, or Two
text: At a recent golf clinic, Annika Sorenstam asked the three dozen recreational golfers standing around her how many wedges they carried in their golf bags. Only one golfer said four.

headline: Emanuel Ungaro: A History
text: An interactive timeline of the designer’s history.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, Katy Perry, ‘Tosh.0’ and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Here Comes the Bride. Again.
text: SARAH LANDMAN wore an elaborate silk satin and tulle gown on June 12, befitting her traditional wedding to David Schwarz. But by the time a band started playing for their 350 guests on the grounds of the Philadelphia Navy Yard, Ms. Landman had ditched her Oscar de la Renta for a custom-made white cocktail frock embellished with sequins and ostrich feathers.

headline: The Fall of the House of Ungaro
text: When I first heard this story from Asim Abdullah’s own lips, over tea at the St. Regis hotel in New York, I thought he was one of the saddest cases I had ever met. He is really in over his head, I thought, and he isn’t even done yet. I should probably tell you that this was not my first meeting with Asim Abdullah  that occurred late one night in January, briefly and quite by chance, as I was leaving the Hôtel Plaza Athénée in Paris following dinner with some girlfriends, but clearly it left an impression on me. As we set foot toward the revolving door, one of my friends, a lively, stunning woman, nudged me and said under her breath, “That’s the man who owns Ungaro.”

headline: For Pianist, Software Is Replacing Sonatas
text: The pianist Robert Taub was puttering around the house one afternoon in 2004 while his teen-age daughter was practicing for a violin lesson  a Schubert sonatina in A minor. His assessment of her playing was diplomatic: “She needed to be reminded about notes and rhythms.”

headline: E-Books Make Readers Less Isolated
text: VOLUMES have been written about technology’s ability to connect people. But burying one’s nose in a book has always been somewhat isolating  with its unspoken assertion that the reader does not want to be disturbed. So what about a device that occupies the evolving intersection between?

headline: ‘Morning Miracle’
text: 1. Balls and Ghosts

headline: Tribune Co. Bankruptcy Plan Hits New Snag
text: 6:53 p.m. | Updated  The troubled saga that has become the Tribune Company bankruptcy unraveled further on Friday as a lawyer for the publishing giant said negotiations with creditors had broken down, The New York Times’s Jeremy W. Peters reports.

headline: Week in Pictures, Aug. 20
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: How to Be Frugal and Still Be Asked on Dates
text: Saving may be making a comeback, but it still hasn’t gotten its sexy back, particularly if you’re a man.

headline: On Dance: A Q. and A. With Li Cunxin
text: When Mikhail Baryshnikov defected from the Soviet Union in 1974, it was a major news event, drawing world attention to both the ballet dancer and ballet. But he was hardly the only dancer to defect from a Communist country and take up residence in the West in that era. Li Cunxin (pronounced Lee TZWUN-sheen) left his home in rural China and his way of life to pursue ballet in the United States, a journey chronicled in “Mao’s Last Dancer,” a new movie by Bruce Beresford.

headline: ‘The Balfour Declaration’
text: Chapter One: Palestine Before World War I

headline: Book Review Podcast: Eliza Griswold
text: This week: Eliza Griswold, author of “The Tenth Parallel”; Chrystia Freeland on the problem with business journalism; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: At the Royalton’s Bar, a Collective of Cocktail Talent
text: Like a Danny Ocean of the cocktail world, Howard Wein, senior vice president of food and beverage of Morgans Hotel Group, has cherry-picked some of the most prominent and talented bar figures from across the United States to create the liquor program at Forty Four, the lobby bar and restaurant of Midtown Manhattan’s Royalton  hotel, which closed this summer for a revamp and is set to reopen in mid-September.

headline: Eurofile | Smitten With Sitges
text: Just before dusk in Sitges, Spain, a few bathers are still bobbing up and down in the gentle surf of the Mediterranean, and a man dressed in white is stacking the beach loungers for the day. Starlings streak through a melon-colored sky garnished with raspberry-colored clouds, and when the lights come on at the parish church on the promontory overlooking the sea, it means it’s probably time to start to thinking about dinner.

headline: No Charges Filed Against Working Families Party
text: Federal prosecutors have closed an investigation of the Working Families Party without filing any charges, party officials said on Friday, a major boost for the beleaguered organization as it gears up for the November statewide elections.

headline: Films in Search of the Faithful
text: LIKE the Nativity story told at Christmas, or the 30,000th rerun of “It’s a Wonderful Life,” the story of mainstream cinema and Christian America has a familiar ring to it: a surprise hit comes along, revealing a huge, underserved religious audience ready to be relieved of its entertainment dollars. There is a subsequent gnashing of teeth or rending of garments along the corporate canyons of Hollywood. Regret, anguish and then some gestures of atonement, through marketing outreach and promises of more faith-friendly entertainment.

headline: G.M. Names Perry Head of Marketing for Chevrolet
text: Joel Ewanick, vice president for American marketing at General Motors, announced Thursday that Christopher J. Perry would replace Jim Campbell as vice president for Chevrolet marketing. Mr. Campbell will remain a part of the Chevrolet marketing team as vice president for performance vehicles and motorsports.

headline: A Leaner Fish Hungers for Open Success
text: MASON, Ohio – The burger joint taunted Mardy Fish.

headline: Addressing Money in Your Online Dating Profile
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I look at the question of whether frugality is sexy. Apparently, a lot of people don’t think so, though plenty of people will at least admit that frugal people are smart.

headline: Umpires Moved, and a Tactic Is Removed
text: Bill Walsh had figured out every angle of his West Coast offense by the time Brent Jones was a young tight end for the San Francisco 49ers. But more than 20 years later, Jones is still struck by an edge Walsh had divined that never appeared in a playbook.

headline: ‘Lost’ Auction Features Prop Cars
text: They’re not exactly vehicles you’d find at the Barrett-Jackson auctions, but for fans who followed the six seasons of “Lost,” a 40-year-old Chevrolet Camaro and an old blue-and-white Volkswagen Type 2 van may be valuable mobile souvenirs.

headline: Sternberg: Chief Director of Private Dream Factory
text: MOST of Hollywood’s great directors were compulsive storytellers — spellbinders, as different as John Ford and Samuel Fuller, who liked nothing better than to spin a gripping yarn.

headline: Embedistan: Embedding in Iraq During the Invasion and the Drawdown
text: At dusk one day in late March 2003, an editor got through on my satellite phone somewhere out in the desert north of Najaf, where I was embedded with the First Brigade of the Army’s Third Infantry Division as it pushed toward Baghdad.

headline: Your Experience With Tutors for Your Children
text: In this weekend’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan looks at the world of private tutors for school-age children, whether for specific subject matters, standardized test preparation or college admissions.

headline: Democracy, the Hard Way
text: Congratulations, New York: You are about to be compliant with federal election guidelines. True, it took about eight years, and sure, 49 other states got there first. But don’t worry about that.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Eliza Griswold
text: This week: Eliza Griswold, author of “The Tenth Parallel”; Chrystia Freeland on the problem with business journalism; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Taking a Spin With Electronic Voting
text: The City Critic tries out New York’s new ballots and voting machines, describes each step in the process.

headline: Sex Scandal Has U.S. Buddhists Looking Within
text: Sooner or later, every traditional faith has to confront sexual impropriety by its spiritual leaders: extramarital sex, or sex with the wrong people (members of the congregation, minors) or, for supposedly celibate clergy, any sex at all.

headline: In the City, Serious Laughter
text: Every week, a group of people gather in a Manhattan textile office to exercise their laughter. No joke. It's called laughter yoga, and its popularity is growing.

headline: Judge Rejects Challenge Against Willets Point Project
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg won a victory on Friday for his $3 billion blueprint for apartments, offices and stores in the shadow of Citi Field in Willets Point, Queens, when a judge rejected a challenge from opponents in the area.

headline: Improvox: Unzipping the DNA of Music
text: Improvox is a new iPad application developed by the concert pianist Robert Taub and his company MuseAmi. Improvox came about after Mr. Taub tried to help his children learn music.

headline: Congo River Journey Ends in Boat Troubles
text: Thursday, Aug. 19

headline: Music That Rises Above the City’s Roar
text: NEW York is a ceaseless cacophony of screeches, rumbles and honks, an improvisational score of stilted, urban jazz. Some call it noise. We drown it out with our iPods, become inured to sleeping and working under it and eventually tune the city out. But New York is also filled with veritable sidewalk symphonies: free, live concerts in public places that attract their own devoted groupies.

headline: Wikipedia Editing for Zionists
text: Updated | Monday | 10:14 a.m. This week in Jerusalem, two Israeli groups hoping to smite their online enemies, both domestic and foreign, began a course in the “Zionist editing” of Wikipedia entries.

headline: Chic in Review | Snooki’s Got a Brand New (Gucci) Bag
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Free Music in New York City
text: Where to go for sidewalk symphonies worth listening to.

headline: Through a Joint Venture, Rio Tinto Strives to Repair Its Relations With China
text: SHANGHAI  Not long ago, China and the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto seemed to be locked in battle.

headline: Lambs Club to Open for Breakfast, With Lunch and Dinner Soon
text: It has taken years for Sant Chatwal to convert what had been the Lambs Club, in a landmarked Stanford White building at 132 West 44th Street, into the Chatwal Hotel. Geoffrey Zakarian, the executive chef of the Lambs Club restaurant in the hotel, has already been on board for three years.

headline: Would You Declare or Defend?
text: The Summer Nationals in New Orleans produced many fascinating deals, none more so than the one from the Von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs in the diagram.

headline: D.S.C.C. Barely Outraises N.R.S.C. in July
text: In the race between two Senate campaign groups to raise cash this election year, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee was ahead in July – but not by much.

headline: Street Hoops, Close Up and Personal
text: A popular tournament in Harlem brings famous and almost-famous players back to the game’s raucous urban roots.

headline: Kraft Goes Bowl-ing to Help Feed the Country
text: Critics of the commercialization of popular culture often say that silly names of sponsored college bowl games — like the Poulan Weed Eater Independence Bowl or the I.B.M. OS/2 Fiesta Bowl — are from hunger. One marketer, however, is devoting its first sponsored bowl game to fighting hunger.

headline: TV Loves Rex Ryan but Sacks His Mouth
text: The bag of tricks that NFL Films uses to turn the repetitive thump-and-crunch of football into operatic entertainment hasn’t changed much over the last 40 years. Wagnerian music. Voice-of-God narration. Steam rising off overheated players. Slow-motion passes that ... take ... forever to nestle in a receiver’s hands.

headline: An Abundance of Tomatoes
text: Arisco Farms maintains numerous greenhouses, in which it grows herbs, annuals, perennials and various other ornamental plants. But in a summer that has been hot and sun-drenched, you may come away with the impression that this 70-acre enterprise is all about tomatoes.

headline: Nespresso and Rivals Vie for Dominance in Coffee War
text: PARIS — George Clooney and John Malkovich aren’t the only coffee lovers fighting over a Nespresso these days.

headline: Big Sisters
text: The September issues are a nice bit of heavy lifting, along with the sack of tomatoes I picked up this morning, and I may fold before I finish reading them. Or make a pot of tomato sauce.

headline: Data on Demand Is an Opportunity
text: The real-time Web is a bit of a chaotic mess.

text: The pianist performed this week as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival.

headline: In an East Harlem Town House, Traces of the Area’s Italian-American Past
text: The owners, both artists, have filled virtually every corner of the house with their work.

headline: Pictures of the Day: At the Mosques and Elsewhere
text: The second Friday of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan is marked in the first three pictures in the slide show. Slide 4 offers a most unusual angle on an all-too-familiar scene: the delivery of desperately needed food to a besieged village.

headline: Roommates Who Click
text: MADDI GILJE, who will soon leave home in St. Louis to start at New York University, has chatted all summer with her new roommate, Amelia Dudley of Baltimore. She could be talking to her twin.

headline: Obama Spends Vacation Day Shopping and Golfing
text: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass. — As if the cover of Time magazine were not enough, now the writer Jonathan Franzen has a presidential plug to add to the advance publicity for his latest novel, “Freedom”: On Friday President Obama bought the book on the first full day of his 10-day stay on Martha’s Vineyard.

headline: Gyros-a-Go-Go
text: Kalamaki, a new cafe in Roslyn, offers Greek street food with a pedigree. The owners are also the people behind Trata, the refined Mediterranean seafood restaurant in Roslyn (with a second Trata in Water Mill and Kouzina by Trata, a sibling, in Manhattan). Here they are turning out souvlaki and gyros in a sleek, modern space with six tables and additional seating at the counter.

headline: Striving for a Menu as Nice as the Scenery
text: VIEW is aptly named. The Oakdale restaurant, formerly known as Riverview, has the panoramic vistas of the Connetquot River and the Great South Bay that have always made this location special. Now the restaurant is too.

text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: The Improbable and the ‘Impossible’
text: While remarking on the tendency of Americans to display both ignorance and credulousness in conversations with pollsters (a tendency I’ve commented on before), Matt Yglesias notes that people are much more likely to believe in ghosts, E.S.P. and so forth than they are to think that Barack Obama is a Muslim. Then he adds:

text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Richard A. Kessler
text: Mr. Kessler, 53, is the chief operating officer of Benenson Capital Partners, a New York-based private company that owns and manages about 150 domestic and foreign properties, including the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers, which it owns through a partnership.

headline: Goodbye, Glitzy Condo Pitches
text: THE recession has not been kind to many new condominium developments in New York City. Some have stalled midconstruction; others have shuttered their sales offices because of inactivity; some developers have had to return deposits to buyers as prices took a nosedive.

headline: Measuring Real Estate by Compass Point
text: AFTER 22 years in a four-bedroom two-bath high ranch in Lindenhurst, Michele Cacciatore is headed north. To the North Shore, that is.

headline: New Online Help From Fannie Mae
text: SINCE foreclosures started to rise sharply in 2007, struggling borrowers have been offered a lot of help online. Some is well-meaning, but some is simply a scam in the form of expensive “debt relief” services that may be offered free elsewhere.

headline: A Rental Rebound in Fairfield County
text: AT this time last year, the Fairfield County housing market was so saturated with rental properties that landlords were cutting rents to hold onto tenants.

headline: Hudson Square
text: THE compact area known as Hudson Square  and also known, at times, as West SoHo and the South Village  is nestled among three of the most desirable neighborhoods in Manhattan: the West Village, TriBeCa and SoHo. As luxury condominiums take root in this once overwhelmingly commercial sector, it is establishing a presence.

headline: Caretakers of a Vanishing Little Italy
text: FOR decades, the signs along East 116th Street have promoted cheap airfare to San Juan and Mexico City, and the restaurants and bodegas have hawked cuchifritos and tacos. Except for venerable institutions like Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church and culinary landmarks like Rao’s and Patsy’s, little survives from the days when East Harlem was the city’s largest and most vibrant Italian-American neighborhood.

headline: A Lot of Laundry, and a Little Luck
text: SINCE their arrival in the city two years ago, Jennifer McCarron and Brandi Molitor have had more than their share of bad apartment luck.

headline: A Chill in High-End Alpine
text: HERE’S what a lagging market looks like in Alpine, N.J., the town perennially identified by Forbes Magazine as one of the “most expensive” ZIP codes in the country:

headline: Just Hanging Out Under the Bridge, in Summer’s Heat
text: “Why then just close the eyes  and wait for the day to come  the happy day to come when flesh melts at so many degrees,” says Winnie in Samuel Beckett’s “Happy Days,” up to her waist in earth. Later she mentions “this hellish sun” to whose light she is exposed. It is by no means sure that the day of eventual melting will indeed be happy.

headline: Alternative Asanas
text: Activities like laughter yoga, AntiGravity yoga and acroyoga may bear little resemblance to a traditional yoga practice, but have benefits of their own.

headline: In Balances and Counterbalances, the Classicism of India
text: Amid the often flimsy dance offerings of the New York International Fringe Festival, it’s heartening to find something as beautiful, serious and substantial as “Swaha: Rituals of Union” (would that it had a more winning title). Performed on Wednesday by five women from Trinayan Dance Theater in the Odissi style of Indian dance, it’s a 70-minute suite of solos, duets and larger ensembles that demonstrates a range of truly classical virtues.

headline: Brant vs. Brant: Divorce Celebrity Style
text: AROUND 9:55 a.m. on Aug. 6, a parade of lawyers filed into Room 7B at the courthouse in Stamford, Conn., to hear a motion in the divorce case between the newsprint magnate Peter M. Brant and his estranged wife, Stephanie Seymour. Last year Ms. Seymour, a beauty prized for her angel-winged walk as a Victoria’s Secret model, sued to end their 15-year marriage. She claimed he was too controlling. He contended she cheated on him and abused drugs and alcohol.

headline: Portraits of a Marriage
text: The bitterness of a dispute between a former model and her wealthy husband has taken on a life of its own.

headline: Heading West: A Ballet Dancer From China Looks Back
text: When Mikhail Baryshnikov defected from the Soviet Union in 1974, it was a major news event, drawing world attention to both the ballet dancer and ballet. But he was hardly the only dancer to defect from a Communist country and take up residence in the West in that era. Li Cunxin (pronounced Lee TZWUN-sheen) left his home in rural China and his way of life to pursue ballet in the United States, a journey chronicled in “Mao’s Last Dancer,” a new movie by Bruce Beresford.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 20
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include bilingual nannies, the annual Assumption Day Parade and Central Park trees.

headline: George Georgiou in Modern Turkey
text: Correction appended | Through a series of haunting architectural and landscape scenes of Turkey’s rush toward modernization — and the resulting tension between the secular and the modern — George Georgiou has visually put his finger on a kind of listless alienation which at times can seem to pervade globalized society. Turkey, traditionally a bridge between East and West, seemed a logical choice for such a cautionary vision.

headline: Garb Fest
text: ‘Oh, those are fantastic! I want to see them! They’re adorable! Let me fix your socks,” Patricia Fox cries out when she spies Suzanne Golden’s shoes, a pair of black and white Comme des Garçons winkle pickers festooned with rhinestone buckles that serve as a counterpoint to the rest of Golden’s black-and-white Junya Watanabe ensemble. Fox, who is wearing a veiled chapeau with a blossom brim, a 1950s sequined floral jacket, a chiffon dress with a hobble skirt and a pair of beaded gloves, is meeting Golden for the first time at a tea party I have organized at the Carlyle Hotel, an event I refer to (but not out loud) as a “nutty-dressers” luncheon. In addition to Golden and Fox, there are two other invited guests: Tziporah Salamon (1930s cheongsam, bamboo pinwheel hat, 200-year-old Chinese handbag) and Iris Apfel (a tunic made by one of China’s ethnic minorities, a clanging necklace from a Tunisian souk, signature humongous spectacles). I’ve been seeing these grande dames around town for years, and now, finally, I’ve got them all in one spot — at one table — so I can ask them how it came to be that the four of them glitter like spectacular if wacky jewels in an otherwise mostly mundane pedestrian landscape.

headline: One Night, Two Shows, Four Masters
text: Despite the thorough dissimilarity between the two concerts that the Mostly Mozart Festival presented on Thursday night, you could tease out common threads if you tried hard. Both the performance by the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall and the after-hours recital by the pianist Jeremy Denk at the Kaplan Penthouse hung on a central duality. The Freiburg ensemble offered works by Haydn and Mozart for side-by-side comparison; Mr. Denk performed what appeared to be disparate works by Liszt and Beethoven, proving in the process that the pairing was far from incompatible.

headline: Atlantic Yards Show Finds a Home Stage
text: The downtown theater company the Civilians has announced that its new show, “In the Footprint: The Battle Over the Atlantic Yards,” will open in November at the Irondale Center, a theater space not far from the future home of the planned 22-acre development. “In the Footprint,” a series of songs and monologues, is about the conflicts over the building of the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project near Brooklyn’s downtown that is to include eight million square feet of apartments, offices, stores and an arena for the New Jersey Nets. The show’s material has been taken from interviews that members of the Civilians conducted with Brooklyn residents, community organizers, business owners and politicians who are either for or against the project. Performances are scheduled to begin on Nov. 12 and continue through Dec. 11 at the center at Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene. The Civilians have scheduled a cabaret performance with songs from the show at Joe’s Pub on Sept. 10.

headline: ‘Brother’ Outruns N.F.L.
text: The latest “Big Brother” elimination helped CBS earn another ratings victory as that reality show drew 7.5 million viewers on Thursday night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. With live coverage of the N.F.L. preseason, Fox finished in a virtual tie for second place with ABC. Final ratings were not immediately available for the matchup between the New England Patriots and Atlanta Falcons, but preliminary estimates show the game drew roughly as many viewers as ABC’s average for the night with a “Wipeout” rerun at 8 (6.6 million), “Rookie Blue” at 9 (6.4 million) and the debut episode of “Nightline Prime: Secrets of Your Mind” at 10 (4.1 million). NBC was a distant fourth with repeats.

headline: When Heroes Return
text: THE scene around the basketball court at Holcombe Rucker Park in Harlem was bordering on chaos.

headline: Colbert to Welcome Home Iraq Troops With Specials
text: As American troops return from concluding combat operations in Iraq, some of them will soon be deployed to a friendlier front: the studio audience of “The Colbert Report.” During his Comedy Central show on Thursday night, Stephen Colbert, right, said that he would devote two of his shows, on Sept. 8 and 9, to celebrating and thanking American service members. Announcing the special series, “Been There, Won That: The Returnification of the American-Do Troopscape,” Mr. Colbert said: “No matter how you felt about this war, we Americans sent them off to fight it. And now that it’s over, we should thank them. And quickly, because I think a lot of them are getting sent to Afghanistan.” Comedy Central said in a news release that the two episodes will feature guests including Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.; Gen. Ray Odierno, the commander of the United States military forces in Iraq; and Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia. The audiences on those nights, the network said, will comprise “veterans and active-duty service men and women in the studio as well as by satellite audiences from Walter Reed hospital, Iraq and Afghanistan.”

headline: Fatal Dive Onto Stage at California Concert
text: One day after a man was injured after jumping from a balcony at a Phish concert in Wantagh, N.Y., a concertgoer was killed at a performance by the Swell Season in Saratoga, Calif., after diving onto the stage and landing near the band. Sgt. Rick Sung, of the Santa Clara County Sheriff’s Office, said on Friday morning that sheriff’s deputies were dispatched about 9 p.m. on Thursday to the Mountain Winery after reports that a man had jumped from a roof above the stage. The man, whose name was not released, attended the concert with a friend. The friend told sheriff’s deputies that the man had disappeared during the outdoor performance, leaving behind his personal belongings, then reappeared on the roof, from which he jumped. Sergeant Sung said a doctor in the audience and an emergency medical technician at the performance space tried C.P.R. but were unable to revive him. The death is being investigated as a suicide, pending an autopsy.

headline: Patterson and Meyer Are Top-Earning Authors
text: The publishing industry may be in the doldrums, but it appears that James Patterson ($70 million), above left, Stephenie Meyer ($40 million), above right, and Stephen King ($34 million) are not. They topped the list of the 10 highest-paid authors, according to Forbes magazine, which tracked earnings collected over the last year, ending June 1. They were followed by Danielle Steel ($32 million), Ken Follett ($20 million), Dean Koontz ($18 million), Janet Evanovich ($16 million), John Grisham ($15 million) and Nicholas Sparks ($14 million). No. 10 was J. K. Rowling ($10 million), even though she did not publish a new book that year.

headline: Troubled Folk Museum Receives a Reprieve
text: The financially struggling American Folk Art Museum received a reprieve on Thursday. Six months after disclosing that it could no longer make payments on the $32 million it borrowed through a bond issue to finance its new building, the museum has reached a forbearance agreement with the company that insured its bonds. The agreement, which expires on June 30, means that the insurer, ACA Financial Guaranty, will cover payments to the bondholders and will not immediately exercise its rights under the financing agreement, which include foreclosing on the museum’s home. The museum’s director, Maria Ann Conelli, wrote in an e-mail that the institution considered the agreement “a positive step forward,” but that the details were confidential. ACA officials did not respond to phone messages left at their office. The bonds were issued through the Trust for Cultural Resources, a public benefit corporation created in 1980 to help cultural institutions finance capital projects. The museum, which has occupied its home on West 53rd Street since 2001, is the first organization to default on an agreement to pay off bonds that have been issued through the trust.

headline: Mozart as Appetizer, Schumann as a Main Course

The festival’s resident orchestra, playing in Avery Fisher Hall, offered Weber, Mendelssohn and Schumann, the last in a nod to his 200th birthday this year. Another 200th birthday, that of Chopin, was recognized in an after-hours recital by the Macedonian pianist Simon Trpceski at the Kaplan Penthouse.

headline: Sneaking a Poundcake Out of the Food Processor
text: POUNDCAKE, with its impressive amounts of butter, eggs, flour and sugar, has long been something I’ve loved to eat, and I thought I produced a pretty good one. But the one made by Grandaisy Bakery in Manhattan kills mine. Perhaps not too surprising, since it turns out its recipe is adapted from the great Flo Braker’s “Simple Art of Perfect Baking.”

headline: When Is a Muslim Not a Muslim?
text: Do you think Barack Obama is a Muslim? According to the Pew Center, many Americans do. According to Politico’s Josh Gerstein, Time magazine’s pollsters found that a majority of Republicans do. But here’s another question: How many of the Americans who say they think Barack Obama is a Muslim actually believe that he is one? That’s not as obtuse a query as it might appear, as some of the blogosphere’s better minds have argued in recent days.

headline: No Safe Harbors in Argentina

Soon, she wrangles a small, serious role Off Broadway that reminds the world she can act (and show up on time). Other roles follow. Critics nod, the media applaud, Martin Scorsese is on the phone. Lindsay Lohan is back. Bow, curtain, fin.

headline: Not Just Peking Duck, but a Ceremony
text: PEKING DUCK, a centuries-old tradition in Beijing restaurants, customarily comprised several courses. John Blofeld, an English scholar who lived in Beijing (then called Peking) during the 1930s and wrote about its culture in “City of Lingering Splendour” (Shambhala Publications, 1989), describes the progression of dishes like this: First the crisp skin was carved from the bird, tableside, in pieces, and wrapped in hot bread with shredded spring onion and sauce; this was followed by an omelet cooked in duck fat; then the meat, sautéed with bamboo shoots; the innards, batter-fried; finishing with soup, made from the bones.

headline: The Beat Goes on, With Echoes of the Dead
text: IT will not surprise fans of the Grateful Dead to learn that the official origins of the Rhythm Devils, a group helmed by Mickey Hart and Bill Kreutzmann, former percussionists for the Dead, are a little murky.

headline: A Tech-Happy Global Race, at the Speed of Jules Verne
text: Phileas Fogg, the icy Englishman with a mania for whist and punctuality, was born in 1873, in Jules Verne’s deliciously wry novel “Le Tour du Monde en Quatre-Vingts Jours” (translated that same year into “Around the World in 80 Days”). By 1874, Fogg’s bet-generated circumnavigation of the globe had already found a home on the Paris stage, in a spectacular production that featured a steamship, a live elephant and a locomotive pulling a three-car train.

headline: Bodies, and Souls, Rocking Away

headline: Does It Make Sense? Who Cares? It’s a Pinter Play
text: Really, what’s all the fuss about Harold Pinter’s plays being so mysterious, confusing, unknowable? Yes, they can be all those things, but that’s the essence of their charm. And it can be an enormous relief to go to the theater and not worry about logic or factual truth.

headline: Steaks, Yes, but Aiming to Please All Appetites

headline: 50 Years of Wedded Life in Two Acts
text: Agnes and Michael may not have the instant name recognition of other long-term musical-comedy couples, like Tevye and Golde or Georges and Albin. But as the bride and groom at the center (and also the periphery) of “I Do! I Do!” they spend a lot more time together, plowing through 50 years of wedded life, blissful and otherwise, as we watch.

headline: An Act of Creation, Laid Bare
text: SEEKING to woo audiences, some symphony orchestras have been opening rehearsals to the public. But on Sept. 12, the New Haven Symphony Orchestra will go further, supplementing the open rehearsal of a new work with a public discussion and performance that will involve the composer, who will also be the soloist. The format will be a first for the orchestra under the conductor and music director William Boughton.

headline: Baja New York
text: The heart of a food lovers’ microcomplex that has sprouted amid a patchwork of condominium towers, low-rise apartments and porch-encircled homes along the Atlantic Ocean, this stand on Beach 96th Street off Rockaway Beach Boulevard in Queens is like a little slice of Baja at the city’s edge. Now in its third summer, Rockaway Taco attracts robust weekend crowds of beachgoers, many from neo-bohemian north Brooklyn, who line up for tacos, quesadillas, plaintain chips and fresh juices and vie for the few ottoman seats on the outdoor patio. But midday on Tuesday, the scene was mellow, with just a few friends and surfers seeking a good wave.

headline: Disorder in the Court, From the Mind of Mamet
text: May we not have peace?” asks the Judge in “Romance,” a play by David Mamet that turns out to have a deceptively mild-mannered (and puzzling) title. Since it’s a farce that skewers religious prejudices, domestic squabbles and strife in the Middle East, among other targets, the answer is no, we may have no peace during the 80 minutes of this 2005 comedy at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor. We do get frequent laughs, clever puns and an earful of four-letter words and over-the-top insults.

headline: A Day for Food (Bears Not Invited)
text: For Ruth Reichl, the saving grace in losing her decade-long job as editor in chief of Gourmet when the magazine closed last year is being able to live, write and cook virtually full time at her glassy hilltop home in Spencertown, N.Y., in Columbia County. Ms. Reichl, 62, who was the dining critic for The New York Times before joining Gourmet, is the author of four memoirs and is currently working on a cookbook and a novel. She and her husband, Michael Singer, 70, a retired news producer for CBS, have a son, Nick, 21, who attends Wesleyan University, and a 17-year-old cat, Stella, as well as an apartment on the Upper West Side.

headline: Intuit Forecast Tops Estimates, and Its Shares Rise
text: Shares of Intuit, the provider of personal finance software, rose the most in 18 months in Nasdaq composite trading after its annual forecast topped estimates and the company announced plans for a $2 billion stock buyback. Sales will increase at least 8 percent, to $3.74 billion, in the next fiscal year, which ends July 31, 2011, the company said. Excluding some costs, earnings will rise at least 12 percent, to $2.36 a share. Analysts had estimated revenue of $3.72 billion and profit of $2.30 a share on average. Intuit is adding Internet features and using acquisitions to offer more online services. The recently purchased Mint personal finance site increased its customers to more than three million last quarter. Shares in Intuit rose $5.83, or 15 percent, to $44.60.

headline: A Design Challenge for St. Louis: Connecting the City With Its Symbol
text: ST. LOUIS  Since its completion in 1965, the Gateway Arch, Eero Saarinen’s shimmering steel monument to westward expansion, has been an iconic point of pride for this city.

headline: Up From the Streets, Then Gunned Down
text: From his birth in Jamaica to his death at the hands of a robber in a kosher liquor store in Brooklyn on Thursday night, the life of Yoseph Robinson was filled with unusual turns.

headline: Marlins Catcher Suspended
text: Andy Pettitte was eager to talk Friday about pitching and his health, but not about Roger Clemens, his friend and former teammate who was indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he lied to Congress by saying he never used performance-enhancing drugs. Pettitte and his wife, Laura, supplied damaging testimony that contradicted Clemens and helped lead to the indictment.

headline: Pettitte Declines to Say Anything About His Testimony
text: Andy Pettitte was eager to talk Friday about pitching and his health, but not about Roger Clemens, his friend and former teammate who was indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he lied to Congress by saying he never used performance-enhancing drugs. Pettitte and his wife, Laura, supplied damaging testimony that contradicted Clemens and helped lead to the indictment.

headline: Harvard Finds Scientist Guilty of Misconduct
text: Harvard University said Friday that it had found a prominent researcher, Marc Hauser, “solely responsible” for eight instances of scientific misconduct.

headline: Teenage Summer, the Fasting Version
text: Why was Jay Mustafic, 14, wearing slippers over his tube socks the other afternoon on a basketball court in his neighborhood in Ridgewood, Queens?

headline: Tea for Two in Washington
text: The N.F.L. tight end who lost Washington State’s Republican Senate primary Tuesday won’t endorse the Republican nominee until he commits to three Tea Party pillars.

headline: Details Faulted in Plan to Pay Oil Spill Claims
text: NEW ORLEANS  The details of exactly how the $20 billion fund set up by BP will be distributed to those affected by the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, which were made public on Friday, did little to allay worries and suspicions here, drawing instead sharp criticism from several quarters.

headline: Democratic Choice for Attorney General
text: New York State needs a tough, honest and smart attorney general to attack the culture of corruption in Albany, protect consumers and the environment, and promote civil rights. An effective attorney general also can take on major national issues. Eliot Spitzer, before becoming governor and imploding, went after Wall Street fraud. The present attorney general, Andrew Cuomo, has forced reforms on the corrupt student loan industry.

headline: Mexico: 6 Police Officers Held in Fatal Abduction of Mayor
text: Five local police officers and a transit officer have been arrested in connection with this week’s kidnapping and killing of Mayor Edelmiro Cavazos of Santiago, a town about 20 miles south of Monterrey in the northern state of Nuevo León, state officials said on Friday. One suspect had been assigned as a guard to Mayor Cavazos, and the others are accused of acting as lookouts for a group of gunmen who took the mayor from his home on Sunday night. His body was found on Wednesday on the side of a mountain road. He had been bound, blindfolded and then shot to death.

headline: Russia: Putin Ousts Forestry Chief
text: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin dismissed the head of Russia’s forestry service on Friday in the wake of this summer’s horrific wildfires, which consumed more than two million acres of land and caused more than 50 deaths. Mr. Putin had criticized the official, Aleksei Savinov, for shoddy fire prevention efforts, which he said allowed the blazes to burn out of control, overwhelming firefighters and consuming whole villages. Mr. Savinov will be replaced by his deputy.

headline: Ukraine: Searching for a Missing Journalist
text: President Viktor F. Yanukovich said on Friday that he was taking “personal control” over the search for a missing investigative reporter, whose disappearance over a week ago has prompted colleagues and rights groups to raise concerns about the possibility of foul play. Mr. Yanukovich called on law enforcement agencies across Ukraine to do everything “possible and impossible” to find the journalist, Vasyl Klymentyev, the editor of a newspaper in the eastern city of Kharkiv, a statement on the president’s Web site said. Press freedom advocates have complained about media censorship since Mr. Yanukovich took office in February.

headline: For Mets’ Rodriguez, a Possible Path
text: CHICAGO  Thursday afternoon was a test for Carlos Zambrano.

headline: Some Help for Pakistan
text: Pakistan needs more help now and will need much more in the weeks and months ahead. This week the world  finally  began waking up to the devastation wrought by monsoon flooding that has already affected 20 million people.

headline: Eric T. Schneiderman Is Endorsed by the Times Board
text: The editorial board of The New York Times has endorsed State Senator Eric T. Schneiderman, who represents parts of Manhattan and the Bronx, in the Democratic primary for attorney general of New York.

headline: A Mountain in the Stream
text: It is now possible to imagine the beginning of the end of a ruinous form of mining called “mountaintop removal.” Local opposition is growing, and the Environmental Protection Agency is tightening rules and threatening to veto one of the largest projects ever proposed.

headline: U.S. Inaction Lets Look-Alike Tubes Kill Patients
text: Thirty-five weeks pregnant, Robin Rodgers was vomiting and losing weight, so her doctor hospitalized her and ordered that she be fed through a tube until the birth of her daughter.

headline: Russia: Lease on Base Is Extended
text: Russia has extended the lease on a military base in Armenia until 2044, further entrenching its military forces in the strategic south Caucasus region, where it fought a war with Georgia in 2008. The extension is also expected to help Russia in its role as an arbiter of the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the separatist region of Nagorno-Karabakh. The new agreement also allows forces from the base to be deployed outside the borders of the former Soviet Union.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,218 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Mario Obledo, Hispanic Rights Leader, Dies at 78
text: Mario G. Obledo, who slept on the floor with 12 siblings as the child of illegal immigrants and went on to become the founder and leader of major Hispanic-American organizations, a top state official in California and an acid critic of stereotypical treatment of Mexicans, died Wednesday in Sacramento. He was 78.

headline: ‘A Little Bugging!’
text: President Richard Nixon stage-directed White House aides on how to deny the conspiracy to undermine the 1972 presidential election. “Just say this is a comedy of errors, without getting into it,” he insisted with his signature mordancy, a year before he resigned in disgrace. Nearly 40 years later and the loyalists are still determined to block a full accounting of Nixon’s central role in the Watergate scandal.

headline: Consumers Clamoring for a Leader
text: So it turns out that the Elizabeth Warren rap video that went “viral” this week is actually a made-in-Hollywood production.

headline: Bloggingheads: Bomb Iran?
text: Flynt Leverett, left, of the New America Foundation and Reuel Marc Gerecht of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies debate bombing Iran.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sew Up a Hole
text: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times

headline: Oy Vey, Obama
text: Is President Obama good for the Jews? For more and more Jewish-Americans, the answer is no.

headline: Mets’ Manuel Predicts Bay Won’t Be Back This Season
text: PITTSBURGH — Mets left fielder Jason Bay’s season may be over because of lingering effects of a concussion, Manager Jerry Manuel said Friday.

headline: Consistency Eludes Burnett Again as Seattle Hits Him Hard
text: A. J. Burnett and Felix Hernandez are right-handed pitchers who share immense talent, a blazing fastball and a number but not a whole lot else. Burnett has spoken about his admiration for Hernandez’s changeup and his repeatable, fluid mechanics: At 33 years old, Burnett is striving to pitch with the consistency  and the dominance  that Hernandez, at 24, seems to supply in every start.

headline: Five and Five: No. 17, Utah
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 17, is Utah. You can find a larger Utah preview here.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Imam Behind New York Project Starts Mideast Tour
text: CAIRO  Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, the organizer of the planned Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan, arrived in Bahrain on Thursday to begin a three-country tour of the Persian Gulf sponsored by the United States State Department.

headline: Mets Seeking a First in Pittsburgh
text: PITTSBURGH  The Mets have not won a road series against a National League team this season, but they may have found the perfect foil to end that dismal streak.

headline: ‘Kiner’s Korner’ Returns, Dusted Off and in Digital
text: “Kiner’s Korner” is getting a new life online, providing Mets fans with a chance to see Ralph Kiner in his television heyday as the host of Channel 9’s postgame (and rain delay) show from a cramped studio in Shea Stadium.

headline: Who’s a Joker? Miller to Teach at U.S.C.
text: For a long time, Steve Miller’s rhyming of Texas, “facts is,” justice and taxes in “Take the Money and Run” was the most surprising turn he’d taken in his pop-music career. But he may have outdone himself by becoming an instructor at the University of Southern California. The Thornton School of Music at the university said that Mr. Miller, the guitarist and front man of the Steve Miller Band, will serve as an artist in residence starting with the fall term. He will present master classes for undergraduates enrolled in the school’s popular-music and music-industry programs, and lead seminars on tour planning and record production as well as workshops on more specific topics like guitar tone. “Every time he comes into contact with students, he just comes away energized and wants to work with them on more of a sustained basis,” Chris Sampson, associate dean of the Thornton School, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Miller is expected to be on campus at least twice a semester, following a schedule similar to the Thornton School’s other artists in residence: Patrice Rushen, the pianist and singer, and Lamont Dozier, the songwriter and producer.

headline: Bond Madness
text: Things are looking bleak for the economy; Goldman Sachs (no link) is predicting that 2nd quarter GDP growth will be revised down to 1.1%, and it’s downhill from here.

headline: Heckling and How to Retire in the N.F.L.
text: Mike Tanier, a contributing editor at FootballOutsiders.com, will write a weekly notebook during the preseason.
