text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 16, is Louisiana State. You can find a larger Louisiana State preview here.

headline: 30 Seconds With Venus Williams
text: Venus Williams turned 30 this year and remains one of the top tennis players in the world. A winner of 19 Grand Slam titles, she is ranked No. 5 in singles, and No. 2 in doubles with her sister Serena. On Thursday, she will conduct the Legends Clinic II, a live, interactive online clinic presented by Ralph Lauren from the courts on Randalls Island in New York. Tennis fans can submit questions in advance at RalphLauren.com.

headline: Citrus-Almond Poundcake
text: If poundcake were really as simple as a pound of flour, eggs, butter and sugar, they would all be the same. They’re not, and I’d nominate the recipe offered in this week’s Minimalist — a citrus-almond pound cake based on a recipe by Flo Braker — as one of the best.

headline: Saturday Word: Campaign Spending, and Deficits
text: President Obama criticized Senate Republican leaders on Saturday for blocking legislation that would have put restrictions on campaign spending by corporations and unions after the Supreme Court’s decision in the Citizens United case lifted many of those constraints.

headline: Spill Fund May Prove as Challenging as 9/11 Payments
text: At first blush, it would seem that Kenneth R. Feinberg, the man tapped to dole out BP’s $20 billion oil spill compensation fund, has been down this path before.

headline: U.S. Aids Lebanese Military Because of, and Despite, What It Gets in Return
text: WASHINGTON — Earlier this month, Israeli soldiers were pruning a tree on their country’s northern border when a firefight broke out with Lebanese soldiers across the fence, leaving one Israeli and four Lebanese dead.

headline: Urban Forager | In This Wicked Weed, the Devil’s Trumpet Blows
text: Jimsonweed has been on my radar ever since I researched it for a presentation on wild weeds and fungi last year, so I was intrigued when I discovered some spiny seedpods recently in an alley in Gowanus, Brooklyn. Originally thinking they were empress tree pods, which are similarly sculptural but smooth, I brought them back to my workspace, where a friend helped to correctly identify them as Datura stramonium, or jimsonweed, and their source (the garden of a local artist around the corner).

headline: Support for Same-Sex Marriage, State by State
text: Support in the states for same-sex marriage, in 1994-6 and 2010.

headline: Over Time, a Gay Marriage Groundswell
text: Gay marriage is not going away as a highly emotional, contested issue. Proposition 8, the California ballot measure that bans same-sex marriage, has seen to that, as it winds its way through the federal courts.

headline: Iran Opens Its First Nuclear Power Plant
text: TEHRAN  Thirty-six years after construction began under the shah, Iran finally opened its first nuclear power plant at a ceremony on Saturday.

headline: Three on a Match
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The phrase “three on a match” comes from the old superstition that if three people light a cigarette from the same match, the third is going to die. I learned this from a wonderful 1932 film of that name — a good example of the wit and sophistication of American films before the Hayes code. Check it out if you love movies.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Tall Tales, Truth and My Twitter Diet
text: I want to feel healthy. I have a plan. I’ll outline it later today.

headline: Early Catchers Paid a Heavy Price
text: A baseball mystery was born last week when doctors at Boston University, having discovered a connection between brain injuries and a disorder resembling amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, brought up the possibility that Lou Gehrig did not have A.L.S., commonly known as Lou Gehrig’s Disease.

headline: As Mission Shifts in Iraq, Risks Linger for Obama
text: WASHINGTON  The official end of America’s combat mission in Iraq next week will fulfill the campaign promise that helped vault President Obama to the White House, but it also presents profound risks as he seeks to claim credit without issuing a premature declaration of victory.

headline: Disaster Strategy: The Soft Heart and the Hard Sell
text: Let’s all hope that Egypt, Turkey and Jordan soon get hit by a nice flood, earthquake or volcanic eruption.

headline: Sweden Adds to Drama Over Founder of WikiLeaks
text: LONDON  Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks Web site who is embroiled in a fight with the Pentagon over the disclosure of secret military documents, was caught up in a new drama on Saturday when Swedish prosecutors sought him for questioning on allegations of rape and molestation  and then announced the rape allegation was unfounded.

headline: Income Inequality and Financial Crises
text: David A. Moss, an economic and policy historian at the Harvard Business School, has spent years studying income inequality. While he has long believed that the growing disparity between the rich and poor was harmful to the people on the bottom, he says he hadn’t seen the risks to the world of finance, where many of the richest earn their great fortunes.

headline: With Merchandise Sales Down, Nascar Has High Hopes for Tiny Cars
text: Like fans of almost any other sport, Nascar devotees are eager to buy T-shirts and baseball caps with the names and car numbers of their favorite drivers and to wear them to racetracks  or even just to watch the races on television at home. But die-hard stock-car fans do not just stop there.

headline: A Champion Against Cancer, Now Under Siege
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Barry Bonds. Marion Jones. Alex Rodriguez. Roger Clemens. There is no shortage of athletes who have fallen from grace, their achievements on the playing field and their public stature compromised by accusations of cheating or revelations of criminal or otherwise repugnant behavior.

headline: The Twitter Diet
text: When The New York Times media reporter Brian Stelter wanted to lose weight, he asked for help and support from a surprising place: Twitter.

headline: On Twitter, a Key Flaw in N.F.L. Drug Tests
text: On Tuesday, Cincinnati wide receiver Chad Ochocinco posted on his Twitter page a photograph of a crumpled piece of paper that provided a peek into the N.F.L.’s drug testing program.

headline: Woods, a Man on His Own, Is No Longer One of a Kind
text: What on earth is wrong with Tiger Woods? It’s true he played a little better at the P.G.A. Championship, where he at least made the cut and finished in a tie for 28th, but lately he has been spraying the ball so badly that even the sternest critics of his personal life  the ones who wanted to ostracize him from golf  have to feel a little sorry for him. At the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational at Firestone two weeks ago, he looked like a hacker, hitting more trees than fairways on the way to posting a 75 and a 77 in the last two rounds.

headline: Trip to Europe for U.S. Team: Loose Change, Shrill Taunts
text: MADRID  Tom Izzo recalled seeing guards with machine guns standing in the aisles when he coached a United States basketball team in the Dominican Republic in 2003. Jerry Wainwright looked into the stands while coaching an American team in Serbia in 2007 and saw a sign with the acronym NATO and “North American Terrorist Organization.” The former Duke star Trajan Langdon said he had been hit by coins, seen batteries skip across the floor and felt spittle land on his back as his career took him through Italy, Greece, Turkey and Russia.

headline: Crime (Sex) and Punishment (Stoning)
text: It may be the oldest form of execution in the world, and it is certainly among the most barbaric. In the West, death by stoning is so remote from experience that it is best known through Monty Python skits and lurid fiction like Shirley Jackson’s short story “The Lottery.”

headline: From a Coach’s Whistle to a Drill Sergeant’s Snarl
text: FORT HUACHUCA, Ariz.  There were certainly reasons for Adam Hall, a University of Arizona safety, to be coasting. It was early in the morning, a 7:30 practice; the temperature was approaching 90 degrees; and the drudgery of preseason football camp had begun to take hold.

headline: Mets’ Draft Class of ’08 Shows Startling Promise
text: PITTSBURGH  The day eventually will come, whether next year or the year after, when Carlos Beltran has moved on to another team and the Mets will settle upon a different center fielder. If that is next April, the new center fielder could be Angel Pagan. If it is later, it could be a minor leaguer named Kirk Nieuwenhuis, who has made rapid progress through the Mets’ system.

headline: Heart Lighter and Game Honed, Point Guard Leads the Liberty
text: The pass found Leilani Mitchell deep in the right corner, and she drilled the 3-pointer. Mitchell dribbled along the left sideline, spotted Nicole Powell cutting to the basket on the opposite side and fired a perfect lead feed. Cappie Pondexter made a crosscourt fling to Mitchell on the left wing, and 3 more points swished through the Liberty’s net.

headline: A Breaststroke That Is Hard to Imitate and All but Impossible to Beat
text: IRVINE, Calif.  Breaststrokers are fish of a different school, with styles straight out of Dr. Seuss: flat strokes, surge strokes, high strokes, low strokes.

headline: The Turn From Goat to Hero, in Thomson’s Own Words
text: In 2006, Alan Schwarz interviewed Bobby Thomson for a chapter in his book “Once Upon a Game: Baseball’s Greatest Memories.” They collaborated on this essay, which not only relived perhaps the sport’s most famous moment, but also a day when Thomson feared he would be remembered as, of all things, a goat. Thomson died last Monday at 86.

headline: After Eight Olympic Gold Medals, What Can Phelps Do for an Encore?
text: IRVINE, Calif.  Michael Phelps is not Albert Haynesworth. He is out of shape for swimming, yes, but unlike Haynesworth, the Washington Redskins defensive lineman, Phelps did not fail conditioning tests.

headline: An Athlete With No Illusions About Steroids
text: In 1991, during a relaxed and lubricated private dinner, I said to Harold Connolly, winner of the 1956 Olympic hammer throw and a perennial world and United States champion: “It’s all timing. If you’d been born later, taken steroids, you could have won a few more gold medals.”

headline: Do the Top Billion Need New Goals?
text: Here’s a question to ponder over the weekend. There’s a set of Millennium Development Goals for the poorest of the poor — a cohort of humanity sometimes described as the “bottom billion.”

headline: Pirates Banking on Youth Movement
text: A race to watch in the final six weeks is the dubious one at the bottom of the standings. With the Baltimore Orioles playing better under their new manager, Buck Showalter, the Pittsburgh Pirates may have the edge for the worst record in the majors, which would give them the first pick in next year’s draft.

headline: Now Playing: Night of the Living Tech
text: Life in the media and communications terrarium, it seems, is getting increasingly perilous. The predictions of demise are piling up. Phone calls, e-mail, blogs and Facebook, according to digerati pundits recently, are speeding toward the grave. Last week, Wired magazine proclaimed, “The Web Is Dead.”

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JIMMY KIMMEL

headline: For Imam in Muslim Center Furor, a Hard Balancing Act
text: Not everyone in the Cairo lecture hall last February was buying the imam Feisal Abdul Rauf’s message. As he talked of reconciliation between America and Middle Eastern Muslims — his voice soft, almost New Agey — some questioners were so suspicious that he felt the need to declare that he was not an American agent.

headline: Roy Pinney, Man of Snakes, Baby Photos and Adventure, Is Dead at 98
text: At 17, he was living with natives in the South American jungle and, like them, wore a loincloth, got traditional tattoos, ate monkey and danced with the gods. He fell in love with a beautiful young woman, Mina, who reciprocated. They married. She soon died of malaria, and the young man pondered suicide.

headline: Fighting Words
text: "I've been accused of something I'm not guilty of. ... I have never taken steroids or H.G.H."—THE RETIRED PITCHER ROGER CLEMENS, TESTIFYING BEFORE THE HOUSE OVERSIGHT AND GOVERNMENT REFORM COMMITTEE IN 2008

headline: Prime Number
text: 51: The median age of viewers of the big four broadcast networks, Fox, CBS, NBC, and ABC, according to a study by Baseline Inc., a New York Times company that tracks data on the film and television industries. The audience has aged at twice the rate of the general population, according to Baseline, a trend that is changing the way broadcasters are approaching their business. The younger demographic once sought by the networks has increasingly migrated to cable and the Web, leaving the broadcasters to court older viewers, an adjustment that some in the industry welcome. “Don’t discount people who are in their 50s and 60s. ...,” one executive told The Associated Press. “The reality is these are the people with the money.”

headline: Back Then: 1951
text: Bobby Thomson, the New York Giant who hit "the shot heard round the world" against the Brooklyn Dodgers, propelling his team to the World Series, died last week at the age of 86.

headline: Smoke Is Not Getting Into Filmgoers’ Eyes
text: True, only one in five Americans smoke, down from almost one in four a decade ago. But the decline has stalled in recent years.

headline: Taliban Intensify Attacks Against Afghan Police
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban campaign focusing on the Afghan police appears to have intensified in recent days, with five attacks reported Saturday in which at least 15 policemen were killed throughout the country. Three of the policemen died in a NATO airstrike.

headline: University Head’s Housing Raises Ire
text: Five minutes before midnight on June 30, movers hauled the last boxes from a spectacular rented home in the Oakland Hills. The tenant’s lease was about to expire, and in his haste to get out, he left behind thousands of dollars of damage to the hardwood floors and Venetian plastered walls.

headline: Experience Isn’t Enough in Pakistani Flood Plain
text: KUNAL SHARIF, Pakistan  Half of the primary school for girls was shorn right off by the floodwaters that passed through here 20 days ago. The rest of the red-brick building now gapes over a steep drop to a new waterway that never existed before.

headline: The Summer That Ended All Summers
text: Leverett, Mass.

headline: Rookie Provides a Lift After a Day of Anxiety
text: The Yankees rookie Eduardo Nunez will probably never match Alex Rodriguez’s success. But for one game, at least, Nunez replaced Rodriguez at third base and was the star.

headline: Megamansion Estate Sale
text: Hundreds of strangers — many in little black cocktail dresses, some in white linen suits — showed up for an estate sale at Larry Dean’s Xanadu-like mansion.

headline: In Georgia, a Megamansion Is Finally Sold
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Bit by bit, Larry Dean’s life, at least as he had constructed it over the last two decades, was ebbing away.

headline: Come Again?
text: Republicans claim to be deeply worried about the deficit  their favorite political target, followed closely by President Obama’s relentlessly demonized health care reform. So why are they so determined to overturn one of the central cost-control mechanisms of the new reform law?

headline: Tom DeLay’s Legacy
text: The Justice Department decided last week not to bring charges against Tom DeLay, whose unethical conduct represented a modern low among Congressional leaders. The decision is a reminder that some of Washington’s worst big-money practices remain either legal or far too difficult to prosecute.

headline: In Case of Emergency: What Not to Do
text: WHOEVER suggested that all publicity is good publicity clearly never envisioned the wave of catastrophe engulfing high-profile corporations over the last year, laying waste to some of the most meticulously tailored reputations on earth.

headline: Injured Del Potro Will Not Play U.S. Open
text: A day after Serena Williams withdrew from the United States Open with a foot injury, the tournament announced that Juan Martin del Potro, the defending men’s champion, would also be unable to play. Del Potro has not competed in a tournament since the Australian Open in January because of a wrist injury. He had surgery on his right wrist in May.

headline: No Clear Winner in Australian Voting
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s Parliament faced the rare prospect of a stalemate on Saturday after voters apparently failed to deliver a clear majority to either the governing center-left Labor Party or a conservative opposition coalition in the tightest race seen here in decades.

headline: Debt’s Deadly Grip
text: IT’S one of the toughest lessons an investor has to learn: while the value of assets can plummet posthaste, it takes forever to shrink the debt that was used to buy them.

headline: Fixing a World That Fosters Fat
text: WHY are Americans getting fatter and fatter? The simple explanation is that we eat too much junk food and spend too much time in front of screens  be they television, phone or computer  to burn off all those empty calories.

headline: $9 Here, 20 Cents There and a Credit-Card Lawsuit
text: IT’S easier to steal a million dollars a dollar at a time than a million dollars once. So goes an old saying.

headline: Tax Cuts and the Wealthy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Feeding Those Parking Meters
text: To the Editor:

headline: Putting a Different Kind of Urban Decline to Use
text: If only the commute downtown could always be this much fun.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about proposed mountaintop mining at Coal River Mountain in West Virginia referred incorrectly to a court-brokered compromise in January on a planned wind farm in Greenbrier County, W.Va. It allowed work to proceed on more than half, or 67 of 124 proposed turbines there, and allowed up to 33 others to be added later, though some at sites not in the original proposal; it did not allow just “a small part” of the project to proceed.

headline: How Fox Betrayed Petraeus
text: THE “ground zero mosque,” as you may well know by now, is not at ground zero. It’s not a mosque but an Islamic cultural center containing a prayer room. It’s not going to determine President Obama’s political future or the elections of 2010 or 2012. Still, the battle that has broken out over this project in Lower Manhattan  on the “hallowed ground” of a shuttered Burlington Coat Factory store one block from the New York Dolls Gentlemen’s Club  will prove eventful all the same. And the consequences will be far more profound than any midterm election results or any of the grand debates now raging 24/7 over the parameters of tolerance, religious freedom, and the real estate gospel of location, location, location.

headline: Surprise, Surprise, Surprise
text: I just saw the movie “Invictus”  the story of how Nelson Mandela, in his first term as president of South Africa, enlists the country’s famed rugby team, the Springboks, on a mission to win the 1995 Rugby World Cup and, through that, to start the healing of that apartheid-torn land. The almost all-white Springboks had been a symbol of white domination, and blacks routinely rooted against them. When the post-apartheid, black-led South African sports committee moved to change the team’s name and colors, President Mandela stopped them. He explained that part of making whites feel at home in a black-led South Africa was not uprooting all their cherished symbols. “That is selfish thinking,” Mandela, played by Morgan Freeman, says in the movie. “It does not serve the nation.” Then speaking of South Africa’s whites, Mandela adds, “We have to surprise them with restraint and generosity.”

headline: Taking bin Laden’s Side
text: Is there any doubt about Osama bin Laden’s position on the not-at-ground-zero mosque?

headline: Nonprofit Fund Faces Questions About Conflicts and Selection Procedures
text: In late July, the Social Innovation Fund, a new $50 million federal program aimed at financing the replication of nonprofit programs that work, made its first grants.

headline: Enough, Already! One Consumer’s Pet Peeves
text: THE Haggler, as regular readers know, typically works on a very grand and ambitious scale, swashbuckling for consumer justice with just his bare hands and a telephone. The results often dazzle and amaze. But much of what is vexing about life as an American consumer today are teeny-weeny irritations  minor outrages that add up to a low background hum of bother.

headline: For Social Security, a Birthday Makeover
text: Social Security, now celebrating its 75th birthday, is receiving mixed diagnoses. Some analysts think the program is on solid fiscal ground for decades to come, while others fear that the impending retirement of the baby boom generation precipitates a crisis. In either case, it is always worth considering innovations to make the program more efficient and equitable. The Op-Ed page editors asked six experts to recommend specific fixes that could be part of a comprehensive reform package for the nation’s largest social insurance program.

headline: Harrison Price, a Planner of Disney Parks, Dies at 89
text: Harrison Price, an internationally known research economist who told the developers of the world’s most famous theme parks where to situate them  in the process putting Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., and Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla.  died on Aug. 15 in Pomona, Calif. He was 89.

headline: The Overconfidence Problem in Forecasting
text: BUSINESSES in nearly every industry were caught off guard by the Great Recession. Few leaders in business  or government, for that matter  seem to have even considered the possibility that an economic downturn of this magnitude could happen.

headline: Stretch | Laughter Yoga, Serious Benefits

headline: Betting on Growth While Playing Defense
text: INVESTORS shifted from full-blown fear as the stock market plummeted in 2008 to a mood of rampant risk-taking after the market took off in March 2009. They have now become nervous again, or so the conventional wisdom goes.

headline: Japan and the Ancient Art of Shrugging
text: GROSS domestic product figures for the second quarter show that China has overtaken Japan as the world’s second largest economy. I have been traveling while on leave from the university in Tokyo where I teach, and was in Paris when the news broke last week. My first reaction, frankly, was one of relief. In English, perhaps, one might say it was “a load off my shoulders.”

headline: The Healing Power of Construction Work
text: THE call came at 9:30 at night from the police detective, asking me about one of my carpenters. The detective was doing a follow-up investigation on a domestic disturbance and wanted to ask a few questions. Fine, no problem, I said  thinking of the big job we were in the middle of and how much I was depending on that carpenter.

headline: Martha Daniel: President, C.E.O. and Deacon
text: I’M the youngest of five. My dad worked two jobs, and my mother worked hard to make ends meet. In school, I was in the choir and the glee club and on the dance team. I also played sports. I needed money for several of these, so my mother would sew clothes and clean houses. Once she pawned our silverware and her wedding ring to get the money to make me a dress. She wasn’t educated, but she was smart.

headline: Rodriguez to Disabled List; Nova to Start Monday
text: Heading into Friday night’s game against the Seattle Mariners, the Yankees’ offense seemed back on track, and they had their cleanup batter back in the lineup.

text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  A band of gun-wielding men invaded a luxury hotel in Rio de Janeiro early Saturday and took 35 people hostage, before the police negotiated their freedom and the gunmen’s surrender, officials said.

headline: Free That Tenor Sax
text: For jazz fans, nothing could be more tantalizing than the excerpts made available by the National Jazz Museum in Harlem of newly discovered recordings from the 1930s and ’40s. Nearly 1,000 discs containing performances by masters like Coleman Hawkins, Lester Young, Billie Holiday and the long-neglected Herschel Evans suddenly re-emerged when the son of the audio engineer, William Savory, sold them to the museum.

text: MIAMI  The streets of Haiti remained calm on Saturday, a day after the country’s election officials ended the singer Wyclef Jean’s brief, electrifying run for president, suggesting that the distraction of politics had once again given way to the country’s struggle for survival.

headline: In New Approach to Titanic, an Exhibitor Aids Scientists
text: In the 23 years since divers first reached the wreckage of the Titanic, commercial efforts to salvage artifacts from the doomed ocean liner have aroused as much scientific dispute as public curiosity.

headline: Ship Postpones Aid Mission Set for Gaza
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Lebanese aid ship destined for Gaza delayed its departure on Saturday after Cyprus refused to allow the ship to sail through its waters or to use its ports, organizers and Lebanese officials said.

headline: The Pulse | Iraqi Refugee Gets His Green Card at Last

headline: Local Intelligence | Building 1
text: Behold Building 1, whose design is as artificial as the island underneath it. It is the twin of a former European airport terminal, recreated here to serve as the administrative center for the 1939 Golden Gate International Exposition. On Tuesday, San Francisco officials signed a transfer deal to finally pass ownership of Treasure Island from the Navy to the city.

headline: Joyless Seasons for White Sox and Cubs
text: Is it over yet? I mean this baseball season, one of the most dispiriting, unsatisfying campaigns Chicago has endured. I’m a baseball guy, but I’m ready to call it a year. When do the Blackhawks start?

headline: Blagojevich Fatigue? Get Used to It

headline: The Perks Keep On Flowing for Water District Employees
text: Working for the public agency that handles Cook County’s storm water and wastewater often involves unglamorous trips into the cavernous Deep Tunnel or to the malodorous sewage treatment plant in south-suburban Stickney. But duty has also called district employees on trips to Thailand, Denmark, the Greek islands and some of Chicago’s nicest steakhouses  all at the taxpayers’ expense.

text: Renewed economic uncertainty is testing Americans’ generation-long love affair with the stock market.

headline: Absence of Power Disrupts Mariners
text: Two of the first 10 pitches from Javier Vazquez touched down in the Yankee Stadium seats on Saturday. The first was a fly ball by Ichiro Suzuki that just cleared the right-field wall. The second, by Russell Branyan, was the first home run ever to reach the fourth deck, above the right-field suites. Two innings later, Suzuki went deep again.

headline: Westbrook Makes His Case
text: MADRID — After practice Friday, Team USA guard Russell Westbrook and said all the right things. He said he was not worried about being the final cut on Team USA, that he had not spoken with Coach Mike Krzyzewski about it and that he was going to continue to play hard.

headline: U.S. Effort Gives Spain a Reason to Be Optimistic
text: MADRID  Basketball in this sports-mad country will be forever viewed through the prism of the 1992 Olympics. The Spanish view the United States Dream Team’s romp through Barcelona as a turning point in their country’s interest in basketball, as the presence of Michael Jordan, Magic Johnson and Larry Bird ignited a new passion for the game.

text: A 20-year-old man was arrested and charged on Sunday in the fatal stabbing of a Yonkers man outside a Midtown Manhattan bar, the police said.

headline: Parsing the Record of Feisal Abdul Rauf
text: The Internet is crowded with claims and counterclaims about Feisal Abdul Rauf, the imam behind the proposed Muslim community center and mosque two blocks from ground zero. The following is a sampling of some of the most often quoted complaints, combined with writings and statements from Mr. Abdul Rauf and his Cordoba Initiative, which has posted a frequently asked questions page on its Web site about the proposed project and the planners’ views.

headline: India Tries Using Cash Bonuses to Slow Birthrates

headline: When Republicans and Jihadis Agree…
text: My Sunday column is about “ground zero mosque” that of course isn’t precisely a mosque and isn’t at ground zero. I argue that the proposed Islamic Center in lower Manhattan can be force for moderation — but, more important, that opposition to it from some Republicans feeds into the jihadi narrative that America is at war with Islam.

headline: Vows: Matt & Alana
text: Like so many entertainers, Alana Niehoff and Matthew DeCapua met while working at a restaurant to support their careers. One night their shifts coincided and a romance blossomed.

headline: In Race for Global Dominance, China Is Gaining on Russia
text: There was little doubt why the Soviet Union was so dominant in chess  the government poured money and other resources into programs that cultivated players. Yet even after the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, Russia remained the world’s leading chess country. Its strength might be a vestige of the Communist-led system, or of the country’s historical affinity for the game.

headline: The Côte Fleurie
text: To the Editor: “Normandy’s Quiet Glamour” (Aug. 8) clearly misses the mark. I just returned from a three-day visit to Normandy with my wife and youngest daughter. The restaurants, film festival stars and horse racing lionized in the article pale in comparison to the Norman- dy D-Day sites, which were not even mentioned. The Normandy beaches and related sites and monuments, including the American Cemetery and Memorial, honor and memorial- ize our soldiers and their important sacrifices. The article would have presented a much more accurate and significant depiction of Nor- mandy if the author had also includ- ed them.

headline: When Hendrix Met Handel at a London Flat
text: If you have ever dreamed of having a snoop around Jimi Hendrix’s apartment, now you can. Forty years after his death, the American rock legend, who performed, recorded and lived in London, will be reincarnated through the “Hendrix in Britain” exhibition at the Handel House Museum, starting Aug. 25. And for two weeks only, the apartment Hendrix lived in, next door to the museum, will also be open to the public for the first time since his death in 1970.

headline: Lessons for President Obama, and No Mulligans
text: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — Gene Mulak, the golf pro at the Vineyard Golf Club on Martha’s Vineyard, does not know how many golf lessons President Obama has taken. But Mulak is certain he was the first to tutor him on his bunker play. And Mulak is certain Obama needed the help.

headline: In Reimagined 2007 N.F.L. Draft, Jets Are Big Winners
text: Gregg Easterbrook wrote his annual draft reimagining  for ESPN last week. He reviewed the 2007 draft and listed where players should have gone, now that we have the benefit of three years of hindsight. The Jets were the big winners. Cornerback Darrelle Revis, who was chosen No. 14 by the Jets in that draft, tops the list. And linebacker David Harris, chosen in the second round, is No. 4.

headline: The Fish Are Really Biting Those Women in Bikinis
text: “Piranha 3D” is a movie that wants to have its cheesecake and eat it too. I mean this more or less literally. The entertainment formula behind this short and nasty movie — devised according to someone’s idea of what teenage boys with the guile, the facial hair or the “guardian” to gain admission to an R-rated movie are likely to enjoy — is sloppy and simple. Young women dance around in, and frequently shed, their bikinis, and are then devoured by swarms of predatory fish.

headline: Barajas Claimed By Dodgers, So Thole’s Time Is Now
text: PITTSBURGH — The Mets’ commitment to younger players continued Sunday when the Los Angeles Dodgers claimed catcher Rod Barajas off waivers and the Mets declined to pull him back. That leaves Josh Thole, who has been considered the Mets’ catcher of the future for the past year or so, as the catcher of the present, too. Allowing Barajas to go signals the Mets believe Thole is ready to catch every day.

headline: Proposed Muslim Center Draws Opposing Protests
text: Around noon on Sunday, Michael Rose, a medical student from Brooklyn, approached some of the hundreds of protesters who had gathered near ground zero to rally against a mosque and Islamic center planned for the neighborhood.

headline: Wyclef Jean Says He’ll Challenge Election Ruling

headline: Florida Candidate Veers From Tea Party’s Script
text: PENSACOLA, Fla.  When the year began, the stars could not have shone brighter for Marco Rubio, the fresh voice of newly invigorated conservatives who embodied the change that frustrated grass-roots Republicans demanded from inside their own party.

headline: Searching for Planet X, and Other Untamable Yearnings
text: “Watch out for oddballs,” one character warns another at the beginning of “Percival’s Planet,” Michael Byers’s warmly intelligent second novel, about the discovery of Pluto. But nearly everyone in this book is mad in some way, from the merely obsessive to the completely delusional. And as we watch these oddballs orbit their obsessions, it becomes increasingly clear that the distinction between passion and mania can be all but invisible.

headline: A Rarely Heard Mozart Cantata Completes a Wide-Ranging Festival
text: Since becoming the music director of the Mostly Mozart Festival in 2002, the conductor Louis Langrée has worked closely with Jane Moss, the festival’s artistic director, to expand its repertory horizons. This season we have heard everything from ancient Georgian polyphony to an avant-garde work by Helmut Lachenmann.

headline: Floods Force Thousands From Homes in Pakistan
text: SUKKUR, Pakistan  Floodwaters surged deeper into areas of southern Pakistan on Sunday, forcing thousands more people to abandon their homes in haste and flee to higher ground. Attention has now focused on the province of Sindh as the floods that have torn through the length of the country for three weeks finally move toward the Arabian Sea.

headline: Cheering on Your Favorite Team With Your Lawn
text: To show allegiance to their favorite teams, fans have long painted their cheeks, sometimes even their bare chests. Soon they can paint their lawn.

headline: Rallies in Downtown Manhattan

headline: Long Goodbye for Barajas and Long Afternoon for the Mets’ Hitters
text: PITTSBURGH  Despite having become a member of the Los Angeles Dodgers, Rod Barajas sat in the Mets’ clubhouse wearing Mets shorts and a Mets undershirt watching a game he was not allowed to take part in Sunday. With his friends and former teammates trailing by a run in the ninth inning, he found himself cheering hard for Chris Carter when he drove a ball down the right-field line, just foul.

headline: The Taylor Rule And The “Bond Bubble” (Wonkish)
text: Here’s a thought for all those insisting that there’s a bond bubble: how unreasonable are current long-term interest rates given current macroeconomic forecasts? I mean, at this point almost everyone expects unemployment to stay high for years to come, and there’s every reason to expect low or even negative inflation for a long time too. Shouldn’t that imply that the Fed will keep short-term rates near zero for a long time? And shouldn’t that, in turn, mean that a low long-term rate is justified too?

headline: The Open Road Wasn’t Quite Open to All
text: For almost three decades beginning in 1936, many African-American travelers relied on a booklet to help them decide where they could comfortably eat, sleep, buy gas, find a tailor or beauty parlor, shop on a honeymoon to Niagara Falls, or go out at night. In 1949, when the guide was 80 pages, there were five recommended hotels in Atlanta. In Cheyenne, Wyo., the Barbeque Inn was the place to stay.

headline: How to Get From Alabama to Harlem? Ride the Internet
text: The story of how the debut New York performance of the Huntsville, Ala., rap duo G-Side ended up in the basement rec room of a storefront movie house in Harlem can be traced back, in part, to some money changing hands at an Italian restaurant in the East Village several years ago.

headline: New CDs
text: RAY LAMONTAGNE

headline: Seductress Sylph and Her Romantic Rival, the Flirt
text: How many ballets by George Balanchine have you seen? My own tally — counting both items as short as the “Tschaikovsky pas de deux” and as long as the three-part “Jewels” as one each — is over 60. And though I began watching them in his lifetime, I have also seen all but one of them since his death. Surely no choreographer now dead has left so large a store of work in repertory.

headline: Giants Expect Manning to Practice This Week
text: After being sidelined from live action with a cut on his forehead, Giants quarterback Eli Manning will return to practice this week — and he will be wearing a helmet.

headline: The Third Replicator
text: All around us information seems to be multiplying at an ever increasing pace. New books are published, new designs for toasters and i-gadgets appear, new music is composed or synthesized and, perhaps above all, new content is uploaded into cyberspace. This is rather strange. We know that matter and energy cannot increase but apparently information can.

headline: Western Schools Sprout in South Korea
text: SEOGWIPO, South Korea  Here on Jeju Island, famous for its tangerine groves, pearly beaches and honeymoon resorts, South Korea is conducting a bold educational experiment, one intended to bolster opportunity at home and attract investment from abroad.

headline: Spike Lee’s New Orleans, Take 2
text: Released just a year after Hurricane Katrina swamped New Orleans, “When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts” was a thrilling achievement: both intimate and magisterial, angry and eloquent, an indictment and a testament, it represented a high point in the career of its director, Spike Lee.

headline: Float Like a Butterfly, Lecture Like a Penitent Professor
text: The headline on Randy Cohen’s column, “The Ethicist,” in The New York Times Magazine on Aug. 15 reads, “Degree of Disclosure.” So in approaching his “Punishing Blow,” at the Clurman Theater, let’s begin with a disclosure.

headline: Yankees Recall Nova, and Give Him a Start
text: Eduardo Nunez, a utility infielder who joined the Yankees last week and helped them to a win on Saturday, has a likely roommate for the six-game trip which begins Monday night in Toronto.

headline: Like a Line, in Brief
text: MONDAY PUZZLE NOTES — Oliver Hill has taken a collection of street signs and planted them at the beginning of four theme entries.

headline: Who Was First Sponsor to Win World Team Title?
text: Professionals in sports and games usually make money from three possible sources: pay, prize money and sponsorship.

headline: Sabathia and Cano Lead Yankees Through Void and to a High Point
text: As the winning pitcher in a 10-0 victory over Seattle on Sunday afternoon at soggy Yankee Stadium, C. C. Sabathia improved his record to 17-5 and enhanced his candidacy for the American League’s Cy Young Award.

headline: The Ghosts of Unquiet Souls Doomed in a Wartime Ghetto
text: “The Dybbuk,” the 1914 play written by S. Ansky that is a pre-eminent work of Yiddish theater, dramatizes the Ashkenazi Jewish myth of a dislocated soul that inhabits a living person. Ansky’s play itself has something of a shape-shifting spirit, revised many times for the stage, film, dance and even opera. In revisiting the story, the English playwright and director Julia Pascal, who has often mined Jewish themes for their universality, has framed it in the context of the Holocaust, powerfully elevating a folk tale to an existential meditation.

headline: Canceled Brooklyn Concert Reinstated
text: The final Pool Party is back on.

headline: Footnote
text: A critically praised production of Shakespeare’s “Merry Wives of Windsor” is on its way to New York. Directed by Christopher Luscombe and featuring Christopher Benjamin as Falstaff, the show was a hit when it was staged two years ago at Shakespeare’s Globe in London. It reopened there Thursday night, will travel to Los Angeles from Oct. 14 to 24 and then will arrive at Pace University’s Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, where it will run from Oct. 28 through Nov. 7.

headline: ‘The Pacific’ and Betty White Among Emmy Winners
text: The sweeping World War II mini-series “The Pacific” was the most-honored program at the Creative Arts Emmys on Saturday, winning a total of seven statues for sound editing, makeup, visual effects and casting, among other categories. The Creative Arts awards, primarily technical in nature, were a precursor to the Emmys telecast on NBC next Sunday. “The Pacific” (with, from left, Tom Budge, James Badge Dale and Joshua Helman) helped bring HBO to a total of 17 awards, topping second-place ABC, which received 15. Notably, Betty White was named best guest actress in a comedy for her appearance on “Saturday Night Live.” The Tony Awards telecast in June 2009, hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, was the winner in the special class category. While most Emmy winners are associated with networks, one independent production, the fan film StarWarsUncut.com, was recognized this year in a relatively new category, outstanding creative achievement in interactive media. The Creative Arts ceremony will be shown Friday on the E! channel.

headline: Gift to the Harn Museum
text: During Dr. David A. Cofrin’s life he offered critical financial support to the Samuel P. Harn Museum of Art at the University of Florida in Gainesville. His death last year at age 88 did not end his contributions, however. The Harn museum has announced that Dr. Cofrin bequeathed 312 works of Asian art estimated to be worth $4.2 million and established a million-dollar endowment for the acquisition of Asian art. Dr. Cofrin and his wife, Mary Ann, helped establish the museum; it is named after Mary Ann’s father, Samuel Peebles Harn, an alumnus of the university. Since 1983, the Cofrins have donated more than $30 million to the Harn, according to the museum. The latest gift includes jades, ceramics, cloisonné and bronze, glass, ivory and lacquers from Japan, China and Southeast Asia. These will eventually be housed in a new 26,000-square-foot extension named the David A. Cofrin Asian Art Wing.

headline: Author Credit for Widow of Baseball Historian
text: In baseball terms you might describe it as a walk-off hit deep into extra innings. Dorothy Jane Mills, below, the widow of the revered baseball historian Harold Seymour, has been belatedly recognized by Oxford University Press as co-author, along with Mr. Seymour, of three landmark scholarly works on the history of baseball, Publishers Weekly reported. Tim Bent, Oxford’s executive editor, said that Ms. Mills, 81, formerly Dorothy Z. Seymour, would be given formal credit and that her name would now accompany her late husband’s on the covers and title pages of “Baseball: The Early Years” (1960); “Baseball: The Golden Age,” (1971); and “Baseball: The People’s Game” (1991). Mr. Bent said that to his knowledge, Oxford had never before changed the authorship of a major scholarly work. In an interview with The New York Times in March, when she was recognized for the first time along with Mr. Seymour by the Society for American Baseball Research, Ms. Mills said that she had served as the primary researcher and essentially a co-author of all three books but that her husband had steadfastly refused her request that her work be credited. “All these things were done jointly,” she said. “He just couldn’t share credit. And I didn’t say anything at the time, because at the time, wives just didn’t do that.” He died in 1992, and in her 2004 autobiography, “A Woman’s Work,” she described her extensive role in the creation of the books. Ms. Mills, who is now at work on a historical novel about baseball, said that even after all these years, she still does not consider herself a fan: “You write a lot more objectively about a subject you’re not in love with.”

headline: ‘The Expendables’ Tops Box Office Again
text: Aging action heroes ruled the North American box office for the second weekend in a row. “The Expendables” (Lions Gate), with Sylvester Stallone leading an ensemble cast, was No. 1 with about $16.5 million, bringing the cumulative total to about $65 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data. “Vampires Suck” (20th Century Fox), a low-budget spoof of the “Twilight” movies, was second with about $12.2 million for a five-day total of $18.6 million. “Vampires Suck,” which opened on Wednesday, appeared to narrowly beat Julia Roberts as her “Eat Pray Love” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) took third place with $12 million, earning a total of $47.1 million in North America since it opened on Aug. 13, a soft result that has renewed worries that Ms. Roberts has faded as a box-office draw. The comedy “Lottery Ticket,” from Alcon Entertainment and Warner Brothers, opened in fourth place with about $11.1 million. Fifth place appeared to be a tie, with each earning about $10.1 million: “The Other Guys” (Sony), with a new total of $88.2 million, and “Piranha 3-D,” a new horror romp from the Weinstein Company. Two other new movies fared poorly despite wide releases: “Nanny McPhee Returns” (Universal Pictures), already a hit overseas, earned $8.3 million. “The Switch” (Walt Disney Studios), a comedy starring Jennifer Aniston and Jason Bateman, sold $8.1 million.

headline: Van Gogh Painting Remains Missing
text: A van Gogh painting valued by some experts at $50 million was stolen from a Cairo museum on Saturday, Egypt’s minister of culture announced. Egyptian law enforcement officials blamed lax security at the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum for the incident, saying that none of its alarms and only a few of its surveillance cameras were working when the painting (above, known as “Poppy Flowers” and “Vase and Flowers”), a depiction of a vase filled with yellow poppies, was sliced from its frame and taken. The culture minister, Farouk Hosni, announced shortly after the disappearance of the painting was made public that it had been recovered at the Cairo airport and that two Italians had been arrested in connection with theft. But Mr. Hosni said later that he had been given bad information and that the search continued. Egypt’s top prosecutor, Abdel Meguid Mahmoud, told the BBC that the museum’s security system was nothing more than a “facade.” He said museum officials had been looking for spare parts to mend the system but “hadn’t managed to find them.”

headline: An End to Prison Gerrymandering
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York took a stand for electoral fairness earlier this month when he signed legislation that bans prison-based gerrymandering  the cynical practice of counting prison inmates as “residents,” to pad the size of legislative districts. The new law, which requires that prison inmates be counted at their homes, deserves to be emulated all across the country.

headline: Say It Loud
text: The class assignment for the eighth graders deep in rural Appalachia was to stand up guilt-free about extolling the dialect spoken in their local mountain “hollers.” Sound forth; never mind the “hillbilly” stigma that can especially haunt teenagers. On a visit a decade ago to Ellenboro, W.Va., I delighted to hear Kyre Bartz tell a “handed down” story from her family that flowed with “crick” and “young uns” and “tomorry at sunrise.” It was a lyrical Appalachian aria. Kyre even noted “that ole woman stumblin’ up that there hill with a poke and a pig walkin’ right beside her.”

text: Fresh from vacation, workers returning to Wall Street may see their healthy glow turn ashen as the threat of further job cuts looms. Although there’s been a rebound in hiring, companies and analysts told The Wall Street Journal that deeper cuts are on the horizon unless business picks up.

text: For its first renminbi-denominated private equity fund, TPG Capital will raise five billion renminbi ($736.3 million) in the next several months, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Reduce Gasoline Wagers
text: Hedge funds cut bullish bets on gasoline by the most in almost four years as petroleum stockpiles surpassed the highest level since 1990 and the American vacation season drew to an end, Bloomberg News reported on Monday.

headline: Mexican Investors and Pilots Buy Aeronautic Group

headline: The Apocalypse as Ego Trip
text: Today’s idea: We’re suckers for stories of our own demise because they make us feel special, an article says.

headline: Madrid’s Late Night of Culture
text: Anyone who has spent time in Madrid knows that Madrileños don’t like to go to bed, preferring to walk the streets with friends and hang out in cafes, restaurants and clubs until the sun comes up. So, it seems only natural that the city should treat its citizens, and visitors, to an all-night celebration of contemporary art and culture. Planned to coincide with the full moon, White Night in Madrid, takes place on Sept. 11.

headline: With Hulu I.P.O., Yahoo Could Buy Big Stake
text: Yahoo may buy a “considerable” stake in Hulu if the video Web site pursues an initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported, citing aStifel Nicolaus analyst.

headline: J.C. Flowers Said to Be Bidding for Ireland’s EBS
text: J.C. Flowers is bidding to take control of EBS, Ireland’s biggest customer-owned lender, a person with knowledge of the talks told Bloomberg News.

headline: A.I.G. Leasing Unit Said to Repay U.S. $4 Billion
text: American International Group‘s aircraft leasing unit International Lease Finance Corporation repaid nearly $4 billion of United States loans after raising new debt from investors, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters on Sunday.

headline: Sterling Raises $730 Million to Avert Foreclosure
text: Sterling Financial on Friday said it has raised $730 million from private equity and institutional investors which will help Sterling Savings Bank, Washington’s second-largest bank, avoid being seized and sold, The Seattle Times reported.

headline: BofA’s U.S. Trust Makes Spate of Hires

text: Deutsche Bank started dark-pool trading in Hong Kong on Monday, the German lender’s first such platform in Asia, to meet growing demand in the region.

headline: Tip of the Week: Start Menu Submenus
text: The default layout of the Windows 7 Start menu is designed to give you quick access to the most-used folders on the PC. If you’d prefer to see the contents of those folders in a submenu instead of having Windows pop open a whole new window, just right-click the Start Menu button and choose Properties. In the box that appears, click on the Start Menu tab and then on the Customize button.

text: SAN FRANCISCO  Data storage used to be one of the more mundane corners of the technology industry. Now it is where an increasing number of tech companies  and Wall Street  want to be.

headline: Spitzer’s Lawsuits: A Contested Legacy
text: Eliot Spitzer, the former governor of New York and before that the state’s attorney general, has taken issue with a recent Op/Ed in The Wall Street Journal over several suits he brought while in office. His legacy is at stake.

headline: Judge Presses 9/11 Lawyers on Fees
text: The federal judge overseeing the settlement between the city and workers who were exposed to environmental health risks at ground zero is asking the plaintiffs’ lawyers to justify in detail as “reasonable and necessary” some of the legal expenses they are charging their clients.

headline: We’re Starting to Think ‘Mad Men’ Isn’t a Documentary
text: Warning: this post may contain spoilers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Over at Interfluidity, Steve Waldman debriefs the world on the recent discussion Treasury had with the luminaries of the financial blogging world. “The headline act was Timothy Geithner. Off the record (or “on deep background”), Geithner is entirely different from the sometimes stiff character who appears on television. He is fun to argue with, very smart, good natured, and intellectually wily. As Yves Smith quipped afterwards, Geithner ‘gives good meeting.’ Despite that, our seminar was an adversarial affair.”

headline: A Different Way of Ranking Colleges
text: That’s Paul Glastris, the editor of Washington Monthly, writing in that magazine’s new guide to colleges. His suggested answer: the terrible disservice that higher education does to millions of low-income students.

headline: Graft Dispute in Afghanistan is Test for U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  As corruption investigations begin to focus on President Hamid Karzai’s inner circle, an Afghan official on Monday pinned blame for endemic corruption in Afghanistan on foreign contractors, which he said had created an “economic mafia” in the war-torn country.

headline: Yea and Nay Rallies Near Proposed Muslim Center
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Potash Producer Says It Is Talking to Buyers Other Than BHP
text: The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, the fertilizer producer, confirmed on Monday that it was seeking bids to counter an unsolicited $38.6 billion offer from BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company.

headline: Gunman and 8 Hostages Dead in the Philippines
text: MANILA A former police officer took a busload of tourists hostage in downtown Manila on Monday morning, opening a 12-hour standoff that was broadcast live on television, including its end as police commandos stormed the bus before a watching crowd.

headline: 5 Guards Killed in Tajikistan Prison Break
text: MOSCOW  More than two dozen prisoners with suspected ties to Islamist militants have escaped from a detention center in Tajikistan, killing five prison guards, officials there said Monday.

headline: Spike Lee Returns to New Orleans for ‘If God Is Willing and da Creek Don’t Rise’
text: Four years ago Spike Lee took his cameras to New Orleans to document the disaster wrought by Hurricane Katrina in 2005, as told by the people still dealing with its calamitous effects. The film Mr. Lee returned with was “When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts,” a four-hour HBO documentary that won a Peabody Award and three Emmys. So as the fifth anniversary of Katrina approached, Mr. Lee went back to New Orleans this year, hoping to tell the story of that city’s recovery and rejuvenation, starting with the Super Bowl victory of its underdog New Orleans Saints football team.

headline: A Different Way of Ranking Colleges
text: Over at the Economix blog, David Leonhardt writes about Washington Monthly’s effort to build better college rankings. The magazine tries to grade colleges based on what they do, rather than whom they enroll. Read more on Economix…

headline: The Early Word: Primary Squeeze
text: Candidates in five states — Alaska, Arizona, Florida, Oklahoma and Vermont — are squeezing in their final pitches before voters head to the polls Tuesday for primaries.

headline: Burkle vs. the Bookstore Magnate
text: Len Riggio bought the original Barnes & Noble in 1971. Since then, he has turned the bookstore chain into a distribution giant dominating the American retail scene and changed the way we buy books.

headline: Numberplay: Shackled Communication
text: 12:41 p.m. | Updated Today, we present a version of a famous problem that is extraordinarily rich in the possibilities it offers for constructing strategies. I have altered some of the details, changed the story somewhat and have also decreased the numbers, so you can more easily try strategies without being intimidated by large numbers. The basic scenario is as follows:

headline: A Short Second Life for a Building With History
text: This is the second of a two-part On the Records series examining the 2007 sale of the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society’s former headquarters at 122 East 58th Street to a celebrity-studded Long Island synagogue. The $24 million deal has not gone as planned for either party. On Sunday, we looked at the transaction from the seller’s side. Today, we look at the experience of the buyer.

headline: Speed Read for Monday, Aug. 23
text: Highlights from media coverage in today’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Rwandan Rebels Raped at Least 179 Women in Congo, Humanitarian Officials Say
text: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo  A mob of Rwandan rebels gang-raped at least 179 women last month during a weekend raid on a community of villages in eastern Congo, the United Nations said Monday.

headline: Monday Reading: Free Scheduled Car Maintenance
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Making It Up
text: According to Bloomberg, Raghuram Rajan is now getting specific: he wants Bernanke to raise the Fed funds rate by 200 basis points in the face of 9.5 percent unemployment and inflation under 1 percent.

headline: Children’s Day at the Four Seasons
text: “This is a pretty good view,” Ethan Royce allowed as he surveyed the thriving lunch crowd from the terrace of the Pool Room at the Four Seasons and toyed with a forkful of the $21 agnolotti stuffed with organic chicken in Parmesan broth. Nothing unusual in that — save for his age, which is 8.

headline: Singer Dies After Jump at Belgian Pop Festival
text: The lead singer of a British pop band was killed on Friday after jumping from a telecommunications tower at a Belgian festival. The incident followed others at rock performances earlier in the week where concertgoers jumped from great heights and were injured or killed.

headline: Stalling Problems Could Affect 1.2 Million Toyotas
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified an investigation into stalling problems on almost 1.2 million Toyotas. The models are the 2005-7 Corolla and Matrix.

headline: More Accident Data: Motorcyclists and the Elderly, Beware
text: New Yorkers may now know more about the dangers of being a pedestrian than residents of any other city, thanks to the ambitious traffic study released last week by the Bloomberg administration.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: An Episode of Shame
text: Season 4, Episode 5

headline: Scant Progress in Effort on Old Racial Killings
text: ATLANTA  In February 2007, Alberto R. Gonzales, the attorney general under President George W. Bush, issued a stern warning to those who murdered blacks with impunity during the civil rights era: “You have not gotten away with anything. We are still on your trail.”

headline: Canon Punches Up Its PowerShot Line
text: Update | Aug. 23, 10:35 p.m.: Corrected information about manual control ring on PowerShot S95Canon has unwrapped three new PowerShots, highlighted by a lightweight Elph model that packs a 10X optical zoom into a very slim package.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: Congress is in recess, and there are no Food and Drug Administration scientific panels meeting this week.

headline: Question of Perspective in Courtroom Paintings
text: WASHINGTON

headline: A Photographer’s Coney Island
text: Just when you thought Coney Island had been considered from every possible documentary angle, our pals at Lens have posted a starkly picturesque portfolio by a photographer named Andy Levin, who in the late ’70s “began exploring Coney Island as a G-rated family destination, not entirely unlike the seaside community on Long Island where he was raised.” As G-rated family destinations go, it’s pretty gripping. Check it out on Lens.

headline: The Bidding War for 3PAR
text: 3Par, a data storage company, is the billion-dollar prize in a battle between two tech heavyweights, Hewlett-Packard and Dell.  Who wants it more? Or perhaps the question really is: Who needs to win this to make a public statement?

headline: Baseball Chases Leak of Financial Documents
text: Major League Baseball is narrowing down the search for who was behind the leaks of team financial reports that reveal how profitable the Pittsburgh Pirates are despite an 18-year string of losing records, and how much they, the Florida Marlins and the Tampa Bay Rays receive in revenue-sharing from wealthier clubs, according to a baseball executive who was not authorized to speak publicly.

headline: Food Photography: How to Plan a Food Shoot
text: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce. There are several things that you have to be very conscious of when planning a food shoot. The first thing I do, almost without fail, is look at a weather report. Like surfers, baseball managers and airline pilots, you will become an amateur meteorologist when you commit to a food photo shoot. I prefer to shoot in daylight whenever possible, and the quality of that light is obviously a major factor.

headline: Study Finds No Link Tying Disaster Losses to Human-Driven Warming
text: The pull of the “front-page thought” and the eagerness of climate campaigners to jog the public have sometimes created a tendency to tie mounting losses from weather-related disasters to human-driven global warming.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Fischerspooner
text: The homecoming leg of Fischerspooner’s recent tour found Casey and the gang at the Highline Ballroom on Aug. 12. It was a performance powerful in its energy and creativity, complete with gaggles of costumed dancers in full geisha makeup, wigs and electric hats. The disarmingly sweet Casey Spooner charmed a room of 150 dancing fans at this semi-private show with tales of another age, when the band performed at MoMA and felt like it still had yet to “emerge.”

headline: Jumble of Air Safety Rules
text: Aviation officials often cite the industry’s low accident rate after a plane crash, and statistics back up their assertions: last year, there were about 2.5 accidents for every one million commercial flights worldwide.

headline: Bocelli to Perform at Metropolitan Opera
text: Over the course of his career Andrea Bocelli has sold millions of records, helped to close out the 2010 World Cup in a grand finale concert, performed “Jingle Bells” with the Muppets and been praised by no less an authority than Celine Dion. But he has never performed on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: What We’re Reading: Ramadan Is Good for Stocks
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: A Stellar Galaxy, This One With a Keyboard
text: Another Samsung Galaxy phone is being released. This one, the Epic from Sprint, sports two significant differences from others in the family.

headline: TPG to Create Chinese Currency Funds
text: SHANGHAI  TPG, one of the world’s biggest private equity firms, said early Tuesday that it was teaming up with the municipal governments of two of China’s biggest cities to raise nearly $1.5 billion and create its first funds denominated entirely in Chinese currency.

headline: Piniella’s Exit
text: On the occasion of his retirement, allow me to share my favorite Lou Piniella moment, from his days as a player for the Yankees: it was a World Series game, with all the usual tension, and Piniella was up to bat. He swung at a pitch so hard, he corkscrewed himself around, and with his legs twisted, he fell over sideways. He was laughing so hard, it took him several minutes to get back in the batter’s box. Everyone on the field was laughing too: opposing players, umpires included. I was not a Yankees fan. I was laughing.

headline: Nepal’s Parliament Fails in 5th Try to Select Prime Minister
text: KATMANDU, Nepal  Nepal’s Parliament on Monday failed for a fifth time to select a new prime minister, in a deepening political stalemate fueled by ego and ideology that is alienating the public and crippling the government and the economy in this Himalayan nation.

headline: Busch Sweeps Three Nascar Races in Bristol
text: When Kyle Busch won the Irwin Tools Night Race on Saturday night at the Bristol Motor Speedway in Tennessee, he became the first driver to complete a Nascar hat trick — winning the Camping World Trucks race, the Nationwide Series support race and the Sprint Cup headliner in the same week. Nascar began running the three races 15 years ago.

headline: Printed Matter | The Book on Pucci
text: More than six decades ago, the Florentine aristocrat Emilio Pucci decided to break from 1,000 years of family tradition and work. What started with some comfortable ski wear for his girlfriend grew into one of the world’s first fashion lifestyle houses. From bathing suits to bath towels, if there was a need, Pucci sought to fill it in print.

headline: Bar Codes and One-Night Stands That Last
text: Is a party still fashionable if there’s no clipboard-wielding gatekeeper to decide whether you should be on the list?

headline: Wells Fargo’s Odd Mortgage Essay Question
text: When Linda Falcão applied for a mortgage from Wells Fargo, she didn’t realize she would be required to write the type of essay that’s more commonly included with a college application.

headline: TimesCast | August 23, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on election primaries in Florida and Arizona, housing as a faltering investment and a Science Times preview of a pioneering neurosurgeon's brain collection.

headline: And Now A Brief Report From That Other Fringe Festival
text: EDINBURGH — At least a couple of the hotter theater tickets among hundreds of current offerings here at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe are headed to New York in the coming season.

headline: Human Eggs for Sale and Other Tales
text: An article about the business of in vitro fertilization in the September issue of Fast Company examines the international marketplace for human eggs — and the disparities in oversight, which have led to variable compensation for donors as well as pricing and waiting times for would-be parents.

headline: Potash Seeks Out White Knights
text: Potash, seeking to thwart a hostile $38.6 billion takeover bid by the mining giant BHP Billiton, says it is looking for possible counterbids.

headline: A Different Take on the Intel-McAfee Deal
text: Pricey, if strategic, and mainly about bringing computer security into the future of Internet-connected smartphones, consumer electronics, cars, even household appliances.

headline: Fringe Festival Journal: ‘Veritas’
text: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival continues through Sunday. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors.

headline: The Claim: Dark Cats Cause More Allergies Than Light Ones
text: THE FACTS Cats, love them or hate them, are among the most common causes of allergies, affecting twice as many Americans as dogs do.

headline: Readers Discuss Wikipedia Editing Course That Aims for ‘Balanced and Zionist’ Entries
text: Since it touched on two subjects of great interest to readers of The Lede, Wikipedia and Israel, it is not surprising that Friday’s post, “Wikipedia Editing for Zionists” — about an initiative to edit entries in the online encyclopedia to make them “balanced and Zionist in nature” — has generated an impassioned debate in one of our comment threads.

headline: Journey to Antarctica in 1959
text: Photographs from Robert A. McCabe's expedition to Antarctica, 50 years after the Scott-Amundsen race to the South Pole.

headline: Client to Broker: Clean My Windows!
text: Even in the strongest economies, New Yorkers of sound mind find that talking with a real estate broker can result in rolled eyes, raised voices and a New York version of “taking it outside” by threatening litigation. But now, as the sales market whimpers along in the languid last days of summer, some brokers say they have never been met by so many demands from their clients, or so much hostility.

headline: Chileans Will Work to Sustain Miners
text: It was a remarkable tale of survival from the depths of a collapsed Chilean mine: After more than two weeks of failed rescue efforts, a video camera threaded deep underground captured the first images of 33 miners, all alive and apparently in good health.

headline: Childhood: Hearing Loss Grows Among Teenagers
text: One in five teenagers suffer from at least slight hearing loss, a significant rise from a decade ago, when the rate was only one in seven.

headline: Egyptian Art Minister Arrested as Search for Stolen van Gogh Continues
text: Prosecutors have arrested a top official in Egypt’s culture ministry and some museum security guards pending an investigation into the theft of a van Gogh painting over the weekend, Reuters reported. The painting, a depiction of a vase filled with yellow poppies, known as “Poppy Flowers” or “Vase and Flowers” and valued at more thanr $50 million, remains missing after it was stolen Saturday from the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum in Giza, where none of the alarms and only some of the security cameras were working at the time. Egypt’s minister of culture, Farouk Hosni, retracted an announcement that the painting was recovered at the Cairo airport, saying the announcement was based on faulty information.

headline: 50 Years Ago: Photographs of an Antarctic Odyssey
text: In 1959, when Robert A. McCabe ventured to Antarctica as a freelance photojournalist, there were no rules against handling penguins and seals. So when an emperor penguin wandered onto McMurdo Base, Mr. McCabe and his cohorts put the almost three-foot-tall bird on a bar for snapshots. At Cape Royds, he photographed a man holding a diminutive Adélie penguin under its wings as if it were a toddler. Another photograph shows a man about to pet a seal pup.

headline: Some Service Restored on Long Island Rail Road After Crippling Fire
text: Click here for the latest rail roundup, including Tuesday morning’s Amtrak and NJ Transit delays.

headline: Michelle Obama, Laura Bush to Honor 9/11 Victims
text: First Lady Michelle Obama and her immediate predecessor, Laura Bush, are expected to speak at a ceremony next month honoring victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the National Park Foundation announced Monday.

headline: Backstory | The New Collectibles
text: Sandra Ballentine cherry-picks the season’s keepers. See more from our latest issue, T Women’s Fashion Fall 2010.

headline: A House of Worship Near Ground Zero
text: A building damaged on 9/11 and then abandoned has become a prayer space, envisioned as a future Islamic cultural, educational and recreational center.

headline: New Orleans Levees Nearly Ready, but Mistrusted
text: LAKE BORGNE, La.  The great wall of Lake Borgne is a monster. Nearly two miles long and 26 feet high, it spans a corner of the lake, 12 miles east of New Orleans. On Aug. 29, 2005, that corner funneled Hurricane Katrina’s surge into New Orleans, causing some of the city’s most violent flooding. Now the corner is being blocked.

headline: TimesCast: Primaries in Arizona and Florida
text: In the latest edition of TimesCast, The Times’s Jeff Zeleny looks at the upcoming primaries in these battleground states.

headline: Rethinking How to Cool the Indian Point Nuclear Plant
text: The Indian Point nuclear plant is quite literally in hot water:  As I reported today, the plant’s current cooling system requires huge volumes of Hudson River water, and New York State instead favors the use of cooling towers to lower the impact on fish and other river organisms.

headline: Trying to Get a Sweetener Back in the Pink
text: “Think pink,” advises the fashion magazine editor played by Kay Thompson in the 1957 movie “Funny Face.” Now, a leading brand of sweetener, identified by that color perhaps as much as by its name, is asking consumers to do the same thing.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Matthew Bottkol and Todd Eisner joined Dentsu America, New York, part of Dentsu, as a creative team. Mr. Bottkol becomes associate creative director and copywriter; he has worked at agencies like Cossette New York and DraftFCB. Mr. Eisner becomes associate creative director and art director; he has worked at agencies like DraftFCB and Mad Dogs and Englishmen.

headline: New Law Takes Aim at Wealthy Tax Cheats
text: The tax man cometh — and now he has backup.

headline: Building a Ring Around New Orleans
text: Map of levees being built or restored around New Orleans.

headline: Talks ‘Doable,’ Says Palestinian Official
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The chief Palestinian negotiator said Monday that he believed reaching an agreement with Israel within a year was “doable,” echoing remarks by the Israeli prime minister a day earlier that a peace agreement would be difficult but “possible.”

headline: Smilorexia & the Veneer Nazis
text: An obsession with obtaining the “perfect smile” – and the cosmetic dentists who exploit it.

headline: How Seniors Live Now: Six Portraits
text: Six video portraits of aging Americans.

headline: Is Team USA Traveling On the Way to World Championships?
text: MADRID – Team USA coaches spent a lot of time during the team’s 86-85 victory over Spain on Sunday night disagreeing with the officials. And the source of much of the coaching staff’s angst portends something to watch for at the world championships, which begin Saturday in Turkey, when the United States opens against Croatia in Istanbul.

headline: Hearing Loss in Teens
text: One in five teenagers suffer from at least slight hearing loss, a marked increase from a decade ago, according to a study reported in today’s Vital Signs column.

headline: Video of Manila Hostage Drama
text: As my colleague Carlos Conde reports from the Philippines, “Eight hostages were killed and one was critically wounded when an armed police officer who was fired last year took a tourist bus hostage in downtown Manila on Monday.”

headline: Added Safety in the Saddle
text: Spectators gasped and expected the worst when the horse ridden by Karim Florent Laghouag somersaulted over a fence and fell on top of him at a prestigious equestrian competition last September in France.

headline: New 2012 Mercedes-Benz CLS Breaks Cover
text: Mercedes-Benz provided an advance look at the new CLS in January at the Detroit auto show, where Gorden Wagener, head of design for Mercedes, displayed a raw metal model of the car, polished and gleaming like a prop from a “Terminator” film.

headline: The Dirty Work of Being a Broker
text: In another reminder how far the real estate market has fallen from its frothy peak, this week’s Appraisal column explores how buyers, sellers and renters are taking their anger out on real estate brokers. Sellers are demanding that brokers clean their apartments and change their sheets before open houses. Buyers are demanding that brokers tell coop boards how long their interviews will last. Renters are just engaging in full-fledged arguments with brokers.

headline: Hurricane Protection in Louisiana
text: Nearly five years after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, the $15 billion upgrade to the city’s hurricane defenses is taking shape.

headline: Red Bulls Rookies Quietly Making a Difference
text: For all the commotion kindled by the Red Bulls’ acquisition of the international stars Thierry Henry and Rafael Marquez, what often has been overlooked is the near-flawless play of two rookies plucked from the American college system.

headline: How the Battle for 3Par Could Escalate
text: The bidding for 3Par has at first glance become very expensive, very quickly. But this battle has a way to go. Hewlett-﻿﻿﻿Packard and Dell may not be alone in the the fray for the last high-end data storage provider on the market.

headline: Hagel to Endorse Sestak
text: Chuck Hagel, a former Republican senator from Nebraska, is weighing in on the Senate race in Pennsylvania – on the Democratic side of the ticket.

headline: Diet: Chocolate in Moderation May Help Heart
text: Note to chocoholics: When it comes to chocolate’s health benefits, less may be more.

headline: Case Study | Cloudy, With a Chance of Ginger
text: The dark ’n’ stormy has become a cult highball due to a felicitous combination of its no-fault simplicity and the balance of its exotic, headstrong ingredients, each of which is perfectly suited to the common goal: reviving the flagging, heat-pummeled constitution. It is simply dark rum — very dark rum — with ginger beer and some fresh lime. The rich spirit is shaken awake by the buoyant piquancy of the ginger beer, while the lime slashes through the sweetness of both.

headline: How Americans Pay for College
text: My colleague Trip Gabriel has an article on Monday about parents who linger around after they drop their children off at college. This chart below might explain why parents are so involved:

headline: Former Executive at Gucci to Lead Barneys
text: The chic retailer Barneys New York, which has been through a turbulent period since it was bought three years ago, announced on Monday that Mark Lee, the former head of the Gucci brand, would become its chief executive on Sept. 1.

headline: Teaching With Infographics | Places to Start
text: Update: Feb. 29, 2012 Please note: The original video we used for this post was a video podcast by Gestalten TV in which New York Times Graphics Director Steven Duenes and Graphics Editor Archie Tse describe how their team works with breaking news to create clear, concise visualizations of data for readers. Since that has now been taken down, we have substituted a classic TED talk by David McCandless that we refer to in the post.

headline: Peter Greenaway’s ‘Last Supper’ Coming to the Armory
text: Since 2006, the filmmaker Peter Greenaway has done a series of installations using cutting-edge technology to illuminate and reinterpret famous paintings. So far none of these works has been displayed in the United States. But from December 2 to January 6, Mr. Greenaway will bring his exploration of Leonardo’s “Last Supper” to the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: Airgas Shoots Back at Air Products Over Bid
text: With its annual shareholders meeting a little over three weeks away, Airgas struck back at Air Products and Chemicals on Monday, asserting once more in a letter to shareholders that its rival is trying to buy the company at “the lowest possible price.”

headline: Allergies and the Color of Your Cat
text: In today’s “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor looks at the science of cat allergies, including whether the color of a cat’s coat makes the pet more or less allergenic.

headline: Rising Stars Win NH Chess Tournament
text: The younger players built a formidable lead and then held on to win the match.

headline: Republican Candidates Not in Accord on Mosque
text: When it comes to the planned Muslim center and mosque near ground zero, one would be forgiven for assuming that the Republican candidates for governor of New York would be on the same page as the Republican candidate for attorney general.

headline: Study Links Chronic Fatigue to Virus Class
