text: When the journal Science published an attention-grabbing study last fall linking chronic fatigue syndrome to a recently discovered retrovirus, many experts remained skeptical — especially after four other studies found no such association.

headline: When Battlefield Humor Backfires
text: “I saw the Whale in clinic this week. Her incision looks great!”

headline: Doctors Who Mock Their Patients
text: Does your doctor call you names once you leave the exam room? In today’s Cases column, Dr. Michael W. Kahn writes about doctors who speak about their patients in unflattering terms, and the risk that poses to patient care. He writes:

headline: A Religious Base
text: Religion and spirituality are important aspects of life for some of the soldiers at Forward Operating Base Kunduz.

headline: A Different Take on the Intel-McAfee Deal
text: From Steve Lohr at Bits:

headline: The Building of a Symbol: How It Got There, and Why It’s Orange
text: It’s the western bookend to the Brooklyn Bridge  as iconic an American edifice as the Statue of Liberty, and a favorite spot for lovers, photographers and suicides. It’s been hailed as one of the modern wonders of the world, “perhaps the most successful combination of site and structure since the Parthenon,” a “democratic masterpiece” and a “giant harp hung in the western sky.”

headline: Big Shot | Schnabel’s Polaroids
text: Consider the Polaroid picture. When taken by a great artist, does it somehow become more than just a dull and grainy impression? Last year, this question prompted a shouting match on The Moment, with readers arguing about the artistic merit of a series of Andy Warhol Polaroids shown at Danziger Projects. Now the artist and filmmaker Julian Schnabel shows us his own Polaroids in a new book by Prestel creatively titled “Julian Schnabel: Polaroids.” In addition to shots of his Montauk, N.Y., studio, his family and a series of rephotographed late-19th-century images called “Crazy People,” Schnabel pointed his rare 1970s-era Polaroid camera at Lou Reed, Placido Domingo, Christopher Walken, the Beastie Boys and Mickey Rourke. The book comes out Sept. 1 and is already on sale via Amazon.com.

headline: A Profound Lesson in Freedom, Learned in Extraordinary Places
text: I AM the last business traveler who actually loves flying and airports. I always try and take a slightly different route when I go places, and I even plan all my trips in great detail.

headline: Promotions on the Base
text: On the base in Kunduz, there are two kinds of military ceremonies: official and unofficial.

headline: What to Tell the Patients After a Trial Goes Awry
text: Dr. Joel Ross, the founder and chief executive of the Memory Enhancement Centers of New Jersey, makes his living enrolling subjects in drug company clinical trials that are testing drugs for Alzheimer’s disease, among others.

headline: Frank Talk About Care at Life’s End
text: Legislators have begun to recognize the medical, humanitarian and economic value of helping terminally ill patients and their families navigate treatment options as they approach the end of life.

headline: Hacker’s Arrest Offers Peek Into Crime in Russia
text: MOSCOW — On the Internet, he was known as BadB, a disembodied criminal flitting from one server to another selling stolen credit card numbers despite being pursued by the United States Secret Service.

headline: Parkinson’s Disease, 1858
text: Parkinson’s disease is second only to Alzheimer’s as the most common neurological illness in the United States, and its symptoms  rigidity, imbalance and uncontrollable shaking  are all too familiar. By the time James Parkinson formally described it in 1817, the illness had been known for centuries.

headline: Tomatoes Pack a Nutritional Punch
text: Tomatoes receive a lot of attention from nutritionists largely because of a phytonutrient called lycopene. Studies have long suggested that lycopene, which is contained in the red pigment, has antioxidant properties. Now growers are raising and marketing “high-lycopene” tomatoes. Indeed, a company based in Israel has developed a dried cherry tomato, which it is calling a “raisin tomato,” that contains almost 100 times the amount of lycopene in a regular cherry tomato.

headline: TV Star Puts Arcimoto Electric Vehicle in the Spotlight
text: EUGENE, Ore. — On Aug. 12 at 8:20 p.m., Nathan Fillion, star of ABC’s “Castle,” sent the following Twitter message: “I found it! I found my spaceship! It’s real and I’m getting it! http://arcimoto.com/”.

headline: Risks: Full-Calorie Beer Has a Link to Psoriasis
text: A new study has found a surprising link between beer drinking in women and psoriasis, the autoimmune disease characterized by itchy, scaly skin.

headline: Inside Neurosurgery’s Rise
text: NEW HAVEN — Two floors below the main level of Yale’s medical school library is a room full of brains. No, not the students. These brains, more than 500 of them, are in glass jars. They are part of an extraordinary collection that might never have come to light if not for a curious medical student and an encouraging and persistent doctor.

headline: Replacing a Pile of Textbooks With an iPad
text: When I’m not blogging away about technology for the Bits Blog, I’m also an adjunct professor at New York University in the Interactive Telecommunications Program.

headline: Big Banks Still Threaten Small Ones, Fed Official Says
text: Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, warned Monday that recently enacted financial regulations might not end market perceptions that taxpayers would rescue the largest banks, and he cautioned against speculative investments in housing, Reuters reports.

headline: Technology: Light and Cheap, Student’s Microscope Holds Promise for Tuberculosis Tests
text: A Rice University student has designed a microscope that costs only $240 to make, uses flashlight batteries and can fit in a lunchbox  but does nearly as well at detecting tuberculosis as top-quality laboratory instruments costing far more.

headline: 85 Million Years Added to Oldest Animal Fossils
text: Until now, the oldest known fossils of animals were of a snail called Kimberella that lived 555 million years ago in Australia and Russia.

headline: Back-to-Back Births May Leave Second Lamb at Higher Risk of Neglect
text: An adult bighorn sheep can weigh well over 200 pounds. Just the horns of a large ram can weigh 30 pounds. So lambs need a great deal of nourishment to grow, and nursing can be draining on a mother, often leaving her weak.

headline: In Fossilized Leaf, Clues on Zombie Ant
text: The fossilized leaf may not look like much, especially with a chunk missing. But to scientists who examined it closely, it told the story of a 48-million-year-old ant infected by a parasite, and then driven to its own death in zombielike fashion.

headline: Earth’s Plant Growth Fell Because of Climate Change, Study Finds
text: Drought linked to climate change has reversed a decades-long trend of increased global plant growth, according to a new analysis of NASA satellite data.

headline: Woods Divorce Becomes Final
text: Tiger Woods and Elin Nordegren were officially divorced Monday, with a judgment entered in Bay County Circuit Court in Florida to dissolve the marriage. Woods confirmed the divorce with a statement on his Web site, nine months after a car crash on Thanksgiving night set off the infidelity scandal that has rocked Woods’s career.

headline: Overestimating the Safety of Bonds
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital.

headline: Backstory | Retrofitted
text: In the new film “Gainsbourg,” and in Retrofitted, styled by Anne Christensen and photographed by Willy Vanderperre, Laetitia Casta pays homage to the French sexpot Brigitte Bardot — curves and all.

headline: The High Price of the N.F.L.’s Preseason Games
text: The N.F.L. perpetrates two annual frauds: one against the American public, the other against players who give body and blood to make the league a multibillion-dollar enterprise.

headline: Goodness, Snakes!
text: Q. I found a snake in Riverdale, the Bronx, pale brown with a couple of dark stripes on the back. What is it? What is it doing there?

headline: Last-Minute Change in Forum Rankles Rangel Rivals
text: Are organizers of tonight’s closely watched candidate forum trying to keep the troubled incumbent Representative Charles B. Rangel from taking any heat from his Democratic challengers?

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 23
text: A view of the day in sports, with diving in Singapore and badminton in Paris.

headline: Weighing Threats and Rules of Engagement in Afghanistan
text: DARAH-I-PECH, Afghanistan — Last month, at the outpost guarding the mouth of the infamous Korangal Valley, Lt. Col. Joe Ryan gathered a company’s-worth of noncommissioned officers in their mess hall and asked them what was on their minds. The room was sweltering hot, and gunshots snapped occasionally outside.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Kevin Frayer of The Associated Press keeps finding visually compelling ways to convey a story whose dimensions are difficult for outsiders to fathom. Here, he has rendered a scene of refuge almost sepulchral, conveying the heaviness that weighs on those who have survived.

headline: Obama Gets Franzen Novel Early, and Publishing Panic Ensues
text: Little did President Obama know that by accepting an early copy of “Freedom,” the new Jonathan Franzen novel, he would set off a small panic in the publishing world.

headline: Peeling Away Theories on Gender and the Brain
text: “Delusions of Gender” takes on that tricky question, Why exactly are men from Mars and women from Venus?, and eviscerates both the neuroscientists who claim to have found the answers and the popularizers who take their findings and run with them.

headline: Truth and Conspiracy in the Catskills
text: A small gathering of 50 or 60 people; roughly 95 percent white, 90 percent male, a few blond-haired kids, average age 45, all nodding in assent as a series of speakers explains that our government is conspiring against us and fabricating massive lies in order to hide its own crimes and frighten us into giving up our constitutional rights and liberties.

headline: Henry Hudson Parkway, 9:43 A.M.
text: Rain on a car windshield distorted the view of a tree and the Hudson River on the West Side Highway near 95th Street on Monday morning.

headline: A Man of Many Roles Reads the Market Right
text: THE actor Liam Neeson has played Oskar Schindler and Rob Roy; he has portrayed a scientist, a monk and — many times over — a romantic. This summer, he played a role that required less of the dashing hero: apartment seller.

headline: A Big Star Transforms Into a Small Moon for a Season
text: “30 for 30,” ESPN’s yearlong series of original documentaries, keeps paying dividends. On Tuesday night it brings us the first nonfiction film by the king of the modern sports drama, Ron Shelton (“Bull Durham,” “White Men Can’t Jump,”“Tin Cup”).

headline: Acuvue Contact Lenses Are Recalled in Asia and Europe
text: The eye care unit of Johnson & Johnson said on Monday that it was recalling several million disposable soft contact lenses sold primarily in Japan, but also in five other countries in Asia and 19 counties in Europe.

headline: Eli Broad Selects Diller Scofidio + Renfro to Design New Museum
text: The philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad has selected the architecture firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro to design a museum for his contemporary art collection on Grand Avenue in downtown Los Angeles, Mr. Broad and his wife Edythe announced on Monday. The museum also received its last round of public approvals on Monday when the Grand Avenue Authority, a panel of city and county officials, approved a plan to lease 2.5 acres of county-owned land to Mr. Broad.

headline: Studying Acupuncture, One Needle Prick at a Time
text: For at least 2,000 years Chinese healers have used acupuncture to treat pain and other ailments. Now Western doctors want proof that it works.

headline: Vain Glorious | Liz Earle’s Cult Cleanser
text: Who: Liz Earle Naturally Active Skincare, a 15-year-old botanicals-based brand located on the Isle of Wight, England’s aptly nicknamed “Garden Isle.”

headline: Scholars Test Web Alternative to Peer Review
text: For professors, publishing in elite journals is an unavoidable part of university life. The grueling process of subjecting work to the up-or-down judgment of credentialed scholarly peers has been a cornerstone of academic culture since at least the mid-20th century.

headline: Dr. Harvey Cushing’s Patients
text: Dr. Harvey Cushing, one of America’s first neurosurgeons, kept extensive samples from his practice, but many of the details have been lost. Here is a sample of his body of work.

headline: From Argentina, Interpretations of an Argentine Interpreter
text: The impetus for Guillermo Klein’s new music, and the basis of most of his rapturous set at the Village Vanguard on Sunday night, is a set of melodies written or adapted by Cuchi Leguizamón, an Argentine modernist-folklorist composer and poet who died in 2000.

headline: In Power Grab, the Force Is With Him
text: LENOX, Mass. — Take a good look at the recumbent, inanimate figure that occupies center stage at the beginning of Shakespeare & Company’s rousing production of “Richard III.” That’s the last time you’ll see it so motionless or so horizontal. The body is that of the title character of Shakespeare’s grisliest history play. And as portrayed by John Douglas Thompson, this monarch-in-the-making quickly establishes himself as a man who is almost never still and who takes absolutely nothing lying down.

headline: Biden: U.S. Remains Committed to Helping Iraq
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Monday that the American pull-out of combat troops from Iraq does not mean that the United States is abandoning the country, promising instead to remain committed to helping Iraqis.

headline: Giving ‘Fashion Editor’ a Makeover
text: NINA GARCIA, the “Project Runway” judge and fashion editor, was on a flight from New York to Paris fashion shows last year when a flight attendant crouched beside her and meekly tried to strike up a conversation. Just another fan of the show, Ms. Garcia assumed, seeking gossip.

headline: Carry-Ons and Courtesy Need to Co-Exist
text: SPIRIT recently surprised the airline industry by introducing fees of $20 to $45 each to stow carry-on bags in overhead bins. In a Web video, Ben Baldanza, the chief executive of Spirit Airlines, describes the problem while his body is scrunched inside a bin.

headline: Photographer Withdraws Lawsuit in Shepard Fairey Case
text: The photographer who took the shot of Barack Obama that was later transformed by the street artist Shepard Fairey into the well-known “Hope” campaign poster has withdrawn a lawsuit against the Associated Press, in which he claimed he was not working for the agency when he took the picture.

headline: For Spike Lee, a New Requiem for New Orleans
text: Four years ago Spike Lee took his cameras to New Orleans to document the disaster wrought by Hurricane Katrina in 2005, as told by the people still dealing with its calamitous effects. The film Mr. Lee returned with was “When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts,” a four-hour HBO documentary that won a Peabody Award and three Emmys. As the fifth anniversary of Katrina approached, Mr. Lee went back to New Orleans this year, hoping to tell the story of that city’s recovery and rejuvenation.

headline: New Site For Artworks
text: A panel of city and county officials on Monday approved a plan to lease 2.5 acres of land owned by Los Angeles County to the philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad for his contemporary art collection in downtown Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. The deal advances Mr. Broad’s proposal to build the museum with his own money, up to $100 million for construction and $200 million more for an endowment. He has said that he would pay $7.7 million for a 99-year lease. Mr. Broad, whose 2,000-piece collection includes major works by Jeff Koons, Cindy Sherman and Andy Warhol, considered at least two other sites for the museum before deciding on the current one, located next to Disney Hall and across the street from the Museum of Contemporary Art.

headline: Bocelli To Perform at Met
text: Over the course of his career, the Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli, below, has sold millions of records, helped to close out the 2010 World Cup in a grand finale concert, performed “Jingle Bells” with the Muppets and been praised by no less an authority than Celine Dion. But he has not performed on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera. On Monday the Met said that Mr. Bocelli would make his Met solo recital debut on Feb. 13. The concert will feature Mr. Bocelli singing works by Handel, Beethoven, Wagner and other composers, with accompaniment by the pianist Vincenzo Scalera (but no Muppets). Tickets will go on sale Sept. 12.

headline: Egyptian Official Arrested In Theft of Painting
text: Prosecutors have arrested a top official in Egypt’s culture ministry and several museum security guards pending an investigation into the theft of a van Gogh painting over the weekend, Reuters reported. The painting of a vase filled with yellow poppies is known as “Poppy Flowers” or “Vase and Flowers” and is valued at more than $50 million; it remains missing after being stolen Saturday from the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum in Giza, where none of the alarms and only some of the security cameras were working at the time. Egypt’s culture minister, Farouk Hosni, retracted an announcement that the work was recovered at the Cairo airport, saying the announcement was based on faulty information. On Monday Mohsen Shaalan, a deputy culture minister who heads the department’s fine arts division, was detained, and he and the guards were accused of “negligence and failing to carry out their employment duties,” according to the Egyptian state news agency, though no formal charges have been filed. Reuters said nine other officials from the culture ministry had been prevented from traveling while the investigation continues. In an interview Monday with Agence France-Presse, Mr. Hosni said: “The search is ongoing. We still haven’t found the painting.”

headline: Another Favre Return, Another Football Win
text: NBC’s broadcast of an N.F.L. exhibition game that featured Brett Favre’s brief four-play return to the Minnesota Vikings dominated the ratings on Sunday, helping the network lead the night by a wide margin in prime time. Final audience figures for the game, which the Vikings lost, 15-10, to the San Francisco 49ers, were not immediately available on Monday, but Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates for the game were higher than for any other program on the night. The estimates also showed that the live football broadcast attracted slightly fewer viewers than the N.F.L.’s “Hall of Fame” exhibition game that drew 11.4 million two weeks ago. CBS ranked second over all, garnering its best ratings with “60 Minutes” (8.2 million) and “Big Brother” (7.8 million). ABC was third with repeats followed by a new episode of “The Gates” (2.8 million) while Fox finished fourth with its lineup of animated sitcom reruns.

headline: New Visions of Old Works
text: Since 2006 the filmmaker Peter Greenaway, below, has done a series of installations using technology to illuminate and reinterpret famous paintings. So far none have been displayed in the United States. But from Dec. 2 to Jan. 6 Mr. Greenaway will bring his exploration of Leonardo da Vinci’s “Last Supper” to the Park Avenue Armory. For one night in 2008, he turned the real “Last Supper,” which is in the refectory of Santa Maria Delle Grazie in Milan, into a sound-and-light show using projectors, computers and speakers. Light and shadows played over the painting, parts seemed to move and some images appeared three-dimensional. Mr. Greenaway will do the same thing at the Armory, but with a full-size reproduction of the mural, set within a recreation of the refectory. The installation at the Armory will also feature other projections including parts of another work by Mr. Greenaway based on Veronese’s “Wedding at Cana,” which was exhibited at the 2009 Venice Biennale.

headline: A Fringe Too Tame? Too Bad
text: Does it matter that New York has a drearily mediocre Fringe Festival?

headline: HSBC Seeks to Acquire Major Stake in Nedbank
text: HSBC, the international bank, said Monday that it was in exclusive talks with the African insurer Old Mutual to buy a controlling stake in the South African lender Nedbank, as it aimed to strengthen its presence on a continent that was one of China’s major trading partners.

headline: Singer Dies After Jump at Belgian Pop Festival
text: The lead singer of a British pop band died Friday after jumping from a telecommunications tower at a Belgian festival. The incident followed others at rock performances earlier in the week where concertgoers jumped from great heights and were injured or killed. The Guardian reported that Charles Haddon, the 22-year-old singer of Ou Est Le Swimming Pool, an electro-pop music trio from London, died at the Pukkelpop festival in Hasselt, Belgium, in a jump that followed his band’s performance that night. A statement by the festival said that Mr. Haddon had decided to take his own life, adding, “Our thoughts and sympathies go out to his family and friends.” Last Wednesday, a man at a Phish concert in Wantagh, N.Y., jumped from the balcony at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater and sustained injuries. The following night a concertgoer at a performance by the Swell Season jumped from a roof at the Mountain Winery in Saratoga, Calif., onto the stage and was killed.

headline: Edinburgh Fringe Plays Coming To New York
text: At least a couple of the popular productions among hundreds of current offerings at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe are headed to New York in the coming season. “Penelope,” the latest play by Enda Walsh, will be presented at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn (where his plays “The Walworth Farce” and “The New Electric Ballroom” have been produced). A production of the Druid Theater of Galway and scheduled to run in Brooklyn Oct. 23 to Nov. 14, “Penelope” is an absurdist interpretation of part of Homer’s “Odyssey.” Also headed to New York, and also to St. Ann’s, from Feb. 24 to March 27, 2011, is “Beautiful Burnout,” above, about the allure, competition and potential dangers of boxing, by Bryony Lavery (“Frozen”). It includes grimace-inducing intricately timed fights and fight-training sequences, choreographed by Steven Hoggett (“Black Watch,” “American Idiot”) and Scott Graham. Both shows received “Fringe First” awards by The Scotsman newspaper for the best new plays of the festival.

headline: Your Ballot Designs: An Interim Report
text: This weekend, The Times’s City Critic reviewed New York’s new voting machines, which we’ll be using for the first time during primary elections on Sept. 14, and found them to be a confusing mess. So City Room invited readers to reinvent the ballots and submit your ideas for a better design.

headline: On an Island During a Rainstorm, a Titan of Entertainment Appears
text: Diddy first appeared in shadow on Sunday night, 20 feet tall behind a scrim, a Superman come with the intent to rescue.

headline: Vale Denies It Is Potash’s White Knight
text: Forget about one possible white knight for Potash. Vale, the big Brazilian mining company, denied on Monday afternoon that it was in talks to acquire the giant Canadian fertilizer company.

headline: How to Submit a Wedding Announcement
text: To submit news of your wedding to The New York Times, please follow these instructions closely. Click here for the form to submit your announcement.

headline: Booksellers Brace for ‘Mockingjay’ Landing
text: Long before it was published, it reached the coveted top spot on Amazon.com. Its publisher ordered an enormous number of copies printed. Eager readers have planned to celebrate its arrival at elaborate midnight release parties.

headline: A Long-Forgotten Tale Rises From the Irish Sod
text: The Mint Theater is certainly making an elegant case that the Abbey Theater in Dublin missed an opportunity almost 70 years ago when it declined to produce “Wife to James Whelan,” a drama by Teresa Deevy (1894-1963), whose six previous plays had been staged to some acclaim there.

headline: Apple Patents a Desktop Touch-Screen Computer
text: It was only a matter of time.

headline: Swedish Prosecutor Hopes to Conclude Investigation of WikiLeaks Founder Soon
text: In an interview with the Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet on Monday, Sweden’s chief prosecutor, Eva Finne, said that she expects to make a decision about whether or not to charge the founder of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, with the crime of molestation or harassment this week, “hopefully tomorrow.”

headline: On Our Radar: Coal Plant Construction
text: More than 30 new coal-fired power plants have been built since 2008 or are under construction, representing the coal power industry’s largest expansion in decades. “Building a coal-fired power plant today is betting that we are not going to put a serious financial cost on emitting carbon dioxide,” an energy policy expert says. [Associated Press]

headline: Arms Dealer Faces New Charges
text: Efraim E. Diveroli, the brash young Miami Beach arms dealer who landed a $300 million contract with the Pentagon to buy and ship munitions to Afghanistan only to have it unravel in a sprawling criminal case, was in custody again in Florida on Monday, facing new federal charges.

headline: A.I.G. Pays Back $4 Billion in U.S. Loans
text: The bailed-out insurer American International Group confirmed on Monday that it had paid back nearly $4 billion in government loans in its single largest cash payment so far to reduce its debt to taxpayers, Reuters reports.

headline: Desert Dwellers on a Fast-Food Diet
text: Elizabeth Demaray, an artist based in Brooklyn, is at the counter at a McDonald’s in Midtown Manhattan. She is ordering up a storm. Cheeseburger. Apple dippers. Chicken nuggets. French fries. Baked apple pie. A strawberry shake.

headline: Four Are Awarded Medal in Mathematics
text: The Fields Medals, often considered the most prestigious awards in mathematics, have been given to four men in diverse areas of research.

headline: Noticing a Magnitude-8.0 Earthquake Months Later
text: To the amazement of seismologists, they missed a magnitude-8.0 earthquake last year.

headline: Readers Share Their Home Video Setups
text: As part of our “Sofa Wars” package, where we examined the battles being waged between start-ups and media and cable companies over the television screen, we asked our readers to share their thoughts, habits, hacks and overall experiences with the new ways we watch television.

headline: As HUD Chief, Cuomo Earns a Mixed Score
text: As Andrew M. Cuomo campaigns for governor, he points to his leadership of the Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Clinton administration as proof he possesses the ability and vision needed to lead New York out of its fiscal and political swamps.

headline: Still Afloat (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Other People’s Crises (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Gift of Sight (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,223 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: U.S. Judges Sound Off on Bank Settlements
text: WASHINGTON  Everything was rolling along traditional lines. A bank broke the rules. The government found out. The company agreed to pay a fine and improve its behavior.

headline: U.S. General Cites Goals to Train Afghan Forces
text: WASHINGTON  The American commander in charge of building up Afghanistan’s security forces said Monday that in the next 15 months he would have to recruit and train 141,000 new soldiers and police officers  more than the current size of the Afghan Army  to meet President Obama’s ambitious goals for getting Afghan forces to fight the war on their own.

headline: 3Par and Hewlett’s Hunger for Acquisitions
Egg Industry Faces New Scrutiny After Outbreak
text: As it reeled from the recall of half a billion eggs for possible salmonella infection, the American egg industry was already battling a movement to outlaw its methods as cruel and unsafe, and adapting to the Obama administration’s drive to bolster health rules and inspections.

headline: An Easy Way to Share iPhone Photos Online
text: Picplz, a low-profile photo sharing start-up from the founders of Imeem, expanded its reach Monday with the introduction of an iPhone app.

headline: Drive to Overhaul Low-Performing Schools Delayed
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  Secretary of Education Arne Duncan set an ambitious goal last year of overhauling 1,000 schools a year, using billions of dollars in federal stimulus money.

headline: U.S. Judge Rules Against Obama’s Stem Cell Policy
text: WASHINGTON  A federal district judge on Monday blocked President Obama’s 2009 executive order that expanded embryonic stem cell research, saying it violated a ban on federal money being used to destroy embryos.

headline: Plotting Doubted in WikiLeaks Case
text: STOCKHOLM  Although Swedish prosecutors have yet to complete their review of sexual abuse accusations that two Stockholm women made last week against Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, those who say they have detailed knowledge of the case discount conspiracy theories linking it to efforts to discredit WikiLeaks.

headline: Judges Taking Tougher Line on Bank Settlements
text: Everything was rolling along traditional lines. A bank broke the rules. The government found out. The company agreed to pay a fine and improve its behavior. And then the judge assigned to approve the deal blew his top.

headline: Iran: Officials Suspended Over Detainees’ Treatment
text: Iran’s top prosecutor said Monday that three judiciary officials had been suspended in connection with the mistreatment of detainees at a notorious holding center during the unrest that followed last year’s disputed presidential election, the semiofficial Fars news agency reported. Mistreatment at the holding facility, known as Kahrizak, prompted widespread outrage last year, especially after it emerged that the son of a leading conservative figure had been beaten to death there. Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered the center closed, and the government began an investigation. In December, the Judicial Organization for the Armed Forces said that three men had been killed while being detained at Kahrizak.

headline: A Magazine Now Tailored to the Not Necessarily Retired
text: WHEN Nancy Perry Graham, the editor of AARP The Magazine, attended a Bruce Springsteen concert at Giants Stadium in New Jersey last October, she and several editors on her staff wore black T-shirts with the words “AARP The Magazine  Rocking Generations of Readers” printed on the back.

headline: Brady’s Inner TV Critic Says, ‘I Hate the Jets’
text: Tom Brady hates the Jets; Jets Coach Rex Ryan does not like Tom Brady  so what else is new?

headline: A Wonk’s Guide to Andrew M. Cuomo and HUD
text: Andrew M. Cuomo is a relatively rare bird as a gubernatorial candidate, as he already has executive experience that gives us a window into his thinking and management style.

headline: Weight of Bush Ties at Issue in Ohio Senate Race
text: MAUMEE, Ohio  As he travels through Ohio, Rob Portman, the Republican Senate candidate, talks to economically stressed voters incessantly about jobs  how to keep existing ones and create new ones for workers who have seen opportunities vanish as businesses cut back or pulled out of this once-proud manufacturing hub.

headline: The Mosque, the Imam and the Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Fight on New York’s Skyline
text: To hear the two sides in the skyscraper war tell it, never has so much been at stake.

headline: Irrational Exuberance Comes Home
text: The irrational economic exuberance of the 1990s and 2000s has been rightly criticized for creating overheated markets and overextended pocketbooks, particularly in housing. That money, especially in luxury apartment towers, promoted a group of designers who emerged largely in the wake of postmodernism and who brought an unprecedented level of futuristic glamor to domestic lifestyles. Think Frank Gehry, Jean Nouvel and Herzog & de Meuron, people referred to, derisively or not, as “starchitects.”

headline: To Help Haiti’s Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Defending Karzai’s Brother
text: To the Editor:

headline: Crash Course at Plate Revives Granderson
text: TORONTO  The heat index was 106 degrees at Kauffman Stadium on Aug. 12, so the Yankees received a reprieve: no outside batting practice. Hitting in the indoor batting cages was also optional  optional for everyone but Curtis Granderson.

headline: Five and Five: No. 13, Miami (Fla.)
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 13, is Miami (Fla.). You can find a larger Miami preview here.

headline: Indian Point’s Proposal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nordstrom Links Online Inventory to Real World
text: SEATTLE  Retailers have been flailing about a bit in their efforts to get people to shop again, deploying all sorts of gimmicks and promotions to spur customer spending.

headline: Paying for School Supplies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Muscle Injuries Rattle an Oregon High School
text: Two dozen Oregon high school football players who went to a hospital last week complaining of sore and swollen muscles  including three who required surgery  probably suffered from an extreme version of a muscle syndrome caused by intense exercise, sports medicine experts said Monday.

headline: A Difficult Decision for Johnny Damon
text: Could Johnny Damon actually play for the Boston Red Sox again? If he does, the folks at Fenway Park will face the ultimate test of the Jerry Seinfeld Theory that sports fans basically root for laundry.

headline: Some Service Restored on L.I.R.R.
text: A short in a pair of waterlogged track cables in Queens on Monday led to the near-total shutdown of the Long Island Rail Road and hours of waiting for thousands of stranded commuters, a frustrating reminder of the fragility of a rail network still dependent on antiquated equipment.

headline: In the Fields of Italy, a Conflict Over Corn
text: VIVARO, Italy  Giorgio Fidenato declared war on the Italian government and environmental groups in April with a news conference and a YouTube video, which showed him poking six genetically modified corn seeds into Italian soil.

headline: McCain Looks to Complete a Comeback
text: PHOENIX  Workers were busy decorating the Phoenix Convention Center on Monday in preparation for an event honoring Senator John McCain, who is finishing up a bruising primary battle. This will be no retirement party, however. “Six more years!” is expected to be the refrain.

headline: Amid Furor on Islamic Center, Pleas for Orthodox Church Nearby
text: The furor over plans to build an Islamic center two blocks from ground zero had already been joined by several politicians. On Monday, two politicians were joined in turn by officials of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, who sought to use the controversy to focus attention on their long-stymied effort to rebuild a church destroyed on 9/11 at the foot of the World Trade Center.

headline: Afghans Say NATO Troops Killed 8 Civilians in Raid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Officials and residents of Baghlan Province, in northern Afghanistan, accused NATO troops on Monday of killing eight civilians during an early morning raid.

headline: Are Mergers Back? Well, Sort Of
text: On Wall Street, it is called the “black car indicator”  a reference to the limousines lined up around investment banks to ferry home young analysts who have pulled near-all-nighters while working on deals.

headline: As Claims for Spill Losses Shift to Administrator, Queries Follow
text: BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss.  “The day is here,” Kenneth R. Feinberg announced on Monday at the American Legion Post 139 Bingo Hall, just over a mile from this town’s quiet gulf beaches. “If you’ve got a claim from BP, those days are over,” he continued. “BP’s out of the business.”

headline: Maintenance of Oil Rig Is Subject at Hearing
text: HOUSTON  Government investigators are turning their attention this week to actions by onshore managers for BP and Transocean that may have contributed to the oil rig disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Fresh From College, Still Eager to Learn
text: For all the commotion kindled by the Red Bulls’ acquisitions of the international stars Thierry Henry and Rafael Marquez, what often has been overlooked has been the near-flawless play of two rookies plucked from the American college system.

headline: In Scarred Land, a Haven for Victims of Acid Burns
text: TRAPAENG VENG, Cambodia  Touch Eap stroked her husband’s scarred and discolored back as she described the night six years ago when she poured a tub of acid over his head, burning off his eyes and ears and lips and leaving him as dependent on her as a child.

headline: Blazing Campaign Trails in a Certain 3-Inch Heel
text: Reshma Saujani has a lot to say about her bid to challenge Representative Carolyn B. Maloney in the Sept. 14 Democratic primary, and I listened carefully as I accompanied her while she canvassed in Astoria, Queens, on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Dr. James M. Tanner, an Expert in How Children Grow, Is Dead at 90
text: Dr. James M. Tanner, an English pediatrician who developed standards for measuring a child’s development during puberty and helped define what constitutes normal growth, died Aug. 11 in Wellington, near Taunton, in southwestern England. He was 90.

headline: Ground Zero: Its Boundaries Are Elastic
text: The question is basic, first raised in this space months ago. It matters even more now with the intensified struggle over Park51, the Muslim community center and prayer space planned for Park Place, two city blocks and a dogleg from ground zero.

headline: ‘Ooh-la-la!’
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE NOTES — Today’s puzzle was the creation of a crossword class sponsored by J.A.S.A. (the Jewish Association of Services for the Aged) and taught by the 17-year-old constructor Caleb Madison. This article has all the details.

headline: For Mets, Wild Card Is, Who Stays?
text: Only 38 games remain in the regular season, and the Mets are eight games back in the National League wild-card standings. The end is fast approaching. A playoff appearance is a distant fantasy but mathematically possible, which is why no decisions have been made regarding major changes.

headline: George David Weiss, Writer of Hit Pop Songs, Dies at 89
text: George David Weiss, a songwriter who had a hand in some of the biggest hits of midcentury pop music, recorded by some of the biggest stars, died on Monday at his home in Oldwick, N.J. He was 89.

headline: A Case of Mental Courage
text: In 1811, the popular novelist Fanny Burney learned she had breast cancer and underwent a mastectomy without anesthesia. She lay down on an old mattress, and a piece of thin linen was placed over her face, allowing her to make out the movements of the surgeons above her.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Yankees Rookie Gives as Good as He Gets
text: TORONTO  The major league leader in home runs, who three innings earlier clobbered a ball halfway to Saskatchewan, had just watched a 92-mile-per-hour fastball zip over his head and rattle off the backstop. The pitch was more high than inside, but Jose Bautista probably could not tell the difference, and he popped up off the dirt to glare at Ivan Nova, the Yankees’ rookie starter who was glaring right back at him with his arms outstretched.

headline: A Hero Named Bobby
text: I was surprised  but probably shouldn’t have been  that so many people had never heard of Bobby Thomson, who died at his home in Savannah, Ga., last week at the age of 86.

headline: The Yen’s Lesson for the Yuan
text: AMONG the many points of tension between the United States and China, perhaps the single greatest one concerns exchange rates. For more than a decade, Beijing has kept the value of the renminbi, also known as the yuan, more or less constant to the dollar, a strategy that critics say increases the price of American exports to China and fuels the rapidly growing trade deficit with Beijing.

headline: A Real Debate on Taxes
text: A deadline is supposed to concentrate the mind. But the year-end expiration of the Bush-era tax cuts, and the November elections, are having the opposite effect.

headline: Tainted Eggs
text: The blame for the nationwide recall of tainted eggs must fall on the producers who allowed their eggs to become contaminated and distributed them for sale. But after a decade of tainted beef, spinach, the list goes on  federal officials also must take the rap for moving too slowly to strengthen the country’s food safety system.

headline: Rangel on the Hot Seat in Debate
text: It was a gentle but unmistakable nudge President Obama gave Representative Charles B. Rangel recently, suggesting in an interview three weeks ago that Mr. Rangel, 80, should retire to “end his career with dignity.”

headline: Mr. Lazio’s Bid for Attention
text: The former congressman Rick Lazio may be the front-runner in the Republican primary race for New York governor, but he lags far behind the Democratic nominee, Andrew Cuomo, in both the polls and fund-raising. That may explain, but can never excuse, his increasingly hysterical attacks on plans to build an Islamic community center and mosque two blocks from ground zero.

headline: Far From Ground Zero, a Good-Will Tour
text: MUHARRAQ, Bahrain — The latecomers to Sheik Salah al-Jowder’s majlis, or weekly assembly, wished peace upon their cousins and shook all the men’s hands before sitting down on the deep striped sofas that lined the oblong reception hall.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Acid Rain 30 Years On
text: Just over 30 years ago, a skeptical Daniel Patrick Moynihan persuaded his Senate colleagues to approve a major study to see whether a relatively unknown phenomenon called acid rain was worth worrying about. The study, completed in 1990, showed that pollution blowing eastward from coal-fired power plants was killing off aquatic life. One-quarter of the Adirondacks’ 3,000 lakes and streams had become too acidic to support fish life, or were headed that way.

headline: Commission Votes to Put Term Limits on November Ballot in New York City
text: Should New York City leaders be limited to two terms in office? Should the fine for violating conflict-of-interest laws increase? Should the city reduce the number of signatures required to get on a ballot?

headline: Bloggingheads: The Radicalization Threat
text: Adam Serwer, left, of The American Prospect and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate the danger of radicalization of American Muslims.

headline: Roche Backs New Method for Drug Delivery to Cells
text: The Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche is throwing its weight behind an experimental technology that could be used to treat a number of diseases.

headline: Radiation, Risks Are Focus of Breast Screening Studies
text: When Dr. Deborah Rhodes orders a diagnostic test that involves radiation, she consults a chart in her office that lists the amount of radiation exposure from each test. She considers the patient’s total past exposure, and then carefully weighs the risks and benefits of each test and any alternative approaches she can take.

headline: Word of the Day | synoptic
text: synoptic •\si-nopˈtik\• adjective

headline: On Primary Day, McCain Seeks Political Comeback
text: PHOENIX  Workers were busy decorating the Phoenix Convention Center on Monday in preparation for an event honoring Senator John McCain, who is finishing up a bruising primary battle. This will be no retirement party, however. “Six more years!” is expected to be the refrain.

headline: Blagojevich Plays Defendant on ‘The Daily Show’
text: The scandal-scarred ex-Illinois governor returns to television.

headline: Blagojevich on ‘The Daily Show’
text: Rod R. Blagojevich made his return to television Monday night with an appearance on The Daily Show. The Caucus blog has the details.

headline: News Quiz | August 24, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Are Mergers Back? Well, Sort Of
text: While this August has seen an unexpected resurgence in deals — huge deals — the banking business still hasn’t made up its mind where the trend is going, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: PocketGear Pockets $15 Million in B Round
text: PocketGear has raised $15 million in a second round of funding, VentureBeat reported. The mobile application store operator said it would use the funds to continue product development, increase its sales and marketing team and to move toward global expansion.

headline: Nimbula Nabs $15 Million in Accel-Led Round
text: Nimbula on Monday announced it had raised $15 million in a second round of funding. The round was led by Accel Partners whose Ping Li had taken a seat on the board, VentureBeat reported.

headline: 3Par Contest Shows Demand for Data Storage
text: Data storage used to be one of the more mundane corners of the technology industry. Now it is where an increasing number of tech companies — and Wall Street — want to be, Ashlee Vance reports in The New York Times.

headline: TPG to Create 2nd Currency Fund, With Chongqing
text: TPG, one of the world’s biggest private equity firms, said early Tuesday that it was teaming up with the municipal governments of two of China’s biggest cities to raise nearly $1.5 billion and create its first funds denominated entirely in Chinese currency.

headline: Overestimating the Safety of Bonds
text: From Carl Richards at Bucks:

headline: Former Executive at Gucci to Lead Barneys
text: The chic retailer Barneys New York, which has been through a turbulent period since it was bought in 2007 by the investment arm of Dubai World, announced on Monday that Mark Lee, the former head of the Gucci brand, would become its chief executive on Sept. 1.

headline: Court Dismisses Mortgage Claims vs. Morgan
text: A mortgage servicing company’s claims that would push responsibility for faulty mortgage loans onto Wall Street titan Morgan Stanley were dismissed by a Delaware court, according to a court filing, Reuters reported.

headline: F.D.I.C. Says Basel Proposals Crucial for Safe Banks
text: Excessive bank leverage has had a disastrous effect on the economy, a top United States bank regulator said on Tuesday, defending a proposal by the Basel Committee to reshape the financial system and avoid another credit crisis, Reuters reports.

headline: Thoma Bravo Agrees to Buy LANDesk Software
text: Thoma Bravo, the private equity firm, has agreed to acquire the LANDesk Software unit from Emerson Electric.

headline: Lou Simpson to Retire From Berkshire
text: Lou Simpson, who oversees investments at Geico and was long considered a possible successor to Warren Buffett at Berkshire Hathaway, is retiring at the end of the year, Mr. Buffett told The Chicago Tribune on Monday.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Scandiknavery
text: Today’s word, in association with the fabulous Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: 3Par and Hewlett’s Hunger for Acquisitions
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: BofA Chief Buys 30,000 Shares of Company Stock
text: A regulatory filing shows that Bank of America‘s chief executive, Brian Moynihan, has bought 30,000 shares of common stock in the company, a possible signal to Wall Street that the executive believes the stock is undervalued.

headline: GMP Capital Chief to Hand Over Daily Duties
text: The chief executive of GMP Capital will turn over the day-to-day management of the firm to his successor, The Globe and Mail reported citing an unidentified source.

headline: The First Family’s Second Summer Vacation
text: WHO is in the president’s entourage while he is on vacation?

headline: Polaroids on Gorilla vs. Bear Blog
text: In a studio or backstage or bobbing in a sea of digital S.L.R.s at a concert, David Bartholow’s camera always gets a reaction.

headline: AWB Recommends Agrium Bid to Shareholders
text: AWB, the Australian wheat service company, said Tuesday that it would recommend Agrium‘s cash bid to take over the firm for 1.24 billion Australian dollars ($1.1 billion).

headline: Defendant’s Hearing Set in $880 Million Fraud
text: A Florida man accused of running an $880 million Ponzi scheme that authorities said paid for lavish spending sprees and sports philanthropy may have reached a deal with federal prosecutors, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Ex-Wesleyan University Investment Chief Sued by Connecticut
text: Connecticut Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, left, said Monday he is suing Wesleyan University‘s former investment director and three companies, accusing them of misusing the university’s endowment for personal trips and other expenses, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Do You Watch Shows on Your TV or Computer?
text: Many Americans, despite the increased availability of programming online, continue to watch shows on network and cable television. What about you?

headline: Guilty Plea in Disney Insider-Trading Case
text: A Los Angeles man pleaded guilty on Monday to conspiring between March and May this year with his girlfriend, then a Walt Disney employee, in trying to sell confidential company information to hedge funds.

headline: Accretive: Returns in Search of Investors
text: Like most money managers, Rick Fearon thought outsize returns would be more than enough to grow his $20 million fund. But he now faces what industry experts say is an almost impossible task.

headline: In London, a Look Back at Ealing Classics
text: Few films offer more endearing, self-effacing views of life than the Ealing comedies. Starting this month, the Museum of London begins its series of free screenings of these classics.

headline: Good Intentions, Bad Policy
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: K.N.O.C. Chief Says No Plan to Raise Dana Offer
text: Korea National Oil will not consider raising its $2.6 billion hostile takeover offer for British oil explorer Dana Petroleum in return for management backing, K.N.O.C.’s chief executive said on Tuesday.

headline: Xstrata in $381 Million Takeover of Sphere
text: Xstrata, the coal and base metals mining company, pushed deeper into the iron ore sector on Tuesday with a $381 million agreed takeover of Australian-listed Sphere Minerals, which holds magnetite iron ore deposits in Mauritania.

headline: At Least 30 Killed in Somalia Hotel Attack
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somali insurgents disguised in government military uniforms stormed a Mogadishu hotel on Tuesday and killed at least 30 people, including 4 lawmakers, laying bare how vulnerable Somalia’s government is, even in an area it claims to control.

headline: An Investor’s Dilemma: I.P.O.’s or Las Vegas?
text: With such instantly recognizable brands as Skype and General Motors planning initial public offerings, investor interest is picking up. But, advisers worry that familiarity will rope in investors whose emotional responses lead to overpaying.

headline: Giants’ Manning Ready for Ravens, but Ross Is Out
text: Eli Manning and Brandon Jacobs said that they would play against the Baltimore Ravens in the Giants’ third preseason game after injuries sidelined them last Saturday against the Pittsburgh Steelers.

headline: Ruling Is Due in Virginia Climate Change Case
text: A ruling is expected within a week on a demand by Virginia’s attorney general that the University of Virginia release the research records of a well-known climate change researcher.

headline: Chi-X Acknowledges an Approach by Potential Bidder
text: Addressing rampant speculation that a bidder might emerge for the pan-European share trading platform Chi-X Europe, the company acknowledged Monday that it had received an expression of interest from an unidentified third party.

headline: Team DeMint vs. Team Lott
text: Today’s idea: The Republican Party is divided between Tea Party true believers and K Street insiders, a columnist says. It’s Team DeMint vs. Team Lott.

headline: Blankfein Said to Swim, and Win, for Charity
text: Goldman Sachs‘s recent drive to help improve its image may have gotten a boost this weekend when the bank’s chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, used a flip-turn to win a charity swim event at the Southampton Bath & Tennis Club.

headline: Norwegian Property Sells Hotels for $1.33 Billion
text: Norwegian Property has agreed to sell Nordic hotel company Norgani Hotels to Sweden-based real estate firm Pandox and its Norwegian owners for around $1.33 billion, the real estate group said.

headline: Different Mind-Sets of Mangold and Revis
text: Center Nick Mangold and the Jets have agreed to the outline for a contract extension, and are close to working out the final details.

headline: Here Are My Three Problems This Week
text: Problems, problems, problems. I’ve been mulling over some thorny issues this week. They aren’t really related to each other, but I’m going to need to make decisions on each of these soon. As always, your comments and suggestions are greatly appreciated.

headline: Lehman’s Sale Was ‘Best Deal’ It Could Make
text: Lehman Brothers made “the best deal it could” when it sold its brokerage to Barclays in “one of the most uncertain weeks in financial market history,” a former Lehman restructuring executive told a judge, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Financial Research? There’s an App for That
text: Morgan Stanley on Monday became the first Wall Street firm to introduce an application for its financial research in Apple‘s App Store.

headline: India’s Viom Considers an I.P.O.
text: Viom Networks, an Indian mobile phone tower operator partly owned by the Tata Group, is considering selling shares in an initial public offering, a company official said.

headline: Enel Expects $3.8 Billion From Green Power
text: Enel‘s chief executive, Fulvio Conti, said he expects the company to raise “at least” 3 billion euros ($3.8 billion) from the sale of a minority stake in its Enel Green Power unit, less than his previous estimate.

headline: Dell Said to Prepare Higher Bid for 3Par
text: Dell is preparing a sweetened offer for data-storage provider 3Par after it was outbid by a $1.6 billion proposal by Hewlett-Packard, a person familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: AMC’s Credibility Problem
text: So I Tivoed an episode of AMC’s show Rubicon. As best I can make it out, it’s about a sinister cabal that runs everything, and sends assassination orders via crossword puzzles. That’s completely realistic.

headline: Q. & A.: Dealing With Apple App Lemons
text: Q.

headline: A Nice Little Dinner: Heirloom Tomatoes and Corn
text: I had cooked beans in the fridge, and corn. I stopped at the greenmarket and picked up tomatoes — heirloom, I suppose (you’d have to call them that given the price), but in any case ripe and local. (To me, ripe and local and non-heirloom would be just fine.) I bought basil.

headline: Sanofi-Genzyme Talks Said to Stall on Price
text: Talks between the French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi-Aventis and the American biotech company Genzyme have hit a snag as the two sides try to agree on a threshhold price that would allow Sanofi to proceed with due diligence, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: Hangover Theory At The Fed
text: This Jon Hilsenrath piece on the Fed is an impressive piece of reporting; it seems that somebody is talking out of school. And as Tim Duy says, it’s also depressing for anyone believing, as I do, that we’re sliding steadily into a long-run low-growth, high-unemployment trap, and that aggressive action by the Fed is urgent.

headline: Wall Street Hit Again, This Time by Housing Data
text: The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index ended lower Tuesday for a fourth consecutive day, unable to rebound from a disappointing report on existing-home sales.

headline: Australian Independents Huddle as Vote Remains Deadlocked
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Three independent legislators who could hold the balance of power in a deadlocked Australian Parliament met Tuesday behind closed doors to discuss the future shape of government here, as officials continued tallying votes for several seats that were still too close to call.

headline: Boehner Urges Obama to Fire Economic Team
text: CLEVELAND  Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, called on President Obama on Tuesday to fire his top economic advisers as Mr. Boehner tried to make the economic case for restoring Republicans to the majority in Congress in the November elections.

headline: Austria Indicts 3 in Killing of Chechen Exile
text: MOSCOW  Prosecutors in Austria said Tuesday that they had filed a formal indictment against three men in connection with the killing of a Chechen whistle-blower in Vienna last year. But the prosecutors said they did not have enough evidence to charge Chechnya’s leader, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, who had earlier been implicated in the crime.

headline: A Tale of Two Apprentices: Bret Michaels and Rod Blagojevich
text: In a moment made possible by the serendipity of summer television, two former “Celebrity Apprentice” contestants, Bret Michaels and Rod R. Blagojevich, found themselves back on the airwaves Monday night, under very different circumstances. Let’s see how their lives have changed since they exited the board room of Trump Tower, shall we?

headline: A Refuge for Acid Burn Victims
text: An increase in the number of reported acid attacks in Cambodia, with 17 so far this year, has drawn attention to Cambodia's only shelter.

headline: Yes, $3 Million
text: I gather that some people are claiming that my numbers in Monday’s column were wrong. They weren’t.

headline: Everything From This to That
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Everything From This to That
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: A Battle for the New York Skyline
text: To hear the two sides in the skyscraper war tell it, never has so much been at stake.

headline: Craig Wasserman, M&A Lawyer, Dies at 49
text: Craig M. Wasserman, a lawyer at  Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, died on Monday.  He was 49 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: The Early Word: Stem Cell Surprise
text: In what has been called a surprising move, a federal district judge has blocked the Obama administration’s expansion of embryonic stem cell research.

headline: More Commuter Chaos in the Region
text: Thousands of commuters into New York City confronted another round of potentially heavy delays on the Long Island Rail Road on Tuesday morning, a day after an electrical short in a pair of cables sparked a fire in a control tower, causing an almost total shutdown of train traffic for part of the day.

headline: Vital Wave
text: Brooke Partridge explains how her technology consulting company dealt with smaller contracts and shrinking revenue.

headline: Once on This Island: Matthew Fox Talks About Life After ‘Lost’
text: Warning: if you haven’t yet watched the “Lost” finale, this post will surely spoil it for you.

headline: Mamils
text: Middle-Aged Men In Lycra – an increasingly common sight in Britain, and elsewhere, exacerbated by the popularity of cycling.

headline: U.S. Home Sales at Lowest Level in More Than a Decade
text: Housing sales in July plunged to their lowest level in more than a decade, exceeding even the grimmest forecasts.

headline: Grand Cherokee Is Investigated for Gas Tank Danger
text: 4:02 p.m. | Updated The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said on Tuesday it would grant a consumer group’s request to investigate whether an estimated three million Jeep Grand Cherokees had gas tanks that were too vulnerable to fires after a rear impact.

headline: N.J. Transit and Amtrak Are Hobbled This Morning, Too
text: Long Island Rail Road is not the only commuter carrier with problems Tuesday morning.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Egg Recall’s Impact
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: New York Wins Race to the Top Grant
text: New York State has won about $700 million as part of a competitive federal education grant known as Race to the Top, federal officials said on Tuesday. The money comes after months of wrangling in the State Legislature and fights with the state and city teachers’ unions.

headline: U.S. Troop Count Dips Below 50,000 in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  The American military said Tuesday that the number of troops in Iraq had dropped below 50,000, in line with the Obama administration’s deadline of Aug. 31 for what it describes as the end of combat operations in the country.

headline: New York City Opera Announces Its New Season
text: The soprano Lauren Flanigan, who last year sang the title role in “Esther” for New York City Opera in a performance that Anthony Tommasini called “vocally blazing and vulnerable” in a review for The New York Times, will return to the opera company for its 2010-2011 season to sing the role of Myra Foster in “Séance on a Wet Afternoon,” a new work by Stephen Schwartz (“Godspell,” “Wicked”), New York City Opera said. “Séance on a Wet Afternoon” will have its debut at the David H. Koch Theater on April 19 as part of a season that will open on Oct. 27 with a new production o “A Quiet Place” by Leonard Bernstein and Stephen Wadsworth, directed by Christopher Alden and featuring the soprano Sara Jakubiak in her City Opera debut as Dede.

headline: Officials Admit Failings in Manila Hostage Standoff
text: MANILA  In the face of growing Chinese anger, Philippine officials acknowledged failings in how the police handled a 12-hour hostage standoff on a tourist bus, which unfolded on live television and ended with the deaths of eight passengers from Hong Kong and the armed captor, a former police officer.

headline: Another View: Gleaning the Bond Market’s Message
text: Daniel Alpert, managing partner of Westwood Capital, notes that while the bond market does not lie, its message can be confusing.

headline: Anticipating the Send-Off, Though It’s Still a Year Away
text: If I hadn’t been feeling anxious about my daughter’s departure to college — a whole year away — I’m beginning to now.

headline: Backstory | Two for the Rue
text: The legendary photographer Hans Feurer shoots women as if they were wild animals: from a safe distance and with a long lens. In Two for the Rue, he captures some of the chicest looks of the fall season in their natural habitat — the streets of Paris.

headline: White Lies and Clean Underwear
text: Always tell the truth.

headline: An iPhone Workout, Barbells Optional
text: While a number of exercise apps tell you how to sculpt and tone in the gym, a new app from celebrity trainer Christine Hazelton does that as well as telling you how to work out when you don’t have a gym.

headline: Plane Crashes Near Everest; 4 Americans Among Dead
text: KATMANDU, Nepal  Fourteen people, including four Americans, died Tuesday in Nepal when their plane crashed in inclement weather, after a failed attempt to reach a popular destination for touring hikers near Mount Everest, according to Nepali officials.

headline: G4 Calls Action on ‘Hurt Locker’-Style Reality Show
text: A new reality series ordered by the G4 cable channel may not have the pedigree of the director Kathryn Bigelow or much chance of toppling James Cameron‘s “Avatar” at major awards shows, but it shares other key details with “The Hurt Locker,” Ms. Bigelow’s Oscar-winning feature about an American bomb squad in Iraq. The Hollywood Reporter said G4 had committed to 10 episodes of “Bomb Patrol: Afghanistan,” which will document a Navy Explosive Ordnance Disposal unit as it trains in the United States and is deployed in the war zone. Neal Tiles, the president of G4, told The Hollywood Reporter that the show provides “a rare opportunity to showcase the work of the courageous men and women on the front lines” and would also connect with the young male viewers already tuning in to G4 programs like “Attack of the Show!” Mr. Tiles said, “Both G4 and the Navy like this for the same reason: It appeals to the tech side of G4’s demographic.” “Bomb Patrol: Afghanistan” is planned for a spring debut.

headline: Climate ‘CSI’ Team Takes on Russian Heat
text: A couple of years ago, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration established a “Climate Scene Investigation” strike team tasked with quickly assessing the causes of extreme events — mega downpours, off-the-chart heat waves and the like. One goal is to gauge any contribution from the global buildup of human-generated greenhouse gases. I’ll soon be interviewing Martin Hoerling, the climate scientist who heads this effort, but I wanted to highlight the team’s latest product, an incredibly thorough post mortem on the Russian heat wave, posted on August 13. [6:38 p.m. | Updated  Tom Yulsman at the University of Colorado interviewed Hoerling about Russian heat and the climate attribution team (it helps to be local) and I encourage you to have a read.]

headline: A Moment to Ask: Will This Protect New Orleans?
text: The Army Corps of Engineers traditionally oversold the strength and quality of the New Orleans levees before Katrina.

headline: Surveying Rwanda’s Water Supply
text: When I tell people I am going to Rwanda, I usually get the “are you kidding me?” look.  Most people in the West have come to know Rwanda through its bloody civil war; more than 800,000 people were killed there in 1994, marking one of the most infamous genocides of modern history.  Apart from this sad event, however, very little is known about contemporary Rwanda and the people who live within its borders.

headline: Flow of Oil Money Beats a Flood of U.S. Debt
text: London

headline: 10 Questions for Marco Rubio
text: If the year had played out as it began, the biggest moment in Marco Rubio’s political career would be unfolding Tuesday in Florida’s primary for the open Senate seat.

headline: Existing Home Sales Swan Dive
text: Sales of existing homes plunged 27.2 percent in July, down to their lowest level since the National Association of Realtors began keeping track over a decade ago.

headline: Ansel Adams Trust Sues Over Negatives
text: The debate over whether negatives bought at a California garage sale are really the lost work of Ansel Adams has now landed where it always seemed destined: a courtroom.

headline: They’ll Always Have Boston
text: It is not, it seems, a great time to be a former Red Sox star. Roger Clemens’s fall from grace is more like a cliff dive, with a potential landing in jail on perjury charges. Manny Ramirez is apparently headed to baseball’s version of purgatory, when, or if, the Dodgers waive him and hope some team is nuts enough to bail them out. And Johnny Damon finds himself in the bind of being waived by Detroit, claimed by Boston, and not being at all happy about it.

headline: Just How Good Was Revis Last Year?
text: Bill Barnwell of Football Outsiders recently answered questions from readers of The Times’s Freakonomics blog.

headline: Now Voyager | Orient Express Bar
text: For those of us still in recession rigmarole and unable to flee to far-off lands this month, Osman Cakir has saved the day. Last week he opened his dream bar, Orient Express. “I have always wanted to open this bar,” Cakir says. “I have been fascinated by the train since I was a kid in Istanbul.”

headline: New York Send-Off | Where Music Sails
text: Jan Benzel is an editor at The Times who is being reassigned to Paris. Before she leaves, she is attempting to do all the things in the city that every New Yorker should do, at least once.

headline: Midday Take-out
text: — Next time you’re in coach trying to catch some sleep on the red-eye, whatever you do, don’t think of the private planes, the flying penthouses that could have been yours, if only you had dropped out of that English program and joined a hedge fund before they were in style. The Telegraph of London has a slide show from inside the the jets that carry the jet set.

headline: TimesCast | August 24, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on an insurgent attack in Somalia, preventing salmonella in eggs and the fight over flavored milk in school cafeterias.

headline: Eastern States Dominate in Winning School Grants
text: When Secretary of Education Arne Duncan announced on Tuesday the latest states to win the Race to the Top competition  and a share of $3.4 billion in federal financing  he said they were chosen because they outlined the boldest plans for shaking up their public school systems.

headline: Sherrod Turns Down Job Offer
text: Shirley Sherrod, the official who was ousted from her job at the Agriculture Department last month, said on Tuesday that she was declining the chance to return to the agency.

headline: Casting Announced for American Ballet Theater’s ‘Nutcracker’
text: It’s never too early to start dreaming of sugarplums. Casting has been announced for American Ballet Theater’s new production of “The Nutcracker” with choreography by Alexei Ratmansky. The principal dancers Gillian Murphy and David Hallberg will lead the world premiere on Dec. 23 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the roles of Clara and the Nutcracker Prince.
10-year bond rates:

headline: After Mozart’s Death, an Endless Coda
text: Direct medical evidence? None. Autopsy? Not performed. Medical records? Nowhere to be found. Corpse? Disappeared.

headline: ‘Mosque’ Coverage Dominates News
text: This should come as little surprise to anyone who hasn’t been living under a rock.

headline: Scientists Find Oil-Eating Bacteria Plentiful in Deep Gulf Waters
text: Oil-eating bacteria exist in significant quantities even in the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico, and may be breaking down submerged oil from the Deepwater Horizon leak faster than previously believed, scientists are reporting today.

headline: Reader Response: How Americans Pay for College, by School Type
text: On Monday, we posted some charts showing how American families pay for the costs of college. In response, a few readers wrote in asking about how the breakdown would look if organized by attendees of private versus public colleges.

headline: Not-Sleeping Your Way to the Top
text: Like a well-trained soldier, the actor Judah Friedlander does more before 9 a.m. than you do in an entire day. He can accomplish so much because he rarely wastes time sleeping, operating on zero to five hours of sleep a night.

headline: Adviser Says He Raised Concerns to BP on Well
text: HOUSTON  An official for Halliburton, the company hired by BP to perform a critical step in the process for closing the well connected to the Deepwater Horizon oil rig, testified Tuesday that days before the rig exploded he had raised concerns to BP about its plan for executing the procedure, but that he continued with the job anyway.

headline: Yankees to Dedicate Monument to Steinbrenner on Sept. 20
text: The Yankees will dedicate a monument in honor of George Steinbrenner, their longtime principal owner, on Monday, Sept. 20, at Yankee Stadium, the owner’s family said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Samurai Shopper | TV or not TV
text: “How sleek is turquoise with black?” Give up? It isn’t. Turquoise is never sleek for anyone over age 12. And coupled with black? The horror. This is why the Samurai Shopper avoids TV shopping networks: fear of brain death from rhetorical idiocies (see above). Still, I’m often compelled to focus on TV’s goings-on with pitiless exactitude, even if it’s too easy to slag, too much like taking candy from a baby.

The name comes from the ancient kingdom of the Medes.

headline: Inside Out | A Closet Full of Clean
text: I have started looking for a new apartment. Within 48 hours, I became that clichéd New Yorker, addicted to real estate Web sites and printing floor plans out to rearrange them into my perfect apartment; I even bought a printer on Sunday so that I could print them at home! There are few things that I like more than redesigning spaces on the back on an envelope, creating rooms with little squares that represent sofas and end tables, and imagining scenes of afternoons and evenings with people popping over, and dinners being cooked in a kitchen that was once a closet and second bathroom, and which is now a place where herbs are chopped and corks are pulled from bottles.

headline: New Case of Civilian Deaths Investigated in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A team of investigators from the American-led forces here headed to a volatile corner of northeast Afghanistan on Tuesday after local officials reported that a nighttime raid by NATO commandos there had left 8 civilians dead and 12 wounded.

headline: Digital Devices Deprive Brain of Needed Downtime

headline: Going 12-0 Without Your Cleanup Hitter

Before losing, 3-2, Monday night to the Blue Jays, the Yankees had won all 12 games this season in which Rodriguez did not play. So much has to go right for a team to win one game that, one might think, something wouldn’t go its way over the course of 12. But nothing did, and here are a few reasons the Yankees were able to thrive in a Rodriguez-less world:

headline: ‘Deliverance’: A Dark Heart Still Beating
text: On the page and off, James Dickey (1923-1997) was a maximalist. His roomy, loquacious poems spill down the page in a waterfall style and in a voice he called “country surrealism.” It makes sense that he called some of these poems “walls of words,” similar to the record producer Phil Spector’s echoing “wall of sound.” Dickey’s music, rougher and weirder than Mr. Spector’s, was similarly packed with reverb.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Mogadishu and Elsewhere
text: Somali insurgents disguised in government military uniforms stormed a Mogadishu hotel on Tuesday and killed at least 30 people, including six lawmakers, Jeffrey Gettleman reported. The insurgents methodically moved room to room, killing hotel guests who tried to bolt their doors shut. When government forces finally cornered the insurgents, two blew themselves up with suicide vests. The attack laid bare the vulnerability of Somalia’s government, even in an area it claims to control.

headline: Sustaining the Forest, Maintaining a Bridge
text: There are 11,000 tropical wood planks in the Brooklyn Bridge boardwalk, and millions of feet and wheels tread on them every year. Eventually, the boards wear out and must be replaced. Currently, the city uses similar tropical hardwoods, though under pressure from rain-forest advocates, it has begun to test alternative materials.

headline: Voices Pitched to a Fine-Tuned Hollow Sound
text: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. — Watching combative friends and relatives lob epigrams at one another has long been a favorite spectator sport at summer theaters. When you’re feeling overheated and limp-brained, there’s undeniable satisfaction in hearing awkwardness and animosity translated into graceful, gliding prose. But does anyone ever pause to think how trying it must be always to speak that way, or that such articulateness might be — gulp! — a hard-fought existential commitment?

headline: A Temple of Drama, Burnished
text: Fall in love with the Broadway theater, and sooner or later you will probably find yourself developing an ancillary ardor for Broadway theaters  the grand old buildings themselves, I mean, irrespective of the hits and flops that inhabit them. The most beautiful are splendid representations of architecture styles in fashion in the early decades of the 20th century. And like most old buildings with character, the great Broadway houses  and even some of the not-so-great ones  seem to absorb some of the historical mystique that passes through.
