headline: Weekend Orchestra Seats to the Met for $25?
text: It’s hard to imagine being able to see a Metropolitan Opera weekend performance from an orchestra seat for $25  particularly when the top ticket price is $420. But Agnes Varis, a Met board member, believes “opera is for everyone,” so she has decided to subsidize 13,600 seats for weekend performances for the 2010-11 season. The program extends a weekday Rush Ticket program sponsored by Ms. Varis that subsidizes 200 seats at $20 each for every weekday performance, excluding galas. “I thought a weekend program would give even more people an opportunity to enjoy the opera,” Ms. Varis said in a statement. “The Met has never been greater.” The seats in the orchestra and Grand Tier, which range from $322 to $137, will be available for $25 through weekly drawings for Friday evening, Saturday matinee and Saturday evening performances. (The premieres of new productions of “La Traviata,” on Dec. 31, and “Die Walkürie,” on April 22, are not part of the program.) Entry forms will be available only at the Met’s Web site, metopera.org. Beginning Sept. 27, every Monday through the end of the Met season in May operagoers can sign up for the drawings, which will be held on Tuesday mornings. Winners’ names will be posted by noon. The number of tickets available will vary each week.

headline: The Gates Path to an Energy Revolution
text: Jason Pontin, the editor in chief of Technology Review, recently spoke with Bill Gates about everything from software entrepreneurship to promoting polio vaccination in northern Nigeria. But the heart of the conversation, published today on the magazine’s Web site, was about how to make non-polluting energy technologies so cheap that coal reverts to being the shiny black rock it was before the industrial revolution.

headline: Ansel Adams Trust Sues
text: The debate over whether negatives bought at a California garage sale are really the lost work of Ansel Adams has now landed where it always seemed destined: a courtroom. The Ansel Adams Publishing Trust, which controls the licensing rights to Adams’s work, filed a federal trademark infringement suit Monday in San Francisco as part of an effort to block the sale of prints by Rick Norsigian, a Fresno school-maintenance worker who bought the negatives 10 years ago for $45. The suit argues that Mr. Norsigian and a consulting firm run by his lawyer, Arnold Peter, have “acted knowingly, willfully and with malice” in marketing the negatives as Adams’s work, according to a report in The Bay Citizen. Prints from the negatives are being sold online and through a Beverly Hills, Calif., gallery. Mr. Peter said in a statement that he was disappointed by the lawsuit, which he described as an effort to harass Mr. Norsigian.

headline: New York City Opera Announces Season
text: The soprano Lauren Flanigan, who last year sang the title role in “Esther” for New York City Opera, above, will return to the opera company for its 2010-11 season to sing the role of Myra Foster in “Séance on a Wet Afternoon,” a new work by Stephen Schwartz (“Godspell,” “Wicked”), New York City Opera said. “Séance on a Wet Afternoon” will have its debut at the David H. Koch Theater on April 19 as part of a season that will open on Oct. 27 with a new production of “A Quiet Place” by Leonard Bernstein and Stephen Wadsworth. Other planned productions include Strauss’s “Intermezzo,” opening Oct. 31; Donizetti’s “Elixir of Love,” opening March 22; and a program of monodramas, opening March 25, comprising John Zorn’s “La Machine de l’Être,” Arnold Schoenberg’s “Erwartung” and Morton Feldman’s “Neither,” with a libretto by Samuel Beckett. City Opera will also present a fall concert, “Lucky to Be Me: The Vocal Music of Leonard Bernstein,” on Nov. 6 and 7, featuring the Broadway performers Victoria Clark, Christine Ebersole, Kelli O’Hara, Donna Murphy, Michael Cerveris, Darius de Haas and Michael Urie.

headline: After Upheaval, Not All Is Well With Thai Youth
text: NA CHUEAK, THAILAND — Three months ago, images of protesters battling the military in the streets of Bangkok seized the world’s attention. Now, by some measures, Thailand is bouncing back: the country’s economy is projected to grow as fast as 7.5 percent this year, and the government is pushing ahead with a program of “reconciliation” with its opponents.

headline: New Yorker Festival Announces Lineup
text: Today’s secret words are alter ego: Paul Reubens, below, the artist known forever in our hearts as Pee-wee Herman, will make a rare out-of-character appearance as himself for a public interview as part of the 11th-annual New Yorker Festival in October, its organizers said on Tuesday. Other performers and authors who will appear in conversations with that magazine’s contributors include the “Office” star Steve Carell, the actress Patricia Clarkson, the musician James Taylor, the fantasy writer Neil Gaiman and the filmmaker Werner Herzog. The festival, which runs from Oct. 1 through 3, will also feature panel discussions on “Saturday Night Live,” with Seth Meyers and other cast members, and moderated by The New Yorker editor, David Remnick; on vampires in popular culture, featuring Stephen King and the “Twilight” screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg and moderated by Joan Acocella; and on the rise of the political right, with the FreedomWorks chairman, Dick Armey, Representative Anthony Weiner, Democrat of New York, the CNBC host Rick Santelli and The New Yorker’s Jill Lepore, also moderated by Mr. Remnick. A full lineup for the festival will be posted at newyorker.com/festival.

headline: Katie Finneran to Leave ‘Promises’
text: Sean Hayes, above, will need to find a new drunken dance partner in “Promises, Promises.” Katie Finneran, also above, who won a Tony Award for her scene-stealing Act 2 turn as the barfly Marge MacDougall, is leaving the cast on Oct. 10. A spokesman for the show announced on Tuesday that Ms. Finneran and Darren Goldstein, who married on Sunday, were expecting a baby in the winter. Mr. Hayes, who shares a memorable Christmas Eve jitterbug with Ms. Finneran’s character in the musical, is signed to appear through Dec. 26, as is his co-star, Kristin Chenoweth, who plays his main love interest. The show, which opened in April, was one of last season’s biggest hits. Producers said that a new Marge would be announced soon. The role is small, but juicy: like Ms. Finneran, Marian Mercer won the best-featured-actress Tony playing Marge in the original 1968 production.

headline: American Ballet Theater Sets ‘Nutcracker’ Casting
text: It’s never too early to start dreaming of sugarplums. Casting has been announced for American Ballet Theater’s new production of “The Nutcracker” with choreography by Alexei Ratmansky. The principal dancers Gillian Murphy and David Hallberg will lead the world premiere on Dec. 23 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the roles of Clara and the Nutcracker Prince. Veronika Part and Marcelo Gomes will take on the leads during a preview performance on the evening of Dec. 22. Additional lead casting during the two-week engagement includes Yuriko Kajiya and Daniil Simkin, Paloma Herrera and Cory Stearns, and Xiomara Reyes and Herman Cornejo. The production features scenery and costumes by Richard Hudson and lighting by Jennifer Tipton. Tickets go on sale Wednesday.

headline: New York Pizza Enters a Golden Age
text: NEW YORK’S pizza moment is stretching into a pizza era. The wood-burning ovens and rock-star pizzaioli that seemed exotic not long ago are becoming familiar. A blistered, bubbling 12-inch Naples-style pizza, once a hard-to-find pleasure, is almost routine.

headline: Children’s Day at the Four Seasons
text: “This is a pretty good view,” Ethan Royce allowed as he surveyed the thriving lunch crowd from the terrace of the Pool Room at the Four Seasons and toyed with a forkful of the $21 agnolotti stuffed with organic chicken in Parmesan broth. Nothing unusual in that  save for his age, which is 8.

headline: Their Daily Bread Is a Local Call Away
text: SKOWHEGAN, Me.

headline: A School Fight Over Chocolate Milk

headline: In the Greenmarkets, Think Small and Sweet
text: Among the dizzying array of heirloom tomatoes in shiny red, gold, green, purple and pink at the Greenmarket, it’s easy to miss a few boxes of shy little butter-yellow ones, the size of plums. Some are lightly blushing and all have delicately fuzzy skin. That’s why they are called garden peach tomatoes; one bite of their rich, balanced sweetness and you know why the tomato is a fruit. Quarter them on a platter or in a salad so the unusual skin can be seen.

headline: ‘Gorgeous Vegetables’
text: A bit of bacon sneaks into a recipe or two, and there are eggs and cheese aplenty, but meat and fish are not missed in the bright, well-composed and mostly uncomplicated recipes in the aptly titled “Gorgeous Vegetables” by Annie Bell, an English writer.

headline: The Soulful Side of Bordeaux
text: ST.-JULIEN-BEYCHEVELLE, France

headline: Blue Smoke Opens a Bakery
text: Pecan pie and other appropriate confections for barbecue have been on the menu at Blue Smoke from the beginning. Now, the restaurant has opened a bakery near the entrance where many creations from the pastry chef, Jennifer Giblin, left, are sold retail. Straightforward corn bread offers a little kick, banana cream pie is ultra-custardy, and pecan pie is not cloying. Cupcakes, triple-layer chocolate cake, chocolate chip cookies and cakey brownies are usually available, too. Tender, fragrant raisin-fennel bread with a brioche texture is less typical but inviting, and leftovers can be recycled into uncommon French toast.

headline: Bordeaux’s More Humble Winemakers
text: Jean-François Fillastre epitomizes the traditional French vigneron, one who tends the vines and makes the wines — a rarity for the region.

text: Warning: if you haven’t yet watched the “Lost” finale, this interview will surely spoil it for you.

text: Twitter is getting more serious about making money.

headline: Democrats Look to Paint Buck as Extremist
text: The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee has a pretty simple message it’s trying to get across to Colorado voters: Ken Buck, the Republican nominee for Senate in their state, has some extreme beliefs.

headline: Random House Wins Battle for E-Book Rights
text: An e-book battle between Random House and the Wylie Agency appears to have ended.

headline: Shop Speaking Tevye’s Language Needs Rich Man’s Aid
text: Every few months news seems to arrive of another nail in the coffin of Yiddish  the death of another poet or actress, the shuttering of another socialist or anarchist office, the failure of a century-old literary magazine to publish for yet another year.

headline: Some Doubt if Any King Is Still Fit for Sweden
text: STOCKHOLM — Two dozen members of an association to abolish the monarchy were settled around a table in a spacious apartment in the north end of the capital when someone in the back of the room muttered, “Two hundred years since the French Revolution, and still we have a king.”

headline: With New Products, Nissan Plays Up Innovation Angle
text: EIGHT years after urging consumers to “Shift” their buying behavior when it comes to cars, trucks and minivans, Nissan North America is changing brand themes.

headline: In the Shadow of a Palace
text: A four-bedroom duplex, in a four-story building that was renovated from top to bottom, is a hideaway from the city of Versailles.

headline: In Versailles, a House With a Famous Neighbor
text: VERSAILLES, FRANCE  Unlike its neighbor on the same road, the Palace of Versailles, No. 37, avenue de Paris, hidden behind a humble green door, is no attention seeker, at least from the outside.

headline: Chinese Company in Talks on South Africa Rail Project
text: The China Railway Group, a construction company, said Tuesday it was in talks with South Africa’s government for a $30 billion high-speed rail project between Johannesburg and the eastern port city of Durban.

headline: To Catch Cairo Overflow, 2 Megacities Rise in Sand
text: 6 OCTOBER CITY, Egypt  The highway west out of Cairo used to promise relief from the city’s chaos. Past the great pyramids of Giza and a final spasm of traffic, the open desert beckoned, 100 barren miles to the northwest to reach the Mediterranean.

headline: Edward Kean, Chief Writer of ‘Howdy Doody,’ Dies at 85
text: In the days when television sets were rare and children gathered each afternoon at the neighborhood house in which one of those big, boxy black-and-white sets stood, “The Howdy Doody Show” was one of the biggest draws, and a blessing for mothers making dinner.

headline: Jets Settle on Benchmark Extension With Mangold, but Not With Revis
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Early Tuesday afternoon, Nick Mangold stood on the sideline at Jets headquarters, his rare and partial absence from practice authorized by none other than Coach Rex Ryan. Mangold, though, was not waiting for an injury to heal or a different drill to start.

headline: Opening Ceremony Reinvents the Fashion Wheel
text: I INCREASINGLY admire the curatorial talents of certain people who, blessed with arcane knowledge and enviable taste, are able to assemble a bunch of unrelated stuff beneath a sure-eyed, all-encompassing ethos, and create a little world that is more than the sum of its parts. It’s a kind of visual bartending — an understanding of how to balance the alchemical tensions and interplays within a vocabulary of distilled spirits, and mix a rare and intoxicating mood.

headline: A Choice of Two Cancer Screenings
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Cowher, Coaching Was Never the Priority
text: For more than three years, Bill Cowher has resisted the impulse to return to the sideline. He had not lost his fire so much as he had started a new life that did not make finding the next coaching job an urgent priority.

headline: U.S. Rejected Hen Vaccine Despite British Success
text: Faced with a crisis more than a decade ago in which thousands of people were sickened from salmonella in infected eggs, farmers in Britain began vaccinating their hens against the bacteria. That simple but decisive step virtually wiped out the health threat.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Apple Said to Seek Show-Rental Deal
text: Apple, which is widely expected to announce a revamped product for television sets next month, is pressing the television networks to rent their TV series through its iTunes service for as little as 99 cents an episode.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Stem Cell Biology and Its Complications
text: The renewed debate over embryonic stem cells highlights the advances and complications that have arisen in the field since its controversial beginnings.

headline: Egg Recall Exposes Flaws in Nation’s Food Safety System
text: Federal investigators have descended on Iowa to try to figure out the cause of a salmonella outbreak that may have sickened thousands of people and led to the recall of a half billion eggs.

headline: Britain: Daughter Is Born to Prime Minister and Wife
text: Prime Minister David Cameron’s wife, Samantha Cameron, gave birth to the couple’s fourth child, a daughter, on Tuesday at the Royal Cornwall Hospital, near where the family is vacationing. The prime minister, left, said they had not decided on a name for the baby, whose birth had been expected next month. After experiencing contractions, Mrs. Cameron went to the hospital around 8 a.m., and the baby, weighing just over six pounds, was delivered around noon by Caesarean section. Mr. Cameron’s office said he would take some paternity leave. British men may take two weeks off in the 12 months after a child is born. In 2000, Prime Minister Tony Blair and his wife, Cherie, had their fourth child, the first born to a serving prime minister in more than 150 years.

headline: Israel: Arabic to Be Taught to Fifth-Graders
text: The study of Arabic will be compulsory for fifth-grade students in Jewish public schools in Northern Israel under a pilot project starting in September, an Israeli Ministry of Education official said Tuesday. Arabic is already compulsory from seventh to ninth grade in Jewish schools throughout the country, after which it is elective. The program will begin with about 50 Arab teachers, and could expand depending upon its success and the availability of teachers, said Shlomo Alon, the ministry’s chief supervisor for Arabic language. The program is a way for students and teachers “to look at the other and to share views about life, customs and culture,” Mr. Alon said. About half the students in northern Israel are Arab, and the study of Hebrew is mandatory in Arab schools.

headline: Housing Market Plunged in July, Fueling Anxiety
text: Americans’ long infatuation with owning a home, which even the economic collapse of 2008 could not kill, shuddered and stalled last month.

headline: At West Point, Hidden Gay Cadets Put in Spotlight
text: WEST POINT, N.Y.  Code words, secret societies, covert meetings, fake identities: these are tools that a certain set of cadets learn here at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

headline: Wariness in the Push for a Longer N.F.L. Season
text: N.F.L. owners are not expected to vote to formally embrace an 18-game regular season when they meet in Atlanta on Wednesday. While owners are still almost certain to push forward with their pursuit of 18 games in labor negotiations with the players union, there is sentiment among at least a few of them that approval is not the slam dunk it once appeared to be.

headline: Japan Shifting Views on Managers
text: Just three seasons ago, the Land of the Rising Sun seemed to be the land of opportunity for American baseball managers. Trey Hillman, Bobby Valentine, Marty Brown and Terry Collins piloted four of Nippon Professional Baseball’s 12 teams.

headline: Passing on Return to Boston, Damon to Stay in Detroit
text: There will be no reunion of Johnny Damon and the Boston Red Sox. Damon, the Detroit Tigers outfielder who helped the Red Sox win the 2004 World Series, told Detroit reporters Tuesday that he would not approve a trade to Boston.

headline: France: Rights Group Faults Roma Policy
text: The European Commission against Racism and Intolerance on Tuesday joined critics of France’s efforts to deport Roma who overstay their visas and to demolish illegal Roma camps. The commission accused the French government of “stigmatizing Roma migrants” and holding them “collectively responsible for criminal offenses.” On Sunday, Pope Benedict XVI urged French pilgrims “to accept human diversity” and French Cardinal André Vingt-Trois was promised a meeting with the interior minister to discuss the France’s Roma policy, which the government defends as strategy to fight crime and illegal immigration. France says that the problem of the Roma is a European one that must be solved in their home countries.

headline: DirecTV’s N.F.L. Games To Be Online
text: N.F.L. fans who have coveted watching the NFL Sunday Ticket package, which has long been available only on satellite on DirecTV, can buy it starting next month online for $350.

headline: Job Losses Over Drilling Ban Fail to Materialize
text: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration called a halt to virtually all deepwater drilling activity in the Gulf of Mexico after the Deepwater Horizon blowout and fire in April, oil executives, economists and local officials complained that the six-month moratorium would cost thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in lost revenue.

headline: New York Wins Nearly $700 Million for Education
text: New York captured almost $700 million for schools when it was selected Tuesday as one of 10 winners in the federal Race to the Top competition, a victory for state education officials as well as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who had pushed the Legislature to enact changes that helped secure the money.

headline: Insurance Companies Focus Of Probe
text: As the financial reports of a sixth team, the Texas Rangers, were leaked to Deadspin.com on Tuesday, Major League Baseball was focusing its investigation on insurance companies that do business with clubs, said two baseball executives who were not authorized to speak publicly.

headline: A Forgotten Fight for Suffrage
text: Chicago

headline: Racial Patterns Are Found in Recent School Budget Elections
text: Voters in most school districts in New York State passed proposed budgets this year, but in some of the places where the budgets failed or where they were narrowly approved, a revealing correlation emerged.

headline: Mechanic for Sheriff in Inquiry Is Charged
text: The director of the Passaic County Sheriff’s Department motor pool, which has been the focus of a criminal investigation into whether mechanics there repaired vehicles for a former sheriff’s political donors, was charged Tuesday with stealing $100,000 in drug money and a sport-utility vehicle engine, the authorities in New Jersey said.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Marlins Get More for Their Money Than Mets
text: You have to wonder if the Mets, deep down, are more frustrated or inspired by the example of the Florida Marlins. Year after year, the Marlins stay competitive in the National League East, getting extraordinary value for what they spend. The Mets win at about the same rate while spending far, far more.

headline: Lottery Numbers
When an Arab Enclave Thrived Downtown
text: Conjure, for a moment, a place just steps from City Hall but a world apart. Salaam.

headline: The Two Plaintiffs at Center of the Ban on Stem Cell Use
text: The two researchers whose claims of injury led to a judge’s decision Monday to issue a  preliminary injunction banning federal funding for the research using human embryonic stem cells, have a history of disputes with colleagues as well as ethical objections to embryonic stem cell research.

headline: Led by Germany, Manufacturing in Europe Is Stronger Than Expected
text: PARIS  Euro zone manufacturers met with unexpectedly strong demand for industrial goods in June, a report showed Tuesday, suggesting Germany’s export-driven factories will continue to strengthen output  even as the American economy slows and fears linger that the debt crisis could return to hamper the Continent’s recovery.

headline: AARP Says Brand-Name Drug Prices Up 8% in 2009
text: A new report on retail prices of brand-name drugs shows the 217 products most used by older Americans increased by an average of 8.3 percent during 2009, the largest increase in years, even as inflation was negative.

headline: A Relieved Chile Braces for a Long Mine Rescue
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile  Through a skinny borehole from the surface, the 33 miners trapped more than 2,000 feet below the parched earth here have gotten a gel-like substance to keep them alive, tiny lights to illuminate the darkness and encouraging notes from their families waiting above.

headline: A Gulf Science Blackout
text: Baton Rouge, La.

headline: The Customer Always Comes Last
text: The credit card industry is working hard to subvert the Credit Card Act of 2009, which banned many of the industry’s most predatory practices. The Federal Reserve Board, which oversees and coddles this industry, needs to ensure that consumers get the protections Congress intended, and Americans so clearly need.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,407 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,227 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: N.Y. Political Leaders’ Rift Grows on Islam Center
text: Even as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg firmly rejected calls for the relocation of a planned Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero, signs of growing division emerged on Tuesday within the political establishment in Manhattan, as the powerful speaker of the State Assembly expressed forceful opposition to the plan.

headline: Babble
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE NOTES — Records and technical achievements are a part of crosswords, to varying degrees of relevance. Some people couldn’t care less. In today’s puzzle, however, an astounding grid is the theme itself — every answer in the puzzle contains at least one B! The result is just terrific.

headline: Plane Crashes in Northeastern China, Killing 42
text: BEIJING  Forty-two people were killed and 54 others were injured Tuesday night when a Chinese jet crashed and burst into flames while trying to land on a fog-shrouded runaway in northeastern China, state media reported.

headline: As Mediocrity Rules, Takahashi Is Exception
text: To be known as “an interesting .500 team” is faint praise, but that is the reality of the Mets this season.

headline: Wrong Direction on Stem Cells
text: In a huge overreach, a federal judge has decided that the legal interpretation that has governed federal support of embryonic stem cell research for more than a decade is invalid. If the ruling stands, it will be a serious blow to medical research.

headline: New York’s Iconic Skyline
text: In the drowsy month of August no less, New York’s City Council is poised to make one of the most important decisions in years about Manhattan’s skyline. Council members will decide today whether to allow developers to build a skyscraper almost as tall as the Empire State Building  900 feet west on the site of the current Hotel Pennsylvania, on Seventh Avenue. For many people looking from the western part of Manhattan and New Jersey, the iconic tower would no longer be visible.

headline: Off to College
text: How is it that children suddenly know things? One minute they’re adrift in infancy. Then they acquire a private expertise, a growing awareness of their inner lives and the shifting labyrinth of their family and school. Then, abruptly, they know things about the wider world around them  know them passionately, surprised that everyone doesn’t know them, especially their parents. After that, there’s only one thing to do: send the children off to college.

headline: Artist’s Work, Out of Attics, Goes to Walls of a Museum
text: DENVER  Charles Deas is the kind of artist who fuels the fantasies of people watching “Antiques Roadshow.” His story makes you want to go take another look at those musty old paintings in grandma’s den.

headline: Searching for a Lost Artist
text: Popular in the mid-1800s, the paintings of Charles Deas have achieved new popularity, and the artist’s madness is part of their mystique.

headline: Trial in Synagogue Bomb Case Opens With Clashing Images of 4 Defendants
text: In opening arguments on Tuesday in the trial of four men accused of trying to blow up Bronx synagogues and shoot down military planes in May 2009, there seemed to be little disagreement that the defendants were offered something for joining the plot.

headline: For This Week, Nova Is in, Vazquez Is out as Starter
text: TORONTO  By pitching so well Monday night, Ivan Nova gave the Yankees options. He impressed them enough to merit another start, a decision that has consequences for Javier Vazquez, whose rotation spot Nova will take, and Phil Hughes, who is gradually approaching his innings limit.

headline: Steal This Movie, Too
text: While Washington is consumed with whether our president is secretly a Muslim, or born abroad, possibly in outer space, I’d like to talk about some good news. But to see it, you have to stand on your head.

headline: Yankees Hit Five Homers, and Moseley Earns Victory
text: TORONTO  Out beyond the left-field fence, Brian Tallet was warming up for the Blue Jays in the third inning when a ball rocketed over his head and into the stands. He got in a few more pitches before another ball headed his way, landing in the bleachers.

headline: Hazards of Long Confinement
text: Two mine safety experts assess problems that could arise for the trapped miners in Chile.

headline: Even at Commuter Schools, Dorm Life Beckons
text: Ken Meyer and Carmine Fiore shook hands in the kitchen as their daughters, Sabina Meyer and Stephanie Fiore, pondered logistical problems on opposite ends of Room 227 on Monday, which was moving-in day at the sole dormitory at Queens College. Stephanie Fiore, for example, wondered where to store her many pairs of shoes, since her closet already seemed too small to fit all her clothes.

headline: A Helping of Mexican Culture (Between Meals)
text: National parks, check. Ruins, check. Beaches, check. Mountains, check. Waterfalls, jungle cruise, homestays, check. Eating insects, check.

headline: Jets Players React to Brady’s Comment
text: Kristian R. Dyer covers the N.F.L. for FoxSports.com and is the publisher of the subscription site GreenAndWhiteReport.com, which covers the Jets. He can be reached at KristianRDyer@yahoo.com and followed at twitter.com/kdyer1012.

headline: California: Colleges Cut Kaplan Tie
text: Nine months after Kaplan University signed an agreement with the chancellor of the overcrowded California community colleges, opening the way for students shut out of classes at their own campus to take an online version at Kaplan, the chancellor has canceled the agreement. In an Aug. 17 letter calling off the November memorandum of understanding, Barry Russell, the vice chancellor of academic affairs, cited concerns that it could have a “negative effect” on students who transferred to a California State University or University of California campus and could not get credit for the Kaplan course. Under the agreement, which was apparently never used at any of the state’s 112 community colleges, Kaplan was offering students a 42 percent discount, making the cost about $216 a credit, compared with $26 a credit at the community colleges.

headline: BHP Billiton’s Bet on Potash
text: The price of potash is all-important to BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company. BHP’s $39 billion hostile bid for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan is essentially a bet on demand for the commodity.

headline: Benjamin Kaplan, Crucial Figure in Nazi Trials, Dies at 99
text: Judge Benjamin Kaplan, who as an Army officer helped craft the indictment of the Nazi war criminals who were tried at Nuremberg, and who later became a Harvard law professor and served nine years on the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, died Aug. 18 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 99.

headline: Castillo Stars, if Briefly, With Game-Ending Hit
text: After a last-swing victory with two outs in the bottom of the ninth inning, it is common for the player who delivered the game-winning hit to linger in the clubhouse, slowly change into street clothes, joke with his teammates and chat amiably with reporters.

headline: Phys Ed: Does Music Make You Exercise Harder?
text: For a study published last year, British researchers asked 12 healthy male college students to ride stationary bicycles while listening to music that, as the researchers primly wrote, “reflected current popular taste among the undergraduate population.” Each of the six songs chosen differed somewhat in tempo from the others.

headline: Christoph Schlingensief, Artistic Provocateur, Dies at 49
text: Christoph Schlingensief, a filmmaker, theater director and political gadfly who made it his life’s work to upset German complacency and the status quo, died on Saturday in Berlin. He was 49.

headline: William Saxbe, Attorney General During Watergate Inquiry, Dies at 94
text: William B. Saxbe, a former United States senator from Ohio who was appointed as President Richard M. Nixon’s fourth attorney general after the infamous “Saturday Night Massacre,” died Tuesday at his home in Mechanicsburg, Ohio. He was 94 and had been in failing health for some time, said his son Charles R. Saxbe.

headline: Word of the Day | ambulatory
text: ambulatory •\ˈam-byə-lə-ˌtȯr-e\• adjective

headline: Establishment Candidates Prevail
text: Incumbent and establishment candidates beat back strong primary challenges, for the most part, on Tuesday in contests in five states across the country.

headline: News Quiz | August 25, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Sports Replay, Aug. 24
text: A look at the day in sports, from the Youth Olymipcs in Singapore to the Little League World Series in Pennsylvania.

headline: Contender for Cairn India Hesitates
text: State-run Oil and Natural Gas Corporation is divided over making a counterbid for Cairn India, which is the target of a $9.6 billion takeover offer by Vedanta, The Business Standard reported on Wednesday.

headline: Corporate Debt ‘Wall of Maturity’ Crumbling
text: Financial markets are knocking down a wall of debt maturity that has endangered the U.S. economic recovery and threatened to push more companies into bankruptcy, according to an investment firm report on Tuesday, Reuters reported.

headline: In Alaska, Murkowski Trails Tea Party Upstart
text: In the final days before Alaska’s Republican Senate primary, longtime Republicans were bombarded with pieces of direct mail and automated phone calls urging them to oust yet another member of their party’s jilted establishment, Senator Lisa Murkowski.

headline: A Travel Guide From the Jim Crow Era
text: WHAT was the “Green Book”?WHAT were Jim Crow laws?

text: Today’s word, in association with the towering Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Yen Swells and Japanese Market Sags
text: The Japanese stock market sagged again Wednesday, and the yen remained strong, prompting intensified rhetoric — but still no action — from policy makers eager to stem the currency’s rise.

headline: How Important Do You Think It Is to ‘Build Character’?
text: Columnist David Brooks writes that few of us today examine our “mental character” or consider our own weaknesses the way people did in the past. Another recent Opinion page piece by a minister noted that congregations today seem more interested in entertainment than in being pushed spiritually to “resist their lowest impulses and adopt higher, more compassionate ways.” Do you think people today in general need to think more about their own failings and weaknesses in order to become better, stronger and more compassionate? How much of a role does this kind of reflection play in your own life?

headline: Goldman’s ‘Conspiracy’ a Best-Seller in China
text: Goldman Sachs, burned in the United States for its role in the financial crisis, is now getting hammered in the world’s No. 2 economy with a sensationalist book accusing the investment bank of trying to destroy China, The Associated Press reports.

headline: 2 Spaniards Charged for BHP-Potash Inside Trades
text: Federal regulators have charged two Spanish investors with trading on secret information about BHP Billiton‘s bid to acquire Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, The Associated Press reports.

headline: 800,000 Pakistanis Cut Off From Road
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  More rain threatened Pakistan on Wednesday as aid workers pleaded for more help and additional helicopters to reach hundreds of thousands of people isolated by record floods.

headline: Moon Affiliate in Deal for Washington Times
text: The owner of The Washington Times has reached a preliminary agreement to sell the paper to a company affiliated with the Unification Church, the executive editor said late Tuesday.

headline: Five New Y Combinator Start-Ups to Watch
text: From VentureBeat:

headline: Angel Franco and a Hostage Taking
text: “Hostage situation.”

headline: Elevation to Invest $100 Million in Pandora?
text: Elevation Partners, which counts U2‘s Bono among its principals, has reportedly signed a letter of intent to pick up a significant amount of shares in a “leading online music company” from an early investor.

headline: Buffett and Diller to Speak at Big Sky Summit
text: Senator Max Baucus, senior Democrat of Montana, said investor and philanthropist Warren Buffett is scheduled to participate in the Montana Economic Development Summit in Butte next month live via video, The Associated Press reported.

headline: BHP’s Sweetener May Be Restricted by British Rules
text: BHP Billiton‘s hostile $38.6 billion bid for fertilizer group Potash Corporation of Sasketchewan faces a potential obstacle — formal approval by its own shareholders — if it sweetens its offer by more than 22 percent, Reuters reported.

headline: Jimmy Carter Tries to Free American in North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Former President Jimmy Carter arrived in North Korea on Wednesday to seek the release of an American held by the North, its state-run media reported.

headline: Rubio’s Completes Sale to Buyout Shop
text: Rubio’s Restaurants said Tuesday that its purchase by private investment firm Mill Road Capital has been completed.

headline: Pre-Offering Decision on A.I.A. Expected Next Week
text: American International Group is expected to decide by early next week whether to enter formal negotiations with strategic investors for its Asian life insurance business, A.I.A., sources familiar with the process told Reuters on Wednesday.

headline: UBS to Create Chinese M.&A. Team Under Partnow
text: UBS will create a mergers and acquisitions team in China headed by Philip Partnow, after the country’s share of global transactions more than doubled in the last three years, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Pension Funds Drawing Up List of Targets
text: Shareholders may soon get more power to shake up corporate boardrooms in the United States after the financial crisis exposed glaring weaknesses in how companies were managed, Reuters reports.

headline: Finding Fireflies During the Hong Kong Summer
text: Late summer in Hong Kong is the height of firefly season, and enthusiasts can hike one of Hong Kong’s many trails, just as dusk creeps in, and watch for the lovebugs to start blinking their affections in the gloom.

headline: The Costs of War
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Afghan Police Trainee Kills Two Spanish Soldiers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  An argument at a police training camp on Wednesday ended in gunfire when an Afghan trainee shot and killed two Spanish police officers and an interpreter before he was fatally shot himself, Afghan and NATO authorities said.

headline: Coordinated Attacks Strike 13 Iraqi Cities
text: BAGHDAD  Insurgents unleashed a wave of coordinated attacks across Iraq on Wednesday in a demonstration of their ability to strike at will, offering their counterpoint to American aspirations of bringing the war in Iraq “to a responsible end.”

headline: Investors Value Facebook at Up to $33.7 Billion
text: Chomping at the bit for a Facebook I.P.O., investors are buying common stock as high as $76 a share, giving the company a value of as much as $33.7 billion based on secondary market transactions, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Basis Argues for Goldman Suit to Proceed
text: Basis Capital, an Australian hedge fund, urged a New York judge to allow its $1 billion lawsuit over the marketing of credit default swaps by Goldman Sachs to proceed, calling Goldman’s request for a dismissal a “distraction,” Bloomberg News reported.

headline: The Sinking of Quicksand
text: Today’s idea: Quicksand was a major peril of 1960s movies, but it seems to have receded in the popular imagination. Can we blame Vietnam?

headline: BHP Billiton, Chasing Potash, Says Profit Soars
text: BHP Billiton, the mining company that has made a hostile takeover bid for Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan, said Wednesday that full-year profit more than doubled because of higher raw material prices, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

headline: Irish Debt Downgraded on Eve of Bond Sale
text: Standard & Poor’s has downgraded the sovereign debt of Ireland with a negative outlook, citing the unexpectedly high costs of supporting the country’s banks — a move that could make it more expensive for Dublin to borrow.

headline: Dubai World Said Set for $19.4 Billion Sell-off
text: Dubai World plans to sell its prized assets over a period of eight years to generate as much as $19.4 billion to pay off creditors burned by its overambitious expansion, according to a restructuring document obtained by Reuters on Wednesday.

headline: Greed Not So Good, Douglas’s Lawyer Says
text: In court on Tuesday, Academy Award-winner Michael Douglas and his ex-wife’s lawyers traded accusations of greed while fighting over earnings from the actor’s reprise as the avaricious Gordon Gekko in “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps.”

headline: Can an 18-Game Season Be Stopped?
text: The N.F.L. keeps pushing an 18-game regular season. And players keep pushing back.

headline: Alibaba Acquires Auctiva, a California Tech Firm
text: The Chinese e-commerce firm Alibaba Group has announced the acquisition of Auctiva, a California tech company which develops tools for eBay retailers, The Silicon Valley Mercury News reported.

headline: Standard Chartered Teaches Rich Kids M.&A.
text: Standard Chartered has introduced a trainee program for the children of private-banking clients, joining bigger rivals including Citigroup and UBS in reaching out to Asia’s next generation of millionaires, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Rosecrans Baldwin
text: Rosecrans Baldwin’s novel, “You Lost Me There,” was reviewed in last Sunday’s Book Review.

headline: How I Saved My Company: Vital Wave Consulting
text: Vital Wave Consulting is a strategy consulting firm that helps technology companies find business in emerging markets. It is based in Palo Alto, Calif., and its clients have included Microsoft, Intel and the World Bank. But when the recession hit, its revenue fell by more than 50 percent.

headline: Stipple Seeks to Tag the Web’s Images
text: Stipple, a San Francisco-based start-up, is introducing a new service on Wednesday that allows online publishers to add tags to particular parts of an image with information about its contents and related links.

headline: Lloyd’s Aims to Void Stanford’s Insurance Policy
text: The jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford and three of his former executives have racked up millions of dollars in legal fees which have thus far been covered by an insurance policy. But Lloyd’s of London is now trying to turn off the financial spigot by having the policy voided.

headline: Wall Street Overcomes Latest Economic Data
text: Stocks posted small gains Wednesday, with the major indexes advancing for the first time in five sessions, despite new reports of weakness in the housing and manufacturing industries.

headline: Trial Date Set for WaMu Investor Lawsuit
text: Washington Mutual must face a trial over who owns $4 billion in low-ranking debt before the bank can end its bankruptcy, Bloomberg News reported. A United States bankruptcy judge has scheduled a trial of the investor lawsuit for Nov. 1.

headline: SnapSchott: Missing Parrot
text: Co-vocabularists may be interested to learn a little about the leafy north London suburb of Highgate – it’s the kind of neighborhood where some people lose African Grey parrots and others correct their spelling.

headline: With 2011 Buick Regal GS, a Return to Manual
text: As we lament the disappearance of manual transmissions, Buick is actually coming out with its first manual in 22 years with the upcoming 2011 Buick Regal GS.

headline: Stop Speech Recognition From Saying ‘Huh?’
text: The number of phones using sophisticated speech recognition software to let you speak commands and dictate messages is growing quickly. That would imply that the software itself works better than ever, but around the fifth time you shout “Call BOB!” at your phone and it responds with “Calling Doris,” you might wonder. There are tips that will improve your speech recognition results, whether on your phone, an automated customer service system or desktop dictation software.

headline: Color Comes to an E-Reader
text: Dedicated e-readers, like Amazon’s Kindle, Barnes & Noble’s Nook and Sony’s Reader, have one thing in common: they all use black-and-white screen technology from a company called E Ink.

headline: Brevan Said to Pay Partners $133 Million Last Year
text: Brevan Howard Asset Management, Europe’s biggest hedge-fund manager, paid 45 partners a total of £86.1 million ($133 million) for the eight months to March 2009, The Times of London reported, citing accounts filed last week at Companies House.

headline: Chinese Airport Unsafe Before Crash
text: BEIJING  China’s largest passenger airline deemed nighttime landings at a new airport in northeastern China unsafe a year before a Henan Airlines jet crashed there on Tuesday night, killing 42 passengers and injuring 54 others.

headline: Double Vision: Shaq and Bieber
text: We are told by the good people at ABC that this is a photograph of Shaquille O’Neal and Justin Bieber to promote Tuesday’s finale of Mr. O’Neal’s reality series, “Shaq Vs.,” in which he will face-off against that tiny tycoon of teen pop. We’ll add additional caption information as soon as we can determine who is who.

headline: A Rainy Presidential Vacation
text: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass. – On Day 6 of President Obama’s summer sojourn on Martha’s Vineyard, it is Day 4 of wind-whipped rain here. So what if the clouds have followed him here, metaphorically and figuratively? The First Vacationer says he is a happy camper.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: Questions about birthday dinners flooded the mailbox while your faithful correspondent was on vacation these last few weeks. And there was one inquiry about entertaining a first-time visitor to the island of Manhattan. I did my best to answer their needs. Send me your questions!

headline: New-Home Sales Declined Sharply Last Month
text: Sales of new homes declined unexpectedly in July, the government said on Wednesday in the second report this week that showed that the housing sector stalled last month.

headline: Lohan Is Released From Rehab
text: Lindsay Lohan was released from a Los Angeles rehabilitation center on Tuesday, making her a free woman less than two months after she was sentenced to 90 days in jail for violating the terms of her probation, Reuters reported. Ms. Lohan, the 24-year-old actress and “Mean Girls” star, served 22 days at the rehabilitation facility at Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center after her release on Aug. 2 from the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif., where she arrived on July 20 to begin serving her jail term. Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court sentenced Ms. Lohan on July 6 after the actress missed a probation hearing in May stemming from her 2007 arrests on charges of drunken driving and drug possession.

headline: Once, an Arab Enclave Thrived Downtown
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: How Power Has Transformed Women’s Tennis
text: ON THE DAY BEFORE Wimbledon started, when the club grounds had not yet opened to the public, Justine Henin, the diminutive Belgian tennis great, stepped onto practice court No. 3, then still an emerald patch of unspoiled grass. The sun had just come out after several cloudy days, and all around, players, their coaches and families, yammering in various languages, exchanged greetings like veteran bunkmates on the first day at summer camp. Not Henin. Having unretired last year as suddenly as she quit 16 months earlier — saying she had got all she wanted from the sport — she remained absorbed with her coach, Carlos Rodriguez, in their warm-up routine.

headline: Quote Unquote | The World According to Marc
text: Marc Jacobs philosophizes in the Telegraph. So which cliché explains his hair transplant?

headline: His Back Pages Keep Turning: Collection of Dylan Rarities Coming in the Fall
text: Bob Dylan may be too busy these days with his painting career and his year-round touring to create an album of new material — even a record of cherished holiday songs — but that won’t keep a new Dylan album from hitting shelves in the fall, this one comprising material from the earlier end of his 50-year career. A new entry in Mr. Dylan’s Bootleg Series, “The Witmark Demos” — M. Witmark & Sons was one of his early publishers — will be released by Columbia Records on Oct. 19, Billboard reported. It consists of 47 demo recordings that Mr. Dylan made from 1962 to 1964. Among the tracks that will appear on this two-CD release are early versions of future standards like “Blowin’ in the Wind” and “The Times They Are A-Changin’, ”  as well as songs that have not been previously released in any version, like “Guess I’m Doing Fine,” “Long Ago, Far Away” and “Ballad for a Friend.” Columbia will also release new vinyl versions of Mr. Dylan’s first eight albums, taken from their original mono mixes, on Oct. 19.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — A double dip: It’s fun at the swimming hole, forbidden at the dinner table, and likely in Europe, Joseph Stiglitz says, warning for the umpteenth time that in recession, austerity is simply a way of digging yourself deeper.

headline: The Early Word: Mixed Results
text: Some Washington veterans and establishment candidates pulled off hard-won victories in Tuesday’s primaries and now move on to fight for November wins.

headline: BP Oil Spill Has Little Impact on Global Drilling
text: As John Broder and I report in Wednesday’s Times, the economic impact of the Obama administration’s moratorium on new deepwater drilling since the BP accident has been far less than many people predicted.

headline: CollegeOnly, a Social Network Just for the University Set
text: When Facebook arrived at my university near the end of my fourth year, I remember feeling a huge wave of relief.

headline: Nonsultation
text: A specious public consultation on decisions that have already been made.

headline: I’m Back
text: Well, it’s been a crazy, crazy summer. I just wrapped up a 110-day shoot for a PBS “Nova” mini-series that will air this winter. I wrote a children’s book and a computer book. I traveled with my kids for a couple of weeks.

headline: Android or Windows Tablet? Viewsonic Chooses Both
text: Confession: My laptop has a second operating system that I’ve never used. It’s some flavor of Linux that’s supposed to provide instant access to the Web and e-mail, but I’d rather just endure a 45-second start-up and have the full power of Windows 7 at my disposal.

headline: Kim Clijsters | Belgium
text: See the top tennis player in slow motion.

headline: Ghostly Hotel Fill-In
text: Fill in the blanks in this article about a hotel in Arizona many swear is haunted. Use your own words and phrases, or choose from a list of words that were removed.

text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 12, is Texas. You can find a larger Texas preview here.

headline: Murkowski on the Ropes in Alaska Senate Primary
text: Is another political surprise coming from Alaska?

headline: What Has Dick Fuld Been Up To?
text: September is quickly approaching, and with it, the second anniversary of the collapse of Lehman Brothers, the epochal event of the crisis that nearly brought down the global financial system. Since the meltdown, little has been heard from Richard S. Fuld Jr., Lehman’s former chief executive.

headline: Keep Facebook Places From Driving You Crazy
text: Facebook’s new location-based mobile service, Facebook Places, lets you tell your friends where you are and, if they choose to tell you, see where they are. You can also see what friends have posted about specific locations, like a restaurant.

headline: Profile of the Winemaker Jean-François Fillastre
text: I’ve met many exceptional people in the wine business over the years, but  Jean-François Fillastre is one of the most extraordinary. Mr. Fillastre is the proprietor of Domaine du Jaugaret, a tiny producer of St. Julien, and the centerpiece of my column on the vigneron side of Bordeaux.

headline: Introducing ‘Open House': Talking About Power in Women’s Tennis
text: Gerald Marzorati, editor of The New York Times Magazine, enlisted his colleague Michael Kimmelman to go to Wimbledon and report on the state of professional women’s tennis. Here’s their recent conversation about his piece, “How Power Has Transformed Women’s Tennis.”

headline: The WSJ Changes Its Line
text: This morning, in its “Vital Signs” feature (not online, for some reason), the WSJ notes the plunge in interest rates, and says:

headline: FIFA Says North Korean Players Did Not Face Retribution for World Cup Performance
text: SEOUL — FIFA, the governing body of soccer, said on Wednesday that it has dismissed allegations that North Korea’s coach and players were punished for losing all three of their games at this year’s World Cup in South Africa.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Industry’s Response to the Credit Card Act
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Late for Pro-Am, Furyk Is Ineligible for the Barclays
text: 11:57 a.m. | Updated

headline: Tax Charges Prevent ‘Crocodile Dundee’ Star From Leaving Australia
text: Paul Hogan, the Australian actor whose “Crocodile Dundee” movies and tourism ads for American television were surely responsible for the sale of thousands of shrimp and countless accompanying barbies, is not having a good day, mate. A lawyer for Mr. Hogan said the actor was being prevented from leaving Australia until he pays millions of dollars in back taxes, Reuters reported. Mr. Hogan, who is based in the United States, is being investigated by Australian officials who say he put film royalties in offshore tax havens, a charge he denies. His lawyer, Andrew Robinson, said in a statement that Mr. Hogan was served with a departure prohibition order by the Australian Taxation Office when he traveled to Sydney last week for his mother’s funeral. “The process of detaining Paul in Australia away from his wife and child in Los Angeles has devastated Paul,” Mr. Robinson wrote in a statement. A spokesman for the Australian Taxation Office told Reuters that he was unable to comment on individual taxpayers.

headline: Second Thoughts About Parenting
text: Alison Patton is a divorce lawyer and mediator. She watches marriages unravel. She is more than familiar with “the seven-year itch,” when partners find themselves annoyed with things they used to find endearing and when new realities seem to set in.

headline: A Smooth Operator and Classic-Rock Muscle
text: Games

headline: Welcome (and Welcome Back) to FiveThirtyEight
text: FiveThirtyEight.com premiered on March 7, 2008, three days after Hillary Rodham Clinton won the Democratic presidential primaries in Texas and Ohio — victories that were widely described as giving her momentum in her race for the Democratic nomination. Mrs. Clinton was already well ahead in the polls in the next big primary contest, in Pennsylvania.

headline: The Subprime Mortgage Crisis on Trial
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: There Are Bubbles, And Then There Are Bubbles
text: On the whole, I find it amazing and distressing that fear of new bubbles is playing such a large role in current policy discussion, leading too many prominent economists to recommend raising interest rates in the face of a hugely depressed economy. Even if you believe that excessively low policy rates were a key reason for the housing bubble — which I don’t — the idea that we should be raising rates now brings to mind the old joke about the motorist who runs over a pedestrian, then tries to fix the damage by backing up, and running over the pedestrian a second time.

headline: Letter: An Elegant Hospital
text: To the Editor: The excellent article on the Greenbrier resort in West Virginia, “Nothing Boutique About It” (Aug. 15) by Dwight Garner, made an important omission. The Greenbrier also served as the United States Army’s Ashford General Hospital, from which I was discharged from the Army in February 1946. I arrived after three years of living only in tents, barracks and bombed-out houses and was amazed to end my service in such luxury, with German prisoners of war as servants, fine meals in an elegant dining room, and Sammy Snead as golf pro.

headline: Military Computer Attack Confirmed
text: WASHINGTON — A top Pentagon official has confirmed a previously classified incident that he describes as “the most significant breach of U.S. military computers ever,” a 2008 episode in which a foreign intelligence agent used a flash drive to infect computers, including those used by the Central Command in overseeing combat zones in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Do Migraines Run in Families?
text: Are migraines inherited? How do you distinguish a migraine in a child? These are among the questions posed by readers of the Consults blog.

headline: Man and His Symbols (and Signs, and Public Spaces)
text: Even as rain turns August from sweltering to sopping, the media heat, especially on cable news, still burns bright on the topic of Park51, the proposed Islamic cultural center near ground zero.

headline: Yana Paskova on Henri Cartier-Bresson
text: Yana Paskova, 28, was born in Bulgaria, raised in Chicago and is now based in New York. She has worked across the United States and in Eastern Europe, Russia and Asia. Her work has appeared in The New York Times, Newsweek, The Chicago Tribune and Time Magazine. Amanda Rivkin’s conversation with Ms. Paskova has been edited and condensed.

headline: Another Record Low for Housing
text: New-home sales were at their lowest level in July since the government began keeping track in 1963. This follows a comparably terrible report on Tuesday on existing-home sales.

headline: Now Showing | Hussein Chalayan at Lisson Gallery
text: The more banal aspects of clothing a body have never hampered Hussein Chalayan’s creativity. In fact, he has long been inspired by “disembodiment” — an idea that poses a challenge, perhaps, for the fashion runways but one that is certainly well suited to an art gallery. For “I Am Sad Leyla (Üzgünüm Leyla),” the designer’s solo exhibition at London’s Lisson gallery, which opens Sept. 8, Chalayan has created a sound-art installation that includes audio, film, sculpture, musical notation and yes, even a bit of fashion.

headline: National Journal Hires Major Garrett From Fox News
text: Major Garrett, the chief White House correspondent for Fox News, is quitting his job at the cable news channel after eight years. He is joining National Journal as a Congressional correspondent.

headline: Surprise of a Salesman: Christopher Lloyd
text: WESTON, Vt.  “There are some roles I’ve gotten,” Christopher Lloyd said the other day in his gravelly, jittery, half-mumble of a voice, “that when I get the script, sometimes I ask, ‘Why me?’ It’s not that I object. It’s like, ‘What do they see in me that they want to see in this role?’ ”

headline: Elin Nordegren Ends Silence
text: By the end of the week, you are almost guaranteed to be sick of hearing about Elin Nordegren’s first interview about the divorce from Tiger Woods  People magazine does have a knack for tripping your overkill buzzer even if you never actually pick up the magazine  but before that sets in, you have to give Nordegren credit for mastering public relations, something at which her famously philandering ex-husband failed so spectacularly.

headline: Student Arraigned in Anti-Muslim Stabbing of Cabdriver
text: Click to read the final, fuller version of this article.

headline: This Just In From Montana
text: David Brooks: Gail, nearly every year, the Brooks clan retires in August to some Rocky Mountain locale to mistreat horses, crash mountain bikes and safeguard the cutthroat trout by fishing for them so badly. In years past, we have been to Wyoming and Colorado but this year we returned to what may be my favorite state, Montana. Specifically, the area around Glacier National Park.

headline: Kustom Kills and Hot Rod Thrills Show Celebrates 10th Anniversay
text: Tucked cozily under the Brooklyn Queens Expressway near Union Avenue in Brooklyn, the Kustom Kills and Hot Rod Thrills car show celebrated its 10th anniversary on Saturday. The annual show devoted to pre-1964 rat rods and rust rides is organized by the New York Rumblers Hot Rod and Kustom Car Club, which said this year’s show was the biggest yet.

headline: Dealing With Scarcity
text: Julian Cribb, in his book “The Coming Famine” (which I reviewed today over in Arts), contends that we’ve already seen peak oil – the time when production can do nothing but decline. He then goes on to deduce that since we’ve likely seen peak fertilizer, peak water and peak land as well, we’ve probably seen peak food. This at a time, as we all know, when not only is the world’s population growing but also becoming generally better off – that is, more and more people want to eat like Americans.

headline: A New Way to Shop for Credit Cards
text: If you’re in the market for a new credit card and want to sort through more options than most other  credit card comparison sites offer, NerdWallet.com is worth a look.

headline: New Forecast Shows Democrats Losing 6 to 7 Senate Seats
text: The Democratic majority is in increasing jeopardy in the Senate, according to the latest FiveThirtyEight forecasting model. The Democrats now have an approximately 20 percent chance of losing 10 or more seats in the Senate, according to the model, which would cost them control of the chamber unless Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida, who is running for the Senate as an independent, both wins his race and decides to caucus with them.

headline: Walt Disney Studios Withdraws From Animation Group
text: A running squabble over a cartoon awards banquet boiled over on Tuesday when Walt Disney Studios said it would withdraw from the group that hands out trophies for animation achievement.

headline: TimesCast | August 25, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on new insurgent attacks in Iraq, primary election returns and a look at the group working to shape the Tea Party's political power.

headline: Wave of Attacks Target Iraqi Security Forces
text: Anthony Shadid and Stephen Farrell report from Baghdad on the coordinated assaults against Iraq’s security forces on Wednesday morning. Insurgents unleashed a wave of roadside mines and more than a dozen car bombings across Iraq, killing dozens, toppling a police station in the capital and sowing chaos and confusion among the soldiers and police officers who responded.

headline: Coppola to Receive Thalberg Award
text: Francis Ford Coppola will receive the Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award this year from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, while honorary Oscars will go to the director Jean-Luc Godard, the actor Eli Wallach and the film preservationist Kevin Brownlow, the academy said on Wednesday. The recipients were chosen by the academy’s board of governors on Tuesday evening, and the awards will be handed out at a dinner ceremony in Los Angeles on Nov. 13. Mr. Brownlow is known for his work on films of the silent era. Mr. Godard, whose credits include “Breathless” and “King Lear,” has been a central figure in French film, and Mr. Wallach has appeared in a long string of features, including “The Misfits” and “The Magnificent Seven,” after he made his debut in 1956 in “Baby Doll.” The Thalberg award, named for the legendary MGM executive, recognizes Mr. Coppola’s work as a producer of films including “The Conversation,” “The Godfather: Part II” and “Dracula.”

headline: Krugman or Paulson: Who You Gonna Bet On?
text: Sorry, can’t resist. That was the title of this Business Week article a few months ago. The tone made it pretty clear that if you had any sense, you’d ignore the bearded academic and go with the market wizard:

headline: Blazing a Trail at the Arles Photo Festival
text: For 41 years, photo enthusiasts have descended en masse on Arles, the colorful Provencal town, to partake in the annual Les Rencontres d’Arles photography exposition. This summer is no exception. While the buzz is loudest in July, when there are evening screenings and soirées, the festival goes until Sept. 19, giving eager shutterbugs, art admirers and international travelers time to enjoy the exhibitions without the high season’s swarms.

headline: Plug In, Turn On and Tune Out Wi-Fi
text: As a Texan, I find it deeply offensive when the Internet blocks me from watching “Friday Night Lights.”

headline: Continental Shows Off Its New Airliners
text: Continental Airlines, which next year will become the first domestic carrier to fly the new Boeing 787 Dreamliner, offered a preview of the plane’s interior this month at the National Business Travel Association convention in Houston. If the preview matches reality, the new planes will offer several enhancements.

headline: Behind the Florida Primary Surprises, Turnout Tells a Tale
text: MIAMI  Beyond the win-loss results of Tuesday’s Florida primary  with Rick Scott seizing the Republican mantle for governor, and Kendrick Meek winning the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate  there lie more subtle signals of what to look for in November.

headline: Bernadette Peters to Star in ‘Follies’ Revival in Washington
text: Among the high points of the one-night-only concert by Bernadette Peters on Broadway last November were her powerhouse performances of the songs “Losing My Mind” and “In Buddy’s Eyes” from the Stephen Sondheim musical “Follies.” It seemed only a matter of time before Ms. Peters, a leading interpreter of Mr. Sondheim’s scores and lyrics, would take a crack at the role of Sally Durant Plummer, the former vaudeville showgirl who delivers those two numbers in “Follies.”

headline: Vermont Democrat Claims Victory
text: In Vermont, where five Democratic candidates for governor had vied in the primary, State Senator Peter Shumlin declared victory Wednesday despite a likely recount.

headline: Toyota Prius to Get Sound to Alert Pedestrians
text: Starting at the end of the month, Prius owners in Japan will be able to buy an anti-stealth device, an under-hood noisemaker to warn pedestrians of the hybrid’s approach.

headline: A Big Welcome to FiveThirtyEight
text: FiveThirtyEight, Nate Silver’s Political Calculus blog, joined The Times family of blogs on Tuesday. FiveThirtyEight.com, which gained significant attention from its successful forecasts of the 2008 elections, is “devoted to rigorous analysis of politics, polling, public affairs, sports, science and culture, largely through statistical means,” as Mr. Silver writes. Read the first two posts on the blog, as well as view the latest forecast for the November race for Senate seats, at FiveThirtyEight.

headline: Body Found in London May Be Intelligence Officer
text: LONDON  A body found stuffed into a large sports bag in a bathtub at an apartment here was identified Wednesday in British news reports as that of a missing intelligence officer, prompting much speculation about his identity and the details behind his death.

headline: Coordinated Attacks in Iraq
text: Anthony Shadid reports from Baghdad on a string of coordinated attacks on Iraq's security forces.

headline: Social Security and Younger Americans
text: It’s not surprising that Americans over age 65 are virtually unanimous in seeing Social Security as an important government program. As a group, they rely on it as the single greatest source of income in retirement.

headline: What We’re Reading: Un-Branding
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: She Plays a Teacher on TV, and Now She Wants to School Parents
text: A campaign to promote the responsible use of mobile phones is enlisting a television teacher to serve as its lead spokeswoman.

headline: The Flying Geese Model
text: The process by which older technology and know-how is passed down the chain of developing economies.

headline: Tiger Woods Speaks About His Divorce
text: PARAMUS, N.J. – All summer, Tiger Woods has failed to look like himself on the golf course. The turmoil in his personal life always seemed like a logical reason why, even if Woods would not readily admit it.

headline: U.S. Open: Day 1
text: Kim Clijsters, the 2005 champion, marked her Grand Slam return with a defeat of Ukraine's Viktoriya Kutusova in the first round.

headline: Parsing the Price of Drugs
text: There is a subtext to today’s release of an AARP report saying the retail prices of popular brand-name drugs rose 8.3 percent last year while inflation dropped.

headline: The Caucus Podcast: Tuesday’s Results? A Mixed Bag
text: The Caucus Podcast

headline: Apple Invites News Media to Sept. 1 Event
text: In The New York Times on Wednesday, my colleague Brian Stelter and I wrote about Apple’s efforts to persuade television networks to agree to rent shows on iTunes for 99 cents. The negotiations were linked to a widely expected September event at which Apple would introduce new products, including possibly revamped versions of the iPod Touch and Apple TV.

headline: Dollar Thrifty’s Promising Day in Court
text: There is not much question about the outcome of a hearing on a preliminary injunction to block the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group‘s deal with Hertz Global Holdings. I watched the first hour of the hearing in Delaware Chancery Court on Wednesday, courtesy of Courtroom View Network, and my opinion from that time is that Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. is not going to enjoin the deal. He is also unlikely to touch the termination fee or the matching rights that Hertz has negotiated in its agreement. At most, he may require Dollar Thrifty to make more disclosure about the sale process.

headline: Girls’ Rules for Fall
text: A few months back, while visiting showrooms, Paula Sutter, the president of Diane von Furstenberg, introduced me to Kate Ciepluch and some of the buyers from the online retailer Shopbop. Ms. Sutter thought the Shopbop team understood the customer in her 20s and early 30s. “They have a tremendous credibility with these girls,” Ms. Sutter told me afterward. In fact, when the Shopbop buyers are bullish on an item, Ms. Sutter said, her staff will take that as a cue to cut the garment in another pattern or color. “You’re crazy not to pay attention to what they do.”

headline: All That Jazz at the F.D.A.
text: There’s a fascinating rundown in the  In Vivo blog of a dispute last Friday at a hearing of a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee that eventually voted 20 to 2 against a Jazz Pharmaceuticals application for a drug for chronic pain.

headline: The Ten Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Mosques and Islamic centers across country are targets of protests. With flights to New York so expensive, this is how the Tea Party stay-cations.

headline: Now Toting | J. Panther Luggage
text: It’s rare for a European luggage designer to look to the United States for manufacturing, but Johnny Diamandis of J. Panther Luggage appreciates the durability and wear of the American valise. “It has a less precious feel and it gets better with age, not worse,” he says. “Basically it’s luxury goods, American style — more rugged and built for life.”
