headline: One Liberal Voice Dares to Say, Cut the Budget
text: Is there a strong liberal argument to be made for attacking the federal debt?

headline: Eminem Beats New Releases
text: Eminem reigns over the Billboard chart yet again this week, beating a wave of new releases. Eminem’s album “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) is No. 1 for the seventh time, with 116,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. “Intimacy: Album III” (Motown) by the R&B singer Kem opens at No. 2 with 74,000 sales, and “God Willin’ & the Creek Don’t Rise” (RCA), the new album by Ray LaMontagne and the Pariah Dogs, is No. 3 with 64,000.

headline: Missing Piece in Oil Rig Inquiry: Who Was in Charge?
text: HOUSTON  Even after dozens of witnesses, a hundred hours of testimony and three months of investigation, a chairman of a federal panel exploring the Deepwater Horizon disaster admitted Wednesday that he still lacked a simple fact: Who was the top authority on the oil rig when it exploded?

headline: Wal-Mart Asks Supreme Court to Hear Bias Suit
text: Wal-Mart Stores asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to review the largest employment discrimination lawsuit in American history, involving more than a million female workers, current and former, at Wal-Mart and Sam’s Club stores.

headline: Workers at City-Run Laundry to Protest Privatization
text: In the battle against filth, the workers at the Brooklyn Central Laundry in East Flatbush are stalwart foot soldiers. About 80 union workers wash the dirty sheets, towels and uniforms for most of New York City’s hospitals, folding more than 10 million pounds of laundry a year. Employees say the linens sometimes hold body parts. They nearly always contain blood.

headline: The Tax Consequences of Lucky Breaks
text: While the odds are against it, there’s always the chance that you could be the one to catch the home run ball, win the lottery or unknowingly buy Ansel Adams negatives at garage sale.

headline: Germany Plans Limits on Facebook Use in Hiring
text: As part of the draft of a law governing workplace privacy, the German government on Wednesday proposed placing restrictions on employers who want to use Facebook profiles when recruiting.

headline: Working Women in Part-Time Jobs
text: Congress’s Joint Economic Committee released a report on Wednesday on how women’s economic conditions have changed in the last 25 years. Among the more interesting findings was this graph:

headline: Q. & A.: Leaving Fingerprints on Purpose
text: Q.

headline: S.E.C. Makes Access to Proxy Ballots Easier
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted 3 to 2 on Wednesday to adopt a rule that would give shareholders an easier way to nominate company directors, Reuters reports.

headline: Final Vote Set on Silverstein’s Towers at Ground Zero
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to convene Thursday to formally ratify a plan that would allow the developer Larry A. Silverstein to build two office towers at ground zero with up to $1.6 billion in public financing and subsidies, according to Port Authority and real estate executives.

headline: Baryshnikov and Cunningham Company Embark on New Collaboration
text: Though Merce Cunningham is no longer with us, some of the biggest stars in the dance world are working to ensure his legacy. On Oct. 4, Mikhail Baryshnikov will perform as part of a special benefit program to introduce a new collaboration between the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and Baryshnikov Arts Center. “BAC Flicks: Mondays With Merce,” a new monthly film series and programming collaboration, is intended to educate audiences about Cunningham’s legacy and creative process. The event will feature a performance of “Occasion Piece2” by Baryshnikov and the Cunningham company, with music from John Cage’s “Song Books” performed by Joan La Barbara and John Kelly. It will also include a screening of Charles Atlas’s film “With Merce.”

headline: A Tian of Zucchini and Tomatoes
text: Starting in the 1970s, the French publishing house Robert Laffont issued a series of cookbooks by young chefs who were gaining fame as developers of what was then being called nouvelle cuisine – and what is now pretty mainstream. I’m not talking about the parody of that style – a one-ounce red mullet fillet sauced with raspberry vinegar and garnished with kiwi – but about the freedom to experiment with traditional French cooking. The Laffont authors included Michel Guérard, Jean and Pierre Troisgros, Alain Chapel and so many others.

headline: Honda Jazz Hybrid Will Get Paris Premiere
text: 10:08 a.m. | Updated

headline: The Apple Guessing Game Commences
text: By now you might have heard: Apple is holding an invite-only news media event on Sept. 1.

headline: Debt Fears Slink Back in European Markets
text: When the European Union stepped in this spring with a €750 billion rescue package to back Europe’s weaker economies, the threat of imminent default practically disappeared. Little of the money has actually been spent, but borrowing costs fell and pressure on the banks that hold much of Europe’s sovereign debt eased.

headline: BHP Chief on the Road to Defend Bid for Potash
text: Marius Kloppers, the chief executive of BHP Billiton, has shown his shareholders that the world’s largest mining company is in good financial shape. Now he has to prove the same about BHP’s hostile offer for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, Julia Werdigier of The New York Times reports from London.

headline: Victims of Massacre in Mexico Said to Be Migrants
text: MEXICO CITY  The bullet-pocked bodies of 72 people, believed to be migrants heading to the United States who resisted demands for money, have been found in a large room on a ranch in an area of northeast Mexico with surging violence, the authorities said Wednesday.

headline: Fire Alan Simpson
text: I always thought that the deficit commission was a bad idea; it has only looked worse over time, as the buzz is that Democrats are caving in to Republicans, leaning ever further toward an all-cuts, no taxes solution, including a sharp rise in the retirement age.

headline: Obama, Mindful of Elections and Weak Reports, Holds Economic Talks
text: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass.  Amid the latest signs of a faltering recovery, President Obama held a lengthy conference call with economic advisers on Wednesday to discuss a course of action in a partisan election season that leaves them little room to maneuver.

headline: Obama to Give War Address Tuesday
text: President Obama will address the nation on Tuesday night about the end of combat operations in Iraq, in his second televised speech from the Oval Office, the White House announced on Wednesday.

headline: Chicken Chain’s Taste Test Pits Louisiana Against Kentucky
text: For decades, smaller brands have gained traction against much larger rivals by announcing that in taste tests, they best the bigger brands. The strategy, with a geographic twist, is being adopted by a chain of chicken restaurants.

headline: How to Make Phone Calls From Inside Gmail
text: Internet-based phone service is nothing new. Skype, which lets Americans talk to each other free and charges a couple of pennies per minute for long distance, began seven years ago. But on Wednesday, Google began introducing Internet phone service built into the interface of its Gmail service. (For now it is available only in the United States.)

headline: New Skyscraper to Rival Empire State Building
text: Click to read the final, fuller version of this article.

headline: Denver Chefs Head for the Garden
text: DENVER chefs face special challenges cooking a mile above sea level. At that altitude, meat and fish dry out faster and baking requires all sorts of adjustments. Meanwhile, the brutal winters, scorching summers and thin, arid atmosphere can be unkind to produce and livestock, making sourcing ingredients from in and around the city no easy feat.

headline: Nick Rowe Loses It
text: And good for him.

headline: Denver’s Local Food Scene
text: Several ambitious chefs are growing produce themselves.

headline: Using a Fingerprint Scanner on Your Laptop
text: Q. Do you have any tips on using the fingerprint scanner on my Dell laptop? I either do not press hard enough, long enough or smoothly enough. I have had the reader reinstalled once because it simply was not reading. Is this a common issue?

headline: Holding a Candle to the Hamptons
text: The party held last Saturday by the Ellen Hermanson Foundation in honor of the annual Ellen’s 5K Run in East Hampton, N.Y., satisfied all the requirements for a successful Hamptons benefit. Several of the names on the guest list were boldfaced: Donna Karan, Edie Falco and Kim Cattrall, along with an assortment of committee members, socialites and well-to-dos. There was mingling and cocktail drinking and even some donating. Less obvious was the lighting. That was provided by dozens of hand-blown glass votives called Glassybabies. These are the same spherical candle holders that illuminated other summer events, like the Parrish Art Museum Midsummer Party in July and last weekend’s Third Annual Best Buddies Gala, both of which took place in Southampton, N.Y.

headline: China Gives Ex-Official Suspended Death Sentence
text: BEIJING  A former assistant minister of public security linked to a major corruption case in China has been given a suspended death sentence for taking more than $1 million in bribes over six years, the Chinese news media reported Wednesday.

headline: Recipe Redux: Corncakes With Caviar, 1985
text: Most trends arise not from inspiration but from indignation. Food trucks were established by entrepreneurs who bridled at the start-up costs of restaurants. The pizza revolution was started by cooks who thought the form had been maligned by old-school standards like Lombardi’s and Grimaldi’s. And cold-brew coffee nerds just hated the milkshakes-disguised-as-coffee at Starbucks.

headline: 2010: Wood-Grilled Anacortes Spot Prawns (or Shrimp) with Lemon Relish and Corn Pudding
text: By Mark Fuller, the chef at Spring Hill in Seattle. Fuller uses Anson Mills white grits, available at www.ansonmills.com.

headline: 1985: Corncakes With Caviar
text: This recipe appeared in an article in The Times by Craig Claiborne.

headline: Took a Bad Photo? Paint, Sketch or Distort It, Beautifully
text: I rarely take photos with my phone because I am a lousy enough photographer with a real camera.

headline: Sweating the Details for the Fun of Others
text: Ana Matronic wasn’t joking when she said she was switching to running shoes  two-inch heels rather than four-inch ones  during Scissor Sisters’ effervescent set at Terminal 5 on Tuesday night. She needed them as she and the bare-chested Jake Shears, the band’s two lead singers, ran in place while they sang “Running Out” from their current album, “Night Work” (Universal). It’s a perky new wave-electro song that holds some gloomy lyrics: “We’re running out of money, of each other, of confidence/we’re running out of drugs, of patience, of air.”

headline: Barbara Corcoran Obviously Knows a Deal
text: WHAT is the key to a healthy marriage?

headline: Can Preschoolers Be Depressed?
text: Kiran didn’t seem like the type of kid parents should worry about. “He was the easy one,” his father, Raghu, a physician, says. “He always wanted to please.” Unlike other children in his suburban St. Louis preschool, Kiran (a nickname his parents asked me to use to protect his identity) rarely disobeyed or acted out. If he dawdled or didn’t listen, Raghu (also a nickname) had only to count to five before Kiran hastened to tie his shoes or put the toys away. He was kind to other children; if a classmate cried, Kiran immediately approached. “Our little empath!” his parents proudly called him.

headline: Apps to Fit Your Style (or Find It)
text: TECHNOLOGY can be a blessing or a curse. Shopping can be a delight or a nuisance. Put them together and the odds of having a good experience can get a little better.

headline: Chopin and Schumann, at 200, and Their Inspirations
text: Schumann and Chopin, whose bicentennials are being celebrated this year, have been featured frequently in concerts this season. But rather than merely paying homage to the birthday boys, the pianist Ian Hobson is offering a series of 10 recitals at the Dicapo Opera Theater featuring works by the two composers in the framework of their musical influences and legacy.

headline: The White-Collar Pushback After the Skilling Ruling
text: On Friday afternoon, a federal judge swore in Barry Grissom as the new United States attorney in Kansas. Just hours later, his office filed a motion to dismiss its highest profile criminal case, a seven-year-old corporate fraud prosecution against two former top executives at Westar Energy, the state’s largest electric utility.

headline: Benefit Project Promotes Cunningham’s Legacy
text: Though Merce Cunningham is no longer alive, some of the biggest stars in the dance world are working to ensure his legacy. On Oct. 4 Mikhail Baryshnikov, above right, with Cunningham, will perform as part of a special benefit program to introduce a collaboration between the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and Baryshnikov Arts Center. “BAC Flicks: Mondays With Merce,” a new monthly film series and programming collaboration, is intended to educate audiences about Cunningham’s legacy and creative process. The Oct. 4 event will feature a performance of “Occasion Piece2” by Baryshnikov and the Cunningham company, with music from John Cage’s “Song Books” performed by Joan La Barbara and John Kelly. It will also include a screening of Charles Atlas’s “With Merce.” The series will showcase video and dance films from the Cunningham archives as well other films. “BAC Flicks: Mondays With Merce” will be presented one Monday a month, and will continue through the Cunningham company’s final tour, which ends on Dec. 31, 2011. Tickets for the benefit evening go on sale Aug. 30 at smarttix.com.

headline: Shopping With Jason Rowan
text: A cocktail master looked for ice buckets, wine coolers, Champagne buckets and anything else that might help keep drinks cool.

headline: Bernadette Peters To Star In ‘follies’ In Washington
text: Fresh off ecstatic reviews this month for her star turn as the lovelorn actress Desiree in Stephen Sondheim’s “Little Night Music” revival on Broadway, Bernadette Peters has signed on to play Sally in a revival of “Follies” at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, scheduled to run May 7 through June 5. Casting for Sally’s husband, Buddy, and the musical’s other unhappily married couple, Phyllis and Ben, will be announced later, the Kennedy Center said on Wednesday in its statement about Ms. Peters. The revival will be directed by Eric Schaeffer, who oversaw the Kennedy Center’s “Sondheim Celebration” in 2002 and is now artistic director of Signature Theater in Arlington, Va. Ms. Peters is under contract through early November for “A Little Night Music.” Whether she will follow up her “Night Music” with a Kennedy Center-to-Broadway transfer of “Follies” is an open question.

headline: Disney Studios Withdraws From Animation Group
text: Walt Disney Studios has withdrawn from a group that hands out trophies for animation achievement. For years Disney has privately groused about the Annie Awards, presented by the Hollywood chapter of the International Animated Film Society. Disney has complained that the guild allows anyone to buy a membership (in contrast to most awards-bestowing organizations) and that Disney’s rival DreamWorks Animation has too much power because it gives its employees free guild membership. Variety, which reported the split, noted that Disney’s Pixar entries had won 6 of the last 10 top Annie prizes. But Disney started to agitate more aggressively for changes in 2009 after DreamWorks Animation’s “Kung Fu Panda” won a raft of Annies, and Pixar’s “Wall-E” won nothing. “Wall-E” went on to win the Oscar for animation that year. “We believe there is an issue with the way the Annies are judged, and have been seeking a mutually agreeable solution with the board,” Ed Catmull, president of Disney Animation and Pixar Animation, said in a statement. “Although some initial steps have been taken, the board informed us that no further changes would be made to address our concerns.” Antran Manoogian, the guild’s president, told Variety, “The Annies are about honoring the best in animation, and we will continue to do so.”

headline: Ice Buckets
text: JASON ROWAN, 42, is a cocktail maker who creates customized drinks for private events. He also writes about cocktail culture for magazines and has a blog called Embury Cocktails, which he describes as “a clubhouse for drinking and cocktail enthusiasts.”

headline: New Releases Can’t Top Eminem’s ‘Recovery’
text: Eminem reigns over the Billboard chart yet again this week, beating a wave of new releases. Eminem’s album “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) is No. 1 for the seventh time, with 116,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. “Intimacy: Album III” (Motown) by the R&B singer Kem opens at No. 2 with 74,000 sales, and “God Willin’ & the Creek Don’t Rise” (RCA), the new album by Ray LaMontagne and the Pariah Dogs, is No. 3 with 64,000. Iron Maiden’s “Final Frontier” (Universal Music Enterprises) reached No. 4 in its first week, with 63,000 sales, and Trace Adkins’s “Cowboy’s Back in Town” (Show Dog/Universal), also new, is No. 5 with 50,000. Next week there is likely to be a shake-up because Katy Perry’s new “Teenage Dream” (Capitol) is expected to have strong sales.

headline: Lohan Leaves Rehab
text: Lindsay Lohan, below, was released from a Los Angeles rehabilitation center on Tuesday, making her a free woman less than two months after she was sentenced to 90 days in jail for violating the terms of her probation, Reuters reported. Ms. Lohan, the 24-year-old actress and “Mean Girls” star, served 22 days at the rehabilitation center at Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center after her release on Aug. 2 from the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif., where she arrived on July 20 to begin serving her jail term. Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court sentenced Ms. Lohan on July 6 after she missed a probation hearing in May stemming from her 2007 arrests on charges of drunken driving and drug possession. Judge Elden S. Fox on Wednesday ordered Ms. Lohan to undergo psychotherapy and addiction-counseling sessions until November and submit to random drug and alcohol tests.

headline: Footnote
text: Tribeca Film Festival organizers announced on Wednesday that the 10th annual festival would be held April 20 to May 1.

headline: Dylan’s Demo Recordings To Be Released This Fall
text: Bob Dylan may be too busy with his painting career and his year-round touring to create an album of new material, but that won’t keep a new Dylan album from hitting shelves in the fall, this one comprising material from the earlier end of his 50-year career. A new entry in Mr. Dylan’s Bootleg Series, “The Witmark Demos” (M. Witmark & Sons was one of his early publishers), will be released by Columbia Records on Oct. 19, Billboard reported. This two-CD release consists of 47 demo recordings that Mr. Dylan made from 1962 to 1964. Among the tracks are early versions of future standards like “Blowin’ in the Wind” and “The Times They Are A-Changin’,” as well as songs that have not been previously released in any version, like “Guess I’m Doing Fine,” “Long Ago, Far Away” and “Ballad for a Friend.” Columbia will also release on Oct. 19 new vinyl versions of Mr. Dylan’s first eight albums, taken from their original mono mixes.

headline: Helping New Parents While Confronting Her Own Fatal Illness
text: During her first pregnancy, in the mid-1980s, Karen Storek was desperate for information about giving birth and caring for her baby. She decided that there needed to be a place where new parents could gather and disseminate parenting advice, from before conception to the first grade.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: The Facebook Movie
text: “The Social Network”–also known as “the Facebook movie”–is coming in October, but already there’s been drama behind the scenes. Miguel Helft, The New York Times technology reporter covering Facebook, and Michael Cieply, who covers media for The Times, recently examined the tensions between the filmmakers and Facebook executives. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Mr. Helft on this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast about the disagreements over the movie, its portrayal of Facebook’s founder, Mark Zuckerberg, and how Facebook has responded.

headline: Two Saxophonists Step in as a Pair of Substitutes
text: Joe Lovano, the tenor saxophonist, couldn’t make it to the Village Vanguard this week. It was the beginning of an annual two-week stretch with the trio he’s played in for 25 years, with the guitarist Bill Frisell and the drummer Paul Motian. But Mr. Lovano double-booked himself, so he had to be in Edinburgh, soloing with the Scottish National Jazz Orchestra. Two tenors, Tony Malaby and Mark Turner, are filling his spot. Not alternating, but simultaneously.

headline: Former Chief of Drilling Agency Says New Inspection System Is Needed
text: S. Elizabeth Birnbaum, the former head of the Minerals Management Service who resigned under pressure a month after the blowout of BP’s well in the Gulf of Mexico, said Wednesday that the offshore drilling oversight agency needed a thorough overhaul of its regulations, inspection procedures and culture.

headline: Should H.P. Dump Its 3Par Bid for McAfee?
text: Sure, Hewlett-Packard appears to have made an aggressive play by trumping Dell‘s bid for 3Par, a data storage company. Indeed, the bidding war seemed to be heating up even further on Wednesday, with Reuters reporting that Dell was getting ready to come back with a higher bid.

headline: A Flood Of Songs Washing Over a City
text: John Lennon used to say, during the period he was writing overtly political music, that his songs were a form of journalism. Ted Hearne, a composer who was born in 1982, two years after Lennon was killed, seemingly takes a similar view. He described his “Katrina Ballads”  an expansive song cycle about Hurricane Katrina’s devastation of New Orleans, and the government’s inadequate response  as a “somewhat journalistic piece.”

headline: Band Encourages Counseling for Concertgoers Who Saw Fatal Jump
text: The Swell Season said it had attended grief counseling sessions following a concertgoer’s  fatal jump last week at a performance by the band, and said it would pay for similar services for other people who witnessed the fall.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Windsor Locks and Elsewhere
text: Is it news that Specialist John Allegra IV of the 250th Engineer Company of the Connecticut National Guard returned home safely on Wednesday after his deployment in Iraq? Just look at his mother’s face. It is the most important news in the world.

headline: Hounded Online and in Person, Woman Apologizes for Abusing Cat
text: Mary Bale, a 45-year-old woman who earned international notoriety this week when video of her dropping a cat into a garbage bin was posted online by the cat’s owners, issued a formal apology on Wednesday.

headline: Some Business Skills to Go With the Passion
text: IT’S a recipe for a role model: economic anxiety and America’s inherent optimism. Enter that paragon of self-reliance, the entrepreneur.

headline: The Protean Master of the Ballets Russes
text: When he died, at 57, Serge Pavlovich Diaghilev (1872-1929) was many things: the most celebrated of Russian émigrés; the impresario of the Ballets Russes, the world’s most famous ballet company; a pivotal figure in the recent histories of opera, stage design, visual arts, classical music, as well as theatrical dance; the hub of successive schools of artistic modernism; the man who had taken ballet from state patronage into the world of commercial sponsors; the most celebrated homosexual since Oscar Wilde.

headline: ‘Diaghilev: A Life’
text: Chapter I: A Big Head

headline: Foreign Language Courses, Brushing Up or Immersion
text: THEY may be preparing for a vacation in Europe, trying to communicate with colleagues abroad or immigrant clients at home or unlocking the skills, learned in college, that have retreated to an inaccessible part of the brain. For those aiming to learn a foreign language, continuing education courses can lead people toward fluency  or at least help them get by.

headline: Social Networking Your Way to a New Job
text: UNTIL just a few years ago, looking for a job was a relatively straightforward process. Write a résumé. Scour job sites or the classifieds. Submit an application for listings that seem appropriate. Reach out to recruiters. Then, wait.

headline: Making Career Development Pay
text: IN shaky economic times, going back to school needs to be treated like any other investment: you need to weigh the potential returns while closely managing the costs.

headline: Learning Curves on the Career Path
text: “Every day we know less and less about more and more,” said Ray Caprio, vice president for continuing education at Rutgers University.

headline: Community College Training for Managing Green Jobs
text: BEYOND “green-collar” jobs, like retrofitting a home to conserve energy or helping build a wind farm, an energy-conscious economy will need a new generation of environmentally smart managers, and that’s where community colleges are stepping up with new courses and degree programs.

headline: The Humanities for Love, Not Money
text: WHEN the renowned educators Mortimer J. Adler and Robert Maynard Hutchins first decided to expand their Great Books course beyond the University of Chicago’s walls, they recruited some of Chicago’s most prominent businessmen. In what was called the Fat Men’s Great Books Course, the executives and their wives started meeting every other Friday evening in the fall of 1943 to discuss Plato, Shakespeare and Goethe.

headline: A Simple Wireless Network? Not Likely
text: When one of the first instructions a popular wireless Internet router from Netgear gives its owner is a choice between the security protocols known as WPA-PSK (TKIP) and WPA-PSK (TKIP) + WPA2-PSK (AES), you know the home networking industry has problems.

headline: What Do Girls Want?
text: ONE morning early this month, Kate Ciepluch, the fashion director of the online retailer Shopbop, assembled members of her buying team in a conference room in the company’s offices on Broadway in SoHo.

headline: Girls Charter School Will Move One Grade
text: After months of battling and weeks of back and forth with the city, Girls Preparatory Charter School has found a solution to its space problem. The school is expected to move one grade level of students to a building at 51 Astor Place, just off Cooper Square.

headline: My Must-Have Looks for This Fall
text: WHEN shops and fashion magazines begin displaying fall collections  typically in the sweltering days of August  you know it signals the death knell of summer. One of the only things that makes summer’s end bearable is the knowledge that a whole new fall wardrobe awaits.

headline: Imperfect Crime, Indelicate Outcome
text: At first “Den of Thieves” seems like your typical ba-da-bing mob comedy. Neatly composed structurally, the first act begins with hints of romance, moves to plans for a heist and then ends with a question that functions like a set-up to a joke: What could possibly go wrong?

headline: New Kindle Leaves Rivals Farther Back
text: Too bad there’s not a reality TV show called “America’s Most Freaked-Out Tech-Company Meetings,” where you watch classic panicked board meetings. For example, when the Apple employee left an iPhone 4 prototype in a bar. Or when Intel learned that its Pentium chip contained a math error. Or when Microsoft was caught bribing bloggers with $2,500 laptops to promote Windows Vista.

headline: A Hendrix Castle Where Musicians Still Kiss the Sky
text: Just down the street from the hot dogs of Gray’s Papaya, on a row of down-market Greenwich Village shops selling used CDs and a certain kind of glass pipe, 52 West Eighth Street is easy to miss. But a small sign marks hallowed musical ground: Electric Lady Studios.

headline: California Approves First New U.S. Thermal Solar Plant
text: California regulators on Wednesday approved a license for the nation’s first large-scale solar thermal power plant in two decades.

headline: Fringe Festival Journal: ‘Get Rich Cheating’
text: The 16-day New York International Fringe Festival continues through Sunday. Check back regularly on ArtsBeat for guidance about what to see from New York Times writers and editors.

headline: Difficult Pieces Inspire a Pianist
text: The most satisfying aspect of Taka Kigawa’s performance at Le Poisson Rouge on Monday evening was the sense of clarity and apparent ease he brought to a parade of harmonically thorny and, in some cases, texturally dense piano works. He gave himself no breaks in this short but intense recital. You get an idea of how difficult the program was once you realize that the least demanding score Mr. Kigawa played was the Webern Variations (1936), a piece that taxes both the technique and imagination of a pianist intent on winning an audience to its charms.

headline: Simpson Apologizes to Critic
text: Alan K. Simpson, the Republican co-chairman of President Obama’s bipartisan fiscal commission, removed his “size 15 feet” from his mouth to apologize to a critic on Wednesday for a stinging letter in which he compared Social Security to “a milk cow with 310 million tits.”

headline: Two Missed Opportunities for a Mentor in Cyberspace
text: Every Wednesday at 11 a.m. Eastern Time at bridgebase.com, two experts play for an hour, partnering juniors from around the world.

headline: After Work, Jazz Musicians Play
text: A group of jazz musicians battle it out at the ping pong table.

headline: Barnes & Noble Calls Burkle Unfit to Be on Board
text: The heated proxy fight between Barnes & Noble and the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle has quickly become personal.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Report From a Pashtun Teen: The Flood
text: Sher Bano is a 17-year-old Pashtun girl from Pakistan who spent last year as an exchange student in Evanston, Illinois, as part of the Youth Exchange and Study (YES) Program. She is now back in the city of Peshawar in the northwest of Pakistan, and has become a regular contributor to “On the Ground.”

headline: A Proposal to Keep Sewage Away From the California Coast
text: Aug. 26, 3:10 p.m. | Updated The federal Environmental Protection Agency said Wednesday that it intended to ban all dumping of sewage by large cargo and cruise ships in California waters out to the three-mile limit. The state has been requesting the ban for five years.

headline: Problem-Solving Kitchen Products
text: Joseph Joseph, the London kitchen products company, has a reputation for making colorful items with playful shapes. But how they function is more important to the brothers who own the company. “We love producing problem-solving products,” said Richard Joseph, who founded Joseph Joseph with his twin brother, Antony, in 2003.

headline: Browsing | Repaving Madison’s Glitter
text: New boutiques on Madison Avenue bring life back to a key retail stretch.

headline: Blackstone Urges Court to Reject I.P.O. Appeal
text: The Blackstone Group urged a federal appeals court not to revive an investor lawsuit accusing it of hiding bad investments before the private equity firm raised $4.7 billion in its initial public offering in 2007, Reuters reports. A lawyer for Blackstone argued that securities laws did not require the firm to disclose expansive details about hundreds of investments that it believed the investors sought.

headline: Stars, Not Also-Rans
text: In a recent “Theater Talkback” on the ArtsBeat blog, Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The New York Times, asked readers to recall their favorite replacement performers in Broadway shows. Here is an edited selection of their responses:

headline: Dogs: Not a Gardener’s Best Friend
text: DID Bertie Wooster mean to harm Barbara Geltosky in September 2008? The evidence against him is damning. For instance, the hole that Bertie, Ms. Geltosky’s 5-year-old Norwegian elkhound, dug in the garden was 12 inches across and 12 inches deep — the perfect size for a human foot.

headline: A Box of Fresh Air
text: Racine, Wis.

headline: Sales at Aero, Artware Editions and Gretel Home
text: Aero, the furniture and housewares retailer, is offering 30 percent off new Thomas O’Brien for Visual Comfort orders, 25 percent off all new Thomas O’Brien for Safavieh orders and 25 percent off selected Thomas O’Brien for Reed & Barton products, through Sept. 18 (an Austin Floral Indigo flatware five-piece place setting, originally $95, is $71; a 9-by-6-foot Porcelain rug, regularly $3,025, is $2,268; and an 8-by-10 Moroccan Panel rug, regularly $4,480, is $3,360); 419 Broome Street (Lafayette Street), (212) 966-1500 or aerostudios.com.

headline: Devices That Help Plug Electrical Leaks
text: YOU dutifully sort your plastic and paper. You are hip to the latest low- and no-VOC paints. You have even thought about buying a hybrid car. But what about the electricity you use at home? Not only does it come at a cost to the environment, but it also costs you  to the tune of $2,200 a year, on average, for a single-family home.

headline: Candle Holders, Pricked With Light
text: Anna Perring, a London-based publisher-turned-ceramicist who owns a company called Luna Lighting, just introduced her latest series of Mini lights: five hand-thrown porcelain tea-light holders that are pierced so light can shine through. Above, from left, they include Cupcake, Dragonfly, Angel Fish, Sausage Dog and Rubber Duck.

headline: Dansk Reissues Classics From the ’60s
text: Jens Quistgaard’s 1960s teak designs for Dansk are midcentury modern classics — and often quite expensive, if you can find them today. But the housewares company has reintroduced a selection of the salt and pepper grinders, and an ice bucket will follow next month. Fashioned after the original shapes, the grinders bear the original names — from left, Henrik, Lisbet and Jasper — but are made of acacia instead of teak.

headline: Giò Ponti’s Furniture on Exhibit in SoHo
text: Architect, industrial designer, writer, editor, painter Giò Ponti, who died in 1979, was one of the design world’s most versatile figures. A planned exhibition at the Molteni&C Dada Unifor flagship store in SoHo, “La Casa all’Italiana,” focuses on one of the richest parts of his legacy: furniture design.

headline: An Anthropologist’s Take on Homemaking
text: HANCOCK, N.H.

headline: Dedar Brings its Vibrant Fabrics to the United States
text: Dedar, an Italian company known for its vibrant fabrics, wallpapers and trim previously available only to the trade, is introducing its first line of retail products in the United States.

headline: Sometimes There Are Second Acts in Broadway Casting
text: Strange but true: The best new show in town this summer isn’t a new show at all, technically. The Broadway revival of “A Little Night Music” sings with new subtlety and emotional force now that the celebrated veterans Bernadette Peters and Elaine Stritch have taken over the key roles of Desirée Armfeldt and her caustic mum.

headline: A Lake House in Wisconsin Made of Glass and Steel
text: With its modern exterior, a house with views of Lake Michigan stands out in a neighborhood of Tudor, Georgian and colonial-style houses.

headline: On Bars, Ex-Photog Is Bullish
text: On the Lower East Side, in the space of just three blocks, there are four drinking establishments owned by Rob Shamlian, a man who, incidentally, does not drink. There is a cevicheria-cum-tequileria (Los Feliz), a look-at-all-those-beers-on-tap burger joint (Spitzer’s Corner), a two-floor rock club that reminds me of some sweaty Oberkampf boîte (Fat Baby), and Mason Dixon, a bourbon bar with a mechanical bull. “Did you know they have special mechanical bull insurance?” asks Shamlian, who intended the bull as an ironic hat-tip to the rodeo. It’s hipster bait, but still kind of adorable.

headline: Training a Naughty Dog to Behave in the Garden
text: The path to training a naughty dog how to behave in the garden may start with just that: a path. Ian Dunbar, a dog trainer and an author, and an avid gardener, has created a busy highway system through his backyard in Berkeley, Calif.

headline: The Green Features Built Into the Lake House
text: THE house owned by Vera Scekic and Robert Osborne has dozens of green features, ranging from familiar energy savers (compact fluorescent bulbs; ceiling fans) to more esoteric devices (an exhaust fan to vent carbon monoxide from the garage). headline: Imam Rauf and Moderate Islam
text: To some extent, the controversy surrounding the Cordoba Initiative’s Lower Manhattan venture is really a controversy about how non-Muslim Westerners should relate to the would-be spokesmen for a moderate (or “moderate,” depending on your point of view) Islam. One school of thought, prominent among conservatives but associated with liberal thinkers like Paul Berman as well, holds that anything short of an absolute commitment to Enlightenment values is unacceptable from such figures, and that moderate Muslims must demonstrate this commitment, and prove their secular bona fides, by making a frontal assault on Islamic culture as it currently exists. To this school, explicitly-liberal figures like Ayaan Hirsi Ali or Irshad Manji represent the beau ideal of moderate Islam, because they’re forthright in their critiques of Muslim societies’ failings, and unstinting in their insistence that the Western way of faith and politics is ultimately superior. A high-profile bridge-builder like the ubiquitous Tariq Ramadan, on the other hand,  is much more suspect, and possibly beyond the pale — because he tends to use different language and strike different notes depending on his audience, because he often seems to be making excuses for illiberalism in the Islamic world, because he’s less-than-forthright in his condemnations of certain kinds of extremism, and so on down the line. To his critics, such bobbing and weaving is proof enough that his “moderate Islam” project is really just a flowery fraud and a Trojan Horse for Wahhabism, with no redeeming value whatsoever. And this critique is easily extended to many other self-described moderates as well — including, lately, Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, who arguably has a stronger claim to moderation than Ramadan, but who seems to share some of his more evasive qualities when the conversation turns to, say, Hamas or the Islamic Republic of Iran.

text: It did not take long for President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to forget his latest anticorruption promise. headline: Louisiana: $1.8. Billion for Schools Lost to Katrina
text: The Obama administration will give New Orleans $1.8 billion in a lump-sum reimbursement for schools that were damaged or destroyed in the flooding after Hurricane Katrina, Senator Mary L. Landrieu, a Democrat, announced Wednesday. The settlement will pay for 87 school campuses in the city to replace the 127 that existed before Katrina. The public education system in New Orleans was in the first stages of a radical overhaul before the storm, with the creation of a state-run Recovery School District in addition to the pre-existing Orleans Parish School Board. Over three-fifths of the city’s students now attend charter schools. A spokeswoman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency did not confirm the figure but said that a major announcement would come later in the week.

headline: The Wrong Kind of Enthusiasm

headline: Religion-Based Groups Protest Aid Restriction
text: More than 100 religion-based organizations are protesting a provision in pending legislation that would prohibit them from receiving federal money if they consider a job applicant’s religion when hiring. In a letter sent Wednesday to all members of Congress, the groups contend that the provision would dilute protections they have under the 1964 Civil Rights Act and the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, as well as under the First Amendment of the Constitution. The provision is in legislation to reauthorize the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, which makes grants to nonprofit social service organizations with programs in those areas. While many of the groups signing the letter do not get money from the agency, they say the language of the provision is so broad it will affect other, unrelated sources of federal grants.

headline: Agent Tied to Informant Testifies in Bomb Plot Case

One pocket contained what looked like a timer. Wires ran into long, thin packets stored in a middle compartment: the explosives. And from the last compartment, the agent pulled out a plastic packet filled with 500 ball bearings.

headline: BHP Doing Fine Without Potash
text: BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, has shown it doesn’t actually need to buy the Potash Corporation. BHP’s impressive annual results on Wednesday are a reminder of the financial firepower behind its $39 billion hostile bid for Potash, the world’s largest fertilizer group. But they also show that BHP is not broken — and that its chief executive, Marius Kloppers, does not need to bet a strong balance sheet on further diversification.

headline: For Mets, Starters Are Not the Issue

Considering that Jason Bay, Carlos Beltran, Luis Castillo and Jeff Francoeur have contributed less than expected, maybe hovering relentlessly around .500 is not so bad. But considering how strong their starters have been, maybe it is.

headline: David Rowland, Maker of a Tidily Stacked Chair, Dies at 86

He was 86.

headline: France: Talks on the Roma
text: With anger mounting over French deportations of Roma to Romania and Bulgaria, top officials in the Sarkozy government met Wednesday with officials from Romania to coordinate strategies to aid the Roma there. The French government continued flights for Roma, whose departures they classified as voluntary because in return for leaving, the Roma accepted payments of about $380 per adult and $125 per child. On Wednesday, several dozen people arrived in Bulgaria. The government focus on Roma in France, who number more than 15,000, has been criticized as a political tactic by President Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: Kim Jong-il Reported to Be in China

South Korean news media, including the national news agency, Yonhap, and the mass-circulation daily, Chosun, reported the information in their Web sites.

headline: Kodak Adds Touch to Its Mini-Camcorder

headline: Crédit Agricole Quarterly Profit Rises 89 Percent
text: Crédit Agricole, one of the largest French banks, said second-quarter profit rose 89 percent, more than analysts had estimated, as earnings at the corporate- and investment-banking unit cushioned losses in Greece.

headline: Are Western Minds Different?
text: Today’s idea: Westerners see the world in ways that are alien from the rest of humanity, a psychological study finds. In other words, its authors say, we do not know what we thought we knew about the human mind.

headline: Purported Mobster Says He Helped Rothstein in Ponzi
text: An alleged organized-crime figure admitted helping move and hide funds last November to help cover up a $1.2 billion Ponzi scheme run by the South Florida lawyer Scott Rothstein, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Eisner’s Next Role: Tribune C.E.O.?
text: Could the former top cat at the Mouse House become the big cheese at Tribune Company? The Los Angeles Times reported that the former Walt Disney C.E.O. Michael Eisner is in the midst of talks that could place him as chairman of the now-bankrupt media company.

headline: How Would You Spend Grant Money for Schools?
text: The Department of Education announced the winners of “Race to the Top,” in which states competed for federal funding for their school systems. The states submitted proposals for how they would spend the money, and the government rewarded innovative ideas. If your state received funding, how would you want education officials to spend it?

headline: Calling for Calm on the Giants, and for Calm in General
text: Spanning the Web, and wondering how Chad Ochocinco can get away with calling Roger Goodell “Dad.”

headline: Stanford’s Bank Said to Loan Billions Undisclosed
text: In a Wednesday hearing over a Lloyd’s of London‘s insurance policy held by the jailed financier R. Allen Stanford, a witness tesitfied that Mr. Stanford’s Antigua bank made more than $3 billion in loans to Mr. Stanford and his companies without properly disclosing the loans.

headline: Exiled Tycoon Returns to Britain to Face Charges
text: LONDON — Asil Nadir, the disgraced Turkish-Cypriot businessman whose Levantine panache and deal-making zeal rattled Britain’s stodgy corporate establishment in the 1980s, returned here Thursday to face charges that he embezzled £30 million while running the London-based conglomerate Polly Peck International.

headline: Facebook Throws the Book at Internet Startup
text: What’s in a name? Well, “book” better not be, otherwise Mark Zuckerberg and Company might file a complaint. Facebook, has sued a yet-to-begin Internet start-up, Teachbook.com, for trademark infringement.

headline: Looking for a Sign
text: It’s sign time. A restaurant needs a sign. The one I have in mind will have black lower-case letters painted on a piece of Philippine mahogany with a little light above it. It will stand in front of the building, in the garden, two-sided so you can see it when traveling north or south. Maybe it should be a black sign with white letters. We’ll see. It will say Southfork Kitchen. That’s the name of the restaurant.

headline: After the Leak, Restoring the Gulf Coast
text: Back in June, with oil still spewing from BP’s blown-out well, President Obama charged Navy Secretary Ray Mabus with crafting a Gulf Coast restoration plan that would address  the short-term impacts of the spill as well as the long-term environmental challenges facing the region. This week, Mr. Mabus, a former Mississippi governor, pledged that the first iteration of that plan would be unveiled soon.

headline: Watchdog Finds ‘Fatal’ Flaws in British Accounting
text: In a letter to the British Department of Business, a member of the “Urgent Issues Task Force” has warned of a “regulatory fiasco” in which British banks have been adhering to flawed reporting standards for over five years, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Oil India Enlists Banks to Identify Foreign Targets
text: Oil India, a state-owned explorer, hired seven banks including Citigroup and Morgan Stanley to help complete an overseas acquisition this fiscal year as it seeks to increase the country’s energy security.

headline: Electric Vehicle Chargers Planned for Manhattan Parking Lots
text: The route to a fully charged electric vehicle runs through the parking lot. At least that’s the path followed by the Car Charging Group, a Florida-based electric-vehicle service provider that announced on Monday it is teaming up with Icon Parking Systems to install plug-in stations at some of Icon’s more than 200 garages and lots in Manhattan. In July, Car Charging Group announced a similar deal with Laz Parking, which has 1,350 facilities in 21 states.

headline: Where Did All the Easy Money Go?
text: Bloomberg News delivers an opus on the state of the private equity industry. Its conclusion: Things aren’t nearly as good as they were during the buyout boom.

headline: When Preschoolers Get Depressed
text: Childhood should be a carefree time of happiness and discovery. So when doctors begin to talk about depression among preschoolers, it’s no surprise that the diagnosis is met with skepticism, an issue explored in this week’s New York Times Magazine.

headline: Novartis and Nestlé Close $28.3 Billion Alcon Deal
text: Novartis and Nestlé said Thursday that they had wrapped up a $28.3 billion all-cash deal that gives Novartis, the Swiss drug giant, a controlling stake in the eye-care company Alcon, one of the last steps in a deal initiated in 2008.

headline: Carter Wins Release of American in North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Former President Jimmy Carter was expected to leave North Korea on Friday with Aijalon Mahli Gomes, an American who was sentenced to eight years of hard labor for illegally entering the country, the Carter Center said.

headline: An Honest Tale Speeds to Brooklyn: Bridge Project’s ‘Richard III’ Coming to BAM
text: Brooklyn, already no stranger to schemers, misfits and would-be Machiavellis, had better make room for one more such character. On Thursday, the Bridge Project — the trans-Atlantic theater collaboration among the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Old Vic Theater in London and the British production company Neal Street — said it would bring a new staging of Shakespeare‘s “Richard III” to BAM in 2012 for what will be the project’s final season. Not content to serve solely as the artistic director of the Old Vic, Kevin Spacey (pictured), the Tony- and Academy Award-winning actor, will play the title role in “Richard III,” which will be directed by Sam Mendes (who previously directed Mr. Spacey in “American Beauty”).

headline: Bits Pics: Visualizing the Web’s Icons

text: A Chinese term – “what to demolish” or “tear that down” – which plays on the word “China” and reflects a trend in the country for demolishing old buildings.

headline: Poetry Pairing | August 26, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: Unlocking the Mystery of Honegger
text: ARTHUR HONEGGER’S “Chant de Libération” was not a piece I intended to consult during a research trip to Paris in June 2009. Like others who knew of it, I thought the score was lost. Honegger had composed this song for baritone, chorus and orchestra in secret during the German occupation of France. Its only known trace was a tantalizing description of its October 1944 premiere in liberated Paris: a “triumph” by a “musician of the Resistance,” the music critic Maurice Brillant wrote.

headline: Can Stress Cause Hair Loss?
text: Alopecia areata is a mysterious disorder that can cause everything from a barely noticeable loss of a patch of hair to total loss of all body hair, including the eyebrows. When alopecia was recently featured in the Patient Voices series, several readers had questions about the relations between stress and the onset of the disorder. Here, Dr. Maria Hordinsky, a dermatologist from the University of Minnesota, responds.

headline: Foreclosures Fall, but Early Delinquencies Rise
text: The foreclosure crisis might have finally peaked in the first half of this year, but with the continued weakness in the economy and the recent deterioration of the housing market, the gains may prove fleeting.

headline: Vain Glorious | Scents of a Woman
text: Inès de la Fressange is the kind of woman who gets what she wants. And, as the brand ambassador for the shoe designs of Roger Vivier, de la Fressange wanted a sultry signature fragrance — or five, to be exact. “Our goal was a perfume with personality, style and quality, not just a huge launch with lots of ads,” she says, “so we used very precious and rare ingredients, just like a couture collection.” She worked closely with the nose Rami Mekdachi, and the resulting scents — L’Iris, Le Néroli, La Rose, Le Santal and L’Ambre — are heady but not aggressive. Les Parfums Roger Vivier ($195 a bottle) will make their debut at Fashion’s Night Out on Sept. 10 at the New York boutique (750 Madison Avenue), and they will be available at all Roger Vivier boutiques in October.

Microsoft has since started its own in-your-browser version of Office 2010, which I’m currently testing, but Google has built some wow features in to Docs that make it worth looking into as an alternative.

headline: A Dip in the N.F.L. 32
text: Although we have been unable to find this in the fine print of any of our calendars, apparently it is Woe to Rich People Week. First, there was the leaking of financial documents showing how profitable it can be to field very bad baseball teams, prompting much whining from the embarrassed money-making owners. Then there was the Tiger Woods divorce, with rampant speculation on how much that cost him. And now there is the report that the average value of N.F.L. teams dropped 2 percent.

headline: Theater Company Avoids Eviction in Deal With M.T.A.
text: The Lower Manhattan theater company 3-Legged Dog has reached an agreement with its landlord, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, that will allow it to stay in its home at 80 Greenwich Street, The Wall Street Journal reported. In May the M.T.A. threatened to evict the company. At that time 3-Legged Dog owed more than $300,000 in back rent and interest. In a deal reached Wednesday, the company will pay on Oct. 15 all the rent owed since June 1. It will pay the rest over roughly three years, at an interest rate of 5 percent. In addition, the M.T.A. will forgive $59,000 to settle claims related to 3-Legged Dog’s construction costs in the building. The executive artistic director of 3-Legged Dog, Kevin Cunningham, said the company had increased its earned income in recent months and had also received a major grant from a New York foundation, which he said would be announced in October.

headline: Signature Blends at Tokyo Bars
text: THE mention of Japanese whiskey was once most likely to recall Bill Murray’s Suntory Time ad campaign in “Lost in Translation.” But over the last decade, the drink’s reputation has experienced a meteoric rise. Any lingering doubts were put to rest in 2008 when Nikka’s Yoichi Single Malt 1987 and Suntory’s Hibiki 30 Years Old won the World’s Best Single Malt and World’s Best Blended categories, respectively, at the prestigious World Whiskey Awards. Since then, Japanese offerings have continued to earn accolades annually, often with prices to match.

headline: 36 Hours in Sonoma County
text: IF you’re looking for a chocolate pinot noir sauce, keep driving. The rustic region of Sonoma County may be a wine lovers’ playground, but it lacks many of the touristy trappings of its more upscale and better-known neighbor, Napa. Not that Sonomans are complaining. Cars have bumper stickers like “Kill your TV” and “Subvert the Dominant Paradigm,” and people here mean it. The freethinking tradition is being nurtured by a new generation of oenophiles who appreciate Sonoma’s low-key charms, filling its beautiful historic towns with upscale boutiques, art galleries and Old World-style restaurants.

headline: A Weekend in Sonoma County
text: Sonoma’s historic towns are less touristy than those of their more upscale neighbor, Napa.

headline: Hot Water Below Brings Pleasures Above in Germany

Like other parts of rural Germany, villages in this eastern state pop up every few miles. But here, distinctive flat boats float in river harbors. Country roads, lined with tall trees, cut through cucumber farms and marshes.

headline: Restaurant Review: Dining Room at the Dean Street Townhouse

headline: Drunk on His Own Notoriety
text: Vincent Cassel, the cocky, snake-eyed French actor with a prizefighter’s mug is so charismatic in “Mesrine,” a four-hour biography of the notorious French gangster Jacques Mesrine, that you can’t take your eyes off him. Mr. Cassel’s monumental performance fuses the cobralike menace of the young Robert Mitchum with the whipsaw, shape-shifting (from wiry to bulbous) volatility of classic Robert De Niro, and lightens it with a cat burglar’s grace and agility.

headline: London Underground | Dalston Renaissance
text: “Don’t go back to Dalston,” sang Johnny Borrell on Razorlight’s debut album in 2004. But by 2009 things had changed. The Guardian declared the northeast London neighborhood “the coolest place in Britain” by virtue of its young fashion-star residents, including Gareth Pugh and Christopher Kane; its club nights; and the arrival of the hot bar Dalston Superstore. A new train route has made Dalston easier than ever to get to, but at the same time, local urban projects are ensuring that the area does not become over-gentrified and providing new outdoor spaces for Londoners to enjoy.

headline: Federer Trick Shot Video Evokes One by Connors
text: Have you seen Roger Federer smashing a serve that knocks a bottle off the head of a technician in a British studio? “Don’t be nervous,” he tells the technician before hitting the ball.

headline: Afghan Candidate’s Campaign Workers Abducted
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Ten campaign workers for a female parliamentary candidate in western Afghanistan were abducted by gunmen Thursday and the Taliban claimed responsibility for two deadly attacks, one that killed eight Afghan police officers and another that killed two Spanish police trainers and a translator a day earlier.

headline: Letter: The Second Coming
text: Andrew Cuomo — though he may not campaign in the political poetry made famous by his philosopher-king paterfamilias — has it within his power to govern with the administrative élan of an innate problem-solver. And should he ascend to the throne of Albany, Cuomo the younger will surely avoid the blunders and moral pitfalls of Eliot Spitzer and David Paterson. Still, governing the Empire State has become as thorny as it is thankless. The perennially depressed upstate economy, a fractious Legislature and yawning budget deficits make New York nearly ungovernable. Yet while he lacks Mario Cuomo’s gravitas, Andrew Cuomo is preternaturally decisive. Such tenacity should serve him in good stead.

headline: Letter: Shift Paradigm
text: The Medium column about “smart keyboards” perpetuates a misleading legend about the qwerty layout: that it was done to reduce key jamming. The true story urges close minding by designers of new keys and layouts. The qwerty inventor, Christopher Sholes, relied on years of study with trial users to inform his eventually successful design. Critical among his findings was that maximizing alternation of hands on successive keys greatly speeds human use. Reducing key jamming was useful, too, but could have been done in many other ways. The moral of the story is that before making changes or additions to this wonderful and globally necessary device, the results concerning human usefulness and usability need to be empirically evaluated — something easily done but much too often neglected.

headline: Letters: Dumping Across the Digital Divide
text: I found Pieter Hugo’s photo portfolio appropriately haunting. All too frequently those of us living in technologically advanced countries want those in developing countries to have the technology we have. In many cases the countries we donate to are not ready for this technology. There are huge graveyards and dusty storerooms throughout underdeveloped countries that are full of useless equipment that have missing parts or that lack reusable components. Some equipment, in particular medical-diagnostic equipment, breaks down with no means of service. The organization I work with supplies medical and surgical supplies to the Fiji and Solomon Islands. We are very realistic about bringing these countries equipment that is infrastructure-appropriate. Gift giving is a wonderful thing, but that giving must be well thought out and responsible. The best gift we can give countries that wish to increase their level of technology is training in servicing and repairing what we send to them. That is sustainable technology.

headline: In Japan, Party Ex-Leader Will Challenge Premier
text: TOKYO  After just three months in office, Prime Minister Naoto Kan of Japan faces a challenge from a scandal-tainted power broker within his own party in a leadership race that could hamper the government’s response to a debilitating economic slowdown.

headline: Letter: My Life in Therapy
text: While I’m glad to know that Daphne Merkin (Aug. 8) has had positive experiences in psychoanalysis, much of what she describes — endless treatments without much progress, blame for being resistant rather than an analyst who also accepts responsibility for shortcomings, withholding clinicians who don’t acknowledge loving or other feelings — is typical of a more old-fashioned though still prevalent way of working. Contemporary psychoanalysis and in particular the school of thought that has come to be known as relational psychoanalysis emphasizes greater patient-analyst collaboration, the analyst’s selective self-disclosure and other techniques designed to address many of the concerns and limitations Merkin has experienced in her admirable quest to live a more contented life.

headline: Letters: The Copyright Enforcers
text: I am concerned that John Bowe’s article (Aug. 8) may leave the false impression on readers that all business owners are required to pay licensing fees for playing music in their establishments. The Fairness in Music Licensing Act, which was strongly opposed by Ascap, BMI and other performing-rights organizations, exempts certain business establishments from licensing fees. Under the act, small business establishments can play audio music from radio, television, cable or satellite sources without having to pay any licensing fee, provided that certain guidelines are met. This exemption is called the home-style exemption. Generally, to qualify for the home-style exemption, the business must use a consumer-style receiver and cannot transmit the music beyond its establishment or charge admission for listening to the music.

headline: Letters: I Tweet, Therefore I Am
text: I read Peggy Orenstein’s essay (Aug. 1) regarding Twitter and the letters in response to the article and felt compelled to write. I come from a developing country, where technology has more connotations than connectivity, and have found that it is important to be in the stream of people, if only virtually, before one can dwell on “know thyself.” In cities like Mumbai or remote villages in India with their sprawling inequality and islands of poverty, Twitter and other social-networking sites, for all their drawbacks with regards to privacy, intimacy and introspection, have provided a platform of equal sharing and have been silently revolutionary from the bottom up. Social-networking sites have gone a step ahead in expanding the notion of the self and democratizing the essence of the social consciousness. No doubt ruminations of the self and the complete attention to the joy of the moment are life’s DNA of emotional existence, but the Internet and social-networking sites can be a ladder in reaching that level of awareness for the entirety of humanity.

For $350 each month, she is guaranteed around-the-clock access to her doctor, appointments within 24 hours of calling, longer office visits and the kind of personalized attention and care coordination she felt was missing with all her previous doctors.

headline: I Get Around
text: Somewhere in the United States, there may be an attic containing the written remnants of a previously unchronicled 20th-century life that was even more astonishing than the one the writer Justin Spring discovered in San Francisco a few years ago. But even the most skeptical reader of his new book, “Secret Historian,” will have to admit that the bar is now set high. Samuel Steward, the subject of this absorbing act of biographical excavation, had many identities, including several that the subtitle of the book omits: pioneering sex researcher, collector of celebrity conquests, drug addict, masochist, Catholic (briefly), Navy enlistee (even more briefly), conquistador of vast provinces of America’s pre-Stonewall homosexual subculture. Most fortuitously, he was apparently a graphomaniac who documented his long, dark, exuberant, sad, dangerous life in journals, an unpublished memoir, reams of letters, poems, erotica, semifictionalized short stories and even a 746-entry card catalog of his sexual history, scrupulously maintained over five decades and in some cases ornamented — perhaps for future biographers? — with what Spring decorously calls “DNA-verifiable” evidence of his liaisons.

headline: Jama’s Travels
text: Nadifa Mohamed’s ambitious first novel tells the story of a Somali orphan’s odyssey from Yemen to Djibouti, onward to Eritrea, Sudan, Egypt, Palestine, Marseille, Hamburg and Wales — and ultimately to an epiphany in London. Toward the end of this trek, the hero meets up with an old friend, with whom he competes “over who had walked the farthest, starved the longest, felt the most hopeless; they were athletes in the hard-luck Olympics.” Earlier, at a bus stop in Gaza, the hero comes across someone who is everything he doesn’t want to be: Musa the Drunk, a homeless Somali man, “the poster boy of failed migration.” Both moments reveal the weaknesses in this young novelist’s phenomenal, fast-­forward story.

headline: Steam-Driven Dreams
text: Steam is cool. Or rather, hot: the technology that helped usher in the Industrial Revolution shows up these days in neo-nostalgic steampunk fiction, design and fashion. It’s not just affection for leather and brass that drives the fascination; harnessing the power of steam broke humans out of what William Rosen calls the “Malthusian trap” that had kept mankind ever on the brink of famine and collapse. His book, “The Most Powerful Idea in the World: A Story of Steam, Industry, and Invention,” is a sneaky history — ostensibly about the origins of the steam engine, though actually about much more.

headline: How to Send Your Son Off to College, Again
text: Evan is off. It’s different the second time. He and his Dad headed out on the nine-hour drive this morning, in the car he’s now allowed to keep on campus. His younger brother and I waved from the curb. No tears from me this year. Well, maybe one or two. But mostly the feeling that the calendar has turned another page, and he is one step further on his own journey.

headline: Does Your Language Shape How You Think?
text: Seventy years ago, in 1940, a popular science magazine published a short article that set in motion one of the trendiest intellectual fads of the 20th century. At first glance, there seemed little about the article to augur its subsequent celebrity. Neither the title, “Science and Linguistics,” nor the magazine, M.I.T.’s Technology Review, was most people’s idea of glamour. And the author, a chemical engineer who worked for an insurance company and moonlighted as an anthropology lecturer at Yale University, was an unlikely candidate for international superstardom. And yet Benjamin Lee Whorf let loose an alluring idea about language’s power over the mind, and his stirring prose seduced a whole generation into believing that our mother tongue restricts what we are able to think.

headline: Where Hatred Ruled
text: First, the facts. Willie McGee, an African-American driver of a ­grocery-delivery truck, was accused of raping a white woman, Willette Hawkins, in November 1945 in Laurel, Miss. After deliberating for less than three minutes, an all-white jury sentenced him to death, and the “small-town crime,” as Alex Heard writes, “became famous around the world.” Bella Abzug, long before she became a congress­woman, served as McGee’s defense lawyer during the appeals process, working on a case that today evokes the story line of Harper Lee’s “To Kill a Mockingbird.” Albert Einstein, Norman Mailer and Paul Robeson supported McGee, and left-wing journalists ranted about the trial in The Daily Worker. In contrast to their reports, “The Eyes of Willie McGee” does not crackle with rage, despite its horrific ending: on May 8, 1951, McGee was electrocuted in the local courthouse, leaving an odor of burned flesh in the room.

headline: Future World
text: Before he became a writer, Douglas Coupland (“Generation X,” “JPod”) studied art and design, so his current collaboration with the Canadian clothing company Roots is no surprise. Roots X Douglas Coupland, a collection of clothing, accessories and even furniture, stems from the Canadian writer’s interest in the way that electronic media have connected the far-flung provinces of his homeland. Among other things, the collection’s test-pattern logo is reproduced on hang tags and a T-shirt; a motherboard pattern adorns tights and a miniskirt; and tables (the Electric table, shown here, is $1,000) have legs inspired by Canada’s ubiquitous electrical transmission towers. The Paris retail mecca Colette has picked up the limited-supply collection, which goes on sale there Sept. 7. It’s also available at selected Roots stores in Canada, or at usa.roots.com.

These are set in that fraught period of European history starting in 1933, with Hitler’s rise to power, and ending in 1945. Though Furst is a native New Yorker, he lives some of the time in Paris and has adopted a European sensibility ­— perhaps aiming to evoke the atmosphere of his books, which have been compared to the works of John le Carré and Graham Greene.

The writer of Kids and director of the troubling art-house favorites Gummo, Julien Donkey-Boy, and most recently 2009’s Trash Humpers, was ideal, in their minds, to take on the theme of innocence they had explored in the clothes. The results will appear the first week in September on the Proenza Schouler website. We caught up with the designers and the filmmaker to see how it all went down.

headline: Postcards From My Literary Staycation
text: The last two summers, many cash-strapped Americans opted for a staycation: a slimmed-down getaway close to home. A staycation might take you to Cooperstown or Manassas or a town associated with luckless witches. But it would not take you to Machu Picchu or Venice.

headline: Up Front: John Simon

headline: The Language of Exile
text: The Czech novelist Milan ­Kundera’s new essayistic book, “Encounter,” his fourth, is alternatingly elegiac and celebratory. An émigré from the Communist horror of what was then Czechoslovakia, he settled in Paris and proceeded to write in French. But he discovered in France “the sense that we have come to the era of post-art, in a world where art is dying because the need for art, the sensitivity and the love for it, is dying.”
