headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE TENTH PARALLEL: Dispatches From the Fault Line Between Christianity and Islam,  by Eliza Griswold (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) A journey along a latitude line where two religions meet and often clash.

headline: Paperback Row
text: MASTERS OF SEX:  The Life and Times of William Masters and Virginia Johnson, the Couple Who Taught America How to Love, by Thomas Maier. (Basic Books, $18.95.) “Human Sexual Response,” published in 1966, attempted to analyze sex scientifically, and it debunked many myths (while introducing a few new ones). This biography explores the complicated and not especially happy lives of Masters and Johnson, for whom sex was part of the job description and love was elusive. THE EAST, THE WEST, AND SEX: A History, by Richard Bernstein. (Vintage, $16.) Bernstein searches for evidence that the vision of a sexualized East we know as Orientalism exists in reality in this “accessible, much-researched and far-reaching book,” as our reviewer, Toni Bentley, described it. Along the way he examines Marco Polo’s report on imperial concubines in the 14th century and the writings of Gustave Flaubert and Sir Richard Burton. However, he tends to gloss over the power imbalance between Western men and impoverished Eastern women.

headline: When Your Landlord Fights a Foreclosure Sale
text: Back in the October Bucks post “What to Do When Your Landlord Is Going Through Foreclosure,” I described how I came home to find a notice on our building’s front door, and another in our mailbox, saying the foreclosure process had begun on the property. So I did some research on what rights tenants have in such situations.

headline: Where It Hurts
text: A simple understanding of pain would be this: It’s a biological response to injury or disease. Treat the cause and the pain abates. The body, after all, is a relatively efficient machine. But what happens when the wound won’t heal? And what if pain doesn’t stem from injury or disease, but is itself the problem?

headline: Den of Antiquities
text: In a remarkable interlude in Willa Cather’s novel “The Professor’s House,” a New Mexico cowboy named Tom Outland describes climbing a landmark he calls Blue Mesa: “Far up above me, a thousand feet or so, set in a great cavern in the face of the cliff, I saw a little city of stone, asleep. It was as still as sculpture, . . . pale little houses of stone nestling close to one another, perched on top of each other, with flat roofs, narrow windows, straight walls, and in the middle of the group, a round tower. . . . I knew at once that I had come upon the city of some extinct civilization, hidden away in this inaccessible mesa for centuries.”

headline: Long Island Confidential
text: Here’s a formula I just learned: math teacher (hapless, feckless) plus stepdad (bloviating jackass) plus interloping cabal of unsavory characters equals a pleasingly odd and intelligent novel in the hands of Matthew Sharpe. Or maybe I should say in the prose of Matthew Sharpe. What’s most winning about “You Were Wrong,” Sharpe’s fourth novel, is its acumen and the brio with which his sentence-making bears it out. This book is rich with devastatingly comic observations about people, places and things — observations that fortify a novel whose subject and, well, whose stake in the horror and pathos of being alive seem flimsy in comparison.

headline: Revolutionary Road
text: A few blocks from my home in Westchester County lies Boston Post Road, a ribbon of retail dotted with Dunkin’ Donuts franchises, gas stations and drive-through banks. Indeed, for much of its span between New York and Boston, the Post Road is, in Eric Jaffe’s apt phrase, “a gluttonous commercial wild.” But in his valuable if uneven history, “The King’s Best Highway,” Jaffe burrows under the asphalt to reveal a thoroughfare of deeper distinction. Starting with its pastoral founding by American colonists, who exploited rocky, slippery paths that Indians had burned out of the wilderness, he tells how the road became the artery for an inchoate mail service, with loping riders carrying wax-sealed letters from tavern to tavern — the first post offices — and distributing newspapers that united the scattered colonists to revolt against the British. He traces the changes brought on by stagecoach, trolley, bicycle, reminding us that robust railroads led to the neglect of highways, until the automobile enabled the highways’ revenge.

headline: Hangover in a Strange Land
text: Writing comedy about foreign travel has become more challenging in the days since Mark Twain mocked the Moors of Tangier, and even since P. J. O’Rourke wrote in his 1986 essay “Among the Euro-Weenies” that the French are “a smallish, monkey-looking bunch and not dressed any better, on average, than the citizens of Baltimore.” Jokes at the expense of many nations are dicey, and Europe has a small safety zone that includes the Austrians and the French. Credit goes to David Sedaris for wringing the last possible shred of humor out of the American-in-Paris tale 10 years ago, in “Me Talk Pretty One Day.” At that point, travel writers probably should have banded together in one of those self-­regulating industry associations aimed at defusing public hostility and declared a moratorium on wisecracks about Old Europe.

headline: New York’s Huckleberry Friend
text: BACK in Hannibal, Mo., Jane Clemens had no idea that her 17-year-old son, Sam, her sixth child, had gone so far East to be a journeyman printer. She was surprised by a letter, his earliest known to survive, postmarked Aug. 24, 1853:

headline: Her Darkest Places
text: Near the end of Shirley Jackson’s most famous novel, “The Haunting of Hill House,” the heroine, a lonely young woman named Eleanor, thinks to herself, “What I want in all this world is peace, a quiet spot to lie and think, a quiet spot up among the flowers where I can dream and tell myself sweet stories.” And Eleanor does dream, but the stories, for her as for her creator, are rarely sweet. The very welcome Library of America edition of Jackson’s work, edited by Joyce Carol Oates, contains, in addition to “Hill House,” 46 of her short stories, another novel — her last, “We Have Always Lived in the Castle” — and an essay on the furious reactions to the magazine publication of her peerlessly disturbing 1948 tale “The Lottery.” Although few of the narratives collected here are as terrifying as “Hill House” or as shocking as “The Lottery” (which is about an exceptionally nasty small-town ritual), there’s precious little comfort in any of them. They’re quiet, usually, told in calm, precise, scrupulously unsensational prose, but peace of the kind for which poor Eleanor yearns is always elusive. There’s none apparent in the wide world — Jackson wrote at the height of the cold war, when anxiety was general, even fashionable. The first story in the book, “The Intoxicated,” is about a 17-year-old girl who sobers up an inebriated party­goer with a coolly imagined vision of the end of civilization: “Maybe there’ll be a law,” she speculates, “not to live in houses, so then no one can hide from anyone else, you see.” And Jackson knew too well that there’s not much peace in houses, either: no place, anywhere, to hide.

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: Movies

headline: Nuclear Family
text: “As he crossed the street time cracked open before him and he saw a way to the future, death into the world and all our woe, the shape of things to come.” The date of this revelation was 1933; “he” is the physicist Leo Szilard; time cracked open because he had just realized how to initiate a nuclear chain reaction.

headline: Bruce Springsteen Illuminates ‘Darkness On the Edge of Town’
text: More than three decades after Bruce Springsteen first advised us that there’s a spot out ’neath Abram’s Bridge and a darkness on the edge of town, you would think that maybe circumstances had changed. But no: the darkness remains on the edge of town, and yet somehow it’s gotten bigger. On Thursday Columbia Records said it was preparing two releases commemorating Mr. Springsteen’s 1978 album, “Darkness on the Edge of Town,” and containing rare materials from its recording sessions. On Nov. 16, the label will put out “The Promise: The ‘Darkness on the Edge of Town’ Story,” a boxed set containing three CDs and three DVDs that include a remastered version of the album, 21 previously unreleased songs, a 1978 concert by Mr. Springsteen in Houston and a documentary film about the album. On Nov. 14 Columbia will also release a two-disc set called “The Promise” that contains the previously unheard songs from the album.

headline: Inside the List
text: WISH YOU WERE DEAD: As Sweden goes, so goes the United States, at least when it comes to thrillers. “The Postcard Killers,” a collaboration between James Patterson and the Swedish crime writer Liza Marklund, hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 1, five months after it topped the charts in the Land of Larsson in Patterson’s first experiment with an out-of-town tryout. The story takes off in Stockholm, where a Swedish journalist receives one in a series of postcards from picturesque European locales indicating where a pair of vicious killers will strike next. She then forms an odd-couple team with a stoic American detective (and father of one of the victims) and starts tearing around in search of the evildoers. Sound familiar? Patterson and Marklund have insisted they started planning their joint venture before Lisbeth Salander got her “No. 1 global best seller” tattoo.

headline: Footnote
text: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has announced the appointment of two new co-directors for the Ailey School, its training academy. Tracy Inman and Melanie Person will take over its leadership, a role previously held by Denise Jefferson, the longtime director, who died last month. Mr. Inman and Ms. Person have served as co-directors of the school’s junior division and associate directors of the Ailey School.

headline: Heart of Iowa as Fault Line of Egg Recall
text: CLARION, Iowa  The scrambled eggs, as always, were hissing in a skillet on a recent morning at a coffee shop here, in an egg-producing county that has suddenly found itself at the center of the nation’s egg recall over salmonella. But the conversation at the weekly gathering of local ladies turned uncharacteristically tense.

headline: Bridge Project’s ‘richard Iii,’ Starring Spacey, In Brooklyn
text: Brooklyn, no stranger to schemers, misfits and would-be Machiavellis, had better make room for one more. On Thursday the Bridge Project  the theater collaboration among the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Old Vic Theater in London and the British production company Neal Street  said it would bring a new staging of Shakespeare’s “Richard III” to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2012 for the project’s final season. Not content to serve solely as the artistic director of the Old Vic, Kevin Spacey, above, will play the lead in the production, directed by Sam Mendes. Representatives for the Bridge Project said the play would run at the Harvey Theater, February through April, then embark on a short international tour before its transfer to the Old Vic from May through August, followed by a longer tour. Additional casting is still to be announced.

headline: ‘Talent’ Again Pushes NBC to Top
text: The first 5 of the Top 10 performers were selected to advance on Wednesday’s edition of “America’s Got Talent” as 10.3 million viewers tuned in to the NBC reality show, according to Nielsen’s estimates, lifting the network to No. 1 in the night’s ratings, compensating for NBC’s more modest results with the game show “Minute to Win It” at 8 (6.3 million) and rerun of “Law & Order: SVU” at 10 (5.6 million). CBS placed second, drawing its best ratings at 8 with “Big Brother,” which earned its most viewers in almost a year (7.9 million). At 9 and 10, CBS broadcast repeats of “Criminal Minds” (6.6 million) and “CSI: NY” (6.2 million). Fox was third with a two-hour “MasterChef” from 8 to 10 (5.1 million) while ABC was fourth with reruns.

headline: Dance New Amsterdam’s Reprieve
text: Eviction proceedings against Dance New Amsterdam, a dance space in Lower Manhattan, scheduled for Thursday have been postponed until Sept. 27, its executive director, Catherine Peila, said. Dance New Amsterdam subleases space in a city-owned building at 280 Broadway from Fram Realty, which holds a commercial lease on the building. The organization owes Fram more than $500,000 in back rent. Ms. Peila said Dance New Amsterdam was in talks with the landlord and hoping for reduced rent, maybe through allowances from the city or a nonprofit tax abatement. Asked if the city was playing a role in negotiations or if it would reduce Fram’s rent to help, Jennifer Blum, a spokeswoman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, which manages the city’s real estate, said in a statement that “the sublease between Fram and D.N.A. is a private transaction that the city was and is not a party to.” Fram Realty did not return phone calls.

headline: Hurd’s $30 Million Farewell From H.P.
text: After being kicked out of Hewlett-Packard, Mark V. Hurd is cashing out.

headline: Lawrence Wright’s Gaza, Onstage
text: Lawrence Wright, the Pulitzer Prize-winning New Yorker writer, has developed a second career as a playwright and performer. His last play, “My Trip to Al-Qaeda,” had a successful run at the Culture Project in 2007 and has been made into a documentary film that will have its premiere on HBO Sept. 7. Now he has a new play, “The Human Scale,” based on his reporting in Gaza, which he will perform Oct. 2 to 31. A co-production of the Public Theater and 3-Legged Dog, “The Human Scale” will be directed by the Public’s artistic director, Oskar Eustis, and performed at 3-Legged Dog’s home at 80 Greenwich Street in Lower Manhattan. The company avoided eviction by reaching a deal this week with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, its landlord, to pay overdue rent.

headline: Will Forte to Leave ‘SNL’
text: It looks like MacGruber has accidentally detonated his last explosive device for now. Will Forte, the longtime “Saturday Night Live” cast member who portrayed that incompetent adventurer among other eccentric characters, will not be returning to “SNL” when that NBC late-night series begins its 36th season this fall. In an e-mail a representative for Mr. Forte, right, said he offered thanks to his colleagues and the “Saturday Night Live” producer Lorne Michaels, writing: “After eight great seasons, Will has made the decision to move on from ‘SNL’ to pursue new opportunities. He is eternally grateful to Lorne and all of the incredible people he worked with over the years.” Mr. Forte joined “Saturday Night Live” in its 2002-3 season.

headline: Chloé Exit
text: Richemont, the parent company of Chloé, has not commented on news reports that Ralph Toledano has been dismissed as chief executive of the Paris-based fashion house, but people familiar with the company say he has indeed left.

headline: Ozawa To Limit His Work In Return Appearances
text: The conductor Seiji Ozawa, above, said on Thursday that he had successfully completed a treatment for esophageal cancer, but that his continuing recovery would require him to curtail his appearances at the Saito Kinen Festival Matsumoto in Japan next month. Mr. Ozawa, who in January announced that he had cancer and has canceled several months’ worth of dates while he recovers from surgery, said in a statement that his doctor “has declared that I am completely cancer free at this time.” But he added that the doctor had told him not to stand on a podium for long periods because of a sciatic problem that Mr. Ozawa wrote had “gotten much worse, since I was not able to move my body while recovering from the operation.” Mr. Ozawa said he would not conduct two orchestra programs at the festival, where he is to make his return appearance on Sept. 5, and would conduct only the first movement of Tchaikovsky’s “String Serenade” at the start of each concert. (The movement runs about 10 minutes.) Mr. Ozawa said he hoped to make a full recovery in time for his scheduled appearances at Carnegie Hall in December.

headline: Smuggler Caught With Real Cub Amid Toy Tigers
text: Hooray for Thailand’s airport baggage screeners.

headline: Family Swimming and Live Music
text: Sometimes, it takes a village to have fun, or at least a community center.

headline: A Closer Look at Alaska
text: Joe Miller is not yet assured of victory over Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska: With just 1,668 votes separating the candidates, the official result may not be known until September when at least 7,600 absentee ballots are counted. But a victory for Mr. Miller is considerably more likely than not, and even if he were to fall a few votes short, the election will have been far closer than anyone anticipated.

headline: A Fix for Bare Walls
text: The first thing you need to know when entering Philip Williams Posters is the definition of the word “poster.” A poster, at least according to Philip Williams, is not necessarily a lithograph or an art print or a reproduction.

headline: An Autopsy of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: Here’s a last-minute option for summer reading material: An autopsy on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac by their overseer, the Federal Housing Finance Agency.

headline: Sitting, or Selling? The $3 Million Threshold
text: PATIENCE, they tell us, is a virtue. The housing market has required that virtue in saintly proportions over much of the last two years. But in the city market, the pace has quickened a bit, allowing some New Yorkers to return to their customary haste.

headline: Andrew Romanoff’s Birthday Wish List
text: Andrew Romanoff’s campaign to unseat Senator Michael Bennet in a Democratic primary in Colorado earlier this month not only fell short, it also seems to be carrying a fair amount of debt.

headline: Grownups Dig in the Sand, Too
text: ON any given weeknight, lawyers, garment company executives, recent college graduates and other impressively fit men of all ages, sizes and ethnicities gather between the Sheep Meadow and the Mall in Central Park to play in the sand. This is beach volleyball, minus the beach.

headline: On the High Seas, a Mix of Danger and Bumbling High Jinks
text: Reality television can be rough. There are shows in which you can bounce off a big rubber ball and fall into a trough of dirty water. There are shows in which you can be attacked by an alligator, or by Simon Cowell.

headline: Kremlin Relents, for Now, to Foes of Highway
text: MOSCOW — For years, environmentalists have risked arrests and sometimes beatings by the police and masked plainclothes thugs in their efforts to halt the construction of a highway linking Moscow to St. Petersburg that they say would destroy the Khimki Forest, one of the few remaining in the Moscow region.

headline: Wind Turbine Projects Run Into Resistance
text: BARSTOW, Calif.  The United States military has found a new menace hiding here in the vast emptiness of the Mojave Desert in California: wind turbines.

headline: On Our Radar: A Fire Tornado
text: A rare fire tornado whips through the Brazilian city of Aracatuba, in drought-plagued Sao Paulo state. [The Herald Sun]

headline: Obama and the Jews, Part 2
text: Last Saturday in my column “Oy Vey, Obama,” I pointed out the following fact:

headline: AT&T and Crown Media Squabble Over Hallmark Channel
text: For the second time this summer, AT&T is fighting a carriage fee dispute in public days before a contract deadline.

headline: Ireland And Spain, Revisited
text: A couple of months back I asked, does fiscal austerity actually reassure markets? I noted there the curious case of Ireland, which embraced savage austerity early on; quite a few press reports declared that this had gained it the confidence of markets, but the actual numbers said otherwise. And I noted the contrast with Spain, which has been relatively slow and reluctant to embrace austerity, but has been treated no worse by investors.

headline: Thrift Shop Finds a Green Role for Used Film Props
text: ON a recent steamy morning Liz Minot stood on the second floor of an industrial building in Long Island City, Queens, the flea-market-like space around her stuffed with thousands of objects. She was unpacking boxes, and out of one came an enormous vegetable peeler, at least a foot long. Then a huge kitchen whisk.

text: Click to Listen

headline: Five and Five: No. 10, Florida
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 10, is Florida. You can find a larger Florida preview here.

headline: Intense Discussion Prompted Meyer to Reconsider
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — By now, the story of Urban Meyer’s return to the Florida’s sideline has become familiar. He stepped down, went to practice the next day and became inspired to come back after watching his team.

headline: Super Cars Inspire Mixed Feelings in London
text: LONDON  With his canary yellow Ferrari at rest in the forecourt of one of the most expensive hotels in London’s upscale West End, its eight-cylinder, race-bred engine burbling, a young Arab man who gave his name as Khalefa spoke with whimsical regret about the array of even faster, more expensive super cars parked nearby that belonged to other young men like himself from the Persian Gulf oil states.

headline: Al, All Of The Time
text: For tomorrow’s column.

headline: Borrowing by Euro Zone Companies Falls 1.3%
text: FRANKFURT  Borrowing by companies in the euro zone fell at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in July, the European Central Bank said Thursday, in a reminder that economic activity has not returned to normal despite record growth in Germany.

headline: House Tour: Garrison, N.Y.
Restoring the Studio of a Meticulous Sculptor
text: Daniel Chester French, the sculptor best known for the saddened seated president portrayed in the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, lived tidily in studios full of plaster dust and stone chips. He wore a jacket and tie while sculpturing at his homes in Greenwich Village and the Berkshires. He kept meticulous records of his trips abroad, modeling and casting processes and clients’ payments of tens of thousands of dollars for statues of politicians, soldiers and goddesses.

headline: F.T.C. Drops LimeWire Investigation
text: LimeWire, the file-sharing service found liable for copyright infringement in May, has received a bit of good news.

headline: Emerald Deities of Fervor and Flux
text: WASHINGTON  “From whatever vantage point we look, if we are prepared to look historically, civilizations reveal themselves to be processes and not things.” These true words by Sheldon Pollock, a scholar of Sanskrit and Indian history at Columbia University, also apply to art.

headline: Safety in Numbers? Not for This Heroine
text: The ingredients of Kevin Guilfoile’s fast and furious new thriller will be familiar to many readers:

headline: ‘The Thousand’
Who’s the Voyeur Now, Picasso?
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  Degas and Picasso make an odd couple, a Realist-Impressionist and a restless Modernist born nearly 50 years apart. But their relationship, as seen through the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute’s “Picasso Looks at Degas,” isn’t the tempestuous kind typical of blockbuster shows. Neither a partnership (“Picasso and Degas”) nor a competition (“Picasso/Degas”), it’s about one artist regarding another, calmly and from a distance.

headline: Miami Mayor Rethinks Marlins’ Parking Deal
text: Perhaps too little, too late, Mayor Tomas Regalado of Miami on Thursday asked the city attorney to look into whether the city could reopen its contract to build a parking garage for the Florida Marlins.

headline: Fehr Won’t Discuss Union Job
text: TORONTO  Donald Fehr has declined to confirm or deny reports that he has agreed to become the next executive director of the N.H.L. Players’ Association.

headline: Korea's Human Convection Ovens
text: Roasting inside a charcoal kiln has become something of a craze in South Korea these days.

headline: When Stoic Samurai Faced the Camera
text: It’s obvious from the start that “Samurai in New York” isn’t going to be about robed warriors taking the city, in spite of the sensational name. The show’s subtitle  “The First Japanese Delegation, 1860”  makes that pretty clear, and the introductory wall text spells it out: The visit in question, 150 years ago, was “all about trade,” a matter of setting up a business agreement.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: The Pakistani Taliban called the presence of foreign relief workers in their flood-ravaged country “unacceptable” on Thursday and suggested that militants could carry out attacks against members of aid groups, Salman Masood reported. Any violence would add strain to relief efforts that have been slow to reach the millions of Pakistanis uprooted by the worst flooding in the country’s history. A spokesman for the United Nations dismissed the threats, saying that its aid work remained unaffected by security worries. But the United States State Department said it was concerned that militants “may well” attack foreign aid workers or Pakistani government officials trying to help flood victims.

headline: Kiln Saunas Make a Comeback in South Korea
text: HOENGSEONG, SOUTH KOREA — In the relative cool of midnight, Seo Seok-gu’s workers break the seals on the kilns and, using long steel hooks, drag out what remains of the oak logs that were inserted a week before and have by now turned into smoldering charcoal. It gives off a hypnotic glow Mr. Seo calls “my flower.” The temperatures inside the clay domes reach up to 1,400 degrees Celsius.

headline: Have Your Brunch and Listen to It, Too
text: WEEKEND brunch is a luxurious, late-morning salve, a counterpoint to no-nonsense weekday breakfasts devoured on subway platforms or half-chewed while reading e-mail. Hangovers are tended to with syrup-soaked pancakes and jam-slathered toast, as diners drift gently into a not-unpleasant carbohydrate haze. (It helps that brunch is also one of the rare instances in which it’s acceptable — encouraged, even — to slurp a cocktail at noon.)

headline: Forgetting of Things Past: A Duet Off-Key
text: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — “The Memory Show,” which recently opened at Barrington Stage Company here, is a musical in search of a melody. That is what it intends to be. In shaping a portrait of a mother with Alzheimer’s disease and the angry, impotent daughter who cares for her, the young composer Zach Redler has written a score that follows the patterns of minds grasping, often in vain, for clarity, conviction and lost time.

headline: Netflix Now Playing on an iPhone Near You
text: Netflix has been streaming movies for instant viewing of movies for some time on PCs and game machines. As of Thursday, Netflix is on the iPhone as well.

headline: Israeli Actors Boycott Theater in Settlement
text: Updated | Friday | 8:52 a.m. Two Israeli actors have announced that they will not travel with the country’s national theater company to perform in a new cultural center nearing completion in the West Bank settlement of Ariel.

headline: Barrichello’s 300th Grand Prix
text: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS — The summer break has finally ended and Formula One has arrived in rainy Spa for the seven-race countdown to the end of the season. But it is the count of the number of races that Rubens Barrichello has participated in that is the talk of the paddock today.

headline: Complaint Box | M.V.P., Most Vacuous Praise
text: The parents and players on my 7-year-old son’s baseball team assembled near the pitcher’s mound on a recent Saturday. Under a blazing sun, the boys lined up to receive a handshake from the coach, a trophy and an entreaty to smile from their camera-toting parents.

headline: Girls, Bedrooms and the Devil
text: A look at three films that get their chills from innocent girls possessed.

headline: Charges Settled Over Fake Reviews on iTunes
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Discerning Internet users know that glowing online reviews of things like books or restaurants cannot always be trusted. But federal regulators are serving notice that if you stand to gain financially from the review you are writing, you should be upfront about it.

headline: Streetscapes | Avery Architectural Library
text: A new online collection of real estate brochures at Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library of Columbia University casts light on how developers approached their markets.

headline: Taking a Long, Cool Look at Both Sides of the Law
text: If there were such a thing as GQ Jr. or Esquire for Kids — a young-dude analogue for magazines like Seventeen or Teen Vogue — it might be something like “Takers,” a primer in juvenile, aspirational cool for guys who might not be able to handle the suavity of the “Oceans 11” franchise or the leathery angst of “The Expendables.”

headline: The Persuasive Pamphlets of Another Time
text: “THIS apartment will sell itself!” But few of them really do. Nearly as soon as the apartment was invented, so, too, was the sales brochure, ranging from the simplest of floor plans to color photos of the lap pool and the French concierge.

headline: Till Death Does She Part
text: I divorced a few years ago, after a 23-year marriage, and recently remarried. But my sisters remain close with my ex-wife. They spent time with her during the weekend of my wedding and invited her to my nephew’s bar mitzvah. I’ve expressed displeasure in having to see my ex-wife at family celebrations when I no longer wish to, and I told them that their relationship with her is preventing them from becoming closer with my new wife. They appear indifferent. What should I do?

headline: All Kiss-and-Tell and Wink-and-Nod at a Crowded Dinner Party
text: Quite a lot happens in “Change of Plans,” Danièle Thompson’s crowded comedy about a Paris dinner party and its aftermath. There are (in no particular order) near- and actual divorces, last-minute reconciliations, a terrible accident and a miraculous cure, a secret marriage and a surprise pregnancy. Mostly, there is marital infidelity, which seems to come as naturally to the middle-aged, middle-class French couples who populate the film as shopping for goat cheese or going for a medical checkup.

headline: In the Latest Religious Battle, a Call to Arms for Mother Teresa
text: On the 26th of August 90 years ago, American women won the right to vote with the adoption of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution. That step toward a more perfect union was honored in New York style on Thursday night when the Empire State Building bathed its upper floors in lights of red, white and blue.

headline: Terror Suspect’s ‘Canadian Idol’ Audition Tape Returns to Haunt Him
text: The Toronto Star reported on Thursday that a suspected member of an Ontario terror cell who was arrested on Thursday appeared on national television in 2008, as a failed contestant for the reality game show “Canadian Idol.”

headline: With the Help of a Gangly Giant, Tottenham Is on the Move Again
text: LONDON

headline: Mourinho's Arrival Adds Fizz to Spain's 2-Horse Race
text: MADRID — Upon joining Real Madrid last week, Mesut Ozil, the German midfielder of Turkish descent, was asked in his welcome news conference whether he was observing the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

headline: Young Love, Back When It Was Sweet and Innocent
text: Suburban America in the late 1950s and early ’60s as depicted in “Flipped,” Rob Reiner’s sentimental ode to puppy love in that innocent era, might as well be another world, for all its resemblance to the one we live in today. Mind you, it isn’t paradise. But as the movie’s soundtrack of golden oldies unwinds in the background, you can’t help being struck by the romantic optimism and modesty of early rock ’n’ roll ditties cranked out in the years before the term high-tech entered the vocabulary.

headline: A Newspaper Apologizes to United Nations’ Climate Chief
text: Last December, Britain’s Sunday Telegraph newspaper published a 2,000-word article accusing Rajendra Pachauri, the chairman of the United Nations’ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, of potential financial conflicts of interest.

headline: Knicks Wrap Up Youthful Roster but May Be Without Azubuike
text: Landry Fields signed his rookie contract Thursday, completing a Knicks roster that is younger, deeper and more talented than any recent edition. It comes, however, with one minor asterisk.

headline: Two Vastly Different Enemies Share a Common Thirst for Blood
text: From the heaving mass of carnage in Neil Marshall’s galumphing, atavistic gorefest, “Centurion,” a cautionary message struggles to escape. Beware of overreaching, ye imperialists. The indigenous people of whatever region you presume to conquer know the territory a thousand times better than you do and will eventually prevail.

headline: Panel Presses BP on Its Safety Record
text: HOUSTON  Federal investigators pressed senior BP officials on Thursday about whether the company had a troubled record of safety problems even before the Deepwater Horizon oil rig disaster.

headline: Critic Gets to See How the Other Half Squirms
text: For years, the sports columnist Jay Mariotti has cultivated a self-righteous and divisive personality that turned him into a local star at the Chicago Sun-Times and then a national voice at AOL FanHouse and ESPN.

headline: Loosening the Devil’s Grip in Louisiana
text: The Devil is in the entrails in “The Last Exorcism,” an unusually restrained and genuinely eerie little movie perched at the intersection of faith, folklore and female puberty.

headline: Months After Marathon Match, Mahut Still Has Far to Go
text: His back aches, his legs are sore and he requires far more sleep than his schedule permits. But two months after he lost the longest tennis match in history, Nicolas Mahut is being asked to play extra tennis this week.

headline: Some of His Dreams Have Come True, but Taylor Keeps Dreaming
text: PARAMUS, N.J. — The beginning of the FedEx Cup playoffs means different things to different players. Some of the major players have their eye on the $10 million jackpot at the end of the final playoff event, while others are closing their eyes and dreaming.

headline: Germany: Singer Is Convicted for Transmitting H.I.V.
text: A German court on Thursday convicted a musician of causing bodily harm to an ex-boyfriend for having unprotected sex with him though she knew she was infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The singer, Nadja Benaissa, 28, who performed with the band No Angels, avoided prison, receiving a two-year suspended sentence because she expressed deep remorse throughout the trial in Darmstadt, in the western portion of the country, German news agencies reported. Her former boyfriend said she infected him during a brief relationship they had in 2004. A German court ruling in 1988 made it a crime for a person aware of having H.I.V. to not inform a sexual partner of his or her condition. Offenders face up to 10 years in prison, and courts here have handed out lengthy terms.

headline: Acrimony Behind the Scenes of Gulf Oil Spill
text: This article is by  Clifford Krauss, Henry Fountain and John M. Broder.

headline: This Is Not a Recovery
text: What will Ben Bernanke, the Fed chairman, say in his big speech Friday in Jackson Hole, Wyo.? Will he hint at new steps to boost the economy? Stay tuned.

headline: Agent Wanted Backup Charge in Synagogue Bomb Case, Defense Says
text: Worried that an investigation was going cold, a special agent in charge of a case in which four people were later accused of plotting to blow up synagogues in the Bronx appeared to suggest that the F.B.I. needed a backup plan: gun charges against the suspected leader, according to e-mail read on Thursday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Maligned FEMA Chief Visits New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS  “Put yourself in my shoes,” said Michael Brown. “You’ve just come out of a meeting where you’ve just told your boss that nothing’s working, I can’t make stuff happen, state and local government aren’t doing what they need to do, the federal government isn’t doing what it needs to do, things are bad. And he comes out and tells me I’m doing a heck of a job?”

headline: Rain Turns First Round Into Day of Target Practice
text: PARAMUS, N.J. When Tiger Woods teed off Thursday in the first round of the Barclays at 7:10 a.m., it was long before the grandstands filled with spectators and television coverage began. But more significantly, it was long before the sun rose high in the sky and started to dry out the rain-soaked Ridgewood Country Club course.

headline: Gay Bush Aide? No Bombshell in Age of Fiscal Cares
text: Had a former chairman of the Republican National Committee announced in 2004 that he was gay, it would have been a bombshell. In that hard-fought election year, Republicans and Democrats were rushing to condemn a court for establishing the right to same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.

headline: For Once, Hope in the Middle East
text: Washington

headline: A Family Brand With Big Dreams for Its Soy Milk
text: THE cola wars were so 20th century. Now, Madison Avenue is leading the charge in a series of battles involving food products that are meant to be perceived as healthier fare.

headline: Nine Justices and Ten Commandments
text: While the politically manipulated controversy over the proposed Islamic center in Lower Manhattan will eventually end, there is one dispute over religious symbolism and identity that remains, apparently, endless. I’m referring to the continuing effort by state and local governments to post the Ten Commandments in public places.

headline: Facing Long Mine Rescue, Chile Spares No Expense
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile  The government has consulted NASA about the extreme isolation of space. Chilean Navy officers have come to discuss the emotional stress of living in a submarine. Doctors stand at the ready with antidepressants. Even a tiny home theater is being funneled down in plastic tubes to occupy the 33 miners stuck in their subterranean home.

headline: Legacy of Torture
text: The Bush administration insisted that “enhanced interrogation techniques”  torture  were necessary to extract information from prisoners and keep Americans safe from terrorist attacks. Never mind that it was immoral, did huge damage to this country’s global standing and produced little important intelligence. Now, as we had feared, it is also making it much harder to try and convict accused terrorists.

headline: The Egg Scare and Beyond
text: The recent problems with salmonella-contaminated eggs is a reminder of how much more needs to be done to keep dangerous germs out of the American food supply. The Food and Drug Administration should urge egg producers to vaccinate their hens promptly. The Senate must pass long-stalled legislation that could strengthen the hand of regulators to prevent and control outbreaks of all food-related illnesses.

headline: Islamic Center Also Challenges a Young Builder
text: Sharif el-Gamal is a relative newcomer to the New York City real estate business. He got his broker’s license in 2002. He is developing two condominium projects: turning a building in TriBeCa into six lofts, and planning apartments on what is now a West Side parking lot. He comes from the well-off family of a bank executive, but not from real estate billions.

headline: A Big Surprise: Troubled Assets Garner Rewards
text: American taxpayers are already poised to make unexpected billions from rescuing the nation’s banks. Now, they could reap another sizable profit from a government program devised to purge troubled real estate assets from the financial system.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Truth and the Troubles
text: Northern Ireland is finally hearing long denied and much needed truths. In June, a reinvestigation finally set the record straight on the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre, in which British troops opened fire on a Catholic civil rights march in Londonderry, killing 14 unarmed people and wounding 13. Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain won deserved plaudits for his forthright apology.

headline: A Looking Glass Steer
text: Being a farm kid used to be simpler. That was our thought upon learning that this year’s grand champion steer at the Iowa State Fair’s 4-H Market Beef competition is a clone of the 2008 grand champion steer. This year’s winner  who weighs 1,320 pounds and is named Doc  was “conceived” from an ear punch taken from his esteemed predecessor. The result was a cloned bull that was then neutered to produce Doc the steer.

headline: Yankees’ New Boss Determined to Carry On
text: Hank Steinbrenner brought to mind the image of the Boss as he barked at his players to get onto the stage for a news conference. “Let’s go!” he said.

headline: Fleeing Mideast Dictator’s Unscheduled Stop
text: The premise had promise, but “Baghdad, Texas,” a clumsy comedy directed by David H. Hickey, quickly disappoints with an inconsistent tone and painful overacting.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 26
text: Tiger Woods played like the Tiger of old, there was fierce competition on the badminton courts of Paris and Manny Ramirez forgot to was his batting helmet, all during an action-packed day of sports.

headline: Struggling Cities Shut Firehouses in Budget Crisis
text: SAN DIEGO  Fire departments around the nation are cutting jobs, closing firehouses and increasingly resorting to “rolling brownouts” in which they shut different fire companies on different days as the economic downturn forces many cities and towns to make deep cuts that are slowing their responses to fires and other emergencies.

headline: I.R.S. to Drop Suit Against UBS Over Tax Havens
text: The Internal Revenue Service said Thursday that it would drop a closely watched civil lawsuit against the Swiss bank giant UBS after the Swiss government said it was on course to hand over details on thousands of American clients suspected of using their accounts to evade taxes.

headline: Developer of Tablets Loses Apple as Customer
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple severed ties with a small Silicon Valley design firm that for nearly a decade had helped with the development of some of its products, after the firm showcased its own prototype tablet computer.

headline: With Tejada Struggling, Castillo Finds Mets Still Have a Role for Him
text: Mets Manager Jerry Manuel abides by a philosophy that dictates that the lineup be determined by what gives his team the best chance to win on a given day. That decision is magnified when it comes to his second baseman.

headline: Stryker Settles Case That Claimed Deception
text: The Stryker Corporation, a maker of artificial hips and knees, will pay $1.35 million to settle claims that it marketed items without regulatory approval and misled health care providers about the use of its products, the Massachusetts attorney general said Thursday.

headline: A Trauma in Peru
text: As tense as a clenched fist and just as communicative, Fausta (Magaly Solier), the heroine of “The Milk of Sorrow,” scuttles around her mountainside neighborhood in Lima, peering from beneath bangs like guillotine blades. Her mother has just died, leaving Fausta with a deathbed song of rape and violence suffered during “the terrors,” Peru’s decades of civil strife. As a defense against similar violations — and, indeed, any sexual connection — Fausta has blocked her vagina with a potato, oblivious to the physical consequences.

headline: Pursuing an Asian Health Network
text: SINGAPORE  No matter how healthy or rich Asian economies are, one thing is certain: Asians will never stop getting sick.

headline: The Parent Model
text: During the first half of this year, German and American political leaders engaged in an epic debate. American leaders argued that the economic crisis was so bad, governments should borrow billions to stimulate growth. German leaders argued that a little short-term stimulus was sensible, but anything more was near-sighted. What was needed was not more debt, but measures to balance budgets and restore confidence.

headline: Hot Spots: Homages
text: Are the political ad writers channeling Quentin Tarantino these days? Over the past week, we’ve noticed an unusual number of spots that fall under the category of “homage.”

headline: Immigration Agency Ends Some Deportations
text: Immigration enforcement officials have started to cancel the deportations of thousands of immigrants they have detained, a policy they said would pare huge case backlogs in the immigration courts.

headline: Estimate Lowered of Typical Flu Toll
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday substantially lowered its often-quoted estimate of how many people die in a typical flu season, to 24,000 from 36,000.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,230 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Aw, Wilderness!
text: San Jose, Calif.

headline: A Risk for Cancer Patients
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rebuilding Our Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paterson Misled Inquiry Over Tickets, Report Says
text: Gov. David A. Paterson misled state investigators about his acceptance of free tickets to the World Series last year, according to the independent counsel, Judith S. Kaye, who has asked the Albany County district attorney to determine whether Mr. Paterson should be charged with perjury.

headline: Pakistan Flood Sets Back Infrastructure by Years
text: SUKKUR, Pakistan  Men waded waist deep all week wedging stones with their bare hands into an embankment to hold back Pakistan’s surging floodwaters. It was a rudimentary and ultimately vain effort to save their town. On Thursday, the waters breached the levee, a demoralizing show of how fragile Pakistan’s infrastructure remains, and how overwhelming the task is to save it.

headline: A Teenage Zombie Crush
text: A zombie movie like no other, “Make-Out With Violence” uses an undead crush to explore one of our most wrenching transitions: that long, hot summer between high school and adulthood.

headline: Keeping Score: The Number Beyond M.V.P. Numbers
text: At the end of August, the narratives around baseball’s top awards have formed, and the contenders are jockeying for position for the stretch run. The 60 writers who vote for these awards have their reasons for how they vote, but as a body they often favor runs batted in leaders on playoff teams for the Most Valuable Player awards.

headline: Pakistan’s Progress Is Lost in Floodwaters
text: Pakistani and international relief officials despaired that the nation’s worst natural calamity had ruined just about every physical strand that knit the country together.

headline: Siblings in Mexico City, Criminally Exploited
text: Based on a true story and unfolding, we are told in the film’s opening moments, “exactly as it happened,” “Daniel & Ana” takes a dispassionate look at the aftermath of a particularly heinous crime.

headline: Things Pieced Together
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE NOTES — This is a pretty remarkable achievement, stacking a pair of full-width, two-line phrases in a grid. These are the sort of harebrained ideas that constructors try from time to time, usually destined for the file of near misses, but Corey Rubin made this one work.

headline: Cleveland Museum Names Director
text: The Cleveland Museum of Art has named David Franklin, currently the deputy director of the National Gallery of Canada, as its new director. Mr. Franklin will assume the post on Sept. 20, taking over from Deborah Gribbon, who has served as interim director for the last year. The museum’s previous director, Timothy Rub, left to run the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Mr. Franklin has been at the National Gallery of Canada since 1998. In 2008 he was involved in a controversy there over deleted e-mails, which resulted in his dismissal. He was later rehired. In Cleveland Mr. Franklin will inherit a $350 million expansion project designed by Rafael Viñoly, scheduled for completion in 2013.

headline: Man in Cab Stabbing Showed Zeal for Veterans
text: He could not have struck a more thoughtful tone. “My name is Michael Enright,” he began in an e-mail sent in August 2009 to a young military veteran who had written a memoir about being a medic in Iraq.

headline: Franz Schurmann, Cold War Expert on China, Dies at 84
text: Franz Schurmann, an expert on China during the cold war and a globe-trotting professor who helped found the Pacific News Service, a provider of news and commentary about Asia, died on Aug. 20 at his home in San Francisco. He was 84. The cause was complications of Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s diseases, his wife, Sandy Close, said.

headline: American Flight Uses a Firm’s Satellite-Based Landing System
text: Portable global positioning system devices that let travelers know precisely where they are and, more important, direct them to where they want to go, have been around for years. But airline pilots in the United States often must still rely on antiquated ground-based radio and radar equipment to land at airports.

headline: C. Joseph Genster, Marketer of Metrecal, Dies at 92
text: C. Joseph Genster, who masterminded the marketing of Metrecal, the meal in a can for dieters that swept America like the Hula-Hoop at the beginning of the 1960s, died Aug. 17 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 92.

headline: A Newspaper Apologizes to Leader of Climate Panel
text: Aug. 27, 8:19 a.m. | Updated  From my friends over at the Green Blog:

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Bloggingheads: A Dangerous Debate?
text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com debate the effects of the public discussion about Park51.

headline: Michel Montignac, Creator of Trend-Setting Diet, Dies at 66
text: Michel Montignac, the self-trained French diet promoter who wrote best-selling books and built a business based on the idea that losing weight depends on what you eat, not how much, died Sunday at a clinic in Annemasse, France. He was 66 and lived in Juvigny, France.

headline: I.C.B.C. and BOC Set for Slower Growth
text: The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and Bank of China, two of the top Chinese lenders, signaled a peaking of earnings growth after strong second-quarter profits, as they slow their lending and focus on asset quality.

headline: All Hail, His Samminess, Back in the Glare
text: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Doctor Doesn’t Work Hard to Hide Symptoms of Medicare Fraud
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Thriving Industry Built on Low-Compensated Temp Workers
text: Tory Moore worked at the same packaged-food warehouse in Kankakee for six years, but he was denied a loan and apartment rentals after being told he did not have a real job.

headline: On Harvard Misconduct, Climate Research and Trust
text: April 25, 1:44 p.m. | Updated | The journal Science has published new work that largely replicates the conclusions of the controversial 2007 paper on primate intelligence by Marc Hauser that was at the heart of the dispute discussed below.]

headline: Blagojevich Retrial Poses Questions for Judge
text: During the eight weeks Judge James B. Zagel of Federal District Court presided over the trial of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, he often expressed his frustration with defense attorneys’ behavior and the pace of the proceedings.

headline: Perjury Inquiry May Outlast the Governor’s Term
text: Little more than four months before Gov. David A. Paterson is to leave office, his legacy now rests largely in the hands of P. David Soares, the Albany County district attorney. And it could take all of his remaining days as governor, if not more, to determine his fate.

headline: Assessing the Damage as Flooding in Pakistan Moves South
text: Map shows flooding in Pakistan since the initial flash floods that killed hundreds of people in the Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa region.

headline: Looking Askance at Acquisitions
Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Centurion’
text: Neil Marshall, the director of “Centurion,” discusses a scene from his film.

headline: Reyes Has Another Flare-Up, and Mets Continue Limping Toward Finish
text: The happy-go-lucky reputation of Jose Reyes accurately reflects his disposition. But the ugly reality for the Mets is that his fragile nature, and his seeming impatience when recovering from injuries, is becoming just as notable.

headline: University to Manage Home Costs of President
text: The University of California has appointed an official to manage spending and operations at President Mark G. Yudof’s new private residence, after Mr. Yudof ran up nearly $700,000 in expenses and involved senior university officials in time-consuming personal matters over a rented mansion in the Oakland Hills.

headline: Word of the Day | circumscribe
text: circumscribe •\ˈsər-kəm-ˌskrib\• verb

headline: Forever Stoked for More Tasty Waves
text: At the beginning of “Highwater,” Dana Brown, its writer, director and narrator, expresses some ambivalence about the highly commoditized circus that surfing has become. Mr. Brown knows which side his board is waxed on, however — his family has been deeply involved in the mythmaking that sells surfing gear ever since his father, Bruce, made “The Endless Summer” in 1966 — and “Highwater” settles into celebratory mode. Even a surfer’s death becomes an occasion for spiritual uplift.

headline: David Weber, Southwest Expert, Dies at 69
text: David J. Weber, whose groundbreaking works on the American Southwest under Spain and Mexico opened new territory for historians, died on Aug. 20 in Gallup, N.M. He was 69 and lived in Dallas and Ramah, N.M.

headline: In Scandal’s Wake, Police Turn to Quick, Cheap Test for Drugs
text: When Sgt. Chris Schaffer confiscates a brick of what he suspects is cocaine, he no longer sends the material to the San Francisco Police Department crime lab.

headline: A Green Idea That Sounded Good Until the Trees Went to Work
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Burning Man Radio Steps Out of the Box
text: The Burning Man festival is not an easy place in which to be separated from your friends, particularly if you don’t speak English and are not used to the hot, dusty Nevada desert where the art and music gathering takes place each summer.

headline: Judge Resigns Amid Reports of Discovery on Computer
text: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge resigned last week after court officials discovered what may have been pornography on his work computer, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: Way Is Cleared for Developer to Build Trade Center Towers
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey formally approved an agreement on Thursday with the developer Larry A. Silverstein that will allow for the construction of new office towers on the east side of the World Trade Center site.

headline: Plan to Lease St. Vincent’s Falls Through
text: The last hope that the heart of the venerable St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village might be temporarily revived appears to have been dashed by the moving of a planned urgent care center eight blocks north.

headline: Already Under Fire, Lawyers for 9/11 Workers Are Ordered to Justify Some Fees
text: The lawyers representing most of the ground zero workers who sued the city over health issues will be appearing in court in a new role: defending themselves.

headline: News Quiz | August 27, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: An Autopsy of Fannie and Freddie
text: From Binyamin Appelbaum at Economix:

headline: Omnitrol Nabs $1.4 Million for Analysis Software
text: Omnitrol Networks, a maker of supply chain analysis software, indicated in an S.E.C. filing that it has raised more than half of an expected $2.5 million in financing.

headline: A Big Surprise: Troubled Assets Garner Rewards
text: Taxpayers are already poised to make unexpected billions from rescuing the nation’s banks. Now, they could reap another sizable profit from a government program devised to purge troubled real estate assets from the financial system, Eric Dash writes in The New York Times.

headline: Foreclosures Fall, but Early Delinquencies Rise
text: The foreclosure crisis might have finally peaked in the first half of this year, but with the continued weakness in the economy and the recent deterioration of the housing market, the gains may prove fleeting, David Streitfeld reports in The New York Times.

headline: I.R.S. to Drop Suit Against UBS Over Tax Havens
text: The Internal Revenue Service said Thursday that it would drop a closely watched civil lawsuit against the Swiss bank giant UBS after the Swiss government said it was on course to hand over details on thousands of American clients suspected of using their accounts to evade taxes.

headline: What’s on Your Fall Fashion Shopping List?
text: A new blazer? A frilly Topshop dress? Shaggy fake fur? The perfect skinny jeans? The Style section ponders the places Millennial women— those ages 18 to 29 — shop for clothes and what they buy. If you had an unlimited budget for new fashion this fall, what would you buy? Why? Where would you go to buy it?

headline: Fast Money Pours Into Potash, but Influence Limited
text: Fast money is building in Potash after BHP Billiton‘s $39 billion hostile bid, but the sheer size of the potential deal could limit the sway arbitrageurs and hedge funds have on the outcome, Reuters reported.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Pig’s Whisper
text: Today’s word, in association with the legendary Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Carter Wins Release of American in North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Former President Jimmy Carter left North Korea on Friday with Aijalon Mahli Gomes, an American who was sentenced to eight years of hard labor for illegally entering the country, the Carter Center said. Mr. Gomes was granted amnesty by the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, the Carter Center said in an e-mail. Mr. Gomes, 31, and Mr. Carter boarded a plane at the Pyongyang Airport.

headline: $10 Million Bail for Accused New Jersey Fraudster
text: Eliyahu Weinstein, a New Jersey man charged with leading a $200 million Ponzi scheme that targeted fellow Orthodox Jews, was granted $10 million bail Thursday by a U.S. judge.

headline: Saboteur Aims to Improve V.C. Wardrobes
text: Kristen Slowe and her Saboteur line of clothing are making a bid to dress up Silicon Valley. The entrepreneur has created a series of jackets and shirts for the notoriously down-dressed start-up geek that boasts the slogan: “You’re a man. Dress like one.”

headline: Glencore Plans to Spin Off $5 Billion Kazakh Unit
text: Glencore, the commodities trader based in Switzerland, said in its first-half financial report that it was planning to list some of its gold operations, which are said to be worth $5 billion.

headline: Rosneft Deal for German Refineries Could Help BP
text: Russia’s Rosneft is said to be in advanced talks to buy a piece of four German oil refineries, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: A Big Year for Insurance Takeovers
text: Insurance takeovers are headed for the biggest year since the peak of the last merger boom as financial-services firms from Bank of America to Aegon jettison assets.

headline: Commerzbank Could Sell Over $6 Billion in Shares
text: Commerzbank plans to sell new shares as early as the fall to pave the way for an exit by the German government from the Frankfurt-based lender, Bloomberg News reported, citing the German business newspaper Handelsblatt.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –That’s one easy budget cut: Greece realizes it’s paying pensions to the dead.

headline: Five Years Later
text: WHERE were you during Hurricane Katrina?

headline: Icahn Dials Up More Motorola Shares
text: Carl C. Icahn this week bought deeper into Motorola, lifting his holdings to about 10.6 percent, according to a filing made to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Icahn spent $86.2 million on acquiring the shares.

headline: Canada Fund to Acquire Intoll Group for $3 Billion
text: The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board agreed to buy the Intoll Group for 3.44 billion Australian dollars ($3 billion), gaining stakes in toll roads in Toronto and Sydney, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: When Value Judgments Masquerade as Science
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Jazz, Very Much Alive, in Paris
text: No one embraces jazz like the French. They first fell under its spell in the 1920s, when American artists like Josephine Baker and Sidney Bechet found refuge in their country, disillusioned by the racial situation in the United States. Still among jazz’s biggest supporters, the French hold terrific festivals, like Jazz à la Villette, which runs from Aug. 31 to Sept. 12 in beautiful Parc de la Villette and other venues around Paris.

headline: Strange Tales About Giants
text: Max Willens explores the wide Web for stories about the Giants.

headline: A.I.G. Said to Dismiss Idea of AIA Investors
text: The American International Group has scrapped plans to sell a strategic stake in its Asian life insurance business, AIA, ahead of its initial public offering, a source familiar with the process told Reuters on Friday.

headline: The Pittsburgh Pirate Economy
text: Today’s idea: Pirates — as in the Pittsburgh Pirates – symbolize the American economy, a business writer says. By not investing their cash in new talent, the owners maximize profitability while the team loses.

headline: The Most Accurate Fantasy Football Experts
text: David Kim is the co-founder of FantasyPros, a site that rates the accuracy of fantasy experts and provides simple tools that reduce the time and stress involved in making good fantasy decisions.

headline: Kazakh Mining Company Said to Eye Asian Listing
text: Kazakhmys, the copper producer, told The Financial Times that it was mulling a listing in Hong Kong.

headline: State Street Said to Eye Bank of Ireland Asset Unit
text: State Street is in talks to acquire Bank of Ireland’s asset-management business, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people familiar with the matter.

headline: Blockbuster Plans Bankruptcy Filing Next Month, Report Says
text: Blockbuster, the movie rental chain, is said to be readying a bankruptcy filing for mid-September, The Los Angeles Times reported on Thursday, citing people briefed on the matter.

headline: Chevron Remains Committed to Deepwater Drilling
text: I caught up with Chevron’s vice president for global exploration this week to ask him what impact the BP well disaster and the drilling moratorium in the Gulf of Mexico would have on his company’s plans for future deepwater development.

headline: P.E. Firms Open Wide for Dental Chains
text: Two unidentified private equity firms are said to be bidding for the  largest dentist office chains in America, The New York Post reported.

headline: Pershing Square Betting Against BP’s Debt
text: William Ackman’s Pershing Square Capital Management is betting against the debt of BP through credit-default swaps, saying the energy company’s creditworthiness will be dented for years by the biggest offshore oil spill in United States history.

headline: Sudan Leader Travels Despite Warrant
text: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan arrived in Kenya on Friday to participate in a ceremony inaugurating the country’s newly minted constitution, flouting international demands for his arrest on genocide charges.

headline: Mongolian Mining Company Said to Get Nod for H.K. Listing
text: A Mongolian coking coal company, the Mongolian Mining Corporation, has received approval from the listing committee of the Hong Kong stock exchange to proceed with its $800 million to $1 billion initial public offering, sources close to the deal told Reuters on Friday.

headline: I’ve Changed My Mind About P.R.
text: You may remember one of my posts from last year in which I talked about not needing a public relations firm because we were getting plenty of media coverage organically. Well, as I looked back on that coverage recently, I realized that it was more focused on me as a business owner than on the company and the team. And right now, I’m so busy building the company, training new employees, and managing my pregnancy that I haven’t had time to seek speaking and interview opportunities.

headline: ProPublica on the Banks’ C.D.O. ‘Daisy Chain’
text: “Over the last two years of the housing bubble, Wall Street bankers perpetrated one of the greatest episodes of self-dealing in financial history.”

headline: A Sell-Off of Bonds Despite Assurances From Bernanke
text: Stocks rose Friday after the Federal Reserve chairman pledged to help the economy and a revision in second-quarter growth came in slightly better than expected.

headline: Q. & A.: Repairing a Netbook’s System
text: Q.

headline: Video Messages From Trapped Chilean Miners
text: Updated | 5:13 p.m. Relatives of 33 miners trapped in a collapsed mine shaft far below in Chile’s Atacama Desert have been shown new video of the men in which they send greetings to the surface, show the space they are confined in and sing the Chilean national anthem.

headline: Inflation And Interest Dynamics
text: Brad DeLong and Mark Thoma continue to suffer from dropped-jaw syndrome over the fact that (1) a Federal Reserve bank president believes that low interest rates lead to deflation (2) economists who think they’re being sophisticated are actually defending him.

headline: Evacuations Continue in Southern Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Hundreds of thousands more Pakistanis fled their homes as high floodwaters reached the southernmost region of the country and inundated several more districts, the United Nations said Friday.

headline: U.S. Economy Slowed to 1.6% Pace in 2nd Quarter
text: Economic statistics released Friday offered the clearest sign yet that the recovery, already acknowledged to be sauntering, had slowed to a crawl.

headline: Voice Commands This BlueAnt Headphone
text: The Bluetooth accessories maker BlueAnt has released a new earpiece that can do some remarkable things if your phone is up to it.

headline: Paterson Found to Be ‘Misleading’ Over Tickets
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: At What Age May Kids “Date”
text: There are topics I do not have permission to write about on my blog. My children’s social lives are one of those.

headline: All Dolled Up
text: Most fashionistas progress directly from playing with dolls to sticking pins in them, but even the cattiest divas won’t mess with Anna Wintour and Grace Coddington. To celebrate Fashion’s Night Out on Sept. 10, Barneys New York commissioned the Brooklyn-based artist Andrew Yang to make these one-of-kind, hand-sewn, hand-painted rag-doll replicas of the celebrated Vogue editors. Strictly couture (bien sur!), the duo took two weeks to make. “I had to special-order Anna’s wig and cut it myself to get the bob right,” Mr. Yang says. “And Grace’s hair was the right color, but it needed a perm.” Alas, the question on everyone’s lips – What are they wearing? – has a disappointingly democratic answer. “The outfits are my own take on their signature looks,” he says. “It would have been unfair to single out specific designers.” Anna and Grace will be auctioned off on charitybuzz.com beginning August 31, with the proceeds benefiting The New York City Aids Fund.

headline: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: The Beginnings of Alzheimer’s
text: It’s been nearly 30 years since Dr. Peter Rabins, a Johns Hopkins psychiatrist, and his co-author Nancy Mace published “The 36-Hour Day,” the best known guide to caring for someone with Alzheimer’s disease. Now in its fourth edition, it remains a trusted source of information and support.

headline: Video of the Trapped Chilean Miners Stirs a Country’s Emotions
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile  Huddled around a television set in a dining tent, relatives laughed, smiled and clapped on Friday as they watched the first video images of the 33 miners trapped in a chamber about 2,000 feet below.

headline: How Do You Keep an Idiot in Suspense? Television Trailers in the ‘Mad Men’ Style
text: Since ArtsBeat will be closely focused on its coverage of the Emmy Awards on Sunday night, we’ll be unable to watch “Mad Men” in real time when it’s shown at 10 p.m. (And if we’re going to be an hour behind the rest of the East Coast, why even bother?) So we’d like to treat ourselves to a little taste of what we’re missing while we watch the television industry give itself fabulous prizes, but as “Mad Men” fans know, the official trailers for each week’s coming installment provide no help. Because of the series creator Matthew Weiner‘s well-known dislike of spoilers, these previews are edited to the point of inscrutability, and, often, accidental comedy.

headline: USA Today to Remake Itself to Stress Digital Operations
text: The history of USA Today is full of firsts for the newspaper business: the first general-interest national paper of its kind, the first to use color widely in charts and photographs and once first in the number of copies printed each day.

headline: Rights Panel Criticizes France Over Roma Policy
text: GENEVA  A United Nations-backed committee of experts sharply criticized France on Friday for deporting large groups of Roma and said the government in Paris should do more to combat what it called a growing racist and xenophobic tone in the country’s public debate.

headline: Library Volunteers
text: Community members have responded to our town’s tight budget by volunteering at the library, so much so that the library laid off several long-term full-time employees, people who are our friends and neighbors. Having fewer municipal employees means a slight reduction in property taxes for everyone, but it harms those left jobless. Should town residents consider that before volunteering? NAME WITHHELD, NEW JERSEY

headline: Celebrity Sweepstakes
text: Many brands go to ridiculous lengths to associate their products with well-known entertainers. But of course some celebrities are more coveted than others. A brand owner might ask: How popular is the entertainer? Does his or her image sync up with our product’s desired image? And do we really want anything to do with Insane Clown Posse?

headline: Taking Stock
text: It has been three decades since Business Week proclaimed “The Death of Equities” on its cover. That 1979 obituary for the stock market, published when the Dow Jones industrial average languished at a mere 875, became a symbol of an age of doubt. So shattered were ordinary Americans by gas lines, recessions and double-digit inflation that they resorted to pulling cash out of equity mutual funds — for eight straight years.

headline: Frank Gehry’s Fish Lamps
text: Frank Gehry designed the first of his famous fish lamps in 1983, when he was asked by the Formica Corporation for ways to use the company’s new laminate product, ColorCore, which was colored all the way through, rather than just on the surface. When Gehry was playing around with the material, he broke a piece, which looked to him like a fish scale — and the rest is design history, with the fish swimming into the collections of art world notables like Jasper Johns. On Sunday, “Fish Forms: Lamps by Frank Gehry” opens at the Jewish Museum. Organized by Ruth Beesch, the museum’s deputy director for program, the exhibition, which includes just eight lamps, was inspired by the glass fish lamp in the museum’s own collection. The lamps themselves are engaging objects, the gentle glow of the light within them contrasting with their substantial, expressionist bases. But they were never designed just for the sake of making something. The fish form was something that had fascinated Gehry for its purity and its dynamism and was well on its way to becoming a major theme in his architecture, a point that is made quite well in a video that accompanies the exhibition, which runs through Oct. 31.

headline: A Year to Give to Your Heirs, and Save on Taxes
text: THE estate tax is a great wedge issue in a politically polarized time. Take this oft-cited example: If a billionaire dies this year, no estate tax will be paid, but the estate of someone with more than $1 million who dies next year will pay a 55 percent tax on that extra amount. That seems arbitrary if not bizarre, but such is the tax regime unless Congress changes it.

headline: The Architecture Biennale | Welcome to Venice
text: Yesterday was the first day of the three-day vernissage leading up to the official public opening on Sunday of the 12th International Architecture Exhibition in Venice, better known as the Venice Architecture Biennale. This year’s curatorial director is Kazuyo Sejima, principal of the Tokyo-based architecture firm SANAA, better known to most New Yorkers as the architect of the New Museum. Sejima is breaking new ground on many levels: not only is she the first woman to spearhead the Architecture Biennale, but her theme, “People Meet in Architecture,” is also refreshingly simple and easy to understand, for architects and laypeople alike (unlike titles of previous years, like “Metamporh” or “Next”).

text: While we are on the subject of dating, Laura Shumaker is struggling with a variation of Friday morning’s dilemma. Her son, a grown man, has autism, which affects his ability to navigate the world but not his desire to do so.

headline: Engine Problem Delays Delivery of Boeing’s Dreamliner
text: The first of Boeing’s long-awaited 787 Dreamliner aircraft will not be delivered until next year, the company said Friday, adding to a string of problems that has delayed the project by more than two years.

headline: Stop, Look, Listen | James Lavelle at Haunch of Venison
text: These days, everyone is a curator. Fashionistas curate their closets. Interior designers curate rooms. So it wasn’t such a stretch when London’s Haunch of Venison gallery asked the D.J. James Lavelle, a curator of music, to put together a show of work by visual artists set to his own soundtrack. For “Daydreaming With James Lavelle,” Lavelle, the founder of the Mo’Wax record label and the trip-hop collaborative UNKLE, used his personal street-art collection as a starting point, including works by the graffiti legends Futura, Bäst and Faile, and added music-inspired conceptual art by James Shovlin, art-inspired fashion by the London label Boudicca’s and new works made in response to Lavelle’s own compositions to the mix.

headline: Elbow Problems Don’t Scare Off the Yankees

Sergio Mitre and Kerry Wood, who could relieve Burnett, also wear the scar, the telltale sign of Tommy John surgery, which the rookie phenom Stephen Strasburg of Washington most likely needs.

headline: At 40, Circling Back to Teenage Life
text: REMEMBERING the glory days is easy, but Morgan J. Freeman remembers the nadir just as clearly. It was March 2003, and he had traded in his house in the Echo Park section of Los Angeles for his old room in his parents’ house in nearby Long Beach. Hollywood had shredded Mr. Freeman to bits, and this indie director was ready to head back to New York, where he’d last been a success.

headline: Weekend Fare

The weekend is packed with 4-H shows, midway rides, farm animals, art exhibitions and entertainment. Admission is $10, free for children 12 and under. The gates open at 8 a.m., and the midway section stays open until midnight.

headline: Drought in Russia Ripples Beyond the Wheat Fields

headline: Driven by Fierce Visions of Independence
text: THE arc of the actress and filmmaker Barbara Loden’s life was dramatic enough to be a Hollywood movie. She survived a hardscrabble Southern childhood; moved at 16 to New York, where she was a pin-up model and nightclub dancer; then went on to win a Tony award, marry the director Elia Kazan, and in 1970, write, direct and star in her own film — the bracingly realist “Wanda” — before dying of cancer 10 years later at 48.

headline: The Cat Comes Back, in the Name of Science
text: BACK in the 1950s Theodor Geisel, a k a Dr. Seuss, created “The Cat in the Hat” in response to concerns that American children were lagging in literacy. More than half a century later his floppy-hatted hero is being recruited again to help promote childhood learning: this time, though, it’s keeping kids excited about science.

headline: German Sounds Both Familiar and Not Quite So

The program, directed from the organ by Avi Stein, picked up on a subject the group explored pleasingly last summer  the music of German composers in the generation before Johann Sebastian Bach, including the work of an illustrious cousin, Johann Christoph Bach.

headline: A Style Lasting Beyond a Lifetime
text: In jazz, as in any music, a voice can sometimes stop you in your tracks. Abbey Lincoln, who died this month at 80, possessed that kind of voice: taut and insistent, ablaze with authority. It was a gift, and by no means her only one. Ms. Lincoln was also an arresting physical presence, on screen as onstage, and she proved herself an intuitive songwriter and a figure of unyielding social conscience. Her evolution was a part of her art.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Tyler Hicks of The New York Times has photographed the marooned village of Garhr Khairo, where 250 of its 68,000 people have chosen to remain. (Slides 1, 2 and 3.) Even as Pakistani and international relief officials scrambled to save people and property, Carlotta Gall reported, they despaired that the nation’s worst natural calamity had ruined just about every physical strand that knits this country together — roads, bridges, schools, health clinics, electricity and communications. The destruction could set Pakistan back many years, if not decades, further weaken its feeble civilian administration and add to the burdens on its military.

Six months earlier, he had a wife; two children; three dogs; a house in Chevy Chase, Md.; and a gaggle of cameras following him around.
