headline: ‘Brother’ Gets Bigger
text: Two more houseguests were evicted on “Big Brother” Thursday night as the CBS reality show earned its largest audience since April 2008. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the 8 p.m. episode drew 8.2 million viewers, more than any other program in prime time and, in conjunction with repeats of “CSI” at 9 (6.6 million) and “The Mentalist” at 10 (7 million), enough to lift CBS to No. 1 in the night’s ratings. ABC was runner-up, attracting 6.2 million viewers at 9 for a new episode of “Rookie Blue” and 6.3 million for a repeat of “Wipeout” at 8. Fox and NBC broadcast all reruns and repsectively placed third and fourth over all.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Responds After ‘X Factor’ Scandal
text: No sooner has Simon Cowell, below, departed from “American Idol” than the reality series has started to distance itself from that acid-tongued former judge, as his British series “The X Factor” finds itself embroiled in scandal. Producers of Fox’s “American Idol” said in a statement reported by The Associated Press that they do not use pitch-correcting technology to tweak the singing voices of their show’s contestants. The statement appeared to be a pre-emptive measure at a time when “The X Factor” is being assailed for misrepresenting the abilities of its contenders. Producers of “The X Factor,” which Mr. Cowell created and plans to bring to American television next year, have acknowledged that they used the pitch-correcting program Auto-Tune to correct the voices of some singers on the show, though they said it was to compensate for the different microphones used during their performances. In their statement, the “American Idol” producers wrote, “We have never, nor would we ever, use Auto-Tuning during the ‘American Idol’ competition.”

headline: Updated ‘Metamorphoses’ Wins Edinburgh Award
text: A new theatrical adaptation of Ovid’s “Metamorphoses,” set in World War II Britain and mixing live music, video and puppetry with stage performance, received the Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh Award on Friday at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. The award covers all expenses for a three-week production at Off Off Broadway’s Flea Theater. This new “Metamorphoses,” a retelling of the Roman poet’s mythological tales from the London-based theater company Pants on Fire, will run at the Flea in TriBeCa in January. The production was adapted and directed by Peter Bramley, artistic director of Pants on Fire, with original music by Lucy Egger. Ms. Tambor, a portrait artist and long-time Edinburgh Fringe theatergoer, created the award in 2004 to bring a top work from the summertime Scottish festival to New York each year. Last year’s winner was the Dublin-based Guna Nua theater company’s production of Elaine Murphy’s “Little Gem.”

headline: Event About ‘Lost’ Adams Work Is Canceled
text: A film about the discovery of the disputed “lost negatives” of the photographer Ansel Adams will not be shown at California State University, Fresno, as planned, the university has announced. The October screening had been arranged by Arnold Peter, an alumnus who is a lawyer for Rick Norsigian, the man who bought the negatives, one of which is above, at a garage sale 10 years ago. Mr. Peter, who is the executive producer of the film, told the university last week that he no longer wanted to show it there. He said in a statement to The Bay Citizen on Friday that the screening no longer made sense because Adams’s grandson and the managing director of the Ansel Adams Publishing Rights Trust, who dispute that the 65 negatives are the work of Adams, had not agreed to take part in a discussion at the screening. The trust has filed a lawsuit to block the marketing of the negatives as Adams’s works. Experts working with Mr. Norsigian say they feel sure that Adams created the negatives. But the finding has been challenged by several parties, including the Center for Creative Photography, which Adams co-founded and which had been neutral in the debate. “We have no reason to believe that these negatives are, in fact, the work of Ansel Adams, and we support the efforts of the Ansel Adams Publishing Rights Trust to protect its rights in this matter,” the center said in a statement on Friday.

headline: Trevor Nunn To Don a New Cap at Oxford
text: Having taken the summer to recover from the blistering competition for its professor of poetry chair, has Oxford University just opened the door to another heated rivalry? On Friday the university said it had named Trevor Nunn, the venerated former director of Britain’s National Theater and of productions from “Cats” to the current Broadway revival of “A Little Night Music,” as a visiting professor based at St. Catherine’s College at Oxford. The official title that Mr. Nunn will hold, however, is the Cameron Mackintosh Visiting Professor of Contemporary Theater, a post endowed by a fund named for that producer of theatrical hits like “Phantom of the Opera” and “Les Misérables,” among others. Students of theater (and of good ol’ slapfests) may recall that Mr. Nunn said earlier this summer that he “felt betrayed” by Mr. Mackintosh, who hired new directors for a 25th-anniversary “Les Misérables” revival being staged at the Barbican this fall; Mr. Mackintosh responded that he was “saddened by Nunn’s inaccurate and ungracious remarks.” But in his acceptance of the Oxford position Mr. Nunn was gracious, writing in a statement: “Having been invited to fulfill this role on two previous occasions, I am so pleased that this time the dates have worked out.” His yearlong appointment is to begin in October.

headline: ‘Ring’ Cycle For Houston
text: Houston Grand Opera plans to present its first Ring cycle over four seasons between 2014 and 2017, pending successful completion of a fund-raising campaign, the company said on Friday. The company will co-produce the four Wagner operas with Opera Australia. The production will be directed by the Australian director Neil Armfield and conducted by Houston Grand Opera’s music director, Patrick Summers, who have collaborated several times before.

headline: Keeping You Entertained (and on Your Toes)
text: EDINBURGH  Sitting on a bus on a cool, misty evening here, an enthusiastic teenager chatted up nearly every one of the 15 riders, telling them about her recent move to Edinburgh from Nigeria, and about the things she planned to do in her Scottish environs. She and her “Auntie Martha” were on their way to a new life in an Edinburgh flat. A short time later, the bus riders would discover that this immigrant was not going to shop on the Royal Mile, visit Edinburgh Castle, see the Palace of Holyroodhouse or do anything else on her list. Instead, she was to be quickly assimilated into a world of sex slavery.

headline: Pacific Hot Spells Shifting as Predicted in Human-Heated World
text: Federal researchers have published work concluding that a particular variant of the periodic El Niño warmups of the tropical Pacific Ocean is becoming more frequent and stronger. The pattern appears to fit what is expected from human-driven warming of the global climate, said the researchers, Tong Lee of NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory and Michael McPhaden of the Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory, part of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

headline: Grill That Dough, Stack That Bread

Margaret A. Keip, a Unitarian Universalist minister.

headline: The U.N. Report on War Crimes in Congo
text: A confidential U.N. report by a mapping team on atrocities in Congo between 1993 and 2003 has been leaked and implicates Rwanda in stunning levels of brutality aimed at Hutus. It raises the possibility that Rwanda wasn’t just the victim of genocide (mostly against Rwandan Tutsis) but also a perpetrator (mostly against Rwandan Hutus who fled to Congo).

text: A look at the day in sports, from the Badminton World Championships to the UEFA Super Cup final.

text: Most unicyclists ride as a hobby but for a few hardy riders the one-wheeled machines are regular transportation.

headline: Vacation Travel Recovers, but Frugality Is Focus
text: Vacations have become a luxury for many Americans trying to make ends meet in this economic downturn, but there are signs that people are slowly, even timidly, on the move again.

headline: Air Carrier Shuts Down in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  Grupo Mexicana, the country’s largest airline group, is suspending all operations after an investor group that pledged to turn around the failing carrier failed to reach a cost-cutting agreement with unions, the company and Mexican authorities said Friday.

headline: U.S. Considers Possibility of Engaging North Korea
text: WASHINGTON  The last time a former American president traveled to North Korea on a rescue mission  Bill Clinton, a year ago  he was feted by its leader, Kim Jong-il, who seized on the visit to reach out to the Obama administration. This week, Mr. Kim chose to go to China during a visit by former President Jimmy Carter to free another jailed American.

text: One point I haven’t seen made about the troubles of the US economy is that the timing of recent growth tells you a lot about what was — and what wasn’t — wrong with economic policy.

headline: Tacos and Burritos to Go
text: Though a familiar sight in New Haven, food carts are rare on the shoreline. But that is where you will find Taco Pacifico, Greg Sharon’s taco truck, installed as of July 31 in the parking lot of Dino’s Auto Spa on Route 1 in Madison.

headline: Master of Jazz Fusion Gets His Due
text: WHEN the National Endowment for the Arts gives the 2011 N.E.A. Jazz Masters Award to the saxophonist David Liebman in January, it will represent more to him than a personal achievement. It will also mark the establishment’s de facto validation of the fusion aesthetic, he said, because few, if any, of the 118 other award recipients since 1982 have been as strongly identified with fusion and its challenge to mainstream jazz conventions as he has.

headline: Blues and Rock Haven Is Set to Wail Again
text: IN its heyday during the 1970s and ’80s, the blues and rock club Stanhope House attracted legends like Muddy Waters and Stevie Ray Vaughan to its stage. And even as late as the spring of 2008, when a dispute between the owners led to the club’s closing, shows by popular acts like Citizen Cope were on the calendar.

text: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.

headline: Tempting Views on the Waterside
text: THE quaint former whaling village of Cold Spring Harbor has charming shops but very few restaurants. One of its mainstays, the building at 105 Harbor Road, across Route 25A from the harbor, has been home to a series of restaurants for decades.

headline: The Catch of the Day, Preserved on Paper

headline: New American in a Lively Setting
text: THE BLACK GOOSE in Darien has morphed into the Goose American Bistro and Bar — and the change involved a lot more than new owners and staff. The configuration of the space, the décor and the menu have been altered considerably, and the atmosphere has gone from quiet dining to buzz-conscious cacophony.

headline: The Job Was Simple. The Painter Wasn’t.
text: IN retrospect, I realize that I never specifically mentioned to the painting contractor that I would need to open the door. To my apartment. To, you know, get out and go to work and that sort of thing. So perhaps I only had myself to blame.

headline: A Chronicler’s Work Is Never Done
text: Dan Rattiner, 70, the Hamptons’ most prolific Boswell, is the founder, executive editor and lead writer of the free weekly  Dan’s Papers and the author of a dozen books. In his newest, “In the Hamptons Too,” his second memoir, each chapter recreates an encounter with a notable Hamptonite. Mr. Rattiner lives in East Hampton with his wife, Chris Wasserstein, a psychotherapist. They have a wheaten terrier, Moo; a turtle, Dribble; and a city cat, Hank, who house-sits full time at their Upper East Side apartment.  ROBIN FINN

headline: A Local Hangout in a Star Chef’s Empire
text: PETER X. KELLY is a culinary star. He beat Bobby Flay on “Iron Chef America” in 2007. He was nominated for a 2010 James Beard Foundation award for best chef in the Northeast. And his restaurants in New York’s lower Hudson Valley  X2O Xaviars on the Hudson in Yonkers, Xaviars at Piermont and Restaurant X and Bully Boy Bar in Congers  are among the most ambitious and popular in the region.

headline: The Holdouts
text: “WHEN,” announced Luis Davila, glancing at the clock: 11 a.m.

headline: The Choice Was Cupcakes
text: Last year, when Lev Ekster of Brooklyn set about establishing a career, he came to a fork in the road: one direction led to lawyering, the other to cupcake-store entrepreneurship.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: LUDLOW RESIDENCE, a sleek Lower East Side dormitory of the School of Visual Arts, has opened about one-third of its 20 stories to 120 students, mostly freshmen, from Baruch College. Kevin Ng, 20, a senior who spent his first three years at Baruch commuting from his parents’ home on Staten Island, was hired as a resident assistant in the building, Baruch’s first dorm, where students pay $1,100 a month for a diminutive single with a shared bathroom. “I still can’t believe I’m here,” he said Wednesday as he pointed out some of the perks at Ludlow: free laundry machines that send a text message when a load is done, a communal kitchen with stainless-steel appliances, views of the Williamsburg Bridge and the Empire State Building from some floors, and a landscaped terrace. Baruch’s vice president for student affairs, Ben Corpus, said that the college began searching for dorm space four years ago, and that in a survey, most students indicated they wanted to live in a dorm. “They still have some version of the ‘Animal House’ image in their minds when they think of the college experience,” Dr. Corpus said. “We’re happy to provide some of that spirit.” But no alcohol is allowed at Ludlow, so students mingled Monday at a “mocktail mixer” — juices, soda and the like. Not quite “Animal House,” though there was a foosball table.

headline: The Solar System’s Long Life and (Alas) Eventual Death
Filling the Cart With Expectations
text: AS the first day of school approaches, consider the humble bulletin board.

headline: China’s Growth Leads to Problems Down the Road
text: ZHANGJIAKOU, China — Chinese authorities proclaimed an end this week to an epic traffic jam that had brought some drivers here to a dead halt for up to five seemingly endless days. Which is heartening news, save two problems.

headline: 22-Story Fall in Manhattan Kills Daughter of U.S. Envoy
text: With summer winding down, Eric G. John, the United States ambassador to Thailand, made a trip familiar to many parents: he accompanied his 17-year-old daughter to New York as she got ready for her first year of college.

headline: Long Island Arts Listings
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Britain: No Payment for Suicide Bomber’s Widow
text: A panel of two High Court judges ruled Friday against a petition for government payment of legal costs to the widow of one of the four suicide bombers who killed 52 people and themselves in attacks on London’s transit system in July 2005. The widow, Hasina Patel, had appealed a lower court order in May backing a government decision to hold separate inquests into the deaths of the four bombers and their victims, and to deny relatives of the bombers access to the government legal aid that will be available to the victims’ relatives. Ms. Patel, widow of Mohammed Siddique Khan, identified by investigations as the ringleader of the 2005 attacks, has since remarried.

headline: Connecticut Arts Listings
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Kenya: Sudan’s Leader Visits
text: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan arrived in Kenya on Friday to participate in a ceremony inaugurating the country’s newly minted Constitution, flouting international demands for his arrest on genocide charges. Mr. Bashir faces two arrest warrants: one issued in July by the International Criminal Court in The Hague on three counts of genocide and one from March 2009 for war crimes and crimes against humanity. In theory the warrants could be enforced by any of the court’s member countries, which includes Kenya. The role of the international court is particularly delicate in Kenya because in March its judges authorized formal criminal investigations of the political leaders who organized the violence that convulsed the country after its disputed 2007 election.

headline: Arts Listings for Westchester County, N.Y.
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Cultural Calendar, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Iraq: Zaha Hadid to Design Bank
text: The architect Zaha Hadid has been appointed to design a new headquarters for the central bank in Baghdad, two months after an assault on the existing building left at least 15 people dead. Ms. Hadid, 59, was approached by the Iraqi authorities this year, said a spokesman for Zaha Hadid Architects. Ms. Hadid, above, who in 2004 became the first woman to win the Pritzker Prize for Architecture, was born and reared in Baghdad. The bank building was attacked on June 13 by suicide bombers and gunmen in military uniforms, just as staff members were leaving work. The bombers blew themselves up while gunmen clashed for hours with bank security officers. The Islamic State of Iraq, a group affiliated with Al Qaeda in Iraq, claimed responsibility.

headline: Britain: Premier Avoids an Attack
text: British newspapers reported Friday that Prime Minister David Cameron narrowly avoided a Taliban attempt to shoot down the Chinook helicopter that was carrying him to a front-line British base in Helmand Province on his first visit to Afghanistan as prime minister in June. The accounts, quoting military officials, said the helicopter carrying Mr. Cameron and Air Chief Marshal Sir Jock Stirrup, Britain’s top military officer, had been airborne for five minutes heading from a joint British and American military base in the Helmand desert to a remote front-line base for British troops in the town of Shahzad on June 10 when Taliban radio messages about the planned attack were intercepted by a coalition eavesdropping unit. The helicopter was diverted to another British base. Officials at 10 Downing Street said they had no comment on the report.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: President’s Panel, Short on Specifics, Makes Suggestions for Changing Tax Code
text: The former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A. Volcker offered President Obama a menu of options on Friday for revamping the tax code, including simplifying the system and overhauling how corporate taxes are assessed.

headline: Where Dr. King Stood, Tea Party Claims His Mantle
text: WASHINGTON — It seems the ultimate thumb in the eye: that Glenn Beck would summon the Tea Party faithful to a rally on the anniversary of the March on Washington, and address them from the very place where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his “I have a dream” speech 47 years ago. After all, the Tea Party and its critics have been facing off for months over accusations of racism.

headline: Massacre Sets Off New Fears in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  Three days after 72 migrants were found dead on a ranch near the Texas border, a local prosecutor involved in the investigation was reported missing on Friday and the office of a national television network in the region was damaged by an explosion, the authorities said.

headline: A Republican Comes Out of the Closet
text: There’s an old, not terribly meaningful saying in the gay-rights movement that “no matter how far in or out of the closet you are, you still have a next step.” Perhaps, but I propose that we back off and let Ken Mehlman think about his for a while.

text: NEW ORLEANS  Louisiana Democrats were elated.

text: You have to wonder sometimes what they’re smoking over there at the National Association of Realtors.

headline: Season of Labor Unrest Empties South African Hospitals
text: DURBAN, South Africa  Most patients in the hulking, seven-story tuberculosis hospital here  all infected with potentially lethal, drug-resistant strains of the disease  have gone home since a majority of nurses, orderlies and janitors went on strike a week and a half ago.

headline: Two Lives Devoted to Horse Racing, With Just a Pinch of Garlic
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Allen Jerkens and Bill Higgins have been friends and colleagues for more than 30 years. They do not agree on everything, but ask them about the sport of horse racing, and they land on the same word: befuddling.

headline: Harvard Researcher May Have Fabricated Data
text: Harvard authorities have made available information suggesting that Marc Hauser, a star researcher who was put on leave this month, may have fabricated data in a 2002 paper.

headline: Gun Lobby Won’t Endorse Reid
text: Senator Harry Reid’s votes for President Obama’s two Supreme Court nominees have cost him the support of the National Rifle Association.

headline: Tiger Woods Crumbles in Barclays’ Second Round
text: PARAMUS, N.J.  With a birdie putt, Tiger Woods finished the first round at the Barclays on Thursday with a fist pump and a wave to the crowd. For a change, his name sat atop the leader board, and the golf world seemed to have finally righted itself.

headline: In New Orleans, Black Churches Face a Long, Slow Return
text: NEW ORLEANS  Five minutes past 9:30 a.m. on a Sunday this month, which is to say five minutes past the time the worship service was supposed to start, Shantell Henley pushed open the front door of her pastor’s house in the Lower Ninth Ward. She entered the living room to find a gospel song playing on the stereo, two ceiling fans stirring the sticky air and 25 folding chairs for the congregants waiting empty.

headline: Few Details Given as 4 Canadians Are Held in Terrorist Plot
text: TORONTO  The charges are sweeping. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police say that three Canadians, among them a physician, were plotting to blow up targets in Canada and funnel funds to Afghanistan to insurgents fighting against Canadian soldiers.

headline: Judge Rejects $6.1 Million in 9/11 Case Legal Fees
text: The federal judge overseeing the settlement between ground zero workers and the city over health issues told the plaintiffs’ lawyers on Friday that they should absorb $6.1 million in legal expenses they had intended to pass on to their clients.

headline: With Paterson, the Simple Facts Can Get Complicated
text: A thoroughly honest politician has pretty much always been considered an undiscovered species. But for Gov. David A. Paterson, the distinction between the truth and an untruth can get unusually murky.

headline: Looking for Star in Travers
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  For 141 years, the best 3-year-olds have come to the nation’s oldest racetrack to stake their claim among the best of their generation. The Travers Stakes is called the Midsummer Derby because it is contested at the classic distance of a mile and a quarter.

headline: U.S. Wary of Example Set by Tribunal Case
text: WASHINGTON  After working for a year to redeem the international reputation of military commissions, Obama administration officials are alarmed by the first case to go to trial under revamped rules: the prosecution of a former child soldier whom an American interrogator implicitly threatened with gang rape.

headline: Financier’s Largess Shows G.O.P.’s Wall St. Support
text: At a black-tie dinner in April, a politically influential hedge fund manager named Paul Singer offered a blistering critique of the “terrible path” he said Washington politicians were charting on economic issues.

headline: Democrat Tries to Stand Out as Liberal in Primary
text: Bracing for what is expected to be a strong anti-Albany surge this fall, many Democratic candidates in New York have adopted the mantra of the middle, talking up pocketbook issues like jobs and taxes and focusing intently on moderate voters.

headline: Baseball’s Arm of the Future, Headed for Surgery
text: No baseball player has generated as much interest or excitement this season as Stephen Strasburg, the hard-throwing rookie pitcher for the Washington Nationals. Only 22 years old and with a fastball that routinely reaches 100 miles an hour, Strasburg has been watched and monitored and scrutinized  right down to the number of pitches he was allowed to throw in a game.

headline: In Oil Inquiry, Panel Sees No Single Smoking Gun
text: HOUSTON  More than four months after the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion, there appears to be no single smoking gun that implicates one person or company in the disaster. Instead, several missteps and oversights by the crew are being explored by federal investigators as possible triggers of the emergency.

headline: Assault Statistics of Hospitals and City Police Seem to Differ
text: Felony assaults, along with all other major crimes in the city, have sharply decreased over the last decade, according to the New York Police Department.

text: As Elizabeth Sargent prepared for the movers to carry her life out of a ninth-floor studio above Carnegie Hall, she came to a conclusion.

headline: U.N. Congo Report Offers New View on Genocide

headline: America Is Better Than This
text: America is better than Glenn Beck. For all of his celebrity, Mr. Beck is an ignorant, divisive, pathetic figure. On the anniversary of the great 1963 March on Washington he will stand in the shadows of giants  Abraham Lincoln and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Who do you think is more representative of this nation?

text: NATIONAL

headline: Mr. Simpson Has a Cow
text: What are we to make of Alan Simpson, the co-chairman of President Obama’s deficit reduction commission, who recently referred to Social Security as “a milk cow with 310 million tits”?

headline: Financial Intrigue Builds Between Marlins and Miami
text: The back and forth between the Florida Marlins and lawmakers in Miami has heated up in the wake of revelations this week that the team was in fact making tens of millions of dollars when it asked the city and county to pay for three-quarters of a new, $645 million stadium in the Little Havana neighborhood.

headline: I Had a Nightmare
text: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was already dead when I was born, and yet I idolized him the way most children idolized athletes and pop stars. I had the poster and the T-shirt, I knew the speeches and the places he’d marched.

headline: Leaving Iraq
text: On Tuesday the American combat mission in Iraq  a war that should never have been fought  officially ends. President Obama deserves credit for promising the withdrawal and for sticking to it. But America’s responsibilities in Iraq will not end now.

headline: Cube Root of Veintisiete
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE NOTES — There were some interesting surprises in this puzzle.

headline: Sharing the Wealth at a Dumpster Divers’ Feast
text: The Dumpster divers started their bicycle run just after nightfall on a summer Friday, rolling through the steamy streets of Williamsburg and Greenpoint, stopping only to dig through trash bags and pull out produce. They wore plastic gloves for the messier bags and used a flashlight on the darker stretches of sidewalk. Then they loaded their finds onto a cargo bike, retied the bags and cycled on.

headline: Mr. Paterson’s Disappointing Tenure
text: Handed an opportunity to guide New York State through terrible economic times  and restore the luster of the office after Eliot Spitzer’s disgrace  Gov. David Paterson frittered away his chances. When it comes to key decisions, he has been distracted and irresolute. And he has displayed poor judgment about fundamental issues of ethics.

headline: Their Investors’ Voice
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted rules this week to make it easier for shareholders to nominate directors to corporate boards. For decades, business lobbyists blocked the agency’s efforts to give investors a bigger say in corporate leadership.

headline: The Price of Wheat
text: Agricultural experts say they’re not worried about the recent jump in wheat prices, caused largely by the drought in Russia and the ban on Russian wheat exports. The Department of Agriculture is predicting that world wheat production will reach the same level this year  645 million metric tons  that helped bring prices down from their astonishing $13.50 a bushel peak in February 2008. At present, prices for December wheat are about $6.95 a bushel, down over 50 cents from a month ago, but up nearly 55 percent since early June.

headline: Girardi Plays Down Speculation About Cubs
text: CHICAGO  Waiting in Joe Girardi’s office Friday was a copy of The Chicago Sun-Times, which on its back page featured a silhouette of a man wearing a Cubs hat. Beneath a list of nine qualities the next Cubs manager must have, it read, “There’s only one man for the job.” On Page 56, there was a large photograph of Girardi. He did not get that far.

headline: Offense Remains Concern for Jets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  All week, the Jets described their offensive struggles this preseason as an aberration, a small, meaningless sample. That became their mantra: no reason to worry, not yet.

headline: Informer Says Defendant Wanted to Be a Martyr
text: When the two men, a government informer and a man who would eventually be accused of leading a terrorist plot, first met two years ago they bonded for a moment over the sandals on the informer’s feet.

headline: France: Roma Policy Challenged
text: A United Nations-backed committee of experts sharply criticized France on Friday for deporting large groups of Roma and said the government in Paris should do more to combat what it called a growing racist and xenophobic tone in the country’s public debate. On instructions from President Nicolas Sarkozy, the police have been dismantling improvised Roma camps and deporting groups of Roma, also known as Gypsies, to Bulgaria and Romania. The French government said that all those flown back to the Balkans were part of a voluntary repatriation and had accepted payments of about $380 per adult and $120 per child, but the committee questioned the assertion.

headline: First Tentative Steps Back for Bay Before Pelfrey Wins With Authority
text: Jason Bay received a phone call from a Mets trainer at 3:30 Friday afternoon. For the first time since sustaining a concussion on July 23, Bay had gone a two-day span without any headaches, and the trainer wanted to tell him that he could resume physical activity.

headline: New Jersey Schools Chief Fired After Grant Error
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey fired his education commissioner on Friday, just days after the governor said a clerical error had cost the state a $400 million federal education grant.

headline: Jack Pitney, Who Made Much of the Mini, Dies at 47
text: Jack Pitney, a rising star at BMW of North America, where he was the vice president for marketing and led the wildly successful introduction of BMW’s updated Mini Cooper into the American market in 2002, died Thursday in an accident on his farm in Durham, N.Y. He was 47.

headline: U.S. Analyst Is Indicted in Leak Case
text: WASHINGTON  A federal grand jury in Washington has indicted a State Department analyst suspected of disclosing top-secret information about North Korea to Fox News, the third time the Obama administration has filed criminal charges accusing people of leaks to the news media.

headline: Black and Jewish, and Seeing No Contradiction
text: In yeshivas, they are sometimes taunted as “monkeys” or with the Yiddish epithet for blacks. At synagogues and kosher restaurants, they engender blank stares. And dating can be awkward: their numbers are so small, friends will often share at least some romantic history with the same man or woman, and matchmakers always pair them with people with whom they have little in common beyond skin color.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Rethinking the System as N.B.A. Stars Move
text: LeBron James fled, Chris Bosh bolted and Amar’e Stoudemire drifted away. Chris Paul chirped with envy. Carmelo Anthony grumbled. And N.B.A. executives in every time zone shuddered a bit.

headline: Thomas White Jr., City Councilman From Queens, Dies at 71
text: Thomas White Jr., a longtime city councilman from Queens, died Friday at a Queens hospital. He was 71.

headline: Gloria Winters, Perky Star of Wholesome ‘Sky King’, Dies
text: Gloria Winters, who personified youthful, clean-cut American innocence in the 1950s children’s television series “Sky King,” died on Aug. 14 at her home in Vista, Calif., just north of San Diego. She was in her late 70s.

headline: Burnett Struggles Again, and Pettitte Feels Pressure to Return
text: CHICAGO  The most comforting day of the Yankees’ week will come on Saturday. That is when C. C. Sabathia is scheduled to throw, and for those few hours, Andy Pettitte’s absence will be minimized, and their rotation troubles will appear to be overstated. Sabathia emboldens the Yankees every fifth day, but that is all he can pitch. A. J. Burnett started Friday, putting even more of a burden on Sabathia to pitch like an ace when his turn comes up.

headline: Mahut Inches Closer to Open’s Main Draw
text: Nicolas Mahut is still slogging his way toward an entry into the United States Open. Mahut, the French player who two months ago played in the longest match in tennis history at Wimbledon, won his second-round qualifying match Friday and needs only one more victory to lock up a place in the main draw.

headline: Tommy John Surgery, Japanese Style
text: Mets reliever Ryota Igarashi knows what the Washington Nationals rookie pitcher Stephen Strasburg is about to go through with Tommy John surgery. Igarashi missed the 2007 season after he had the same surgery performed on his right elbow in 2006, and had to work hard to come back to full strength.

headline: Petrova, Last in, Will Be One of Last Two
text: Nadia Petrova took advantage of her last-minute addition to the field at the Pilot Pen tennis tournament, moving into the final with a 2-6, 6-2, 6-2 victory over Maria Kirilenko on Friday in New Haven.

headline: John Holusha, a Writer for The Times, Dies at 67
text: John Holusha, who reported on business affairs for The New York Times for nearly three decades, died on Thursday in Montclair, N.J. He was 67 and lived in Glen Ridge, N.J.

headline: Dumpster Diving for Dinner
text: Discarded food becomes a meal for a resourceful group of people in Brooklyn.

headline: Daniel Davison, Banker Who Revitalized U.S. Trust, Dies at 85
text: Daniel P. Davison, a self-described patrician banker and avid yachtsman who took the helm of the august, but slipping, United States Trust Company in 1979 and revived it by riveting its attention on the very rich, died on Wednesday at his family’s home, Peacock Point, on Long Island in Locust Valley. He was 85.

headline: Fumbling and Bumbling for Jets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. –- The Jets fumbled four times and lost possession on three of them in their 16-11 preseason loss against the Redskins on Friday.

headline: Will Sanchez Be Ready for the Ravens?
text: It’s usually O.K. to give veteran N.F.L. players the benefit of the doubt about whether they’ll be ready to rumble for season openers. In the Jets’ case, that means their Monday night game against the Ravens on Sept. 13.

headline: Five and Five: No. 8, Oregon
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 8, is Oregon. You can find a larger Oregon preview here.

headline: An S.B.A. Loan Program Goes Quietly
text: Agenda readers may recall the great expectations set for the Small Business Administration‘s America’s Recovery Capital Loan program when it was inaugurated in June 2009. (Its introduction coincided with The Agenda’s.)

headline: The Conceptual Hot Rods of Lewis deSoto
text: The term “art car” calls to mind the sort of wheeled monstrosities you might see trundling across the playa at Burning Man, or Antti Rahko’s “Finnjet.” The automotive sculptures of Lewis deSoto, an artist who lives in Napa, Calif., are a somewhat different matter.

headline: In Stunning Losses, Winning Over Fans
text: PARAMUS, N.J.  The slate sky was spitting drizzle, and Dustin Johnson was on the 16th tee at the Ridgewood Country Club earlier this week, about to hit his drive the length of three football fields.

headline: Rainy-Day Practice Sessions in Spa
text: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium — Formula One is used to having rain in Spa. In fact, it always rains here at least once during the race weekend. But today’s first two practice sessions were run under incredibly bad weather conditions, which, in the end, did manage to combine a bit of dry and wet running.

headline: Girardi Weighing Rotation Options
text: CHICAGO – The last time Joe Girardi seemed this unhappy after a game, he had also just finished watching A.J. Burnett pitch. That day, Girardi was displeased with practically everything about the Yankees’ loss to Kansas City on Aug. 15 except for Burnett, who was superb.

headline: Saturday Word: Rallies and Midterms

headline: 3Par Calls $2 Billion H.P. Bid a ‘Superior Proposal’
text: 3Par said late Friday that its board had decided the bid it received from Hewlett-Packard was superior to that made by Dell, with whom it is canceling its merger agreement.

headline: For Republicans, an ’80 Déjà Vu?
text: WASHINGTON  The incumbent senator from Alaska is taken by surprise in a primary. A new conservative movement energizes Republicans in a furious response to a Democratic White House. Little-known insurgent candidates prepare to storm the Senate.

headline: Angela And The Fifty Hoovers
text: Via Mark Thoma, Dean Baker points out that real government consumption of goods and services — that’s government buying things, as opposed to cutting taxes or handing out checks — has risen more in “austerity” Germany than in the United States. Dean starts from 2008III, which is somewhat unorthodox; but his result is not, in fact, sensitive to the start date. I can’t post a figure right now, due to an outage on the Princeton servers, but here’s a table, with 4th quarter 2007 as the baseline:

headline: Failure To Rise
text: I’m finding it hard to read about politics these days. I still don’t think people in the administration understand the magnitude of the catastrophe their excessive caution has created. I keep waiting for Obama to do something, something, to shake things up; but it never seems to happen.

text: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium — This was supposed to be one of the tracks where the Red Bull would not be at its best, but that did not prevent Mark Webber from scoring pole position today for the Belgian Grand Prix in a tricky qualifying session that saw a mixture of wet and dry conditions.

headline: At Lincoln Memorial, a Call for Religious Rebirth
text: WASHINGTON — An enormous and impassioned crowd rallied at the steps of the Lincoln Memorial this weekend, summoned by Glenn Beck, a conservative broadcaster who called for a religious rebirth in America at the site where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his famous “I Have a Dream” speech exactly 47 years earlier.

headline: Qaeda in Iraq Says It Was Behind Latest Attacks
text: BAGHDAD  Insurgents affiliated with Al Qaeda in Iraq claimed responsibility on Saturday for a wave of car bombings, roadside mines and hit-and-run attacks this week in at least 13 Iraqi cities and towns, a deadly and relentless campaign whose breadth surprised American military officials and dealt a blow to Iraq’s fledgling security forces.

headline: Staged Acrostic

headline: Pakistanis Scramble to Escape Floods
text: THATTA, Pakistan — This town had already been evacuated because of the threat of flooding, but it filled up again on Saturday with tens of thousands of people fleeing floodwaters that had inundated surrounding districts and villages after the Indus River broke its embankments in several places.

headline: Stanford’s Luck Is a Star in the Crowd
text: In an engineering statics class at Stanford this spring, a hush went through the room when a teaching assistant randomly called out the name Andrew Luck to solve a vector equation at the chalkboard.

headline: In Hard Times, One New Bank (Double-Wide)
text: LAKE CHARLES, La.  The only new start-up bank to open in the United States this year operates out of a secondhand double-wide trailer, on a bare lot in front of the cavernous Trinity Baptist Church. A blue awning covers the makeshift drive-through window.

headline: Ricky Rubio at 19: The Prodigy Is Coming of Age

headline: Bankers Told Recovery May Be Slow
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The American economy could experience painfully slow growth and stubbornly high unemployment for a decade or longer as a result of the 2007 collapse of the housing market and the economic turmoil that followed, according to an authority on the history of financial crises.

Fittingly, it will be played in a stadium of professional gladiators, FedEx Field in Landover, Md., home of the Washington Redskins.

headline: Graft-Fighting Prosecutor Fired in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — One of the country’s most senior prosecutors said Saturday that President Hamid Karzai fired him last week after he repeatedly refused to block corruption investigations at the highest levels of Mr. Karzai’s government.

headline: Harvard Is Favored; Penn Likes Its Odds
text: The University of Pennsylvania football team went undefeated last season in the Ivy League on the way to its 14th championship. The Quakers have 15 starters returning this season and the Ivy League’s longest-tenured coach, Al Bagnoli, at the helm.

headline: Not a Household Name, Not Even in Nevada
text: When Colin Kaepernick interned at a University of Nevada-themed sports apparel store this summer, he sold Wolf Pack clothing to people who often did not know that he plays for the  football team. headline: From Understudy in Hollywood to Star at Richmond
text: RICHMOND, Va.  Aaron Corp uses an electric scooter to navigate the University of Richmond’s walkways, buzzing around redbrick buildings, pine trees and a picturesque lake at the center of campus. In this bucolic setting, he could not be much farther from Hollywood. But the scooter is the lasting reminder of Corp’s years at the University of Southern California, where many Trojans football players ride them.

text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Sarah Palin’s Speech
text: Former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska told the gathering, "It is so humbling to get to be here with you today, patriots. You who are motivated and engaged ... and knowing never to retreat."

headline: Rough Third-Round Start for Woods
text: PARAMUS, N.J. — The question of the day at the Ridgewood Country Club on Saturday was which Tiger Woods would show up: the one who cruised through the first 27 holes at the Barclays, or the one who seemed helpless in the last nine holes of the second round, bogeying four times?

headline: After Fast Fall, Safina Resumes Climb
text: MONTREAL  Dinara Safina was ranked No. 1 in the world when the United States Open began last year. Some thought she was undeserving of the lofty spot because she had not won a Grand Slam tournament. But winning her first major title in New York would have cemented her place among the game’s elite.

headline: Statistics Worthy of a Cy Young, Except for One
text: Mike Mussina used to say that the best pitchers win half their starts. Mussina did that almost precisely over 18 seasons, winning 270 of his 536 career starts. Mussina understood the finicky role luck plays in wins and losses. But he also knew that, over time, a pitcher’s luck tends to even out. He deserved 270 victories, and that is what he got.

headline: Encouraging the Poor to Stay Poor
text: Major League Baseball had a minor scandal last week when closely guarded financial data from several teams was leaked to the public.

headline: Coach Devotes Himself to Game’s Most Selfless Play
text: KEIZER, Ore.  Joe Amalfitano is an evangelist of sorts. Traveling from farm club to farm club for the San Francisco Giants, he preaches something many minor leaguers have never thought much about: the art of the sacrifice bunt.

headline: On the Virtues of Hard Work
text: Philadelphia Phillies pitcher Jamie Moyer sustained a season-ending arm injury July 20. But his team remains in playoff contention, and off the field, the Moyer Foundation, his nonprofit charity dedicated to helping children in distress, has continued to flourish. Moyer, 47, became the oldest major league player to pitch a shutout when he defeated the Atlanta Braves, 7-0, on May 7.

headline: A Misunderstanding, a Beaning, and a Piece of the Gehrig Puzzle

headline: Four U.S. Cities Are Top Picks For Labor Day, Sites Say
text: Online travel sites can predict the future, in a way, by checking their own bookings. If users who booked hotels through Orbitz.com and Priceline.comare any indication, American travelers are remaining stateside for Labor Day, and four cities will get the benefit of their company (and their hotel taxes). New York, Seattle, Chicago and Las Vegas are among the top five cities on lists that each site recently released outlining the most popular destinations for the holiday.

headline: A Palin of Our Own
text: TWO years ago today, Senator John McCain of Arizona, the Republican presidential nominee, introduced the world to his running mate, Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska. Chosen by Mr. McCain’s campaign strategists as a cynical rejoinder to the ill-starred presidential bid of Hillary Clinton, Governor Palin was a historic pick: the second woman to run for vice president on a major party ticket and the first Republican woman in history to do so.

headline: Doors Start to Open to Activists in Syria
text: ALEPPO, Syria  For five years, Chavia Ali’s attempts to start a disability rights group were thwarted  by prejudice, a lack of money and the Syrian government’s stranglehold on civic life. The government gave her a license, but prevented the group from meeting because of what Ms. Ali believes was a whisper campaign against her, a Kurd with a growing profile.

headline: Tall and Nimble, Kevin Love Fits His Role for U.S.
text: ISTANBUL  The United States backup center Kevin Love worried that his most impressive performance this month would not come on the court. Love’s cameo on the HBO show “Entourage” on Sunday night lasted just a few seconds, and despite the lack of Emmy buzz, he said he enjoyed his foray into acting.

headline: Chakvedtadze Wins Bronx Tournament
text: Unseeded Anna Chakvedtadze rallied from an 0-2 deficit in the second set to defeat seventh-seeded Sofia Arvidsson, 4-6, 6-2, 6-2, in the final of the EmblemHealth Bronx Open in Crotona Park. The 72nd-ranked Chakvedtadze, a Russian who had been ranked in the top 10, won her ninth tour event over all and second this summer, following a hardcourt title in Slovenia this past July.

headline: Gholston Is Confident the Wait Is Finally Over

headline: Continue the Race
text: The Obama administration’s Race to the Top initiative has shown that competitive grant programs can be a powerful spur to innovation in education. Most of the 12 states that were awarded grants this year — and the more than 30 states that changed education policies in hopes of winning grants — would never have attempted reform on this scale without the promise of federal help.

headline: Off the Rails
text: After a week of epic awfulness, Long Island Rail Road riders are getting on with life, but with teeth sore from gritting. A railroad is only as strong as its weakest switching station, and after a small fire Monday at Jamaica Station took out century-old switches, the L.I.R.R., the nation’s largest commuter railroad, was crippled.

headline: Egg Factory
text: On Friday, most of the country’s major newspapers, including The Times, featured reports from a small town called Clarion, Iowa. Just outside Clarion are the egg operations, owned by the DeCoster family, at the heart of the salmonella outbreak. The factory — no point calling it a farm — called Wright County Egg, is the source of 380 million of the more than 500 million recalled eggs.

headline: The Politics of Polite

I kept my name when I got married and my husband kept his name.”

headline: New Dissent in Japan Is Loudly Anti-Foreign

The group of about a dozen Japanese men gathered in front of the school gate, using bullhorns to call the students cockroaches and Korean spies.

headline: Policy Options Dwindle as Economic Fears Grow
text: THE American economy is once again tilting toward danger. Despite an aggressive regimen of treatments from the conventional to the exotic  more than $800 billion in federal spending, and trillions of dollars worth of credit from the Federal Reserve  fears of a second recession are growing, along with worries that the country may face several more years of lean prospects.

headline: Obama and the Mess in Sudan
text: My Sunday column is about President Obama’s failure to follow his own campaign rhetoric about paying attention to genocide and Sudan. As a senator, Obama was one of the leaders in calling on the Bush administration to do more about Darfur — and yet he has been disengaged in Sudan issues and his administration hasn’t been as successful as the Bush administration in getting Sudan to behave a bit better.

headline: Martin Dannenberg Is Dead at 94; Found Nuremberg Laws Document
text: It was April 28, 1945, and the war in Europe was in its final hours. Days earlier, Martin Dannenberg, an Army intelligence officer, had seen piles of dead bodies at Dachau, the concentration camp in Germany. He said they were stacked like cordwood.

headline: Robert Ingersoll, who Served as Envoy to Japan, Dies at 96
text: Robert S. Ingersoll, who took his business acumen as head of one of the country’s largest manufacturing corporations to the diplomatic table as ambassador to Japan and later deputy secretary of state, died on Aug. 22 at his home in Evanston, Ill. He was 96.

headline: Jackson Gillis, Prolific Writer of TV Drama, Dies at 93
text: Cops and detectives, doctors and lawyers, spies and cowboys, heroes, superheroes and semi-superheroes. These are staples of television drama, and one of the unsung people who stapled them was Jackson Gillis, a prolific slogger in the trenches of television writing whose career spanned more than four decades and whose scripts put words in the mouths of Superman, Perry Mason, Columbo, Wonder Woman, Zorro, Tarzan, Napoleon Solo and Illya Kuryakin, Jessica Fletcher and, in a manner of speaking, Lassie.

headline: Children of the Storm Revisited

headline: Wright Homes Go Begging
text: How bad is the housing market? Two Frank Lloyd Wright-designed texitle-block houses  in Southern California have been languishing on the market — one for two years, the other a year — though the owners have slashed millions of dollars off the prices, Jori Finkel reports in The Los Angeles Times. What makes the houses especially rare is that Wright built only four such homes, using rows of patterned concrete blocks both as decoration and supporting walls. Both have maintenance issues, and, as the paper noted, “they don’t have high-end comforts for high-end buyers such as spa-style bathrooms or chefs kitchens.” Still, the lack of interest puzzles preservationists. One owner is considering a deal to move one of the houses to Japan. Wright designed the houses with modularity in mind: they can be taken apart and reassembled, block by block.

headline: Years Later, No Magic Bullet Against Alzheimer’s Disease
text: BETHESDA, Md.  The scene was a kind of science court. On trial was the question “Can anything  running on a treadmill, eating more spinach, learning Arabic  prevent Alzheimer’s disease or delay its progression?”

headline: Spokes | When Two Wheels Are Too Many
text: John Stone does not want to hear your joke about his unicycle. He has heard all of them already. He doesn’t want to hear you whistle “Entry of the Gladiators,” that circus song. He is not a clown. He’s a commuter on his way to work, just like you. He just rides a giant 36-inch wheeled unicycle from his home on the Upper West Side down to his job as a composer near Astor Place.

headline: Skilled at the Chessboard, Keyboard and Blackboard

Maynard, and a challenger, William A. Young:

headline: Neighborly Borrowing, Over the Online Fence
