headline: Prime Number
text: 190: The amount, in dollars, that a family earning $75,000 a year would need to save each month over 18 years to cover expenses at a public college ($51,000 over four years), according to Fidelity Investments. The number jumps to $410 a month for a private college ($115,000). A family making $100,000 would need to save $250 a month for a public college and $460 monthly for a private one. To compute the out-of-pocket cost, Fidelity calculated how much in scholarships, grants and gifts the family could expect to receive, and assumed the savings would be invested in a 529 plan that delivered a return in line with what the company’s age-based investment option would provide. The price of college is rising at an average of 5.4 percent a year, Fidelity said, twice the overall rate of inflation.

headline: Warning to Birds: All-Glass Buildings Ahead
text: LIVING the green life can get complicated — even when we’re picking out windowpanes.

headline: The Case for Reviving Revenue Sharing
Police Committee’s Agenda Rarely Concerns Crime
text: Violence and crime do not lead the discussion among members of the City Council committee overseeing violence and crime.

headline: With Race by Father Barred, Son Is Seeking His Old Job
text: Ambrosio Medrano Sr. resigned from the City Council 14 years ago after he was caught taking bribes, and he is prohibited from running for office again. Now his son is hoping to reclaim the father’s old job representing the 25th Ward on the near West Side.

headline: High-Speed-Rail Plan Will Test California
text: The Bay Area has a reputation as a place where it’s hard to get things done, but you’d never know it from all the recent progress on transformative megaprojects.

headline: City’s Restrictive Gun Laws Are Rarely Enforced
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley has long insisted that the city’s restrictive gun laws  including the handgun ban that was essentially nullified recently by the United States Supreme Court  have been a key crime-fighting tool.

headline: It’s Easy to Take Spill Off Political High-Wire
text: In this political summer of living dangerously, Robert Dold is just one of many politicians to inspire head-scratching.

headline: Plan Would Aid Some Veterans’ Businesses
text: Veterans with service-related disabilities who own businesses will have a better chance to win Cook County government contracts under legislation to be introduced this week by a county commissioner.

headline: Every Crisis Is Different
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Pain for Savers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Battling Unhealthy Diets
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rivalry Awaits Its New York Moment
text: Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer performed their compelling act a few times at Wimbledon, several more times in Paris, but also in Madrid, Shanghai, Dubai, Hamburg and Monaco. The rivalry between Nadal and Federer, considered the two best tennis players in the world, has been showcased all over the globe, but never in New York.

headline: How to Match Companies and Causes
text: Q. You are interested in establishing a volunteer program for employees at your company as a way to help the community. Where do you start?

headline: Burnett’s Struggles Don’t End at Hitters
text: CHICAGO  A. J. Burnett’s fastball command abandoned him Friday night, and he could not throw his curveball for strikes, either. Those are obvious reasons why the White Sox battered him for nine runs, extending his August troubles and potentially jeopardizing his spot in the Yankees’ rotation. Manager Joe Girardi has noticed something a little more subtle.

headline: Determined to Learn
text: I WAS the third of four children in a family in Langroud, an agricultural area in northern Iran near the Caspian Sea. My father owned a trucking company. My mother was a homemaker who did not read or write. Her parents would not allow her to attend school after the government in the 1930s abolished the requirement that women cover their heads.

headline: Contrasts In Search For a Closer
text: Because the Mets had no save opportunity Saturday night, Manager Jerry Manuel did not have to decide between Bobby Parnell and Hisanori Takahashi.

headline: Europeans’ Final Tryout to Make Ryder Cup Team
text: PARAMUS, N.J.  With all due respect to the spectators at Ridgewood Country Club, for four players at the Barclays, the audience that matters most this weekend is an ocean away.

headline: Laird Steps Into Void at the Barclays, Where Woods Finds No Way Back
text: PARAMUS, N.J.  Martin Laird, a 27-year-old Scotsman with a single PGA Tour victory, spent this time last year in England with his sisters. Having failed to qualify for the FedEx Cup playoffs, he did not touch a golf club for three weeks.

headline: Planned Parenthood Clinics Are Stripped of Affiliation After Complaints
text: A financial and administrative meltdown in recent years has led to the end of one of the largest Planned Parenthood affiliates in the United States.

headline: Church Censures Minister After Same-Sex Marriages
text: For four days last week, the small beige Covenant Presbyterian Church on the outskirts of Napa was turned into a courtroom.

headline: Black Power Statue
text: Tommie Smith and John Carlos are honored alumni on the San Jose State University campus for their protest gesture on the awards podium at the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City. The $300,000 statue demonstrates the university’s concern for social justice.

headline: Children of the Storm, 5 Years Later
text: The photographer Brenda Ann Kenneally recently visited two of the families she photographed for a 2006 New York Times Magazine photo essay, "Children of the Storm."

headline: A Memorable Travers for the Winning Trainer, and the Photo Proves It
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  They were a couple of horses saddled by quintessential New Yorkers, who had largely been forgotten in the days before the Travers Stakes. But when Afleet Express and Fly Down hit the wire, seemingly in tandem, they put the trainers Jimmy Jerkens and Nick Zito front and center, waiting outside the winner’s circle wondering if it was safe to go in.

headline: Age Rules for Sun City
text: ¶Children under 19 may visit a total of 90 days per year per residence, but they may not live in Sun City.

headline: Retirement Haven Hunts Youthful Violators
text: SUN CITY, Ariz.  From behind the wheel of his minivan, Bill Szentmiklosi scours the streets of Sun City in search of zoning violations like unkempt yards and illegal storage sheds. Mostly, though, he is on the lookout for that most egregious of all infractions: children.

headline: Spit, Glue and Maybe Even Chewing Gum
text: AMERICANS, take heed. Here is what it takes to bring one of the world’s great transportation networks to its knees: a tiny electrical fire in an obscure contraption of levers and pulleys, installed nearly a century ago.

headline: Held for Evading a Fare, Then Charged in a Rape
text: An arrest in an East Harlem subway station on Friday led, through an unusual set of circumstances, to the suspect being charged a day later with the rape and beating last month of a 79-year-old woman in the elevator of her Bronx apartment building, the police said.

headline: Upstarts Chip Away at Power of Pakistani Elite
text: MUZAFFARGARH, Pakistan  In Pakistan, where politics has long been a matter of pedigree, Jamshed Dasti is a mongrel. The scrappy son of an amateur wrestler, Mr. Dasti has clawed his way into Pakistan’s Parliament, beating the wealthy, landed families who have ruled here.

headline: For Obama, Steep Learning Curve as Chief in War
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama rushed to the Oval Office when word arrived one night that militants with Al Qaeda in Yemen had been located and that the military wanted to support an attack by Yemeni forces. After a quick discussion, his counterterrorism adviser, John O. Brennan, told him the window to strike was closing.

headline: Fighting Words
text: A proposed skyscraper two blocks west of the Empire State Building could, if built, obscure the iconic tower in views of the city from the west. Still, plans for the building were approved by the New York City Council.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Santana, Less Than His Best, Gets His Usual Level of Support
text: During Houston’s 4-1 victory against the Mets on Saturday night at Citi Field, a pitch by Johan Santana in the fifth inning hit the Astros’ Michael Bourn on the rear end.

headline: Sabathia Finds Trouble, but Also a Way to Win
text: CHICAGO  When C. C. Sabathia threw his most important pitch of the game Saturday, there were two outs in the bottom of the fifth and no one on base for the Chicago White Sox. The pitch was a slider, and not an especially biting one at that, but it still fooled Carlos Quentin. The previous two innings, Sabathia trudged off the mound wearing a disgusted look, having surrendered two-run homers that ignited a White Sox comeback.

headline: Even Players Are Wondering About Famous Federer Video
text: Did Roger Federer do it, or was it a fake? That has been the question posed to virtually every prominent player who attended a news conference Saturday regarding his now famous William Tell video in which he twice hits a metal bottle off someone’s head with a serve. While most players claimed they hadn’t seen the video, Andy Murray was unequivocal about it’s authenticity.

headline: Manning Holds Up, but Giants Struggle
text: BALTIMORE  After quarterback Eli Manning warmed up for the Giants’ preseason game against the Baltimore Ravens on Saturday, he removed his helmet with ease and placed it on an orange water cooler. A teammate handed Manning a baseball cap, and he nestled it atop his mop of brown hair.

headline: Oudin Will Play First at Ashe Stadium
text: The United States Open announced the schedule of play for Monday and the first player on court at Arthur Ashe Stadium will be none other than Melanie Oudin, the darling of last year’s tournament. Oudin will face the qualifier Olga Savchuk of Ukraine at 11 a.m. Eastern.

headline: Early Lead for Cavendish
text: The Vuelta a España began with an 8.1-mile team time trial Saturday night through the winding streets of Seville. The HTC-Columbia team won in 14 minutes 6 seconds. Its top rider, Mark Cavendish, will wear the leader’s red jersey for Sunday’s stage, from Alcalá de Guadaíra to Marbella.

headline: 5-Year-Old Hurt in Bronx Hit-and-Run
text: A 5-year-old boy was critically injured Saturday evening when he was hit by a sport utility vehicle whose driver then fled the scene, the police said.

headline: Vows: Anne & Tomás
text: Dr. Anne Griffin and Dr. Tomás Neilan met in 2007 at a bar across from their job. After their first date, Dr. Neilan said that every date since has made him wish he met Dr. Griffin 10 years ago.

headline: Corrections
text: An answer in the Q&A column on Aug. 15 about an overnight trip to York and Durham in England misstated the room rate for the Alexander House in York; rates are £42.50 per person in a double, not simply £42.50 for a double. The answer also referred incorrectly to York Minster’s great east window, the largest sheet of medieval stained glass in the world. The window is now covered while it undergoes a restoration, so it cannot in fact be viewed at this time.

headline: Corrections
text: An answer in the Q&A column on Aug. 15 about Balboa Island in Orange County in California misstated the length of time a ferry from Balboa Peninsula to the island takes; it is about 4 minutes, not 30.

headline: Lunchtime in London: Great Composers at St. James’s
text: Three times a week classical music lovers can take in a midday concert at St. James’s Church, centrally located in London’s Piccadilly. Each Monday, Wednesday and Friday works by a variety of great composers, performed by various musicians and groups from the city and elsewhere, come to life in the nearly 400-year-old church.

headline: Coughlin and Tuck Concerned About ‘Energy’
text: As Ross Tucker wrote in Sports Illustrated, you really can’t make too much of a Week 3 August game, even though it’s supposed to be the most important of the preseason games.

headline: S. Korea Premier-designate Quits
text: SEOUL  Prime Minister-designate Kim Tae-ho of South Korea resigned on Sunday amid allegations that he lied about his connections with a businessman convicted of bribery.

headline: Classic Ad: A Love Letter to De Soto
text: O.K., so maybe Lewis deSoto’s concept cars, profiled in today’s Automobiles section by Nick Czap, aren’t actually De Sotos. But Mr. deSoto’s “vague familial connection” with the Spanish explorer, from whom the Chrysler brand took its name, is close enough for us.

headline: Styled to a T | Richard Ashcroft
text: The Trend

headline: Lucic, Former Teenage Star, Makes Grand Slam Comeback
text: Eleven years ago, Mirjana Lucic was a fresh-faced Croatian teenager who wowed the tennis world with a semifinal run at Wimbledon that included wins over Monica Seles and Nathalie Tauziat.

headline: A 64-GB Hard Drive the Size of a Stamp
text: In the not too distant technological past, a computer’s storage drives filled a space not much smaller than my living room. The new 64-gigabyte solid-state drive from SanDisk is the size of a postage stamp.

headline: Afghan Fatalities Rise in Weekend Violence
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Seven American soldiers were killed in fighting in eastern and southern Afghanistan over the weekend, after several weeks of declining death tolls among NATO forces.

headline: Hamilton Races to Victory Through the Chaos
text: It was clear from the first lap that the Belgian Grand Prix through the rollercoaster circuit in the Ardennes Forest was going to be unpredictable to the end.

headline: Sunday Word: Five Years On
text: President Obama travels to New Orleans today, five years after Hurricane Katrina made landfall on the Louisiana-Mississippi border.

headline: Tweet-a-Joke for the Emmys
text: LOS ANGELES –Jimmy Fallon is bringing to the Emmys one of his signatures of “Late Night”: his Web savvy.

headline: Way Back Machine | Citizen Spies, 1901 Edition
text: Asking you to say something if you happen to see something is a modest request. But what might induce you to adopt a disguise and spy on your fellow citizens? How about a generous proliferation of vice, combined with a healthy dose of corrupt law enforcement, and some strong encouragement (including a small stipend) from morally minded civic leaders?

headline: Anger in Hong Kong Over Manila Siege
text: HONG KONG  Drawn by a mixture of anger and grief, tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents poured into the streets on Sunday to protest how the Philippine government handled a bus siege in Manila last Monday that ended in the shooting deaths of eight Hong Kong residents and the dismissed police officer who had taken them hostage.

headline: Sanofi’s Bid Puts Pressure on Genzyme
text: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, publicly disclosed its $18.5 billion bid for Genzyme on Sunday, intensifying pressure on the American biotechnology company to engage in discussions about a sale.

headline: Pettitte Feels Good After Bullpen Session
text: CHICAGO — Everything went well for Andy Pettitte on Sunday morning when he ramped up the intensity in the second half of a 35-pitch bullpen session. No problems with his left groin. His arm bounced back better than he expected. And, after some early tentativeness, he was able to throw cutters and curveballs without discomfort.

headline: Donald Moves Into Contention With Fast Start
text: PARAMUS, N.J. — Ryan Palmer turned heads in the first round of the Barclays when he opened with five consecutive birdies, matching the best start to a round anyone has had on the PGA Tour this year.

headline: At the Emmys: Back to Basics
text: LOS ANGELES — The Primetime Emmys, the most glittering night of the year in television, are a production headache.

headline: Could This Be the Red Bulls’ Championship Season?
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The Red Bulls have built a glittering stadium, added a couple of glittering stars and, especially after Saturday night’s 2-0 win over visiting San Jose, actually look like a soccer team — a real soccer team.

headline: Another Perspective on Revenue-Sharing
text: J.C. Bradbury is right that baseball’s revenue-sharing system is broken. But his recommendation to end it rather than mend it would throw out the baby with the bathwater.

headline: Time Warner Cable and Disney Are Near a Deal on Fees
text: LOS ANGELES — It looks as though Time Warner Cable customers won’t lose ESPN after all.

headline: Montgomerie Picks Three for European Ryder Cup Team
text: 9:01 p.m. | Updated PARAMUS, N.J. — Edoardo Molinari birdied the last three holes at Gleneagles to win the Johnnie Walker Championship on Sunday by one stroke, and his day only got better from there.

headline: Predictions I Wish Had Been Wrong
text: Looking for some other stuff, I found this post from October 2008 in which I predicted a level of right-wing craziness about Obama similar to that facing Bill Clinton, but worse.

headline: The Morning After Beck
text: On the morning after a big Saturday wedding, it is sometimes customary for newly united families to hold a low-key brunch for guests who are still in town.

headline: A Defensive Maneuver Proves Worthy of a Trophy
text: You are West, defending against four spades. You lead the club ace: ten, deuce, three. Partner’s deuce is, by partnership agreement, a suit-preference signal for diamonds. What do you do next?

headline: Belgian Church Leader Urged Victim to Be Silent
text: PARIS — The former leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium urged a victim of serial sexual abuse by a bishop to keep silent for a year, until the bishop — the victim’s own uncle — could retire, according to tapes made by the victim last April and published over the weekend in two Belgian newspapers.

headline: Jets’ Pace to Miss Opener With Broken Foot
text: Linebacker Calvin Pace, who led the Jets with eight sacks last season, will miss at least the regular-season opener against Baltimore with a broken right foot.

headline: Chechen Leader’s Village Is Attacked
text: MOSCOW  Insurgents in Chechnya, in southern Russia, attacked the home village of the region’s leader Sunday, touching off a battle in which over a dozen people were killed, officials said.

headline: Actors’ Protest and Rabbi’s Sermon Stoke Tensions in Israel Ahead of Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Israel was in an uproar on Sunday over a refusal by Israeli theater artists to perform in West Bank Jewish settlements, and Palestinians were outraged by a virulently anti-Palestinian sermon by a Jerusalem rabbi, further fueling the atmosphere days before the expected resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in Washington.

headline: Comments by German on Minorities Are Criticized
text: BERLIN  A board member of Germany’s central bank provoked strong criticism on Sunday after saying that “all Jews share a particular gene” that “makes them different from other peoples,” and that Muslim immigrants across Europe are unwilling or incapable of assimilating into Western societies.

headline: Qualifier Falconi’s Success Rooted in New York City Park
text: Irina Falconi learned to play tennis on the public courts of Inwood Hill Park in Inwood, but the 20-year-old, who moved to Florida as a teenager, made just one visit to the United States Open as a youngster.

headline: McCoy Tyner Helps Claim a Corner of a Harlem Park for Jazz
text: The permanent amphitheater in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem is a void right now. It’s being rebuilt, band shell and seating. So the Harlem part of the two-day Charlie Parker Jazz Festival, on Saturday afternoon, was moved to a rented stage on a lawn at the northeast corner of the park, next to the farmer’s market, which was still open when the first band started. Later on, a boisterous African drum circle took shape not 100 feet from the stage while McCoy Tyner, though unhappy with the piano’s tuning, boistered back through a solo set.

headline: No Victory, but Positives Still for Woods
text: PARAMUS, N.J. — Tiger Woods did not end up contending for his first tournament victory of the year at the Barclays on Sunday, but he at least made a case that his stellar first round was not just blind luck.

headline: Plato’s Pop Culture Problem, and Ours
text: This fall, the U.S. Supreme Court will rule on a case that may have the unusual result of establishing a philosophical link between Arnold Schwarzenegger and Plato.

headline: Obama Pledges Commitment to New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS  President Obama on Sunday sought to assure this city, battered by two catastrophic disasters in five years, that federal efforts to rebuild after Hurricane Katrina would not waver even as the city struggles with the aftermath of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: The Big Game Is Coming, but Where’s the Coach?
text: Thank goodness for Arlene A. McGruder. As Coach Hicks in Layon Gray’s otherwise unremarkable “All-American Girls,” she makes Louis Gossett Jr.’s drill-sergeant character from “An Officer and a Gentleman” look like a weakling.

headline: U.S. Commander Fears Political Stalemate in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  The departing commander of American forces in Iraq, Gen. Ray Odierno, said Sunday that a new Iraqi government could still be two months away and warned that a stalemate beyond that could create demands for a new election to break the deadlock, which has lasted since March.

headline: An Audience Visits With Hedda Gabler at Home, a Real Home
text: Stay out of the way of that Hedda Gabler woman. I’m serious. If you stretch your legs, she might well trip over them. She’s a frisky little thing, in her cropped black pants and ankle boots, prone to activities like jumping up and down on an ottoman or pouring Champagne over a teetotaling guest. And she’s often close enough to you — yes, you, lucky theatergoer — to plop right down into your lap, should she choose.

headline: Report Calls for ‘Fundamental Reform’ of Climate Panel
text: 3:40 p.m. | Updated  The InterAcademy Council report is out, and recommends “fundamental reform of I.P.C.C. management structure.” Here’s coverage in The Times.

headline: Ad Hoc Quartet With Common Roots
text: MARLBORO, N.Y.  A few songs into a jazz summit meeting at the Falcon here on Saturday night, the all-stars went through an unannounced lineup rotation. John Scofield had just started into his guitar solo on “Hacksensack,” a Thelonious Monk tune, backed by the drummer Jack DeJohnette and the bassist Larry Grenadier. That was when the saxophonist Joe Lovano lumbered around the drum kit, grabbed a pair of sticks and took over, without breaking the chug-a-lug on a ride cymbal. Mr. DeJohnette sidled over to a piano to stab at some Monkish chords. The scene suggested the madcap grace and giddiness of a Marx Brothers routine.

headline: New CDs
text: JENNY AND JOHNNY

headline: Open House Kickoff
text: Gerald Marzorati, editor of The New York Times Magazine, and Michael Kimmelman, chief art critic, are blogging the U.S. Open from the fan's perspective.

headline: Monday: Where’s Claudius?
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Give the constructor Richard Chisholm a hand for today’s Monday puzzle. In fact, give him two. That would be more appropriate. Mr. Chisholm turned 86 this year. The photo on XWord Info shows him at an outdoor cafe in Barcelona, Spain. Solving may or may not keep the brain agile, but perhaps constructing does.

headline: Handsome Guy Is Dying, but He Can Afford Care
text: One of the odder movies to come down the Bollywood pike recently, Nagesh Kukunoor’s genre-defying “Aashayein” (“Wishes”) looks at dying in a comic-cosmic way that embraces both magical thinking and fatalism.

headline: Finding Poetry in Schoenberg’s Hurdles
text: When the pianist Steven Beck played Stravinsky, Schoenberg and Debussy at Bargemusic on Friday evening, the intellectual rigor of the early-20th-century works on the program was a palate cleanser after the heady emotions in the flurry of Schumann and Chopin bicentennial events this season.

headline: Detroit Symphony Players Reject Contract Proposals
text: With their contract due to expire at midnight on Sunday, the players of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra on Saturday rejected the administration’s proposals for a renewal and authorized their negotiating committee and union to call a strike if necessary.

headline: China Fortifies State Businesses to Fuel Growth
text: BEIJING  During its decades of rapid growth, China thrived by allowing once-suppressed private entrepreneurs to prosper, often at the expense of the old, inefficient state sector of the economy.

headline: Footnote
text: For the Sept. 14 opening-night performance of its inaugural fall season, New York City Ballet has announced reduced ticket prices: $50 for all seats in the orchestra and in the first, second and third rings of the David H. Koch Theater; and $25 for the fourth ring. Single tickets are on sale at nycballet.com or through CenterCharge, (212) 721-6500.

headline: I Am A Psychotic Ferret
text: And I’m proud!

headline: Theatrical Spills and Award Thrills
text: Brooke Shields, below, broke her right hand during rehearsals for “Leap of Faith,” a new musical at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles, but her representative told People.com that the injury was not expected to delay the show, which begins previews on Sept. 11. The production, which also stars Raúl Esparza, has music by Alan Menken and lyrics by Glenn Slater, and is based on the 1992 Steve Martin film of the same title about a bogus faith healer in rural Kansas. Producers have said they hope to bring it to Broadway. ... The first Horton Foote Prize for playwrights has been awarded for two plays: Lynn Nottage’s “Ruined” won for outstanding new American play, and Will Eno’s “Middletown” took the award for promising new American play. Each winner will receive $15,000 and a photograph of Foote, the playwright and screenwriter (“To Kill a Mockingbird”) who died last year at 92.

headline: A Beatle’s Toilet Gets Top Dollar
text: A toilet that once belonged to John Lennon was sold for £9,500 (about $14,700) at an auction in Liverpool on Saturday, Reuters reported. Lennon had the blue-and-white porcelain commode removed from his home in Tittenhurst Park in Berkshire, in southern England, where he lived from 1969 to 1971; he gave it to a builder, John Hancock, telling him to “put flowers in it or something,” according to the auction catalog. Mr. Hancock stored the toilet in his shed for 40 years, and on Saturday it was sold to an unidentified buyer as part of a sale of Beatles-related memorabilia that included a rare mono copy of Lennon and Yoko Ono’s album “Two Virgins” and a harmonica that belonged to Lennon’s son Julian.  Those items went for £2,500 (about $3,900) each.

headline: ‘Last Exorcism’ Tops Slow Weekend at the Movies
text: Movie theaters were quiet over the weekend, with ticket sales for the Top 12 films down 11 percent compared with the same period last year. A PG-13 rating and a wide release helped push the horror movie “The Last Exorcism” (Lionsgate) to No. 1 with about $21.3 million in grosses, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles sales data. (Right, Ashley Bell, on bed and Caleb Landry Jones.) “Takers,” a moderately budgeted crime thriller from Sony Pictures Entertainment, was a close second with $21 million. Sylvester Stallone’s “Expendables” (Lionsgate), the No. 1 film for the last two weeks, fell to No. 3 with $9.5 million, bringing its total to $82 million. “Eat Pray Love” (Sony) was fourth with $7 million for a new total of $60.7 million, while “The Other Guys” (Sony), starring Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg, was fifth with $6.6 million, for a total of $99.3 million. A rerelease of “Avatar” (20th Century Fox) with eight minutes of new footage squeezed $4 million more out of that blockbuster to bring its domestic box office total to $753.8 million.

headline: Obama Turned Me Into A Newt
text: But I got better.

headline: Rookie Nova Delivers Outing Yankees Have Been Missing
text: CHICAGO  A few hours later, Ivan Nova would be making his second career start for a team locked in a tense division battle. So before going to sleep Saturday night, he placed a call to his mother, Altegracia, who was back in New York. You have nothing to worry about, she told him.

headline: Paris Hilton Arrested on Drug Charge
text: Paris Hilton, below, was arrested in Las Vegas late Friday night on suspicion of felony cocaine possession after a small container of the drug fell out of her purse in full view of a police officer, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Hilton, 29, was in a black Cadillac Escalade being driven down the Strip by her boyfriend, Cy Waits, when a police officer smelled marijuana smoke wafting from the car and pulled it over. When Ms. Hilton stepped out of the car and reached for some lip balm, Sgt. John Sheahan of the Las Vegas Police Department said, “a bindle of cocaine in a plastic bag came out of her purse.” She was booked and released on her own recognizance, and by 2:56 a.m. on Saturday wrote on Twitter that she was in bed enjoying the television show “Family Guy.” Ms. Hilton was arrested this year in South Africa on suspicion of marijuana possession while attending the World Cup, but the charges were dropped.

headline: Court Wins for Dicaprio
text: Leonardo DiCaprio won victories in court last week against two women he had accused of abusive behavior. On Wednesday Judge Carol Boas Goodson of Los Angeles County Superior Court granted a temporary restraining order against Livia Bistriceanu, 41, whom Mr. DiCaprio said had claimed to be his wife and carrying his baby, The Associated Press reported. According to Mr. DiCaprio’s complaint, Ms. Bistriceanu tried to meet him at his home and office, acted aggressively and refused to leave. “Given this obsessive and harassing behavior,” Mr. DiCaprio, 35, said in court papers, “I am frightened of Ms. Bistriceanu and feel that my personal safety, and the personal safety of those around me, is in jeopardy.” On Thursday another woman, Aretha Wilson, 40, was ordered to stand trial on a charge of slashing Mr. DiCaprio’s face with a broken bottle at a Hollywood party in 2005.

headline: Finding Spot in History Without Looking
text: Rafael Nadal greets questions about tennis history, specifically his standing in it, as if someone spiked his Gatorade with sour milk. This is perhaps his least favorite topic. His eyes narrow. His face contorts. He often appears offended.

headline: No Consistency for Giants’ Offensive Line
text: When tackle Kareem McKenzie missed the Giants’ 24-10 loss to the Baltimore Ravens on Saturday because of headaches, his ailment was also an apt description of the offensive line this preseason.

headline: The Best of Rivals and Best of Friends, Then and Always
text: “That’s a woman thing,” Chris Evert was saying the other night.

headline: Jazz in the Park
text: Photos from the Charlie Parker Festival in Harlem.

headline: Point/Counterpoint: Nadal’s Legacy
text: Does Rafael Nadal need a U.S. Open title to cement his legacy? The Times’s Lynn Zinser and Thomas Lin debate.

headline: Preppily Perplexed? A New Guidebook
text: In 1980 “The Official Preppy Handbook” arrived as a field guide to the habits of the cotillion-hopping, madras-wearing, loafer-shod upper crust. Was it a valentine, a joke or a prophecy? This much is clear: It began life as a $3.95 paperback and stayed on the New York Times best-seller list for more than a year. Copies were plentiful, yet asking prices for used ones today can easily top $100 and sometimes exceed $1,000. Somebody must think it contains useful information.

headline: Hip-Hop History, Recreated by Those Who Made It
text: What kind of oldies concert draws a huge audience in its 20s? Rock the Bells, the daylong hip-hop festival that came to Governors Island on Saturday. This year’s Rock the Bells borrowed an idea from the indie-rock festival All Tomorrow’s Parties, booking groups to perform watershed albums in their entirety.

headline: Youth Movement Stalls
text: Boris Becker boomed serves past his elders to win Wimbledon at 17. Michael Chang outran and outwitted them to win the French Open at the same age. Martina Hingis won three Grand Slam titles before she even turned 17.

headline: Rock the Bells
text: Images from the festival of rap music on Governors Island.

headline: What to Watch on Monday at the Open
text: The United States Open kicks off Monday with plenty of star power on display at Arthur Ashe Stadium including Andy Roddick, Kim Clijsters, Venus Williams and Roger Federer.

headline: 2010 Emmy Award Nominees and Winners
text: A list of nominees and winners of 2010 prime time Emmy Awards (winners are denoted in bold with a ).

headline: Emmys Fashion: Dressed for Stress
text: “Gym-tan-laundry Emmys”: Jimmy Fallon sums up the red carpet, riffing on a line from “Jersey Shore.” Lots of tanned and gym-toned bodies packed into gowns. You don’t have the feeling that people are relaxed, or dressed to feel relaxed.

headline: Peace and Roti at the Golden Temple
text: The Golden Temple is the holiest shrine of the Sikh religion. It is also home to one of the largest free eateries in the world.

headline: Opening Up the Peer Review Process
text: To the Editor:

headline: Emmys Fashion: A Relaxed Exception
text: An actress wears her own shoes on the red carpet — for comfort! Julianna Margulies, a best actress nominee for “The Good Wife,” admits she is wearing her own shoes with her navy beaded L’Wren Scott dress.

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for July (Monday); S.& P./Case-Shiller home price index for June and second quarter, Chicago purchasing managers’ index for August and consumer confidence for August (Tuesday); North American car sales for August; construction spending for July, ADP employment for August and the ISM manufacturing index for August (Wednesday); retailers’ same-store sales for August, pending home sales for July, factory orders for July and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for August and the ISM service index for August (Friday).

text: Photographs from the red carpet at the 2010 Emmy Awards.

headline: Unsolved Civil Rights Killings: The F.B.I. View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Orange County’s Changing Politics
text: Orange County, Calif., has been a national symbol of conservatism for more than 50 years, but the percentage of registered Republican voters dropped to 43 percent in June, the lowest level in 70 years.

headline: Orange County Is No Longer Nixon Country
text: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Orange County has been a national symbol of conservatism for more than 50 years: birthplace of President Richard M. Nixon and home to John Wayne, a bastion for the John Birch Society, a land of orange groves and affluence, the region of California where Republican presidential candidates could always count on a friendly audience.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Politicians on the Run
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Pace, Set for Surgery, Will Miss Jets’ Opener
text: Linebacker Calvin Pace, who led the Jets with eight sacks last season, will miss at least the regular-season opener against the Baltimore Ravens on Sept. 13 with a broken right foot.

headline: Healthy and Hungry Again After Three Lost Summers
text: One of the many revelations in Andre Agassi’s autobiography, “Open,” involved Marcos Baghdatis, who is re-emerging as a force after his career went into free fall following his runner-up finish in the 2006 Australian Open.

headline: With Eastern European Flavor, WTA Seeks Recipe for Success
text: MONTREAL  In the 1970s, the early days of the women’s tennis tour, the calendar was dominated by tournaments in the United States, and the draws were filled mostly with Americans. At the end of 1980, the world rankings had 31 Americans in the top 50. Australia was next, with four.

headline: In Israel, Settling for Less
text: Tel Aviv

headline: Emmys Fashion: Some Conspicuous Absences
text: Giorgio Armani and Oscar de la Renta were among the big names represented on the Emmys red carpet tonight, but where were Valentino, Dior and Chanel, to name three labels that actresses typically blurt out?

headline: Benefit of Hitting Second Serve Like the First
text: Robin Soderling played Andy Roddick this month in Cincinnati, a match between two of the top servers in tennis. At one point, Soderling hit a 138-mile-per-hour ace. He missed his next big serve and followed it with a second attempt that crossed the net at 85 m.p.h. Roddick hammered it back to win the point.

headline: View of a Hurricane, 5 Years On
text: The television ratings have been modest for many of the special programs pegged to the fifth anniversary of Hurricane Katrina and the flooding of New Orleans.

headline: Notes for the Underground
text: San Francisco

headline: Revisiting Black History on Martha’s Vineyard
text: OAK BLUFFS, Mass.  As a getaway for two Democratic presidents, including the current one, Martha’s Vineyard is often disparaged as an undemocratic haven for wealthy white elites.

headline: Racket Manufacturer Creates Market for Something That Isn’t There
text: BORDENTOWN, N.J.  Holes.

headline: U.S. Open Tie Breaker Can Be a Concrete Crucible
text: Although Juan Martín del Potro needed five sets to dethrone Roger Federer last year in the United States Open final, the crucial moments came in tie breakers in the second and fourth sets.

headline: Families of Dead Soldiers Sue Insurer Over Its Handling of Survivors’ Benefits
text: Vickie Castro’s only child was killed six years ago just before Christmas, when a suicide bomber blew himself up inside an Army mess tent in Mosul, Iraq, killing more than 20 people.

headline: Katrina Film Takes Aim at Army Corps of Engineers
text: Harry Shearer, the radio host and voice artist behind the likes of Mr. Burns on “The Simpsons,” can’t resist a wisecrack. “Before there was oil, there was water,” reads Mr. Shearer’s tagline for “The Big Uneasy,” his documentary about the destruction of New Orleans by Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Nourishing Souls at the Golden Temple
text: Each day at the Golden Temple, tens of thousands of free vegetarian lunches are served by volunteers who embody India’s religious and ethnic mosaic.

headline: A Sikh Temple Where All May Eat, and Pitch In
text: AMRITSAR, India — The groaning, clattering machines never stop, transforming 12 tons of whole wheat flour every day into nearly a quarter-million discs of flatbread called roti. These purpose-built contraptions, each 20 feet long, extrude the dough, roll it flat, then send it down a gas-fired conveyor belt, spitting out a never-ending stream of hot, floppy, perfectly round bread.

headline: Coughlin Sees a Few Signs of Effort, but Not Enough
text: Maybe it was the few hours of sleep he had, but on Sunday afternoon, Coach Tom Coughlin softened  ever so slightly  his reaction to the Giants’ lethargic 24-10 loss to the Ravens on Saturday night in Baltimore.

headline: It’s Witch-Hunt Season
text: The last time a Democrat sat in the White House, he faced a nonstop witch hunt by his political opponents. Prominent figures on the right accused Bill and Hillary Clinton of everything from drug smuggling to murder. And once Republicans took control of Congress, they subjected the Clinton administration to unrelenting harassment  at one point taking 140 hours of sworn testimony over accusations that the White House had misused its Christmas card list.

headline: Mr. Beck Goes to Washington
text: Entering this weekend, I was convinced that Glenn Beck’s star was about to go into eclipse.

headline: A Book Attracts Loads of Facebook Fans. But Why?
text: Book authors have been searching eagerly for ways to harness social media to promote their works. So it would seem that Gregory Levey had stumbled upon the magic key after the Facebook fan page of his book went from having just 700 fans to 692,000 in a matter of months — more than New York City (570,000 fans) or the George Clooney fan page (613,000).

headline: An Arms Sales Suspect, Bargaining With Secrets
text: WASHINGTON  Accused of a 15-year run as one of the world’s biggest arms traffickers, Viktor Bout is thought to be a consummate deal maker.

headline: Mr. Feinberg and the Gulf Settlement
text: Kenneth Feinberg, charged with administering BP’s $20 billion compensation fund, has been here before. A master mediator, he showed compassion and business sense when he settled claims for the families of those killed in the Sept. 11 attacks, Vietnam veterans damaged by Agent Orange, and women harmed by the defective Dalkon Shield birth control device.

headline: Plans and Benchmarks for Haiti
text: The Interim Haiti Recovery Commission was set up after the Jan. 12 earthquake as a joint Haitian-international effort to effectively channel billions of dollars of donated reconstruction aid.

headline: Massacre in Tamaulipas
text: The full story of the massacre in Tamaulipas, in northeast Mexico, awaits telling by its one survivor. The early news accounts are horrifying: 72 people, said to be migrants from Central and South America on their way to the United States, are waylaid and imprisoned by drug smugglers on a ranch 100 miles south of Texas. They refuse to pay extortion fees and are executed. The survivor, shot in the neck, hears their screams for mercy as he flees. After a gun battle with the authorities, the killers escape in S.U.V.’s. The dead, 58 men and 14 women, are found piled in a room, discarded contraband.

headline: Iran Shifts Assets Out of Europe Banks
text: TEHRAN  Iran has transferred assets out of European banks in its latest effort to defend itself against the effects of sanctions that are part of what Iranian officials have called an “economic war” against the country by the United States and other Western countries.

headline: The Urgent Islands
text: If a country sinks beneath the sea, is it still a country? That is a question about which the Republic of the Marshall Islands — a Micronesian nation of 29 low-lying coral atolls — is now seeking expert legal advice. It is also a question the United States Senate might ask itself the next time it refuses to deal with climate change.

headline: Excelling for Mets, Dickey Has Eye on Side Job
text: With another terrific performance on Sunday, R. A. Dickey continued to demonstrate that he could perform at the highest level of his sport. Now he wants to show he can do it in another sport, only not as a player.

headline: NBC's Brian Williams Interviews Obama
text: NBC's Brian Williams and President Obama discuss New Orleans' long road to recovery, the state of the U.S. economy, the oil spill and Americans' questions about his religious faith.

headline: Accusation of Misconduct in Gambino Case
text: When federal authorities charged recently that the Gambino crime family had been involved in sex trafficking with girls as young as 15, one prosecutor suggested that the activity might represent “a new low for the Gambino family.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,231 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

headline: Obama Dismisses Faith Rumors
text: President Obama said on Sunday that he was not worried that increasing and significant numbers of Americans believe he is Muslim.

headline: Two Wins, Too Early to Get Excited
text: ISTANBUL  Mike Krzyzewski joked on Sunday that as a younger coach he might have thrown a chair in the locker room at halftime of the United States’ game against Slovenia.

headline: Kuchar Surges to Capture the Barclays in a Playoff
text: PARAMUS, N.J.  Tiger Woods saw the Barclays as a tournament he could have won, had his putter not betrayed him for the middle two rounds. The young Scotsman Martin Laird had no such problems, and he entered the final round with a three-stroke lead in large part because of his acumen on the greens.

headline: Bernanke Manages Expectations for Fed Role
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  Federal Reserve officials and economists appear increasingly united in their view that the partisan gridlock on fiscal policy in Washington has clouded the prospects for a faster and stronger recovery.

headline: With Neighbors Unaware, Toxic Spill at a BP Plant
text: TEXAS CITY, Tex.  While the world was focused on the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a BP refinery here released huge amounts of toxic chemicals into the air that went unnoticed by residents until many saw their children come down with respiratory problems.

headline: L.I.R.R. Service to Return to Normal
text: After a week of spoiled dinners, missed recitals and frustrating delays, riders on the Long Island Rail Road are to be greeted on Monday morning with the first day of full service since a fire in an antiquated switching machine snarled nearly every route on the railroad.

headline: Asked for Another Gear, Rachel Alexandra Falters
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The Rachel Alexandra camp had returned to the oldest racetrack in the nation to capture some of that old Saratoga magic. It was here nearly a year ago, after all, that she beat back the challenge of seven older male horses to win the Woodward Stakes and stamp herself, it seemed, as a filly for the ages.

headline: Risk-Taking Rises as Oil Rigs in Gulf Drill Deeper
text: In a remote reach of the Gulf of Mexico, nearly 200 miles from shore, a floating oil platform thrusts its tentacles deep into the ocean like a giant steel octopus.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Hot Day at the Beach, but Dangerous to Swim
text: The sky was so bright and cheering along the coast of New Jersey on Sunday that it practically blinded some beachgoers like Seth Theriault to the fact that they had chosen quite possibly the worst week of the summer to get away from the city.

headline: Woods Strengthens His Ryder Cup Case
text: If player performance in the PGA Tour’s FedEx Cup playoffs is a good predictor for United States success in the Ryder Cup, as the captain Corey Pavin says it is, then Pavin should be pleased by the results from the Barclays on Sunday.

headline: Border Sweeps in North Reach Miles Into U.S.
text: ROCHESTER — The Lake Shore Limited runs between Chicago and New York City without crossing the Canadian border. But when it stops at Amtrak stations in western New York State, armed Border Patrol agents routinely board the train, question passengers about their citizenship and take away noncitizens who cannot produce satisfactory immigration papers.

headline: Immigrants of Two Eras Join Together to Celebrate
text: BRENTWOOD, N.Y.

headline: The Hotel as Art Gallery
text: The James, a sleekly designed hotel rising over Grand Street in SoHo, will open for business on Wednesday with all the support staff a guest could expect: a concierge, receptionists, bellhops, chambermaids, parking valets.

headline: Cricket Scandal Rocks Pakistan
text: LONDON — For many Pakistanis, weighed down by their country’s descent into biblical levels of violence and flooding, there was a sense of a final straw in the crude betting scandal that broke over the weekend around the Pakistani cricket team, whose players have long been idols with feet of clay in a nation with few exemplars elsewhere to sustain fragile pride.

headline: Powell vs. Rangel: Testy Remake After 40 Years
text: About 30 years ago, Representative Charles B. Rangel invited a 19-year-old summer intern named Adam Clayton Powell IV into his office at the United States Capitol for an emotional conversation: He had run a bruising primary campaign in 1970 to unseat Mr. Powell’s father, he acknowledged, ending the career of a celebrated Harlem politician.

headline: Early Obstacle, and Test, at Start of Mideast Talks
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will begin his one-year effort to achieve Middle East peace on Wednesday, joining a long list of his predecessors who have tried to achieve a comprehensive peace between Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: A Flea Market Considers Its Fate in a Casino World
text: To the uncertainties over the arrival of casino gambling in a working-class neighborhood in Queens, add this: What will become of the sprawling flea market that has made its home at Aqueduct racetrack for more than 30 years? Will the vision of a lavish new Aqueduct, filled with thousands of slot machines and high-end restaurants, accommodate a down-market collection of stalls in a parking lot?

headline: Two Killed in Staten Island Car Crash
text: Two young men were killed and four others were injured in a single-car crash on Staten Island early on Sunday, the police said.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Intel Is Close to Acquisition of Infineon Wireless Unit
text: Intel was near a deal late on Sunday to acquire the wireless chip unit of Infineon Technologies, whose products are used in the Apple iPhone and other smartphones, for more than $1 billion, people involved in the negotiations said.

headline: ‘Modern Family’ and ‘Mad Men’ Win at Emmys
text: LOS ANGELES  It was the “Glee” misfits versus the “Modern Family” brood at the Primetime Emmys here on Sunday night, and the family took the top prize.

headline: A Dream Deferred, Almost Too Long
text: LAKE MARY, Fla. — During a doubles lesson at an Orlando sports club this month, Gigi Fernandez dragged her tennis racket along the service line. She told the women gathered around her to picture the line as the edge of a cliff: they stepped beyond it at their peril.

headline: ‘Modern Family’ and ‘Mad Men’ Top Emmy Awards
text: Sunday night, the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences presented the 62nd annual Primetime Emmy Awards. ArtsBeat followed the program live. A list of winner can be found here. A red carpet slide show can be found here and commentary from Cathy Horyn here and on Twitter.

headline: Imam Says Politics Has Stoked Controversy Over Center
text: The imam behind the proposed Islamic center near ground zero, Feisal Abdul Rauf, told a Middle Eastern newspaper that he believed election-year politics had stoked the debate over the project and blamed a “tiny, vociferous minority” for leading the opposition, in his most expansive comments yet on the controversy.

headline: William P. Foster, Pioneer of Florida A&M’s Marching 100, Dies at 91
text: William P. Foster, who revolutionized the once-staid world of collegiate marching bands as the founder and longtime director of the high-stepping, crowd-wowing Marching 100 band of Florida A&M University, died Saturday in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 91.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Retargeting Ads Follow Surfers to Other Sites
text: The shoes that Julie Matlin recently saw on Zappos.com were kind of cute, or so she thought. But Ms. Matlin wasn’t ready to buy and left the site.

headline: In California, an Old-Style Print War
text: San Francisco

headline: Harrington Is Ryder Cup Selection; Partner Isn’t
text: PARAMUS, N.J.  Paul Casey and Padraig Harrington teed off together in the final round of the Barclays on Sunday waiting to hear whether they were among the three captain’s picks for the European Ryder Cup team.

headline: Software War Pits Oracle vs. Google
text: Free open-source software began with high-technology tinkerers and researchers. Sharing code and ideas was their priority, not profits. In the tech industry, they were sometimes compared to socialists and communists.

headline: Japan Eases Monetary Policy to Combat Yen’s Rise
text: TOKYO  Japan’s central bank announced new measures to combat a faltering economy and rising yen on Monday, but held off from bolder steps, while the government said it would unveil a fresh stimulus plan.

headline: Tie Breakers to Remember
text: For Grand Slam tensions, it’s hard to beat a U.S. Open tie breaker.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: For ‘Hawaii Five-0,’ a Music-Filled Push From CBS
text: THERE have been police dramas on television called “Hawaii,” “Hawaiian Eye” and “Hawaiian Heat,” but the biggest gangbuster was “Hawaii Five-O,” which appeared on CBS from 1968 to 1980. Lush scenery in living color, a catchy theme song and a memorable catchphrase, “Book ’em, Danno,” all contributed to a successful run in prime time.

headline: Technology Aside, Most People Still Decline to Be Located
text: Internet companies have appropriated the real estate business’s mantra  it’s all about location, location, location.

headline: The 2010 Emmy Awards
text: The awards for television’s best were presented at the Nokia Theatre in Los Angeles.

headline:
'Hot Line' Opened by U.S. and Soviet to Cut
Attack Risk
text: Washington, Aug. 30 -- A diplomatic "hot line" between Moscow and Washington went into operation today with the simultaneous clattering of telecommunication machines in the Kremlin and the Pentagon.

headline: Shirley Booth, Star of TV, Radio, Stage and Screen, Is Dead at 94
text: Shirley Booth, an actress whose warmth and versatility brought her acclaim on stage, screen and television, died on Friday at her home in North Chatham, Mass. She was 94 years old.

headline: Sports Replay: Aug. 29
text: Images from the day in sports, including battles in a pool, a ring and on a mat.

headline: Platinum Is So Passé. In iTunes Era, the Singles Count.
text: By traditional measures, the British hip-hop artist Taio Cruz is far from being a star. But in the new world of pop music, he is certified gold.

headline: Bankers Told Recovery May Be Slow
text: The American economy could experience painfully slow growth and stubbornly high unemployment for a decade or longer as a result of the 2007 collapse of the housing market and the economic turmoil that followed, according to an authority on the history of financial crises.

headline: 2 New Federal Programs to Help Borrowers Pay Their Mortgages
text: The Obama administration plans to take two new steps in the next few weeks to help struggling homeowners pay their mortgages, said Shaun Donovan, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

headline: Fast-Moving and Manic, and All the Better for It
text: The best television shows are a group effort, so it was fitting that the opening number at the Emmys on Sunday night was a fast and quite funny musical number of many.

headline: United-Continental Merger Clears Federal Hurdle
text: The Justice Department said late Friday that it had approved the planned $3 billion merger between United Airlines and Continental, lifting the biggest regulatory hurdle to the creation of the world’s top airline, Jad Mouawad writes in The New York Times.

headline: Word of the Day | attentive
text: attentive •\ə-ˈten-tiv\• adjective

headline: A Hit Song on YouTube, Unnameable on the Radio
text: THERE is a world where when you see someone driving in a fancy car with the girl you love, you shout out, “Forget you!” It’s the same world where friends will talk smack about the crazy stuff their dads say.

headline: Trichet Cites Debt as Biggest Threat to Recovery
text: The diverging paths of the American and European economies could be discerned Friday in the speeches of Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: Takeover Targets Aren’t Defenseless
text: Companies have let their takeover guards down, but they’re hardly defenseless. Garden-variety antitakeover provisions, including rights plans and classified boards, are disappearing in North America. That ostensibly should make it easier for acquisitive predators to get their way, especially in a depressed market. Target firms, however, are showing pluck fending off unwanted suitors.

headline: Hinting That It’s Good to Be Bad
text: Americans are both privacy-mad, yet blithely self-revealing online. We post all kinds of embarrassing information about ourselves, but periodically erupt in a rage when we feel that our online privacy has been compromised. When do we care about privacy, and when don’t we?

headline: Beach Reads That Can Improve Your Game
text: Here are some books for the last days of summer reading. And yes, golf books qualify as beach reading.

headline: In Hard Times, One New Bank (Double-Wide)
text: The only new start-up bank to open in the United States this year operates out of a secondhand double-wide trailer, on a bare lot in front of the cavernous Trinity Baptist Church. A blue awning covers the makeshift drive-through window.

headline: When Giving Advice Becomes Too Much
text: Anne invited Betsy, Cristina and Elise to her club for a round of golf. Anne promised to give them advice as they played the course. The first hole has a blind tee shot. Anne said that the tree in the distance was in line with the middle of the fairway. The players teed off and proceeded to their balls.

headline: In the Finger Lakes, Enjoying a Master’s Vision
text: While playing the Cornell University golf course designed by Robert Trent Jones before World War II, I wondered at times what the great Jones saw in the land as he laid out the holes. Why does this fairway meander to the left when the landscape slopes to the right?

headline: Intel to Acquire Infineon Wireless Unit
text: 3:18 a.m. | Updated Less than two weeks after Intel said it would buy McAfee, the company announced Monday that it would acquire the German chip maker Infineon‘s wireless business for about $1.4 billion in cash.

headline: At Barça, Price of Dreams Varies
text: LONDON

headline: News Quiz | August 30, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Bernanke Tries to Manage Expectations of Fed Role
text: Federal Reserve officials and economists appear increasingly united in their view that the partisan gridlock on fiscal policy in Washington has clouded the prospects for a faster and stronger recovery, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Sanofi’s Bid Puts Pressure on Genzyme
text: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, publicly disclosed its $18.5 billion bid for Genzyme on Sunday, intensifying pressure on the American biotechnology company to engage in discussions about a sale, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Duff Wilson report in The New York Times.

headline: Morgenson: It’s Not Over Until It’s in the Rules
text: Having passed the Dodd-Frank Act earlier this summer, the bill that aspires to reorder our financial universe in the wake of the most serious economic crisis in generations, Congress has moved on to other matters. Regulators are left to write the rules that will make financial reform a reality — or not — and are beginning that laborious process, Gretchen Morgenson writes in The New York Times.

headline: 2 New Federal Programs to Help With Mortgages
text: The Obama administration plans to take two new steps in the next few weeks to help struggling homeowners pay their mortgages, said Shaun Donovan, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Three Men to Watch at the U.S. Open
text: Mardy Fish

headline: Three Women to Watch at the U.S. Open
text: Victoria Azarenka

headline: Daily Lexeme: Satispassion
text: Today’s word, in association with the incredible Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: From Dr. King to Mr. Beck
text: WHO rallied at the steps of the Lincoln Memorial on Saturday and WHO “summoned” them?

headline: Taiwan ‘Savior’ Is Said to Line Up Bid for A.I.G. Unit
text: A former Taiwanese diplomat who says he wants to “save” American International Group‘s Taiwan unit from being bought by a Chinese firm is lining up a $2.5 billion bid with Japanese and Middle Eastern money, Reuters reported.

headline: Agrium May Be Interested  in Potash Assets if BHP Sells
text: Canada’s Agrium said it would be interested in Potash Corp.‘s nitrogen and phosphates business, worth an estimated $12 billion, if miner BHP Billiton secures its $39 billion Potash takeover and decides to sell the assets, Reuters reported.

headline: Carlyle Said to Buy 51% Stake in Scalina
text: Carlyle Group concluded the purchase of a 51 percent stake in Brazil’s Scalina, the owner of a pantyhose maker, Reuters said, citing a report in Folha de S. Paulo on Sunday.

headline: Posco in Talks to Buy Norway’s Elkem
text: Posco is considering a takeover of Norway’s Elkem, a maker of silicon for solar panels, the chief executive of the South Korean group said, in a move that would give the world’s third largest steelmaker a presence in the fast growing renewable energy materials space, Reuters reported.

headline: As I.P.O.’s Stall, M.&A. Thrives
text: Languishing stock prices have put a brake on companies’ bids to tap public markets for new capital, while sparking a whirlwind of mergers and acquisitions from firms rushing to take advantage of cheap valuations, Reuters reported.

headline: Google Acquires Angstro, a Social Networking Aid
text: Google has acquired Angstro, a start-up that sorts news and information across social networks like Facebook, a spokesman for the leading Web search provider said on Sunday, Reuters reported.

headline: Virgin Active Cancels London I.P.O. Plan
text: Virgin Active Holdings, the health club owned by the billionaire, Richard Branson, has decided against a £1 billion ($1.6 billion) initial public offering of its shares in London, Bloomberg News said, citing a report in The Sunday Times.

headline: Nannies Under the Table
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: When Women Become Drag Queens
text: Today’s idea: In an odd result of the mainstreaming of gay culture, ordinary women are flaunting their inner drag queen, inspired by pop stars like Lady Gaga and Katy Perry, an article says. This raises the question: What’s the point of drag now anyway?

headline: Stylish Maps That Are Chatty
text: In today’s satellite-blanketed world of precise, GPS-determined maps, a splash of watercolor and some hand-written advice are nice, personal touches to pull out of your pocket while traveling. A la Carte Maps offers just that.

headline: Paris’s Belleville Hosts Its Own Biennale
text: Belleville and biennial are two words that are rarely seen together. While the first is the name of a colorful, but mostly run-down neighborhood on the eastern side of Paris, the other evokes international art events that gather the crème de la crème of contemporary art.

headline: AXA Halves Its Goldman Holdings in Quarter
text: AXA, the giant French insurer and once the largest shareholder in Goldman Sachs, cut its holdings in the investment bank in half over the last quarter as Goldman was plagued by the threat of a long legal battle with the Securities and Exchange Commission, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Sweden Moves to Shut HQ Bank, Revoking License
text: Sweden’s Financial Supervisory Authority revoked HQ Bank‘s license to operate and applied for its liquidation, saying the company broke regulations.

headline: Ex-Goldman Execs to Invest in Warehouse Fund
text: Everstone Capital Management, the private-equity and real estate fund adviser started by two former Goldman Sachs executives, may raise as much as $350 million for a new fund to invest in warehouses in India, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: How Do You React to News of Natural Disasters?
text: This weekend was the fifth anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, but this summer the floods in Pakistan have been front-page news, with nearly 20 million people significantly affected. Meanwhile, in Haiti, hundreds of displaced families from the January earthquake are still living in shanties. When you read or hear news of large-scale suffering and devastation like this, how do you react? Why? Why do you think some disasters get more coverage — and more attention and help from individuals — than others?

headline: Cisco Rumored to Make Offer for Skype
text: Cisco has reportedly made an offer to acquire the Internet phone firm Skype before it completes its planned initial public offering, TechCrunch said.

headline: Bullish Bets on Natural Gas Decline
text: Hedge funds cut bullish bets on natural gas to the lowest level this year, a sign that prices may be bottoming if history is a guide, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Klein Got $10 Million Advising Barclays on Lehman
text: Michael Klein, Citigroup‘s former vice chairman, earned a $10 million fee for advising Barclays on its acquisition of Lehman Brothers Holdings‘ brokerage business.

headline: Spotlight: Rachel Shukert
text: In this past weekend’s Book Review, Elisabeth Eaves reviewed Rachel Shukert’s second book, “Everything Is Going to Be Great: An Underfunded and Overexposed European Grand Tour.”

headline: Getting Started: The Chicken-and-Egg Question
text: In her first year of operation, Fran Gunsaulis, founder of Oh Baby Foods, learned that her business plan overlooked the logistical — and costly — realities of producing and distributing her organic, locally sourced baby foods. Her products are sustainable, but at a $5.80 cost per unit — down from $8.01 in 2009 — her business isn’t.

headline: From Fund Manager to Philanthropist
text: Last year, the billionaire fund manager Stanley F. Druckenmiller shifted $700 million of his own money to his family foundation. Before the transfer, the foundation had assets of about $6.5 million, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: How Hurricane Katrina Helped Save the Saints
text: It doesn’t happen often, but sometimes a sporting event is so much more than that. New Yorkers won’t soon forget Mike Piazza’s homer against the Braves in the first major league game in the city after 9/11. A hundred years from now, people will still probably bring up the United States’ hockey victory against the Soviet Union in the 1980 Winter Games.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — Scarce minerals are getting scarcer. From The New York Times: “Deng Xiaoping once observed that the Mideast had oil, but China had rare earth elements.”

headline: Tip of the Week: Turning Smartphones Into E-Readers
text: You don’t need to have a separate piece of hardware to read e-books from the major online bookstores like Amazon and Barnes & Noble. The e-reader software works on phones and computers. But e-readers like the Kindle and Nook do have an advantage over PCs, tablets and smartphones: a grayish screen that’s easy on the eyes.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Vegan Three-Bean Salad
text: “I was a vegetarian for a year, in 1994, when I was at the University of Texas at Austin,” said Tien Ho, 36, the executive chef and co-owner, with David Chang, of Má Pêche in Manhattan. “It was for all the wrong reasons.”

headline: Three Men to Watch in Flushing
text: Mardy Fish

headline: 3M to Buy Cogent Systems for $943 Million
text: Sept. 1, 3:50 p.m. | Corrected 3M said Monday that it had agreed to buy Cogent, a maker of biometric recognition systems, for $10.50 a share in a deal worth $943 million.

headline: Awaiting Jobs Data, Market Falls
text: Stocks fell on Monday as investors braced for a week of unemployment figures and economic data unlikely to stoke confidence in the prospects for growth.

headline: More Life Cereal Slogans Pitched by a Drunken Don Draper
text: Warning: this post may contain spoilers. A complete “Mad Men” recap by Ginia Bellafante will follow later this morning.

headline: Genzyme Rejects Sanofi Bid
text: Genzyme said Monday that it had it rejected Sanofi-Aventis‘s bid of $69 a share after its board voted unanimously against the offer on Sunday night.

headline: Open House: Good Morning, Day 1!
text: 9:47 a.m. | Updated Michael Kimmelman, The Times’s chief art critic and the Abroad columnist, kicked off this blog a few years ago with his “Art of Tennis” posts. He’s back this year, and under the banner “Open House,” he and Gerry Marzorati, editor of The Times’s Sunday Magazine and a longtime tennis fan, will cover Flushing Meadows from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they will discuss what’s happening at the Open. Join the conversation — or ask a fan-oriented question — by sending in a comment below.

headline: Japan Plans New Steps to Curb Yen
text: TOKYO  Japan promised a host of measures on Monday in a bid to ignite its faltering economy and temper a punishingly strong yen.

headline: Aging’s Misunderstood Virtues
text: When I asked Lars Tornstam, a Swedish sociologist, for an example of the state he calls gerotranscendence, he described a hypothetical daughter planning a cocktail party. Her elderly mother usually attends the affairs and enjoys herself, so the daughter invites her as usual — but this time, the mother declines. Naturally, the daughter worries. Is her mother ill? Depressed? This is not like her.

headline: Welcome Home
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared their happiest words in the English language.

headline: An Older Rangel vs. a Younger Powell
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Comedy Skits From a Manic Emmy Awards
text: Unless your name is Bucky Gunts or you had the misfortune to watch the middle third of the program, it’s hard to argue that Sunday’s Emmy Awards show wasn’t a success in its own right as a comedy-variety program. As Alessandra Stanley writes in Monday’s New York Times, the Emmys telecast yielded “a refreshingly light and speedy night that got a little manic at times.”

headline: Now Stitching | Brooklyn Shirting Gallery
text: Epaulet makes custom shirts, selvage jeans and corduroys in a shade of lime called ‘‘go-to-hell green.’’ Welcome to D.I.Y.-crazed Brooklyn. The emphasis at this modest Cobble Hill storefront is on fabric and fit: Epaulet’s button-fly chinos (from $135) have inspired cultish devotion because they fit snugly, like a perfect pair of jeans. ‘‘We run on the Louis Vuitton model,’’ says Michael Kuhle, who opened the store two years ago with his wife, Adele Berne. ‘‘We never do markdowns because all our stuff sells out.’’ Their latest offering is an urban safari shirt (above; $245) created with Hamilton, the Houston-based heritage label. It has easy-to-roll-up sleeves, the better to show off a wry tattoo. Go to epauletshop.com.

headline: Toughening Up a Little Boy?
text: A local ad has caused a national stir this past week. And it raises interesting parenting questions.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: It is the week before Labor Day, and it is largely quiet on the Washington and Wall Street fronts.

headline: Munchau On Germany
text: Wolfgang Munchau has some not-so-nice things to say about the German economic situation. He notes that so far, at least, Germany’s growth simply reflects recovery from an unusually deep slump: “So far, this looks like classic dead-cat bounce.” He also stresses the role of German undervaluation; this is a big problem, and I agree that it’s at the heart of the eurozone’s troubles.

headline: Three Women to Watch in Flushing
text: Victoria Azarenka

headline: When the Border Patrol Comes Aboard
text: Nina Bernstein has an article on the front page today about American Border Patrol agents who board trains running completely within the United States looking for undocumented immigrants. Here is her first-person experience on such a train in upstate New York. If you’ve had an encounter with the Border Patrol, let us know in the comment box below.

headline: N. Korea Confirms Leader’s China Trip
text: BEIJING North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-il, has left China after completing a secretive five-day visit that included a meeting on Friday with China’s president, Hu Jintao, state news agencies in both nations reported Monday evening.

headline: The Google Deal Machine
text: 3:37 p.m. | Updated  Google has made another acquisition today, buying SocialDeck of Canada for an undisclosed price.

headline: British Museum Reopens After Evacuation
text: A cause has yet to be identified for an episode on Saturday at the British Museum that forced the evacuation of the building when several visitors said their eyes and throats had become irritated. BBC News reported that at least 8,000 people were evacuated from the museum Saturday afternoon during what was described as a “gas incident.” A spokesman for London’s Metropolitan Police told The Daily Telegraph that visitors had “reported a funny smell on the premises and had mild irritation to the throat and eyes.”

headline: Monday Reading: Why to Keep Adjustable-Rate Mortgages
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Seagate Network Drive Simplifies Remote Access
text: Seagate has pulled off a remarkable feat: The company has integrated remote access to files stored on its new GoFlex Home Network Storage System so thoroughly and intelligently that it requires no setup.

headline: Fire and Gunshots at Tennessee Mosque Site Called ‘Terrorism’
text: Updated | 11:19 a.m. On Sunday, one day after a fire at the site of a planned Islamic center and mosque in the Nashville suburb of Murfreesboro, Muslim community members reported hearing gunshots as they inspected the damage.

headline: In India, BlackBerry Gets 2-Month Reprieve on Threat of Ban
text: MUMBAI, India  In a sign that India and the maker of popular BlackBerry devices might be closer to settling a dispute over law enforcement’s access to corporate e-mail, the government on Monday said that it would study and test a proposal by the company for two months.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: Lost Weekend
text: Season 4, Episode 6

headline: India Passes Nuclear Deal
text: NEW DELHI  India’s Parliament approved a final, critical piece of a long-delayed landmark civil nuclear agreement on Monday, a pact regarded as a cornerstone of a Bush-era effort to transform the relationship between the United States and the world’s largest democracy.

headline: China Asks C.E.O.’s to Work for State
text: BEIJING — The Chinese government ran an enormous help-wanted advertisement on Monday seeking professional managers for some of its biggest state-controlled companies, a novel but not unprecedented move that apparently reflected unhappiness with the companies’ current performance.

headline: Revel Yelp
text: For those who’ve never had the opportunity to party like a rock star and felt like they were missing out, ‘‘Please Take Me Off the Guest List’’ (Akashic Books) may very well smooth over those regrets. A collaboration between the writer (and singer and Beauty Bar Brooklyn bartender) Zachary Lipez, the photographer (and Yeah Yeah Yeahs guitarist) Nick Zinner and the designer (and former design director of Artforum) Stacy Wakefield, the book chronicles the side effects of a hyperactive night life, including rambling cocaine narratives, a job as a disgruntled clerk at the Strand bookstore and the joys of being sent to fetch a straw from the bodega for your girlfriend’s morning P.B.R. ‘‘I call dibs on the indefensible,’’ Lipez says. Sobriety may not figure, but when consciousness raises its head, it is acerbic, anarchic and definitely not for the faint of heart.

headline: For the Vegetarians at the Cookout
text: Over the Labor Day weekend, many of you will be squeezing in a last picnic or barbecue before school starts, so this week I’m focusing on vegetarian dishes you can pack in a picnic basket or throw on a grill.

headline: Seven U.S. Soldiers Die in Afghan Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Seven American service members were killed by two roadside bombs in southern Afghanistan on Monday, according to the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force.

headline: New Uses for an Old Plug
text: Do you know about that data port in your car? Of course you don’t. But as of 1996, all cars sold in the United States have had to have an on-board diagnostics port  that can give technicians information on the performance of various automotive subsystems. It is usually located under the steering wheel. This is a way for mechanics narrow down what is wrong with a car when the “check engine” light comes on.

headline: Teenage MotoGP Rider Killed in Indianapolis
text: 1:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: With Increase in Partisanship, Fewer Surprises Likely in Governors’ Races
text: Those who bemoan the excessive partisanship in the country today might take comfort from some unlikely seeming residents in governors’ mansions. Red states like Arkansas, Kansas, Oklahoma,  Tennessee and Wyoming have Democratic governors; blue states like California, Connecticut, Hawaii,  New Jersey and Vermont have Republican ones.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Chris Apostle joined R/GA, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, in a new post, managing director for client services. He had been a client partner for client engagement at Razorfish, part of the Publicis Groupe, directing a team of employees based at offices in Atlanta, Chicago and Austin, Tex.

headline: Roger Clemens Arrives for His Arraignment
text: 2:46 p.m. | Clemens Pleads Not Guilty

headline: Review Finds Flaws in U.N. Climate Panel Structure
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations needs to revise the way it manages its assessments of climate change, with the scientists involved more open to alternative views, more transparent about possible conflicts of interest and more careful to avoid making policy prescriptions, an independent review panel said Monday.

headline: Egyptian Culture Minister Talks With Prosecutors in van Gogh Theft
text: Farouk Hosni, Egypt’s minister of culture, said he had been questioned by prosecutors as an investigation continues into the theft of a valuable van Gogh painting from a museum in Giza this month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Hosni said he volunteered for the interrogation, which took more than three hours on Sunday night, to counter accusations that his negligence had been responsible for the theft. The van Gogh, known as “Poppy Flowers” or “Vase and Flowers” and valued at more than $50 million, was taken on Aug. 21 from the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum, where it hung in a room with only some working cameras and no working alarms. Mr. Hosni said that day that the painting had been recovered at the Cairo airport, then had to retract that statement, saying it was based on faulty information.

headline: Not on His Watch, USA Today Founder Says
text: Allen H. Neuharth, 86, the former Gannett executive who founded USA Today nearly 30 years ago, had some tart words for the people now in charge of his beloved paper.

headline: What We’re Reading: Lying Bosses
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Barnes & Noble to Shutter Lincoln Center Store
text: The immense Barnes & Noble store that straddles Broadway and 66th Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan will close at the end of January, driven out by high rents, the company announced on Monday.

headline: A Cathedral to the Shrine of Nature
