text: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo. — The view from the cathedral-size windows of the $27 million visitor center that opened here last week leads down a paved path toward a gently curved mound of rock. A mist of hissing steam drifts from the mound, but every 90 minutes or so, water starts to spurt fitfully, then more aggressively, until it erupts into a tower as high as 180 feet, whose spray may be spread by the breeze toward the hundreds of viewers gathered to watch the spectacle.

headline: "Zombieville"
text: The first "Zombieville" commercial from the Truth campaign that appeared during "The Real World: New Orleans."

headline: The Early Word: Back in Town
text: President Obama is back in Washington for the first time in nearly two weeks after a 10-day vacation on Martha’s Vineyard flanked by two trips to the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Elton John Still on ‘Idol’ Wish List
text: LOS ANGELES — One of the executive producers of “American Idol” still has his fingers crossed that Elton John will join the judges panel for the hit TV show.

headline: Now Booking | Tasmanian Angel
text: With its otherworldly beauty and back-of-beyond remoteness, the Australian island of Tasmania has enjoyed its status at the vanguard of far-flung travel for many years now. That adventurers who make the journey had to be content with a cozy cabin only added to the mystique. So the June opening of Saffire Freycinet, on the eastern end of the island’s Freycinet peninsula, puts a certain wrinkle in the place’s rustic authenticity. But in a good way. Though the property is packed full of features, like hydraulic flat-screen TVs and radiant-heated marble floors, that have come to signify modern luxury, Freycinet’s design complements the surrounding landscape and respects the island’s natural resources.

headline: New York Rebounds From Slump, Unevenly
text: By most standard measures of economic health, New York City’s recovery from the financial crisis and the recession it started is well under way.

headline: Newsstands Will Carry Gourmet Again, After a Fashion
text: Rumors that Condé Nast is bringing back Gourmet are true, up to a point.

headline: Long Live the King
text: King Cuomo II has no endorsements, no money, no campaign. His bid to win the race for governor can, at times, seem like a publicity stunt, or perhaps a kind of revenge campaign against a certain Democratic state official with a similar name. His royal pedigree is highly questionable. And he may or may not have a strong resemblance to this guy.

headline: Browns Make a Needless Power Play
text: Mike Holmgren has made his first major blunder as the president of the Cleveland Browns: he cut the great Jim Brown.

headline: A Closer Look at the Second Quarter G.D.P.
text: On Friday, the Bureau of Economic Analysis  reported a downward revision in the second quarter growth in the gross domestic product to 1.6 percent, from 2.4 percent. While the headline number was bad, the devil is in the details. The downward revision does not signal a new contraction or a double-dip recession. Instead, this revision demonstrates how one component of group that comprises a macro-statistic like the G.D.P. can skew the numbers.

headline: Hurricane Katrina and New Orleans, Then and Now
text: Hurricane Katrina struck the Gulf Coast with devastating force at daybreak on Aug. 29, 2005, pummeling a region that included the fabled city of New Orleans and heaping damage on neighboring Mississippi. In all, more than 1,700 people were killed and hundreds of thousands of others displaced.— From the overview on the  Hurricane Katrina Times Topics page

headline: The Student Loan Debt Clock
text: This post is for everyone adding to their student loan debt this month as they go back to college (and all their worried parents): You are far from alone.

headline: Piers Morgan Finally Admits to CNN Talks
text: LOS ANGELES — Piers Morgan broke his silence about his impending job at CNN on Sunday, saying in a red carpet interview at the Emmys that negotiations are almost finished.

headline: Plans for Print-Free Oxford Dictionary Aren’t Fully Defined
text: The Oxford English Dictionary defines the word “clarify” as “To free from darkness or gloom; to light up, illumine; to brighten” (in an appearance of the word dating back to 1398) and “To make clear (an obscure subject)” (in a coinage from 1823), among other usages. And that’s what representatives of the O.E.D. did in a statement released Monday after remarks by its chief executive were interpreted to mean that the venerable reference work would be not be released in a paper format for its coming third edition.

headline: Qaddafi Sets Up Camp Again in Rome
text: ROME  Less than a year after his last visit, when he invited 200 aspiring models to convert to Islam, the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has pitched his well-known tent in Rome for a two-day media blitz. This time around, the colonel, who has ruled Libya since 1969, had coffee in downtown Rome after delivering a lecture about Islam to 500 young women chosen by a modeling agency. Islam, he said, should be Europe’s primary religion. (Italian media outlets reported that three of the women converted on the spot.)

headline: Oudin Begins With a Win at U.S. Open
text: Flashbacks will clearly be limited at the United States Open. Last year’s men’s champion, Juan Martín del Potro, is in Miami instead of New York, still working his way back from major wrist surgery and unable to defend his title. Nor will there be any tantrums over foot faults from Serena Williams, the game’s leading woman, who is out because of a very different kind of foot problem.

headline: TimesCast | August 30, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on the extradition of arms dealer Viktor Bout, the science of bedbugs and a Sikh temple where everyone is fed regardless of religion.

headline: A Video Show From Google Highlights Hot Topics
text: Although Google likes to think of itself as an army of programmers, the company continues to create more content on a daily basis — and those of us who use its products seem to unknowingly help.

headline: Interest And Inflation Wonkery
text: So I thought I’d produce a simple graphical summary of how I see the whole interest rates etc. thing. Why? Well, I think little teachable models are always useful; and I always enjoy putting them together.

headline: Sebastian Vettel Re-examined
text: Sebastian Vettel was an early favorite to win the drivers’ title this year. He had a good chance to win it last year. He was considered favored by his Red Bull team on more than one occasion this year over his older teammate, Mark Webber. And he has been hailed as the next Schumacher – sometimes called Baby Schumacher. But what is the young German really worth?

headline: Sebastian Vettel Re-examined
text: Sebastian Vettel was an early favorite to win the drivers’ title this year. He had a good chance to win it last year. He was considered favored by his Red Bull team on more than one occasion this year over his older teammate, Mark Webber. And he has been hailed as the next Schumacher – sometimes called Baby Schumacher. But what is the young German really worth?

headline: Numberplay: How Many Light Bulbs Does It Take …
text: Last week on Numberplay, we featured an interesting but complex puzzle involving a bunch of captives communicating with each other using nothing but a light bulb. That puzzle is still going, and we are far from exhausting its richness. So for a change, I give you some lighter fare this week: puzzles that require insight rather than any hard calculations. We’ll have some more fun with light bulbs, and will hopefully set them off inside our minds. And then, as a special treat, we can exchange our favorite light bulb jokes.

headline: Foundation and MTV Hope Campaign Is ‘Dead On’ With Youths
text: When it comes to scaring and delighting youthful audiences these days, zombies are right up there with vampires and werewolves. An effort to discourage smoking among teenagers and young adults is seeking to take advantage of that lively interest in the undead.

headline: Comptroller Looking for Fraud in M.T.A. OT
text: Runaway overtime at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has long been the subject of hand-wringing, mud-slinging and shoulder-shrugging; a convenient rhetorical crutch for wars between labor and management;  reports from good government types; and hands-in-the-air exasperation about the authority’s practices.

headline: Domesticities| At Home on Facebook
text: When it comes to how-to, I operate strictly on a need-to-know basis. I flip right past those articles in Martha Stewart Living that tell you how to stencil your own wrapping paper or ceruse-finish oak furniture à la Jean-Michel Frank. It’s the same with Facebook. I had resigned myself to discovering the odd long-lost friend or learning about an interesting designer or project among the innumerable posts about people’s vacations (“Leaving for Capri today — so excited!”) or yet another breathless ode to a style arbiter of yore.

headline: Embedistan: Reporting With or Without the Military
text: I am not sure who came up with the name, but if ever there was a place whose moniker did not fit it was Camp Happy.

headline: New Study Links Toxic Pollutants to Canadian Oil Sands Mining
text: Native Canadians living downstream from the oil sands mines in Alberta have long contended that their high cancer rates were related to the expanding excavation of bitumen for the production of synthetic crude. Their assertions have been disputed by the reports of a joint oil industry-government research panel that concluded that natural causes — and not mining — were responsible for the high levels of various metals in the sub-Arctic Athabasca River.

headline: Diana Killed in a Car Accident in Paris
text: Paris, Sunday, Aug. 31 -- Diana, the Princess of Wales, was killed shortly after midnight today in an automobile accident in a tunnel by the Seine. The accident also killed Emad Mohammed al-Fayed, the Harrods heir, and their driver, the police said.

headline: William Shawn, 85, Is Dead; New Yorker's Gentle Despot
text: William Shawn, the shy, strong-willed editor who ran The New Yorker for a third of this century, died yesterday morning at the apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan where he had lived since 1950. He was 85 years old.

headline: Who Are You Calling Dense?
text: Matt Yglesias has a nice post about population density, basically arguing that you don’t need to have high-rise metropolises to have remarkably high density compared with the US average.

headline: Brabus Marries the Mercedes and the Office
text: Steve Jobs, your ride awaits.

headline: Burkle: No Plan to Take Control of Chain
text: The billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle has declared that he has no plan to acquire control of Barnes & Noble, the nation’s largest bookstore chain.

headline: High Expectations Met With Similar Misfortune
text: FULLERTON, Calif.  As Mark Prior prepared to warm up in the bullpen, his all-business game face, once the trademark of a familiar commanding presence, was shattered by a 2-year-old girl with blond pigtails.

headline: The Biking Boom Breeds Discontent
text: Biking is booming in New York City, with the number of daily cyclists rising to an average of 236,000 in 2009, up 26 percent from 2008, according to statistics compiled by Transportation Alternatives, a pro-biking nonprofit group.

headline: Using Private Eyes to Keep Track of Tenants
text: As a parade of slovenly dressed 20-somethings passed through the entrance of a downtown Manhattan apartment building on a weekday afternoon, these seemingly savvy New Yorkers did not seem to notice they were the subjects of a photo shoot.

headline: Little Boys and Violence
text: Speaking of boys, Wynne Parry, a reporter for LiveScience, wrote a thoughtful exploration this weekend of the y-linked fascination with violent play. Is it a fundamental part of growing up as a boy? Or, rather, a learned interest, encouraged by media and marketing?

headline: Velcro Parents
text: Devoted parents who are reluctant (or unable) to let go of their children.

headline: Early Bird Specials
text: Campuses are chaotic on student move-in day, with packed cars lingering in loading zones and fully stocked dolly carts fighting for free elevators. What if you could bypass the mayhem and settle in to your dorm room a little earlier?

headline: How New Things Should Look: Architecture and Hipster Edition
text: A Monday question: Should new buildings seek to blend into the existing architecture of a neighborhood? Or should they be purposefully designed in a modern way so as to stand out as new, lest they be confused with the old?

headline: Emmys Draw Same Number of Viewers as Last Year
text: The Primetime Emmys on Sunday, hosted by Jimmy Fallon, drew almost exactly as many viewers as last year’s awards telecast, which was hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, preliminary Nielsen ratings indicated Monday morning.

headline: Another Departure From Newsweek
text: The stream of senior writers and editors departing Newsweek continues, with the announcement on Monday that the National Journal has hired Michael Hirsh, a Newsweek editor based in Washington.

headline: Blue Ribbon Food Overlooking Times Square
text: To complement the view from the picture windows of its cocktail lounge overlooking Times Square, the Renaissance hotel has hired Eric and Bruce Bromberg to create a menu. Among the Blue Ribbon  classics at the R Lounge, starting Sept. 13, will be white bean toast, smoked salmon toast, grilled cheese panini, fried chicken wings, fried rock shrimp and pulled pork sandwiches.

headline: Obama Addresses Economic Anxieties
text: President Obama on Monday chided Senate Republicans for engaging in “pure partisan politics’’ by blocking a bill that would offer tax breaks and ease credit to small businesses, and said the measure was necessary to boost hiring and economic growth.

headline: Airgas Rolls the Dice in Proxy Fight
text: Airgas  has made a smart tactical move in its battle with Air Products. Or maybe it is a desperate gambit.

headline: Plaid Men
text: When grunge exploded onto the scene 20 years ago, it brought a renewed appreciation of two all-American classics: rock ’n’ roll and the plaid flannel shirt. Worn oversize, wrinkled and torn, over smiley-face T-shirts or wrapped at the waist, flannel was a bold anti-fashion fashion statement, one that Marc Jacobs promptly paraded down the runway to instant acclaim.

headline: Another Loss for Mr. Almost
text: Recently, Roger Federer talked about how, on the men’s side, the margin between winning and losing is always narrow because even the lowest ranks players can push the top ranked ones on any given point. Final scores can be deceptive. The first match on Armstrong Stadium proved the point, a slugfest between the sinewy, glum Russian star Nikolay Davydenko, seeded sixth, and Michael Russell, the short, dogged American ranked 80th, an insider favorite because he’s always a joy to watch.

headline: Where States Get Their Money
text: The Tax Foundation recently broke down some new state and local tax data from the Census Bureau, and found some stark variations in where states get their tax revenue.

headline: The Claim: Flying After Breast Cancer Surgery Can Cause Swelling
text: THE FACTS Women who have had surgery to remove lymph nodes, a common breast cancer treatment, are often warned that flying can lead to lymphedema, a painful swelling, in their arms.

headline: Clemens Enters Not Guilty Plea
text: WASHINGTON  For 32 months, they have stood together  a broad-shouldered pitcher from Houston who intimidated major league hitters across three decades, and his colorful, quotable hometown lawyer.

headline: Old Faithful Visitor Education Center
text: The new $27 million visitor center at Yellowstone National Park overlooks Old Faithful, the park’s famed geyser.

headline: Longevity: For New York Men, a Life Expectancy Gap
text: As in the rest of the United States, women in New York City tend to live longer than men. But the gap is wider in New York, according to a new report from the city’s health department.

headline: 10 Investment Mistakes to Avoid
text: Jerry Miccolis, co-author of “Asset Allocation for Dummies” and chief investment officer at the wealth advisory company Brinton Eaton in New Jersey, shared his list of 10 mistakes investors should avoid.

headline: Childhood: Athletes’ Concussions Have Doubled
text: The number of child athletes taken to emergency rooms with sports-related concussions doubled over a recent 10-year-period, a new study reports, even though participation in team sports decreased slightly during the period, from 1997 to 2007.

headline: Taking the Family (and the Briefcase) on the Road
text: How can a family preserve time together that normally would be consumed by work, and even turn it into an adventure and save money? They can combine a family vacation with a parent’s business trip.

headline:
German Army Attacks Poland; Cities
Bombed, Port Blockaded; Danzig Is Accepted
Into Reich
text: Berlin, Friday, Sept. 1--Charging that Germany had been attacked, Chancellor Hitler at 5:11 o'clock this morning issued a proclamation to the army declaring that from now on force will be met with force and calling on the armed forces "to fulfill their duty to the end."

headline: Reuther Dies in Jet Crash With Wife and 4 Others
text: DETROIT, May 10--Walter P. Reuther, the president of the United Automobile Workers, and his wife, May, died last night in a plane crash in northern Michigan. Mr. Reuther was 62 years old, and his wife was 59.

headline: Promising Dutch Slugger Advances
text: The man who ended John Isner’s agony at Wimbledon, the Dutchman Thiemo de Bakker, rolled steadily into the second round of the United States Open with a 6-4, 7-5, 6-2 victory over Marc Gicquel of France.

headline: The Shuttle Explosion, The Seven Who Perished in The Explosion of The Challenger
text: Christa McAuliffe, a high-school social studies teacher from New Hampshire, was the winner of a nationwide competition to be the first private citizen to fly aboard a space shuttle. She was 37 years old.

headline:
Japan Surrenders To Allies, Signs Rigid
Terms On Warship; Truman Sets Today As
V-J Day
text: Aboard The U.S.S. Missouri in Tokyo Bay, Sunday, Sept. 2--Japan surrendered formally and unconditionally to the Allies today in a twenty-minute ceremony which ended just as the sun burst through low-hanging clouds as a shining symbol to a ravaged world now done with war.

headline: In Ad, American Muslims Seek Calmer Message
text: A grass-roots coalition of American-born Muslims started a campaign on Monday aimed at stemming a surge of anti-Muslim rhetoric unlike anything they have felt since the months after 9/11.

headline: Studying Bedbugs
text: In many places around the world, bedbug infestations have been on the rise. But for some reason, the pesky insects don't seem to spread disease.

headline:
Viking 2 Lander Settles On Mars And Sends
Signal
text: asadena, Calif., Sept. 3--The Viking 2 lander, its retro rockets blazing, dropped out of the sky onto Utopia Plains on Mars this afternoon to become the second automated visitor from Earth to land successfully. The landing occurred at 6:38 P.M. Eastern daylight time.

headline: Sarah Orne Jewett, Noted Writer, Dead
text: An illness lasting many months ended tonight in the death of Miss Sarah Orne Jewett, Litt. D., author of many books and regarded as one of the foremost women writers of America. Since last March Miss Jewett had been at her old home here, where for many years she had been accustomed to pass her Summers, and it was in this old home that her death occurred at 6:40 this evening.

headline:
Arkansas Troops Bar Negro Pupils;
Governor Defiant
text: Little Rock, Ark., Sept. 4--The state militia barred nine Negro students from the white high school here today.

headline: Richard Wright, Writer, 52, Dies
text: PARIS, Nov. 29--Richard Wright, the American Negro writer, died of a heart attack last night in a Paris clinic. He was 52 years old.

headline: Vain Glorious | Improving Guys’ Eyes
text: Who: Ole Henriksen

headline: Red Carpet at the 2009 Emmy Awards
text: Television’s stars on their big night.

headline: Engaging North Korea in Twitter Diplomacy
text: A State Department spokesman attempted to engage North Korea on the social network Twitter, but it is not clear if anyone in the “Hermit Kingdom” was picking up his signals.

headline: Weight Index Doesn’t Tell the Whole Truth
text: A frequent question among people of a certain age, including yours truly, is “Why, when I weigh the same as or less than I did when I was younger, does my waist keep getting bigger?” Phrased another way, the question could be “Why, when my body mass index has not changed, am I fatter than I used to be?”

headline: Think the Answer’s Clear? Look Again
text: Presidential elections can be fatal.

headline: A ‘Family’ Celebration at the Emmys
text: LOS ANGELES  “Where’s your cupcake?” Nolan Gould, the trouble-making boy on ABC’s “Modern Family,” asked Ariel Winter, who plays his sister Alex, backstage at the Emmy Awards on Sunday night.

headline: Strange Bedfellows For a Schoenberg Series
text: Michel Galante and his Argento Chamber Ensemble are presenting an unusual set of Sunday afternoon concerts at the Austrian Cultural Forum. Called Lunar Movements, the series includes five programs (one per month, to be repeated every week, through Dec. 19). Most are built around movements from Schoenberg’s “Pierrot Lunaire,” and works influenced by that seminal score.

headline: Body Fat vs. Body Mass
text: In this week’s Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about why the traditional measure of a healthy weight, the body mass index, is not always reliable for determining whether someone is carrying too much fat. She writes:

headline: E.P.A. Develops Grading System for New Car Stickers
text: The Environmental Protection Agency and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Monday introduced proposed new window stickers that would appear on new vehicles beginning in the 2012 model year.

headline: Met Benefactor Comes to Aid of Another Opera Company
text: Agnes Varis, a prominent patron and board member of the Metropolitan Opera, has donated $250,000 to Opera Orchestra of New York, the company said Monday. The money will go toward a concert performance of Meyerbeer’s “Africaine” at Avery Fisher Hall on March 2. Eve Queler, who founded Opera Orchestra in 1967, will conduct. The organization is trying to make a comeback after having suspended opera performances for several years because of financial problems.

headline: Open House: Tweeting From Courtside
text: 6:05 p.m. | Updated Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via Twitter. Because the session is over, you can now follow him at gerrynyt.

headline: Of Time and Tide
text: Q. Living near the seashore, I find that tables of tide times and heights are quite accurate. How are these predictions made?

headline: Biden in Iraq for Talks and Handover
text: BAGHDAD  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in Baghdad on Monday to commemorate the official end of the United States combat mission and to meet with Iraqi political leaders, who have yet to form a government more than five months after elections.

headline: Late-Summer Slump Hits Broadway
text: Broadway’s annual late-summer attendance slump was in full force last week, as 19 of the 21 shows running saw a box-office swoon because of ebbing tourist traffic and vacationing New Yorkers.

headline: Special Adhesive Helps Oysters Stick Together
text: Oysters and other marine organisms like to attach themselves to one another, creating dense reefs that in undamaged conditions can extend for miles.

headline: From a Desert Plant, a Scented Cry for Help
text: Most animals let out a cry when they are wounded. But plants, without a voice to scream, instead let out a smell.

headline: S.E.C. Lawyer Leaves for Steptoe
text: Christoper R. Conte, a longtime lawyer in the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s enforcement unit, is leaving the agency to join Steptoe & Johnson.

headline: Isolation, an Ancient and Lonely Practice, Endures
text: Historically speaking, people with the bad luck to develop an infection have never had it so good. Modern medicine can deploy a vast array of antibiotics and other tools for their benefit.

headline: Geography Has a Hand in Lizards’ Gestation
text: North, south, east or west, all pregnant women take about 38 weeks to reach full gestation. Although this may vary slightly, the geographic location of the mother does not matter. But it does for some lizards. Within the same species, the eggs of some lizards can take a few months to hatch, while others fully develop within several weeks. Environment may have caused lizards in different regions to evolve into having these varying gestation periods, according to a new study in The American Naturalist.

headline: The Trap We’re In (Wonkish)
text: Ah: in this post on interest rates and inflation, I neglected to point out that right now we’re not on the Taylor rule line, because of the zero lower bound. The picture looks like this:

headline: Lasting Pleasures, Robbed by Drug Abuse
text: Of all the things that people do, few are as puzzling to psychiatrists as compulsive drug use.

headline: Art Sales to Continue, for Now, in Parks
text: Updated, 6:05 p.m. | A State Supreme Court justice on Monday upheld last week’s ruling blocking the city from limiting the number of art vendors in the parks.

headline: Africa: Monkeypox Cases Surge in Rural Areas as Price of the Victory Over Smallpox
text: The world’s victory over smallpox has had an unfortunate consequence: monkeypox cases are surging in tropical Africa.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 30
text: A view of the day in sports, including water polo in Croatia, water soccer in England and a rainy diamond in Miami.

headline: Quote Unquote | All Mixed Up
text: –Lindsay Lohan explains to BlackBook Magazine how her 6126 collection pays tribute to Marilyn Monroe. As if Marilyn Monroe would ever have worn sequin shorts and combat boots.

headline: They Crawl, They Bite, They Baffle Scientists
text: Don’t be too quick to dismiss the common bedbug as merely a pestiferous six-legged blood-sucker.

headline: Safety: Assessing the National Bill for Crashes
text: Motor vehicle accidents cost the nation almost $100 billion a year, about $500 for each licensed driver, according to the latest tally from the National Center for Injury Prevention and Control.

headline: Doctors Heed Call for Books for Afghanistan
text: Imagine cutting out a diseased appendix without ever having seen a Gray’s Anatomy diagram, or calculating drug doses without a Physicians’ Desk Reference, and you’ll have an idea what it’s like to practice medicine in Afghanistan.

headline: The Curious World of Bedbug Research
text: Around the country, the bedbugs are biting again, although nobody really seems to know why, reports Donald McNeil in Tuesday’s Science Times. He writes:

headline: Mr. President? President Obama is on the Line.
text: Tuesday, 12:45 p.m. | Updated Before President Obama addresses the nation from the Oval Office on Tuesday night to talk about his withdrawal of combat troops from Iraq, he intends to place a call to the man whose Iraq policy he bitterly opposed: former President George W. Bush.

headline: You Can Only Hope to Contain Them
text: Bedbug experts and the government both say there is no miracle bedbug pesticide.

headline: A 5-Year Journey to Unknown Grave 5061
text: Thousands of Iraqis travel each year to view pictures of their dead relatives at the morgue in Baghdad.

headline: Iraq’s Resting Places
text: In Iraq, death is more than a moment. It lingers in the morgues, the cemeteries, the sacred tombs of Shiite devotion and the memories of families. As the United States declares a conflict over that it helped begin with the invasion in 2003, some are still reckoning with the past.

headline: Restoring Names to War’s Unknown Casualties
text: BAGHDAD  In a pastel-colored room at the Baghdad morgue known simply as the Missing, where faces of the thousands of unidentified dead of this war are projected onto four screens, Hamid Jassem came on a Sunday searching for answers.

headline: Drug Makers on the Trail of an Alternative to Steroids
text: The hunt is on for alternatives to anabolic steroids, which build muscle by mimicking the effects of the hormone testosterone but whose reputation has been tarnished by athletic doping scandals and side effects like liver damage.

headline: Doctors Seek Way to Treat Muscle Loss
text: Bears emerge from months of hibernation with their muscles largely intact. Not so for people, who, if bedridden that long, would lose so much muscle they would have trouble standing.

headline: After Bedbugs, Here Come the Raccoons
text: Carol Aiello used to spot the intruders only at night, prowling her backyard or scurrying along her street in Glendale, Queens. But one morning not long ago, she caught one of them staring at her from a neighbor’s gutter and all of a sudden — perhaps for no reason other than seeing those black-rimmed eyes so close and in broad daylight — she panicked.

headline: Four Secrets of a (Money) Happy Home
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital.

headline: Fossil Hunters in Romania Find a 2-Clawed Relative of Velociraptor
text: Nothing quite like it, a dinosaur with two sicklelike claws on each foot, was known to live in the final period of the age of great reptiles. Little wonder fossil hunters in Romania were astonished when they unearthed remains of a distant relative of Velociraptor, the familiar single-claw predator of fierce repute, and saw its unusual stocky limbs and double-clawed feet.

headline: Intensifying Hurricane Heads North
text: CAROLINA, P.R.  Hurricane Earl tore through the northern Caribbean on Monday, escalating to Category Four status with winds up to 135 miles an hour that downed power lines, damaged homes and sent hundreds of people fleeing to emergency shelters.

headline: The U.S. Team Stays Undefeated, if Underwhelming
text: ISTANBUL  Brazil guard Leandro Barbosa grabbed a bounce pass on the right block, spun to the basket and jumped into United States center Kevin Love as he released the potential game-tying shot at the buzzer.

headline: A Rush to Operating Rooms That Alters Men’s Lives
text: As I scuffed through the stations of the prostate-cancer cross these past two years, I sometimes wondered whether I wasn’t a dupe caught up in a Robin Cook medical thriller.

headline: Now Amusing | Speed Racers
text: Rather than making the pilgrimage to the Ferrari museum in Maranello, Italy, fans of Italian sports cars might want to head to Yas Island in the United Arab Emirates, where Ferrari World Abu Dhabi opens Oct. 28. The autocentric theme park, next to the Yas Marina Circuit racetrack, will offer more than 20 action-packed attractions under its manta-ray-shaped, two-million-square-foot roof. Sure to be a big draw is the Formula Rossa roller coaster, which the park claims will be the fastest in the world, with carts inspired by F1 race cars reaching grand prix-worthy speeds of 149 miles per hour. A flume-type water ride, meanwhile, passes through a supersize Ferrari 599 V12 engine. ‘‘You go in through the grille and then get taken high up above the manifold,’’ says Troy Lindquist, the park’s sales and marketing director. ‘‘At the end, you’re shot out of the tailpipe.’’

headline: Tender at First Blush, but With a Tough and Feisty Core
text: Tamar Kaprelian was discovered in the modern way: winning a cover contest on YouTube, piggybacked onto someone else’s success. The song was “Apologize,” by OneRepublic, one of the more vaporous pop hits in recent memory. Her version, a delicate little slice of piano soul, cuts through some of the original’s haze, its wounded tenderness purposeful, not accidental.

headline: Egg Farms Violated Safety Rules
text: Barns infested with flies, maggots and scurrying rodents, and overflowing manure pits were among the widespread food safety problems that federal inspectors found at a group of Iowa egg farms at the heart of a nationwide recall and salmonella outbreak.

headline: Mormons, Evangelicals and Glenn Beck
text: I enjoyed Dave Weigel’s report from Glenn Beck’s “Restoring Honor” rally, no doubt because it dovetailed with my own take on the proceedings. This passage, in particular, neatly captures what I was trying to get at when I described the rally as an exercise in “identity politics without the politics”:

headline: Deadliest Catch, Found in Unlikely Waters
text: King crab fishing in the Bering Sea is dangerous business, but contrary to what the cable television show suggests, it is not the deadliest catch.

headline: Scientists Square Off on Evolutionary Value of Helping Relatives
text: Why are worker ants sterile? Why do birds sometimes help their parents raise more chicks, instead of having chicks of their own? Why do bacteria explode with toxins to kill rival colonies? In 1964, the British biologist William Hamilton published a landmark paper to answer these kinds of questions. Sometimes, he argued, helping your relatives can spread your genes faster than having children of your own.

headline: Another Way to Look at the iPad vs. Kindle Debate
text: Last week in The Times, I reviewed the Amazon Kindle 3. It’s head and shoulders the best e-book reader on the market — at least among the ones that use an E Ink screen.

headline: Intel to Buy a Wireless Division of Infineon
text: Less than two weeks after saying it would buy McAfee, Intel announced Monday that it would acquire the wireless business of the German chip maker Infineon for about $1.4 billion in cash.

headline: White House Touts Medicare Rebates
text: Stepping up a concerted, election-year effort to highlight aspects of the big health care law enacted earlier this year, the Obama administration on Monday announced that more than one million Medicare beneficiaries had received $250 rebate checks as part of the provision to close the gap in prescription drug coverage known as the doughnut hole.

headline: Egyptian Culture Minister Talks With Prosecutors
text: Farouk Hosni, Egypt’s minister of culture, said he had been questioned by prosecutors as an investigation continued into the theft of a van Gogh painting from a museum in Giza this month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Hosni said he volunteered for the interrogation, which lasted more than three hours on Sunday night, to counter accusations that his negligence had led to the theft. The van Gogh, known as “Poppy Flowers” or “Vase and Flowers” and valued at more than $50 million, was taken on Aug. 21 from the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum, where it hung in a room with only some working cameras and no working alarms. Mr. Hosni said that day that the painting had been recovered at the Cairo airport, then had to retract that statement. In his interrogation, Mr. Hosni said, he told prosecutors he had delegated full responsibility for the museum to Mohsen Shaalan, a deputy culture minister. Mr. Shaalan and four museum guards were detained last week by Egyptian prosecutors.

headline: British Museum Reopens
text: A cause has yet to be identified for an episode on Saturday at the British Museum that forced the evacuation of the building when several visitors said their eyes and throats had become irritated. BBC News reported that at least 8,000 people were evacuated from the museum on Saturday afternoon during what was described as a “gas incident.” A spokesman for the Metropolitan Police of London told The Daily Telegraph that visitors had “reported a funny smell on the premises and had mild irritation to the throat and eyes.” A museum spokeswoman told the BBC that firefighters had come to the scene and searched the building but “could not find anything.” A spokesman for the London Fire Brigade told the BBC that the museum had been checked for four hours but that nothing had been detected. He added, “People may well have smelled something, but it dispersed before we got there.” No injuries were reported, and the museum reopened on Sunday.

headline: Emmy Ratings Stable
text: The Primetime Emmys on Sunday, hosted by Jimmy Fallon, drew almost exactly as many viewers as last year’s awards telecast, which was hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, preliminary Nielsen ratings indicated Monday morning. In the ever-more-fragmented world of television, that’s a victory for NBC, which carried the show. About 13.5 million viewers tuned in, according to the data, up about 32,000 viewers from last year’s telecast. Those extra tens of thousands are enough to make Mr. Fallon’s Emmys the “top-scoring Emmy Awards in total viewers in four years,” NBC said  if the preliminary numbers hold, that is. The awards sank to an all-time low, 12.2 million viewers, in 2008. Among viewers ages 18 to 49, the telecast was down just one-tenth of a ratings point, to 4.1 from 4.2 last year, according to the early data. Because the Emmys were held in August this year, there was less formidable competition on other networks.

headline: The Met Goes to Egypt, in High Definition
text: The Metropolitan Opera’s high-definition cinema broadcast series is about to make another foray into the Middle East. The Met recently reached an agreement with the authorities at the Cairo Opera House to show productions there this season. The company announced the deal on Monday. Now in their fifth year, the live broadcasts will increase to 12 productions from 9 and reach 46 countries, including Spain and Portugal for the first time. The number of theaters showing the operas will rise to 1,500 from 1,200, the Met said. For a season, the program included Dubai, which stopped after the economic crisis hit, a Met spokesman said. Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, said he was negotiating with theaters in Israel to show the operas. A shortage of digital theaters that can receive the broadcasts has kept them out of Spain and Portugal until now, he said, and for the same reason the Met has been unable to find a foothold in Italy, the birthplace of opera. An Egyptian-born businessman, Mahmoud M. Abdallah, who sits on the Met’s board, helped broker the agreement with the National Cultural Center, which is the umbrella organization for activities at the Cairo Opera House, Mr. Gelb said. The broadcasts will be shown in a theater at the complex that seats about 350 people. The HD season begins on Oct. 9 with Wagner’s “Rheingold,” the first installment of the company’s new “Ring” cycle, directed by Robert Lepage.

headline: Plans For O.E.D. Aren’t Fully Defined
text: The Oxford English Dictionary defines the word “clarify” as “To free from darkness or gloom; to light up, illumine; to brighten” (in an appearance of the word dating to 1398) and “To make clear (an obscure subject)” (in a coinage from 1823), among other usages. And that’s what representatives of the O.E.D. did in a statement released on Monday after remarks by the chief executive of Oxford University Press were interpreted to mean that the venerable reference work would not be released in a paper format for its coming third edition. In an interview with The Sunday Times of London, Nigel Portwood, the chief executive, said the market for print dictionaries “is just disappearing.” When he was asked if the new edition of the O.E.D. would appear in print, Mr. Portwood replied, “I don’t think so.” On Monday, Oxford University Press responded with alacrity (“Briskness,” “promptitude,” about 1510) to say, “No decision has yet been made on the format of the third edition.”

headline: NASA Tests Engine With an Uncertain Future
text: One hundred fifty-four feet long, packed with 700 tons of propellant and anchored to the side of a Utah hill, a solid rocket motor developed for NASA’s next generation of rockets is to unleash 3.6 million pounds of thrust in a test Tuesday morning.

headline: Returning to Classrooms, and to Severe Headaches
text: For kids around the country it’s back-to-school time. But for many of them, it’s also the return of headache season.

headline: Forget the Stats as Soderling Wins in Five
text: Statistics can never fully account for what wins close matches. In the Grandstand, Robin Soderling, the fifth-seeded Swede, faced Andreas Haider-Maurer, an Austrian playing in his very first Grand Slam main draw. By the end, Haider-Maurer had more winners, 58 to 44, fewer unforced errors, 65 to 74, and more aces, many more, 34 to 8.But he lost.

headline: State Tax Revenues Tick Up
text: Speaking of the different business models of each of the 50 states, those business models finally seem to be functioning a little better: state taxes rose modestly in the second quarter. They are still below their prerecession levels, however.

headline: An Iraqi Mother Finds Her Eldest Son, Where She Least Wants To
text: BAGHDAD — This video follows an Iraqi family from the moment that they learn of their eldest son’s death, to finding his unmarked grave in Najaf’s Valley of Peace cemetery. See also the accompanying  story  in The New York Times by Anthony Shadid, and photographs by Moises Saman.

headline: And You Thought Radiation Was a Problem for Nuclear Plants?
text: A power plant has overexposed its workers to radiation, and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is proposing a fine. The plant, though, is not a reactor; it runs on coal.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Charade'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at the 1963 caper film starring Cary Grant, Audrey Hepburn and Walter Matthau.

headline: Elton John Still Tops ‘idol’ Judge Wish List
text: Steven Tyler? Jennifer Lopez? Perhaps, but an executive producer of “American Idol” still has his fingers crossed that Elton John, above, will join the show’s panel of judges. “I’m still very supportive of Elton John,” the producer, Nigel Lythgoe, told reporters on the red carpet at the Emmys on Sunday night, seemingly confirming reports that Mr. John was at the top of the “Idol” wish list. But he added, “I don’t believe negotiations have gone well.” There are difficulties, he said, over “accessibility,” because Mr. John would essentially be committing four months of his life to the Fox singing competition. Mr. Tyler and Ms. Lopez are said to be the leading candidates to replace Simon Cowell and Ellen DeGeneres. Asked on Sunday who the "Idol" judges would be, Mr. Lythgoe named only Randy Jackson. A fourth judge from last season, Kara DioGuardi, is expected to leave the show, although that has not been announced. Official word on the new judges is expected in September.

headline: The Lives Gained by Fleeing Jim Crow
text: “We pray for the lady visitor and the book she’s trying to put together,” said the spiritual leader of the Monroe, Louisiana, Club of Los Angeles at a meeting that Isabel Wilkerson attended in 1996. Ms. Wilkerson was there as part of her monumental research job for “The Warmth of Other Suns,” work that seems to have lasted the better part of 20 years and taken a piece of Ms. Wilkerson’s heart in the process. Her hard work, keen insight and passionate personal commitment make “The Warmth of Other Suns” a landmark piece of nonfiction.

headline: Does Google’s Free Phone Service Work in Other Countries?
text: Google’s Call Phones from Gmail lets Gmail users turn their computers into telephones by talking into a built-in microphone or by attaching a headset. The service, Google said when it announced Call Phones last week, is restricted to callers in the United States. Calls within the United States and to Canada are free, and most international calls are around 2 cents a minute. If you also sign up for Google’s free Google Voice service, available only within the United States, you can also receive calls free through Google’s servers.

headline: 13 Hurt in Suspicious Bedford-Stuyvesant Fire
text: A suspicious fire that erupted in a brownstone in Bedford-Stuyvesant early Monday injured 13 people and required a firefighter to charge through a wall of flames carrying an injured civilian.

headline: Slovakia Stunned by Rampaging Gunman
text: PRAGUE — A man armed with a submachine gun and two handguns killed six members of a Roma family in their apartment house in the Slovak capital, Bratislava, on Monday, and then, firing wildly as he tried to evade the police surrounding the building, killed another person and wounded 15 more before fatally shooting himself, police and government officials said.

headline: A Turnaround in Ansel Adams Photo Dispute
text: A leading member of the expert team that declared that a box of negatives bought at a California garage sale were the lost work of Ansel Adams has changed his mind.

headline: Nonprofit Theaters Take On Bold Broadway Ventures This Fall
text: The hit Broadway revivals of “Hair” and “South Pacific” may have closed this summer, but they are continuing to pay important dividends for their producers, the Public Theater and Lincoln Center Theater.

headline: The World Watches America’s Heated Mosque Debates
text: Updated | 6:50 p.m. Last August, there was anecdotal evidence that people in many parts of the global village were watching, if not always quite understanding, the furious debate in the United States over health insurance, as it devolved into televised shouting matches about “death panels.” This year, it seems that the same sort of attention is being paid to the similarly intense fury around proposals to construct a handful of mosques in American cities as far apart as New York and Murfreesboro, Tenn.

headline: Floating and Bobbing in an Oceanic Swell of Sound
text: There were several peculiar sights at the Oneohtrix Point Never performance on Friday night, but none more so than the handful of fans clustered near the front of the stage, nodding their heads rhythmically.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Charade’
text: How well do you know the people you’re close to? A. O. Scott asks that question with this week’s Critics’ Pick, “Charade.” The 1963 film, directed by Stanley Donen, is either “a thriller masquerading as a comedy or a comedy disguised as a thriller,” Mr. Scott says. It stars Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn as a couple wrapped up in mystery and is, Mr. Scott argues, one of the better entries in the action/romantic comedy genre. Have you seen “Charade?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: New York Send-Off | Rise Up Singing
text: Jan Benzel is an editor at The Times who is being reassigned to Paris. Before she leaves, she is trying to do all the things in the city that every New Yorker should do, at least once.

headline: Making Connections, and Celebrating, at 35,000 Feet
text: TRAVELING is a huge part of my job heading up the Women’s Tennis Association Tour and overseeing 53 tournaments in 33 countries. That doesn’t mean that I don’t enjoy seeing new parts of the world. But everyone knows there isn’t a lot of glamour to business travel. It’s work.

headline: Companies Race to Develop Drugs to Reduce Blood-Clotting Problems
text: Leading drug makers are competing to reach the market with a new class of pills to prevent the kind of dangerous blood clots in the veins and lungs that can travel to the brain, causing strokes.

headline: Making Soldiers Fit to Fight, Without the Situps
text: FORT JACKSON, S.C.  Dawn breaks at this, the Army’s largest training post, with the reliable sound of fresh recruits marching to their morning exercise. But these days, something looks different.

headline: The Caucus With John Harwood
text: John Harwood talks with New York Times reporters Jeff Zeleny and Elisabeth Bumiller about how the economy and two wars have been influencing the campaigning for the upcoming midterm elections.

headline: Microsoft Enters Google’s Unwalled Garden
text: In late 2009, when Microsoft introduced a downloadable application for the iPhone from Apple, it set off some excitement in the tech world. For years, Microsoft and Apple had been head-to-head in the war for personal computing.

headline: Training for the 787, Whenever It Shows Up
text: RENTON, Wash.

headline: A Video Look at the Week’s Political Issues
text: New York Times reporters Elisabeth Bumiller and Jeff Zeleny join John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC to discuss President Obama’s focus on the faltering economy this week, its effect on the upcoming elections and other top issues in Washington this week.

headline: On Our Radar: A Biofuels Land Grab
text: The European Union’s biofuels targets are driving a large “land grab” in Africa, a conservation group claims. [The Guardian]

headline: Sanofi’s Offer Is a Plea for Genzyme to Open Its Books
text: To warrant a big increase in price, Sanofi-Aventis would need to look at Genzyme’s books and operations to assess the problems that prompted federal monitoring.

headline: Comfort at Life’s End (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Acupuncture and Science (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Neuro-Pioneers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sticks and Stones (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Freeing Muscadet From a Pigeonhole
text: THE subject today is Muscadet, so let’s dispense with the obvious right away: oysters. Most people, if they know one important thing about Muscadet, know that oysters are its natural partner.

headline: U.S. Soccer Gives Bradley Four-Year Extension
text: U.S. Soccer announced today that it had agreed to a four-year contract extension with Bob Bradley, the coach of the men’s national team, that will keep him at the helm through the 2014 World Cup.

headline: Disney Names Radio Executive to Head ABC Family Cable Channel
text: The Walt Disney Company continued its streak of surprise hires by naming a radio executive to take over its ABC Family cable channel.

headline: Outlines Emerge of Future State in the West Bank
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank  As preparations intensify for a Palestinian-Israeli summit meeting in Washington on Thursday, the crude outlines of a Palestinian state are emerging in the West Bank, with increasingly reliable security forces, a more disciplined government and a growing sense among ordinary citizens that they can count on basic services.

headline: 3M Will Buy Cogent, Maker of Fingerprint ID Systems
text: The 3M Company agreed to buy Cogent, a manufacturer of fingerprint identification systems for governments and companies, for $943 million to expand its security services products.

headline: As Past Recedes, Germans Reconsider the Draft
text: BERLIN  For the first time in more than half a century, Germany’s political leadership appears ready to end the draft, a post World War II mandate embedded in the Constitution to prevent this nation’s military from ever again developing into a state-within-a-state that could impede democracy and start war.

headline: Obama to Make 2nd Oval Office Speech
text: WASHINGTON  For only the second time since he took office, President Obama will speak to the nation from the Oval Office on Tuesday night, in an address meant to convey that he has kept one of the central promises of his campaign: withdrawing American combat troops from Iraq.

headline: New U.S. Sanctions Aim at North Korean Elite
text: WASHINGTON  The latest target for the United States, as it tries to tighten the screws on North Korea, is a shadowy party organization, known as Office 39, which raises hard currency to buy fine liquor, exotic food and luxury cars for cronies of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-il.

headline: Derek Jeter Tries to Reverse Sub-Par Season
text: At 4:40 Monday afternoon, Derek Jeter bounced into the batting cage at Yankee Stadium with great energy and assumed an unusual position, standing in the left-handed batters’ box instead of his usual right side.

headline: Summer, a Slow Season Except for Term Limit Plans
text: Political experts, who at times earn their keep by getting things wrong a day or two ahead of everyone else, accept as axiomatic that New Yorkers in summertime can’t worry their pretty little heads about events much weightier than Paris Hilton’s latest arrest. The hyperventilating over the downtown Islamic center put a few dents in that theory.

headline: Incidents at Mosque in Tennessee Spread Fear
text: ATLANTA  After a suspected arson and reports of gunshots at an Islamic center in Tennessee over the weekend, nearby mosques have hired security guards, installed surveillance cameras and requested the presence of federal agents at prayer services.

headline: Esteemed Literary Journal Closes Offices After Suicide
text: The award-winning literary journal The Virginia Quarterly Review has canceled its winter issue and closed its offices in the aftermath of the suicide last month of its managing editor and a subsequent investigation by the University of Virginia, which operates the journal.

headline: The Shadow of Ben-Gurion
text: This Op-Ed was originally published on September 19, 1993

headline: Majority of Caesareans Are Done Before Labor
text: A new study suggests several reasons for the nation’s rising Caesarean section rate, including the increased use of drugs to induce labor, the tendency to give up on labor too soon and deliver babies surgically instead of waiting for nature to take its course, and the failure to allow women with previous Caesareans to try to give birth vaginally.

headline: Rights Groups Sue U.S. on Effort to Kill Cleric
text: WASHINGTON  Two human rights organizations went to court on Monday to challenge the Obama administration’s decision to authorize the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born radical Muslim cleric now hiding in Yemen.

headline: At Bookstore, Even Nonbuyers Regret Its End
text: On Monday afternoon, Jai Cha walked out of the Barnes & Noble at 66th Street and Broadway in Manhattan as he does nearly every week  without a book.

headline: On the Eve of the Mideast Talks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Petraeus Finishes Rules for Afghan Transition
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top commander in Afghanistan, has completed work on new guidelines for turning some security duties over to Afghan forces in the months ahead, calling for American and allied troops to step back gradually from areas as they are pacified rather than handing off the task all at once to local units, according to senior NATO and Pentagon officials.

headline: Cuomo as HUD Chief
text: To the Editor:

headline: Torture and America’s Soul
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Crisis Facing Blacks
text: To the Editor:

headline: A School Year Wish
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Call for More Patience and for More Hustle
text: N.F.L. teams will receive a memo on Tuesday outlining the tweaks that the league hopes will smooth out the move of the umpire to the offensive backfield.

headline: A Fire on the L.I.R.R.: Our Crumbling Public Transit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Airline Passengers Held on Fears of Terrorist Plot
text: WASHINGTON  Two United States residents of Yemeni descent who flew from Chicago to Amsterdam on Sunday night were detained by the Dutch police after landing on Monday in a bizarre episode that American officials feared might be a dry run for a terrorist plot.

headline: Channeling Outrage to Toughen Traffic Laws
text: Heather Vandenberghe is a mother, but she is also a marketing executive, which is why she consented to have an image of her younger daughter, Elle, who is 4, plastered on bus shelters and in buses all around New York over the coming month, with the text, “She almost died for a parking space.”

headline: Homeowner’s Fight Involves Flag Tied to Tea Party
text: LAVEEN, Ariz. — Don’t tread on Andy C. McDonel.

headline: Chaos and Stranded Tourists After Mexicana Shutdown
text: MEXICO CITY  The sudden shutdown of Mexico’s largest airline on Friday stranded many tourists and left the Mexico City airport in chaos for much of the weekend. But tour operators said on Monday that they were confident they could reschedule flights.

headline: Louisiana: Waves Delay Work on BP’s Relief Well
text: High seas have forced further delays in BP’s efforts to permanently plug the well that leaked millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral who is leading the government’s response effort, said in a conference call on Monday that waves six to eight feet high had prevented crews from replacing equipment on the seabed in preparation for the final plugging of the well through a relief well. The removal of a capping stack, which was installed atop the well last month, and the original damaged blowout preventer will eventually be replaced by another blowout preventer that can manage pressure changes resulting from the final plugging procedure. Admiral Allen said the bad weather would probably delay work for two to three days, pushing the completion of the relief well to the end of next week.

headline: New Stickers Will Go Beyond M.P.G. in Rating Cars
text: The Obama administration proposed on Monday two alternatives to the window stickers in new vehicles, including one that would assign letter grades for fuel economy and greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Arizona: Border Security Gets More Help From Above
text: As National Guard troops began arriving in southern Arizona on Monday, Janet Napolitano, the homeland security secretary, said the boots on the ground would be assisted by more surveillance from the skies. Ms. Napolitano said that with the launching of a fourth Predator drone this week, the entire Southwest border from California to Texas would now be patrolled from above. Previously, drones were not approved by the Federal Aviation Administration for use in a stretch of West Texas. By the beginning of next year, the number of drones operating along the border should be up to six, providing “critical aerial surveillance assistance,” Ms. Napolitano said. “Numbers don’t lie,” she added, arguing that the border region, despite perceptions to the contrary, was more secure than ever.

headline: E.P.A. Turns Down Request to Ban Lead Bullets
text: The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday rejected a request that it ban lead bullets, saying it does not have the legal authority to do so. The American Bird Conservancy and the Center for Biological Diversity had petitioned for the ban. The Toxic Substances Control Act, under which the petition was made, exempts ammunition from its controls. The agency will, however, seek comment on the merit of a ban on lead fishing sinkers. Adam Keats, a senior counsel for the center, said in a news release that “the E.P.A. has the clear authority and duty to regulate this very harmful and toxic substance as used in bullets and shot, despite the so-called exemption for lead ammunition.”

headline: Nobody
text: Via Atrios, this depressing item:

headline: Germany: Bank Board Member Will Not Quit Over Remarks About Minorities
text: A member of Germany’s central bank board, whose disparaging remarks about Jews and Muslims have created a public outcry, on Monday brushed aside calls for his dismissal from the bank and the Social Democratic Party. At a news conference to mark the publication of his book, the board member, Thilo Sarrazin, repeated his views that Muslims threaten the culture of European societies, that immigration is threatening to make Germans “strangers in their own country” and that all Jews share the same gene. The Bundesbank issued an unusually critical statement of Mr. Sarrazin, saying that his “utterances do harm” to its image and that it would hold discussions with him about further steps to take.

headline: One Split Ends for Dodgers as Another Enters Courtroom
text: LOS ANGELES  A man walked through Los Angeles County Superior Court on Monday morning wearing a gleaming white Dodgers jersey with Matt Kemp’s name and his number 27 on the back.

headline: South Africa: President Orders Parties to Settle Public Worker Strike
text: President Jacob Zuma, criticized for going on a state visit to China during a debilitating strike by public employees, told government negotiators on Monday to return to the bargaining table with unions and come up with a settlement to end the strike. A statement issued by the government said the public services and administration minister, Richard Baloyi, had been consulting with trade union leaders and suggested an end to the strike could be imminent. The strike by hundreds of thousands of workers, including nurses and teachers, has crippled health and education services.

headline: We’ve Seen This Movie Before
text: In the first column I ever wrote for this newspaper (“How the Right Hijacked the Magic Words”), I analyzed the shift in the rhetoric surrounding the Oklahoma City bombing once it became clear that the perpetrator was Timothy McVeigh, who at one point acknowledged that “The Turner Diaries,” a racist anti-government tract popular in Christian Identity circles, was his bible.

headline: Banks Grow Wary of Environmental Risks
text: Blasting off mountaintops to reach coal in Appalachia or churning out millions of tons of carbon dioxide to extract oil from sand in Alberta are among environmentalists’ biggest industrial irritants. But they are also legal and lucrative.

headline: At the Game Show Network, Winning Is Everything
text: CAN a dating show hosted by Jerry Springer seduce a robust crowd of game show purists? Do prize winners resonate more deeply with recession-weary viewers? And will online game enthusiasts ever tune in for a remake of “The Newlywed Game?”

headline: Advances Offer Path to Further Shrink Computer Chips
text: Scientists at Rice University and Hewlett-Packard are reporting this week that they can overcome a fundamental barrier to the continued rapid miniaturization of computer memory that has been the basis for the consumer electronics revolution.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Hate Crime Charges in Stabbing of a Cabdriver
text: A film student arrested in the slashing of a Muslim taxi driver in Manhattan last week was indicted on Monday on charges of second-degree attempted murder and first-degree assault as hate crimes.

headline: Why Wall St. Is Deserting Obama
text: Daniel S. Loeb, the hedge fund manager, was one of Barack Obama’s biggest backers in the 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: Alain Corneau, César-Winning Film Director, Dies at 67
text: Alain Corneau, an eclectic French film director and writer who in 1991 leaned on his own experience as a musician to make “Tous les Matins du Monde,” a critically praised movie about the composer Marin Marais, born in 1656 and active in both the 17th and 18th centuries.

headline: Jacob Bigeleisen, Isotope Chemist on Manhattan Project, Dies at 91
text: Jacob Bigeleisen, a chemist who worked on the development of the atomic bomb as part of the Manhattan Project and helped discover new ways of analyzing chemical reactions, died Aug. 7 in Arlington, Va. He was 91.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,236 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

headline: Mets Lose and Wait for Cavalry to Arrive
text: ATLANTA  The long-lost Mets pitcher Oliver Perez made his first appearance since Aug. 1 on Monday night and promptly gave up a home run. It may be a while before Perez gets another chance to pitch, and that may also be the case for another Mets left-hander, Pat Misch.

headline: Wozniacki and Yale Are Cheering Each Other On
text: It was a pretty cool photo opportunity  a bunch of Yale University football players in their game jerseys, cheering for Caroline Wozniacki at the tennis tournament in New Haven last week.

headline: Obama Weighs Smaller Measures on the Economy
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is weighing new steps to bolster the economy, he said Monday. But any measures he takes seem likely to be small ones, and his options are limited with Congress showing little appetite for more spending in a hotly contested midterm election year.

headline: Colombians Build a Tennis Future
text: For two months now, Alejandro Falla has answered questions about the Wimbledon match he did not win. In the first round, he nearly knocked off Roger Federer in what would have ranked among the greatest upsets in Grand Slam history.

headline: What to Watch on Tuesday at the Open
text: Marcos Baghdatis will always have a special place in my heart for the five-set, four-hour marathon he and Andre Agassi played here in 2006 — one of the most memorable matches in United States Open history. So, you can guess where I will be when he and the crafty Arnaud Clement take to the court for their first-round match in Louis Armstrong Stadium.

headline: Building W.P.S. Winner Out of Ruins of First Year
text: It seems incongruous that the coach of the worst team in the first season of Women’s Professional Soccer kept his job, not to mention his balance and good humor. Especially when you consider that the defending league champion, Sky Blue F.C., has gone through a half-dozen coaches over the same period.

headline: Bahrain: Opposition Leader Charged With Trying to Overthrow Government
text: The Shiite opposition leader Abduljalil al-Singace was charged on Monday with attempting to overthrow the government. Mr. Singace was arrested on Aug. 13 in a sweep that the Sunni minority government described as an ongoing counterterrorism operation, but that Shiite leaders and human rights groups call a crackdown on political dissent in which an estimated 230 people have been detained. This weekend the government issued a gag order on local media reporting about the wave of arrests or the charges against Mr. Singace and other detained Shiite leaders.

headline: India: 9 Suspected of Being Pakistani Militants Are Killed
text: Indian troops killed nine men suspected of being Pakistani militants trying to sneak in to Indian-controlled Kashmir late Sunday night. Soldiers posted near the Line of Control that separates the halves of Kashmir controlled by India and Pakistan spotted the heavily armed men, and after challenging them, engaged in a firefight, said an army spokesman, Lt. Col. J. S. Brar. Each man carried an AK-47, he said, and the group had a cache of weapons and communication equipment, including GPS devices and radios. Tensions in Kashmir have been high since June, when a wave of protests against Indian rule prompted a tough crackdown in which more than 60 people died.

headline: Alaska Roundup
text: The undecided Republican primary in Alaska between Senator Lisa Murkowski and Joe Miller has been anything but quiet, despite the fact that the tallying of thousands of uncounted ballots doesn’t get started until Tuesday.

headline: Tuesday: Bit of Derring-Do
text: Four score and seven years ago, our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation, conceived in liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.

headline: Redrawing a Picture of Lincoln’s Assassin
text: The Mad Tragedian: that’s what critics called the eccentric actor Junius Brutus Booth. His brooding son Edwin, the Prince of Players, was one of the great 19th-century Hamlets, perhaps because, as John Wilkes said of his brother, “He is Hamlet.” Johnny was the charmer, a dashing matinee idol whom even the president, the theater-loving Abraham Lincoln, wanted to meet.

headline: Soccer Player From St. Lucia Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn
text: A member of a St. Lucia soccer team was shot to death early Monday in Brooklyn, the police said, only hours after he had scored the winning goal in a semifinal of an international tournament.

headline: Reality, Comedy and Politics Mix in New ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Lineup
text: The coming season of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” will feature another eclectic mix of competitors representing an expansive definition of the word star, including vintage sitcom actors, familiar faces from MTV reality shows and the oldest daughter of the 2008 Republican nominee for vice president, ABC said on Monday night.

headline: Derek Jeter Can’t Solve Slump, but Yankees Win
text: If the Yankees ever honor Derek Jeter with a statue, it may look like a play he made at shortstop Monday night during an 11-5 victory over the Oakland Athletics at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Wilpon Drops In on Mets but Doesn’t Say Why
text: ATLANTA  Jerry Manuel, the Mets’ manager, walked off the field after batting practice late Monday afternoon to find Jeff Wilpon, the team’s chief operating officer, standing on the top step of the dugout.

headline: Battling for Open Coverage (Again)
text: The Tennis Channel is televising its second United States Open. But once again, it is frustrated that it cannot reach more fans, especially in the New York market, during one of the sport’s Grand Slam tournaments.

headline: In Korea, a Model for Iraq
text: Washington

headline: Abandoned in Baghdad
text: New Haven

headline: We Owe the Troops an Exit
text: At least 14 American soldiers have been killed in Afghanistan over the past few days.

headline: Autodesk Will Reintroduce Its AutoCAD Design Software for Macs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When it comes to Apple products, the iPad and the iPhone get all the headlines.

headline: Dancing In the Streets (or Pennsylvania Avenue)
text: Broadway, jazz and country music have all been the focus of cultural events at the White House, and now dance will take center stage. The first lady, Michelle Obama, has announced that on Sept. 7 the White House will kick off its first dance series with a tribute to Judith Jamison, right, the veteran artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, who is retiring next year. She will be celebrated with performances by companies including the Ailey troupe, Paul Taylor Dance Company, the Washington Ballet, Super Cr3w and New York City Ballet, and by one of the Billys from “Billy Elliot the Musical. ”

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the Emmy Awards ceremony misidentified, in some editions, the executive producer and writer for “Modern Family” who said that the show, which was named outstanding comedy series, “is, and will always be, a love letter” to his wife. The tribute was by Steven Levitan, whose wife is Krista Levitan; it was not by Christopher Lloyd, also an executive producer and writer, who is married to Arleen Sorkin. (Mr. Levitan and Mr. Lloyd also won the Emmy for outstanding writing for a comedy series.)

headline: Nation Building Works
text: The U.S. venture into Iraq was a war, but it was also a nation-building exercise. America has spent $53 billion trying to reconstruct Iraq, the largest development effort since the Marshall Plan.

headline: Mexican Police Arrest Alleged Drug Kingpin
text: MEXICO CITY — An American-born man accused of being one of Mexico’s most ruthless drug lords was captured Monday, federal officials said, at a time when President Felipe Calderón has redoubled efforts to convince the public that the government is winning the drug war.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Federer and Venus Williams Leave Little Doubt in First-Round Romps
text: Most years, the opening matches for Venus Williams and Roger Federer would not cause much consternation. But both have been hobbled, and so their debuts at the United States Open on Monday were scrutinized for any wince, grimace or limp that might raise doubts about their prospects.

headline: New Chance for Peace
text: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, will open talks on a two-state solution on Thursday in Washington. These will be the first direct negotiations between the two sides in 20 months, and there will be an early test of the two leaders’ seriousness of purpose.

headline: A Million Women vs. Wal-Mart
text: For nine years, Wal-Mart has fought to stave off a class-action lawsuit alleging that the company has long discriminated against its female workers in pay and promotions. So far it has avoided a trial on the merits of the issue. The battleground instead is whether the million or so women who have worked for Wal-Mart since 2001 really constitute a class, which the company vigorously disputes. In 2004, a federal district court judge said they did, and in April the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals agreed, ruling the case could proceed.

headline: The Wrong Road
text: In late July, President Jakaya Kikwete of Tanzania announced that his government intended to go ahead in 2012 with plans to build a highway running from Arusha in north-central Tanzania to Musoma on Lake Victoria. No one disputes the economic value of developing highways and other public works in Tanzania. But this planned highway includes a potentially tragic pitfall: it cuts straight through the heart of the northern Serengeti, one of the greatest national parks on the planet.

headline: Who Else Will Speak Up?
text: The hate-filled signs carried recently by protesters trying to halt plans to build an Islamic center and mosque in Lower Manhattan were chilling. We were cheered to see people willing to challenge their taunts and champion tolerance and the First Amendment. But opportunistic politicians are continuing to foment this noxious anger. It is a dangerous pursuit.

headline: On Tapes, Terror Suspect Brags and Reveals His Hate
text: On hours of recordings, James Cromitie cursed loudly and made empty boasts, threatened violence, complained of discrimination and revealed his noxious hate. More than anything, though, he talked. And talked some more.

headline: Google Offers Respite From Inbox Overload
text: If you hate your inbox, if the very thought of it makes you fretful and nauseated, you’re not alone. Plenty of people who use e-mail on a daily basis feel the same.

headline: To Win Job, Met Has to Lose Beard
text: R. A. Dickey of the Mets still wants to be a ball man at the 2011 United States Open, but a fuzzy obstacle has been thrown in his way. It’s not that Dickey is a major league knuckleball pitcher and his tosses might create havoc on the court, and it’s not that he will be 36 next year.

headline: Bloggingheads: Faith and Immigration
text: The Rev. Chuck Currie, left, of the United Church of Christ and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative debate churches and immigration reform.

headline: Courtside: Opening Day
text: The Times's Lynn Zinser reports from the first day of action at the U.S. Open.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Aug. 30
text: The first day of the United States Open at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, including opening ceremonies and matches.

headline: Word of the Day | heckler
text: heckler •\ˈhe-kəlr\• noun

headline: South Korean Red Cross Offers Flood Aid to North
text: South Korea’s Red Cross offered the North an estimated $8.3 million in aid to help cope with flooding, the Yonhap news agency reported on Tuesday.

headline: News Quiz | August 31, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Sorkin: Why Wall St. Is Deserting Obama
text: Sept. 1, 2:55 p.m. | Updated A letter from a hedge fund manager to his investors about Washington’s policies is stirring up controversy on a sensitive topic among the moneyed elite, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: East Coast Is Told to Brace for Hurricane
text: ATLANTA  Federal weather officials urged residents along the Atlantic coast to take caution and prepare to possibly evacuate their homes this weekend as a powerful Category 4 hurricane was expected to brush the North Carolina and New England seaboards.

headline: China Asks C.E.O.’s to Work for State
text: The Chinese government ran an enormous help-wanted advertisement on Monday seeking professional managers for some of its biggest state-controlled companies, a novel but not unprecedented move that apparently reflected unhappiness with the companies’ current performance, Michael Wines reported in The New York Times.

headline: Lenders Back Off of Environmental Risks
text: Blasting off mountaintops to reach coal in Appalachia or churning out millions of tons of carbon dioxide to extract oil from sand in Alberta are among environmentalists’ biggest industrial irritants. But they are also legal and lucrative, Tom Zeller Jr. reports in The New York Times.

headline: Google Buys Mobile Networker SocialDeck
text: In its effort to challenge Facebook, Google has become a social butterfly. The latest proof of that is Google’s acquisition Monday of SocialDeck, a maker of games for mobile phones, VentureBeat reported.

headline: H.P. to Pay $55 Million to Settle Kickback Inquiry
text: Hewlett-Packard has agreed to pay $55 million to settle kickback allegations related to federal government contracts, the United States Justice Department said on Monday.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Clamjamphrie
text: Today’s word, in association with the stimulating Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Warren’s Fate Is Gauge of Wall St. Overhaul
text: Elizabeth Warren is folksy and plain-spoken and favors cardigans over Washington power suits. Many on Wall Street view her as their worst nightmare but she is a hero to liberal activists and consumer groups, Reuters reports.

headline: ‘Family’ Night at the Emmy Awards
text: WHO were some of the winners of this year’s Emmy Awards? WHO hosted the awards show?

headline: H.P. Expands Stock Buyback by $10 Billion
text: Hewlett-Packard said Monday that its board approved the buyback of an additional $10 billion of shares to boost investor confidence as it finds itself involved in a bidding war for high-end data storage company 3Par.

headline: Kohn to Become Brookings Academic After Fed
text: Donald Kohn, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, will take his central banking expertise to the Brookings Institution after he retires this week from four decades at the Fed, Brookings announced Monday.

headline: Attacks on U.S. Soldiers in Afghanistan Intensify
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Five American service members were killed in attacks in eastern and southern Afghanistan on Tuesday, according to the NATO-led international forces.

headline: BHP Says It Wouldn’t Divest Potash Assets
text: BHP Billiton denied speculation on Monday that it planned to sell any of Potash Corp.‘s assets if it succeeds with its $38.6 billion hostile bid for the world’s largest fertilizer producer, Reuters reported.

headline: HSBC Sells U.S. Auto Finance Units to Santander
text: British bank HSBC said Tuesday that it had sold its last United States auto finance businesses to Spain’s Santander for about $3.56 billion in cash, completing its exit from a market that cost it billions during the financial crisis, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Katrina Victims Revisited
text: Brenda Ann Kenneally doesn’t cover events. Instead, she burrows in and follows her subjects over the course of many years in projects such as “Upstate Girls” and “Money Power and Respect.”

headline: Major Hedge Funds Cut Back Equity Risk
text: Even some of the savviest hedge fund managers got burned in 2008 by sticking with their hot stocks for too long as the market tumbled, Reuters writes.

headline: Newcrest Opens Field for Gold M.&A.’s After Lihir
